column5: Š—“Janis: Little Girl BlueŠ— is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 43 minutes.

Once Joplin left Big Brother she found it difficult to lead her own band. But with the support of Paul Rothchild, who produced Š—“Pearl,Š— she grew as an artist. That album, which yielded her biggest hit, Š—“Me and Bobby McGee,Š— suggested her potential to become a rock equivalent of Billie Holiday.

In the movie, JoplinŠ—Ès letters to friends, lovers and her cautiously supportive but disapproving parents are plaintive and direct. Read aloud by the singer-songwriter Chan Marshall, a.k.a. Cat Power, in a gentler voice than JoplinŠ—Ès scratchy yowl, they reveal a forthright honesty, emotional openness and fierce intelligence. Her younger siblings, Laura and Michael, offer wistful, caring remembrances.
The end came just when she had begun to exert more self-control and her use of heroin had diminished. In a moment of weakness, those beady-eyed demons caught up with her.

Her stardom was no accident. She was ambitious. Her initial idol was Bob Dylan. But she absorbed the influences of Odetta, Bessie Smith, Otis Redding and Aretha Franklin. Her outspoken advocacy of black civil rights didnŠ—Èt sit well in Port Arthur, where virulent racism was rampant.

But Joplin, who died of a heroin overdose the previous year at 27, wasnŠ—Èt an infant. She had a womanŠ—Ès voice. More than any rock star of her generation she fearlessly vented the emotions of her needy inner girl-child. The film sustains a double vision of both the child and the hard-living folk-blues mama Joplin became.

Although Ms. BergŠ—Ès enthralling film tells a story somewhat similar to Š—“Amy,Š— Asif KapadiaŠ—Ès recent documentary portrait of Amy Winehouse (who also died at 27), the demons that devoured Winehouse came from outside as much from within. Not so with Joplin.

Her romantic relationships with both men and women didnŠ—Èt end well. Particularly hurtful was her abandonment by a San Francisco drug dealer after he had asked her fatherŠ—Ès permission to marry her.

San Francisco in its hippie heyday was her salvation and her destruction. She became the voice of the blues-rock band Big Brother and the Holding Company and a sensation at the 1967 Monterey Pop Festival, singing Š—“Ball and Chain.Š— The film includes the famous shot of Mama Cass in the audience marveling at JoplinŠ—Ès talent.

In Amy BergŠ—Ès documentary Š—“Janis: Little Girl Blue,Š— the sound that erupts from Janis Joplin singing the Š—È60s R&B classic Š—“Cry BabyŠ— comes as close as IŠ—Ève heard to a grown-up singer capturing a babyŠ—Ès primal squall. Heard today, this raw, insistent scream, from JoplinŠ—Ès posthumously released 1971 album, Š—“Pearl,Š— is as disturbing and powerful as ever.

Fame and celebrity in the 21st century are far more toxic than in the early 1970s. Some of the most memorable images in Š—“AmyŠ— show Winehouse cringing on the street as she is virtually eaten alive by flashbulbs, and at such moments, it feels like a true-life horror movie. The demons in Š—“Little Girl BlueŠ— come from inside. You canŠ—Èt lay the blame for JoplinŠ—Ès death on the paparazzi or hangers-on and enablers.

The emotional wounds Joplin sustained are the kind that never completely heal. The worst originated not from her family but from her high school classmates in Port Arthur, Tex. The antithesis of the all-American prom-queen ideal, Joplin suffered merciless verbal abuse and rejection and fought back by donning elaborate hippie regalia and parading as a raucous, bad-girl roustabout. At the University of Texas in Austin, a fraternity campaigned to elect her the Š—“ugliest man on campus.Š— She put on a brave face, but how does anyone really shake off something like that? Later, JoplinŠ—Ès most vulnerable moments followed adrenaline-charged concerts when her band members went home with girls, and she found herself revved-up but alone.

Ms. Vikander, in contrast, acts from the inside out, with an openness and spontaneity that is especially rare in movies like this one. Whether she is painting, smoking, embracing her husband or offering her hand to the woman who replaces him, Gerda is the one figure onscreen who seems to breathe the sharp air of reality. The others have been painted, with practiced skill and impeccable intentions, by numbers.

When Š—“The Danish GirlŠ— was shown at the Toronto International Film Festival this year, Kyle Buchanan, writing for Vulture, complained that it was part of a trend of Š—“queer and trans films that are actually about straight people.Š— Not that the emphasis on GerdaŠ—Ès experience is illegitimate. She is called upon to support the man she loves as he erases himself from her life, and Ms. Vikander registers the anguish and ambivalence, as well as the passionate loyalty, that Gerda feels as Einar gives way to Lili.

Mr. HooperŠ—Ès tasteful, earnest, didactic style Š—” magnified by Alexandre DesplatŠ—Ès decorously overwrought score Š—” does the film no favors. And the asymmetry between the central performances doesnŠ—Èt help, either. Mr. Redmayne is a master of technique, adept at significant gestures, freighted glances and the kind of showiness that masquerades as subtlety. As a result, the passage from Einar to Lili is almost entirely a matter of artifice and surface. EinarŠ—Ès fingers brush against the ballerinaŠ—Ès dresses hanging in UllaŠ—Ès studio. Mr. Redmayne alters the angle of his neck, the rhythm of his walk, the timbre of his voice and the set of his mouth. ItŠ—Ès all very impressive, as it was when he traced the progress of Stephen HawkingŠ—Ès neurological illness in Š—“The Theory of Everything.Š— But like that much-praised performance, this one does not take us where we need to go, which is inside the characterŠ—Ès mind and spirit.

Written for the screen by Lucinda Coxon and based on David EbershoffŠ—Ès novel of the same title, Š—“The Danish GirlŠ— is a fictionalized biography of Lili Elbe (as Einar Wegener came to be known), one of the first people to attempt sex reassignment surgery. LiliŠ—Ès encounters with prevailing medical wisdom, culminating in her meeting with a sympathetic doctor (Sebastian Koch), form a harrowing subplot. And her bravery makes this film a welcome tribute to a heroic forerunner of the current movement for transgender rights. ItŠ—Ès impossible not to be moved by LiliŠ—Ès self-recognition and by her demand to be recognized by those who care most about her.
Š—“The Danish GirlŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Sex, not to be confused with gender. Running time: 2 hours.

Š—“The Danish Girl,Š— Tom HooperŠ—Ès new film, is a story of individual struggle that is also a portrait of a marriage. In this respect and others it resembles Š—“The KingŠ—Ès Speech,Š— Mr. HooperŠ—Ès earlier historical drama, a multiple Oscar winner a few years ago. In that case, the union of George VI and Elizabeth, the Queen Mother, was the foundation on which the tale of GeorgeŠ—Ès elocutionary striving was built. Here, the marriage is bohemian rather than aristocratic, but the stakes, while personal, are every bit as profound and consequential as the matters of state that drove the monarch to the microphone.

But itŠ—Ès also hard not to wish that Š—“The Danish GirlŠ— were a better movie, a more daring and emotionally open exploration of LiliŠ—Ès emergence. As it is, the film, like its heroine for most of her life, is trapped by conventional expectations and ways of being. If, that is, Lili is really the heroine at all. The filmŠ—Ès title phrase is uttered on screen once, by EinarŠ—Ès childhood friend Hans (Matthias Schoenaerts), a Paris art dealer, in reference to Gerda. And it is GerdaŠ—Ès ordeal that provides the narrative with its emotional center of gravity.

But unlike Jill SolowayŠ—Ès Amazon series Š—“Transparent,Š— which embeds gender transition in a dense and detailed weave of family relations, Š—“The Danish GirlŠ— takes place in the airless, elegant atmosphere of quality filmmaking. Every scene is wrapped around a neat nub of feeling. The dialogue is carefully balanced between modern sensibilities and the imaginary language of Fancy Old Europe, which is really just English spoken in a variety of lovely and heterogeneous accents.

When we first encounter Gerda and Einar Wegener, played by Alicia Vikander and Eddie Redmayne, they seem perfectly matched. Both are painters, living amid the soft colors and sea air of Copenhagen in 1926. Gerda is a portraitist, while EinarŠ—Ès landscapes Š—” drawn from his childhood memories of the fjords and marshlands of Vejle, a town on the Jutland peninsula Š—” have brought him a measure of fame. Like many couples who share a profession, they provide each other with support as well as a bit of competition. Their best friend, Ulla (Amber Heard), a dancer, marvels at their mutual devotion, which combines the easy, egalitarian warmth of friendship with the heat of sexual attraction.

But their relationship turns out to rest on a false premise. Through a process that is by turns wrenching and exciting, Einar discovers that the man the world has always taken him to be is not the person he truly is. What begins as an experiment and a bit of a game Š—” dressing as a woman for the Copenhagen artistŠ—Ès ball, wearing one of GerdaŠ—Ès camisoles under his clothes Š—” becomes an existential transformation. For a while, Einar and Gerda pretend that Lili, his female persona, is EinarŠ—Ès cousin, visiting Copenhagen from the countryside. Henrik (Ben Whishaw), a self-described Š—“romantic,Š— falls in love with her. But Lili is not Einar in disguise: The truth is exactly the reverse.

What they donŠ—Èt do is show how their own movies might have been influenced by HitchcockŠ—Ès technique, which Mr. Jones lovingly illustrates in dissections of a few of the masterŠ—Ès most memorable scenes. Though merely a tasting menu, these moments add jolts of pulpy fun and allow their creator to speak for himself. The man who embraced many of the characteristics that movie snobs love to denigrate Š—” his genre; his prolific output (at the time of the interview, he was just completing his 48th film); the constraints of the studio system Š—” is finally his own best argument for the happy coexistence of art and entertainment.

Curating a selection of the original interview recordings (whose sound quality is damn near pristine), Mr. Jones fashions an unfaltering encomium thatŠ—Ès entirely free of the highfalutin monologues that might deter noncinephiles. Bob BalabanŠ—Ès intermittent narration is soft and unintrusive, and a chorus of lauded directors, mostly American and all male (I canŠ—Èt help thinking that a woman might have dug deeper into the significant contributions of HitchcockŠ—Ès wife and collaborator, Alma Reville), chime in with acuity and ardor.

Just as a snooty reader might be enticed to the novels of Stephen King by a thumbs-up from The New York Review of Books, movie buffs were likely to view TruffautŠ—Ès enthusiasm for Hitchcock as a sufficient entree to their discerning fold. But the book, an engrossing record of TruffautŠ—Ès dayslong interview with his idol in 1962, did more than just reposition its subjectŠ—Ès reputation. It also provided riveting insight into the art and craft of moviemaking, revealing HitchcockŠ—Ès mastery of time and space and his unwavering preference, honed by his period of making silent movies, for image over dialogue.

Š—“PsychoŠ— (1960) was the first film I saw in a movie theater, an experience that my 7-year-old self was ill-equipped to parse. Surrounded by jittery adults, I puzzled over everything, and not just the frantic screaming that mimicked Bernard HerrmannŠ—Ès devilishly clever musical cues. Why, I wondered, was Janet Leigh wandering around in her bra in the middle of the afternoon?
Š—“Hitchcock/TruffautŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Have you seen Š—…PsychoŠ—È? Running time: 1 hour 20 minutes.

That juxtaposing of sex and terror was as essential to Alfred HitchcockŠ—Ès cinematic style as his meticulous deployment of icy blond actresses. Disappointingly, Kent JonesŠ—Ès documentary Š—“Hitchcock/TruffautŠ— Š—” though not nearly as dry as its title Š—” barely tickles HitchcockŠ—Ès fascinating fetishes. Despite a promising nod to the brilliant perversions of Š—“MarnieŠ— and Š—“VertigoŠ— (which few can deny is one terrifically sick movie), Mr. Jones remains rigidly focused on hammering home the director Fran’_ois TruffautŠ—Ès motivation for writing the 1966 book on which this film is based: To lead Hitchcock, then widely considered a mere commercial entertainer, out of the shoals of populism and into the cineaste spotlight. Truffaut knew that hindsight was better than no sight at all.

In the 1950s, some jazz musicians believed they couldnŠ—Èt get that Charlie Parker Š—“happy-sad feeling without using drugs.Š— So says a friend of the saxophonist Frank Morgan in Š—“Sound of Redemption,Š— a documentary that revels in the happy despite some seriously sad events.

The film, directed by N.C. Heikin, traces Mr. MorganŠ—Ès career with beautiful black-and-white photographs and newsreels. Those scenes are intertwined with segments from a 2012 tribute concert at San Quentin prison in California, five years after his death.

His renown grew, as did an addiction to heroin. His drug habit was soon financed by crime, and for some 30 years he was in and out of prison. After his last stint, he was released and went on to record some of his finest work.

Š—“Sound of Redemption,Š— subtitled Š—“The Frank Morgan Story,Š— isnŠ—Èt a hard-hitting exploration. Though Mr. MorganŠ—Ès grittier side is outlined, itŠ—Ès not deeply investigated. (When a former wife says that the only way to love Frank Morgan was to Š—“live in a state of exasperation,Š— you long to hear more about their marriage, and his demons.) Instead, itŠ—Ès a fond and forgiving tribute to the man, filled with music that moves beyond happy and sad, and toward something like brilliance.
Š—“Sound of Redemption: The Frank Morgan StoryŠ— is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 24 minutes.

Mr. Morgan was born into music. His father was a professional musician who used to play his guitar while pressing it against the belly of his pregnant wife, and later played by his sonŠ—Ès crib. Mr. Morgan was an accomplished saxophonist by the time he was a teenager; itŠ—Ès said that when he performed with Billie Holiday, his music made her cry.

Noel (Kentucker Audley), the appropriately named protagonist of Š—“Christmas, Again,Š— approaches the holiday season more as he would a duty than an occasion for good cheer. For a brief period each year, he ventures from upstate New York to Greenpoint, Brooklyn, to sell Christmas trees. He stands stoically while customers snap pictures of the firs on their cellphones or pepper him with questions about different evergreens.

But this is a film of process, mood, tempo and even suspense. (Noel will have to pay for any unsold trees.) The writer and director, Charles Poekel, a cinematographer making his feature directorial debut, opened a stand of his own partly for research.
Š—“Christmas, AgainŠ— is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 20 minutes.

Noel, who lives in a trailer, one night takes in a young woman, Lydia (Hannah Gross), who has passed out on a bench. Whether these two might provide some comfort for each other is the closest that Š—“Christmas, AgainŠ— comes to having a plot.

As the title suggests, Š—“Christmas, AgainŠ— is concerned with how the holidays are, for some, a time of lonely resignation. (Sporting a green winter jacket, Noel sometimes looks ready to camouflage himself in his merchandise.) The cinematographer, Sean Price Williams, shoots on 16-millimeter film, suffusing the film with wintry colors and, at times, visible grain. This is a Christmas movie in which magic exists largely on the periphery, and that is just the right mix of chilly and sweet.
A customer mentions the nice girl who worked at the stand last year, clearly NoelŠ—Ès ex. Whether heartbroken or simply laconic, Noel seems reluctant to make conversation unless directly addressed.
This movie knows exactly what it is: shameless royalist fluff.
Š—“A Royal Night OutŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for some sexual content and a brief drug element. Running time: 1 hour 37 minutes.

The aggressively charming Š—“A Royal Night Out,Š— is a grown-up fairy tale for audiences whose hearts go pitter-pat at the mere mention of anything to do with the British royal family. Sorry to be a spoilsport, reader, but my heart sinks at the sight of people bowing and scraping before aristocrats with titles they havenŠ—Èt earned. It all seems so silly.
This raucous descendant of Š—“Roman HolidayŠ— supports the popular perception of Elizabeth as poised and responsible and Margaret as a mischievous, risk-taking flibbertigibbet.

The movie has a gutsy undertow. The citywide celebration is just one step away from becoming a drunken melee. Everywhere, strangers are deliriously kissing. The pubs teem with people singing Š—“Roll Out the Barrel,Š— and the swing music on the soundtrack swamps the film in Š—È40s nostalgia.

The sisters interact with criminal lowlifes, and Margaret unknowingly visits a brothel, befriends a gangster and passes out after a spiked drink. But thereŠ—Ès no real danger to either princess on an evening when euphoria reigns.

What makes Š—“A Royal Night OutŠ— palatable are the lead performances. Ms. GadonŠ—Ès coolly radiant Elizabeth looks a lot like her namesake as seen in vintage photographs. Ms. Powley (Š—“The Diary of a Teenage GirlŠ—) plays Margaret as a headstrong, fun-loving kook who ends up unconscious in a wheelbarrow. But never fear.

Š—“A Royal Night Out,Š— directed by Julian Jarrold from a screenplay by Trevor De Silva and Kevin Hood, evokes a time before paparazzi and cellphones when it was possible for royal figures to venture out incognito. No one identifies the princesses until they give themselves away, at which point those around them melt in worship.

Swept up in the excitement, Margaret gets separated from Elizabeth, who spends much of the rest of the movie frantically looking for her with the assistance of Jack (Jack Reynor), a bitter cockney airman gone AWOL who becomes her reluctant guide. There is just the teeniest hint of a romantic attraction that may or may not culminate in a chaste little kiss that the camera coyly avoids showing.

This what-if fantasy, set on V.E. Day, May 8, 1945, follows the princesses Elizabeth and Margaret, then 19 and 14, through an imaginary night of adventure when they are allowed out of Buckingham Palace to celebrate the official end of the war in Europe. Elizabeth (Sarah Gadon) and Margaret (Bel Powley) have been cooped up for six years. They convince their sourpuss parents, King George VI (a dour, gray-faced Rupert Everett) and the equally sour Queen Mother-to-be (Emily Watson), that they deserve to mingle with the commoners just this once.

Mom and Dad agree that Lilibet and P2, as they are nicknamed, may leave the palace but must be back by 1 a.m. The king is eager for news of the peopleŠ—Ès reaction to a radio address heŠ—Ès about to give. ItŠ—Ès different from the one given by Colin Firth in Š—“The KingŠ—Ès Speech.Š—
Two officers, farcical buffoons both (Jack Laskey and Jack Gordon), are assigned as chaperons and instructed to keep close tabs on the princesses.
As drifting and dreamy as its searching heroine, Š—“My Friend VictoriaŠ— takes a graceful but unsatisfying stroll through the life and longings of a young black woman in contemporary Paris.

As Victoria (Guslagie Malanda), passive and seemingly without ambition, slides from one low-level job to another, her thoughts return repeatedly to the bourgeois white family that sheltered her for one night when she was a child. Infatuated by its membersŠ—È affluent lifestyle and liberal beliefs, she casually stalks them for years, until a summer fling with the younger son (Pierre Andrau) produces a daughter, Marie. It will be seven years before MarieŠ—Ès father learns of her existence, but thatŠ—Ès only one of the many unexplained decisions with which Victoria, whose default position is inaction, will shape her life.

Relying on the beguiling charm conjured by David ChambilleŠ—Ès intimate cinematography and Ms. MalandaŠ—Ès pensive performance, Mr. Civeyrac dabbles in detachment and alienation without digging in. Poking the bear, then jumping back, he presents random jabs of racial conflict that appear jarringly out of nowhere. Isolated comments from MarieŠ—Ès grandparents (Š—“IŠ—Ève always wanted a black grandchild!Š—) suggest a na’Àvet’© and superficiality that beg for thematic excavation. And when Victoria increasingly releases her daughter to their doting care, you begin to wonder if itŠ—Ès an act of defeat or calculation.

Adapting a short story from a 2004 collection by Doris Lessing (itŠ—Ès originally set in London), the French director Jean Paul Civeyrac circles race and class with genteel restraint, choosing tepid over hot and description over exploration. Doing most of the describing is Fanny (Nadia Moussa), whose mother raised Victoria alongside her own children and whose near-constant voice-over muses on every twist and turn of VictoriaŠ—Ès life. That voice, however, is extremely unreliable, commenting on events that Fanny is clearly not around to witness.

ItŠ—Ès often said that Mr. Gomes blurs the boundary between fiction and documentary. What Š—“Arabian NightsŠ— tries to do is something even more radical, which is the erasure of the distinction between the literal and the metaphorical. Symbols in this film have a way of crashing to earth, and mundane facts take on mysterious meanings. Mr. Gomes has a tendency to revel in his own cleverness and to indulge in self-conscious cinematic jokes. He also has a penchant for obscurantism, a habit of confusing ambiguity with depth.

Š—“Arabian Nights: Volume 1 Š—” The Restless OneŠ— runs 2 hours 6 minutes. Š—“Volume 2 Š—” The Desolate OneŠ— runs 2 hours 11 minutes and opens next Friday. Š—“Volume 3 Š—” The Enchanted OneŠ— runs 2 hours 5 minutes and opens on Dec. 18. These films are not rated and are in Portuguese, with English subtitles.

The answer that emerges, a little over six hours later, is: yes and no. Art often emerges out of a struggle with the conflicting imperatives of personal expression, social engagement and formal experimentation. Artists in the past Š—” some mid-19th-century European novelists, many mid-20th-century European filmmakers Š—” have attempted heroic acts of synthesis. What marks Mr. Gomes as a representative artist of his time is his preference for fragmentation, and for an anti-heroic, ironic conception of his own artistic identity. Š—“Arabian NightsŠ— predicts its own failure. It cannot be the great film about post-2008 Europe, because it demonstrates the impossibility of any such thing. ItŠ—Ès an anti-masterpiece.

The first chunk of Š—“Arabian Nights,Š— called Š—“The Restless One,Š— begins with the filmmakerŠ—Ès self-mocking confession of impotence and bafflement. We see him fleeing the set, his panicked crew chasing after him. (Later, as punishment, his colleagues will bury Mr. Gomes up to his neck in sand, as if preparing to stone him to death.) In a voice-over, he lays out his creative predicament. He finds himself both Š—“in the eye of the stormŠ— and Š—“at a dead end,Š— pulled between two contradictory desires. He wants to indulge his taste for beauty and fantasy, but he also wants to tell the truth about the world, and in particular about Portugal at a time of economic and political crisis. Is it possible to satisfy both desires?

The stories that make up Š—“Arabian Nights,Š— the anxious, ambitious new film by the Portuguese director Miguel Gomes, are nestled inside two distinct frames. One is what the title would lead you to expect: Scheherazade, daughter of the grand vizier of Baghdad, invents tales to prevent her fearsome new husband, the sultan, from taking her life. Each vignette in this three-part movie belongs to one of ScheherazadeŠ—Ès 1,001 nights.

On its own, this section would be a small, troubling, strangely lyrical film. In the context of the larger project, though, it loses some of its impact. There is a fine line between delving into the mysteries of life and engaging in mystification, and Mr. Gomes lands on the wrong side of it. There is something disingenuous in the way this movie disowns its own ambitions and scorns the possibility of clarity or coherence. Maybe its opacity is a matter of principle. Or maybe itŠ—Ès just an excuse.

ThatŠ—Ès the theory anyway. In practice, Š—“Arabian NightsŠ— is less elegant and less coy than Mr. GomesŠ—Ès Š—“Tabu,Š— and not as haunting as his Š—“Our Beloved Month of August.Š— Its three parts are being shown in American theaters separately over the next few weeks, but while there is little narrative overlap, they hardly stand alone. Nor do they really add up. Part 2, Š—“The Desolate One,Š— is where you will find the heaviest concentration of fabulism and soft-core nudity Š—” Mr. Gomes is a proud member of the fraternity of directors who persuade women to disrobe in the name of art Š—” while Part 3, Š—“The Enchanted One,Š— represents the most extended engagement with contemporary reality. Part 1 has some of each.

Since the European crisis is far from over, it may be foolish to expect much of a payoff from this film, which makes a virtue of irresolution and indecision. Still, it is worth sticking with it until the end, since the third part is the most powerful. It consists almost entirely of an exploration of the tradition of trapping and training songbirds, which has flourished in some parts of Portugal since the early 20th century. In the middle, we hear of a sad love affair between a Portuguese man and a Chinese student, narrated in Chinese over images of labor unrest.

ItŠ—Ès not that simple, of course. A note at the beginning of each installment explains that these stories are fictionalized versions of events that occurred in Portugal in 2013 and 2014, as the government adopted austerity measures that squeezed an already demoralized population. Some of the anecdotes have the feel of urban legends arising from a climate of malaise and mistrust. Did you hear the one about the lost dog in the housing project? The outlaw who evaded capture in the mountains? At other times, the dislocation of workers and the erosion of middle-class living standards are confronted directly, as we hear men and women who are not professional actors testify to their hardships. Occasionally, the film will take an allegorical, satirical turn, notably in a tale about a group of bankers and government ministers who encounter a wizard peddling a magical cure for impotence.

But Mr. Gomes isnŠ—Èt adapting a famous work of literature. HeŠ—Ès using it as a conceit, a plaything and a structural principle. A lavishly costumed anthology of exotic fables may be the movie he dreams of making, but reality keeps distracting him. Or maybe itŠ—Ès the other way around: His ambition to make a rigorous documentary about the state of the Portuguese working class is continually interrupted by dreams of far-off lands and naked women.

Dan Koeppel, a writer and father, speaks wistfully of the California Cycleway, an elevated wooden bike tollway between Pasadena and Los Angeles that opened in 1900 but was dismantled soon afterward. Aline Cavalcante is a S’£o Paulo blogger-activist with deep convictions and charisma; she is determined to make the cityŠ—Ès perilous streets safer for bike riders. Joel Ewanick, a former auto marketer in Los Angeles, says he is environmentally minded but insists that gasoline is here to stay.

New York CityŠ—Ès fitful, sometimes thwarted efforts at tempering traffic Š—” congestion pricing, Citi Bikes Š—” are not addressed. But after seeing Š—“Bikes vs Cars,Š— Manhattan motorists might think twice about cursing the bicyclist who just cut them off. And Angelenos might ponder this film during their next rush-hour slog on the 405.

Ivan Naurholm, a cabdriver in Copenhagen, grumbles about his cityŠ—Ès ubiquitous cyclists. TorontoŠ—Ès toxic former mayor Rob Ford (not interviewed, but seen in clips) is so pro-automobile that he had many bike lanes painted over; from Nicolas Habib, a Brazilian manager for the Chinese automaker JAC, we learn about ChinaŠ—Ès growing share of the global auto market and, by example, its devotion to fossil fuels.

Breezy, intelligent, diffuse but uncluttered, Fredrik GerttenŠ—Ès documentary Š—“Bikes vs CarsŠ— could be called a tale of congestion-plagued cities. The film, which examines the high cost that urban centers, especially Los Angeles and S’£o Paulo, Brazil, pay for accommodating automobiles, benefits greatly from a range of viewpoints. Though its most persuasive speakers are politically involved bicyclists, car enthusiasts receive screen time as well.

Narrated by Mr. Rybicky and its subject, an outsider artist named Peter Anton, Š—“Almost ThereŠ— opens with the filmmakers discovering Mr. Anton at a pierogi festival theyŠ—Ère shooting in Whiting, Ind., in 2005. Here, Mr. Anton is seen drawing rudimentary but sincere portraits of town folk. (The movie takes the value of outsider art as a given, which might be a stumbling block for viewers who donŠ—Èt.) Mr. Rybicky and Mr. Wickenden find out this artist has a huge stash of wide-ranging material in a crumbling, hazardous house in East Chicago, Ind. For a while, the movie feels like an episode of Š—“HoardersŠ— inflected with a hipster aesthetic.

The filmmakers arrange for Mr. Anton to exhibit his art at a well-respected Chicago gallery. Mr. Rybicky reveals parts of his own family history that shed light on his affinity for Mr. Anton. Then an episode from Mr. AntonŠ—Ès past threatens to derail the whole project.

At a certain point, Mr. Anton rails at the filmmakers for referring to him as just that Š—” a project. Late in the film, Mr. Anton, whose ingenuousness is at least partly a product of mental illness, digs in his heels about his domestic arrangement. Mr. Rybicky, responding, says in voice-over: Š—“If Peter was going to choose to stay in that house, we couldnŠ—Èt be responsible for him anymore. So we stepped back to film what would happen and hoped for the best.Š— That pronouncement somehow sums up whatŠ—Ès both arresting and queasy-making about this well-put-together movie.

Š—“I think as a journalist Š—” I donŠ—Èt think as a filmmaker,Š— one interviewee says, almost off-handedly, late into Š—“Almost There.Š— This first feature from Dan Rybicky and Aaron Wickenden demonstrates that these documentary filmmakers might do well to think more like journalists sometimes.

A family prepares to gather for festive meals and the exchange of gifts. They are not necessarily bad people, but they behave horribly. He soon discovers that the fancy house that was their trysting place isnŠ—Èt MadelineŠ—Ès. It belongs to her married ex-boyfriend, Will (Peter Krause), a revered college football coach who is KevinŠ—Ès boss and idol. Kevin is mortified.

Š—“River of FundamentŠ— is not rated. Running time: 5 hours 30 minutes.

Mr. Mailer and Egypt donŠ—Èt remove Mr. Barney from his usual preoccupations so much as they complement them; the movieŠ—Ès title speaks directly to the workŠ—Ès practically overwhelming concern. A second thread concerns a skinny, bullied high school nerd (Hiroya Shimizu), who makes the mistake of falling for Kanako. His own search for her eventually becomes a grisly rite of passage into bloodthirsty manhood. A sharp tool, a cheek and an ear lobe are involved.

This exercise in lurid excess follows the quest of Akikazu Fujishima (Koji Yakusho), a sweaty, dissipated middle-aged former detective, to find his daughter, Kanako (Nana Komatsu), who has fallen down a rabbit hole of underworld depravity. Š—“MacbethŠ— is rated R (Under 17 not admitted without accompanying parent or adult guardian). Ye olde hurly-burly. Running time: 1 hour 52 minutes.

The results are visually striking, even if beautifying carnage in this manner is distracting and complicated, both for what it means for the drama unfolding on screen and for the audience. The slow-motion scenes suggest that thereŠ—Ès a timeless aspect to this slaughter and, perhaps by extension, an inevitability to such violence. And if war is inevitable and eternal, what does this say about Macbeth? Then again, the carefully choreographed and filmed violence, with its flowing sword-clanging and blood-spurting, is kind of cool. You canŠ—Èt look away, even when one warrior draws a blade across anotherŠ—Ès throat Š—” which may be another reason (or the main one) for this deceleration.

Kenneth Tynan once wrote that Š—“nobody has ever succeeded as MacbethŠ— because the character shrinks from a complex figure into a cowering thug. The exception, Tynan continued, immediately contradicting his claim, was Laurence Olivier, who in a 1955 production Š—“shook hands with greatness.Š— With his Macbeth, Mr. Fassbender, who routinely shakes hands with greatness in films that donŠ—Èt remotely do the same, produces a man whose anguish eventually becomes a powerful counterpoint to his deeds, partly because heŠ—Ès already dead by the time he utters his first word. ThereŠ—Ès no doubled trouble in the slickly handsome new version of Š—“MacbethŠ— with Michael Fassbender. Quietly, insistently, he pulls you to him in scene after scene, largely with a restrained intensity that, in its near-husbandly closeness, creates an intimacy between you and the character, effectively turning you into another Lady Macbeth.

Mr. Ellis longed for stardom, but he was either the wrong man in the wrong place at the wrong time, or the opposite of that. Shelby Singleton, the president of Sun Records, had him perform in a mask, billed as Orion and sounding like Presley, and he developed a passionate following. The story of Jimmy Ellis, a singer blessed and cursed with a voice that sounded too much like Elvis PresleyŠ—Ès, is strange and tragic, a piece of musical history that says worlds about the fickleness of fame and ends with a jolt that makes it even sadder. The setting of Š—“Youth,Š— Paolo SorrentinoŠ—Ès new film, is an Alpine resort Š—” a picturesque place rich with cultural associations and full of rich, cultured guests. Good as it looks, the film starts to feel like an airline magazine collaboratively produced by the editorial staffs of Playboy and Modern Maturity. This notion has always been sexist, but it hasnŠ—Èt always been boring. Can we please move on to the after-party?

Mr. SorrentinoŠ—Ès concentration on the pathos of male senescence is an aspect of the filmŠ—Ès nostalgia. His main characters are two aging artists, friends since way back and easygoing twilight companions. Fred Ballinger (Michael Caine) is a prominent composer in semi-retirement, his longed-for serenity disrupted by the marital crisis of his daughter, Lena (Rachel Weisz), and by the attentions of an emissary from the British royal family, who wants Fred to conduct a command performance of one of his best-loved works. The problem with Š—“YouthŠ— is not that itŠ—Ès empty Š—” the accusation Kael and others lodged against Mr. SorrentinoŠ—Ès precursors Š—” but that itŠ—Ès small. Its imagination feels shrunken and secondhand, in spite of the gorgeous vistas and beautiful naked women. Or actually, because of them.

Mr. Keitel and Mr. Caine are pleasant company, even if it too often sounds as if they were speaking lines translated into English. Mr. SorrentinoŠ—Ès pictorial sense remains exquisite, as it was in Š—“The Great BeautyŠ— and, before that, in Š—“This Must Be the PlaceŠ— and Š—“The Consequences of Love.Š— As befits a movie about a composer, the music (by David Lang) makes its presence felt in more than a merely decorative manner. It carries the intimation of something deeper and grander into this minor fable of waning potency.

She didnŠ—Èt think they were all that much fun. IŠ—Ève always loved them Š—” especially the ones hosted by Fellini and Antonioni, to which I was too young to be invited Š—” and Mr. Sorrentino concocted a pretty good one a couple of years ago, a meditation on stasis and hedonism aptly called Š—“The Great Beauty.Š— That film, an Oscar winner set amid a drifting Roman literary and social elite, pulled off the nifty trick of combining spiritual emptiness with aesthetic repletion, so that you could walk away feeling both starved and satisfied, exhilarated and inexpressibly triste. The notable absence of any whisper of ItalyŠ—Ès social, economic and political crises was not necessarily a sign of disengagement, since the obliviousness of the Italian elite was one of that filmŠ—Ès main themes.

In Š—“Youth,Š— the melancholy is more explicit, and appears, at least on the surface, to be individual rather than systemic. And universal, rather than tied to any particular facts of geography and history. ItŠ—Ès a movie about getting old, which happens to everyone. In the movieŠ—Ès view of life, this happens with special poignancy to men.

Mick and Fred may belong to a fading world of high culture and jet set glamour, but they share their rarefied aerie with a movie star (Paul Dano) and a recent Miss Universe (Madalina Ghenea). Lena pursues a romance with a rock climber, and other guests involve themselves in sexual and metaphysical shenanigans. The two old pals reminisce about lost loves, one of whom shows up, briefly and memorably, in the person of Jane Fonda.

ItŠ—Ès all the same. Not really, of course. These are highly specific mountains and trees, and the people gamboling and gambling in their shadows are exquisite in their individuality. But still. Mr. SorrentinoŠ—Ès camera glides across a landscape pocked with signifiers of European Decadence, one of the continentŠ—Ès most durable and distinguished exports.

We are here to contemplate a civilization that has been declining, with sighs and kisses and world-weary lyricism, for a very long time. So long that decline has become its own kind of vigor. On the eve of World War I, and in its aftermath, aristocrats and artists walked these grounds in tuxedos and evening gowns. The malaise hovered in the air, like the Black Death in BoccaccioŠ—Ès Š—“The Decameron.Š—
Š—“YouthŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Hubba hubba. Running time:  2 hours 4 minutes.

ThereŠ—Ès no such character in Š—“Lysistrata,Š— but DolmedesŠ—Ès name and sartorial flamboyance evoke Dolemite, the titular pimp played by the comic Rudy Ray Moore in the 1975 blaxploitation flick. Among the routines that Mr. Moore (1927-2008) was known for is the Signifying Monkey toast, a boasting, humorously raw recitation and linguistic practice (like the Dozens), involving a sly, agitating monkey that provokes a fight between a lion and an elephant. To an extent, Dolmedes registers as a trickster, a wily figure who always shows up at the right time to deliver exposition with a wink and some showy wordsmithing. At the same time, Lysistrata Š—” a magnificent Teyonah Parris Š—” is stirring up trouble, angling to dethrone kings like her guy, a gang leader, Chi-Raq (Nick Cannon).

The war in Š—“Chi-RaqŠ— is strictly a domestic affair, waged by black male citizens on other black citizens. The main combatants are rival gangs, the Spartans and the Trojans, who have helped turn Chicago into a war zone Š—” hence the tragic, bleak portmanteau title. The gangs seem to take some of their cues from the real Crips and Bloods, whose blue versus red color coding has been translated into Spartan purple and Trojan orange. Flying their respective colors, the Chi-Raq gangs violently run their hoods, or at least think that they rule. Š—“Chi-RaqŠ— can be read as an illustration of signifyin(g), to borrow the spelling of Henry Louis Gates Jr., in how it rewrites Š—“the received textual tradition,Š— as he puts it in his book Š—“The Signifying Monkey.Š— There are limits to every rewriting, of course, to how far a revision riffs on the idioms, ideas and forms of its influences. Mr. LeeŠ—Ès most radical move in Š—“Chi-Raq,Š— which he wrote with Kevin Willmott, is to transport a classical Greek play to a Chicago that is highly fictional and painfully real, geographically specific and unmistakably metaphoric. That this is a movie about the United States is as obvious as the Stars and Stripes that late in the movie looms (as in Š—“PattonŠ—) behind Dolmedes, even as it is also a showbiz showcase for the likes of Dave Chappelle and Wesley Snipes.

Mr. Lee then raises the stakes with a series of chilling statistics that juxtapose American deaths in the Iraq war from 2003 to 2011 (the movie puts the number at 4,424) with homicides in Chicago from 2001 to 2015 (a staggering 7,356, according to the movie).

That he pulls off Š—“Chi-RaqŠ— is a testament to his cinematic imagination, which he cuts loose with split screens, direct address, surreal fillips and outsize performances. With the composer Terence Blanchard, who wrote the wall-to-wall score, and the cinematographer Matthew Libatique, Mr. Lee creates a Š—“LysistrataŠ— that entertains, engages and, at times, enrages as it takes on violence, ogles lady parts and expounds on greed and democracy. He stumbles plenty, including in an awkward, didactic scene in which John Cusack, as a priest, delivers a sermon for a dead child. (Jennifer Hudson plays the mother.) Yet while you can argue with Mr. LeeŠ—Ès ideas, cinematic and political, few directors shake you up this hard, creating laughter that is as bitter as tears.

The movie opens with a series of shocks, including a red, white and blue graphic of the United States made entirely of guns. This illustration, which creates a visual bookend with DolmedesŠ—Ès flag, forms part of the overture, which features a succession of blood-red lyrics blown up on the screen (from the song Š—“Pray 4 My CityŠ—), each word reverberating like a shout:

Mr. Lee doesnŠ—Èt go that far, alas, but he does go cinematically all out with exuberant set pieces, musical numbers, bursts of phantasmagoric color, oceans of tears and blunt-force rhetoric. Written in verse, sometimes rhymed and sometimes not, Š—“Chi-RaqŠ— is at once old and new, from its polymorphous narrative strategies to its musical forms (hip-hop, jazz, gospel, R&B), and by turns fiercely funny and deadly sincere. It rolls along smoothly and fitfully, carried by the boldness of Mr. LeeŠ—Ès conceit, his love of the form and the largely excellent company of artists heŠ—Ès gathered, including Samuel L. Jackson as Dolmedes, a loquacious Greek chorus of one who pops in and out with a cane and in a series of lusciously colored suits.
Š—“Chi-RaqŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Gun violence and expletives. Running time: 1 hour 58 minutes.

These numbers are followed by the voice of the Rev. Michael Pfleger, a real Roman Catholic priest who preaches and agitates in Chicago and is an outspoken critic of gun culture and the National Rifle Association. Father Pfleger, after saying that itŠ—Ès young black men killing young black men, closes the overture with a prayer: Š—“Heaven help us all.Š— The flag, the statistics, the guns make for a powerful, unsettling opener, perhaps especially because the movie opens in a week of high-profile mass shootings Š—” and not in Chicago. By virtue of the heaviness of their documentary truth, though, which grows weightier with each number and word, these elements almost torpedo the movie before it begins. Like many filmmakers who draw on the historical record to shore up their fictions, Mr. Lee has to work hard to rise to the challenge of the real world.

Subtlety isnŠ—Èt in Mr. LeeŠ—Ès dictionary, which makes him a fine fit for a bawdy comedy that tosses out an orgiastic aside in its first sentence. Gleefully blunt, Š—“LysistrataŠ— is thought to have been first performed in Athens at a festival of Dionysus, the god of wine. It opens with its title character fretting that the women sheŠ—Ès asked to meet havenŠ—Èt materialized. LysistrataŠ—Ès brilliant, daft idea is that together they can end the bloodshed with a full-body shutdown, which, after much scheming and whining, they do, leaving the men incredulous, desperate and tumescent. Some of the men end up delivering their lines erect, which the ancient Athenian players expressed by wearing artificial phalluses. (Somehow I donŠ—Èt remember that detail from school.)

The laughs in Spike LeeŠ—Ès corrosive Š—“Chi-RaqŠ— burn like acid. Urgent, surreal, furious, funny and wildly messy, the movie sounds like an invitation to defeat, but itŠ—Ès an improbable triumph that finds Mr. Lee doing his best work in years. Set in contemporary Chicago, where sidewalks are washed with blood, and human hearts beat to the rhythm of gunfire, it takes as its inspiration AristophanesŠ—È Š—“Lysistrata,Š— the fifth-century B.C. comedy in which women organize a sex strike to stop men from making war or, as Mr. Lee puts it with a vulgar flourish, Š—“No peace, no [expletive]!Š—

Set mostly during the late 1940s and early Š—È50s, the film, written and directed by William Riead, follows this nun on a straightforward path as she decides to leave her teaching order to work with the impoverished in Kolkata.

Š—“The LettersŠ— doesnŠ—Èt preach to the converted, or to anyone else, for that matter. Instead, this fairly standard biopic about Mother Teresa tells its tale with a minimum of flourish, resisting most opportunities to grandstand. ThatŠ—Ès not high praise, but itŠ—Ès also not an insult.

Š—“The LettersŠ— sidesteps any hint of the controversy that sometimes dogged its subject, and avoids delving too deeply into what were surely horrid conditions. (No one here seems to sweat in the heat of India; the poor and the dying look as if they are merely down on their luck.) At times itŠ—Ès even a handsome film, with pretty scenes to watch. For a story set in slums, that too is not high praise.
Š—“The LettersŠ— is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for threats of violence and scenes of poverty.

She encounters some resistance from the church and from suspicious Hindus, and readily overcomes such trials. She does the same with the occasional crisis of faith, which is spoken about rather than shown. Struggles arenŠ—Èt ignored here; theyŠ—Ère just surmounted with patience and devotion. That may be a good strategy in life, but it can be static to watch on screen.

Juliet StevensonŠ—Ès Mother Teresa is tireless and solemn, aside from a rare smile and a friendly touch. Though speechifying and mawkishness are thankfully scarce, the bland script gives her few chances to go beyond the expected formula. Max von Sydow and Rutger Hauer deliver their exposition-heavy lines with relative ease.

Watching Š—“The MessengerŠ— Š—” the visuals alone are soothing, at least as long as the birds are flying to the sound of soaring violins Š—” we cling to the beauty and the emotional resonance of birdsong. But we know whatŠ—Ès coming: the tiny cold bodies, their claws curled, littering the sidewalk after smashing into glass; the migrating flocks disoriented by light pollution; the fallen victims of zealous oil drilling in the Boreal Forest.

Shot with a propagandistŠ—Ès eye for the inflammatory image, the film manipulates us, stoking our instinct to root for the good guys. Vintage news footage depicts Mao ZedongŠ—Ès 1957 attempt to save ChinaŠ—Ès grain crops from sparrows by mobilizing the citizenry to eradicate the birds (Boo!), an effort that backfired, contributing to a famine that killed millions.

We canŠ—Èt really expect the director, Su Rynard, to give equal time to bird haters (assuming one or two exist), although the film shows markedly less respect for other creatures. Cats, for one, are branded as invasive and likened to kudzu, but the film wisely stops short of recommending wiping out the species.

Young, earnest and, I daresay, charming Frenchmen (yay!) creep through cornfields to photograph evidence of illegal bird-trapping. A local gent, missing a few teeth, threatens the bird lovers with an implement resembling a giant fireplace poker. He rhapsodizes about plump ortolan buntings drizzled with Armagnac and grilled until the bones dissolve. A close-up follows of a diner tearing into a cooked bird, grasping its little head like a handle. (Eew!)

Jewel-colored birds flapping their wings in languid motion draw the viewer into this lush but ultimately grim assessment of our planetŠ—Ès future: Climate change and development are altering habitats more rapidly than birds can adapt, and that doesnŠ—Èt bode well for people.

Over all, the arguments are persuasive, the message from the birds powerful, and the film a rich and satisfying call to action that is presented with some novel ideas for how to restore the ecological balance .

Set in the early 1990s, like some lost entry from a golden age of tabloid news, Mr. SilverŠ—Ès movie is a strange brew. ItŠ—Ès part of-the-moment micro-budget indie hybrid, part throwback to improvisational exercises of yore. And itŠ—Ès shot with a pre-high-definition broadcast video camera, which roughs up the images nicely but engenders tight, disorienting shots that do the story no favors. While Mr. Douvry and Eileen Kearney (in a small role) burn up the screen with ragged bluster, the younger cast members do not readily evoke hard-knock lives, especially Ms. Gross as the dreaded but thinly drawn Ann.
Š—“Stinking HeavenŠ— is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 10 minutes.

Twisted and telegraphic, Nathan SilverŠ—Ès Š—“Stinking HeavenŠ— watches a home for substance abusers in Passaic, N.J., erupt in conflict, writhe in turmoil and collapse over a mere 70 minutes. EveryoneŠ—Ès crowded into a small suburban house overseen by Jim (Keith Poulson) and his wife, Lucy (Deragh Campbell), who enforce a form of therapy employing songs, chores, and filmed re-enactments of trauma. When two residents Š—” the ravaged old-timer, Kevin (Henri Douvry), and the younger Betty (El’©onore Hendricks) Š—” are married on site, weŠ—Ère tipped off to the dubiousness of JimŠ—Ès methods. Then BettyŠ—Ès old partner in crime, Ann (Hannah Gross), is unwisely welcomed into the group, and to top it all off, Jim is sleeping with KevinŠ—Ès daughter, Courtney (Tallie Medel), also a resident.
Yet Mr. Silver gets credit for raising the stakes with each sinewy new film, from the adolescent apathy of Š—“Exit ElenaŠ— (2013), all the way to this filmŠ—Ès unholy sobriety program.
Š—“American HeroŠ— starts off seeming as if it is going to be a fresh take on superheroes, but Nick Love, who wrote and directed, turns out to have nowhere to go with his intriguing premise.

The idea of a man with a superpower who aspires to little beyond being an ordinary guy is interesting, yet this ordinary guy is in the end rather lazily drawn despite the telekinesis. The absentee dad who suddenly wants a relationship with his son is a tiresome construct, and itŠ—Ès even more tiresome when the dadŠ—Ès behavior is defined by selfishness. We donŠ—Èt learn much about what wrecked his marriage or why Melvin is such a layabout. The guy is just plain unlikable, superpower or not.

Mr. Love isnŠ—Èt interested in a hokey Melvin-saves-the-world fantasy or the big-budget scenes of Š—“Hancock,Š— another deadbeat superhero movie. He keeps his protagonist in the gritty side of New Orleans, and in a state of personal inertia: Melvin repeatedly vows to clean up his act and do something useful with his life and gift, then backslides. The best he can manage is to confront a few drug dealers, a scene that overworks the special effects that up to that point had been the filmŠ—Ès best feature.

Melvin (Stephen Dorff) has the power to move objects with his mind, but he has never done much with it, or with his life in general. He yearns to spend time with his young son but has lost visiting privileges, and mostly he knocks around with his friend Lucille (Eddie Griffin), behaving self-indulgently.

The curious, nameless boy Š—” his face is like a shirt button Š—” is at first our portal to the unfiltered beauty of the fields and jungles of rural Brazil. Mr. AbreuŠ—Ès bouquets of crayon color and jazzy sound design explode on the screen, treated as an arena to roam left and right, up and down. Then the tykeŠ—Ès journey plunges into the depths of reality when he hops a train, joining the spindly migrants heading to the city in search of work.

What follows is a jaw-dropping sketch of towering cities and mechanized factories that brings in dark wit and satire (and clever collage) without abandoning the childŠ—Ès wonder. Mr. Abreu and his filmŠ—Ès music makers further set up a rousing duel of leitmotifs: the cacophony of the brown-gray city, apparently in the throes of a fascist takeover, versus a recurring parade of folk music accompanied by a florid phoenix.

Al’é AbreuŠ—Ès Š—“Boy and the WorldŠ— unleashes the exuberance of a child on the harsh realities of Brazil today. ItŠ—Ès both the best childrenŠ—Ès animated film this year since Š—“Inside OutŠ— Š—” you might call it Š—“Outside InŠ— Š—” and, unexpectedly, a more stirring depiction of the deadening modern megalopolis than most heal-the-world documentaries.
Š—“Boy and the WorldŠ— is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for some grim thematic material and images.

Not the most subtle critique, but this is a childrenŠ—Ès film, after all, and it acquires a primal purity by avoiding intelligible dialogue. (The few spoken lines seem to be played in reverse.) ItŠ—Ès like some lost globally conscious colorfest from the 1970s, reinvented with Mr. AbreuŠ—Ès verve.

Another question has to do with the targets of the filmŠ—Ès humor. With its supporting cast of ambitious megachurch pastors and na’Àve churchgoers, this might look like a satire of religion, or at least of certain aspects of 21st-century American Christianity. But Š—“Don Verdean,Š— written by Jared and Jerusha Hess, the couple who cooked up Š—“Napoleon Dynamite,Š— Š—“Nacho LibreŠ— and Š—“Gentlemen Broncos,Š— and directed, like those movies, by Mr. Hess, is more accurately described as a religious satire. Its intentions are, to some degree, corrective: It mocks some of the popular corruptions of faith so as to invite the audience to reflect upon what real faith might be.

Offered a fortune by Mr. McBrideŠ—Ès character for exclusive rights to whatever he unearths, Don finds himself in a bit of a moral pickle. The reverend wants big stuff, and Don obliges by finding the pillar of salt better known as LotŠ—Ès wife. Though it might not be her. ThereŠ—Ès a bit of anatomical and archaeological confusion on that score. When he tries to top that with GoliathŠ—Ès skull, Don finds himself on the road to perdition, saddled with an increasingly unhinged sidekick.

The goofiness is resolutely inoffensive, though the low-key clowning may not be to everyoneŠ—Ès taste. There is an absence of meanness in the HessesŠ—È comic worldview that makes their films almost impossible to dislike. Everyone in Š—“Don Verdean,Š— including Don himself, misbehaves in the full expectation of forgiveness, and if you donŠ—Èt love the movie, or donŠ—Èt quite get it, youŠ—Èll be forgiven, too.

With his shaggy haircut, ill-trimmed beard, safari vest and plastic-framed glasses, Don Verdean will never be mistaken for Indiana Jones. But to his admirers, Don, played with hoot-owl deadpan by Sam Rockwell, is every bit as charismatic as his fellow archaeologist. DonŠ—Ès specialty is biblical artifacts Š—” actual stuff mentioned in the Old and New Testament Š—” and he captivates church audiences with tales of his discoveries. He claims to possess the very scissors used by Delilah to clip poor SamsonŠ—Ès locks.

One of the questions that hovers around the early scenes of Š—“Don VerdeanŠ— is whether its title character is a knowing charlatan or a true believer. He certainly seems to be in earnest. He has also fallen on hard times, speaking in front of sparse audiences and living in the kind of recreational vehicle that might, thanks to Š—“Breaking Bad,Š— evoke a meth lab rather than the chariot of a righteous man.
Š—“Don VerdeanŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Some naughty language and sinful behavior. Running time: 1 hour 36 minutes.

This makes it sound like Sunday school, but Š—“Don VerdeanŠ— makes fun of that too, and of a whole lot of faith-based popular culture. And if the Hesses carry the viewer, and Don, toward a higher truth, they bear us upward on wings of pure silliness. This is a movie that features Danny McBride as a slick, smiling minister, Will Forte as his scowling, ex-Satanist rival and Jemaine Clement as an Israeli excavator named Boaz. The cast also includes the reliably, sneakily hilarious Amy Ryan as Carol, DonŠ—Ès loyal assistant and eventual dupe.

A completely useless scene involving the nosy boyfriend of one of the women underscores the storyŠ—Ès essential thinness. And when, at one point, the ostensible alpha female snarls, Š—“I did what needed to be done,Š— very bad recollections of the very bad 1998 movie Š—“Very Bad ThingsŠ— came to mind. Š—“BodyŠ— eventually goes for that movieŠ—Ès brand of cheap irony in a less blackly comedic register, and unfortunately achieves it. But those five minutes were pretty effective.

The rest of the movie, while confidently constructed for the most part, doesnŠ—Èt work as well. Three young women, sketched with something approaching callow misogyny, but well played by Helen Rogers, Alexandra Turshen and Lauren Molina, stage an impromptu holiday romp in a mansion they have no right to visit. Alas, it isnŠ—Èt long before a plainly angry man turns up, played by Larry Fessenden, the perennial bird of ill omen in contemporary American low-budget horror films. Mishaps and conflicts ensue, some scarier and more credible than others, and some just plain irritating.

ThereŠ—Ès an approximately five-minute section of Š—“Body,Š— a relatively brief horror movie written and directed by the young filmmakers Dan Berk and Robert Olsen, that accomplishes something rare in the genre. For a little bit, while the filmŠ—Ès twists are coming fast enough to keep the viewerŠ—Ès mind off the storyŠ—Ès implausibilities, Š—“BodyŠ— manages to turn a pitiable, helpless victim of criminal negligence into an object of fear and terror. It suggests Mr. Berk and Mr. Olsen have some viable inspiration to go with their above-average talent.

Mr. Bedford, directing his first feature (which he also wrote), cuts brief interviews of real Mississippians into the story. They talk about their hard lives with unadorned honesty. ItŠ—Ès a refreshing flourish that gives the film some of its best moments.

Hank BedfordŠ—Ès Š—“DixielandŠ— has nothing to do with music, but it certainly has intriguing musical connections. Steve Earle, the country rocker, turns up in a secondary role and acquits himself well. So does Faith Hill, the country star. And one of the leads is played by Riley Keough, granddaughter of Elvis Presley.

This is well-worn territory, and though the two leads are very good, the romance that is supposed to drive the story isnŠ—Èt particularly well delineated; Kermit and Rachel meet and fall instantly in love, few questions asked. Maybe thatŠ—Ès part of Mr. BedfordŠ—Ès point Š—” in a world where no one has much, people grab onto whatever they can Š—” but it feels thin. The film is long on atmosphere, short on details.

The story, though, isnŠ—Èt quite as attention-getting as the casting. It involves Kermit (Chris Zylka), who, after being released from prison, returns home to a run-down part of Mississippi, vowing to stay on the straight and narrow. But Š—” guess what? Š—” thatŠ—Ès harder than it might seem, especially once he falls into a relationship with Rachel (Ms. Keough), whose sick mother has racked up medical bills. The temptation of easy money lures Kermit back to the sketchier side for what he hopes will be just one big payday.

A true crime story and a madcap comedy, a heist movie and a scalding polemic, Š—“The Big ShortŠ— will affirm your deepest cynicism about Wall Street while simultaneously restoring your faith in Hollywood.

ItŠ—Ès a trip. At the end, your brain hurts and you feel sick to your stomach, as can happen when too much adrenaline has been surging through your system. But that queasy, empty feeling is the point: This is a terrifically enjoyable movie that leaves you in a state of rage, nausea and despair. What is to be done with those feelings is the great moral and political challenge Mr. McKay has set for the audience, which I hope is vast and various. I donŠ—Èt condone mob violence and IŠ—Èm supposed to keep my political opinions to myself, but as soon as IŠ—Èm done writing this IŠ—Èm going out to the garage to look for a pitchfork.

Written by Adam McKay (Š—“Anchorman,Š— Š—“Anchorman 2Š—) and Charles Randolph, and directed by Mr. McKay and released in the midst of Š—“Star WarsŠ— advent season, the film sets itself a very tall order. It wants not only to explain the financial crisis of 2008 Š—” following the outline of Michael LewisŠ—Ès best-selling nonfiction book Š—” but also to make the dry, complex abstractions of high finance exciting and fun. Celebrity cameos (from Margot Robbie, Anthony Bourdain and Selena Gomez, among others) are turned into miniseminars on the finer points of credit-default swaps and collateralized debt obligations. The story swerves and swings from executive suites and conference rooms to hectic Manhattan streets and desolate Florida subdivisions. The performances, the script and the camera itself seem to be running on a cocktail of Red Bull, Adderall and mescaline.

Back in 2010, when Mr. LewisŠ—Ès book came out, it was as ubiquitous an accessory for business-class airline passengers as the Š—“TwilightŠ— novels were for adolescent girls. Part of the bookŠ—Ès appeal Š—” a side effect of its authorŠ—Ès smart, breezy, plain-spoken style Š—” was that it offered readers the illusion of retroactive prescience. You could read about the insanity of bundling subprime mortgages into highly rated investment products and think: Well, of course that was a recipe for disaster. Of course a drop in the housing market would bring the whole thing crashing down like a Jenga tower. It was obvious. We knew it all along.

Š—“The Big ShortŠ— is not the first movie to reckon with the fraud and stupidity that brought the world economy to the brink of collapse not so long ago and that continues to exact a heavy toll in social misery and political alienation. Charles FergusonŠ—Ès 2010 documentary Š—“Inside JobŠ— remains the definitive cinematic account of the regulatory, intellectual and ethical failures that led to the crisis. J .C. ChandorŠ—Ès superb Š—“Margin CallŠ— (2011) depicts the minute-by-minute bursting of the mortgage-backed-securities bubble, while Ramin BahraniŠ—Ès excellent Š—“99 Homes,Š— released this year, dramatizes some of the long-term consequences of the crash. But rather than rehash familiar ground, Š—“The Big ShortŠ— achieves a fresh and brilliant synthesis of knowing insiderism and populist incitement.

But when we root for Baum and Burry to be proven right, for Shipley and Geller to hit pay dirt and for Vennett to earn the right to be smug in perpetuity, we are also hoping for ruin to be visited on millions of ordinary people. Houses, nest eggs, jobs and lives will be lost. Brad Pitt, in a gravelly turn as Ben Rickert, Shipley and GellerŠ—Ès paranoid guru, makes this point explicitly when he scolds his prot’©g’©s for celebrating their good fortune. He says what needs to be said, but the achievement of Š—“The Big ShortŠ— is that Mr. McKay doesnŠ—Èt only underline the moral of the story in dialogue. The filmŠ—Ès final images, its abrupt shift in tone from exhilaration to exhaustion, its suddenly downbeat music (by Nicholas Britell) all combine to trigger a climactic wave of almost unbearable disgust.

There is the antisocial numbers guy, Dr. Michael Burry (Christian Bale), a fund manager who sits in his office wearing a T-shirt and flip-flops, blasting death metal, beating on his desk with drumsticks and betting his clientŠ—Ès money on financial catastrophe. There is the righteously angry crusader, Mark Baum (Steve Carell), a disaffected Wall Streeter who sees a similar wager as the perfect expression of his contempt for the big banks (including the one he technically works for). And there are the young indie upstarts, Jamie Shipley (Finn Wittrock) and Charlie Geller (John Magaro), college buddies whose Š—“garage bandŠ— fund was started with their own money and who want to show that they can play in the big leagues.

In fact, almost none of us did. Certainly not the government officials and banking executives who remain at liberty and in positions of power to this day. Or if they did know, they didnŠ—Èt care. The truth about what the banks and their enablers were doing was obvious only to a handful of people (one of whom, in the movie, is shown demonstrating the Jenga tower metaphor I just borrowed). Mr. McKay, with a comedy writerŠ—Ès eye for archetypes, sorts them into an amusing array of strongly defined characters.

Because, as we know Š—” and as we can stand, from time to time, to be reminded Š—” there is no happy ending to this story, no punishment for the crime. A movie is unlikely to change that, and Š—“The Big Short,Š— in many ways a startlingly ambitious film, is modest about what it can do. It offers no solutions, and no comfort. The best it can do is put down a marker.

Linking these motley iconoclasts, and serving as our guide to the apocalypse unfolding around them, is Jared Vennett, a silky cynic played, with all the seductiveness that has made him a beloved Internet meme, by Ryan Gosling. From time to time Vennett will cast his baby blues toward the camera to tell us that something didnŠ—Èt really happen in quite the way itŠ—Ès being shown Š—” or that, incredibly enough, it actually did. His slick, winking wit inoculates the movie against excessive earnestness and allows us to think that Š—“The Big ShortŠ— is going to be one of those boisterous, amoral rich-guy movies, complete with geysers of Champagne and visits to strip clubs.
Š—“The Big ShortŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). All that is solid melts into air; all that is holy is profaned. Running time: 2 hours 10 minutes.

Which, to some extent, it is. Mr. McKay is not above using paid-for female nudity as a signifier of capitalist excess, nor acknowledging, more generally, the hedonistic aspects of greed. He is a naturally exuberant director, and his antic energy matches the rhythms of the story. The teams conspiring to short the market are impossible not to root for, and the work of the movieŠ—Ès sprawling ensemble is never less than delightful. (This is the place to appreciate the contributions of Rafe Spall, Hamish Linklater and Jeremy Strong, who play BaumŠ—Ès baffled minions; Adepero Oduye, who plays his liaison to the bank that houses his fund; and Marisa Tomei, who as BaumŠ—Ès wife is like the only civilian in a combat picture.)

Another Carrollian allusion Š—” distantly evoking the inspirational if mysterious relationships of Charles Dodgson (a.k.a. Lewis Carroll) with Lorina and Alice Liddell Š—” informs the scenes with Milan and the 14-year-old Alice (Ana Mulvoy-Ten).These encounters, which induce a quiet, queasy suspense, teeter between MilanŠ—Ès sexual agenda and AliceŠ—Ès desire for paternal encouragement, and play havoc with her adult future.

ThereŠ—Ès a glimmer of hope in AliceŠ—Ès present when, through her best friend, Sadie (Ali Ahn), a pregnant stay-at-home mother, she meets Emmett (David Call), a handsome, earnest but easygoing political activist who refers to his Š—“abnormally normalŠ— upbringing. But as Milan re-enters her life, Alice is again lost in a familiar spiral; itŠ—Ès no accident that she and Sadie meet at the Š—“Alice in WonderlandŠ— statue in Central Park. Soon Alice must fight to hold on to Emmett.
Š—“The Girl in the BookŠ— is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 28 minutes.

The director, Ms. Cohn, making her feature debut, wrote the script and handily keeps the storyŠ—Ès many elements in motion. A third-act sequence in which the Internet unlocks AliceŠ—Ès creativity as she pleads for EmmettŠ—Ès forbearance is a little tidy in its overnight resolution. But Ms. Cohn stops well short of overweening sentiment. Given her confident hand behind the camera and gift for rich female characters, you hope to see more portraits from her in the future.

Now a former client of her father, the established writer Milan Daneker (Michael Nyqvist), is taking his latest novel to AliceŠ—Ès boss, and Alice is assigned to promote it. SheŠ—Èd rather not: From flashbacks, we learn that 15 years earlier, when Alice was a teenager, Milan attempted to seduce her under the pretense that he was cultivating her budding literary skills. The exploitation did not end there; she was the model for a character of his who is regarded in literary circles as the Š—“female Holden Caulfield.Š—

Mr. Nyqvist (the male protagonist in the Swedish Š—“The Girl With the Dragon TattooŠ— movies) is part sanctimonious celebrity and part insinuating predator; the tentative Ms. Mulvoy-Ten appears somewhat uneasy in her role, which only helps her performance. As for Ms. VanCampŠ—Ès adult Alice, she is a rounded, winning blend of self-doubt and fitful initiative.

As Marya CohnŠ—Ès romantic drama Š—“The Girl in the BookŠ— begins, Alice (Emily VanCamp, formerly of Š—“RevengeŠ— on ABC), an editorial assistant at a Manhattan publishing house, lacks self-esteem. She flounders at writing fiction; she is tiring of one-night stands; her supercilious boss (Jordan Lage) ignores her discovery of a promising novelist; and her dominating father, an old-school hotshot literary agent (Michael Cristofer), refuses to believe she can make her own decisions. Clearly, Alice has problems with men, especially male authority figures.

The biggest mistake here, though, is a misbegotten decorousness that sinks the movie, stoving it as calamitously as an enraged whale. Whether out of squeamishness, Oscar ambitions or because the story never coheres, Mr. Howard puts his pulp instincts in check and consistently (tastefully) pulls back, deploying splatters rather than torrents. Yet Melville was drawn to the story of the Essex for good reason, including the ghastly turn of events that led Mr. Philbrick to drop memorable phrases like Š—“gastronomic incestŠ— into his book. ThereŠ—Ès no such corollary Š—” no frenzied horror, no unspeakable truth Š—” in the movie, which takes a 19th-century story of manŠ—Ès survival in nature and turns it into a reminder that the whole domination of nature thing wasnŠ—Èt such a great idea.

Mr. Howard goes all out when the ship finally sets sail: The camera whips around, going wide and eye-jabbingly close as you follow the crew up the masts, across the deck and into the galley. He comes across as keenly interested in the sweat labor it takes to run a whaling ship (the industrial organization evokes that of a major production like this one), but shortly after touring the operations, the movie loses momentum. One problem is the obvious artificiality of many of the digital effects. These often take you out of the story partly because, unlike the impressionistic painted backdrops in old Hollywood films, theyŠ—Ère trying hard to replicate the real world. When a rope runs along a post, the heat rising from it looks faked, while itŠ—Ès the grappling men who give the moment a fleeting vibrancy.

Directors tend to have a tough time making the act of writing pop visually, and the pleasant scratching sound of a quill on paper only goes so far. So itŠ—Ès understandable that Mr. Howard, whoŠ—Ès best when heŠ—Ès in touch with his B-movie pulp side, seems as anxious as Owen to set sail. First though thereŠ—Ès the typical scene-setting, including some dutiful domestic drama with OwenŠ—Ès loving yet resentful wife (Charlotte Riley, in a placeholder role), which Mr. Howard and company try to enliven with sincere looks, earnest promises and panoramic views of the unconvincingly antiqued island. More promising are OwenŠ—Ès exchanges with his employer, a shipping company that forces him to serve under George Pollard (Benjamin Walker), an inexperienced captain with family connections.

OwenŠ—Ès dealings with the shipping company introduce some hefty topics Š—” capitalism, nepotism, corruption, democracy Š—” that vibrate throughout the story without ever developing into an argument. ThatŠ—Ès too bad, but as the movie lurches along by fits and starts, toggling between the little Nantucket room and the great watery world, it becomes apparent that the filmmakers have no idea how to reconcile not just two parallel stories but also the past and our contemporary age. In one corner thereŠ—Ès the ambitious author hungrily absorbing a tragic tale that will help lead him to a masterpiece; in the other is the old-fashioned adventure story outfitted with manly action, churning waters and a catastrophe in the wild that meant something very different in the 19th  century than it does today.

Mixing fact and fiction, the movie pulls a thread from history and tries to weave it into a tapestry. On a Nantucket night in 1850, Herman (a wan Ben Whishaw) blusters into the home of an old seaman, Tom Nickerson (Brendan Gleeson), who has a story but is in emotional lockdown. Making his case with cash, Herman persuades Tom to talk, which he does with booze and much actorly harrumphing from Mr. Gleeson. Winding the clock back to 1819, Tom begins the story of the whaling ship, the Essex, and its first mate, Owen Chase, a role that once would have belonged to Burt Lancaster and which Mr. Hemsworth plays with a straight-edged seriousness that is among the movieŠ—Ès virtues.

As the ice caps melt, the trickle of movies about natureŠ—Ès revenge may turn into a deluge. There are oceans already sloshing through Š—“In the Heart of the Sea,Š— the latest from the director Ron Howard, about the shipwreck that was an inspiration for Herman MelvilleŠ—Ès Š—“Moby-Dick.Š— Epic in ambition, it spans decades and miles as it moves from Nantucket to a Pacific whale hunt that pits man (Chris Hemsworth) against Leviathan. ItŠ—Ès at once a biopic and an adventure yarn that, with harpoons and ploddingly good intentions, turns a story of survival into an ecological cautionary tale.

The film is based on Nathaniel PhilbrickŠ—Ès 2000 nonfiction best seller, Š—“In the Heart of the Sea: The Tragedy of the Whaleship Essex.Š— Among Mr. PhilbrickŠ—Ès sources are NickersonŠ—Ès posthumously published account, Š—“The Loss of the Ship Š—…EssexŠ—È Sunk by a Whale and the Ordeal of the Crew in Open Boats,Š— and ChaseŠ—Ès 1821 book, which has an even more charmingly prolix title: Š—“Narrative of the Most Extraordinary and Distressing Shipwreck of the Whale-Ship Essex, of Nantucket; Which Was Attacked and Finally Destroyed by a Large Spermaceti-Whale, in the Pacific Ocean; With an Account of the Unparalleled Sufferings of the Captain and CrewŠ— and so on. That more or less tips what happens in the movie, with the sufferings regularly interrupted by scenes of HermanŠ—Ès writing and TomŠ—Ès talking.
Š—“In the Heart of the SeaŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Gun play and butchery. Running time: 2 hours 1 minute.

Š—“The Tainted VeilŠ— explores the history and the contradictions of the hijab, the head and neck covering that many Muslim women wear. This documentaryŠ—Ès subjects variously describe the garment as an expression of, and a denial of, femininity; a source of beauty and a concealment of it; a backward-looking symbol and a modern fashion accessory.

Early on, a mother and daughter argue about the hijabŠ—Ès merits, with the mother having decided to go without it, feeling that it makes her look old. Dr. Ahmed Barqawi, identified as head of philosophy and social studies at Damascus University, frames the views over the hijab as, essentially, a conflict between different reasons for wearing it Š—” ideological and personal.

Sarah Joseph, editor of Emel Magazine in Britain, considers her hijab an expression of religious identity in a country thatŠ—Ès reserved about religion. As the movie trots through Europe and the Middle East, academics and clerics weigh in on the hijabŠ—Ès purpose and scriptural basis. Some interviewees note its changing use over time.

The movie also looks beyond individuals to explore perceptions of the hijab in society. (In a moment no doubt intended to upend expectations, one wearer is shown practicing martial arts.) The subject matter makes Š—“The Tainted VeilŠ— much more visually interesting than many issue-oriented documentaries, though the thriller-like score goes too far in trying to counter dryness.

For Mr. Rocha, itŠ—Ès all about the emotion. Recurring close-ups of a playerŠ—Ès face, streaks of sand suggesting tribal markings, underscore the fierce inter-favela rivalry that drives the spectators to frenzies of anxiety and elation. Dips into slow motion, along with a spare soundtrack of classical pieces and percussion, bathe game and players in a reverence thatŠ—Ès normally conferred only on their professional counterparts. This respect is evident in every frame, revealing two religions: the prayers and Hail Marys of one indistinguished from the tackles and pep talks of the other.

Plopping us down on a patch of dirt in the Sampaio neighborhood of Rio de Janeiro Š—” mere months before the 2014 World Cup Š—” the movie joins teams from two rival favelas as they face off in the final of an annual 14-team tournament. But Mr. Rocha (the son of Glauber Rocha, one of BrazilŠ—Ès most influential filmmakers) cares little for demonstrating game strategy or shaping a coherent narrative. As rain clouds and supporters gather, and chalk boundaries are carefully laid down, he prepares to turn churning legs and pistoning arms into a ritualized sensory experience Š—” a fragmented sports opera whose parts inform the whole.

A happy marriage of rudimentary conditions and highly sophisticated filmmaking, Eryk RochaŠ—Ès passionate documentary Š—“Sunday BallŠ— dives into an amateur soccer game in the Brazilian slums and barely comes up for air.

Captured more for poetry than for clarity, the topography of penalties and free kicks can be impossible to follow. But L’©o BittencourtŠ—Ès photography has flash and flair, and hardscrabble determination on a real-life field of dreams has a narrative all its own.

Much of the screenplay consists of vaguely poetic pronouncements, which Ms. Swinton delivers with an undertone of amusement. Š—“Every generation thinks that is the modern age.Š— Š—“Our time is a time of total connection. Distance is zero.Š— Š—“To be is to be connected.Š— Š—“Geography is history.Š— Blah, blah, blah. Other aphorisms include: Š—“If we see whatŠ—Ès in store for us, could we refuse it?Š— And, most scarily: Š—“Today in our pockets. Tomorrow woven into our bodies.Š—

Simultaneously backward-looking and forward-looking, the film makes you feel like a tiny scurrying insect on the global anthill. The unspoken dread that infuses the film is older than OrwellŠ—Ès Š—“1984Š—: a fearful fascination with the obliteration of personal identity and the nightmare of human beings as robotic puppets manipulated by the mass media. A recurrent theme is surveillance. Electronic media have allowed us to surveil ourselves, while the powers that be secretly watch us without our knowledge. But Š—“Dreams RewiredŠ— makes no judgments.
