The movieŠ—Ès vaguely ominous tone is established by the opening images of a restless crowd in an unidentified location. It quickly settles into an informal history of the invention of various technological miracles: the telephone, movies, radio, the phonograph and eventually television and computers. One of the most vivid scenes shows telephone operators making connections. The narrator wryly observes that they were mostly women because men didnŠ—Èt have the patience for the job.
Š—“Dreams RewiredŠ— is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 25 minutes.

Names are dropped. There are brief excerpts from Charlie Chaplin and Buster Keaton movies and the works of pioneering filmmakers like Alice Guy-Blach’©, Georges M’©li’ås, Sergei Eisenstein and D. W. Griffith. A longer sequence consists of scenes of the 1936 Olympics, described as the first made-for-television event.

Š—“Dreams Rewired,Š— a montage of clips from nearly 200 vintage films, is a lively, visually enthralling attempt to gaze into the future by remembering the past. The snippets Š—” mostly obscure excerpts from dramas, cartoons and scientific and educational films Š—” are seamlessly fused into a whoosh of images, many of them zany, all from the 1880s to the 1930s. The later ones have sound.

Directed by Manu Luksch, Martin Reinhart and Thomas Tode, a German-Austrian team, and written by Ms. Luksch and Mukul Patel, Š—“Dreams RewiredŠ— reminds you that anxieties about the potentially destructive effects of new technologies are nothing recent. The film is narrated by Tilda Swinton, whose words have the pseudo-oracular tone of an introduction to a Š—“Twilight ZoneŠ— episode.

Š—“Dreams RewiredŠ— is mostly content to entertain. Its explanations of how new inventions work are simplified to the point of superficiality. Although it plays with a fundamental question Š—” how much and in what ways does technology change us? Š—” it barely begins to address the issue. It may sound cool to say, Š—“To be is to be connected.Š— But what does that really mean?

Rhythmically blending vintage recordings and live performances, Š—“The Winding StreamŠ— exudes a quirky warmth that counters its PBS-pledge-drive aura. Mike OlsonŠ—Ès photo-animations have a Terry Gilliam-like oddness, and, despite a welcome interview with Johnny Cash (conducted just weeks before his death in 2003), itŠ—Ès the Carter women who shine. ThereŠ—Ès MaybelleŠ—Ès virtuosic ability to play rhythm and lead guitar simultaneously; JuneŠ—Ès flair for comedy; JanetteŠ—Ès Saturday-night hoedowns at the Carter Family Fold, where neither drunkenness nor dirty dancing was allowed.
Š—“The Winding Stream: The Carters, the Cashes and the Course of Country MusicŠ— is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 32 minutes.
Hints at Mr. CashŠ—Ès demons aside, Ms. Harrington, like her subjects, doesnŠ—Èt dwell on the darkness. Obeying one of the CartersŠ—È most famous songs, she prefers to keep on the sunny side.

With music like this Š—” Rosanne Cash calls it Š—“primalŠ— Š—” thatŠ—Ès not hard to do. Rooted in the folk songs of Appalachia, the playlist of the original Carter family grew and was spread in those early years by the powerful signal of a Mexican radio station. Performed by A. P., a traveling salesman and inveterate impresario, his wife, Sara, and her cousin Maybelle, the tunes would prove indestructible. Not even Pearl Harbor Š—” which supplanted a Carter feature in Life magazine and inspired a family joke that they had been Š—“bombed out of their careerŠ— Š—” could stop them.
American royalty gets a well-deserved encomium in Beth HarringtonŠ—Ès fond documentary, Š—“The Winding Stream: The Carters, the Cashes and the Course of Country Music.Š—

Thoughtfully assembled to showcase the music and the temperaments behind it, this jam-packed oral history of the Carter and Cash families weaves the voices of prominent musicians (Sheryl Crow, George Jones) with those of family members past and present. Leading us from Poor Valley, Va. Š—” where the seventh generation of Carters still attends the church that its patriarch, A. P., built in 1906 Š—” through decades of personal and professional landmarks, Ms. Harrington sweeps divorce, disappointment and the Great Depression into a single, upbeat package.
Š—“The EmperorŠ—Ès New ClothesŠ— is moderately effective agitprop.

Free-market fundamentalism Š—” the belief that the economy, if left to its own devices, will self-correct in times of stress Š—” is the source of all evil in Russell Brand and Michael WinterbottomŠ—Ès inflammatory documentary, Š—“The EmperorŠ—Ès New Clothes.Š— And the economist Milton Friedman, whose laissez-faire economic theories were embraced by Margaret Thatcher and Ronald Reagan, is portrayed as a kind of Antichrist foreshadowing the global meltdown of 2008.

The movie begins with the Hans Christian Andersen tale Š—“The EmperorŠ—Ès New Clothes,Š— about two weavers who promise the ruler a new suit that is invisible to those who are stupid or incompetent. As he parades before his subjects, they pretend that heŠ—Ès dressed in silk and gold until a child in the crowd pipes up and shouts that he isnŠ—Èt wearing anything at all.

Mr. Brand indulges in many of the same stunts Mr. Moore has pulled, ambushing bankers and plutocrats and asking them uncomfortable questions, which they brush off. In the most clever running gag, he quizzes a group of schoolchildren with loaded questions about income disparity in Britain, and asks if itŠ—Ès fair, only to be answered with a resounding Š—“No.Š— In one assertion, not credited to a source, he declares that if all the money in Britain were divided equally, each person would get 200,000 pounds (about $300,000).

Mr. Brand, the tousled-haired British comedian, actor and left-wing activist once briefly married to Katy Perry, might be described as Michael Moore with fangs. Instead of a genial, shuffling Everyman, he is an outspoken, fiery-eyed political gadfly preaching revolution. With his shrill, acrid voice, filled with nagging indignation, he wants to goad listeners into taking action. Voting isnŠ—Èt enough to reverse income inequality, he warns. Active involvement is necessary, he insists, as he spreads his message from a sound truck touring London.

That willful blindness is a metaphor for the behavior of the masses who accept on faith the free-market doctrine, a tenet of which is the unproven Š—“trickle-downŠ— theory that great wealth benefits everyone by seeping down from above.

Š—“The EmperorŠ—Ès New ClothesŠ— ends on a positive note, with the true story of how Mr. Brand and fellow activists fought an American equity firm, Westbrook Partners, whose proposed purchase of the New Era Estate, an East London development, became a public relations disaster. Once it was refurbished, the raised rents would have rendered many of the longtime residents homeless. Under pressure, Westbrook backed down.
The most infuriating revelations have to do with the system of tax avoidance, by which he says an estimated $21 to $32 trillion are held in offshore tax havens like the Cayman Islands.
Š—“The EmperorŠ—Ès New ClothesŠ— is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 42 minutes.

Shot in the Tuscan Alps, the documentary-fiction hybrid Š—“The Creation of MeaningŠ— moves between suspending us in timeless nature and listening to the echoes of the past. A mountainside farmer, Pacifico Pieruccioni, clad in shorts, is one of the last men standing (for a few miles, at least) in an area wracked by ItalyŠ—Ès economic dysfunction and still touched by the memories of the Germans in World War II. The setting is an idyll fading before our eyes (with a bit of secret).

The filmŠ—Ès slightly pompous title is fulfilled in prismatic ways: the stories we hear, the impending renewal of the land under its new owner (who will allow Pacifico to stay), the tours Pacifico gives of the area, even an excerpt from a low-budget film about partisans thatŠ—Ès shot there. Cutaways to natureŠ—Ès splendor abound: Mists enfold the mountain; Mr. Casanova mesmerizingly holds one cross-fade from these clouds.

According to a published interview with the director, the film is a mix of fiction and documentary not far removed from the auteurs Pedro Costa or Lisandro Alonso: Mr. Pieruccioni is in fact playing out a scenario he hadnŠ—Èt experienced personally. The information is a curious footnote Š—” and raises the not-often-raised question of how such foreknowledge might affect the average viewerŠ—Ès intake of the film Š—” but itŠ—Ès another potent example of the creation of meaning.
Š—“The Creation of MeaningŠ— is not rated and is in Italian with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 35 minutes.

Shooting from still positions, the director, Simone Rapisarda Casanova, watches the relaxed, resigned Pacifico doing his chores, sometimes in a shadowy house, once while listening to truly toxic talk radio. The hale and hearty farmer listens to an old womanŠ—Ès stories about the war and hosts a German man with a baby. The visitor is buying PacificoŠ—Ès land and wonders aloud to his captive audience about why Italy puts up with corruption.
Š—“Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Road ChipŠ— is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for rude humor and language.

It also puts the focus back on the boys. The Chipettes, a female version of the trio, had been hogging a lot of screen time recently, but here theyŠ—Ère relegated to support status. Alvin (the voice of Justin Long), Theodore (Jesse McCartney) and Simon (Matthew Gray Gubler) are concerned that their human minder, Dave (Jason Lee), is getting too chummy with his girlfriend (Kimberly Williams-Paisley). They reluctantly join forces with her obnoxious son (Josh Green) to travel to Miami, where they think Dave intends to pop the question, an event they plan to disrupt.

Why the Chipmunks still command an audience more than a half-century after their initial incarnation on novelty records defies explanation, but they do; the first three movies each earned a nine-figure box office gross. The third installment, Š—“Chipwrecked,Š— in 2011, was somewhat chaotic and didnŠ—Èt do as well as the first two; the new movie is a bit of a corrective, with a simpler plot and an abundance of catchy (if you can stand that grating, high-pitched harmony) songs.

Now would be an excellent time for parents of young children to invest in earplugs. A new Alvin and the Chipmunks movie has landed. This oneŠ—Ès called Š—“Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Road Chip,Š— the fourth in the series, which began in 2007 and mixes live-action and computer-generated characters.

The shoddiness of the airline security they encounter is appalling. (Tony Hale of Š—“VeepŠ— has an undignified turn as an incompetent air marshal.) Some familiar songs are given the Chipmunk treatment, most successfully Š—“Iko Iko,Š— which, it must be admitted, is well suited to their fingernails-on-a-chalkboard sound. The film delivers the standard upbeat message about family, along with one particularly outstanding and incongruous cameo that Š—” sorry Š—” wonŠ—Èt be spoiled here.

The party movie is a venerable genre. So is the movie-as-party, which is a slightly different creature. Š—“SistersŠ— is a hybrid of the two, and also, therefore, a fairly standard specimen of modern post-Š—“HangoverŠ— commercial film comedy. It falls into the same category as Š—“NeighborsŠ— or Š—“The Night Before,Š— which is to say itŠ—Ès uneven, generally enjoyable, self-consciously naughty and also, despite drug use and jokes about anal sex, more concerned with reassurance than transgression.

Since Maura has a crush on a hunky neighbor (Ike Barinholtz, playing a handsome dullard rather than the goofball you might know from Š—“The Mindy ProjectŠ—), she is allowed to cut loose and go crazy. Kate reluctantly agrees to be the sober Š—“party mom.Š— At first the guests glumly act their age, but then the tequila starts to flow, the music becomes loud, the joints are lit and the requisite funny stuff starts to happen. The respectable wife and mother (Samantha Bee) takes her top off. The jokey fat guy (Bobby Moynihan) loses his pants. The sad, weird woman (Rachel Dratch) gets drunker and weirder and sadder. The mean girl (Maya Rudolph) tries to crash the party, and then to sabotage it. The audience learns which groups Hollywood is still willing to treat as comic stereotypes, with the usual escape clause that the stereotypes themselves are being held up for mockery. It turns out to be Asian women and lesbians.

Š—“SistersŠ— is best when it allows itself a hint of cruelty. Ms. Fey wrote the screenplay for Š—“Mean Girls,Š— after all, and the affection and inspiration that flows so easily between her and Ms. Poehler carries a bracing undercurrent of hostility toward everybody else. But Š—“SistersŠ— is both too careful and too sloppy to take full advantage of the thornier implications of its premise. ItŠ—Ès too awkward Š—” because scenes drag when they should swing and jokes sag when they should pop Š—” and not awkward enough.

To add to their woes, Kate and MauraŠ—Ès parents (James Brolin and Dianne Wiest) have decided to sell the family home in Orlando, Fla., and move into a condominium complex where they have less space and more sex. Their easygoing retirement bliss is a rebuke to their daughtersŠ—È midlife misery. Kate and Maura donŠ—Èt seem to know how to be happy, except when they are together in the childhood home they are about to lose.
Š—“SistersŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian).  Trash talk. Running time: 1 hour 58 minutes.

Š—“SistersŠ— is a movie to go out and see when youŠ—Ève run out of television to watch. Which could happen, at least theoretically. Directed by Jason Moore (Š—“Pitch PerfectŠ—) from a script by the longtime Š—“Saturday Night LiveŠ— writer Paula Pell, this raunchy-huggy comedy features, in keeping with Hollywood custom, a gaggle of well-known and well-liked sitcom and sketch-comedy performers being a little less funny than you want them to be. They are allowed to swear more robustly than on network or basic-cable shows, to deliver sentimental speeches along with punch lines and to play with or against type as the mood suits.

Tina Fey, as Kate Ellis, falls Š—” or rather leaps Š—” into the Š—“againstŠ— category. WeŠ—Ère used to seeing Ms. Fey (especially but not only on Š—“30 RockŠ—) as an anxious overthinker using her caustic sarcasm as a weapon against both her own insecurities and the flakes and train wrecks who surround her. This time, she gets to be the train wreck. Kate is sometimes scolded for her irresponsibility by her teenage daughter, Haley (Madison Davenport), but her real foil is her younger sister, Maura, played in full goody-two-shoes splendor by Amy Poehler. Way back in 2008, in Š—“Baby Mama,Š— Ms. Poehler was the wayward yin to Ms. FeyŠ—Ès uptight yang. This time, the polarities are reversed, but the performers are too restless, and too much in sync, to settle into a simple pattern.

First, though, in order for Š—“SistersŠ— to become a comedy rather than the somber little indie melodrama it may secretly want to be, Kate and Maura have to hold one last big bash. Defying their parents and the snooty New York transplants who are buying the house, the sisters take to Facebook and summon their old high school crowd, and random other people, to the suburban split-level they call Ellis Island.

When they were growing up Š—” as attested to in passages from diaries they find in their old bedroom Š—” Kate was hedonistic and adventurous, while Maura was prudent and prudish. In their 40s, they find themselves stuck in these roles. Kate is a hothead who canŠ—Èt hold down a job. Maura, a nurse, is divorced and lonely.

But nobody really gets hurt (except for maybe Mr. BarinholtzŠ—Ès character, who has an uncomfortable encounter with a ballerina music box), and nobody stays mad. Unlike small-screen sitcom characters, who can change slowly over seasons or not at all, the protagonists of movie comedies must grow, learn, change and forgive. This is almost always a drag, even when itŠ—Ès kind of touching, as it is here.

At the beginning of Sanjay Leela BhansaliŠ—Ès Š—“Bajirao Mastani,Š— a Bollywood romance set in 18th-century India, thereŠ—Ès much talk of planting saffron (that is, Hindu) flags in Delhi, the heart of the Mughal (that is, Muslim) empire. Is this going to be an unpleasant India-for-Hindus epic? On the other hand, the movie seems to have some feminist bona fides: Mastani (Deepika Padukone) is an impressively fierce woman warrior, who saves the life of the equally fierce Bajirao (Ranveer Singh) on the battlefield as arrows whiz by her head. Š—“Mastani writes her own destiny,Š— she says. Well, O.K.

But soon neither theory proves true. Š—“Bajirao MastaniŠ— is no nationalist cri de coeur; instead, itŠ—Ès the story of a Hindu man (Bajirao) who falls for a Muslim woman (Mastani). Bajirao gives Mastani his dagger, which, in her kingdom, means theyŠ—Ère married; she follows him home, only to be rejected by custom, her mother-in-law and BajiraoŠ—Ès Wife No. 1, Kashibai (Priyanka Chopra, familiar to American viewers from ABCŠ—Ès Š—“QuanticoŠ—). MastaniŠ—Ès fierceness is now all about love, service and motherhood.

ThereŠ—Ès plenty of story here, but Š—“Bajirao MastaniŠ— has more visual pop than narrative traction. The central pair of defiant lovers are never particularly convincing as convention-busters, nor are they as appealing as the rooms they inhabit or the clothes they wear. You may find yourself rooting for Ms. ChopraŠ—Ès pushed-aside Kashibai: She has beauty to spare, a good song and something the rest of the movie lacks Š—” warmth and a touch of humor.

Mr. Bhansali, a Hindi cinema auteur, fills his movie with gorgeous things: green walls painted with delicate pink flowers, a twinkling palace of mirrors, lush fabrics. (The effects-laden battlefield scenes tend to be more pompous, in the Š—“300: Rise of an EmpireŠ— mold.)

The winking becomes more pronounced as the film goes along. HereŠ—Ès Cara, trying to make small talk with Jack once it dawns on her that heŠ—Ès centuries old: Š—“So, the Civil War Š—” what was that like?Š— But Mr. Krawczyk never lapses into over-the-top horror parody, which too many others have done too often.

Jack has spent what turns out to be a very long lifetime perfecting the art of being nondescript, presumably to avoid getting into situations that lead him to indulge his taste for human flesh. For entertainment, he plays bingo. He goes to the same diner most every day. The waitress there, Cara (Kate Greenhouse, playing it perfectly), seems to be sweet on him, but somehow Jack, in his hundreds of years on the planet, has not mastered basic social skills, like holding a conversation.

Performances donŠ—Èt come more deadpan than the one Henry Rollins gives in Š—“He Never Died,Š— an enjoyably strange horror film directed by Jason Krawczyk. Though perhaps Š—“deadpanŠ— is a poor choice of words, given that Mr. RollinsŠ—Ès character, Jack, seems unable to die.

But when JackŠ—Ès blood supplier runs into trouble with gangsters, his bubble of anonymity is breached, and his comfort zone is further intruded upon when he learns that he has a daughter (Jordan Todosey). The humor in Mr. KrawczykŠ—Ès script is deliciously subtle, as it has to be when your lead character is a man of few words; a viewer might easily spend the first half of the movie not even realizing itŠ—Ès there.
Š—“He Never DiedŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for gore and strong language.

Mr. Deschamps glosses over rougher patches: There is no mention of Mr. RedzepiŠ—Ès split with NomaŠ—Ès co-founder, Claus Meyer, and only light coverage of a norovirus outbreak in 2013 that sickened more than 60 patrons. He also soft-pedals true news, filming in passing a site where the chef hopes to open an urban farm and a new incarnation of Noma. (Those plans, which include closing the restaurant after New YearŠ—Ès Eve in 2016, were announced in September.) Such evasions make Š—“NomaŠ— less a documentary than a glittering souvenir, but itŠ—Ès still a record of a legend.

Directed by Pierre Deschamps, Š—“Noma: My Perfect StormŠ— is a foodieŠ—Ès valentine. Journalists, fellow chefs Š—” including Ferran Adri’¾, his former boss at El Bulli Š—” and even foragers who supply NomaŠ—Ès wild mushrooms and sea urchins attest to Mr. RedzepiŠ—Ès inspirational creativity. Still in his 30s, Mr. Redzepi knows fine diningŠ—Ès star-making machinery is as much curse as blessing. Even so, he is driven to compete; the son of an Albanian immigrant father and a Danish mother, Mr. Redzepi recalls feeling excluded from Danish society while growing up. That he now leads a food movement essential to contemporary Nordic culture is a twist he savors.

In the combat sport of haute cuisine, few recent careers have intrigued as much as that of Ren’© Redzepi, the head chef of Noma, in Copenhagen, which has topped a list of the worldŠ—Ès best restaurants four of the last six years. Mr. Redzepi co-founded Noma first on the principle of resurrecting Nordic cuisine, and then on the idea of Š—“time and placeŠ— Š—” intricately preparing dishes using only local and seasonally appropriate ingredients.

One notable plot point: Hu and Wang had visited the region 20 years earlier as members of the Communist Youth League of China. Bad things happened when the team leader, quoting Mao, ordered the students to yank down statues guarding the area. A major Chinese release that implies misguided Cultural Revolution behavior Š—” if only for spooky thrills Š—” is no Equinox Flower, but itŠ—Ès a rare artifact even today.

Directed by Wuershan (Š—“Painted Skin: The ResurrectionŠ—), Š—“MojinŠ— concerns three former professional treasure hunters, Hu (Chen Kun), Wang (Huang Bo) and Shirley (Shu Qi). Eking out a living on the streets of New York in the late 1980s, they are hired for a subterranean expedition financed by a mysterious businesswoman seeking an ancient burial ground in Mongolia. Why is not clear at first, but it involves a gateway between the living and the dead, zombies that foam at the mouth and a quest for the Equinox Flower.

Adapted from a best-selling series of Chinese fantasy novels, Š—“MojinŠ— wastes some fine actors Š—” Shu Qi plays the lead in Š—“The AssassinŠ— Š—” on predictable, one-dimensional characters, and once the tomb is entered, the underground sets become all but interchangeable. What starts eerie becomes strictly cartoonish.

Chinese cinema has become so reliably engaging that itŠ—Ès a genuine surprise when a clunker shows up on American screens. Š—“Mojin: The Lost LegendŠ— seeks adventure blockbuster status like Š—“Raiders of the Lost Ark,Š— Š—“Lara Croft: Tomb Raider,Š— Š—“The MummyŠ— or other action flicks that spend a lot of time underground. But it gets no traction whatsoever.

Just as notable is the filmŠ—Ès dedication to showing difficult work rather than only speaking of it. ThereŠ—Ès something innately satisfying about watching the herding of cattle and the other physical labors that go into running a farm. Footage of the scenic Virginia countryside also doesnŠ—Èt hurt.
Granted, you donŠ—Èt watch a documentary about sustainable agriculture for Š—“Star WarsŠ—-type thrills. Yet you may still find yourself quietly cheering for the low-key rebels of Š—“Polyfaces.Š—

The film, directed by Lisa Heenan and Isaebella Doherty, focuses on Polyface, a farm in Northern Virginia. There, for decades, the Salatin family has shunned chemical-heavy farming practices in favor of sustainable rotation and grazing methods. Family members also teach those methods to others; their success has led to many devotees and appearances in several documentaries and books.

To be sure, even as the film avoids sermonizing, there are a few too many cutesy shots of happy children and lovely butterflies. More perspective on the hard economics of agriculture would be helpful. Yet, those concerns aside, this tale of an unorthodox farm may have you nodding along to most everything its operators say, and believing that their methods are the best way to help us eat (and live) a whole lot better.

Though we hear a little about the evils of processed foods and industrial agriculture, the filmmakers and their subjects more often take an optimistic tone when describing their hopes and illustrating the changes they seek in the American way of farming. This is no Š—“Food Inc.Š— or Š—“Super Size Me,Š— but instead a story of a determined and environmentally conscious operation.

In the immediate aftermath of World War II, the mass murder of the Jews seemed to many artists and intellectuals to exist beyond the reach of representation. It was something to be handled with the utmost care and gravity. But art, especially popular art, abhors a vacuum, and the Shoah is, among other things, a rich reservoir of stories, true and speculative. There are works of narrative Š—” like Claude LanzmannŠ—Ès Š—“ShoahŠ— or the novels of Patrick Modiano Š—” that try to measure the gulf between past and present and to document the inadequacy of memory. There are others that try to bridge that gap by recreating or retrieving a sense of what actually happened. Š—“SchindlerŠ—Ès ListŠ— remains the best-known Š—” and one of the best examples. And there are some that try to fill the void with fable and fantasy, like Š—“Inglourious BasterdsŠ— and Š—“Life Is Beautiful.Š—

This disorientation is meant to convey immediacy, and to signal an uncompromising vision. Mr. Nemes wants to serve the horror raw, to bring us as close as he possibly can to the machinery of murder, to make cruelty palpable. He subscribes to one of the dubious dogmas of post-World War II aesthetics, namely the idea that the representation of real-life atrocity requires the chastening of artifice, the stripping away of anything that might smack too much of style.

This larger history is kept outside the frame. Shot mostly in extended close-ups (the skilled director of photography is Matyas Erdely), Š—“Son of SaulŠ— moves rapidly and relentlessly in the present tense, never leaving SaulŠ—Ès side. Not that we penetrate his thoughts. Mr. Rohrig, a poet and former teacher appearing in his first film, has the intriguing opacity that distinguishes nonprofessional actors. Like Lamberto Maggiorani in Š—“Bicycle ThievesŠ— or Maria Falconetti in Š—“The Passion of Joan of Arc,Š— he is an indelibly particular, almost spiritually intense, screen presence. His face is hard to read and impossible to forget Š—” a mask of stoicism, anguish, exhaustion and cunning.

Š—“Son of SaulŠ— belongs more in the third category than the second. ItŠ—Ès a beat-the-clock thriller wrapped around an allegory. Saul witnesses the death of a boy who may or may not be his son, and becomes obsessed with giving the body a proper Jewish burial. He scrambles through the camp, a buzzing hive of hideous and mundane routines, in search of a rabbi. He barters and begs, and his quixotic project intersects with desperate plans for rebellion and escape that other prisoners are hatching. Mr. Nemes orchestrates a tour de force of suspense, a swift symphony of collisions, coincidences and reversals that is almost unbearably exciting.

But of course, everything I have said about this movie so far has to do with its formal strategies and visual tactics. To say that Š—“Son of SaulŠ— is a highly stylized, self-conscious and calculating piece of narrative is not to say that itŠ—Ès a bad movie, only that itŠ—Ès a movie. And to say itŠ—Ès a Holocaust movie is not so much to identify its subject matter as to specify its genre. Mr. Nemes may disdain Š—“SchindlerŠ—Ès ListŠ— Š—” as every ambitious European art-film director must Š—” but he is very much in its debt.

Here I should step back a bit, though Mr. Nemes, who favors a hand-held, intimate, in-the-moment shooting style, decidedly does not. The Sonderkommando occupy an especially painful and contested place in the history of the Holocaust. Slave laborers like nearly everyone else in the camps who was not immediately killed, they had the job of shepherding their fellow Jews to their deaths and cleaning up afterward, sorting through clothes, eyeglasses, jewelry and other personal effects and burning the corpses.

The shape of the screen is unusually narrow in Š—“Son of Saul,Š— the 38-year-old Hungarian filmmaker Laszlo NemesŠ—Ès debut feature. Nearly square, it evokes an earlier era, when all movies looked this way, and also emphasizes the claustrophobia of the story and the setting. We are in a Nazi death camp, and really in it, to a degree that few fictional films have had the nerve to attempt. The camera doesnŠ—Èt just survey the barracks and the guard towers, the haggard prisoners and brutal guards. It takes us to the very door of the gas chambers, in the close company of Saul Auslander (Geza Rohrig), a Jewish inmate who is a member of the campŠ—Ès Sonderkommando (special commando) unit.

His skill is undeniable, but also troubling. The movie offers less insight than sensation, an emotional experience that sits too comfortably within the norms of entertainment. This is not entirely the directorŠ—Ès fault. The Holocaust, once forbidden territory, is now safe and familiar ground.

They were rewarded for this service with meager privileges that included improved rations and the postponement of their own inevitable deaths. In Auschwitz-Birkenau, where Š—“Son of SaulŠ— takes place, there was a Sonderkommando uprising in 1944, an event that is echoed in parts of the film. After the war, members of the Sonderkommando were shunned by many other survivors because they had, however involuntarily, participated in the slaughter. Some were executed or otherwise punished for collaborating with the Germans.

Our eyes are trained on Saul, and therefore we donŠ—Èt see much of what he sees. Mr. Nemes uses shallow focus techniques that blur everything not immediately in front of his protagonistŠ—Ès face. Though we find ourselves in close proximity to death, we are also detached from it. Human figures are blurred, movements are indistinct, and horrifying sounds Š—” cries, gasps, footsteps, blows Š—” reach us from invisible sources.

Š—“Son of SaulŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Death everywhere. The film is in Hungarian, German, Yiddish and Polish with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 47 minutes.

The movie just barely avoids being insufferable because of its low-key humor and quick pace. Even so, itŠ—Ès hard enough for whimsy to sustain a five-minute sketch; expecting it to fuel an existential flight of fancy all but ensures a flameout.

Frank Ewington, an elderly patient in a psychiatric ward in Hamburg, Germany, awakens one morning itching to bang out a screenplay, one that has two old lovers of his, Lena and Barbara, meeting on a park bench and learning that, decades earlier, they both had failed relationships with Frank as well as with his nemesis, Viktor. With the help of a magic wand, the women travel back in time, initially to take revenge on the men who done them wrong.

From there, events occur as if hurled from a salad spinner. Matthew O. L. Way, the filmŠ—Ès writer and director, is enamored with the concept of meta, having his characters comment on their stories; he also has different actors play the characters for each time period. The movie touches on some worthy topics Š—” sex, age, ego, desire, reason, insanity, death Š—” but never focuses long on any of them: Some bits are amusing, most are simply tedious. More unfortunate, Mr. Way sticks with a few that quickly sour: an extended interaction with a 1970s-era John Lennon and Yoko Ono, and a film-within-a-film that, as one character notes, sexualizes children.
The worst thing about Š—“The Genital WarriorsŠ— is the title of this would-be absurdist contemplation on the lifelong need for love. The competition was pretty fierce, though.

The free-flowing vignettes, ostensibly seen from the vantage point of a roving spirit, are closer to portraiture than journalism. As in the films of Terrence Malick, a philosophical voice-over (Š—“God, IŠ—Èm wandering across this land. The past. The feeling of peace we once had.Š—) provides a tenuous glue. The viewer shares in the disorientation. Frequently, it is necessary to ask what Š—” and whom Š—” we are looking at, how a scene was constructed and who is doing the filming.

The immersive style is always fascinating. But it also seems uneasily suited to the material. With its gravity-defying camera, Š—“Those Who Feel the Fire BurningŠ— sometimes seems less interested in observation or empathy than in calling attention to the virtuoso behind the lens.

Mr. Knibbe shows poverty, humiliation and addiction. Subjects collect scraps for money or gather by a bonfire. Afghans await fingerprinting as they apply for asylum. Coffins are loaded onto a ship. Mr. Knibbe doesnŠ—Èt shy from underlining misery: At one point, the camera whips away from a Senegalese immigrant to follow a cockroach along a wall and onto a ceiling.

Š—“Those Who Feel the Fire Burning,Š— a nervily abstract vision of refugee life in Europe from Morgan Knibbe, a first-time feature filmmaker, arrives at a moment when Syrian refugees are a major topic in the news.

Yet from the start, as the camera bobs with the waves rocking a boat in a storm, the movie, a sort of experimental documentary, adopts an unusual, visceral perspective. (The sequence, reminiscent of Lucien Castaing-Taylor and V’©r’©na ParavelŠ—Ès superb Š—“Leviathan,Š— ends with a drowning.)

Over the decades, as Š—“Star WarsŠ— grew into an entertainment machine, it took on the aspect of a cult. That, at any rate, is how it could feel to those of us looking at it from the outside in, especially as one mediocre movie after another with noxious creations like Jar Jar Binks crushed the box office. Mr. Abrams may be as worshipful as any Š—“Star WarsŠ— obsessive, but in Š—“The Force AwakensŠ— heŠ—Ès made a movie that goes for old-fashioned escapism even as it presents a futuristic vision of a pluralistic world that his audience already lives in. He hasnŠ—Èt made a film only for true believers; he has made a film for everyone (well, almost). So, will Rey, Finn and Poe save the day? Will they battle Kylo Ren and Oedipus, too? Stay tuned for the next potentially thrilling, or at least pretty good, adventure.

Mr. Abrams became a small-screen name with television shows like Š—“AliasŠ— before making a discouraging transition to film directing with the third, prophetically titled Š—“Mission: Impossible.Š— He scaled down nicely for Š—“Super 8,Š— getting his Spielberg on with a story about some kids who help an alien return home. Even better was his Š—“Star Trek,Š— an enjoyable big-screen gloss on the 1960s series that he followed with a disappointing sequel, taking two steps back. Mr. Abrams is still trying to transcend the worst of the blockbuster imperative, but with Š—“The Force Awakens,Š— he shows that he hasnŠ—Èt stopped learning and that the lessons have begun to pay off. (HeŠ—Ès backed by some of his regular crewmates, notably the cinematographer Dan Mindel and the editors Maryann Brandon and Mary Jo Markey.)

That Finn saves Rey and she saves him in turn isnŠ—Èt a new dynamic; Princess Leia, created in the wake of second-wave feminism, was always a thoroughly liberated woman, whether shooting a laser gun or working a metal bikini. Leia is now a resistance general and played with a muted twinkle and tasteful up-do by Ms. Fisher. Like Mr. Ford, she has become more of a supporting player in a crowded room that also includes Adam Driver, who brings intensity and flowing physical grace to Kylo Ren. Among the strongest creations of Team Abrams, Kylo Ren is a kind of baby Darth Vader who throws tantrums in inky-black robes while wearing a leather-and-metal head appliance that looks like a domination mask by way of the grille of a 1952 Chevy.

ItŠ—Ès no surprise that paternal problems have made a comeback in Š—“The Force Awakens,Š— which folds in a father-and-son schism that evokes the one between Luke and Darth Vader. Even so, the more interesting Oedipal struggle may turn out to be between Mr. Lucas and his cinematic sons, starting with Mr. Abrams. He has delivered a more seamlessly diverting movie than Mr. Lucas has in years, but his most far-reaching accomplishment here is casting Mr. Isaac, Mr. Boyega and Ms. Ridley Š—” a Latino, a black man and a white woman Š—” in this juggernaut series. ItŠ—Ès too early to know how this will play out as the whole thing evolves, but the images of Mr. Boyega and Ms. Ridley each holding a lightsaber are among the most utopian moments in a Hollywood movie this year.

Mr. AbramsŠ—Ès smart idea Š—” an overarching ethos, really Š—” in Š—“The Force AwakensŠ— is to have returned to basics, largely by dispensing with a lot of clutter. This is no small thing in a complicated movie universe in which the series sequence doesnŠ—Èt even align with the release dates: The original 1977 film, for instance, is the fourth in the series and now known as Š—“Star Wars: Episode IV Š—” A New Hope.Š— Š—“The Force AwakensŠ— is the seventh chapter but also the first film in whatŠ—Ès being called a sequel trilogy. This sounds headache-inducing, but it just means that Š—“ForceŠ— picks up years after Š—“Return of the JediŠ— (1983), the third release, left off, after Luke Skywalker (Mark Hamill) prevailed over villainy with his sister, Princess Leia (Carrie Fisher), and their pal Han Solo (Mr. Ford).
Š—“Star Wars: The Force AwakensŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Running time: 2 hours 15 minutes. The Dark Side lives.

You could call Mr. Abrams a love child of Mr. Lucas and Mr. Spielberg, born to the blockbuster world they helped make. At its best, that world taps into the wonder that can come with new visions and realms, sending you into raptures with earthly delights or those in galaxies far away. Too often, though, this world gives privilege to special effects and anonymity over story, character, directorial vision or just a little creative intelligence. Instead, moviemakers bludgeon viewers, numbing them into quiescence with pictorial monotony punctuated by apocalyptic clamor, with the same repetitive story beats, explosions, close shaves and grindingly unsurprising saves. In these pictures, good invariably triumphs over every evil except moviemaking formula.

J. J. Abrams, the director of Š—“The Force Awakens,Š— may not have the makings of a god or an empire builder like George Lucas, but he turns out to be what this stagnant franchise needs: a Š—“Star WarsŠ— superfan and pop culture savant. Given that the fans have been doing much of the heavy lifting for a while, holding up the franchise even as the filmmakers let them down with some titanic clunkers (Š—“Attack of the ClonesŠ— Š—” why, George, why?), it seems fitting that the new film was directed by one of their own. Mr. Abrams was 11 when he saw the original Š—“Star WarsŠ— back in 1977; by the time he was a teenager, he had a gig cleaning Steven SpielbergŠ—Ès old student movies.

The big news about Š—“Star Wars: The Force AwakensŠ— is Š—” spoiler alert Š—” that itŠ—Ès good! Despite the prerelease hype, it wonŠ—Èt save the world, not even Hollywood, but it seamlessly balances cozy favorites Š—” Harrison Ford, ladies and gentlemen Š—” and new kinetic wows, along with some of the niceties that went missing as the series grew into a phenomenon, most crucially a scale and a sensibility that are rooted in the human. It has the usual toy-store-ready gizmos and critters, but it also has appealingly imperfect men and women whose blunders and victories, decency and goofiness remind you that a pop mythology like Š—“Star WarsŠ— needs more than old gods to sustain it.

Written by Mr. Abrams, with Michael Arndt and the Š—“Star WarsŠ— veteran Lawrence Kasdan, Š—“The Force AwakensŠ— takes off with a battle and closes on a meaningful moment of quiet. Mr. Abrams doesnŠ—Èt pile on the mayhem, and, for the most part, the pace remains fast without being overly frantic. In the inaugural skirmish, you can follow Poe Dameron as he darts across the screen; he doesnŠ—Èt get lost among the shadows and editing, a clarity that remains fairly consistent. As for the story, well, itŠ—Ès as simple as ever, with the usual complications and a bestiary of cute, cuddly and loathsome creatures (humanoid and not) with odd names and habits that keep this circus jumping. ItŠ—Ès the old war of all against all, with fur and feathers, snouts and slapstick, and a guest appearance by Oedipus.

Much as in the real world, though, the war has dragged on, and now Luke, Leia and Han have been succeeded by a charismatic, talented trio Š—” played by Oscar Isaac, John Boyega and Daisy Ridley Š—” who look more like the multitudes humankind contains, a genuine diversity infrequently represented in our movies. Yet while these three are variations on the original holy trinity, part of what makes them contemporary isnŠ—Èt just their skin colors but also the slippery playfulness of their roles. Mr. Isaac, as a resistance pilot, Poe Dameron, suggests a next-generation Han, but so does Mr. Boyega as Finn, stormtrooper turned refusenik. The one seemingly unambiguous note is that the new-school Luke Skywalker is a young woman, a desert scavenger named Rey (Ms. Ridley), who shares LukeŠ—Ès skill set and love of natural fabrics.
Š—“45 YearsŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Brutal regret. Running time: 1 hour 35 minutes.

Film is an art that plays tricks with time. A movie is a fixed, finite, relatively short experience Š—” a hundred minutes or so in a given viewerŠ—Ès life Š—” that can span years, even centuries. The phrase Š—“real time,Š— sometimes applied to movies that match their internal and external chronologies, expresses a wish and a delusion. In reality, as on screen, time compresses, expands, doubles back on itself and even, now and then, appears to stop.

The specter of the lost lover brings with her the implication of a wholly different life, a subjunctive, shadow existence in which Kate and Geoff were never together. KatyaŠ—Ès return warps and unravels time itself. It bends and buckles, even as it seems, to everyone watching, to pass in the usual way, marked out in hours and calendar pages.

It isnŠ—Èt hard to supply adventurous pasts for Geoff and Kate, who reminisce fondly about the early days of their relationship. But the past intrudes on them in an unexpected and unnerving way. As they are arranging a big anniversary party, a letter arrives from Switzerland. The body of Katya, a former girlfriend of GeoffŠ—Ès who died in a mountaineering accident while they were traveling together, has been recovered from a glacier, and the authorities believe Geoff is the next of kin.

The last shot of Š—“45 Years,Š— Andrew HaighŠ—Ès sensitive and devastating portrait of a long, happy marriage in sudden crisis, is one such frozen moment. Everything is paused, suspended in curious limbo. A wife Š—” IŠ—Èm treading cautiously to avoid revealing too much Š—” looks at her husband as if seeing him for the first time, as if seized by a sudden and unwelcome new understanding. What will she do with her knowledge? We may think weŠ—Ève reached the end of the story, but maybe this is just the beginning.

Š—“45 YearsŠ— is far from a supernatural melodrama, but Mr. Haigh allows the spookier implications of the story to hover around the edges. Geoff and Kate are rational, practical-minded people. The news about Katya comes into their house like a visitation from another dimension of experience, a reminder of the uncanny, irrational power of memory and desire. Mr. Courtenay, a naturally demonstrative actor, registers a convincing blend of longing, confusion and shame. Ms. Rampling, a stiller, deeper-running pool, conveys emotions so strange and intense that they donŠ—Èt quite have names.

What is he to make of this news? How should Kate, who met Geoff after KatyaŠ—Ès death, react to it? At first, they reach for comforting truisms: It was a long time ago, and decades of steady marital happiness surely outweigh a few months of tragic romance. But before long, Geoff and Kate find themselves haunted in different ways. Geoff falls into a restless funk. He starts smoking again, and digs up keepsakes and photographs that remind him of the beautiful young woman he sometimes calls Š—“my Katya.Š— Kate, whose name is an echo of her predecessorŠ—Ès, wonders how she can be jealous of someone who has been dead for a half-century. That strikes her as completely unreasonable, and yet itŠ—Ès undeniable that Katya, from beyond the grave, is stealing her husband.

Mr. Haigh, who at 42 is a few years shy of his movieŠ—Ès title, shades his picture of the Mercers with subtle nostalgia. Like the couple played by Jim Broadbent and Ruth Sheen in Mike LeighŠ—Ès Š—“Another Year,Š— Geoff and Kate are serene survivors of BritainŠ—Ès postwar transformation, beneficiaries of the collapse of old hierarchies and the expansion of opportunity. Ms. Rampling, 69, and Mr. Courtenay, 78, are themselves both avatars of the Š—È60s, though her star rose a bit later than his. In Š—“Billy LiarŠ— and Š—“The Loneliness of the Long-Distance RunnerŠ— he established himself as one of the eraŠ—Ès great rebels, a wiry, jumpy young man pushing upward and outward against the constraints of class and circumstance.

What, exactly, came before? By the time the final credits appear, in effect stopping the narrative in the middle (which is where all plots really end), it feels as if we have known this couple, Kate and Geoff Mercer, forever. ItŠ—Ès only been about a week (or, in another sense of Š—“really,Š— just an hour and a half or so), but that has been enough to establish the rhythms of daily routine and longstanding intimacy. Kate (Charlotte Rampling) is a retired schoolteacher. Geoff (Tom Courtenay) was a factory manager. They never had children. Their life Š—” walks with their dog in the countryside near their rambling old house; lunches with friends; tea in the afternoon; books at bedtime Š—” is a quiet celebration of hard-won middle-class comforts.

In his previous feature, the wondrous Š—“Weekend,Š— Mr. Haigh showed how a brief sexual encounter between two young men could contain a lifetimeŠ—Ès worth of feeling. After 48 hours together, the lovers had somehow arrived at a complete and perfect knowledge of one another. Š—“45 yearsŠ— points its inquiry into the ways of love in the opposite direction, and suggests that even after decades together, two people can remain perfect strangers.

Mr. Moore, who wrote, directed and produced the film, is his usual screen alter-ego, a glib, blue-collar Everyman lumbering along and playing na’Àve when it helps make his point. There are none of the ambushes of those he sees as high-level villains that he staged in previous documentaries. There may be too much music and newsreel bloat, but Š—“Where to Invade NextŠ— is nevertheless stirring.

In Italy, Mr. Moore interviews a radiant couple; they love their work in a furniture factory, where the employees have more than 30 days of paid vacation every year. Across Italy, mothers have five months of paid maternity leave.

In Slovenia, he discovers that college education is not only free but also available to foreign students (though students pay small registration fees to the colleges). In Germany, the workers in a thriving pencil factory are sent to a spa when they feel overstressed.

As Mr. Moore Š—“invadesŠ— one country and then the next, beginning in Italy and ending in Iceland, you begin to suspect that heaven on earth is anywhere but in America Š—” unless, of course, you belong to the top 1 percent.

Š—“Where to Invade NextŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). The film has strong language, some violent images, drug use and nudity. Running time: 1 hour 59 minutes.

Michael MooreŠ—Ès latest documentary, Š—“Where to Invade Next,Š— is a sprawling, didactic polemic wittily disguised as a European travelogue. Watching it made me feel like a deprived child with my nose pressed against the glass of a magical toy store in a faraway land. On one side is a happy, harmonious land of productive people. On the other is a world of misery, anxiety, war and greed.

As for the future, Mr. Moore points out, enormous positive change often happens suddenly and with little warning. His best example of this is the fall of Communism and the tearing down of the Berlin Wall. Behind despair lurks hope.

His examples of progressive European social institutions are cherry-picked to make American audiences feel envious and guilty. In a running joke he notes that many progressive European ideas and policies originated in the United States.

At the beginning of the film, Mr. Moore fantasizes being summoned for advice by the Joint Chiefs of Staff, whose members, he imagines, are perplexed by AmericaŠ—Ès having lost so many wars since World War II. Oh, what to do? Although he doesnŠ—Èt try to answer that question, the movie strongly implies that funding AmericaŠ—Ès military is starving the country of money that would be better devoted to humanitarian endeavors. With a camera crew in tow, he tours Europe, with a side trip to Tunisia, looking for solutions to our social ills that he can bring back home.

AmericaŠ—Ès original sins, Mr. Moore says, are the genocide of its native population and slavery, tragedies with which, he says, the country is still unable to come to terms. The mass incarceration of African-Americans for petty drug crimes, he suggests, is slavery in a new guise. The movieŠ—Ès most unsettling images are familiar from newscasts: black people, in and out of prison, being savagely abused by white police officers.

In Iceland (population around 320,000), the recent global financial crisis gutted the economy, which quickly recovered with the help of tourism, the mending of the domestic banking system and debt restructuring. The key to the countryŠ—Ès resilience and stability, Mr. Moore concludes, is its strong female leadership, and he goes on to suggest that testosterone drives a patriarchal society to violence and irrational risk-taking. In his view, the world would be peaceful and just if women were in charge.

The filmŠ—Ès premise is only half serious and wildly exaggerated, but there is enough truth in it to make you squirm and consider what went wrong. Every country has problems, many of them very serious. (The film was completed before the migrant crisis in Europe.)

At around this point, Š—“Where to Invade NextŠ— becomes more serious and its critical attitude sharpens. Mr. Moore believes that every country has its own original sin, which in the case of Germany would be the Holocaust. In atonement, along with concerted efforts at remembrance, Germans are continually reminded of the countryŠ—Ès Nazi horrors in monuments, landmarks and public art.

Š—“Where to Invade NextŠ— is really a fairy tale with a moral. As Mr. Moore visits European schools, workplaces, hospitals and prisons, the movie builds into a cri de coeur about AmericaŠ—Ès weakening social contract: the widening inequality gap, the disappearing middle class and a military-based economy. Š—“A land of we,Š— one talking head remarks, has transformed into a Š—“land of me.Š—

The next stop is France, where he visits a public school that serves multicourse, high-quality lunches to its students. Shown images of the typical slop served at a public school in the United States, the students recoil. In Finland, a country whose students are among the worldŠ—Ès best educated, he learns that little to no homework is assigned, standardized testing is a rarity and education is based on learning an array of skills with the emphasis on the growth of the whole person.

Š—“Where to Invade NextŠ— becomes almost giddily optimistic once Mr. Moore visits Norway to investigate that countryŠ—Ès prisons; the maximum sentence is 21 years. Even convicted murderers are housed in the equivalent of small Manhattan studio apartments equipped with televisions and cookware, even sharp utensils. No one is locked in solitary confinement, prisoners have a lot of mobility and the principal punishment is separation from the rest of society.

The ending makes a bold gesture in upholding Mr. Six as an actual mortal rather than an invincible vigilante. It pulls the camera back from his dissatisfied point of view (and is more intriguing than a bit of symbolism involving an ostrich on the loose), but itŠ—Ès a long time coming.

Mr. Six is a grumpy old fixture on his Beijing back street, ready to scold or shoot a withering look. But as we are frequently reminded in the director Guan HuŠ—Ès character study Š—“Mr. Six,Š— he was one bad dude back in the day. That was before the money-obsessed modern age in China gave rise to spoiled rich kids, fancy modified cars and a general lack of decency. All these problems bedevil Mr. Six, whose estranged son is held captive by a wealthy, speed-racing brat named Kris.
Š—“Mr. SixŠ— is not rated. In Mandarin with English subtitles. Running time: 2 hours 17 minutes.

As the rough-hewed Mr. Six, Feng Xiaogang (who is also a director of some of ChinaŠ—Ès biggest blockbusters) carries himself with impeccable stoicism. He exudes moral conscience whether standing up for a beggar against the police or staring down a ridiculous adversary like Kris (the singer Kris Wu, with Olympian bearing and platinum hair).

But the baggy 137-minute story drowns out Mr. FengŠ—Ès assorted sharp moments with hoary family drama and clumsy plotting, and Li Yifeng is generic as Mr. SixŠ—Ès son. ItŠ—Ès also a shame that the movie doesnŠ—Èt develop our heroŠ—Ès girlfriend, the lamentably named Chatterbox (Xu Qing), or his crew of streetwise friends from way back when.

The movie, directed by Sean Anders (Š—“Horrible Bosses 2Š—), from a screenplay he wrote with Brian Burns and John Morris, is a cruel, muscle-flexing fantasy of domination and emasculation. Early on, it is revealed that Brad has been infertile since an accident (shown in flashback) involving an X-ray machine in a dentistŠ—Ès office. Dusty slyly informs him that Sarah would like to have another child, and persuades Brad to see an endocrinologist (Bobby Cannavale), who crudely compares the two dadsŠ—È private parts.

Brad is the flabby, furry, contentedly married executive of a smooth-jazz radio station, whose loving relationship with his two stepchildren comes under siege when their biological father, Dusty (Mark Wahlberg), roars back into their lives on a motorcycle like an avenging superhero. Brad, ignoring the advice of his wife, Sarah (an insipid Linda Cardellini), insists on befriending him.

Š—“DaddyŠ—Ès HomeŠ— is an ugly psychological cockfight posing as a family-friendly comedy. Laugh-free Š—” except for some farcical, life-threatening stunts at the expense of Will FerrellŠ—Ès character, Brad Š—” it is best avoided unless a movie that has the attitude and mind-set of a schoolyard bully happens to be your thing.
Š—“DaddyŠ—Ès HomeŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Crude and suggestive content and some strong language. Running time: 1 hour 35 minutes.

Just as the movie is building toward a face-off, its testosterone suddenly drains, and it expires in a feel-good dance sequence; all is forgiven. Consider Š—“DaddyŠ—Ès HomeŠ— a lump of coal in your Christmas stocking.

Dusty initiates a competition with Brad in which he wins every round, all the while refusing to acknowledge that they are competing. He wows the kids by building a treehouse with an attached skateboarding ramp, which he navigates like a pro. He bribes them with cash and introduces them to sports heroes. Brad remains unflappably good-natured until he canŠ—Èt take it anymore and has an excruciating public meltdown.

The gentle, caring Brad is the kind of second husband women sometimes wed to exorcise the nightmare of having suffered through a marriage to a preening, macho control freak. As Dusty is about to descend on the household, Sarah warns Brad that Dusty is a combination of Jesse James and Mick Jagger. ThatŠ—Ès not meant as a compliment.

Mr. Ferrell gamely tries to give Brad some comedic dimension, but for much of the movie, he wears a stunned, deer-in-the-headlights expression. The humor, such as it is, lies in BradŠ—Ès serial humiliations in front of his family. Mr. Wahlberg, who has little gift for comedy, is a blank. He camouflages DustyŠ—Ès diabolical machinations under a veneer of deadpan affability with no comedic subtext. Whenever possible, Dusty takes his shirt off and flaunts his pumped-up chest.

Š—“ConcussionŠ— charts the diagnosis Dr. Omalu made and the ensuing fight both to force the N.F.L. to publicly acknowledge the truth of his findings and to do something to prevent C.T.E. It also gives Dr. Omalu a blandly tasteful Hollywood makeover. Working from Ms. LaskasŠ—Ès magazine profile, the writer-director Peter Landesman takes the doctorŠ—Ès discovery and turns it into a heroŠ—Ès journey with Bennet forced to trudge past some awfully familiar professional and personal signposts. While some of these milestone moments add detail and shading Š—” namely any scene involving Albert Brooks, who periodically drops by to goose the movie to life as BennetŠ—Ès boss Š—” others are too off-the-shelf generic to be of use, including those with BennetŠ—Ès eventual wife (Gugu Mbatha-Raw).

In the hands of a filmmaker like Michael Mann, who took on Big Tobacco in his 1999 thriller, Š—“The Insider,Š— the clash between industry and humanity would be front and center and very loud. But while Š—“ConcussionŠ— has some fine things going for it, notably science and Will Smith, it lacks the exciting, committed filmmaking that rises to the level of its outrageous topic.

What Dr. Omalu discovered were splotches called tau proteins and a progressive degenerative brain disease. (Misshapen tau proteins are also associated with AlzheimerŠ—Ès disease.) As Jeanne Marie Laskas explains in a sympathetic, no-nonsense 2009 GQ profile of Dr. Omalu, a buildup of tau proteins had done a horrific number on Mr. WebsterŠ—Ès brain. Š—“Tau was kind of like sludge, clogging up the works, killing cells in regions responsible for mood, emotionsŠ— and executive functioning, as Ms. Laskas puts it. Š—“This is why Mike Webster was crazy.Š— Dr. Omalu diagnosed Mr. Webster with chronic traumatic encephalopathy, or C.T.E., three letters that have Š—” through scientific studies, news reports and lawsuits Š—” become inextricably connected with three others: N.F.L.

In familiar Hollywood fashion, Š—“ConcussionŠ— sells a complex issue through an attractive, upstanding Everyman turned hero. A real-world underdog, Bennet Omalu is the Nigerian-American pathologist who, while working in the Allegheny County coronerŠ—Ès office in 2002, performed an autopsy on Mike Webster, a former Pittsburgh Steelers center. Mr. Webster had endured a strange, disturbing slide into the abyss Š—” he had taken to using Super Glue on his rotting teeth and to stunning himself into unconsciousness with a Taser gun to relieve his back pain Š—” that ended when he suddenly dropped dead at 50. Puzzled by this hall of famerŠ—Ès troubling behavior and the seemingly inexplicable cause of his death, Dr. Omalu began studying Mr. WebsterŠ—Ès brain, probing its mysteries for a possible answer.

The greater problem is that the movie never gives Bennet a persuasive antagonist, someone Š—” something Š—” thatŠ—Ès substantive enough for him to push against to create the necessary narrative sparks. Instead, his fight is often waged within his own psyche (he doubts, he prays), against proxies like a sniping morgue co-worker (a fine Mike OŠ—ÈMalley) or merely suggested, as with a mysterious car that glides through like a threat. The N.F.L., meanwhile, remains a vague, largely anonymous presence, represented in one unintentionally comic scene by a gathering of unsmiling, corporate crypt keepers, and later by its new commissioner, Roger Goodell (Luke Wilson, in a flattering bit of casting). Every so often cheering football fans pop into the picture, but they too remain strategically off the hook.

Mr. Smith doesnŠ—Èt look anything like the man he plays (and is roughly a decade older than Dr. Omalu was when he discovered C.T.E.), but he does what every great screen star can do, which is keep you watching despite the material heŠ—Ès working with. Playing with a lilting accent and a narrow range of thoughtful expressions Š—” searching, noble, outraged, wounded Š—” he mounts a quietly effective charm offensive thatŠ—Ès the performance equivalent of a bloodless coup. Surrender is easy; welcome too. The gravitational force of Mr. SmithŠ—Ès persona as well as the periodic moist signal that a good man is being driven to tears are especially crucial because the movieŠ—Ès version of Dr. Omalu turns out to be too pleasant, honorable and seamlessly perfect to generate any tension.
Š—“ConcussionŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Football. Running time: 2 hours 3 minutes.

The sickening crunch of football players crashing against each other, helmet to helmet, echoes through Š—“ConcussionŠ— like an alarm. ThereŠ—Ès another appalling sound here, too, created by the collision of corporate avarice Š—” in the blurred form of the National Football League Š—” and a doctor fighting a righteous fight.

ItŠ—Ès not so easy, of course. And if Š—“JoyŠ— seems to move toward a foreordained conclusion, it zigzags and covers its tracks along the way, sending its heroine on a roller-coaster ride of raised hopes and brutal disappointments and playing tricks with the audienceŠ—Ès expectations. What kind of spark will ignite between Joy and Neil Walker, a big shot in the world of home-shopping cable television? Since heŠ—Ès played by Bradley Cooper, the answer could be anything.

It can be argued that Ms. Lawrence is miscast, that sheŠ—Ès too young, too glamorous, insufficiently dented by lifeŠ—Ès hard knocks. It can also be argued: So what? JoyŠ—Ès Cinderella qualities suit her perfectly, and she has the rare ability to combine radiance with realism. Like some of the great screen goddesses of old Š—” for some reason, Lauren Bacall seems like the best point of comparison Š—” she seems at once impossibly magnetic and completely down to earth, regal and democratic, ordinary and perfect.

The movie struggles to keep up with her. Perfection does not lie within the scope of Mr. RussellŠ—Ès chaotic methods, and Š—“JoyŠ— can wear you out even as it tries to lift you up. The pursuit of happiness is a lot of work.

And Mr. Russell gives this meat-and-potatoes parable of upward mobility, set in the early 1990s, a childrenŠ—Ès-book quality. I donŠ—Èt mean that the story is simplified, but rather that its magical, improbable and cruel elements are heavily underlined, so that Joy feels more like a princess laboring under a terrible spell than like a struggling working-class mother. The trolls, witches and ogres she must beguile and vanquish are, for the most part, her own kin. She is, like a fairy-tale hero or heroine, on a long and complicated quest, relying on spells and charms as well as her innate goodness to deliver her.

But the movie, in all its mess and glory, belongs almost entirely to Ms. Lawrence. She is the kind of movie star who turns everyone else into a character actor. This is not a complaint but an acknowledgment of both her charisma and her generosity. The rest of the cast members have the freedom to be weird, awful and lovable in spite of themselves, to orbit eccentrically around her celestial presence. Mr. De Niro and Ms. Rossellini in particular seem to be having the time of their lives playing parental grotesques who might have wandered out of a Roald Dahl novel.

Just when you begin to wonder where the movie is going Š—” Toward domestic comedy? Second-chance romance? Lurid dysfunction? Š—” Joy has an idea. Sketching with her childrenŠ—Ès crayons, she invents a new kind of mop, the kind that can be wrung out without touching the head. (This household convenience really exists, and the character is very loosely based on its inventor and her career.) Flush with entrepreneurial zeal, Joy borrows money from her fatherŠ—Ès new companion (a supremely haughty Isabella Rossellini), works out the patent and supply-chain issues, and prepares to revolutionize American floor cleaning.
Š—“JoyŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). A lot of messes to clean up. Running time: 2 hours 4 minutes.

On paper, David O. RussellŠ—Ès new film, Š—“Joy,Š— looks perfectly straightforward, even square. ItŠ—Ès a bootstrap-capitalist fable, a tale of adversity overcome and rags exchanged for riches, a case study in success suitable for a self-improvement seminar.

But Mr. Russell likes to tell conventional stories in unconventional ways. In the chapter of his career that began with Š—“The FighterŠ— (2010), he has emerged as something of a genre magician, able to make formulas and clich’©s disappear behind a smoke screen of artful misdirection. Š—“Silver Linings PlaybookŠ— (2012) was an assembly-line romantic comedy tricked out with a wild paint job and a souped-up, custom-built engine. Š—“American HustleŠ— (2013) was a caper movie blown up into a pop opera. Š—“The FighterŠ— itself Š—” the movie Š—“JoyŠ— most resembles Š—” was a boxing picture with an irregular heartbeat and a wildly talented cast.

All of this information is conveyed in Mr. RussellŠ—Ès breathless, breakneck style. The camera never stops moving, the people never shut up, and the resulting buzz is both stimulating and enervating. There are a few bright spots and calm moments in JoyŠ—Ès drab, frenetic life. Her grandmother, Mimi (Diane Ladd), believes in her (and provides benevolent voice-over narration). JoyŠ—Ès ex, Tony (’_dgar Ram’_rez), is actually a pretty nice guy and is able, like Amy AdamsŠ—Ès character in Š—“The Fighter,Š— to be an ally against the familial back stabbers.

Like Micky Ward, the striving pug played by Mark Wahlberg in that movie, Joy Mangano (Jennifer Lawrence) finds herself thwarted and undermined by her own family. In the filmŠ—Ès opening scenes, her various relations nearly erase her altogether, blocking Ms. LawrenceŠ—Ès quiet incandescence with ugliness and noise. The divorced mother of two young children, Joy left college when her parents split up and now contends daily with a small army of needy narcissists. Her mother, Terry (Virginia Madsen), lies in bed all day watching a soap opera (a fake one that Mr. Russell has cast with real-life soap opera stars). Rudy (Robert De Niro), TerryŠ—Ès ex-husband, acts like a helpless child when heŠ—Ès single and like an entitled patriarch when thereŠ—Ès a woman in his life. Joy also has a passive-aggressive sister (Elisabeth Rohm) and an ex-husband of her own, who is living in her basement until his singing career takes off.

Š—“The Hateful EightŠ— takes this revisionist project into a post-bellum West that has always been more mythic than real. Mid-20th-century movie westerns Š—” from old studio oaters to Technicolor pageants to spaghetti-flavored shoot-Š—Èem-ups Š—” typically include Civil War veterans from both the Union and Confederate sides in a state of wary reconciliation. They are preoccupied with railroads, Indians and outlaws, preferring not to speak of the recent unpleasantness. Slavery is almost never mentioned, and on rare occasions when African-American characters appear (like Pompey, John WayneŠ—Ès nearly silent companion in Š—“The Man Who Shot Liberty ValanceŠ—), their stories remain untold.

The movie is a western, a tale of vengeance and double-dealing set in a frontier outpost some time after the Civil War. In spite of the vast screen, the sprawling length and the larger-than-life genre archetypes, itŠ—Ès a curiously small-scale entertainment. After a preliminary stagecoach ride through snow-lashed mountains, the ragged story settles into a confined space, where the main characters (a motley crew of outlaws and bounty hunters) drink coffee, warm themselves by the fire, and talk about this and that until itŠ—Ès time for them to start killing one another.

In Mr. TarantinoŠ—Ès world, hostility and camaraderie are close neighbors. Marquis encounters the friendly, grizzled face of John Ruth (Mr. Russell), a colleague in the business of pursuing miscreants. They have different approaches to the job, in particular the Š—“dead or aliveŠ— part. Marquis prefers the first option, but John, known as the Hangman, believes in delivering his quarry to the proper authorities more or less intact. And so he is in the company of a live prisoner, Daisy Domergue (Jennifer Jason Leigh), who takes an instant dislike to Marquis.

Mr. Tarantino rewrites this tradition by casting Mr. Jackson as Marquis Warren, who wears a blue United States Army majorŠ—Ès uniform and carries with him a personal letter from Abraham Lincoln. Currently employed, like so many Tarantino heroes, as a bounty hunter, Marquis is well aware that neither his service record nor his connection to the martyred president will secure his dignity or protect him from bigotry. Before long, racial epithets and threats of harm are coming his way from all directions.

Unfortunately, it knows just what to do with Ms. LeighŠ—Ès Daisy, who enters the film with a black eye and exits it Š—” well, I guess IŠ—Èd better not reveal much more. Suffice it to say that she is the filmŠ—Ès scapegoat and punching bag and, above all, its excuse for its own imaginative failures. At a certain point, the n-word gives way to the b-word as the dominant hateful epithet, and Š—“The Hateful EightŠ— mutates from an exploration of racial animus into an orgy of elaborately justified misogyny. The final scenes wrap up this shaggy-dog story with a nasty punch line, delivering on the promise of the filmŠ—Ès title. I wonŠ—Èt spoil it. See for yourself.

Quentin Tarantino is a scholar of old movies with a particular antiquarian fetish for the ways they used to be made and consumed. His eighth feature, Š—“The Hateful Eight,Š— was shot on film with antique lenses and is being projected at some theaters in sumptuous, wide-screen 70-millimeter Panavision.

The violence is less a shock tactic than a sorting mechanism, a way of separating the fans from the scolds. Mr. Tarantino has made a career out of forcing critics and cinephiles to choose, knocking the ambivalent off the fence with brilliant barrages of offensive language and mayhem. So maybe IŠ—Èm repeating myself: Š—“The Hateful EightŠ— is a Quentin Tarantino movie. But Mr. Tarantino is also repeating himself, spinning his wheels here in a way he has rarely done before. None of his other films venture so far into tedium or manage to get in their own way so frequently.

The three of them, along with the stagecoach driver (James Parks) and a newly appointed sheriff (Walton Goggins) seek shelter from a blizzard at a saloon known as MinnieŠ—Ès Haberdashery, where they find a further collection of characters, including a retired Confederate commander (Bruce Dern) guilty of massacring black Union soldiers during the war, an itinerant hangman (Mr. Roth) and two fellows of dubious background (Mr. Madsen and Demian Bichir). Does this add up to eight? DonŠ—Èt worry too much about the math. If you read the names that appear on screen just after the overture, youŠ—Èll know to expect even more company.

Some of the filmŠ—Ès ugliness is therefore a sign of integrity, and of relevance. But much of it seems dumb and ill considered, as if Mr. TarantinoŠ—Ès intellectual ambition and his storytelling discipline had failed him at the same time. Marquis Warren is a remarkable character Š—” one of the boldest products of Mr. JacksonŠ—Ès fruitful collaboration with Mr. Tarantino Š—” but the movie canŠ—Èt quite figure out what to do with him.

Mr. Tarantino and his director of photography, the three-time Oscar winner Robert Richardson, revel in the tonal and compositional possibilities of the format. The dense colors and clever shifts in focus hold your attention when the dialogue starts to sputter. There is quite a lot to see and hear. Almost three hours long, Š—“The Hateful EightŠ— has an overture at the beginning Š—” a static title card accompanied by a sinister and swaggering Ennio Morricone score Š—” and an intermission a little past the midpoint.
Š—“The Hateful EightŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). How many times do I have to say that itŠ—Ès a Quentin Tarantino movie? Running time: 2 hours 48 minutes.

The timing and manner of their arrival should remain a surprise. ItŠ—Ès enough to note that Š—“The Hateful EightŠ— is, structurally speaking, an Agatha Christie mystery Š—” with Marquis in the Hercule Poirot role Š—” that ends in geysers of blood. Not only spurting from gunshot wounds, but also vomited from the mouths of poisoning victims.

Š—“Inglourious Basterds,Š— with an audacity that may still be underappreciated, revisited the anti-Nazi Hollywood action dramas and comedies of World War II and pushed them to an outlandish and weirdly effective conclusion, as if the Holocaust could be avenged or undone by a lost platoon of time-traveling movie stars. Š—“Django Unchained,Š— more controversially but no less brazenly, turned both moonlight-and-magnolias Southern sentimentality and he-man revenge-mongering upside down, offering a vision of African-American male empowerment to rival the wildest dreams of blaxploitation. Set in the Deep South before the Civil War, it transformed the prelude to that conflict from a grinding chronicle of resistance and political agitation into a burst of righteous score-settling.

In its blending of verbiage and violence, its deft manipulation of tension, its blurring of the line between slapstick and shock, and its intricate weave of allusions to obscure and canonical films of the past, Š—“Hateful EightŠ— is Š—” whatŠ—Ès the term IŠ—Èm looking for? Š—” a Quentin Tarantino movie. The cast is full of familiar faces from his earlier work: Kurt Russell and Zo’â Bell from Š—“Death Proof,Š— Michael Madsen and Tim Roth from Š—“Reservoir Dogs,Š— and Samuel L. Jackson from just about everything else. The old films that Mr. Tarantino bites off and riffs on now include his own.

Though Š—“Hateful EightŠ— takes place in a hermetic and familiar cinematic universe, it also, like Š—“Inglourious BasterdsŠ— and Š—“Django UnchainedŠ— before it, has more than just the history of cinema on its mind. It shares with those movies an impulse to imagine how the fantasy world of film genres might intersect with the cruelty of real-world history and offer a kind of belated symbolic redress. The winking and filibustering are undertaken with the serious intent of collecting make-believe payback for actual wrongs. This is an ethically tricky, artistically risky undertaking, but in Mr. TarantinoŠ—Ès hands, it is never not interesting.

His provocative rereading of history is overshadowed by a plot that manages to be both cumbersome and flimsy. There is some real heat Š—” some real hate Š—” in the confrontation between Mr. Jackson and Mr. Dern, whose acting rises above the mannered self-consciousness that Mr. TarantinoŠ—Ès writing often calls forth. And the sense that the business of the Civil War remains unfinished produces a current of tension that stretches beyond the walls of MinnieŠ—Ès Haberdashery into the present. Mr. Tarantino doesnŠ—Èt make films that are Š—“about raceŠ— so much as he tries to burrow into the bowels of American racism with his camera and his pen. There is no way to do that and stay clean.

Almost all of Mr. MizoguchiŠ—Ès films from the silent era, and many from the early sound years, are lost, and those that survive have long existed in less than ideally preserved celluloid materials. While contemporary digital restoration can sometimes make decades-old films look like new, sometimes it just cannot. The restoration of Š—“ChrysanthemumŠ— was clearly done with sensitivity and care, and the beauty of Mr. MizoguchiŠ—Ès imagery is almost wholly present. But this is a movie whose age does show, particularly in what might be called a Š—“softnessŠ— in the projected image. The restoration nevertheless speaks to the viewer with new clarity. One can now, for instance, see the matching pattern design of the deerstalker cap and cloak that Kiku wears as he catches the train to Osaka from Tokyo. (Emulations of such Western dress were common during JapanŠ—Ès Meiji era, in which this film is set.)

Š—“ChrysanthemumŠ— is a desperately sad story told with utter and potentially unsettling conviction. The filmŠ—Ès ideology embraces OtokuŠ—Ès sacrifice as necessary; thereŠ—Ès zero irony here, no implied disapproval of the social order that excludes Otoku. But Mr. MizoguchiŠ—Ès artistry and empathy are such that he makes OtokuŠ—Ès ostensibly ennobling pain palpable. Hence, the movieŠ—Ès tragic dimension is formidable.

For this rashness, he is obliged to leave Tokyo and go to Osaka on his own, to work with a new troupe. A year later, Otoku follows. In one of the filmŠ—Ès most moving scenes, she gives Kiku an elaborate dressing table and mirror, which barely fits into their tiny living quarters. And so KikuŠ—Ès artistic redemption begins, even as the coupleŠ—Ès material circumstances dwindle.

The Japanese director Kenji Mizoguchi (1898-1956) was not only a great artist, but he was also an unusually prolific one. By 1939, the year he completed Š—“The Story of the Last Chrysanthemum,Š— a breathtaking melodrama opening in a new restoration Friday, he had over 50 films to his credit. Yet, it was only with his 1936 feature Š—“Osaka ElegyŠ— that, by some accounts, Mr. Mizoguchi felt he had finally found his artistic footing. Š—“Chrysanthemum,Š— set in late 19th-century Japan, tells the story of Kikunosuke (Shotaro Hanayagi), an egotistic Kabuki actor, and Otoku (Kakuko Mori), who sacrifices her own happiness to help him achieve greatness.

While Š—“Osaka ElegyŠ— and Š—“Sisters of the Gion,Š— the two Mizoguchi pictures of this period that have been most widely seen in the West, were relatively brisk features, Š—“Chrysanthemum,Š— at nearly two and a half hours, shows the director working in an expansive mode, one that would flower even more fully with his postwar masterpieces such as Š—“The Life of Oharu,Š— Š—“UgetsuŠ— and Š—“Sansho the Bailiff.Š—

Watching this version, I was struck not just by newly visible detail in the frame itself, but also the spectacularly effective nuances of performance from the entire cast, particularly the leads. Look for the mincing walk Mr. Hanayagi bestows on the callow Kiku as he negotiates the theater and the geisha house early in the story. As for the perfectly pitched small voice that Ms. Mori uses in her heartbreaking final scene, it is impossible not to hear and be moved by it.
Š—“The Story of the Last ChrysanthemumŠ— is not rated. It is in Japanese with English subtitles. Running time: 2 hours 23 minutes.

Otoku, were she a real person, would protest emphatically that for all she gives up over the course of her relationship with the Š—“young masterŠ— Kikunosuke (Š—“KikuŠ— for short), her happiness is in fact realized through her sacrifice. From the beginning of their alliance, she insists that her only desire is to help the arrogant actor, who is portrayed at the storyŠ—Ès outset as a dim, pampered hack more concerned with juggling geishas than learning the family business Š—” his adoptive father heads up a renowned Kabuki troupe.
