Otoku works as a wet nurse for KikuŠ—Ès family, and so itŠ—Ès not her place to even speak to him, let alone offer the withering assessment of his work that hits Kiku like a head-butt. Recognizing Otoku as the only person who will talk to him honestly, Kiku resolves to make her his life coach and his wife.

Š—“ChrysanthemumŠ— is also a dazzling demonstration of a perfectly calibrated cinematic style. The early scenes Š—” in which characters lie to one anotherŠ—Ès faces one moment and reveal their true feelings in the next room just moments later, all within the same shot Š—” feature beautifully fluid camerawork that draws from the formal traditions of Japanese scroll paintings. Later in the film, during a climactic theater performance scene in which Kiku finally gets his thespian mojo working while Otoku hides in the basement and prays for him, Mr. Mizoguchi breaks out of that stylistic mode. Here he uses relatively fast-moving and emphatic cutting, calling to mind, improbable as it may seem, vintage Warner Bros. backstage musical dramas like Š—“42nd Street.Š—

In Š—“The Revenant,Š— a period drama reaching for tragedy, Leonardo DiCaprio plays the mountain man Hugh Glass, a figure straight out of American myth and history. He enters dressed in a greasy, fur-trimmed coat, holding a flintlock rifle while stealing through a forest primeval that Longfellow might have recognized. This, though, is no Arcadia; itŠ—Ès 1823 in the Great Plains, a pitiless testing ground for men thatŠ—Ès littered with the vivid red carcasses of skinned animals, ghastly portents of another slaughter shortly to come. The setting could not be more striking or the men more flinty.

Sometimes, as with Š—“Birdman,Š— Mr. I’±’rrituŠ—Ès last movie, this desire to knock the audience out pays off. Š—“The RevenantŠ— is a more explicitly serious, graver and aspirational effort. Working again with a team that includes the director of photography Emmanuel Lubezki (whose credits include Š—“BirdmanŠ—) and a handful of special-effects companies, Mr. I’±’rritu creates a lush, immersive world that suggests what early-19th-century North America might have looked like once upon an antediluvian time. Yet he complicates the myth of the American Eden Š—” and with it the myth of exceptionalism Š—” by giving Glass an Indian wife and mixed-race son. ItŠ—Ès a strategic move (and another bit of sizzle) that turns a loner into a sympathetic family man. It also softens the story. Instead of another hunter for hire doing his bit to advance the economy one pelt at a time, Glass becomes a sentimentalized figure and finally as much victim as victimizer.

If youŠ—Ère familiar with Mr. I’±’rrituŠ—Ès work, you know paradise is generally short-lived, and here arrows and bullets are soon flying, bodies are falling and the muddy banks of a riverside camp are a gory churn. Glass, part of a commercial fur expedition, escapes with others on a boat and sails into an adventure that takes him through a crucible of suffering Š—” including a near-fatal grizzly attack Š—” that evokes by turns classics of American literature and a Š—“Perils of PaulineŠ—-style silent-film serial. Left for dead by two companions, Glass crawls out of a shallow grave and toward the men who abandoned him. ItŠ—Ès a narrative turn that suggests he, like so many before him, is one of D. H. LawrenceŠ—Ès essential American souls: Š—“hard, isolate, stoic and a killer.Š—

From Davy Crockett to Kit Carson, the mountain man has long had a hold on the American imagination and recently made a revisionist appearance in the form of Katniss Everdeen, the heroine of Š—“The Hunger Games.Š— The mountain men in Š—“The RevenantŠ— are drawn along more traditional and masculine lines, from their bushy beards to the buckskins and bulky furs that at times make them look almost indistinguishable from the animals they kill. Mr. I’±’rritu is entranced by this world, with its glories and miseries, its bison tartare and everyday primitivism, which he scrupulously recreates with detail and sweep. HeŠ—Ès particularly strong whenever Glass, employing that old can-do pragmatism, goes into survivalist mode to cauterize a wound, catch a fish or find shelter.

Š—“The RevenantŠ— is an American foundation story, by turns soaring and overblown. Directed by Alejandro G. I’±’rritu (Š—“Birdman,Š— Š—“BabelŠ—), it features a battalion of very fine, hardworking actors, none more diligently committed than Mr. DiCaprio, and some of the most beautiful natural tableaus youŠ—Ère likely to see in a movie this year. Partly shot in outwardly unspoiled tracts in Canada and Argentina, it has the brilliant, crystalline look that high-definition digital can provide, with natural vistas that seem to go on forever and suggest the seeming limitless bounty that once was. Here, green lichen carpets trees that look tall enough to pierce the heavens. ItŠ—Ès that kind of movie, with that kind of visual splendor Š—” it spurs you to match its industrious poeticism.
Š—“The RevenantŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult companion). Intense, at times graphic violence, including scenes involving animals. Running time: 2 hours 36 minutes.

The movie is partly based on Š—“The Revenant: A Novel of Revenge,Š— a 2002 historical adventure by Michael Punke inspired by the real Hugh Glass. In 1823, Glass signed on with the Rocky Mountain Fur Company for an expedition on the upper Missouri River that almost did him in when Arikara Indians attacked the group and, sometime later, he was mauled by a grizzly sow that may have been protecting her cubs. The bear should have killed Glass. Instead, its failure to do so Š—” along with GlassŠ—Ès frontier skills, some help from strangers and the indestructible romance of the American West Š—” turned him into a mountain man legend and the inspiration for various accounts, including a book-length poem and a 1971 film, Š—“Man in the Wilderness.Š—

The historical Glass was somewhat of a question mark, which makes him a spacious vessel for interpretation. Mr. I’±’rritu, who wrote the script with Mark L. Smith, fills that vessel to near overflowing, specifically by amplifying Glass with a vague, gauzily romantic past life with an unnamed Pawnee wife (Grace Dove) seen in elliptical flashback. By the time the movie opens, the wife is long dead, having been murdered by white troops, and GlassŠ—Ès son, Hawk (Forrest Goodluck), has become his close companion. The sonŠ—Ès name evokes James Fenimore CooperŠ—Ès Hawk-eye (Š—“The Last of the MohicansŠ—), and together Glass and Hawk create an intimate, familial bulwark Š—” and a multicultural father-and-son dyad Š—” in a wilderness teeming with assorted savages.

I thought of that artfully boiling blood while watching Š—“The Revenant,Š— with its butchered animals, muddled ideas, heart-skippingly natural landscapes and moment after moment of visual and narrative sizzle. What makes too many of his moments, ghastly and grand Š—” an arrow piercing a manŠ—Ès throat, the beatific face of a beloved, a man scooping the innards out of a fallen horse, the enveloping softness of the dusk light Š—” isnŠ—Èt the moment itself, but that little something special that he adds to it, whether itŠ—Ès a gurgle of blood in a throat or the perfectly lighted sheen of a hunk of offal. Mr. I’±’rritu isnŠ—Èt content to merely seduce you with ecstatic beauty and annihilating terror; he wants to blow your mind, to amp up your art-house experience with blockbusterlike awesomeness.

But Mr. I’±’rritu blows it when he moves from the material to the mystical and tries to elevate an ugly story into a spiritual one, with repeated images of a spiral and even a flash of homespun magical realism. Worse, he makes Glass not just a helpless witness to a murder thatŠ—Ès a stand-in for the genocide of the Indians, but also a proxy victim of that catastrophe. ItŠ—Ès disappointing in a movie that offers much and that actually points to another foundation story that emerges when one of GlassŠ—Ès companions, Fitzgerald (Tom Hardy), tries and fails to get paid for his labor. He learns too late that the system that turns people and animals into commodities is rigged against men like him. And while the simple facts of that system may be too brutal to feed the ambitions of a movie like Š—“The Revenant,Š— we know that the system nevertheless helped build a nation.

Who exactly the savage is here is never much of an issue; as a sign scrawled in French spells out in one scene, everyone is. Mr. I’±’rritu likes big themes, but he isnŠ—Èt given to subtlety. ThereŠ—Ès a shocker of an image, for instance, in Š—“Amores Perros,Š— his feature debut, which expresses his talent for finding the indelible cinematic shot, the one you canŠ—Èt look away from even when you want to, and also underscores his penchant for overstatement. One of those multi-stranded stories that he helped repopularize (Š—“Babel,Š— etc.), Š—“Amores PerrosŠ— includes a murder capped by the vision of human blood spilled on a hot griddle. This being a big moment as well as an illustration of Mr. I’±’rrituŠ—Ès sensibility, the blood doesnŠ—Èt just splatter, it also sizzles. ItŠ—Ès filmmaking as swagger.

ItŠ—Ès complicated, as are most of Mr. KaufmanŠ—Ès scripts; Š—“AnomalisaŠ— is more narratively and philosophically streamlined. Next up is a pale cloudy sky Š—” itŠ—Ès the most expansive image in the movie as well as the only representation of the natural world Š—” a dreamscape thatŠ—Ès soon pierced by the plane taking Michael to his talk in Cincinnati.

He didnŠ—Èt; he was busy working, including on the play that became Š—“Anomalisa.Š— Like that production, the movie stars an excellent David Thewlis as Michael, an author and motivational speaker who has traveled to Cincinnati to deliver a speech. Š—“AnomalisaŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). A puppet penis in action.

Mr. Kaufman has a co-director this time out, Duke Johnson, whoŠ—Ès a partner in the production company that turned the play into an animation. They make a seamless team. And this isnŠ—Èt the first time that Mr. KaufmanŠ—Ès work has involved puppets. And Ms. Leigh, who brings Lisa to trembling life with soft mewls of feeling, perfectly timed pauses and a poignant a cappella rendition of Š—“Girls Just Want to Have Fun,Š— makes you see how much is at stake both for her and Michael. This is, in other words, the human comedy as brought to you by Charlie Kaufman. HeŠ—Ès best known for his dense, wily, rebuslike screenplays Š—” including Š—“Being John Malkovich,Š— Š—“AdaptationŠ— and Š—“Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless MindŠ— Š—” and least loved for Š—“Synecdoche, New YorkŠ— (2008), the only other feature he directed before Š—“Anomalisa.Š— A delirious, brutally undersung masterwork about a tormented theater director who stars in his own self-devouring production, Š—“SynecdocheŠ— closes with a voice providing the ultimate stage direction: Š—“Die.Š— It seemed like a portentous omen given that Mr. Kaufman subsequently seemed to disappear for the next seven years.

With his sallow complexion, drooping eyes and air of exhaustion (or perhaps exasperation), Michael could be merely another business traveler. Working with the cinematographers Chananun Chotrungroj and Bruce Thierry Cheung, Ms. Demeestere (who previously worked with Mr. Franco on the anthology movie Š—“The Color of TimeŠ—) offers up a slow-paced series of carefully composed, meticulously uncluttered shots. If Walter is the filmŠ—Ès official mouthpiece, Ms. StewartŠ—Ès sullen character, Sophie, one of his students, is its despairing op-ed voice.

Š—“AnesthesiaŠ— opens up to reveal a world of interconnection in the manner of films like Š—“CrashŠ— and Š—“BabelŠ— that in many criticsŠ—È minds has become an irritating pseudo-profound movie clich’©. WouldnŠ—Èt it be better not to be born than to live and suffer? he wonders. Š—“But Eros seduces us into striving for the falsely ethereal, and worse, propagating, and thereby subjecting another generation to the same suffering we endure,Š— he goes on.

Š—“AnesthesiaŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Strong language, sexual content, drug taking and violence. Running time: 1 hour 29 minutes.

ItŠ—Ès heavy stuff delivered in a warm, avuncular tone with a twinkle in his eye. We discover that Walter has a blissful, long marriage to Marcia (Glenn Close), whom he regularly brings hydrangeas from a corner flower shop.

Š—“The world has just become so inhuman,Š— she complains. Š—“EveryoneŠ—Ès plugged in, blindingly inarticulate, obsessed with money, their careers, stupidly arrogantly content. I crave interaction, but you just canŠ—Èt anymore.Š— She goes on to blame herself and declare that, if anything, sheŠ—Ès worse than those she despises.

Š—“Anesthesia,Š— Tim Blake NelsonŠ—Ès exquisitely compressed cri de coeur about the meaning of life in a hyper-connected world, begins as a knife-wielding stranger viciously attacks Walter (Sam Waterston), a wise, kindhearted Columbia University philosophy professor at the door of his apartment building. The circular story immediately backtracks to observe Walter, who is on the verge of retirement after 34 years, addressing a class and posing the same unanswerable questions he has been pondering out loud for more than three decades.

One scene, in which impatient mothers picking up their children after school in fancy cars angrily honk their horns and raise their middle fingers at one another, captures the generalized meanness and incivility that has seeped into modern life. The characters are smart, articulate upper-middle-class New Yorkers seeking relief from pain and frustration and finding it in the usual palliatives. Hovering somewhere between fiction and documentary, Š—“Sweaty BettyŠ— makes unlikely heroes of two young single fathers and a 1,000-pound pig named Ms. Charlotte. Guess which of the three receives a dedicated segment on the local news?

Shakily shot on a hand-held camera in a mostly black, low-income neighborhood on the outskirts of Washington, this first feature by Joseph Frank and Zachary Reed offers a shambling observation of lives rarely seen through a cameraŠ—Ès lens. Š—“The TreasureŠ— is like the work of Samuel BeckettŠ—Ès long-lost Balkan cousin Š—” bleak, stoic and suffused with a flinty, exasperated empathy for its ridiculous characters. Not that the filmŠ—Ès director, Corneliu Porumboiu, has much interest in showy magic or pat moral lessons. His films Š—” Š—“The TreasureŠ— is his fourth feature Š—” take place in the thoroughly disenchanted world of post-Communist Romania, and the attention he pays to that world is measured and meticulous. He favors extended takes, medium- to long-range shots and minimal camera movements. Rather than forcing anything to happen, he is content to wait until dramatic events emerge from the quirks and puzzles of human behavior.

Costi, the Romanian Everyman at the center of Š—“The Treasure,Š— leads a reasonably comfortable if not terribly exciting life. Played by Cuzin Toma, an actor with a melancholy, sensitive face and a gentle manner, Costi has an office job and a tidy, somewhat sterile apartment, where he lives with his wife, Raluca, and their young son, Alin (played by Mr. TomaŠ—Ès real-life wife and son, Cristina and Nicodim). The boy likes to hear fairy tales at bedtime, and his father soon finds himself on an adventure that has all the markings of a modern fable.
Š—“The TreasureŠ— is not rated. It is in Romanian, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 29 minutes.

Well, for one thing, there might not be any treasure. For another, the property might not really belong to Adrian, who might turn out to be such a jerk that he alienates Cornel (Corneliu Cozmei), the guy with the high-tech sonar and imaging machines. There are plenty of other potential problems. Somehow, even the most banal possibilities Š—” an empty hole in the ground, a trove of worthless junk, a find worth fighting over Š—” are weighted with dread and suspense.

In his debut, Š—“12:08 East of BucharestŠ— (2007), a prizewinner at Cannes and one of the essential European films of the past decade, Mr. Porumboiu observed the interactions of a highly undistinguished panel on a provincial television broadcast commemorating the revolution that overthrew the dictatorship of Nicolae Ceausescu. That film is at once a brutal deadpan comedy and a devastating anatomy of the ambiguous legacy of the Eastern European revolutions of 1989. Mr. PorumboiuŠ—Ès next effort, Š—“Police, AdjectiveŠ— (2009), exhibited a similar doubleness, offering both a dry satire of bureaucratic working conditions and a furious critique of the petty authoritarianism that has persisted in Romania long after the disappearance of Communism.

How can everything not go wrong? An almost palpable aura of fatalism hangs over Costi and, especially, the sullen, volatile Adrian, whose promises and equivocations are like bounced verbal checks. ItŠ—Ès hard to tell if heŠ—Ès a con artist or a sucker who has somehow fallen for his own scam, and it may not make a difference. HeŠ—Ès an avatar of bad luck, a reminder of RomaniaŠ—Ès miserable history, not least the ruinous large-scale Ponzi scheme that wiped out much of the countryŠ—Ès meager wealth in the 1990s.

Most immediately, though, Š—“The TreasureŠ— is an absurdist anecdote, a modest story that has the feel of an urban legend. One evening, Costi is visited by one of his neighbors, a jumpy, dour fellow named Adrian, who has a business proposition that sounds like either a plea or a threat. Adrian (played by Adrian Purcarescu, a friend and colleague of Mr. PorumboiuŠ—Ès) is desperate for money and claims to have a surefire way to get hold of some. He believes there is treasure buried under a tree on a country estate that belongs to his family. If Costi can pay to rent the equipment that can locate the loot, Adrian will give him a cut. What could go wrong?
Repeatedly breaking into the action is a faux talk-show reunion of the main players, looking back. It destroys the suspense and seals a sense of the movie as both slick and amateurish.

Set in Singapore and just as densely packed, Ken KwekŠ—Ès debut feature Š—“Unlucky PlazaŠ— bundles loan-shark drama, culture-clash comedy, hostage negotiations and a talk-show framing device. The multicultural milieu lends an initial boost as Mr. KwekŠ—Ès jokes and plot entanglements take potshots at life in Singapore, but all the air seeps out of this attempt at zippy, tabloid-nutty storytelling.

Onassis (Epy Quizon), an immigrant from the Philippines with a failing takeout joint, canŠ—Èt make the rent and mistreats his Chinese employee. A rich motivational speaker, Sky (Adrian Pang), wants to sell a family apartment to pay the Chinese gangster who has taken over his gambling debt. Meanwhile, his bombshell wife, Michelle (Judee Tan), has seduced her feckless pastor, Tong Wen (a woeful Shane Mardjuki), who is also a property manager.

When Michelle and Onassis cross paths in a bar, all the naughty behavior eventually leads to a hostage crisis, instigated by a cleaver-wielding Onassis, at Michelle and SkyŠ—Ès luxury house. Mr. Kwek makes sure that nobody seems mean; even the gangster, Baby Bear (Guo Liang), makes some good points. But not all the actors thrive under this sympathetic and ultimately mawkish approach: Mr. Pang is a neat sketch in hypocrisy, but Ms. TanŠ—Ès calamitous Michelle just never adds up.
Š—“The ForestŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for frights and, of course, its overriding suicide theme.

When specters materialize, the movie can look a little cheesy, like a Halloween haunted house, but Ms. Dormer handles her flirtations with madness adeptly. Is Aiden really an ally, or did he have something to do with JessŠ—Ès disappearance? Is the strange Japanese girl Sara keeps encountering in the woods a phantom or real? The movieŠ—Ès main problem is that the actual story of the Suicide Forest is more unsettling than this fictional one.

It needs to be said at the start that there is something unsavory about using suicide as the underpinning for a horror movie. Anyone who has experienced the suicide of a loved one should stay away from Š—“The Forest,Š— set in the so-called Suicide Forest at the base of Mount Fuji in Japan, where an inordinate number of people go to kill themselves.

Š—“If she were dead, I would know,Š— Sara explains to Aiden (Taylor Kinney of Š—“Chicago FireŠ—), a travel writer she meets when she reaches Japan. He accompanies her into the forest, where spirits lurk, and a person can easily lose both her bearings and her mind.

If you can get past that unpalatable aspect, though, Š—“The Forest,Š— directed by Jason Zada, is a decently executed creeper built around a convincing performance by Natalie Dormer (Š—“Game of ThronesŠ—). She plays identical twins: Jess, who has disappeared in the forest, and Sara, who has traveled to Japan to try to find her.

As well as it does its job, the movieŠ—Ès tone suggests a PBS program. So, too, does its brevity: The film clocks in at a leave-them-wanting-more hour and 12 minutes. Some potential viewers may take this as a cue to wait for Š—“TroublemakersŠ— to turn up on television, but that would be a mistake. The filmŠ—Ès generous views of spectacular works like SmithsonŠ—Ès monumental Š—“Spiral JettyŠ— (the work projects into the Great Salt Lake in Utah) and Mr. HeizerŠ—Ès Š—“Double NegativeŠ— in Nevada (a huge trench bisected by a canyon) are best seen on the largest screen available.

Š—“Earthworks are an older tradition than oil painting, going back 3,000 years,Š— the artist Carl Andre observes late in Š—“Troublemakers: The Story of Land Art,Š— a cogent, brisk, sometimes thrilling documentary written and directed by James Crump. More than a couple of shots of Stonehenge turn up as supporting evidence for that claim. Mr. CrumpŠ—Ès film, though, is mostly concerned with a group of American artists who, in the early 1960s, began not just working with natural materials for their pieces but also went out into the open, sometimes arid, spaces in North America to mold or scar, or both, the land itself.

Mr. Crump does a terrific job of detailing the aesthetic and intellectual motivations of this loose movement: concern for the environment, continuation of the Š—“What is art?Š— inquiries of earlier 20th-century forms and disillusionment with galleries and with the art scene in general. This film provides short but satisfying sketches of intriguing individuals like the artists Robert Smithson, Walter De Maria, Michael Heizer, Charles Ross, Nancy Holt and the arts patron Virginia Dwan. The relative isolation in which these artists worked makes them seem more maverick iconoclasts than actual Š—“troublemakers,Š— but itŠ—Ès not my title to choose.

Lamb Š—” played by the movieŠ—Ès writer and director, Ross Partridge Š—” first meets Tommie (a solid Oona Laurence) when she toddles up to him in a parking lot clutching a pink purse and almost falling off her high heels. SheŠ—Ès a stick figure with a curtain of lank hair, but she has grit, watchful eyes and friends who have dared her to bum a cigarette. For reasons that are never altogether clear, including, apparently, to Lamb, he gives her a smoke and then hustles her into his SUV, insisting that heŠ—Ès teaching her a cautionary lesson. This abduction turns out to be a practice run for the extended snatching that consumes much of the story.

Mr. Partridge, a character actor who looks like he auditions for Dermot Mulroney types, has a relaxed, pleasant presence; what he doesnŠ—Èt have is a grasp on the storyŠ—Ès ugliness, its viewpoints or how his nice-guy vibe is at odds with the self-deluded exploiter he plays. In the novel, Lamb is a fantasist who uses Tommie as a blank (pure) slate on which to write a new life story. Mr. Partridge never figures out how to complicate his version and its voices, or maybe doesnŠ—Èt want to. He softens Lamb and Tommie with tears, safe hugs and averted looks and, once they land in the countryside, mires them in sentimentality. He tries to turn Lamb into a sheep in wolfŠ—Ès clothing, but itŠ—Ès a bad fit.

Š—“LambŠ— is based on a 2011 novel by Bonnie Nadzam that reads like an oblique response to NabokovŠ—Ès Š—“Lolita.Š— What makes it an interesting exercise is the way Ms. Nadzam plays with narrative viewpoint, especially in her use of the limited third person for Lamb, which allows you to see whatŠ—Ès squirming in his head but doesnŠ—Èt force you deep in the cranial muck as Nabokov does with that first-person fabulist Humbert Humbert. Ms. Nadzam shares LambŠ—Ès thinking, but at a distance, as when she writes about how he sees Tommie: Š—“HeŠ—Èd taken her for 13 at least.Š— She further complicates her novel with some speculation (Š—“letŠ—Ès sayŠ—) and through her sly deployment of the wiggly Š—“would,Š— which suggests that LambŠ—Ès thoughts have shifted into the hypothetical.
Š—“LambŠ— is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 36 minutes.

The movie opens with a little leisurely narrative table-setting, including some back story for Lamb and peeks at TommieŠ—Ès generically bleak home life, which is largely illustrated by a scene of two parental zombies (Lindsay Pulsipher and Scoot McNairy) staring at a blaring television. Soon, though, Lamb is sidling up to Tommie and your internal klaxons are sounding, as, for instance, when he says that heŠ—Ès not Š—“corruptingŠ— her. Is Lamb trying to convince Tommie or himself or us? Coyly, Mr. Partridge doesnŠ—Èt say. Instead, even after Lamb takes a willing if wary Tommie on a promised short trip, the movie leaves room for vaguely Š—“innocentŠ— readings that suggest he only wants to rescue her even while it insinuatingly moves them into cozy hotel rooms that signal the worst is guaranteed.

Š—“Lamb,Š— a slow-burning creep-out about a kidnapping, would like you to see it as a requiem for the lost and the loveless. Set in a present that looks like real life but doesnŠ—Èt feel like it, the story pivots on its title sad sack, David Lamb, a habitual dissembler and possible sociopath mired in personal and professional crisis. Death, marital and work woes, a young mistress Š—” Lamb has it all when one day he sweeps away an 11-year-old girl, taking her for, well, what exactly is the question that reverberates queasily through this movie, its hotel rooms and weepy moments.

Directed by Fernando Le’_n de Aranoa, who shares script credit with Diego Farias, Š—“A Perfect DayŠ— is a movie of moments, some quite fine. The most memorable of these have little to do with the aid workers, though, who are soon joined by another beautiful female irritant, Katya (Ms. Kurylenko), Mambr’_Š—Ès combustible ex-lover. The bickering between them is discordant filler, particularly given the miseries Š—” the bullet-pocked buildings, the orphaned, the starving, the desperate and the dead Š—” that surround the aid workers. ThereŠ—Ès another story in Š—“A Perfect Day,Š— one that oozes in between the cracked walls and gallows humor and finally has little to do with this movie.
Š—“A Perfect DayŠ— is rated R (under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Guns and trauma. Running time: 1 hour 46 minutes.

Benicio Del Toro shambling around like a latter-day Robert Mitchum is the best reason to see Š—“A Perfect Day.Š— A serviceable, watchable movie set someplace in the Balkans in 1995, this oddity was shot in Spain and features a tight, largely English-speaking cast Š—” including the American veteran Tim Robbins, and two European actresses, M’©lanie Thierry and Olga Kurylenko Š—” that seems to have been tapped to reach as many film markets as possible. This talent sampler fits the movie, which primarily registers as a would-be business opportunity for investment types.

Mr. Del Toro plays Mambr’_, an international aid worker who tools around the Balkan countryside trying to help locals while also doing his best to stay alive. His primary comrade in battleground salvage jobs is B (Mr. Robbins), a character whose cynical yuks suggest that someone here read Kurt VonnegutŠ—Ès Š—“Slaughterhouse-FiveŠ— at an impressionable age. Mr. Robbins tosses around his lines with amiable lightness, like the professional he is. But heŠ—Ès basically stuck performing second-banana duties for Mr. Del Toro, who dominates the movie with his innate je ne sais quoi-ness, a loose gestural performance and nice slow burns that never quite ignite a much-needed fire.

ThereŠ—Ès not much of a story, which wouldnŠ—Èt be bad if there was something other than blasts of music filling the longueurs. The action, such as it is, involves Mambr’_; B; a humorless new recruit, Sophie (Ms. Thierry); and their interpreter, Damir (Fedja Stukan), driving around doing good works. The corpse that early on they try and fail to haul out of a village well becomes the movieŠ—Ès guiding visual idea, one that the filmmakers return to several times, though the resonance of this bloated body remains fuzzy. The dead weigh heavily on this land? Humanitarian efforts like Mambr’_Š—Ès are doomed to failure? One lesson is that these aid workers need to carry better, stronger rope.

The whimsical crime comedy Š—“Band of RobbersŠ— might be described as a hipsterŠ—Ès answer to the Š—“National TreasureŠ— movies, made for a more sophisticated audience and outfitted with literary credentials. This comic take on Š—“The Adventures of Huckleberry FinnŠ— and Š—“The Adventures of Tom SawyerŠ— is infused with a gleefully absurdist sense of humor while retaining a childlike sense of wonder.

The story, divided into chapters, is narrated by Huck (Kyle Gallner), newly released from prison, who reunites with the eternally boyish Tom. Huck, a brooding loner, is determined to find a job and stay out of trouble. Tom (Adam Nee, who with his brother, Aaron, both directed and wrote the screenplay) is an innocent who nurtures childish dreams about being a hero. HeŠ—Ès pushing 30 but is as enthralled by fantasies of buried riches as he was when he was a boy.

The caper on which they embark, with Huck a reluctant fellow conspirator, and two misfit friends, Joe (Matthew Gray Gubler) and Ben (Hannibal Buress), involves the robbery of a pawnshop inside of which Tom believes is stowed a legendary cache of gold. The funniest scene is a farcical holdup by robbers wearing plastic grocery bags over their heads.

Tom is as eager to break rules as any Apatow bad boy, but they have nothing to do with women and sex. The Twain character Becky Thatcher (Melissa Benoist, a.k.a. CBSŠ—Ès Supergirl on CBS) appears as a wholesome, strait-laced police officer assigned to work with Tom, but the movie doesnŠ—Èt really know what to do with her.

The jaunty tone is established with an epigraph from Š—“Huckleberry FinnŠ—: Š—“Persons attempting to find a motive in this narrative will be prosecuted; persons attempting to find a moral in it will be banished; persons attempting to find a plot in it will be shot.Š—

The carefully scrubbed language is of the sort found in a G-rated Disney film, but larded with self-conscious references to racism and political correctness involving two characters: the Š—“Tom SawyerŠ— villain, Injun Joe (Stephen Lang), and Jorge (Daniel Edward Mora), a persecuted Mexican immigrant. Tom has his own moral code, inspired by the legend of Robin Hood. He would rather be an outlaw in Sherwood Forest for one year than president of the United States for infinity, he declares.
Š—“Band of RobbersŠ— is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 35 minutes.

The story, set in the present, recycles characters and incidents from those Mark Twain classics with an unabashed nostalgia. Tom and Huck are now young adult yokels with the imaginations of 19th-century country boys.

For the Nee brothers, whose first feature was a micro-budgeted comedy, Š—“The Last Romantic,Š— verisimilitude and tonal consistency hardly matter. Š—“Band of RobbersŠ— is a goof that defies logic in its creation of a witty double vision of mid-19th-century and 21st-century Missouri.

There is a connection between then and now. Like the overgrown adolescents in a Judd Apatow movie, Tom and his pals crave adventure, though not of the carnal variety. The screenplay is blessedly free of snickering double entendres.

When the robbery yields only a few dollars, Tom remains undaunted, and Š—“Band of RobbersŠ— turns into a comedic treasure hunt with guns blazing. At a certain point, the charm of a movie that is essentially a loosely connected series of riffs on Twain begins to wear thin, though there may actually be a moral here: One way or another, boys will be boys, even after they grow up.

While the audience debates which is less appealing, Rob SenskaŠ—Ès photography or the charactersŠ—È morals, the actors (including Rory Culkin as a hapless fifth wheel) grit their teeth against a plot bristling with pain and payback. The house joins in, reconfiguring itself at AnnaŠ—Ès commands into a shape-shifting torture chamber. Yet aside from the bashing of an unlucky budgie, the filmŠ—Ès violence Š—” like its trite revelation of AnnaŠ—Ès sleazy family history Š—” leaves us unmoved. Ms. Riesgraf, who at times recalls the young Teri Garr, is gutsy and committed, but not even Meryl Streep could make this hokum credible.

Grafting ideas from the Š—“SawŠ— franchise onto a Š—“Wait Until DarkŠ—-style premise, the writers, T. J. Cimfel and David K. White, work efficiently if unimaginatively to place the recently bereaved Anna (Beth Riesgraf) at the mercy of three would-be burglars. Suspecting hidden cash and an absent owner, these opportunistic goons arrive with quarreling machismo and without much of a plan. This they will regret as Anna, a quavering agoraphobic who has spent the previous decade indoors, has been far from idle.
Š—“Intruders,Š— a distasteful thriller with a bludgeoning sensibility and little common sense, turns a cozy family home into a clockwork house of horrors.
Š—“IntrudersŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Attack by hammer, hairpin and interior design.

A swift slide from cool idea to hot mess, Š—“Intruders,Š— economically directed by Adam Schindler, was filmed in Shreveport, La., and originally titled Š—“Shut In.Š— ThatŠ—Ès one feeling that the viewer should easily appreciate.

His new movie finds him trying something different. ItŠ—Ès based on the book Š—“13 Hours: The Inside Account of What Really Happened in Benghazi,Š— written by Mitchell Zuckoff with security contractors who were working for the Central Intelligence Agency. The book is largely an on-the-ground account from five surviving contractors who were stationed at the C.I.A. base, known as the Annex, near the American diplomatic mission. The movie is unlikely to change the minds of those who subscribe to opposing accounts of the attack, its lead-up, how it went down beginning on Sept. 11, 2012, and the continuing political fallout. Then again, anyone seeking clarity on anything shouldnŠ—Èt look to Mr. Bay; cinematic intelligibility has never been in his wheelhouse.

The very existence of the Global Response Staff is at odds with the pop-culture vision of James Bond-types triumphing one kill and beauty at a time, and itŠ—Ès too bad that the movie doesnŠ—Èt poke around in its shadowy corners. Who knew spies need bodyguards? The movie glides over the organization, but the quick references to LibyaŠ—Ès traumatic past and present (Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi being dragged from his hole and so on), make the case for why the contractors are more or less on babysitting detail. This dovetails with The PostŠ—Ès characterization of modern (human) spy work as Š—“showing up in a Land Cruiser with some [former] Deltas or SEALs, picking up an asset and then dumping him back there when you are through.Š— ItŠ—Ès a touch sexier in Š—“13 Hours,Š— which features intrigue over nice meals before everything goes to hell.

That hell feels interminable, registering as little more than a succession of strung-together, fragmented images of men running and gunning. And while the fight with the Libyans dominates the movie, its significance finally pales next to the battles they wage with the C.I.A. whiners and snobs they guard, particularly the Annex chief known only as Bob (David Costabile). Bob treats the contractors like the help Š—” suggesting that thereŠ—Ès an essential schism between those with white collars and those with blue Š—” which is one of the more interesting underdeveloped ideas, along with nods to the contractorsŠ—È financial struggles back home. But BobŠ—Ès arrogance, his dismissiveness, isnŠ—Èt that of a run-of-the mill bad boss. It is, as Mr. Bay and company hammer away, symptomatic of the deeper problems that emerge one disaster at a time: Jack and his brethren are fighting on two fronts, the one outside the Annex controlled by the Libyan militias and the one inside, which is controlled by the American government.

Mr. Bay likes to go bold and likes to go bonkers, fattening his often-outrageous material with crazed visual strokes and thunderous explosions, helter-skelter angles and scattershot editing. He has moderately scaled back his extreme-cinema approach for Š—“13 Hours,Š— perhaps realizing that its story or the ordeals endured by the C.I.A. security team merit a level of sobriety rather than showboating. Whatever the case, the results are more about the teamŠ—Ès prowess and less about his. Mr. Bay still wants to drop jaws (hence the fiery Mercedes), and he continues to bring that certain Bay obviousness to each scene. Here, though, his excesses are most apparent in the emphasis on the numbingly endless fighting than on the image plane.

Written by Chuck Hogan, Š—“13 HoursŠ— follows the arc of Mr. ZuckoffŠ—Ès book, mixing scene setting with an introduction of Jack Silva (John Krasinski, pumped and cut), a member of the Navy SEALs turned private security muscle who is en route to Benghazi. Once there, he joins a bearded and burly brotherhood that includes Tyrone Woods (James Badge Dale, radiating low-key charisma) and Kris Paronto (Pablo Schreiber), who are also special operations veterans. The real Benghazi contractors were part of a stealthy organization, the Global Response Staff, which, according to a December 2012 Washington Post article, was created by the C.I.A. after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks to provide security for field workers. The contractors were, as The Post put it, Š—“part of a broader expansion of the C.I.A.Š—Ès paramilitary capabilities over the past 10 years.Š—

That the American government is as much the villain in Š—“13 HoursŠ— as the attacking Libyan hordes (only a few are remotely individualized) isnŠ—Èt especially surprising. Mr. Bay likes to wave the Stars and Stripes in his movies, but he prefers his heroes to be rugged individuals, even when they join together as they do here. This doesnŠ—Èt necessarily always make sense, especially for filmmakers, whose work is inherently a collective effort. But Mr. Bay has built a career by proving that coherency Š—” visual, narrative, ideological Š—” need not be a prerequisite for his style of blunt-force cinema, which answers every potential problem with another display of power. In this way, of course, he mirrors the mostly faceless government powers criticized here, which itself makes him very American.

Slipped into Š—“13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi,Š— among the torrential bullets and convulsive mayhem, is a protracted advertisement for a Mercedes-Benz S.U.V. A dramatization of the 2012 attack on the American diplomatic mission in Libya that resulted in the death of four Americans, including Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens, the movie is a pummeling slog Š—” 45 minutes of setup and an eternity of relentless combat. So itŠ—Ès a relief when the director Michael Bay, amid this bleak fusillade, provides a little zigzagging action-movie-style relief. You canŠ—Èt help but admire how well the truck holds up with its wheels aflame, like a 21st-century chariot of fire.
Š—“13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of BenghaziŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult companion). War carnage. Running time: 2 hours 24 minutes.

Those blazing wheels and several nods to Joseph Campbell suggest that there is more going on in Š—“13 HoursŠ— than in the usual Michael Bay conflagration. The king of screen chaos, he is best known for the Š—“TransformersŠ— series, with its battling robots. He makes big, bludgeoning movies stuffed with nonsense, special effects and military fetishism, and while they are ridiculous they can be absurdly entertaining when theyŠ—Ère not boring you out of your mind. A maximalist to the max, he has no interest in artistic niceties like nuance, scale and pacing, but he does know how to blow stuff up. What makes his commitment to mayhem somewhat interesting is that itŠ—Ès never clear if this aesthetic of bombast originates from self-parody, a lack of self-awareness or maybe both.

Of all the creatures in the animal kingdom, it is arguably the polar bear whose real-world behavior differs most starkly from that of its anthropomorphized iterations. Cartoon polar bears are almost unfailingly benign and cute; real-world polar bears will swipe your head off before you can contrive an observation of how surprisingly intimidating they appear. A real-life grizzly you might be able to run from, or successfully play dead for. With a polar bear, youŠ—Èd have to be really, really good at playing dead, I reckon.
Š—“Norm of the NorthŠ— is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). Š—“mild rude humor and action,Š— e.g., lemmings urinating.

Š—“Norm of the North,Š— an almost entirely misbegotten computer-animated film, makes a small concession to the actuality of polar bear existence by showing its titular bear hero to be a hunter, albeit an inept one, of seals. (Early in the film, a killer whale does eat a seal, but it maintains the filmŠ—Ès absence of gore by swallowing it whole.) Directed by Trevor Wall from a screenplay by three other mammals, Š—“NormŠ— aspires to the second-rate smart-aleckyness that characterizes current DreamWorks animated fare but doesnŠ—Èt even get within, um, swiping distance.

Its plotline, involving NormŠ—Ès trek to New York to foil a condos-in-the-Arctic scheme, is inane even by the standards of animated funny animal comedy. Its gag set pieces run the gamut from uninspired to incoherent; Rob Schneider, voicing the title role, is energetic but bland. At various intervals, supposedly cute lemmings join Norm in a dance that he calls Š—“the Arctic Shake.Š—
The title character of Š—“Norm of the NorthŠ— may be a bear, but the movie is a dog. Actually, that assessment is unfair to dogs Š—” real, anthropomorphic and metaphorical.

The coupleŠ—Ès project involves an interview with a veteran of the French Resistance, who holds forth about his own heroism as his wife offers Pierre and Manon homemade cookies Š—” another example of a woman dwelling in a manŠ—Ès shadow. When Pierre starts an affair with Elisabeth, a graduate student he meets at a film archive, the movie seems to be heading into familiar territory. ItŠ—Ès all about him, his desires, his confusion, his cruelty. But Mr. Garrel turns out to be less interested in Pierre, who is a sullen, inert presence on screen, than in the women whose love he inspires and whose feelings he hurts.

This doesnŠ—Èt quite make Š—“In the Shadow of WomenŠ— a feminist movie. Written by Mr. Garrel, Jean-Claude Carri’åre, Caroline Deruas (who is married to Mr. Garrel) and Arlette Langmann, the film has a curiosity about how women deal with a selfish and unreliable man that feels more gallant than empathetic. But Mr. Garrel is always worth attending to when he takes up the rhythms and paradoxes of love, and even though this is a minor entry in his canon of melancholy romances, it is brief, brisk and intermittently affecting.

The reasons have less to do with the story Š—” a nearly anecdotal chronicle of reciprocal betrayal, recrimination and regret Š—” than with the delicacy of the filmmakerŠ—Ès eye and ear. Working with the cinematographer Renato Berta, he moves his camera seductively and chastely through lovely black-and-white wide-screen compositions. As in some of his earlier films, (Š—“JealousyŠ— most recently), his Paris belongs at once to the present and an undefinable age of cinematic romance. Jean-Louis AubertŠ—Ès discreet score does not so much underline the emotion of the characters as annotate it, something the occasional third-person voice-over narration (by the directorŠ—Ès son, the actor Louis Garrel) also accomplishes.

At first, Š—“In the Shadow of Women,Š— Philippe GarrelŠ—Ès slender new drama, invites you to take its title ironically. Manon and Pierre, the married couple at its center, are Parisian bohemians who embrace a traditional asymmetry in their roles. They work together making documentary films, but they are PierreŠ—Ès films. Manon, who earns money serving lunch in a school cafeteria, is proud to subordinate her own ambitions to her husbandŠ—Ès. Š—“ItŠ—Ès not a sacrifice, itŠ—Ès a choice,Š— she tells her skeptical mother.

In the end, though, knowledge Š—” of oneself or another Š—” proves elusive, which is reliably the case in this filmmakerŠ—Ès work. What is missing, though, is a sufficiently vivid sense of enigma, the implication that the people we are observing could ever be more than strangers to us.

And true to its title, Š—“In the Shadow of WomenŠ— throws the handsome, pouty Pierre Š—” played by Stanislas Merhar Š—” into a state of semipermanent eclipse. As Manon, Clotilde Courau is intriguingly open and complicated, a woman whose belief in her own honesty blinds her both to her husbandŠ—Ès lapses and her own capacity for deceit. Lena Paugam, as Elisabeth, has a simpler, smaller role: She is available and needy, but not quite comfortable with her dependence on the scraps of attention Pierre gives her. Mr. Garrel is especially attentive to the womenŠ—Ès faces, as if he could find clues to character in their physiognomy.
Š—“In the Shadow of WomenŠ— is not rated. It is in French, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 13 minutes.

ItŠ—Ès 1969, and Ron Perlman plays Kidman, a C.I.A. troubleshooter with post-traumatic-stress issues from war service, who is sent to England to oversee filming of a sham lunar landing. The idea is that the footage will be used if the actual landing by Neil Armstrong and company goes awry.

Kidman hopes to recruit Stanley Kubrick for the job (a riff on a conspiracy theory that has been around for years), but a case of mistaken identity causes him instead to give the assignment and a suitcase full of cash to Jonny, a down-and-out rock promoter played by Rupert Grint of the Š—“Harry PotterŠ— movies. The misguided Š—“MoonwalkersŠ— invests too much in the comedy potential of things that havenŠ—Èt been funny for a long while. Its plot revolves around the notion Š—” what, again? Š—” that there was a conspiracy to fake the Apollo 11 lunar landing. Š—“MoonwalkersŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Nudity, drug use and gore.
Š—“The BenefactorŠ— is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 32 minutes.

Except for occasional glimpses, Richard Gere has always held his dark side in reserve, the better to embody romantic dreamboats like those in his box-office calling cards Š—“An Officer and a GentlemanŠ— and Š—“Pretty Woman.Š— But that was then. At 66, with a snowy mane and an imperial demeanor, Mr. Gere now exerts the magnetism of a swashbuckling lion in winter.

Franny doesnŠ—Èt make friends; he buys them. When in a jovial mood, he is charming, if overbearing. With the pressure off to play swoon-worthy heartthrobs, he is free to explore the depths of his talent by inhabiting roles like the homeless man in the recent Š—“Time Out of MindŠ— and a creepy megalomaniacal, morphine-addicted philanthropist known as the King of Philadelphia in his new film, Š—“The Benefactor.Š—

The movie begins several years earlier with a fatal accident. At the same instant, the car is smashed by an oncoming vehicle. Bobby and his wife, Mia (Cheryl Hines), are killed. Franny survives, but with serious injuries and a crushing burden of guilt.

The couple leave behind a daughter, Olivia (Dakota Fanning), a.k.a. Poodles, whom Franny adores. When Olivia marries Luke (Theo James), a handsome young doctor, and becomes pregnant, Franny impulsively buys them the magnificent country house in which she grew up. He also insists on paying off LukeŠ—Ès six-figure college loans and makes him a board member of the childrenŠ—Ès hospital he owns. FrannyŠ—Ès courtship of Luke, with its homoerotic subtext, bears an uncomfortably close resemblance to John du PontŠ—Ès patronage of the Olympic wrestler Mark Schultz, played by Channing Tatum in Š—“Foxcatcher.Š— In the most disturbing scene, Franny pressures Luke to take Ecstasy, and they go on a daredevil joy ride. The potential for evil, often tinged with twisted sexual menace, has always lurked in Mr. GereŠ—Ès eyes, which when narrowed can suggest the diabolical mind of torturer. And Mr. Gere milks the subtext of this mentor-prot’©g’© connection for all its worth.

His character, Francis L. Watts, a.k.a. Franny, is a vainglorious manipulator of other people accustomed to getting his way, often by playing God. So long as the camera is studying Franny maniacally bestowing his largess or throwing temper tantrums, Š—“The BenefactorŠ— is mesmerizing. But Mr. GereŠ—Ès flamboyant performance is the sole raison dŠ—È’étre for this melodrama, written and directed by Andrew Renzi. Its other elements are given short shrift.

At its midpoint, Š—“The BenefactorŠ— shifts gears, and a study of a control freak becomes a nightmarish movie about addiction. Unable to refill his prescription for morphine, Franny, in the throes of withdrawal, becomes a desperate, pitiable wreck. The inability of a man as powerful and well connected as Franny to fulfill his craving is implausible, and Š—“The BenefactorŠ— becomes a heavy-handed, crazily histrionic mess.

But that may be an unfair standard. Movies these days are where comedians are paid to play it safe. In half-hour weekly installments Š—” or in a weekend binge Š—” Ice Cube and Mr. Hart might have more room to explore their comic chemistry rather than just cashing in on it.

Mr. Bratt moves through his hackneyed role with resigned good humor. Olivia Munn, serving as third wheel and ostensible romantic interest for Ice Cube, seems a bit more tentative. Ken Jeong, as a nutty nerd mixed up in some bad business, does what he can to make Mr. Hart look calm and dignified. Except, that is, when he makes Mr. Hart eat discarded nachos out of a garbage can.
Š—“Ride Along 2Š— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Gunplay and profanity. Running time: 1 hour 42 minutes.

Š—“Ride Along 2,Š— it may not surprise you to learn, is a lot like Š—“Ride Along,Š— only less so. The buddy-cop action-comedy is a foolproof genre, though itŠ—Ès also one that requires a fool. Mr. RipsteinŠ—Ès hallucinatory, deliberate style is engrossing, and Š—“Bleak StreetŠ— is full of strange, vivid images and scenes, especially when the twins are together, practicing wrestling moves or musing on the demands of their craft. Š—“Bleak Street,Š— Arturo RipsteinŠ—Ès new film, turns a lurid tabloid true-crime story into a somber, surreal, monochromatic dream. The wrestlers, Alejandro and Alberto (Juan Francisco Longoria and Guillermo L’_pez), who are twins, wear the masks favored by Mexican luchadores, never revealing their faces, even to their wives and children. Known professionally as Little Death and Little AK, Alejandro and Alberto take their work seriously and are ferociously loyal to each other and to their mother. They spend the day preparing for a match that will be followed, according to longstanding custom, by a night of paid female companionship.

The filmŠ—Ès enigmas are atmospheric, and somewhat superficial. It solicits the audienceŠ—Ès morbid curiosity rather than gripping our emotions or haunting our dreams. ItŠ—Ès a creepy and beguiling oddity, willfully weird but, at the same time, not quite weird enough.

That is provided by Adela (Patricia Reyes Sp’_ndola) and Dora (Nora Velazquez), whose lives give the filmŠ—Ès title its saddest resonance. Dora lives with her sexually confused husband and their rebellious daughter, while Adela shares a room with her mother, whom she exploits and abuses. The women have money troubles to go with their other frustrations, and plan a simple robbery to make things a little easier.

Mr. Ripstein, a few years older than David Lynch Š—” a North American kindred spirit Š—” started out in the 1960s as a prot’©g’© of the exiled Spanish maestro Luis Bu’±uel, whose socially conscious surrealism is an obvious influence. Š—“Bleak Street,Š— through drawn from recent history, unfolds in a stylized world that recalls old movies and pulp novels. It is populated by masked, pint-size wrestlers and middle-aged prostitutes, by married couples vacillating between resignation and bitterness, by the desperate, the defeated and the determined. Mr. Ripstein follows these sad souls down misty alleys, into bleak motels and cramped bedrooms. The dramatic action unfolds in a single day as a series of vignettes that coalesces into a grim existential joke.

That movie, which opened in New York a few weeks ago, might be described as a perverse folk tale set in the present day. Its dry, wry minimalism will be familiar to devotees of the Romanian New Wave. Mr. Jude, while he shares with his contemporaries an unsentimental interest in human folly and failure, departs from the naturalism that has been their collective signature for the last decade. Shot in richly toned, wide-screen black and white, Š—“Aferim!Š— looks like an elegant exercise in period playacting. But it casts a fierce, revisionist eye on the past, finding the cruelty and prejudice that lie beneath the pageantry.

The systematic destruction of human dignity is painful to witness, but in Š—“Aferim!Š— itŠ—Ès just a fact of life. Mr. Jude has no interest in preaching, or in flattering modern audiences by re-enacting the bygone horrors of the old days. Anti-Roma bigotry and extreme inequality have hardly vanished from Romania, and the political implications of the story ripple far beyond that countryŠ—Ès borders.

A shocking slight, but maybe not all that surprising. Romania, a small country on the fringe of Europe, has a long history of being trampled, disrespected and ignored by the worldŠ—Ès great powers. Why should Hollywood be an exception? Marginality is part of the national identity and very much a theme in the recent flowering of Romanian cinema. Persistent unluckiness, low self-esteem and compensatory pomposity define the comic universe of Š—“The Treasure,Š— Corneliu PorumboiuŠ—Ès most recent film, for instance.

But there is nothing grim or scolding about this movie. Quite the opposite: It is raucous, funny and full of life. Nor does the collision of moral horror and profane humor seem in any way forced, as it might in, letŠ—Ès say, a Quentin Tarantino movie. Constandin, an inexhaustible talker, overflowing with corny wisdom, snippets of poetry and philosophical musings, resembles one of Mr. TarantinoŠ—Ès garrulous bounty hunters. He also seems entirely at home in his milieu, even as he is troubled from time to time by stirrings of compassion or remorse.

Constandin is a gruff, good-humored fellow, who walks with a limp and swaggers toward trouble with the confidence of someone accustomed to winning fights. He can be menacing when his job and circumstances call for it, but he isnŠ—Èt malicious, and he treats Ionita with tough paternal tenderness. He clearly regards himself as a good father and a fair-minded guardian of law and order, proud of his title (Š—“ConstableŠ—) and aware of the responsibility it confers.

Squeezed between the Russian and the Ottoman Empires, this part of the world is a semi-feudal patchwork of villages, monasteries and estates. Danger is everywhere, and what government exists seems to rest on the principle of might makes right. Power and wealth are concentrated in the hands of aristocratic boyars. One of them has dispatched Constandin and Ionita to capture an enslaved Gypsy who has run away after sleeping with the boyarŠ—Ès wife.

But he is also the paid enforcer of a system of racist domination and economic exploitation that is breathtaking in its brutality. Without undue didacticism Š—” but also without euphemism or antiquarian excuse-making Š—” Mr. Jude, drawing in part from contemporary records and writings, exposes how deeply the oppression of the Roma was woven into the 19th-century Balkan social order. Gypsies are routinely referred to as Š—“darkiesŠ— or Š—“crows.Š— (They address Constandin and his employer as Š—“bright lord.Š—) They can be bought, sold, beaten, killed or mutilated according to the whims of anyone in authority. When Constandin and Ionita find Carfin (Cuzin Toma), the slave theyŠ—Ère looking for, they shackle his feet and throw him across the front of ConstandinŠ—Ès saddle.

Mr. Corban, who may be familiar to fans of Romanian film from his work in Mr. PorumboiuŠ—Ès Š—“12:08 East of BucharestŠ— and Cristian MungiuŠ—Ès Š—“4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days,Š— gives an exuberantly soulful performance. He has some of Anthony QuinnŠ—Ès rough charisma, and a touch of the loose, wised-up humor that John Wayne brought to his later westerns.

In another kind of film Š—” maybe the kind more in tune with Oscar-time magical thinking Š—” Constandin might be a hero, a man of conscience awakened by the injustice in which heŠ—Ès implicated. But Mr. Jude loves humanity too much to tell comforting lies about it. His pessimism is somehow the opposite of despair, and while the ringing affirmation of his filmŠ—Ès title is obviously sarcastic, Š—“Aferim!Š— is neither mocking nor mean. As a species, weŠ—Ère pretty awful, but we can also be a lot of fun, and even sometimes decent, compassionate and wise. How can we live with ourselves? The answer, this brilliant movie suggests, is that we canŠ—Èt but somehow we do.

ItŠ—Ès 1835, in the principality of Walachia, a northern region of what is not yet Romania that resembles the territory of a classic western. A lawman named Constandin (Teodor Corban) and his deputy, Ionita (Mihai Comanoiu) Š—” who is also his son Š—” ride through broad mountain valleys and sun-dappled forests on horseback, looking for a fugitive. One of these is a priest whose godly wisdom consists of a hair-raising litany of ethnic and religious hatreds. Š—“Gypsies,Š— he says, are technically human, though as descendants of Ham they are cursed with servitude and backwardness. DonŠ—Èt get him started on Jews.
Š—“Aferim!Š— is not rated. It is in Romanian, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 46 minutes.

Do you need another reason to be mad about the Oscar nominations? Well hereŠ—Ès one, expressed as tradition demands in the form of a hashtag: #WhataboutAferim! Š—“All Mistakes BuriedŠ— opens by following Sonny (Sam Trammell of Š—“True BloodŠ—), a once-respectable businessman now reduced to an addictŠ—Ès existence, on his busy schedule. As adults, however, the demands on that friendship are so brutal and preposterous that AnnaŠ—Ès devotion is never remotely believable. Saddled with a screenplay (by Mark L. Smith) that prioritizes slaughter over sisterhood, the actresses scream and groan in contorted close-up as they morph from victims to killers and back again. In Bruce LeeŠ—Ès unfinished film Š—“Game of Death,Š— there is a classic bout between Lee and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar. Š—“Ip Man 3,Š— the latest installment in a series  starring Donnie Yen as LeeŠ—Ès fabled instructor, offers similar stunt casting, in a fight between Mr. Yen and the former pro boxer Mike Tyson, who plays a gang boss. Despite Mr. YenŠ—Ès impressive physical virtuosity, his stoic, often humorless presence tends to neutralize the emotional temperature. There are diverting moments, in addition to the Tyson brawl. ANDY WEBSTER

Similar disappointments pervade Š—“Ip Man 3,Š— which strives to link three plot threads Š—” the gangŠ—Ès attempt to seize the school that Ip ManŠ—Ès son attends; an illness that strikes Ip ManŠ—Ès wife, Cheung Wing-sing (a wan, fawning Lynn Xiong); and Ip ManŠ—Ès rivalry with another wing chun practitioner (Max Zhang) Š—” but doesnŠ—Èt generate much suspense about the outcome of each.

The ancient setting has the trappings of a mythical tale of two kingdoms, as the pregnant queen of the monster realm flees a civil war into human lands. But from then on, this is really a baby-in-peril caper about her tiny offspring and its two human protectors. In an earlier film, Š—“Bigger, Stronger, Faster*,Š— about steroids, Mr. Bell used his own family as a window onto the subject, and he does so again here, starting off with the death of his brother, a former professional wrestler who had substance abuse problems. If there are patients who have actually been helped by prescription painkillers, anti-psychotics or other legal medications, donŠ—Èt expect to meet them here.

So the film is already on shaky ground when Mr. Bell drops a bombshell about his own relationship with prescription medications. Yes, thereŠ—Ès something terribly wrong in the prescription drug world, but when Mr. Bell reaches his preachy conclusions about AmericansŠ—È reluctance to tolerate pain and take personal responsibility, you just want him to shut up.
Even before a Š—“do as I say, not as I doŠ— twist costs it all credibility, Š—“Prescription ThugsŠ— is a not very good documentary about a very important subject.

The filmmaker, Chris Bell, wants to be seen as a Michael Moore-style provocateur as he examines why Americans take far too many prescription drugs. But he mostly doesnŠ—Èt go much farther than his own backyard and to the doorsteps of people like Gwen Olsen, a former sales representative in the pharmaceutical industry who has already been quite vocal about prescription abuse.

Once Jack sits down across from Thomas, the movie shifts from a portrait of solitude into a progressively violent duel. While Mr. HedlundŠ—Ès performance until that point suggests a man who has retreated inward, Mr. IsaacŠ—Ès jumpy facial expressions instantly feel like an outward assault. ThereŠ—Ès danger here, though what type becomes the question that Mr. Monahan teases for the rest of the movie in between dropping lines from Š—“HamletŠ— and throwing on a clip from Š—“Greed,Š— the famously butchered epic from the Š—“Sunset BoulevardŠ— co-star Erich Von Stroheim. Not really, but it passes the time nicely, working best when Mr. Monahan keeps it vague and off-kilter as his characters roam among the Hollywood ghosts.

Gauging just how much of Š—“MojaveŠ— is about Thomas and his unsettled state of mind is part of the fun in this low-key evisceration (and celebration) of Hollywood and its monsters. Nasty, glib and often spikily funny before a late, unconvincing swerve into sentimentalism, it features a tight crew of very fine actors, including Oscar Isaac as Jack, a stranger who materializes before Thomas like a hallucination. William Monahan, the writer-director of Š—“Mojave,Š— is best known for writing the adaption of Š—“The Departed,Š— the Martin Scorsese puzzler with Matt Damon and Leonardo DiCaprio as doppelg’_ngers working opposite sides of the law. Mr. Monahan likes dangerous doubles.

The dyspeptic amusement Š—“MojaveŠ— opens with a snapshot of Hollywood narcissism at its most unconscious. Thomas (Garrett Hedlund), a Los Angeles demigod with artfully tousled hair and the morals of, well, just wait, is talking into a camera as if for a celebrity interview. Š—“IŠ—Ève been famous one way or another since I was 19,Š— he says, shrugging the words off with the indifference that only years of stardom can bring. From his indolent delivery to his slouch (he canŠ—Èt bother to sit up), he comes off as supremely self-absorbed. ItŠ—Ès all about him.

JackŠ—Ès appearance gives the movie a sustained jolt. Up until that point, Š—“MojaveŠ— has mostly come across as a kind of meandering, heavy-on-atmosphere, light-on-story drift in the vein of Sofia CoppolaŠ—Ès Š—“SomewhereŠ— and its Chateau Marmont anomie. ItŠ—Ès terribly overfamiliar, though Mr. Hedlund makes watching and waiting easy. ThereŠ—Ès a stillness to his beauty that draws you in and just enough warmth to suggest he welcomes the attention. (He played Dean Moriarty in the 2012 film of Š—“On the Road.Š—) His performance here is at once real and unrevealing, characterized by contained gestures and a face that readily becomes a mask. ItŠ—Ès often a guess as to what Thomas is thinking; even his booze-lit blowups donŠ—Èt add much. If anything, they feel almost practiced, as if he were playing at being tortured.

So donŠ—Èt be surprised if, when Jack and Thomas first meet, you flash on Alfred HitchcockŠ—Ès Š—“Strangers on a Train,Š— with its sly, insinuating psychopath and uptight patsy-hero. Mr. Monahan is clearly a fan of that film and other noirs, in particular, Š—“Sunset Boulevard,Š— the ultimate movie industry horror show. Mr. Monahan hasnŠ—Èt made a film thatŠ—Ès anywhere as good, but heŠ—Ès gnawing on similar material, including the self-loathing of the Hollywood hire. (He even slips in a discount version of the waxworks in Š—“Sunset Boulevard,Š— here represented by Mark Wahlberg and Walton Goggins.) In Š—“Sunset Boulevard,Š— the screenwriter-narrator (William Holden) wonders how the nutso silent star Norma Desmond could breathe in her Š—“grim sunset castle,Š— a shrine Š—” mausoleum, really Š—” to herself that sheŠ—Ès stuffed with Norma Desmonds.

ThomasŠ—Ès castle is far more modest than NormaŠ—Ès cobwebbed sarcophagus, and there isnŠ—Èt a chatty corpse floating in his pool, just palm fronds. Even so, ThomasŠ—Ès house is crowded with monuments to himself, from the beautiful woman (Louise Bourgoin as Milly) in his bed to the Oscar-like golden statuette on a shelf. That this statuette is shaped like a skeleton fits the movieŠ—Ès humor and feels like a carefully placed clue, as does the later nod to a company called Norman Films on Sunset Boulevard. Yet while Š—“Sunset BoulevardŠ— is narrated by HoldenŠ—Ès screenwriter after he dies, Thomas appears to have a pulse, though the opening interview, with its jejune braggadocio and world weariness, suggests that something in him Š—” artistic drive, a sense of purpose Š—” has died.

ThomasŠ—Ès behavior indicates as much when, shortly after the movie opens, he heads off into the Mojave Desert for some solitary heavy drinking and inadvisable off-road driving. In one shooting, the gangŠ—Ès leader is killed. The followers who remain make an unstable, combustible mix: One is chronically paranoid, another a sadistic narcissist and the third terminally stupid.

Four swaggering thieves wearing leather masks and toting automatic weapons apparently rob a bank. The details are hard to discern from the visuals, obscured as they are by the blue cloud of smoke spewing from a canister the robbers tossed, but a radio news report provides exposition.

One problem is that the movieŠ—Ès thin digital visual texture and unattractively dingy palette look really bad blown up on the big screen. In some instances, Mr. Gentry and his team have managed to cheat their obviously limited budget, using extreme camera angles and brutalist-type architecture to suggest a dystopian future filled with menace and cement. MANOHLA DARGIS

The writer-director Jacob Gentry obviously loves the genre heŠ—Ès taken on, or at least he loves Š—“Blade Runner,Š— to judge by the shadows, window blinds and synthesizer flourishes ornamenting Š—“Synchronicity.Š— TheyŠ—Ère a mistake. The endearing title characters of Jay DockendorfŠ—Ès film Š—“Naz & MaalikŠ— are 18-year-old best friends who recently became lovers, living in Bedford-Stuyvesant, a Brooklyn neighborhood in the throes of gentrification. Naz (Kerwin Johnson Jr.) and Maalik (Curtiss Cook Jr.) are closeted and Muslim, and especially for Naz, the Islamic taboo against homosexuality weighs heavily.

The film, set on a Friday afternoon, is essentially a dual portrait of the pair and of their neighborhood. At a convenience store, they buy lottery tickets, scented oils and saint prayer cards,which they hawk to pedestrians. The neighborhood is facing rapid development, and the camera lingers on a hideous new high-rise apartment building.

But Š—“Naz & MaalikŠ— isnŠ—Èt as well made and is bedeviled by technical problems that include a musical soundtrack that obscures the dialogue. A rushed, extraneous scene involving the purchase of a halal chicken for the birthday dinner of MaalikŠ—Ès mother seems shoehorned into the movie.

Both Naz and Maalik are subject to mild harassment by these authorities. A plainclothes police officer offers to sell them a gun. Before a prayer meeting at a neighborhood mosque, the imam welcomes any Š—“undercover police or federal agentsŠ— in a tone of cheerful sarcasm.

Both live with observant Muslim families for whom any sex outside of marriage is forbidden. NazŠ—Ès disapproving sister, Cala (Ashleigh Awusie), discovers their secret and teasingly threatens to expose them.

As the lovers wander around Brooklyn, they bicker and make up, idly converse about current events and speculate about the future. Maalik is outgoing and optimistic, and Naz reserved and slightly paranoid. While selling his wares on the street, Naz is picked up by an older man, but seems only dimly aware that a potential sale is really a sexual come-on. The movie has a keen eye for panhandlers and oddballs.

In scenes set on the subway, where they sell candy and peanuts, Š—“Naz & MaalikŠ— recalls Sam FleischnerŠ—Ès 2014 gem, Š—“Stand Clear of the Closing Doors,Š— about an autistic boy who gets lost on the subway on the eve of Hurricane Sandy.
Despite its deficiencies, Š—“Naz & MaalikŠ— feels authentic, and Mr. Johnson and Mr. Cook bring their characters completely alive.

In a production note, the director explains that the movie was inspired by his conversations with a closeted Muslim graduate student from Bed-Stuy. In the aftermath of Sept. 11, that student recalled, undercover agents for the New York City Police Department and the F.B.I. conducted door-to-door interviews with Muslim residents, infiltrated mosques and pressured civilians accused of petty crimes to become informants.

The film, while observing the surveillance the young men endure, doesnŠ—Èt make more of it than they do themselves. It is a continual annoyance they have learned to live with, although, in Naz, you sense a rising outrage. The most insistent thorn in their sides is an officious F.B.I. agent (Annie Grier). Because Naz is afraid, he lies to her about his whereabouts on a night he spent with Maalik. She warns him that lying to an F.B.I. agent is a federal crime.

When the supporting player Christopher MacDonald asks Mr. Reeves, Š—“You ever seen one of those ant farms?Š— with precisely the intonation Peter Graves used to inquire about Š—“gladiator moviesŠ— in Š—“Airplane!,Š— my own interest in viewing a directorŠ—Ès cut plummeted even further. GLENN KENNY

Š—“Dirty GrandpaŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Torrents of profanity, with graphic nudity and drugs.
Dan MazerŠ—Ès crude, mindless Š—“Dirty GrandpaŠ— is like watching a friendŠ—Ès mediocre improv troupe do an extended spring-break sketch. And your friend just happens to be Robert De Niro.

Mr. De Niro plays Dick, the horny, foul-mouthed grandfather of a corporate lawyer, Jason (Zac Efron), who is about to be married. Š—“Whatever it might look like on the outside,Š— the father tells her, Š—“our son is here. He is very much with us.Š—

What we didnŠ—Èt know was which A-list actor would be recruited to provide the voice of this father. What star could the producers get who would match the other household names Š—” Dustin Hoffman, Angelina Jolie, Lucy Liu and more Š—” routinely attracted by this franchise?

Simmons with particular menace), and he has been collecting the chi, or vital life force, of all of ChinaŠ—Ès kung fu masters, imprisoning them on his belt like so many charms on a bracelet.

Š—“The Finest HoursŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). It has intense sequences of peril. Running time: 1 hour 57 minutes.
While watching Š—“The Finest Hours,Š— I thought of a less stuffy alternate title, Š—“Ride the Wild Surf.Š— That, of course, is already taken.

Unlike todayŠ—Ès space adventures, Š—“The Finest HoursŠ— doesnŠ—Èt flaunt the kind of computer-generated effects that turn so many would-be blockbusters into cheesy-looking cartoons.
