The waterlogged disaster movie Š—“The Finest HoursŠ— is a moderately gripping whoosh of nostalgia that shamelessly recycles the Š—È50s clich’© of the squeaky-clean all-American hero. In this Disney movie, adapted from a book by Michael J. Tougias and Casey Sherman and based on real events in February 1952, Bernie Webber (Chris Pine), a Coast Guard sailor based in Chatham, Mass., leads a next-to-impossible rescue mission during the most fearsome norŠ—Èeaster this side of Š—“The Perfect Storm.Š—

Š—“The Finest HoursŠ— never departs from a tried-and-true formula, but thatŠ—Ès one of its quaint charms. Although set in the 1950s, itŠ—Ès really an old-fashioned World War II film and a paean to the Š—“greatest generation.Š— Instead of Nazis, the villain everyone can hiss at is nature on the rampage.

Still, there is a haunting dimension to the film that is only obliquely related to the particulars of its setting. Mr. Gitai conducts an inquiry of the consequences of political extremism, a case study of how inflammatory language can sow the seeds of violence. Š—“RabinŠ— shows a democratically elected leader not merely criticized and disrespected but demonized, depicted as a dictator and a monster, a traitor, an alien and an enemy of his people. The kind of rhetoric aimed at Rabin, including from the floor of the Israeli Parliament and from members of the opposition party, will hardly sound unfamiliar to American ears. We have been lucky so far. But it would be a mistake to view this troubled, troubling movie simply as an inquest. ItŠ—Ès also a warning.

We are in the hushed chambers where the commission of inquiry struggles to assess a violent and unprecedented episode with sobriety and rationality; in the interrogation room where a detective questions the suspect; in meetings where rabbis find warrant in Jewish law for taking the life of a Jew who brings harm to his own kind.

No one, therefore, is likely to be satisfied with it. Anyone with a stake in Israeli politics is sure to find grounds for quarrel, while those approaching from the outside may find some of the filmŠ—Ès silences as troubling as its speeches. The Palestinians, to the extent that they are mentioned, function as an abstraction, as if the polarization of Israeli politics didnŠ—Èt concern them at all. And while itŠ—Ès true that RabinŠ—Ès killing exposed and deepened a schism within Zionism, itŠ—Ès also true that Zionism exists in a larger political context. Acknowledging this would not have made Š—“Rabin, the Last DayŠ— less upsetting but might have relieved some of the claustrophobia.

Mr. PeresŠ—Ès reminiscences give way to footage of the murder itself Š—” harrowing, blurry images that at once bring the event into the present and remind viewers that it belonged to a bygone, pre-smartphone era. Then, our attention shuttles back and forth in time as episodes before and after the attack are recreated by actors.

Š—“RabinŠ— is not merely an expression of political pessimism, though it certainly is that. In movie terms, it is radically negative, undermining any of the genre categories that might make sense of it. ItŠ—Ès a political thriller with an almost infinite tolerance for tedium, a detective story with an obvious culprit, a courtroom procedural caught up in irrelevant details. ItŠ—Ès a profoundly frustrating movie, which is to say that itŠ—Ès an authentic expression of profound frustration.

A somewhat ungainly blend of documentary and historical re-enactments, Š—“RabinŠ— begins with an interview with Shimon Peres, the former Israeli prime minister and president and RabinŠ—Ès longtime partner and rival in the leadership of the Labor Party. Mr. Peres recalls the polarized, poisonous atmosphere of 1995, as the Israeli right mobilized against the Oslo accords and RabinŠ—Ès negotiations with Yasser ArafatŠ—Ès Palestine Liberation Organization. Posters depicting Rabin in a Nazi uniform were set on fire at rallies. He was heckled in the Knesset, IsraelŠ—Ès Parliament, and spat at in public.

Š—“Rabin, the Last DayŠ— is not interesting in spite of its flaws as a film. ItŠ—Ès interesting because of them, because of Mr. GitaiŠ—Ès refusal or inability to clarify or even coherently narrate the history he addresses. Hebrewless readers can find an illuminating version of the story in Š—“Killing a King,Š— Dan EphronŠ—Ès admirably concise and meticulously reported recent book. But Mr. Gitai is not a journalist. In some of his earlier films, he has burrowed into painful, ambiguous episodes. Š—“Kedma,Š— about the 1948 War of Independence, and Š—“Kippur,Š— about the 1973 Yom Kippur War (in which he fought) are difficult, stubbornly antiheroic war stories.
Š—“Rabin, the Last DayŠ— is not rated. It is in Hebrew, with English subtitles. Running time: 2 hours 33 minutes.

How did it happen? Two decades later, the question is still raw, and Mr. Gitai, for many years one of the most praised and prominent Israeli filmmakers, poses it with undiminished anguish. While the earnest bureaucrats of the commission question police officers and limousine drivers, a world of religious and ideological zeal is explored that exists at once in plain sight and beyond the reach of their inquiries.

None of the people in these scenes are identified. Some of them may be well known to Israeli viewers, but even so, the effect Š—” and perhaps the intention Š—” is to disorient the audience and strip away the literalism of historical dramatizations. Apart from archival news clips and retrospective interviews with Mr. Peres and Mr. RabinŠ—Ès wife, Leah, Š—“Rabin, the Last DayŠ— often feels more like theater than cinema. It is a series of speeches and depositions, a whirlwind of discourse surrounding a terrible and confounding act of violence.

According to the report, the Š—“Commission was not appointed to investigate the circumstances and causes that led to the creation of the social and political culture of which the murder was an expression,Š— and its findings did not Š—“mitigate the need for in-depth soul-searching in Israeli society.Š— Amos GitaiŠ—Ès new film, Š—“Rabin, the Last Day,Š— is part of that soul-searching. Arriving 20 years after the assassination, it tries both to delve into those incendiary Š—“circumstances and causesŠ— and to measure, at least implicitly, the lingering effects of RabinŠ—Ès death.

On Nov. 4, 1995, after addressing a large peace rally in a Tel Aviv square, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel was assassinated by a law student named Yigal Amir. In March of the following year, an official commission of inquiry, headed by the president of the Israeli Supreme Court, documented lapses in security on the night of the killing and intelligence failures in the months before.

A psychologist lectures a room full of right-wing activists on the Š—“schizoidŠ— tendencies that Rabin supposedly shares with Hitler. Several rabbis pronounce anathema on the prime minister. Settlers on the West Bank fight with the soldiers who have come to evict them. Benjamin Netanyahu, RabinŠ—Ès opponent and now IsraelŠ—Ès prime minister, appears before angry crowds, encouraging their rage and seeking to turn it to political advantage. The last shot of the film in effect identifies him as the ultimate beneficiary of the assassination.

What they Š—” or the men playing them Š—” really need to learn to do is act. Instead, the director, Matt Hullum, allows them to just clown around. Pair that with the wan, juvenile script and you have a movie that only those who invested in it Š—” itŠ—Ès crowd-funded Š—” could love.
Š—“Lazer TeamŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for the usual sexual references and strong language.
Š—“Lazer TeamŠ— ends by setting itself up for a sequel, but thatŠ—Ès mighty wishful thinking. ThereŠ—Ès not a big demand for laugh-free comedies.

The film focuses on four small-town idiots in Texas, who accidentally end up possessing a top-secret suit of high-tech armor that is EarthŠ—Ès best defense against a pending invasion from outer space. Toph, a man-child D.J. and pot dealer with a pregnant girlfriend, turns giddy when his overly serious big-city-lawyer brother, Cooper, returns to their small hometown to attend their motherŠ—Ès wedding. Their father is dead, and over the years the siblings have drifted apart.

After the ceremony, this perfectly mismatched pair sets out on the expected road trip, venturing deep into the forest to check on their old cabin. There they become stranded and begin a trek on foot to reach civilization. Along the hike they crack wise, make confessions and wax pseudo-philosophic.

There are three good laughs in Š—“Mountain MenŠ— and two modestly dramatic sections. That averages out to a decent moment every 18 minutes. While it may seem unfair to judge a movie using a calculation, itŠ—Ès appropriate for a script that repeatedly falls back on formulas.

The comedy takes a solemn turn when one brother is injured, leading the other to deliver the stock lines like Š—“IŠ—Èm not leaving you here!Š— (even though the logical decision would be to keep the immobile man in the safe cabin theyŠ—Èd found, while the other goes for help).

Tyler Labine, as Toph, and Chace Crawford, as Cooper, have little to work with in the director Cameron LabineŠ—Ès often-implausible script, and they recline to the occasion. (The Labines are real-life brothers.) Still, Catherine LutesŠ—Ès camera catches magnificent views of Revelstoke, British Columbia, that are worth watching as you wait 18 minutes for the next semi-interesting scene.

The filmŠ—Ès opening titles say these constitute Mr. ChomskyŠ—Ès Š—“final long-form documentary interviews,Š— but this well-paced and cogent seminar spotlights a man who, now 87, seems at the height of his intellectual powers. Still, the film, directed by Peter Hutchison, Kelly Nyks and Jared P. Scott, is called Š—“RequiemŠ— for a reason: Mr. Chomsky concludes that Š—“thereŠ—Ès a lot that can be done if people organize, struggle for their rights as theyŠ—Ève done in the past.Š— You get the feeling, though, that, given all the challenges he lists, Mr. Chomsky no longer quite believes that.

Š—“Requiem for the American DreamŠ— is a timely 75-minute teach-in by Noam Chomsky, the M.I.T. linguistics professor who has been a leading leftist political analyst, critic and writer for six decades. Mr. Chomsky, already the subject of several documentaries, focuses here on an election-season theme: financial inequality in America and what he calls its corrosive effect on democracy. Assembling Š—“10 Principles of Concentration of Wealth and Power,Š— he lays out rules like Š—“Run the Regulators,Š— Š—“Marginalize the PopulationŠ— and Š—“Manufacture Consent.Š—

None of these perspectives are new to, say, the Bernie Sanders campaign staff (though they might be startled by Mr. ChomskyŠ—Ès opinion that Mr. Sanders Š—“doesnŠ—Èt have much of a chanceŠ— to win). But citing Aristotle, Adam Smith and James Madison, among others, he melds history, philosophy and ideology into a sobering vision of a society in an accelerating decline. He never raises his voice in this easy-listening jeremiad. Š—“ThereŠ—Ès nothing surprising about this,Š— he repeats gently in describing what he sees as a 40-year trend of government bent to the will of the superrich at the expense of everyone else. Š—“ThatŠ—Ès what happens when you put power in the hands of a narrow sector.Š—

Š—“Jane Got a Gun,Š— a western directed by Gavin OŠ—ÈConnor, is a prime example of what French critics used to call a Š—“film maudit,Š— or cursed film. The production, started in early 2013, was thrown into disarray when its original director, the visionary Lynne Ramsay, left mere days into shooting. At least two key cast and crew members followed her. In addition, the movieŠ—Ès original distributor, Relativity Media, lost the rights to the picture in a bankruptcy proceeding. The final film was released by the Weinstein Company, without screenings for reviewers.

Whatever feminist angle the film might have once aspired to is lost in its listless shuffle. ItŠ—Ès probably no coincidence, then, that the viewer canŠ—Èt tell whether the movieŠ—Ès reluctance to serve up a rousing climax is the result of poor planning, or some kind of declaration of principles.

Under such circumstances one hopes for, if not a lost masterpiece, then something quirky and entertaining. The tale of a frontier wife, Jane (Natalie Portman), in the New Mexico Territory, enlisting a former lover (Joel Edgerton) to defend home and hearth after her husband has been laid low did not seem to be an unreasonable scenario. I was hoping for something along the lines of a gender-reversed Š—“Shane,Š— with Noah Emmerich (he plays the husband) in the Jean Arthur role. No such luck.
Š—“Jane Got a GunŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for violence and some language. Running time: 1 hour 38 minutes.

Instead, Mr. OŠ—ÈConnor presides over a somber slog, full of gorgeous vistas nicely captured by the cinematographer Mandy Walker. The strife-filled story isnŠ—Èt made more engaging through a lumbering structure made up of flashbacks. Ewan McGregorŠ—Ès villain, leader of a gang called the Bishop Boys, sports jet-black-dyed hair and a nearly twirlable matching mustache, while his cohort has sufficient face tattoos and scarification marks that I began thinking of them as the Bushwick Boys.

The more resonant lines comment on politics, both presidential and racial: In a bar, Christian asks Hannah, Š—“Are you drunk like Donald Trump-running-for-president drunk?Š— When Hannah is Tased by ChristianŠ—Ès mother (Jane Seymour), he snaps, Š—“How many times do I have to tell you: Black lives matter!Š—

Mr. Wayans, who skewered horror flicks with the Š—“Haunted HouseŠ— and Š—“Scary MovieŠ— series, has found another ripe subject for pillorying. (At least two stage parodies got to Š—“Fifty Shades,Š— the novel, first.) But as with other staples of the screen-parody genre, the comic bullŠ—Ès-eyes arrive only intermittently.

Š—“Fifty shades of terrible!Š— says Christian Black (Marlon Wayans), as he reads E. L. JamesŠ—Ès erotic best seller Š—“Fifty Shades of Grey.Š— Š—“Who wrote this, a third grader?Š— Other trenchant observations pepper Š—“Fifty Shades of Black,Š— a scattershot satire of the bookŠ—Ès 2015 screen adaptation, but a lot of wading is required to find them.
Š—“Fifty Shades of BlackŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for sexual situations. Running time: 1 hour 32 minutes.

Š—“BlackŠ— parallels the outline of Š—“GreyŠ— Š—” here, the millionaire, Christian, tries to coax the college student, Hannah (the appealing Kali Hawk), into signing a contract for kinky sex Š—” but only as much as it permits Mr. Wayans to riff on pop ephemera. Fortunately, Mr. Wayans (who wrote the script with Rick Alvarez; Michael Tiddes of Š—“A Haunted HouseŠ— directed) has dependable support from Jenny Zigrino as HannahŠ—Ès lascivious roommate and Florence Henderson Š—” you read that right Š—” as an older seductress.

Predictably, there are jokes about over- and under-endowments, body hair (Š—“ThatŠ—Ès very sasquatch of youŠ—) and premature ejaculation. An amusing sight gag has Christian announcing, Š—“LetŠ—Ès break the Internet!Š— as he caricatures Paper magazineŠ—Ès photo renderings  of Kim Kardashian by Jean-Paul Goude.
In the end, Christian Š—” whom Hannah at one point calls Š—“a sicko who likes abusing womenŠ— Š—” is given his comeuppance. With a sex toy, of course.

But AdiŠ—Ès love is purely for the game: He sees a fighter like himself Š—” a rebel with a temper Š—” and takes her on. (AdiŠ—Ès temper got him into trouble with the villainous head of the womenŠ—Ès boxing association.)

Naturally, the path isnŠ—Èt smooth: In her way is a corrupt system that runs on cronyism and sexual favors. No wonder Madhi is suspicious of Adi (R. Madhavan), the coach she comes to call Master, when he spots her brawling and decides to make her a star. The director, Sudha Kongara, plays this up as a boy-meets-girl moment: Adi peeks over his Ray-Bans to take in the spectacle that is Madhi, a wild girl who needs taming.

In the Indian movie Š—“Saala Khadoos,Š— the twist is that the boxer is a woman, Madhi (Ritika Singh), and that her fists, rather than more traditional female allures, are what can lift her out of the slums of Chennai.
Š—“Saala KhadoosŠ— is not rated. It is in Hindi, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 50 minutes.

Š—“SaalaŠ— has an appropriately grimy B-movie look that doesnŠ—Èt try to make the city spick-and-span. MadhiŠ—Ès neighborhood is convincingly poor, and Ms. KongaraŠ—Ès movie voices a populist sentiment heard in other Indian sports films: ItŠ—Ès from these streets that a champion will rise, weŠ—Ère told. And so Madhi does.
You know the story or one like it: Underdog boxer from the mean streets is taken up by a coach, himself in need of redemption. Together, this scruffy pair hope to make it to the big championship.

As Madhi, Ms. Singh, a newcomer, fares less well. She has a rawness that dovetails with the role, but she doesnŠ—Èt know how to show us MadhiŠ—Ès interior life as she goes from fishmonger to contender. That leaves the movie with a hole at its center and a question thatŠ—Ès never satisfactorily answered. What does Madhi really want?
Ms. Kongara seems to know the clich’©s of fighter movies and is mostly unembarrassed to embrace them. That keeps the film humming along, as does Mr. Madhavan, who grows in stature along with Adi.

Mr. HakonarsonŠ—Ès patient attention to the brothersŠ—È daily routines yields some low-key humor, and Š—“RamsŠ— is in some respects a familiar kind of Nordic comedy, deadpan and touched with melancholy, about stoical men with unusual jobs. There are simple, satisfying sight gags built around the clumsiness of farm machinery, the absurdity of sheep and the indignities of advancing age and cold weather. But despite its affection for the quirks of its characters and their milieu, the film is most memorable for its gravity, for the almost tragic nobility it finds in sad and silly circumstances.
Š—“RamsŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Lambs to the slaughter. In Icelandic, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 33 minutes.

As the crisis deepens, and as Gummi devises a devious, illegal response to it Š—” one that will also settle scores once and for all with his brother Š—” the film takes on a stark, elemental power. The landscape of snow and volcanic rock threatens to overwhelm the creatures that call it home, and the modern world recedes in the face of a primal story of kinship and survival. The last shot is especially hard to shake. Tender and poignant, it also has the haunting authority of an ancient stone carving, as if these brothers were ordinary flesh-and-blood creatures transformed into figures of myth.

An outbreak of scrapie, an ovine affliction similar to mad cow disease, brings havoc to the valley. Flocks are slaughtered, livelihoods are wiped out and an ancient way of life is threatened with ruin. Mr. Hakonarson observes the grief and the fatalism that the epidemic provokes in Gummi and KiddiŠ—Ès other neighbors, and at times Š—“RamsŠ— has the quiet specificity of a documentary. Government inspectors and veterinarians show up to monitor the killing of the animals and the cleaning of the barns, and their calm, implacable authority only increases the sense of helplessness and devastation.

Even though they live in rural Iceland, thousands of miles from the Holy Land, and in a modern reality of computers and mechanized farm equipment, Gummi and Kiddi have a decidedly Old Testament vibe. ItŠ—Ès not just the untended beards and the well-tended sheep. The two men, who live on neighboring farms in a quiet valley, are feuding brothers, locked in a sibling rivalry that recalls Jacob and Esau or Cain and Abel. The sources of the bad blood are never specified, but it trickles though Š—“Rams,Š— Grimur HakonarsonŠ—Ès new film, like an icy stream.

Kiddi (Theodor Juliusson) is larger, ruddier, drunker and luckier than Gummi (Sigurdur Sigurjonsson), and maybe better at raising and breeding sheep. Neither brother seems to have any other family, but their isolation does not spark any desire for each otherŠ—Ès company. When GummiŠ—Ès best ram comes in second to KiddiŠ—Ès at an annual contest for local breeders, itŠ—Ès clear that this is not his first such humiliation. His desire for revenge, which may be aided by something like divine intervention, gives this cleareyed and eccentric movie its plot.

But the director, Andrew Nackman, in making a super-mainstream film, leans so far toward the feel-good end of the spectrum that he forgoes the opportunity to make something that is more real, more fraught, more complex, but still entertaining and accessible to the Marthas of this world.

Much of the humor in Š—“4th Man OutŠ— comes from the broadly drawn ancillary characters, like Martha, a fanatically churchgoing neighbor whoŠ—Ès always at the door, offering up muffins, her niece and, ultimately, pamphlets for a sexual orientation conversion camp that arrive accompanied by an elaborately decorated Virgin Mary sheet cake.

In this tender, funny, but none too daring film, Adam, a regular guy who works as a mechanic in his little hometown, comes out on his 24th birthday. After a night of serious partying, he shares the news with his three lifelong buddies, who are completely gobsmacked.

When, with their encouragement, Adam tries some dating apps, he finds a parade of ultra-losers. (Rule No. 1: Do not list Š—“ScarfaceŠ— as your favorite film.) The most amusing is the creepy Š—“Bradstar.Š— Dishonest, slimy and unaware of his own pathologies, he lives an upstairs-downstairs existence and brags about his basement lair, complete with an Xbox 360. He invites Adam to spend Fourth of July in the basement, far from the fireworks, and even promises to sneak down with a portion of his wifeŠ—Ès outstanding potato salad.

As an ensemble, Adam (Evan Todd, from Š—“Grumpy CatŠ—Ès Worst Christmas EverŠ— and Š—“Heathers: The MusicalŠ—) and his friends, played by Parker Young, Chord Overstreet and Jon Gabrus, work together almost as one being, as many close friends do. It takes some adjustment, and a great deal of hilarity, to restore their communal equilibrium as they cycle through their poker games, their backyard workout sessions and other rituals. They try to be cool but manage to stumble into every potentially offensive assumption and unintended double entendre.

The movie gleefully demolishes the clich’© of a great artist as a brooding, omniscient eminence. Not since Ken RussellŠ—Ès screen biographies of painters and composers (Š—“The Music LoversŠ—) has a director deconstructed the myth of the heroic creator with such merciless delight. In Š—“Eisenstein in Guanajuato,Š— Mr. Greenaway (Š—“The Cook, the Thief, His Wife and Her LoverŠ—) goes to lunatic extremes Russell himself rarely approached.

As the movie goes along, Thanatos increasingly wins out over Eros. Images of skeletons and JesusŠ—È crucifixion multiply. Eisenstein and Palomino appear masked and dressed as skeletons to do a dance to celebrate MexicoŠ—Ès Day of the Dead. EisensteinŠ—Ès heart is broken and his film unfinished. He must return to Stalinist hell.

In Mr. GreenawayŠ—Ès heavily researched screenplay, Eisenstein expounds on film theory, the grimness of Russian life, and Hollywood, often in his own words, and drops the names of countless famous artists. The palette arbitrarily alternates between black and white and color. Many images are divided into triptychs. When Eisenstein ventures out of his hotel, he visits the cityŠ—Ès famous El Museo De Las Momias (The MummiesŠ—È Museum), and after the news of a catastrophic mudslide, goes to the disaster scene and is traumatized by the death of a child in his arms.

Beyond the arty trappings and flamboyant showmanship that are typical of Mr. Greenaway, 73, Š—“Eisenstein in GuanajuatoŠ— is a brazen provocation that focuses on the Eisenstein characterŠ—Ès embrace of his homosexuality while in Mexico. Shortly after arriving there from Los Angeles, his virginity is taken by his handsome Mexican guide, Palomino Ca’±edo (Luis Alberti), a married philosopher of comparative religion with two young sons. Physically painful though his initiation is, Eisenstein quickly embraces homosexuality as the path to ecstasy and falls in love. As he puts it, Š—“I had to come to Mexico to go to heaven.Š—

Embroidering the love story is a densely allusive biography of Eisenstein, who had completed at least three silent films Š—” Š—“Strike,Š— Š—“Battleship Potemkin,Š— and Š—“OctoberŠ— Š—” before his Mexican sojourn. The film includes clips from his silent movies, accompanied by a live orchestra playing ProkofievŠ—Ès majestic Fifth Symphony. There are no scenes of him making Š—“Que Viva Mexico!,Š— for which he shot 250 miles of footage that he could not retrieve before he was ordered to return to Russia.
Š—“Eisenstein in GuanajuatoŠ— is not rated. In English and Spanish, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 45 minutes.

Sex and death, or in the elevated language of the British director Peter Greenaway, Š—“Eros and Thanatos,Š— walk hand in hand in Š—“Eisenstein in Guanajuato.Š— This comedic fantasy from Mr. Greenaway about the seminal Russian filmmaker Sergei EisensteinŠ—Ès trip to Mexico in the early 1930s quotes Eisenstein at length, while imagining a scandalous personal life, about which little is known. Referring to his classic film Š—“October: Ten Days That Shook the World,Š— Eisenstein calls this working vacation Š—“the 10 days that shook Eisenstein.Š—

Like few films not marketed as pornography, Š—“Eisenstein in GuanajuatoŠ— revels in male full frontal nudity and unblinkingly observes the naked EisensteinŠ—Ès defloration from a middle distance. Eisenstein frequently talks to his penis and laments the lumpy shape of his own body, which Palomino assures him isnŠ—Èt unattractive. After one encounter, Palomino ceremoniously plants a miniature Soviet flag between EisensteinŠ—Ès buttocks. Such scenes suggest that the film is partly intended as a deliberate affront to Vladimir V. PutinŠ—Ès Russia, where Eisenstein is celebrated as a cultural deity, and homosexuality officially despised.

As embodied by the Finnish actor Elmer Back, Eisenstein is a roly-poly, motor-mouthed clown with a mop of wiry hair and body-image issues. His raucous behavior recalls the Italian comic Roberto Benigni on a tear. In certain shots he resembles the comedian Billy Crystal, and in others the fitness guru Richard Simmons.

EisensteinŠ—Ès trip to Mexico, by way of Hollywood, to make a film, Š—“Que Viva Mexico!Š— was funded by the American muckraking novelist Upton Sinclair (Š—“The JungleŠ—), whose wife, Mary Craig Sinclair (Lisa Owen), appears in the film as a frivolous, snobbish caricature offended by EisensteinŠ—Ès cheeky disregard for conventional manners.

As the Coens have done in the past, they use an unseen narrator (Michael Gambon), who gives the movie a slight fairy-tale vibe, announcing that weŠ—Ère not in Kansas or anywhere like life. Instead itŠ—Ès once upon a time in Tinseltown in the 1950s, the decade after Barton FinkŠ—Ès meltdown. The studio is again Capitol, but here the focus is a suit, Eddie Mannix (Josh Brolin), a front-office true believer and a devout Roman Catholic. As tightly wound as the watch he regularly checks, Mannix makes problems disappear before they become headaches or scandal-sheet headlines. HeŠ—Ès a pit bull in a fedora, but his loyalty to the studio suggests that heŠ—Ès either an idealist or a fanatic. So what is he?
Š—“Hail, Caesar!Š— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). The usual Hollywood high jinks, dames and drama. Running time: 1 hour 46 minutes.

No one, though, is more competent than Mannix, who in his looks, loyalty and especially his piety is finally the biggest fantasy figure on screen: the studio executive as a man of virtue. For all his church prayers, MannixŠ—Ès faith is invested in Capitol. HeŠ—Ès an embodiment of the industryŠ—Ès self-delusion and self-mythology, the kind of executive who invokes vision and bullies the help. In this, he makes a sly contrast with some Communist screenwriters who are true believers of a different stripe. Their discussions about art and dialectics mirror a side-splitter of a scene in which Mannix consults with four religious leaders about the studioŠ—Ès depiction of Jesus. As it turns out, everyone has something to peddle Š—” a talent, an angle, a god Š—” and, truly, thatŠ—Ès entertainment.

The clock may be ticking for Whitlock, but the Coens are not in any great rush to see him rescued. TheyŠ—Ère more interested in meandering in and around their dream factory, in showing DeeAnna wiggling underwater in a mermaid costume and Hobie doing a headstand in a saddle. Like all the performers at Capitol, these two prove supremely good at their jobs, which feels almost sentimental for the Coens but is also an acknowledgment of the old film factoryŠ—Ès brilliance. Even Whitlock, a high-wattage dim bulb, delivers the goods, as does Mr. Clooney, who paints the purloined actor in 50 shades of smiling idiocy. Whitlock is a boob; heŠ—Ès also a great Hollywood star.

In their circuitous way, the Coens get around to sketching in a story with the kidnapping of a major Capitol star, Baird Whitlock (George Clooney), whoŠ—Ès nearing the end of production on one of its big prestige pictures. Also titled Š—“Hail, Caesar!,Š— it looks and sounds like one of those dopily sincere religious spectacles that the studios never tire of. (In a Coen-esque flourish, it appears at least partly modeled on the 1959 epic Š—“Ben-Hur,Š— in which a lock-jawed Charlton Heston, a few years after parting the Red Sea, plays a Jewish prince turned Roman slave turned charioteer who has a life-changing encounter with Jesus.) WhitlockŠ—Ès kidnapping stirs up turmoil and mystery Š—” the snatchers portentously call themselves Š—“the FutureŠ— Š—” which leads to Mannix playing shamus as he tries to get back his star.

If this were anyone other than the Coens you might think that success and a couple of Oscars had mellowed them. Not likely. Š—“Hail, Caesar!Š— is one of those diversions that they turn out in between masterworks and duds. ItŠ—Ès a typically sly, off-center comedy, once again set against the machinery of the motion-picture business. And, as usual with the Coens, it has more going on than there might seem, including in its wrangling over God and ideology, art and entertainment. Some of it is familiar and satisfyingly funny, even if there are laughs and bits that seem as if they were written to amuse only the Coens and the Turner Classic Movies crowd. (Love the Loretta Young nod!)
The last time Joel and Ethan Coen dropped by Hollywood, they nearly burned the place down.

In their gleefully bilious 1991 comedy, Š—“Barton Fink,Š— John Turturro plays the title sap, a New York playwright who goes west to work for Capitol Pictures, where his Louis B. Mayer-like boss insists straight-faced that Š—“the writer is king!Š— ItŠ—Ès a cruel joke, one that the Coens play out as Barton is engulfed in flames and madness. As apocalyptic as a Nathanael West hallucination, Š—“Barton FinkŠ— felt like the testament of two filmmakers who, however much they loved movies, were happy to torch the industry. Yet here they are in Š—“Hail, Caesar!,Š— back on the lot and cracking jokes.

HeŠ—Ès playing a role, for starters, much like the stable of stars and extras under his wing. Like some other Coen creations, he shares a name with a real person, Eddie Mannix, a behind-the-scenes fixer who worked for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer when it claimed to have more stars than there are in heaven. From the mid-1920s on, Mannix prowled that studio, serving as Louis B. MayerŠ—Ès trusted aide and the studioŠ—Ès go-between with the unions; he even greenlighted films. He pops up dealing and scheming in some of the sleazier, less reliable Hollywood histories, but in Š—“Hail, Caesar!Š— heŠ—Ès a straight arrow and effectively an executive suite of one Š—” the only big shot on the lot.

In its shape, Š—“Hail, Caesar!Š— at times brings to mind one of those old plot-free film revues that featured a grab bag of studio talent performing in strung-together musical, comic and dramatic scenes. Among the other marquee names Mannix handles are DeeAnna Moran (Scarlett Johansson), an aquatic star who enters with a snarl and an Esther Williams splash, and a singing cowboy, Hobie Doyle (a charming Alden Ehrenreich), who goes from trick riding to wearing a tuxedo amid a froth of satiny gowns and Mid-Atlantic accents. ItŠ—Ès a rough transition, especially for HobieŠ—Ès director, Laurence Laurentz (Ralph Fiennes, perfection), who tries to squeeze the drawl out of the cowboy in an elocution lesson that makes for a very funny duet and illustrates Hollywood magic at its dissembling best.

The Coens like to open their movies with a question mark Š—” the spurious truth claims in Š—“Fargo,Š— the tumbling tumbleweeds in Š—“The Big Lebowski,Š— the Old World shtetl in Š—“A Serious ManŠ— Š—” which suits their playfully layered, sideways storytelling. (TheyŠ—Ère masters of the narrative tease.) Both blunt and opaque, the first image in Š—“Hail, Caesar!Š— is of a large crucifix in a church where Mannix, clutching a rosary, is bowed in prayer and soon making the first of his confession-box appearances. Grimacing, he comes across as a man with far more on his mind than spiritual matters; Mr. BrolinŠ—Ès large, magnificently sculptural head has rarely looked heavier.

At first, the kidnapping seems like an excuse for the Coens to fool around with genre and, as they like to do, riff on classical Hollywood form and style. Usefully, the kidnapping gets Mannix out of his office and onto the set, including a soundstage where a song-and-dance man in a sailor suit, Burt Gurney (Channing Tatum), makes like a randy Gene Kelly. Mr. TatumŠ—Ès number is delightful, at once satirical and virtuosic, although the winking bawdiness of the choreography is more risqu’© than what would have been allowed in a real 1950s musical. Here, as elsewhere, the Coens are scratching off the glossy studio veneer to show what lies beneath, including unspoken desires, even as theyŠ—Ère also putting on the kind of good show that helped build MGM.

So reads the single-page handout for Š—“MisconductŠ— that was distributed to reviewers in lieu of production notes. This clumsy, poorly written action thriller is such a complete catastrophe that you wonder how actors with the stature of Mr. Hopkins and Mr. Pacino were bamboozled into appearing in it. As for Mr. Duhamel, this human vanilla milkshake seems totally lost in a movie that requires him to be more than a generic nice guy with a pretty face.
Š—“MisconductŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for  foul language, violence and some nudity. Running time: 1 hour 46 minutes.

On paper, it sounds juicy: Š—“An ambitious lawyer (Josh Duhamel) finds himself caught in a power struggle between a corrupt pharmaceutical executive (Anthony Hopkins) and his firmŠ—Ès senior partner (Al Pacino). When the case takes a deadly turn, he must race to uncover the truth before he loses everything.Š—
Except for Mr. Hopkins and Mr. Pacino, going through their familiar paces, incompetent is the word.

Š—“MisconductŠ— is the directorial debut of Shintaro Shimosawa, the producer of Š—“The GrudgeŠ— and Š—“The Grudge 2,Š— from a screenplay by Simon Boyes and Adam Mason, a filmmaking team behind low-budget horror movies of which youŠ—Ève probably never heard. It begins as a whistle-blower drama about a young lawyer determined to expose and prosecute the crimes of Mr. HopkinsŠ—Ès evil plutocrat.

From there it goes haywire and becomes a laughably inept, crazily edited, incomprehensible, suspense-free thriller, one of whose villains repeatedly runs people down with a motorcycle. Malin Akerman, as the plutocratŠ—Ès scheming girlfriend, wildly overacts the role of a film noir temptress. Alice Eve plays the lawyerŠ—Ès depressed wife as a pouting, one-note baby doll.

The movie is adapted from the 2009 novel by Seth Grahame-Smith, who hit commercial pay dirt with a catchy title and the fusion of two ludicrously opposed, nominally irreconcilable cultural touchstones: Austen and zombies. With tongue in cheek and a copy of AustenŠ—Ès novel of manners apparently by his side, Mr. Grahame-Smith added a zombie apocalypse to the Bennet family concerns, peppering the chatter about balls, romantic prospects and the uncertain future of its five unmarried daughters with asides about human brains scooped out like Š—“pumpkin seeds from a jack oŠ—È lantern.Š— Mr. Darcy is as proud and disagreeable as ever, but like Elizabeth, heŠ—Ès also a warrior.

In AustenŠ—Ès novel, the mutually hostile Elizabeth and Darcy are already combatants of a kind whose primary weapons are their witty, wounding, deeply meaningful words. In the movie, Elizabeth and Darcy (Sam Riley, a persuasively brooding presence), sling metaphoric arrows at each other now and again, but theyŠ—Ère so busy fighting the zombies overrunning the country that their actions invariably drown out everything else. Both pride and prejudice still play their parts, but now in service to one tediously repeated joke: the sight of a gentleman or a lady, together or alone, playing cards or ballroom dancing, fatally swarmed by devouring zombies.

As it turns out, fighting zombies does nothing to improve on the original Elizabeth Bennet, Jane AustenŠ—Ès heroine from Š—“Pride and Prejudice.Š— In Š—“Pride and Prejudice and Zombies,Š— a character claiming to be Elizabeth Bennet (Lily James), wields swords and other deadly blades, fires guns and occasionally flashes a leg in order to stomp on a zombie head. Battling the undead keeps her, friends and family safe from the flesh-eating hordes, but the character has been so radically transformed from AustenŠ—Ès that Elizabeth already feels like a goner.
Š—“Pride and Prejudice and ZombiesŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Zombie society. Running time: 1 hour 48 minutes

The writer-director Burr Steers came prepared for battle, if not much else, with appealing actors Š—” Charles Dance, Jack Huston and an amusing Lena Headey Š—” as well as handsome drawing rooms and impressive estates. But as one zombie brain after another is pulverized, and as Elizabeth and her crew slip through another close call, the storyŠ—Ès lone joke and its grinding literalness grow dull. It doesnŠ—Èt help that Mr. Steers, as his occasional leering peeks up ElizabethŠ—Ès skirts underscore, clings to some old-fashioned ideas about women and their on-screen uses. The larger problem, though, is that each moment spent on this movie is another spent away from AustenŠ—Ès novel.

Š—“The PackŠ— was already used as the title of a 1977 movie about dogs run amok.

Š—“SirensŠ— (Roxanne Benjamin), the best of the segments, begins with a horror story classic: a vehicle that breaks down on a remote road. In this case, itŠ—Ès the touring van of a girl band. The seemingly harmless couple who come to their rescue arenŠ—Èt.

Š—“SouthboundŠ— is something you donŠ—Èt see much anymore: an anthology horror film. Š—“The ChoiceŠ— is the 11th film to ooze from the syrupy scribblings of Nicholas Sparks, who informs us in the publicity notes that he considers it to be Š—“even more memorable and profoundŠ— than his 1996 sobfest, Š—“The NotebookŠ— (filmed in 2004). HeŠ—Ès a commitment-phobic veterinarian whose father, Shep (Tom Wilkinson), is so kindly heŠ—Ès even named after a dog. Directed by Ross Katz and filmed like an ad for erectile-dysfunction medication, Š—“The ChoiceŠ— is almost repellently synthetic. TravisŠ—Ès dog, Moby, however, should be given his own movie immediately.

Father Garc’_a, lean and serious and relatively young, empties the liquor bottles, cuts back on the dog-racing and declares the clubhouse Š—“a place of penance.Š— He presents himself as the representative of Š—“a new church,Š— but though he institutes a program of spiritual healing, he doesnŠ—Èt seem interested in transparency or justice. Not that the four men and one woman at the center of this clammy, unsettling film regard themselves that way, or look that way to their neighbors. The five of them live in a neat, yellow-painted house in a small coastal town, where they share meals and strolls along the beach and devote themselves to training their beloved racing dog. His winnings pad the household budget, and while their lives are hardly opulent, the members of this group of outcasts seem to enjoy a measure of peace.

Š—“The ClubŠ— divides its attention among its characters, spending time with poor Sandokan as well as with his enemies. Mr. Larra’_n and the cinematographer, Sergio Armstrong, use a deliberately ugly, gray-washed palette, blurring the edges of the figures on screen and making the world look as if it could only be seen through a layer of grime.

Mr. Larra’_n, whose previous films (Š—“Post-Mortem, Š—“Tony ManeroŠ— and Š—“NoŠ—) have dwelled on cruelty and moral corruption in Chile during the Pinochet dictatorship, has an acute sense of how socially sanctioned authority feeds individual sadism. Mr. Castro, a fixture in this directorŠ—Ès cinematic universe, is the perfect vessel for his pessimistic, unnervingly empathetic view of human nature. The actorŠ—Ès sad eyes and weary countenance suggest both pathology and sensitivity. Like the murderer he played in Š—“Tony Manero,Š— Father Vidal is a monster with a soul.
Š—“The ClubŠ— is not rated. It is in Spanish, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 37 minutes.

There is power in this vision, but it can also feel forced, almost mechanical. Š—“The ClubŠ— is most effective when it resists the imperatives of plot, compelling us to keep company with damaged souls who still believe in the possibility of grace. Toward the end, though, Mr. Larra’_n wills them toward a reckoning that is dramatically unpersuasive, crosscutting between acts of brutality that are simultaneously too grindingly literal and too obviously symbolic. You are left queasy and sad, but not much more.

These men speak openly, even righteously Š—” though often through a veil of euphemism Š—” about what they have done. Tom McCarthyŠ—Ès Š—“Spotlight,Š— deservedly nominated for a bunch of Oscars, examines evil from the outside, shining a beam of journalistic illumination at the abuse and corruption that festered within the Roman Catholic hierarchy for decades. Š—“The Club,Š— the latest feature from the Chilean writer-director Pablo Larra’_n, looks at the same issue from the inside out, bringing the viewer into an uncomfortable state of intimacy with the perpetrators of hideous crimes.

Š—“TumbledownŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for a sex scene.

When Hannah (Rebecca Hall) is introduced in Š—“Tumbledown,Š— roaming her rustic Maine cabin and working at a typewriter next to her two dogs, you half expect the scene to turn into a coffee commercial (maybe right after the canine reaction shot). Š—“RegressionŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Violence, language, baloney. Running time: 1 hour 46 minutes.

In the late 1990s and early 2000s Alejandro Amen’bar directed two of the most striking and dynamic genre movies of the time, 1997Š—Ès knotty and terrifying virtual-reality/time travel tale Š—“Abre los OjosŠ— (Š—“Open Your EyesŠ—) and 2001Š—Ès innovative but in many respects gratifyingly old-fashioned ghost story Š—“The Others.Š—

Š—“Or is it?Š— is the question that horror movies have been asking since well before Bela Lugosi intoned the immortal line: Š—“Supernatural, perhapsŠ—_baloney, perhaps notŠ— in 1934Š—Ès Š—“The Black Cat.Š— Here Mr. Amen’bar is concocting a story Š—“inspired by real eventsŠ— Š—” the decidedly nonfictional town of Jordan, Minn., where satanic ritual abuse allegations were made in the early 1980s, is invoked in the movie Š—” and as such finds himself ethically compelled to finally debunk the thing heŠ—Ès relying on for cinematic scares in the first place. If Ms. Ting doesnŠ—Èt invest her pretty movie with enough substance, she at least knows when to stop: just short of a pat ending. ThatŠ—Ès the movieŠ—Ès wisest moment.

Suffice it to say that hooking up, for these two, would not be without consequences.
Š—“DeadpoolŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Bangs, booms and splatter. Running time: 1 hour 48 minutes.

These sections push the story forward, laying the foundation for the existential divide that defines every superhero, even a putative roguish outlier like Deadpool. And while the tears salting these scenes may be cynical given the movieŠ—Ès embrace of a what-me-worry nihilism, they offer a necessary break from the strained patter and violence. They also show that the director, Tim Miller, and Mr. Reynolds can do more than hit the same bombastic notes over and over again. ItŠ—Ès no surprise that the teams hired to bring a property like Š—“DeadpoolŠ— to the screen know how to keep the machine oiled and humming; itŠ—Ès the ones who somehow manage to temporarily stick a wrench in the works, adding something human Š—” a feeling instead of another quip Š—” who are worth your attention.

The filmmakers do a lot of winking and rib poking; they sell Š—“DeadpoolŠ— so hard that you might wonder if the studio has started to pay on commission. The sales pitch starts with the opening credits, which consist of a series of genre clich’©s Š—” Š—“hot chick,Š— Š—“British villainŠ— and Š—“comic reliefŠ— Š—” instead of the usual headliner cast and crew names. ItŠ—Ès one of the best sequences in the movie, partly because itŠ—Ès a bit complicated. At that early point, the audience can pretend (wink, wink) that it doesnŠ—Èt know whether Š—“DeadpoolŠ— is going to deliver on each of those clich’©s, from the requisite babe (Morena Baccarin, appealing and age appropriate) to the regulation British baddie (Ed Skrein). But what else would an entertainment juggernaut deliver in a movie like this? Surprises?

The opening credits are worth lingering over because theyŠ—Ère enjoyable and because theyŠ—Ère a clever pre-emptive strike. By immediately announcing the clich’©s that they will soon deploy, the filmmakers at once flatter and reassure the audience even as they lower any expectations that what follows will be new or different. You can almost hear the studio suits whispering in your ear: Š—“Come on, we all know that these kinds of movies rely on silly stereotypes Š—” thatŠ—Ès part of the fun!Š— And seriously who doesnŠ—Èt like fun? Yet to laugh (as I did) at these self-mocking credits is to give in to a somewhat compromised pleasure. The movie is the latest entry in the incessantly expanding comic book movie universe, which is crowded with beautiful physical specimens battling hordes of bad guys. Jokes and bullets are tossed like confetti in Š—“Deadpool,Š— a feverishly eager-to-please comic-book movie about a supervillain who suits up like a superhero. In uniform, the title character, an ordinary mercenary turned freakishly powerful mercenary, may look a little like Spider-Man, at least to the comic-book agnostic. But Deadpool is far more psychotic than heroic, which he cheerfully establishes by painting the screen red with one kill after another. He points, shoots, jokes (repeat), often while cracking wise right into the camera.

It is or it isnŠ—Èt. In Š—“How to Be Single,Š— an innocent post-collegiate newcomer to New York named Alice disappears down a rabbit hole of deadening life lessons and half-baked screenwriting. New York locations are flaunted, and the filmŠ—Ès interiors are warmly shot by Christian Rein, who seems fond of light streaming through windows. The rest of the movie isnŠ—Èt a pretty sight, delivering the hodgepodge that its listicle-like title maybe promised all along.

The conclusion would be chilling if it werenŠ—Èt so reserved. For Denmark, the film, an Oscar nominee in the foreign-language category, might seem quietly radical, but Mr. Lindholm errs too far on the side of quiet.

Mr. Lindholm sets about leveling out our expectations early, after an opening patrol sequence steeped in angst and blood. Handsome and self-possessed, Noor has his great career expectations met upon arrival in Delhi, where he instantly becomes the Next Big Thing on the art scene Š—” a glittery, multicultural world of gents with man buns and women in miniskirts. Š—“FitoorŠ— doesnŠ—Èt get much political resonance out of its Kashmiri setting, though the wintry sadness of the first scenes has power. Nor does it get much resonance out of class differences between Noor and Firdaus.
