In the first words heard in the film, Johnny, on horseback, warns that if you keep running a horse, youŠ—Èll break its spirit. He observes: Š—“Anything that runs wild got something bad in Š—Èem. You want to leave some of that in there Š—Ècause they need it to survive out here.Š—

ThereŠ—Ès a cultural specificity to this movie that will make it, for Western audiences, even more enigmatic than it is in its Thai context. This ought not be a stumbling block, though. Š—“Cemetery of Splendour,Š— which is opening as part of a wide-ranging Weerasethakul retrospective that runs through Thursday at the IFC Center (also screening is the directorŠ—Ès dreamy 2012 short feature Š—“Mekong HotelŠ—), has an emotional pull thatŠ—Ès terribly sad and that practically transcends its underpinnings in political allegory.

The exchange is unusual because the corresponding imagery contains no pink stone: The shot is of a forest floor, covered in dead leaves and a few stones; the womenŠ—Ès feet are in the top edge of the frame. Then thereŠ—Ès the matter of the exchange being among three of the characters, even though only two performers are in the frame and speaking to each other. This is because Keng is channeling Itt (Banlop Lomnoi), a soldier who has a mysterious sleeping sickness. Itt, it seems, can travel in his sleep from the world of the present to the world of the past. And this forest, near the makeshift hospital where Keng and Jen work, and where Itt is a patient, was once the site of a regal palace. Itt is able to see and describe the palace, because his ailment makes him a kind of prisoner there.
Š—“Cemetery of SplendourŠ— is not rated, is in Thai with English subtitles, and runs 2 hours 2 minutes.
Š—“This is the first time in my life,Š— replies Jen (Jenjira Pongpas Widner), a volunteer assistant nurse and physical therapist.
In the final quarter of Š—“Cemetery of Splendour,Š— the latest feature from the Thai filmmaker Apichatpong Weerasethakul, thereŠ—Ès an unusual exchange among the three main characters.
Š—“Have you ever seen pink stone before?Š— asks Keng (Jarinpattra Rueangram), a young psychic.

The colors and deliberate, assured editing rhythms of Š—“CemeteryŠ— imbue it with a distinctive quality. Shots range in duration between 10 seconds and several minutes; the viewer feels to be floating with the imagery, and when the cutting briefly quickens, a lulling, bobbing motion is simulated. The mood Mr. Weerasethakul conjures is all the more extraordinary when you consider that the movieŠ—Ès premise, in the hands of almost any other director, would be used to build some kind of horror movie.

Even so, Itt, JenŠ—Ès charge, is sometimes able to snap out of his stupor, and once awake and mobile, he has sharpened senses Š—” Š—“I can tell the temperature of the lights,Š— he says to Jen when they visit a plaza full of food stalls. Together, Jen and Itt explore the town. They go to the movies; we see them watching a trailer for a lurid horror film; then they stand up with the rest of the audience and stay still for a while. As it happens, itŠ—Ès the custom in Thai movie theaters for audiences to stand for the national anthem; in the scene in Š—“Cemetery,Š— though, no music plays.

Its final scene, in which the director moves his heretofore respectfully distant camera in for a couple of devastating medium close-ups, also features the most galvanic melding of pop music and cinematic imagery since the finale of Lynne RamsayŠ—Ès 2002 Š—“Morvern Callar.Š— The mysterious universality that Mr. Weerasethakul achieves in this sequence, and in other moments throughout Š—“Cemetery of Splendour,Š— is among the greatest of cinemaŠ—Ès many glories.

Itt and a group of other soldiers lie immobile in a facility in Khon Kaen (the directorŠ—Ès hometown, as it happens). Keng and Jen, among others, provide them with care, and early on they are all hooked up to some unusual machines (Š—“They used it with American soldiers in Afghanistan,Š— the nurses are told) that help them Š—“dream good dreams.Š— Each model has a standing tube that changes color, sometimes suffusing the ward with a cool blue or hot pink. Two goddesses Š—” Jen prays to their statues Š—” show up, as real people, and they tell Jen that the sleeping soldiers will never get better because the hospital sits on an ancient cemetery. The spirits of dead kings still at war with one another inhabit the place, and they are sucking the spiritual energy from the soldiers.

Mr. Weerasethakul is probably the most quietly surprising director working today. Š—“CemeteryŠ— is a peaceful but troubled picture Š—” thereŠ—Ès a lot roiling beneath. Its muted, largely naturalistic color palette is a contrast from the highly saturated and lush tones of the last Weerasethakul picture to play in the United States, Š—“Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives,Š— which won the Cannes Film FestivalŠ—Ès Palme dŠ—ÈOr in 2010.
Š—“Knight of CupsŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). I donŠ—Èt know, maybe they just didnŠ—Èt feel like getting dressed. Running time: 1 hour 58 minutes.

That would be a plausible psychological interpretation, in any case, but Mr. Malick has always been more interested in states of being than in cause and effect. His philosophical temperament and his sensual disposition can produce work of haunting, almost ecstatic power Š—” I certainly feel that way about Š—“The Tree of LifeŠ— Š—” but in Š—“Knight of Cups,Š— as in Š—“To the Wonder,Š— the deployment of beauty strikes me as more evasive than evocative.

Layered into these episodes are invocations of RickŠ—Ès childhood and family life, which make clear his kinship with the main character in Š—“The Tree of Life,Š— and thus with Mr. Malick himself. Rick grew up with two brothers. One of them has died, and the other (Wes Bentley) is a tormented soul, with a suggested history of addiction and instability. Their father (Brian Dennehy, in effect playing Brad PittŠ—Ès role in the earlier movie) is full of grief and regret, and the ache at the center of RickŠ—Ès existence seems to arise from the inadequacy of paternal and fraternal love.

In Š—“Knight of Cups,Š— the manŠ—Ès name is Rick, and he is played, with mopey eyes, a diffident half-smile and a scruff-bedecked chin, by Christian Bale. Rick is a Hollywood screenwriter who seems stuck in the long second act of his mortal script. The questions of how to begin, how to proceed, haunt him, and determine the elusive structure of the filmŠ—Ès narrative. Its title is drawn from the tarot deck, as are the titles of its constitutive sections: Š—“The Moon,Š— Š—“The Hanged Man,Š— Š—“The High Priestess,Š— among others. This suggests that the order of events may be random, serendipitous, a matter of occult meaning rather than chronological sequence.

The last word uttered in Terrence MalickŠ—Ès Š—“Knight of CupsŠ— Š—” whispered in voice-over, like most of the other speech in the movie Š—” is Š—“begin.Š— Curiously enough, that is also the penultimate word of Š—“PortnoyŠ—Ès Complaint.Š—

And the deployment of beauties is more exploitative than anything else. The nameless, voiceless, topless women Š—” whose lithe bodies at once symbolize RickŠ—Ès existential quest and distract him from it Š—” might as well be premium-cable eye candy. Like Paolo SorrentinoŠ—Ès Š—“Youth,Š— Š—“Knight of CupsŠ— settles into a lukewarm bath of male self-pity, a condition perhaps more deserving of satire than sanctification. Rick mopes and mutters through an elegantly appointed malaise, wandering the desert in an Armani jacket and driving aimlessly in his midnight-blue vintage convertible. In the room, the women come and go. ItŠ—Ès all very poetic and rarely boring, except maybe to Rick himself. But itŠ—Ès hard to trust his anguish and hard not to suspect that what is being solicited is not your empathy but your envy.

This juxtaposition is less far-fetched than you might suppose. The concluding sentence of Philip RothŠ—Ès novel is a punch line, turning the tale that has come before into an extended Jewish joke. Mr. MalickŠ—Ès film is not especially comical, and he is surely one of the least Jewish directors in the annals of American cinema, but his ending has a similarly startling effect. WeŠ—Ève been watching a manŠ—Ès life Š—” his sex life, in particular Š—” unspool before our eyes, only to learn that we havenŠ—Èt even gotten started. Or that he hasnŠ—Èt.

And yet, at the same time, a linear direction to RickŠ—Ès wanderings is implied by the invocation, early and late, of John BunyanŠ—Ès Š—“The PilgrimŠ—Ès Progress.Š— We must be going somewhere, toward some place of redemption. BunyanŠ—Ès allegorical City of Destruction Š—” and also, perhaps, the Celestial City that is its antithesis Š—” is incarnated by modern Los Angeles. Its architecture, its vegetation and its light are all exquisitely rendered by the great cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki, who just won his third consecutive Oscar. Los Angeles, like Paris and Manhattan, is vulnerable to cinematic clich’© and at the same time, through the right eyes, endlessly resistant to it. Mr. Lubezki can infuse Sunset Boulevard, Venice Beach and other often-filmed spots with a beauty that feels erotic and metaphysical at the same time.

As it happens, the confusion of eros and cosmos Š—” or maybe, to be generous, their mutual entanglement Š—” is RickŠ—Ès big problem, and also Mr. MalickŠ—Ès. At its most literal level, Š—“Knight of CupsŠ— is an encyclopedia of its protagonistŠ—Ès love affairs, casual and serious, painful and frolicsome, blonde and brunette. There are threesomes, pillow fights, rooftop debauches and skinny-dipping parties. Also a marriage (to Cate Blanchett), an affair with someone elseŠ—Ès wife (Natalie Portman) and a trip to Las Vegas with a stripper (Teresa Palmer) who drops pearls of wisdom from the edge of the stage.

The history of Zionism Š—” and the movementŠ—Ès changes before and after the establishment of Israel Š—” is a topic that could easily fill multiple libraries. Š—“Colliding DreamsŠ— takes on the unwieldy task of condensing it into a feature documentary that presents several points of view.

The directors, Joseph Dorman (Š—“Sholem Aleichem: Laughing in the DarknessŠ—) and Oren Rudavsky (Š—“A Life Apart: Hasidism in AmericaŠ—), capably if somewhat dryly assemble material that covers more than a century, roughly from the pogroms that drove Jews from Europe in the 1880s to the assassination of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel in 1995.

Orly Noy, a peace activist, recounts a description of Zionism as jumping out of a burning building, only to fall on someoneŠ—Ès head. Through interviews and archival material, the film portrays the movement as complex and often contradictory, divided between secular and religious goals almost from its inception. We hear from academics and writers on both sides of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. There are stories of Jews who were in what is now Israel before 1948 living alongside Palestinians.

The filmmakers also conduct sidewalk and cafe interviews in Tel Aviv and Ramallah for a present-day view; one Palestinian recalls realizing at camp that her Israeli friends might grow up to be soldiers at checkpoints. A swift primer that favors breadth over depth, the movie saves some hopeful notes for the end. Discussing his Palestinian son-in-law, the Israeli historian Mordechai Bar-On suggests that time has a way of generating empathy.

In the first movie, Gerard Butler, who plays Banning, came close to the likably taciturn effect he was going for, but here heŠ—Ès just boring and annoying. Over and over, this written-by-committee movie (Babak Najafi directed) tries to give him and Mr. Eckhart the kind of clipped one- and two-liners that aspire to be the next Š—“IŠ—Èll be back,Š— but all of them fall flat. The gun battles are incoherently filmed, and the flag-waving is embarrassing. Will this hard-luck president again defy death while his stoic sidekick vanquishes the nasty, uncivilized terrorists? ItŠ—Ès hard to care when a movie is this formulaic and moronic.

The president, along with practically every other significant world leader, travels to London for a state funeral, and a preposterous number of terrorists with an equally preposterous supply of guns and explosives are waiting for him. They blow up a good portion of the city in the process of taking him captive, planning to execute him live on the Internet. Only one man can save him.
President Benjamin Asher needs two things: better security personnel and better scriptwriters.

The first time the president (Aaron Eckhart) was snatched by terrorists, in the 2013 thriller Š—“Olympus Has Fallen,Š— watching his favorite Secret Service agent, Mike Banning, rescue him was at least somewhat fun in a mindless sort of way. Now, incredibly, the same president has been snatched by terrorists again, in the new Š—“London Has Fallen,Š— and this time the rescue is an unimaginative, repetitive slog.
Š—“London Has FallenŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian), because blood is shed and unprintable words are uttered.

Neither do the filmŠ—Ès actors, who seem uncertain where to land on the continuum between arch and earnest. Working hard to hold things together, Louisa Krause plays Ava, an exhausted survivor of demonic possession, as a cross between an amnesia victim and that weird girl in high school who might have belonged to a cult. We meet her mid-exorcism, heaving and twitching on a bed wearing nothing but a T-shirt and panties as a priest expels an Š—“ancient, malicious entity.Š— For the rest of the movie, neither her wardrobe nor her behavior will become notably classier.

Written and directed by Jordan Galland, Š—“AvaŠ—Ès PossessionsŠ— is a novelty piece that likens its monsters to abusive lovers who refuse to accept their marching orders. Though at times pleasingly quirky, the story is too slackly written and insipidly photographed to entertain. Demons might be a girlŠ—Ès best friend, as the movieŠ—Ès tag line declares, but theyŠ—Ère not doing much for Mr. Galland. JEANNETTE CATSOULIS

There is off-kilter fun, however, in watching the fallout from a lost month of demonic shenanigans. A wrecked apartment and miffed friends are the least of AvaŠ—Ès problems; thereŠ—Ès a bloodstain beneath her rug, and there are criminal charges for assault and indecent exposure to be faced. Enter Spirit Possessions Anonymous, a government-sanctioned recovery program for the formerly bedeviled. ItŠ—Ès time to make amends.
Š—“AvaŠ—Ès PossessionsŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Murder most foul and sex most twisted.
A goofy horror movie with little to say and not a lot to see, Š—“AvaŠ—Ès PossessionsŠ— sacrifices scares in favor of a rambling addiction metaphor that never finds an emotional rhythm.

Working from Richard Raymond Harry HerbeckŠ—Ès script, Mr. Thelin plays with genre clich’©s without upending them, and the results are more creepy than scary, with shivers that are primarily generated by the sight of threatened children (and that helpless animal), including the 11-year-old scrapper Jacob (Joshua Rush). (Carly Adams plays his sister, Sally; Thomas Bair plays their younger sibling, Christopher; and a charmer named Dante Hoagland plays a neighbor, Howie.) Š—“EmelieŠ— is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 20 minutes.

Soon afterward, another young woman, calling herself Anna (Sarah Bolger), is rubbing blood off her sneaker and hopping into a different car, on her way to a babysitting gig. For the first two seconds, as she chats up the dad, Dan (Chris Beetem), itŠ—Ès not clear if sheŠ—Ès the heroic babysitter Š—” the girl who fights the monster, as in John CarpenterŠ—Ès classic freakout Š—“HalloweenŠ— Š—” or the evil child-minder who, with a glint in her eye, violently rocks the cradle, the household and ideally the audience.

Like some other contemporary shockers that bridge the art house and the grindhouse, the low-key horror movie Š—“EmelieŠ— opens with a scene straight out of the auteur Michael HanekeŠ—Ès playbook. In long shot, a teenage girl walking on a tree-canopied street in Anywhere, U.S.A., is suddenly snatched and hustled into a car. ItŠ—Ès a disquieting overture, partly because it takes place in daylight. Mostly, though, itŠ—Ès because there are no close-ups of the assault, no cutaways to the presumably terrified victim or views of her two abductors, a man and a woman who materialize as if out of nowhere. This is terror at an artful remove.

But thereŠ—Ès something too intense, rigid and rhythmic about AnnaŠ—Ès smiles (itŠ—Ès as if she were reminding herself to express emotion), and something unsettling, almost predatory, about how she fixes her gaze. By the time Dan and his wife, Joyce (Susan Pourfar), are walking out the door, leaving their three rowdy tots in AnnaŠ—Ès care, you may be ready to call child services. Dan and Joyce seem too distracted by their anniversary to notice their new sitterŠ—Ès weird vibe, but they also come off as fairly witless. Yet in making the parents so careless, the director, Michael Thelin, has to work to bring you back into the movieŠ—Ès world, which he does with unnerving fits and starts, an imperiled pet and several appealing peewee actors.

Country-road helicopter shots, a synthesizer barrage and the presence of Ms. Crampton all advertise the directorŠ—Ès fondness for 1980s American movies. But Mr. Pastoll isnŠ—Èt able to resurrect the pop pleasures of that decadeŠ—Ès enthusiastic schlock.

Mr. Pastoll encourages us to let our suspicions float freely over everyone (and keeps it a little ambiguous as to whether Jack, who speaks English, understands all the French he hears). Yet the houseŠ—Ès horrors Š—” weird attic rooms and a weirder neighbor Š—” simply bring in aspects of other, routine thrillers. Jack (Andrew Simpson) and his companion, V’©ronique (Jos’©phine de La Baume), bond after failing to find safe rides in the French countryside. Getting into a strangerŠ—Ès car has been ill-advised in movies at least since Ida LupinoŠ—Ès 1953 pressure-cooker-on-wheels Š—“The Hitch-Hiker.Š— That doesnŠ—Èt stop the two hitchers in Abner PastollŠ—Ès Š—“Road GamesŠ— from getting into the wrong Peugeot. But their predicament comes to feel less chilling than mildly confusing, and a little disappointing, as Mr. PastollŠ—Ès halting thriller goes through its paces.

When, in 2012, Islamic jihadists imposed an extreme version of Shariah law on northern Mali, banning all music and destroying radio stations, many of that countryŠ—Ès most prominent musicians were forced to hide or flee. In a nation where music is a vital tool for education, enlightenment and connection Š—” in the words of one artist, songs are Š—“like the pressŠ— Š—” the ban felt especially devastating. Defying it, however, meant risking torture or worse.

Following a handful of exiled, homesick musicians as they try to play the pain away, Ms. Schwartz blends their often joyful performances with candid interviews that show the damage wrought by extended conflict. (The ban officially ended in 2014, but musicians still fear reprisals from extremists.) Blues and ballads, rap and soul fill the soundtrack (as well as an original score by Nick Zinner of the Yeah Yeah Yeahs), while Karelle WalkerŠ—Ès camera searches faces for every emotional clue.

Two of those faces are particularly memorable. The so-called Nightingale of the North, Khaira Arby, allays her sadness by planning a return concert in her beloved Timbuktu. Meanwhile, her fellow songstress, Fadimata Walett Oumar, deals with displacement by helping women in refugee camps and pondering her countryŠ—Ès political complexities. To the uninitiated, these are not always clear; but the movieŠ—Ès insistence on the healing power of cadence and beat needs no explanation.

Filmed partly in refugee camps and on the war-ravaged streets of Timbuktu and Gao, Johanna SchwartzŠ—Ès miraculously hopeful documentary, Š—“They Will Have to Kill Us First: Malian Music in Exile,Š— delivers a vibrant testimony of resilience under oppression.

Mr. Hosoda is skilled with fight scenes, and his settings Š—” the pastel-hued Jutengai and the drab Shibuya, evoked at times with surveillance-camera perspectives and crowd-paranoia angles Š—” are impressive. But the characterizations and conflicts here are strictly generic.
Š—“The Boy and the BeastŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for mild violence.

When Ren discovers a mystical portal, he is transported to Jutengai, a world that will look familiar to fans of the Jack Kirby comic book Kamandi, the Last Boy on Earth. Jutengai is populated by animals with humanoid aspects, and Ren befriends Hyakushubo, a pig aspiring to be a monk; Tatara, a skeptical chimpanzee; and Kumatetsu, a gruff, temperamental bear who resolves to train Ren in kendo.

Cue sifu-student training montages and RenŠ—Ès evolution from a defiant delinquent to a warrior of noble bearing, with shrill intermittent humor sequences of Ren and Kumatetsu bickering. When Ren becomes a teenager, he returns to Tokyo, where he meets Kaede, a young woman who teaches him about books (and about Š—“Moby-DickŠ— in particular, from which the movie very loosely borrows themes). He also re-encounters his father, whom he had abandoned years before. And he confronts a giant whale monster, when a nemesis from Jutengai comes to Tokyo.

Mamoru HosodaŠ—Ès anime fantasy Š—“The Boy and the BeastŠ— is a curious hybrid with a foot in two realms. It begins vividly, in a gritty and monochromatic rendering of the Shibuya district in Tokyo, where a 9-year-old runaway, Ren, scrapes by.

The filmmakers (the script is by John Kare Raake and Harald Rosenlow Eeg) cook up the sort of unpleasantness that turns the better disaster pictures, like this one, into nail-biters. There are minor and fateful human dramas and errors, as well as a missed getaway, a strategic separation and even some ticking clocks. By the time disaster strikes, Kristian and his youngest child are bidding a nostalgic goodbye to their house while his wife, Idun (Ane Dahl Torp), and Sondre are at the hotel where she works. Both Mr. Joner and Ms. Torp have somewhat protuberant eyes that make them a mirror for the audience, though as their characters swing into parental survivor mode youŠ—Ère reminded that this is the land of the Vikings, from their resolve to their awesome man-crushing thighs.

Up until then, Š—“The Wave,Š— which centers on a family swept up by a tsunami in Norway, has been as seductively calm and beautiful as a tourist board commercial. The director, Roar Uthaug, and his team make some smart moves, none shrewder than setting the story in and around a real southwestern town, Geiranger, which faces a long, deep fjord. A Unesco World Heritage site, the fjord is the movieŠ—Ès true commanding star, with soaring verdant and denuded rock walls flanking a glassy inlet that snakes along for miles before spilling into the sea. ItŠ—Ès one of those dreamy destinations that by virtue of its appeal can turn goose bumps of delight into nightmarish shivers.

Like most disaster movies, Š—“The WaveŠ— has three ready-made narrative movements Š—” setup, catastrophe and aftermath Š—” populated by indispensable, regrettably sacrificial and casually disposable characters. In other words, somebody has to play Shelley WintersŠ—Ès role in Š—“The Poseidon Adventure,Š— somebody else gets to be Charlton Heston (pick your flick), while everyone else goes bye-bye. The filmmakers amusingly stack the deck by making the heroes members of an attractively close family thatŠ—Ès packing up to move when the story opens. Better yet, the father, Kristian (Kristoffer Joner), is a jumpy geologist whoŠ—Ès been monitoring a nearby mountain, a restless giant whose collapse would instigate a tsunami that would wipe away the town and turn pleasure boats into broken bathtub toys.

The flashy number in Š—“The WaveŠ— rolls in like a star. You know itŠ—Ès coming, just not when. (Fanning the crowdŠ—Ès anxiety is crucial to making a great entrance.) Once it arrives, the crowd gawks and freezes, mesmerized by the spectacle of so much ferocious power. And, like all stars, the wave waits for no one. A palpably convincing digital creation, this churning gray inundation powers straight into the little people, who panic and scatter, creating a regular day-of-the-locust free-for-all that separates children from parents, the survivors from the newly dead.
Š—“The WaveŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for disaster and death. It is in Norwegian, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 45 minutes.

Mr. Uthaug plays with the initial tranquillity nicely, mixing smiling, friendly faces with beauty shots of the pristine, conspicuously unpopulated landscape. The mountains are summertime green, but the inlet isnŠ—Èt yet jammed with cruise ships and the village isnŠ—Èt overrun with visitors. The limited number of ships and sightseers concentrates your focus on the family and the natural world, allowing you to see the ease with which these people navigate their environment. You can intuit an entire family drama in the shot of the teenage son, Sondre (Jonas Hoff Oftebro), perched alone at the waterŠ—Ès edge, dwarfed by a place he doesnŠ—Èt want to leave. The scale of that image has other implications, too, since the story will soon shift from the great outdoors to some intensely claustrophobic interiors.
Š—“TrappedŠ— is not a balanced analysis of the abortion debate; it makes its sympathies clear. But it is a powerful and persuasive rendering of a corner of womenŠ—Ès health care under siege.

We are reminded of Roe v. WadeŠ—Ès hard-won decision, and glimpse the 11-hour filibuster by State Senator Wendy Davis of Texas, a Democrat, against restrictive abortion legislation in 2013. And we meet other abortion rights advocates, like June Ayers, owner of Reproductive Health Services in Montgomery, Ala., who blends graciousness and fortitude while contending with protesters outside her office. Amy Hagstrom Miller, the chief executive of the clinic chain Whole WomanŠ—Ès Health, which is the plaintiff in the Supreme Court case, cites the plummeting number of Texas clinics after the 2013 law was passed and the long distances many patients must now travel for treatment. Gloria Gray of the West Alabama WomenŠ—Ès Center in Tuscaloosa invokes a familiar refrain: Š—“Closing the clinics is not going to stop abortions. Women are going to have abortions; itŠ—Ès just that they are not going to be safe and legal.Š—

Dr. Willie J. Parker, a churchgoing obstetrician and gynecologist who provides abortions, is heckled by an anti-abortion campaigner en route to his job. Doctors, he says, Š—“have been killed doing this work,Š— but, he adds, Š—“when you have a sense of duty about what you do, it allows you to ignore the naysayers.Š—

With the Supreme CourtŠ—Ès hearing of  a challenge to a 2013 Texas law imposing stringent requirements on abortion providers comes Dawn PorterŠ—Ès Š—“Trapped,Š— the winner of the Sundance Film FestivalŠ—Ès Special Jury Award for Social Impact Filmmaking and an urgent, vital examination of Southern abortion clinics. The filmŠ—Ès subjects face so-called TRAP laws (the letters stand for targeted regulation of abortion providers), whose critics say aim to close clinics or reduce their number by placing unaffordable or unfeasible demands on them.

To an extent, the filmŠ—Ès shortfalls feel bound up with high expectations for Ms. Fey. As Kim, she wants to show how the risky search for scoops in Kabul feeds something within her without really sustaining her. It also doesnŠ—Èt help that Ms. FeyŠ—Ès sharpest past work has simultaneously skewered the archetype of the neurotic single professional and complicated it with a self-conscious edge that this film could use.

Based on Kim BarkerŠ—Ès memoir, Š—“The Taliban Shuffle,Š— Š—“Whiskey Tango FoxtrotŠ— contains the fondly, proudly recalled details of battle-tested experience. ThatŠ—Ès not to judge Š—“Whiskey Tango FoxtrotŠ— (the title is a play on a common profane phrase using the military phonetic alphabet) by its starŠ—Ès previous successes. Š—“Whiskey Tango FoxtrotŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for language, sexual content, drug use and images of war. Running time: 1 hour 52 minutes.

Kim embeds with the military to chase stories, half-reluctantly hooks up with a foul-mouthed British journalist (Martin Freeman) and generally gets her groove back. Bouncing on and offscreen like recurring TV characters are her protective, traditional-minded young fixer, Fahim (Christopher Abbott); her frenemy news colleague Tanya (Margot Robbie); and that goofily forward government official (Alfred Molina).
[ Read an interview with Tina Fey ]

As written by the TV veteran Robert Carlock, KimŠ—Ès rise-and-fade arc is sympathetically rendered, with humor and the urgency of an underhand pitch. The frazzled editing of KimŠ—Ès arrival in Kabul as a na’Àf subsides early, replaced by a narrative glide that hints self-knowledge will emerge from the chaos. KimŠ—Ès achievements are swiftly packaged as personal wins, such as when she proves her savvy to a top Marine officer (Billy Bob Thornton) sheŠ—Ès reporting on.

Some of the filmŠ—Ès shorthand reflects the cut-to-the-chase caricature of someone forced to adapt to frequently hostile surroundings (in which Kim is harassed as an independent woman in the streets). But the film also rests in a tidiness thatŠ—Ès at odds with the messiness of the milieu. And even when we are exposed to glimpses of wartime violence and menace, itŠ—Ès undercut by fuzzy platitudes near the end of the film. Ms. Barker seems to have earned the reward of such a reassuring conclusion, but itŠ—Ès not clear the movie has.

Somewhere along the way, she also finds herself and cracks a few jokes. ThatŠ—Ès not entirely unexpected, because Kim is played by Tina Fey, an old hand at portraying the self-deprecating, nerdy workaholic getting a handle on her personal life. Directed by Glenn Ficarra and John Requa, Š—“Whiskey Tango FoxtrotŠ— suggests a serious extension of Ms. FeyŠ—Ès best-known comedic persona, on more treacherous terrain and with an Afghan culture clash. Instead of walking the absurdist halls of Š—“30 Rock,Š— Ms. FeyŠ—Ès character is sucked into the grueling but addictive pursuit of war journalism.

What ensues is RebeccaŠ—Ès agonized regimen as she approaches labor, accompanied by the simmering antagonism between Paraiti and Maraea, who condescendingly refuses to address Paraiti in their native tongue. And Rebecca and Maraea certainly have issues of their own.

Move ahead to the early 20th century. Paraiti (Whirimako Black) has become a respected healer and midwife versed in Maori medicine, so renowned that Maraea (Rachel House), the Maori housekeeper for a landownerŠ—Ès wife, enlists her help. MaraeaŠ—Ès mistress, the insulated, petulant Rebecca (Antonia Prebble), is pregnant, and seeks to induce the birth Š—” for reasons we eventually discover Š—” before her husband, a businessman, returns from an extended trip. Maraea knows Paraiti has the skills, and the discretion, for the job.
Ms. Black, a New Zealand recording artist making her film debut, and Ms. House, both actresses of formidable presence, are well-matched opponents. Ms. Prebble, too, has reserves of power.

Quiet, graceful, stately and infused with slow tension, Dana RotbergŠ—Ès Š—“White LiesŠ— unfolds with inexorable weight. Set in rural New Zealand, the movie begins in the late 19th century, with the death of the father of Paraiti, a Maori girl, at the hands of white settlers, in a conflict that leaves her permanently scarred on her cheek. You might assume that a story of vengeance awaits, but it does not, at least how you would expect.

Š—“White LiesŠ— has a Maori title, Š—“Tuakiri HunaŠ— (meaning Š—“hidden identityŠ—), that gets at the heart of its revelations. But itŠ—Ès the movieŠ—Ès delineations of oppression Š—” cultural, sexual and familial Š—” that will haunt you.

Easter is still weeks away, but pet stores may find that the added demand for rabbits the holiday brings will come early this year thanks to the irresistible Š—“Zootopia,Š— an animated movie with an intrepid bunny named Judy Hopps at its core. Her fox sidekick, Nick Wilde, is mighty enjoyable, too.

Anyway, Judy learns some hard truths as she delves deeper into the mystery, and young viewers will, too. Chief among those is one adults know well: Being civilized doesnŠ—Èt mean tension and ugly thoughts disappear. Also, bringing about positive change isnŠ—Èt as easy as it seems.

This film, action-packed and filled with enough savvy jokes that adults should consider slipping into the theater even if they donŠ—Èt have an accompanying child, is set in a world where animals have transcended the carnivore-and-prey dichotomy and now live together more or less harmoniously.

If youŠ—Ève seen the trailer for this delightful movie youŠ—Ève already had a taste of what might be the greatest takedown of bureaucratic ineptitude ever filmed. It involves a trip by Judy and Nick to the Department of Motor Vehicles, with its all-sloth staff. In the context of childrenŠ—Ès movies, itŠ—Ès a fairly daring scene, since in an otherwise fast-moving story the joke takes a loooong time to roll out. But it sure is worth it.
Funny, smart, thought-provoking Š—” and musical, too. Shakira provides the voice of a pop star named Gazelle, and her vocals complete the package appealingly.

Judy (the voice of Ginnifer Goodwin of Š—“Once Upon a TimeŠ—), a country bunny, wants to become the first rabbit police officer in the bustling metropolis of Zootopia, but her parents are not exactly the follow-your-dreams type.
Š—“ZootopiaŠ— is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for gently rude humor and occasional scariness. Running time: 1 hour 48 minutes.
Š—“I came here to make the world a better place,Š— Judy laments after her good intentions backfire, Š—“but I think I broke it.Š—

Š—“If you donŠ—Èt try anything new, youŠ—Èll never fail,Š— her father (Don Lake) tells her. ItŠ—Ès a gag that encapsulates one of the best things about this film: It trusts young viewers to recognize the clich’©s theyŠ—Ève been fed by other animated movies over the years and to appreciate seeing them subverted.

Judy graduates from the police academy and ends up on the force in Zootopia, but her boss (Idris Elba) relegates her to parking-ticket duty while more experienced officers investigate 14 missing-mammal cases. While obsessively writing tickets, Judy meets Nick (Jason Bateman), a world-weary hustler who slowly becomes her friend and adviser as she pokes her nose into the missing-mammal epidemic despite her bossŠ—Ès resistance.

The tools of portable video were such, the members recall, that men and women started at the same learning curve, and women were able to cover the feminist movement in great detail. As financing and transmitting concerns mount, the movie sees the collective mutating from activists to educators and community entertainers. The utopia they envisioned has yet to materialize, to say the least, but seeing their efforts is heartening.

The Portapak early adopters David Cort and Parry Teasdale stumble upon each other at Woodstock, both of them recording Š—“none of the musicŠ— and instead capturing possibly incriminating (in retrospect) pronouncements from shaggy baby boomers. (One hippie drawls that Š—“the parents of the past generation haveŠ— made a mess of their kids Š—” the hippie actually uses a barnyard epithet to describe what theyŠ—Ève done Š—” and one has every confidence that this individual has since heard something similar or worse from his own children or grandchildren by now.) With some like-minded friends and lovers Mr. Cort and Mr. Teasdale created the Videofreex collective. An alliance with media giant CBS is pursued, and proves abortive, but not before the Videofreex capture some galvanizing footage, including an interview with Fred Hampton, the Illinois chairman of the Black Panther Party, conducted weeks before Hampton was killed by the police in 1969.

The 1968 introduction of a record-playback model of the Sony Portapak, which yoked a video camera to a video recorder in a lightweight format, was without a doubt seminal in media history. For various counterculture idealists, the relatively affordable, low-resolution devices had utopian truth-telling potential. Š—“Here Come the Videofreex,Š— a concise and informative documentary directed by Jon Nealon and Jenny Raskin, tells the story of one such collective.
Š—“Here Come the VideofreexŠ— is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 19 minutes.

The first of these occurs almost immediately, a truly unnerving incident that leaves Michelle (a smashing Mary Elizabeth Winstead) chained to a bed in an underground bunker. Her captor Š—” savior? Š—” is Howard (John Goodman), a dour survivalist who informs her that the world has been depopulated by some kind of chemical or nuclear attack. Howard suspects Russians or Martians; Michelle suspects that heŠ—Ès nuts.

But Mr. Abrams, who returns as a producer here and leaves the directing to Dan Trachtenberg, is nothing if not a savvy salesman. Luckily, he has something worth peddling: Š—“10 Cloverfield LaneŠ— might have cost little more to put together than a season of Š—“SurvivorŠ— (the budget permitted Bradley CooperŠ—Ès voice, though not, alas, the rest of him), but the movie is a master class on narrative pacing and carefully managed jolts.

Š—“10 Cloverfield LaneŠ— demands to be seen before reading a single review. So I plan to divulge even less than its makers, whose hype-by-omission campaign Š—” which included a late title change to summon fans of J. J. AbramsŠ—Ès hurtling thriller Š—“CloverfieldŠ— (2008) Š—” seems unnecessarily manipulative.
Sneakily tweaking our fears of terrorism, Š—“10 Cloverfield Lane,Š— though no more than a kissing cousin to its namesake, is smartly chilling and finally spectacular. A sequel is virtually a given.

Employing a playlike setup and an unflinching camera (Jeff CutterŠ—Ès cinematography is miraculously lucid), the filmmakers lean heavily on Mr. GoodmanŠ—Ès disconcerting performance and Ms. WinsteadŠ—Ès spunky resolve. John Gallagher Jr. works wonders with his underwritten role as the bunkerŠ—Ès third resident, and pops of 1960s tunes add a creepy nostalgia.
Š—10 Cloverfield LaneŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Barrel of acid, a whole heap of destruction.

She recruits for a traveling companion a man from a nearby psychiatric care center named Sam (James Frecheville). His wrists are still bandaged, which tells us as much about him as any of the dialogue does. They steal a car and head off in search of the carnival where Ray works.

Scout is old enough that her traveling dynamic with Sam isnŠ—Èt the kid-adult one of Š—“Paper MoonŠ—; itŠ—Ès more like a tweener with a crush on a college man. The film, though, doesnŠ—Èt really do enough with the possibilities inherent in that, or give us enough back story on either of them to make their improbable partnership credible.

Š—“About ScoutŠ— is another entry in the Š—“charming road movieŠ— genre, one that banks a little too heavily on charm and not enough on story. The two young leads pair engagingly, though, and the screenwriter and director, Laurie Weltz, surrounds them with name actors in small roles, a sweet reversal of the usual casting structure.

The supporting characters Š—” the cast also includes Nikki Reed, Jane Seymour and Danny Glover Š—” add dashes of interest, but by the filmŠ—Ès end, youŠ—Ère left with a sketch more than a full portrait. The characters were fleetingly interesting, yet you donŠ—Èt feel as if you have come to know them.

India Ennenga (Sofia from the HBO series Š—“TremeŠ— and Ms. WeltzŠ—Ès daughter) is Scout, a teenager who, along with her younger sister, Lulu (Onata Aprile), is being raised by her great-grandmother (Ellen Burstyn). It is Scout, though, who is doing most of the raising, and when their absentee father, Ray (Tim Guinee), takes custody of Lulu, Scout goes off in search of her.

Š—“This film is about the AchillesŠ—È heel of capitalism,Š— Terry Jones says at the opening of Š—“Boom Bust Boom.Š— Š—“How human nature drives the economy to crisis after crisis, time and time again.Š—

We see how economic models have continually been proved wrong, and how money and emotions cloud good sense. Such scenes could be infuriating to watch if Mr. Jones (with his son, Bill, and Ben Timlett as co-directors) didnŠ—Èt make the topic accessible and entertaining through animation, puppetry and song, as well as clips from Š—“South ParkŠ— and Mr. JonesŠ—Ès old Š—“Monty PythonŠ— troupe.

Š—“Boom Bust BoomŠ— is pithy and clever, and an excellent companion to the film Š—“The Big ShortŠ— and the book Š—“Freakonomics.Š— ItŠ—Ès also an upbeat tale, though weŠ—Ère given plenty of warnings. Š—“Every generation thinks itŠ—Ès smarter than its parents and its grandparents,Š— one economist says. Š—“And it never appears to be the case.Š— Or, in the words of another, Š—“Nothing is ever learned for long.Š—

Š—“Boom Bust BoomŠ— explores the economic collapse of 2008 and uses it to investigate past financial panics and depressions. Nobel Prize winners, academics and economists are interviewed, and while they mention numerous reasons for these meltdowns, hubris is often cited as the chief culprit.

From the Dutch tulip mania of the 1600s through the Depression and on, we find that, to summarize the economist Hyman Minsky, stability leads to optimism, which leads to overconfidence and deregulation, which leads to disaster. Those disasters, in turn, prompt caution and new laws, which can foster stability and an eventual repeat of the cycle.
ItŠ—Ès an ominous statement, and one that belies what follows: a remarkably enjoyable, and sometimes very funny, documentary about a frightening topic.

Christopher Plummer puts on a master class in acting, and his director, Atom Egoyan, delivers one in audience manipulation in Š—“Remember,Š— a psychological thriller featuring that most blood-boiling of plot devices: a Nazi who escaped justice.
Š—“RememberŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for moments of violence and some strong language.

Mr. Plummer is Zev and Martin Landau plays Max, fellow residents of some sort of assisted-living complex. Max realizes they were both at Auschwitz. He is the brains and Zev is the brawn, so to speak, of a plan Max has hatched to seek vengeance on a concentration camp official who escaped to the United States under a false identity.

Max is in a wheelchair, but he arms Zev and sends him on a cross-country journey to interview four people who could be the missing Nazi, the hope being that heŠ—Èll kill the man once he finds him. But Zev is floating in and out of dementia, complicating the task and giving Mr. Plummer a chance to turn in a very fine performance. Yes, this type of role has become a sort of must-have accessory in an older actorŠ—Ès kit bag, but Mr. Plummer is never less than convincing.

Mr. Egoyan, working with a script by Benjamin August, pushes every button he can as Zev gets himself into various kinds of jeopardy, makes incorrect assumptions and so on. The twist ending feels like a cop-out, but it certainly leaves an impression. NEIL GENZLINGER

This is more than boosterism. Mr. Gold, whose first love was music Š—” he studied classical cello and fell in love with punk rock Š—” blends his search for culinary excellence with advocacy and ethnography, and writes in the service of a humane, multicultural vision of urban life. While he eats in and writes about high-end restaurants and ambitious, would-be celebrity chefs, his heart is in the vernacular gastronomy of immigrant and working-class neighborhoods. He is a Walt Whitman of taco trucks, hot-dog stands and pho parlors, of unassuming storefront and strip-mall joints that bring the flavors of the world to Southern California.

Not that Los Angeles is any kind of utopia. Mr. Gold remembers both the Watts riots of 1965 and the unrest that followed the 1992 acquittal of the police officers who had beaten Rodney King. He is likened at one point to Raymond Chandler, another writer who explored the hidden, unglamorous corners of a city too often besotted by its own hype. And there is an intriguingly melancholy strain in both his writing and in this mostly celebratory film. Great cities are places of constant change, hectic loss, occasional violence and painful division. To live in one is to grapple, every day, with ambivalence and disappointment, with constant reminders of how the pursuit of perfect happiness (or even reasonable contentment) can fail.
Š—“City of GoldŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for spicy food and salty talk. Running time: 1 hour 31 minutes.

Š—“Criticism is criticism,Š— says Jonathan Gold, who writes about food for The Los Angeles Times. Š—“An aria is like a well-cooked potato.Š— To which I can only say: Amen. Creative inspiration can be found in a great variety of human pursuits, and criticism is the name we give to the act of identifying and sharing it. A painting is, in that respect, like a poem. A well-written book is like a well-built shelf. A newspaper column is like a documentary film.

But Š—“City of GoldŠ— transcends its modest methods, largely because it connects Mr. GoldŠ—Ès appealing personality with a passionate argument about the civic culture of Los Angeles and the place of food within it. His enthusiasm and generosity of spirit stand in definitive rebuke to the myth that critics are crabbed, hostile, pleasure-hating creatures. Rejecting the restaurant reviewerŠ—Ès customary anonymity, Mr. Gold is warmly received by cooks, servers and restaurateurs, many of whom are grateful for his positive reviews.

Š—“City of Gold,Š— directed by Laura Gabbert, is an affectionate portrait of Mr. Gold, a genial walrus of a man with a graying ginger mane and a gentle, gaptoothed smile. The film accompanies him in his green pickup truck as he patrols the streets of Los Angeles, pointing out the best places to find fiery Southern Thai stews and sublime Oaxacan moles. We sit in on editorial meetings and peek over his shoulder as he writes on his laptop at the dining room table. Colleagues and expert witnesses are summoned to pay tribute to his genius and annotate his quirks. We spend some time with Laurie Ochoa, his wife and erstwhile editor, and their two children. We learn about Mr. GoldŠ—Ès childhood, his early career, his Pulitzer Prize. Ms. Gabbert, in other words, follows the usual documentary recipe.

Before becoming a full-time food writer, Mr. Gold resolved to eat at every restaurant on Pico Boulevard, a 15-mile thoroughfare that runs from downtown Los Angeles in the east to Santa Monica in the west. The project confirmed what he had already suspected about his native city, whose geography and demography created a complex and constantly shifting mosaic of cuisines: Los Angeles is an incubator of cultural and commercial variety. The decentered sprawl of the city tends to disorient visitors from the opposite coast, but real estate prices are less than ruinous, and the supply of hungry people is limitless.

In the face of that reality, Mr. Gold finds intimations of perfection Š—” meals, dishes, single bites that sustain his faith in Los Angeles and, by implication, in humanity. Š—“City of GoldŠ— is a lovely testament to that faith, worth attending to even if you think you have no interest in food, California or criticism.

Defying its title, this frigid satire concerns an unprepossessing antihero with no control at all. David (Mr. Dickinson), a stressed-out adman, pops pills that look like buttons and drinks and works to excess. Instructed to design a marketing campaign for a revolutionary pair of reality-augmenting eyeglasses, David instead uses them to conjure a lubricious avatar of his romantic obsession, the lovely Sophie (Alexia Rasmussen). That Sophie is the girlfriend of his best friend, Wim (Dan Gill), a swinging Š—È60s-style fashion photographer, bothers David not at all.

Concocted with heaps of style but only a smattering of substance, Benjamin DickinsonŠ—Ès sophomore feature, Š—“Creative Control,Š— is as brittle and unwelcoming as its charactersŠ—È surroundings. Those would be Brooklyn, some time in the near future when everyone enjoys panoramic city views from habitats bristling with glass and chrome. Tactile surfaces, like emotional satisfaction, are in short supply.
Š—“Creative ControlŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for a fake full-frontal woman and full-of-themselves men. Running time: 1 hour 37 minutes.

Rehashing themes of detachment, pornography and subservience to gadgetry that have been developed much more imaginatively elsewhere Š—” most notably by David Cronenberg and Kathryn Bigelow, and most recently in Spike JonzeŠ—Ès Š—“HerŠ— (2013) Š—” Mr. Dickinson never pushes beyond the superficial. At times, he seems mainly to be mocking a certain kind of comfortably off, conspicuously arty Brooklynite, with scenes involving the real-life yogi Paul Manza and the musician and comedian Reggie Watts. Playing a supposed creative genius, Mr. Watts mugs and wiggles in loony videos that are among the movieŠ—Ès most grating moments.

Thanks to a classy soundtrack thatŠ—Ès heavy on the Vivaldi, and Adam Newport-BerraŠ—Ès mostly black-and-white photography, Š—“Creative ControlŠ— has a cool severity thatŠ—Ès occasionally quite beautiful. Yet its sterile aesthetic and strained conversations have a numbing effect that mimics the charactersŠ—È emotional disengagement. Lingering on the couch in his Google Glass-like specs, David fools around blissfully with the naked, simulated Sophie, while his actual partner, Juliette (Nora Zehetner), waits obliviously in bed. Sucked into this new addiction, David has persuaded himself that his virtual affair is real.

Depressing in the extreme, Š—“Creative ControlŠ— surfs its subject as if unaware of the possibilities. Watching David use his glasses to surreptitiously record his encounters with the real Sophie, I was reminded of a recent episode of the fascinating Showtime documentary series Š—“Dark Net,Š— in which a filmmaker who lost an eye in a gun accident replaced it with a camera. In a world, not that far off, where our every interaction could be recorded, how would we behave?

Not very authentically, I would imagine, but itŠ—Ès a question that Mr. Dickinson doesnŠ—Èt care to explore. What is scrutinized, most dispiritingly, is the shallowness of our aspirations. When presented with a magical new technology, is conjuring more lifelike blowup dolls really the highest we can reach?

Afghanistan has been a combat zone for so long that itŠ—Ès become a film genre unto itself, with documentaries like Š—“Restrepo,Š— features like Š—“Lone Survivor,Š— even comedies like Š—“Whiskey Tango Foxtrot.Š— Now a Canadian movie, Š—“Hyena Road,Š— adds another perspective.

Refreshingly free of jingoism, that detachment unfortunately winds up working against the movie, which doesnŠ—Èt engage emotionally. (That might explain a misguided subplot about SandersŠ—Ès romance with a female officer.) Even so, Š—“Hyena RoadŠ— is a skillfully filmed reminder, if one is needed, about why Afghanistan earned its status as the Š—“graveyard of empires.Š— DANIEL M. GOLD

Written and directed by Paul Gross, the film, which takes place before Canadian forces ended their military role in 2011, opens with a sniper team led by Ryan Sanders (Rossif Sutherland) killing a Taliban rebel who is planting an I.E.D. along a highway being built in Kandahar Province by coalition forces Š—” the Hyena Road. Soon, with Taliban fighters in pursuit, the team ducks into a village, where an elder hides them before disappearing himself. Back at base, Pete Mitchell (Mr. Gross), a military intelligence officer, tells Sanders he believes the teamŠ—Ès protector is the Ghost, a revered mujahedeen leader in the war against the Soviets (and who seems based on Š—“the lion of Panjshir,Š— Ahmed Shah Massoud). Mitchell thinks the Ghost could be a vital ally, and Sanders helps locate him. Before long, all three find themselves in harmŠ—Ès way.
Š—“Hyena RoadŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for war violence, language and sexual material.

In tutoring Sanders, Mitchell maintains a running commentary on the shifting alliances, and layers of insurgents, warlords, tribal loyalties and age-old clan feuds that make the nation all but impossible for outsiders to subdue.

With Š—“Lolo,Š— Julie Delpy (Š—“2 Days in New YorkŠ—) makes a much simpler addition to her prickly, idiosyncratic comedies, which have doubled as a frank running commentary on life (as with her roles in Richard LinklaterŠ—Ès films). In Ms. DelpyŠ—Ès broadest effort yet Š—” which she directs, and wrote with Eug’©nie Grandval Š—” she plays a Paris fashionista who dotes on a snooty son and finds their clingy bond getting in the way of a rejuvenating romance.

As an urbane schemer, Mr. Lacoste is proficient but not great at being the man we love to hate. Many little touches in the film reflect the offbeat hand of Ms. Delpy. But she sells herself short by not giving the mother-son conflict a bit of a sharper edge beyond LoloŠ—Ès awfulness.

Lolo (Vincent Lacoste, a house-music maven in Š—“EdenŠ—) is a simpering, heavy-lidded 19-year-old artist crashing with his divorced mom, Violette (Ms. Delpy). Prodded by her pal Ariane (Karin Viard), Violette pursues the dorky banking I.T. engineer Jean-Ren’© (the star comedian Dany Boon, playing decent straight man). Their lovey-dovey dating sets off LoloŠ—Ès Oedipal alarms, and he secretly schemes against Jean-Ren’© like someone out of a Moli’åre farce.

But Ms. DelpyŠ—Ès funniest writing here involves poking fun at insecurities about dating, and salty talk between Violette and Ariane. As a character, Lolo is a conceit of indulgent parenting and never fully blooms. The farcical disasters he sets in motion Š—” like getting Jean-Ren’© sloppy-drunk at a party honoring Karl Lagerfeld Š—” feel tired. And VioletteŠ—Ès blindness to her sonŠ—Ès behavior becomes a relatively unexploited joke.

In the opening scene, Lucien (Sylvain Dieuaide), a foppish, acid-tongued journalist, scales a wall to crash the war orphans benefit. Amused and horrified by her shrieks, he writes a slyly ambiguous review titled Š—“The OrphanŠ—Ès Voice,Š— which describes MargueriteŠ—Ès sound as revealing Š—“the human truth.Š— When the review is published, the Dumont mansion is mysteriously flooded with floral tributes, and Marguerite, interpreting LucienŠ—Ès words as a rave, befriends him.

Jenkins gave recitals for private audiences for three decades, until her major public concert debut in 1944 at Carnegie Hall was critically savaged and left her devastated. She died shortly thereafter. In a forthcoming biopic directed by Stephen Frears, she is played by Meryl Streep.

Georges, for all his faults, sincerely wants to protect his wife from the scourge of public ridicule. MargueriteŠ—Ès tragic flaw is her impenetrable narcissism. Her tin ear makes it impossible for her to gauge the sounds coming out of her own mouth. The actual voice heard in the film is a composite of Ms. FrotŠ—Ès and another voice dubbed and sometimes electronically altered; Ms. Frot does some skillful lip-syncing.

Š—“The self-deception that believes the lie.Š— That phrase from the Rodgers and Hart song Š—“I Wish I Were in Love againŠ— distills the theme of Š—“Marguerite,Š— Xavier GiannoliŠ—Ès satirical comedy about a tone-deaf would-be opera diva who thinks she can sing.

In the funniest scene, she is persuaded to screech the French national anthem in a nihilistic tableau vivant conceived by LucienŠ—Ès mischievous sidekick Kyril (Aubert Fenoy), an anarchist; the audience is scandalized, and Marguerite is ostracized.

Madelbos is instrumental in the hiring of a rotund, decadent voice teacher, Atos Pezzini (Michel Fau), a fading operatic tenor in desperate need of money whom he blackmails into coaching her. Like everybody else around Marguerite, Pezzini lies to her. He travels with a retinue of bohemians, including a bearded woman, who frequent a jazz club and are one step removed from circus attractions.

The story begins in 1921 with a performance by Marguerite in her mansion to benefit war orphans. One no-show is her unfaithful, financially dependent husband, Georges (Andr’© Marcon), who is so embarrassed by her singing that he can neither bring himself to attend (his car mysteriously breaks down) nor tell her the truth about her caterwauling. Protected by a conspiracy of silence orchestrated by her husband and her butler and driver, Madelbos (Denis Mpunga), Marguerite, whose identity is inseparable from the music she cannot sing, lives inside a bubble.

The character, Marguerite Dumont, is not to be confused with Margaret Dumont, the Marx BrothersŠ—È comic foil in seven films. The similarity of names, however, seems intentional in this lavishly appointed period fantasy, inspired by the life of Florence Foster Jenkins, an American socialite and aspiring opera singer who was the butt of a cruel joke that everyone got but her.

A sweet-natured na’Àf with a streak of grandiosity, Marguerite is embodied by the great French actress Catherine Frot, who recently won a C’©sar, the French equivalent of an Oscar, for her performance. Her screeching, off-pitch desecrations of MozartŠ—Ès Š—“Queen of the NightŠ— aria from Š—“The Magic Flute,Š— the Bellini aria Š—“Casta DivaŠ— from Š—“NormaŠ— and other coloratura showpieces are accurately captured in a movie that gleefully lays waste to the pretensions of highbrow musical culture. The world it uncovers is a poisonous nest of preening dandies, bejeweled grande dames, hypocritical sycophants and assorted hangers-on.

The most serious failing of Š—“MargueriteŠ— is that it doesnŠ—Èt know when to stop. An undeveloped, time-wasting subplot is thrown in involving LucienŠ—Ès shy pursuit of Hazel (Christa Th’©ret), a promising young soprano who sings at the same benefit and has all the talent Marguerite lacks. But as a character or a symbolic counterweight to Marguerite, she barely exists.

Š—“MargueriteŠ— is in French, with English subtitles. It is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for brief graphic nudity, sexual content and drug use. Running time: 2 hours 7 minutes.

The movie is divided into chapters organized around a series of photo sessions featuring Marguerite elaborately costumed for various roles and striking poses. For one session, she dons angel wings and wears a diamond tiara. The photographer is the enigmatic, mostly silent Madelbos, whose slavish loyalty recalls Max von Mayerling, Norma DesmondŠ—Ès butler in Š—“Sunset Boulevard.Š— Periodically the movie shows a close-up of an eye as Madelbos peers through the camera lens like a spy.

Like a self-enraptured, attention-starved diva who canŠ—Èt tear herself away from the stage after the applause has faded, Š—“MargueriteŠ— overstays its welcome by at least 20 minutes. What redeems it is Ms. FrotŠ—Ès subtle, deeply compassionate portrayal of a rich, lonely woman clutching at an impossible dream until reality intrudes.

Mr. LandisŠ—Ès sensibility, which combines sitcom jokiness with mumblecore sentimentality, tends to be more grating than amusing in Š—“Me Him Her,Š— though scattered moments will make you laugh. (Movie nerds will appreciate that in one of its appearances, the penis is outlined against Saul BassŠ—Ès vortex design for Š—“Vertigo.Š—)

High jinks ensue, including a fairly funny back-seat sex scene and a not so funny moment-of-truth-in-your-underwear scene in the desert that echoes Š—“Breaking Bad.Š— Occasionally, Mr. Landis slides into fantasy Š—” Gabbi and Cory float on a bed through the solar system, and a giant penis shows up to threaten both her and Brendan.

Š—“Me Him Her,Š— a loose, rambling, indie comedy, shows the mark of one of the fatherŠ—Ès less well-known films, the cult favorite Š—“Into the NightŠ— from 1985. ThereŠ—Ès something about that year Š—” Mr. LandisŠ—Ès debut also echoes the rhythms and style of a couple of other 1985 indie-style comedies, Martin ScorseseŠ—Ès Š—“After HoursŠ— and Susan SeidelmanŠ—Ès Š—“Desperately Seeking Susan.Š— When Mr. Landis finds his sweet spot, he stays there.

The screenwriter and director Max Landis Š—” he wrote the recent action-comedy-horror-thriller mash-ups Š—“American UltraŠ— and Š—“Victor FrankensteinŠ— Š—” is the son of John Landis. You can see the elder LandisŠ—Ès touch in Max LandisŠ—Ès first feature as a director, Š—“Me Him Her.Š— But itŠ—Ès not Š—“Animal HouseŠ— that shows up.

His hazily focused screenplay entwines three stories of late-20-somethings emerging from confusion. Brendan (Luke Bracey) is a macho television star who wants to come out of the closet; his best friend, Cory (Dustin Milligan), is a slacker idiot who may want to grow up; Gabbi (Emily Meade), whom Cory meets in a gay bar, is a lesbian who discovers to her horror that she enjoys sex with men, or at least with Cory.
Š—“Me Him HerŠ— is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 37 minutes.

Ms. Meade (Š—“The LeftoversŠ—) makes the strongest impression among the three leads, giving Gabbi a hesitant, awkward intensity. Perhaps reflecting Mr. LandisŠ—Ès Hollywood heritage, a number of recognizable performers, old and new, pop up in small parts Š—” Casey Wilson, Kyle Bornheimer, Chris Hardwick, Haley Joel Osment (as himself) and, most pleasingly, Scott Bakula and Geena Davis as BrendanŠ—Ès solicitous parents.

Š—“Eye in the SkyŠ— covers many of the same issues addressed in Š—“Good Kill,Š— Andrew NiccolŠ—Ès underrated critique of American drone strikes in Afghanistan, released last year. At what point does warfare by remote control become an impersonal video game in which the human element is overlooked in the pursuit of a so-called Š—“good killŠ—? In that movie, Ethan Hawke played a drone operator in Las Vegas increasingly sickened by having to deploy missiles that killed women and children. The movie reserved special contempt for the Central Intelligence Agency, whose attitude toward collateral damage was portrayed as one of indifference. Mr. PaulŠ—Ès pilot, like Mr. HawkeŠ—Ès in Š—“Good Kill,Š— is the farthest thing from a blas’© video-gamer eager to set off an explosion. At moments, he seems near tears.

General Benson is Mr. RickmanŠ—Ès final screen performance, and it is a great one, suffused with a dyspeptic world-weary understanding of war and human nature. Because his character is observed early in the movie buying a doll for a child, he is not unsympathetic so much as profoundly sad. Ms. Mirren has rarely been icier, and her powerful, scary performance doesnŠ—Èt strive to make her character likable.
Š—“Eye in the SkyŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for violent images and strong language. Running time: 1 hour 42 minutes.

The movie still makes very clear the contrast between military personnel who want to discharge their duties as efficiently as possible, and their more cautious overseers who calculate the chances that the attacks could spur a diplomatic crisis, or worse.

That means securing an official go-ahead to deploy a Hellfire missile on a house in a crowded neighborhood in Nairobi, Kenya, where terrorists are meeting. But the British foreign secretary is at an arms trade fair in Singapore and the American secretary of state is attending a table tennis tournament in Beijing. How inconvenient! Meanwhile, the military, champing at the bit to unleash its firepower before the terrorists disperse, are increasingly frustrated.

An assistant of Colonel Powell is strongly pressured to estimate the chances of the girlŠ—Ès being killed as less than 50 percent, in which case Colonel Powell can give the order to proceed. Another film might have found black comedy in the continuing Š—“risk assessmentŠ— that accompanies each step of the operation. But Š—“Eye in the SkyŠ— allows the storyŠ—Ès absurdist elements to speak for themselves.

Colonel Powell quickly secures permission from her superior, Lt. Gen. Frank Benson (Alan Rickman), to upgrade the order from Š—“captureŠ— to Š—“kill.Š— Those orders are relayed to Steve Watts (Aaron Paul), a drone pilot in Las Vegas poised to launch the air-to-surface missile. But unforeseen interruptions keep delaying the attack.

As in Š—“Good Kill,Š— civilians keep intruding into the line of sight at the last second. Moments before the Nairobi attack is to begin, a spunky little girl (Aisha Takow) selling bread posts herself opposite the terroristsŠ—È house, and nothing can be done until she leaves. A Somali undercover agent (Barkhad Abdi, from Š—“Captain Phillips) is dispatched to buy up her loaves, but that assignment is interrupted.

Helen Mirren, in one of her fiercest screen performances, plays Col. Katherine Powell, the chilly officer in charge of Egret, an operation to capture a radicalized English woman meeting with Shabab terrorists at the house in Nairobi. Colonel Powell has been pursuing her for years. But as the moment of capture arrives, Colonel PowellŠ—Ès plans abruptly change when a cyborg beetle, a small whirring surveillance device, reveals two inhabitants strapping on explosives for a suicide mission.

The metallic spy, the movieŠ—Ès creepiest element, reinforces the Orwellian notion that nowadays there are no hiding places if the powers-that-be are out to get you. The charactersŠ—È robotic techno argot, intended to convey military expertise while camouflaging human element, is equally Orwellian.
Mr. Rickman, musing in oracular tones, delivers the filmŠ—Ès despairing overview that pierces to the heart: Š—“Never tell a soldier that he does not know the cost of war.Š—

Š—“Eye in the Sky,Š— directed by Gavin Hood (Š—“TsotsiŠ—) from a screenplay by Guy Hibbert (Š—“Five Minutes of HeavenŠ—), is a grim, suspenseful farce in which unpredictable human behavior repeatedly threatens an operation of astounding technological sophistication. Like many films of its type, it doesnŠ—Èt dwell on geopolitical minutiae.

Sharper, better made and better acted, Š—“Eye in the Sky,Š— doesnŠ—Èt present as overtly critical a view of drone warfare. The military officers take their work seriously and fret over every detail as they try to estimate the number of casualties for various scenarios.

An alternative title to Š—“Eye in the Sky,Š— a riveting thriller about drone warfare and its perils, might be Š—“Passing the Buck.Š— When urgent life-or-death decisions are required in a race against time to kill terrorists preparing a suicide attack, officials, wary of being held responsible for civilian casualties, repeatedly Š—“refer upŠ— to higher authorities for final approval.

Alas, the plot and subplots are variations on time-honored Hong Kong cinema devices: The young Fei (played as an adult by Eddie Peng) grows up training alongside a buddy, Fiery (Jing Boran); both pine for the same woman, Chun (Wang Luodan), a minder of street waifs. Fei, a formidable warrior, is adopted by the kingpin Lei Gong (the kung fu movie veteran Sammo Hung), only to subvert his empire. When Chun and Fiery lead an insurrection and torch Lei GongŠ—Ès opium dens, furious but graceful brawls (orchestrated by the renowned fight choreographer Corey Yuen) erupt.

The blending of vast sets and digital effects is not quite seamless in Chow Hin YeungŠ—Ès kung fu period extravaganza Š—“Rise of the Legend,Š— but itŠ—Ès close. Revisiting the story of Wong Fei Hung, a martial arts master whose life has passed into Chinese folklore, Š—“LegendŠ— takes place in 19th-century Guangzhou, where two crime factions vie for control of the docks. This movieŠ—Ès Guangzhou is a marvel: sprawling, detailed, abounding in narrow alleys and vivid street scenes.

Mr. Peng has charisma, though his moves are less convincing than those of an earlier Fei: Jet Li, in Tsui HarkŠ—Ès 1991 classic Š—“Once Upon a Time in ChinaŠ— (and less humorous than those of Jackie Chan, who played Fei in Š—“The Legend of Drunken Master,Š— a.k.a. Š—“Drunken Master 2,Š— from 1994). But Š—“LegendŠ— does offer the hefty authority of Mr. Hung, who at 64 can still Š—” almost Š—” hit, kick and do wire work with the best of them.
Š—“The Brothers GrimsbyŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for gun violence and assaulted genitals. Running time: 1 hour 18 minutes.

So, you know, Bob Hope and Bing Crosby reloaded, except that now itŠ—Ès Mr. Cohen and Mark Strong swimming both in fountains of fluids and an elephant vagina that proves as bustling as Grand Central Terminal at rush hour. If that sounds gross, it is; more important, it isnŠ—Èt funny, starting with the premise. As a comedian, Mr. Cohen revels in extremes. At his best, he can push an outrageous conceit right up to its limits (and yours). HeŠ—Ès especially adept at finding that sweet, destabilizing spot where an audienceŠ—Ès comfortable laughter turns suddenly, confusingly, queasy. But while there may be comedy gold in an elephantŠ—Ès vagina, Mr. Cohen fails to find it here.

The problem is partly rhythmic. Like too many of the more elaborate comic bits in Š—“Grimsby,Š— the elephant sketch soon drags and dies, its foundational visual gag (Jonah in pachyderm privates) never reaching gagging hilarity. Mr. Cohen just seems off his game in Š—“Grimsby,Š— and it may be that the movieŠ—Ès high concept proved too constricting for someone who has done some of his best work (as in the Š—“BoratŠ— film) with a looser, more episodic format. He seems boxed in, rather than liberated by, the spy movie, which of course is already self-parodying, as illustrated in the opener of Š—“Grimsby,Š— which crams an entire franchise of action-movie clich’©s under the credits.

Mostly, Mr. Cohen is done in by his character, Nobby, a mutton-chopped caricature of vulgarity whose unreconstructed stupidity and deep-veined sentimentality suggest that he may have other relatives tearing it up in Mike LeighŠ—Ès class-conscious comedies. Mr. Cohen remains committed to his inner adolescent, but he has latched onto a potentially sharp political idea in Š—“GrimsbyŠ—: that the British poor are every bit as tough, ingenious, spirited and finally murderous as an agent in Her MajestyŠ—Ès Secret Service. Mr. Cohen has a gift for plumbing the depths of ignorance, and other peopleŠ—Ès rank stupidity has been both his target and weapon. In Nobby, he instead finds a hero, and defeat.

A Freudian might be able to make something of Sacha Baron CohenŠ—Ès emphasis on bodily orifices and protrusions in Š—“The Brothers Grimsby.Š— I prefer a more obvious explanation: At some point during the making of this 1-hour-18-minute burlesque, Mr. Cohen became bored. Given the production budget, the pitch was obviously good enough for someone to write a check and hire an action director, Louis Leterrier, who could give the material the requisite spit-shine: After years of separation, two drastically different brothers Š—” a sleek superspy and a bumbling fool Š—” reunite and, in between guffaws, heal old wounds, zip around the world and fight a global crime syndicate.

DorisŠ—Ès burgeoning friendship with John, meanwhile, leads her down alternately goofy and sweet avenues involving online stalking, late-night clubbing and new alliances, including with his girlfriend, Brooklyn (Beth Behrs). DorisŠ—Ès female attachments, including with her best friend, Roz (Tyne Daly), are particularly appealing because Š—” as with JohnŠ—Ès first kindness Š—” theyŠ—Ère reminders that you can tell a lot about people from how they are loved. To that end, in one funny, meaningful passage, Doris ends up at a concert with John, wearing an eye-popping yellow outfit, a look that draws compliments and attention from various young revelers, who, treating her as a kindred spirit, are understandably taken with her. Doris turns out to be an excellent mirror, including for your own chauvinism.

Indirection can be a beautiful tool in comedy and so it is in Š—“Hello, My Name Is Doris,Š— which uses this funny, outwardly ridiculous character to tell a simple story about a love that rarely speaks its name, including in movies: that of an older woman for a much younger man. These kinds of screen stories have always been few and far between, and itŠ—Ès instructive, given the prevailing cultural horror of aging, that some of the more memorable ones turn on her-or-his pathology, whether itŠ—Ès the deranged actress in Š—“Sunset BoulevardŠ— or the traumatized boy-man in the cult film Š—“Harold and Maude.Š— Doris has issues, mostly grief and social isolation, which Ms. Field makes movingly real with a performance that reveals its truth incrementally.

The first time that the heroine in the disarming comedy Š—“Hello, My Name Is DorisŠ— sees the kid, theyŠ—Ère in a crowded office elevator. HeŠ—Ès not a child at all, but somewhere in his mid-30s, which can seem light-years away for a woman who has been of a certain age for decades. So when he jostles Doris (Sally Field), she braces for the usual morning-elevator scrum. Instead, he straightens her lopsided eyeglasses. With this one small, human kindness he does something that astonishes Doris, something that doesnŠ—Èt often happen to the worldŠ—Ès invisible women: He sees her.

Not that Doris, whoŠ—Ès in her 60s, tries to be invisible, exactly. From her cat-eye glasses to the headscarves that make her look hastily regifted, she seems like someone yearning to be seen. But wrinkles have a way of making women disappear one crease at a time, and Doris, whoŠ—Ès in mourning when the movie opens, has done her part to vanish. When this kid Š—” he turns out to be a new co-worker, John (Max Greenfield, an effortless charmer) Š—” notices Doris, it changes everything. Doris is more than just surprised by his attention, she is also transformed. He makes her visible, most importantly to herself, a revelation that turns Doris into a woman who desires and is desired in turn. ItŠ—Ès a ferocious awakening.

The movie starts big and broad at the funeral for DorisŠ—Ès mother, where everyone is shedding stage tears. Mr. Showalter continues to play with comic tone and mood Š—” he folds in some slapstick, enables the mugging and stages several cringing fantasy sequences that encourage you to laugh at Doris. Š—“Hello, My Name Is DorisŠ— is rated R (under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for some language, none of which should shock anybody. Running time: 1 hour 30 minutes.

Less interestingly, Doris has also become a hoarder. ItŠ—Ès also a fairly slow, gaudy bloom. Like his heroine, the director Michael Showalter eagerly oversells the goods. Right off, he throws in a lot thatŠ—Ès hard on the eyes and ears. ThereŠ—Ès DorisŠ—Ès dowager-dumpster wardrobe and topsy-turvy Staten Island house, along with her mutterings and facial contortions, which seem one tic away from a medical diagnosis. As he puts these messy parts into play, I kept thinking no, no, no, no. ItŠ—Ès all much too much (those shoes, that hair!) and together they announce that youŠ—Ère in for an ingratiatingly cutesy slog about a lovable kook Š—” except that the movie and Doris arenŠ—Èt easy to love, which is partly why they work.

Two high school sweethearts, Victor and Ginger (Robert Christopher Riley and Lauren London), are planning a wedding, and Victor canŠ—Èt quite handle the fact that his future wife is a bigger earner than he. Adapted from Anne RiceŠ—Ès 2005 best seller Š—“Christ the Lord: Out of EgyptŠ— (the reverent script is by Mr. Nowrasteh and his wife, Betsy Giffen Nowrasteh), and devoid of dramatic tension, the film hits New Testament basics as it depicts the flight of Joseph, Mary and their son from Alexandria, in Egypt, to Nazareth and eventually to Jerusalem.

It doesnŠ—Èt take long for the Devil (never identified onscreen, but described in publicity materials as the Demon) to frame Jesus (the newcomer Adam Greaves-Neal, all gentle eyes and British accent) for a fatal encounter with a bully. Mojdeh (Hedieh Tehrani), the central character of Š—“Fireworks Wednesday,Š— is a cold, haughty woman who suspects her husband, Morteza (Hamid Farokh-Nejad), of having an affair with Simin (Pantea Bahram), a divorced beautician, who lives next door. Š—“Fireworks WednesdayŠ— is not rated. It is in Persian, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 44 minutes.

People set off fireworks and make bonfires in the streets. As dusk falls, the racket intensifies. The celebrations, which suggest a combination of Halloween and the Fourth of July, but without masks, costumes or political pageantry, grow more chaotic and fraught with danger. Complicating matters, a buzzer in the coupleŠ—Ès apartment that allows guests entry into the building is broken, and visitors have to ring SiminŠ—Ès buzzer to get in. Neighbors have complained about the beauty shop, which Simin operates illegally in her apartment.
