As RouhiŠ—Ès reluctant involvement deepens, the light in her eyes dims. And her blissful expectations for the future are tainted by doubt. When Abdolreza interrogates her at the end of an exhausting day, clouds have darkened the sunny skies.

On a superficial level, the movie is a tawdry tale of marital discord in which Mojdeh and Morteza go at it tooth and nail. Their plans to visit Dubai with their young son, Amir Ali (Matin Heydarnia), are disrupted by their domestic strife. Their apartment, strewn with possessions under sheets of plastic, is in a state of chaos. There is a smashed window, broken by Morteza in a fit of rage.

The holiday, a time of spring cleaning and dressing up in new clothes for family reunions, is the backdrop for this incisive 2006 film by Mr. Farhadi, the Iranian director who achieved international recognition with Š—“A Separation.Š—

The movie pointedly contrasts Mojdeh with Rouhi (Taraneh Alidousti), an ebullient young woman first seen on the back of a motorcycle driven by her fianc’©, Abdolreza (Houman Seyedi). When her chador becomes caught in one of the bikeŠ—Ès wheels, they narrowly avoid an accident. Hired by Mojdeh as a house cleaner, Rouhi takes a bus to the apartment, where she finds herself embroiled in the domestic dispute. Mojdeh enlists her to pick up Amir Ali at his school, and to spy on Simin by going next door for a beauty treatment for which Mojdeh pays.

Belatedly released in the United States, Š—“Fireworks WednesdayŠ— is Mr. FarhadiŠ—Ès third film, with a screenplay by him and Mani Haghighi. The same gender conflict drove Mr. FarhadiŠ—Ès fourth film, Š—“About Elly,Š— released last year, in which a lurking unease affected couples sharing a house on a summer holiday. In their sophistication and unsparing portraiture of grown-up combatants, these films are diametrically opposite in spirit to the first wave of Iranian films focusing on children and nature.

In the film, the festival is a reflection of the troubled marriage of an affluent middle-aged couple and, by extension, a larger battleground in an undeclared war of attrition between the sexes and the classes. Iranian society may be a traditional patriarchy, but at least in the sophisticated precincts of Tehran, its capital city, wives often call the shots, and husbands tremble in fear of their rage. As with Mr. FarhadiŠ—Ès other films, every detail of speech and body language resonates.

If you didnŠ—Èt know that the continual explosions heard in Asghar FarhadiŠ—Ès film Š—“Fireworks WednesdayŠ— were the sounds of firecrackers and cherry bombs celebrating the Persian New Year in the streets of Tehran, they could easily be mistaken for deadly wartime explosions in a city under siege. Christy proves to be a determined mother, flying with Anna from their Texas home to implore a specialist in Boston to treat the girl. Yet despite ChristyŠ—Ès Christian faith Š—” the opening of the movie shows the Beams preparing for church Š—” she begins to doubt God as AnnaŠ—Ès condition worsens.

Š—“Miracles From HeavenŠ— is rated PG (Parents strongly cautioned) for a few tough scenes of childhood illness and pain. Running time: 1 hour 49 minutes.

Adapted by Randy Brown from Christy BeamŠ—Ès memoir, the film, directed by Patricia Riggen, focuses much more on the familyŠ—Ès love and sacrifices than on its specific creed. Even scenes set in a church look to uplift viewers rather than convert them. Š—“Miracles From HeavenŠ— is based on Š—“the incredible true storyŠ— of the Beam family. The installation itself paid homage to 20th-century engineering and applied science. From NASA identity cards to excursion module to land vehicle, the Mars project created the components for Mission Control and each phase of the journey out of steel and plywood and found objects. Spacesuits, for example, were made from the Tyvek of many an overnight mailing envelope. Š—“Our space program is handmade,Š— Mr. Sachs explains, Š—“guided by the philosophy of bricolage.Š—

As much installation video as documentary, Van NeistatŠ—Ès film is the record of an extended tongue-in-cheek simulation of a voyage to Mars by the artist Tom Sachs and a crew of assistants that was performed before an amused audience at the Park Avenue Armory in 2012. It comes at the front edge of a boomlet of Sachs openings: a solo show at the Noguchi Museum in Queens next Wednesday, and an exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum in April.

Whatever else the film carries, it packs some serious whimsy. The Mars landing is handled by an astronaut successfully completing an ancient Atari video game; planetary explorations to gather and dispatch samples feature a handsaw and bottle rockets. Displaying primitive ingenuity, the movie recalls Georges M’©li’ås and the early days of cinema. And as a tribute to NASA, Š—“A Space ProgramŠ— is rich in the core elements that have always propelled humanityŠ—Ès flights of fancy: imagination and the right tools.

Š—“The Martian,Š— Ridley ScottŠ—Ès big-budget Hollywood adaptation of Andy WeirŠ—Ès novel, gave a sense of how a state-of-the-art mission to the red planet might look. Now Š—“A Space ProgramŠ— offers a decidedly low-tech alternative.

Spouting biological balderdash with a commendably straight face, David declares Tris Š—“pure,Š— a designation that comes with all-white outfits and an all-access pass to DavidŠ—Ès private aerie. (This doesnŠ—Èt sit well with Four, who, being Š—“damaged,Š— is stuck below, wearing Mad MaxŠ—Ès postapocalyptic castoffs.) Tris, too, seems becalmed and unsure, vacillating between DavidŠ—Ès professed humanitarianism and FourŠ—Ès insistence that evil is afoot. Š—“The Divergent Series: AllegiantŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Body slams and lip locks. Running time: 2 hours.

The Š—“DivergentŠ— series Š—” a derivative saga of family, factions and overstressed females Š—” soldiers within sight of the finish line with its third installment, Š—“Allegiant.Š— But a story that kicked off two years ago at a reasonable gallop has now slowed to barely a limp.

The first film in a two-part finale (the second, Š—“Ascendant,Š— is expected next year), Š—“AllegiantŠ— sends Tris (Shailene Woodley), her brother, Caleb (Ansel Elgort) and her hunky squeeze, Four (Theo James, even more expressionless than usual if thatŠ—Ès possible), fleeing from a still-walled-in Chicago. One shower of toxic rain and a blasted landscape later, they wash up at the gleamingly pristine Bureau of Genetic Welfare, where David (a smugly sinister Jeff Daniels) presides over unspecified hanky-panky with the human genome.

Beaming and blunt in equal measure, Š—“Everything Is Copy,Š— Jacob BernsteinŠ—Ès gossipy tribute to his mother, the writer and director Nora Ephron, is bursting with so many fond and famous faces that you can imagine its subject swooning with delight Š—” and then criticizing their makeup.

That engagingly confessional humor, showcased here in clips from EphronŠ—Ès many television appearances, injected her romantic comedies with blasts of uniquely authentic insight. In particular, a tantalizing segment with the directorŠ—Ès father, the journalist Carl Bernstein, casts a slightly different light on the painful divorce that Ephron seemingly laid bare in her novel-turned-movie, Š—“HeartburnŠ— (1986). Digging into the psychological space between her wildly public life and intensely private death, Š—“Everything Is CopyŠ— is a pickle slathered in whipped cream. Just like its subject.

Š—“She was very funny and very mean,Š— says Barbara Walters, as a portrait builds of a fiercely ambitious, highly opinionated and instinctively empathic hustler who found her voice when her essays for Esquire magazine in the 1970s intersected with an invigorated womenŠ—Ès movement. To read her was to discover a scathingly witty and bossy best friend, one whose willingness to air her failings and insecurities encouraged us to laugh at our own.

The latest project to prove that making a 10-minute webisode is nothing at all like making a feature film is Š—“Ktown Cowboys,Š— a mess of a movie about five young men on the prowl in the Koreatown section of Los Angeles. They sample various forms of night life while grown-up problems bark at the door, and eventually bonding occurs, but the film doesnŠ—Èt have the focus, pacing or plotting of the best of such bromance tales.

The web series of the same name is better, and the temptation to try a feature film must have been irresistible: The episodes have hundreds of thousands of views. But the movie-length treatment exposes the limitations of the actors, and the storytelling becomes diffuse.
Š—“Ktown CowboysŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for strong language, most of it about sex.

The main plotline belongs to Jason (Shane Yoon), who runs his uncleŠ—Ès company and has sailed it into troubled waters that include an F.B.I. investigation. Danny (Danny Cho, who is also among the filmŠ—Ès writers) is a struggling comic; Sunny (Sunn Wee) has a parent-care problem; and Robby (Bobby Choy), who was adopted by a white couple, is wondering about his roots. Peter Jae plays the most interesting character, a muscle-bound fashion designer, but his story is underdeveloped.

Mr. Shannon Š—” whose broad forehead, squinting eyes and hard-set jaw are as essential to Mr. NicholsŠ—Ès imagination as shotguns and pickup trucks Š—” shows up in Š—“Midnight SpecialŠ— as one of a pair of outlaws who have recently kidnapped a child. Or so it appears. Though Roy (Mr. Shannon) and Lucas (Joel Edgerton) are grim-faced, heavily armed and unnervingly competent, their victim, a boy named Alton (Jaeden Lieberher), doesnŠ—Èt seem afraid of them, and indeed acts more like an accomplice than like prey.

At its heart, Š—“Midnight SpecialŠ— is a parable of parental love, a heartfelt look at the challenges involved in loving and possibly losing an extraordinary child. Š—“I like worrying about you,Š— Roy says to Alton at an especially grave and touching moment, and his words are a beautiful and concise summary of a common emotion. The context in which they occur is completely outlandish, and the charm and audacity of this film lie in the way it blends the commonplace and the bizarre.

The scene shifts quickly to a religious compound that sets off another, equally misleading, set of associations. Here is a stern patriarch (Sam Shepard) flanked by goons in bad suits. Here are platoons of women with long plaited hair and long homespun dresses. Here is the F.B.I., coming in heavy. We might assume that weŠ—Ère in the territory of the Branch Davidians or a polygamous quasi-Mormon sect. It seems possible that Alton, who was taken from their midst, was not abducted but rescued.

My only real quarrel is with the blandness of the bizarre stuff. What is meant to be a dazzling climax, a flight of visual sublimity, looks a little too much like images pulled from an advertiserŠ—Ès dream board or an architectŠ—Ès digital sketchpad. Sometimes the best move for a visionary is to keep the visions out of sight. And the surest way to arouse a sense of wonder is to leave us with something to wonder about.

The music that plays over the end credits gives the trickiness a final flourish. ItŠ—Ès an updated cover of the song (most famously recorded by Lead Belly) that inspired the title. You may well wonder what that old, defiant prison ballad has to do with what you just saw. I have some thoughts on the subject. The Midnight Special in the song is, strictly speaking, a train, but itŠ—Ès also a symbol of redemption, one of many that decorate the many-colored garment of American folklore.
Š—“Midnight SpecialŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Rough magic.  Running time: 1 hour 51 minutes.

Roy, we learn, is AltonŠ—Ès father, and Lucas is an old buddy of RoyŠ—Ès who has literally seen the light. The boyŠ—Ès disappearance becomes less a matter of religious freedom and pastoral authority than of national security, as a geeky National Security Agency operative (Adam Driver) takes over the case from the law enforcement guys. The boy somehow has access to top-secret codes and coordinates. He becomes a human GPS, tracing a zigzagging route along the picturesque back roads of Texas and Louisiana and pausing to visit his mother, Sarah (Kirsten Dunst), and to pull a satellite out of the sky into a parking lot.

Who is this kid supposed to be? Jesus? E. T.? Clark Kent? Edward Snowden? Mr. Nichols, whose fondness for high-stakes boys-adventure stories was especially evident in the Mark Twain-inflected Š—“MudŠ— (2013), plays with various allusions and possibilities. He doesnŠ—Èt overdo the self-consciousness, but he knows that the audience has a soft spot for unusual children, whose aura of innocence is a screen for otherworldly powers. Alton could be a boy genius or a musical prodigy. The adults in his life fear for his safety and are also a little afraid of him, and their desire to protect him is mingled with the urge to exploit his gifts.

Mr. Nichols, a writer and director of three previous features, has a sincere interest in the traditions of American spirituality, including its wilder manifestations. He is also willing to entertain Š—” and to entertain his audience with Š—” the possibility that the zealots and crackpots may be onto something. In his second feature, Š—“Take Shelter,Š— (2011) Michael Shannon played a hard-working family man plagued by forebodings of cosmic catastrophe. The movie spun a web of anxiety and ambiguity around the question of whether he was delusional or clairvoyant.

Alton has just been introduced to comic books, which he pores over with scholarly intensity as if they were works of reference rather than fantasy. And in comics, anything can happen. The rules of space, time and narrative order can be redrafted at will, as long as the writers and inkers stay on the right side of the line that separates chaos from coherence. Mr. Nichols has an efficient, naturalistic style. His movies look and sound like Sundance-sourced exercises in regional realism, and he is sensitive to the nuances of feeling that infuse even the strangest circumstances, and also the most ordinary.

As it turns out Š—” and here the spoiler siren starts to wail in earnest Š—” he isnŠ—Èt a member of the flock at all, but rather its godhead. You get that impression looking into his eyes, especially when tractor beams of bright blue radiance shoot out of them like bolts from Harry PotterŠ—Ès wand. His gaze has the power to set walls, grown men and the earth itself atremble.

Readers afflicted with extreme spoiler sensitivity may want to cover their ears and start humming right now, since even the vaguest, most careful description of Jeff NicholsŠ—Ès Š—“Midnight SpecialŠ— risks giving away some important surprises. This is a film that generates much of its suspense through genre sleight of hand. If I even try to tell you what kind of movie it is Š—” crime story, road picture, science-fiction allegory, religious prophecy Š—” I might be telling you something youŠ—Èd rather not know just yet.

The story is straightforward; the telling, less so. It opens on the middle-aged Paul (Mathieu Amalric, Mr. DesplechinŠ—Ès longtime collaborator), an anthropologist in Tajikistan. HeŠ—Ès packing for his return to France after a lengthy time abroad, and trading looks with a slinky blonde, Irina (Dinara Drukarova), whoŠ—Ès in a manŠ—Ès shirt and little else. The women in his life run the gamut: blond, brunet, young, old, underdressed, undressed, sane and rather less so. When this one crawls on top of him in bed, he murmurs in voice-over, Š—“I remember,Š— as the scene fades to black. What follows are three epoch-defining chapters from PaulŠ—Ès life, the longest dedicated to the turbulent teenage affair thatŠ—Ès still haunting him in the filmŠ—Ès epilogue.

Š—“My Golden DaysŠ— is rated R (under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for love and desire, bien s’r. It is in French, Russian and Hebrew, with English subtitles. Running time: 2 hours.

Mr. Desplechin stages and shoots this encounter beautifully, pulling back to show Paul walking across a suddenly emptied courtyard toward Esther. As Paul walks, the wind picks up, and fallen leaves begin eddying around his feet, their swirling movement echoing the fluid, sweeping camera and helping shift the movie from its more familiar realism into a lyrical register. Head bowed, Paul approaches Esther like a sly supplicant, advancing obliquely; she, in turn, appears haughty and amused as she looks down from her perch. The distance between them disappears when he at last sits next to her, inaugurating a flirty conversation relayed in sumptuous close-up.

Did it happen this way? Did the leaves scatter and Esther smile with such seductive knowing? Does it matter? For Paul, these memories are the truth (Š—“I rememberŠ—), the foundations of his existence. They have shaped him, making him the man who, when someone asks, Š—“Who are you?,Š— looks genuinely bewildered. Š—“I canŠ—Èt remember,Š— Paul answers. ItŠ—Ès a strange assertion, particularly given that most of the movie is a collection of remembrances. Then again, as Paul says several times, Š—“life is strange,Š— a (true) statement that becomes as much a refrain in Š—“My Golden DaysŠ— as another of his repeated confessions: Š—“I feel nothing.Š—

These first two sections move swiftly and elliptically. Like the first, the second turns on a flashback introduced by the adult Paul, who, having been stopped at the French airport, ends up describing his mysterious Soviet trip to a French intelligence agent (Andr’© Dussollier). As the present gives way again to the past, Paul recounts how, during his Soviet jaunt, he gave his passport to a Jewish dissident, who assumed PaulŠ—Ès identity, becoming an effective double. Mr. Desplechin likes to throw a lot into his stories, and not everything he puts into play necessarily seems to fit. But the passport and PaulŠ—Ès refusenik doppelg’_nger add layers to a story that, chapter by chapter, evolves into a meditation on identity.

The brilliant French director Arnaud Desplechin likes to mix lofty touchstones with George Clinton beats, slipping in nods to Š—“UlyssesŠ— alongside the post-punk band Marine Girls. ThereŠ—Ès a restless intelligence to his sampling, which always feels organic, experiential instead of merely ornamental. In Š—“My Golden Days,Š— which largely takes place in the 1980s, every musical, literary and fashion cue speaks to the moment when Paul began a feverish love affair. When he reads the Yeats poem Š—“Among School ChildrenŠ— (Š—“She stands before me as a living childŠ—), thereŠ—Ès meaning in the moment, as there is when the score picks up a haunting thread from Alfred HitchcockŠ—Ès Š—“Vertigo.Š—

Š—“My Golden DaysŠ— is a memory movie, a story told through a glass darkly. By the second chapter, Paul is a lanky adolescent (the newcomer Quentin Dolmaire) and a jittery charmer, ready for love. Yet Paul, we know, feels deeply, all the way to the shattering epilogue, which suggests that his memories of Esther Š—” who, teary encounter by teary encounter, he makes the very image of the needy woman consumed by passion Š—” donŠ—Èt line up with who she was. The final scene echoes the opening, with Paul once again in bed with a woman he will separate from. For all the slim-hipped boys who cluster around him, it is women Š—” his mother, his great-aunt, her lover, his beloved professor and, most important, Esther Š—” who serve as the signposts in his life. They help write the story of this solitary man, this restive anthropologist, who, after leaving his tribe and losing his identity, has a chance to make himself whole with a girl whose love is, at last, too great for him to bear.

Near the end of Š—“My Golden Days,Š— an elegy for young love and its lingering ache, a wind starts to stir. Š—“The hour of the waning of love has beset us,Š— William Butler Yeats writes in his poem Š—“The Falling of the Leaves.Š— Paul, we know, began reading Yeats early.

Along comes Tokue, an old woman, seemingly out of nowhere. Played by Kirin Kiki, she has a disarming smile, but also a haunted air Š—” it seems to follow two steps behind her. Early in the film, as cherry blossom trees flower outside his place, we see him preparing batter, frying it up and putting dollops of red bean paste between two little pancakes. HeŠ—Ès devoted to his work, but somethingŠ—Ès missing.
The movie, beautifully shot and acted, earns its ultimate sense of hope by confronting real heartbreak head-on, and with compassion.

If youŠ—Ève ever wondered what became of the young Japanese actor who played the insouciant, too-cool-for-Elvis (he preferred Carl Perkins) rock-and-roll fan in Jim JarmuschŠ—Ès 1989 Š—“Mystery TrainŠ— Š—” well, Masatoshi Nagase, now nearly 50, doesnŠ—Èt smirk even once in Š—“Sweet Bean,Š— a new film directed by Naomi Kawase.

Some of the most entertaining food-themed films ever made have arrived from Japan over the past 30 years. Š—“Sweet BeanŠ— crosses this subgenre with the old-person-imparts-wisdom-to-younger-acolyte variety, but it is not typical of either kind of movie. The Yoshida Brewery, in Ishikawa Prefecture, has been making sake for more than 140 years, using artisanal means Š—” that is, touch, taste, sight and smell, instead of just machines Š—” to steam, sift and ferment the rice into a premium sake brand, Tedorigawa. About a dozen employees leave their families from October to April for the plant, where they live together while following the directions of Teruyuki Yamamoto, the 68-year-old toji, or head brewmaster. They eat, sleep, sometimes even bathe together, rising at 4:30 a.m. for a workday that often runs past 8 p.m.

Yachan Yoshida, 28, is being groomed by his father, the companyŠ—Ès president, to be the sixth generation of his family to lead the brewery. Eager for the challenge Š—” Š—“The brewery will always be where I feel most at peace,Š— he says Š—” he knows its survival is not assured. Young workers willing to put up with a life this demanding and immersive are hard to come by; as important, the sake market in Japan is shrinking, and the mass brands that do well often lack the nuance and subtle textures of the artisanal brews.

Mr. Shirai nicely shuffles in the back stories of several workers, and his shots of sky, sea and early morning landscapes could fit amid Hokusai woodcuts. At 94 minutes, the filmŠ—Ès pacing drags at times. But as Mr. Yamamoto might say, it takes what it takes. You canŠ—Èt rush the process.

Chronicling a season at a small family-owned brewery, Erik ShiraiŠ—Ès Š—“The Birth of SakeŠ— is an engrossing introduction to the traditional cultivation of the rice-based alcohol that is part of JapanŠ—Ès cultural heritage. But the filmŠ—Ès true focus is an endangered way of life.

So why the movieŠ—Ès title? To please his mother, as well as a priest (played with nuanced foreboding by Stephen Tobolowsky), Anthony is to prepare for a religious rite of passage. He also has solid leads: Though Mr. LieberherŠ—Ès character is slightly overinnocent Š—” a straight-A student so sensitive that he weeps at the death of an insect Š—” the actor complements Mr. Owen, whose hangdog charisma serves him well as a man struggling with addiction while he strives to reconnect with his son.

The pleasures are modest but rewarding in Bob NelsonŠ—Ès character study Š—“The Confirmation.Š— The story is seemingly simple: A handyman, Walt (Clive Owen), whose drinking cost him his marriage, has a weekend with his 8-year-old son, Anthony (Jaeden Lieberher), while his ex (Maria Bello) is on a church-sponsored couples retreat with her new man (Matthew Modine).

When tools are stolen from WaltŠ—Ès truck, he and Anthony cruise around their small town seeking the culprits. Trying to assist are a fatuous drywall repairman (Patton Oswalt) and another working-class father (Tim Blake Nelson, no relation to the director), whose son befriends Anthony.
Š—“The ConfirmationŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for adult themes.

Mr. Shults maintains tight control over his whirring parts almost to the frenetic finish, so itŠ—Ès all the more impressive that he cast not just his aunt, but also himself, his mother and grandmother in several critical roles. This gives the movie an extra frisson, adding to its portrait of a self-destructive woman. There can be something pitiless about Mr. ShultsŠ—Ès gaze, but the steadiness of his look is that of the artist who refuses to sell the truth out for sentimentalism. When Krisha stands in the kitchen, wild-eyed amid all these human sights and sounds, you see a woman overwhelmed by life itself, as well as a movie that is an expressionistic tour de force.

Few movies bore into a characterŠ—Ès head as deeply as Š—“Krisha,Š— and with such uncompromising ferocity. A family drama in alternately appalling and queasily hilarious extremis, this bravura first feature takes place over an epically terrible Thanksgiving that may inspire you to start leafing through the collected poems of Philip Larkin, looking for that one about Mum and Dad. It takes some time to grasp who wronged whom here, but itŠ—Ès clear from the get go that serious damage has been done.

Even as Mr. Shults goes light on the exposition, the characters Š—” with their rapid gestures, cacophonous movements and ductile faces Š—” express a great deal. The extraordinary peripatetic camerawork and fluid editing (the cinematographer is Drew Daniels; Mr. Shults is the editor) bring characters together, even when theyŠ—Ère not talking to one another, the rapid lateral pans mapping relationships with revelatory geometric precision. And while Mr. Shults does leave Krisha to check in on the other relatives (wrestling, shouting, nuzzling, conspiring), the camera is largely associated with her, beginning with the long take that starts at her truck and ends in the house.
Š—“KrishaŠ— is rated R (under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for family fun. Running time: 1 hour, 22 minutes.

Most of the movie takes place in a sprawling McMansion in Austin, Tex., a multitiered theater thatŠ—Ès already populated with yelling, yammering relations and barking, agitated dogs when Krisha (CREE-sha) rings the doorbell. She arrives in a pickup and, notably, first approaches the wrong house. Mr. Shults, who also wrote the streamlined script, lets the story emerge through such seemingly minor incidents, as well as through conversational snippets, private rituals and the sort of choreography of chaos that Š—” as bodies and cameras pirouette Š—” suggests he has put in time with some touchstones of Eastern European art cinema (Emir Kusturica, Alexei German).

The young director Trey Edward Shults suggests as much by opening with a close-up of Krisha (played by the directorŠ—Ès aunt Krisha Fairchild) staring into the camera, her lined, tanned face framed by a mass of springy gray hair that might as well be a mess of snakes. SheŠ—Ès isolated in the shot, and, as she continues to stare and the eerie music gets to shrieking, you might think Š—” it wonŠ—Èt be for the first time Š—” that this looks and feels a lot like a horror movie. Though itŠ—Ès one, after a fashion and too many drinks, that finally owes more to the likes of John Cassavetes than the usual genre influences.

At once a stage and a confessional, the house becomes the site of KrishaŠ—Ès undoing, a process she hurries along with furtively swallowed pills she keeps in a small locked box marked Š—“private.Š— This little safe, with its childish scrawl and adult contents (a PandoraŠ—Ès boxful of woe), is a perfect manifestation of Krisha, who is herself in mysterious lockdown. (She keeps the key to her safe on a chain around her neck.) Much of the movie, which runs a very fast, expertly jammed 82 minutes, involves opening Krisha, as it were. ItŠ—Ès a revelation (at times more like an exhumation) that involves old and new wounds and reaches a frenzied climax with a culinary catastrophe.
ThereŠ—Ès dramatic potential in RyderŠ—Ès struggle to assert his identity, only to be upstaged by unforeseen troubles, but Mr. SobelŠ—Ès film skates past any persuasive sense of motivation.

In Matt SobelŠ—Ès Š—“Take Me to the River,Š— a gay California teenager becomes enmeshed in scandal during a family reunion in Nebraska. What looks like a coming-of-age premise, though, is upended by a dubious plot involving suspected sexual wrongdoing.

On the way to a farm owned by his grandmother, Ryder (Logan Miller) is asked by his parents to keep his sexual orientation a secret from their conservative relatives. No real attempt is made to explain what happened, and Ryder is banished to a derelict house. Until, that is, heŠ—Ès not: Suddenly, Keith invites Ryder to dinner, encourages him to hang out with Molly alone and teaches him how to handle a gun. As RyderŠ—Ès mother, navigating a delicate situation while returning to her roots, Robin Weigert is a bit more compelling.

The filmmakers, David Osit and Malika Zouhali-Worrall, eavesdrop on the parentsŠ—È heart-rending discussions about things like whether to use JoelŠ—Ès actual laugh as a sound effect in the game. But the GreensŠ—È intentions in making the game arenŠ—Èt overly clear, even though the film acknowledges the obvious question by showing Mr. Green reading a critical comment about the project from off his laptop.

As filmmaking has become technologically easier, more and more documentaries have sprung up that chronicle personal loss: a loved oneŠ—Ès struggle with cancer or dementia, for instance. Š—“Thank You for PlayingŠ— isnŠ—Èt as coherent and impactful as the best of these films, but itŠ—Ès certainly unusual.

The game ends up being called Š—“That Dragon, Cancer,Š— and as Mr. Green and his wife, Amy, are conceptualizing it, they are also watching Joel slowly lose his battle against brain tumors.

The details of the game itself also arenŠ—Èt particularly clear, which leaves the film feeling somewhat vague. But if nothing else, itŠ—Ès evidence that the digital age has opened up new ways to work through grief.

Š—“I keep hearing about this game, and it keeps annoying me that JoelŠ—Ès dad is turning his struggle into a piece of interactive entertainment,Š— it reads. Š—“ItŠ—Ès like making a video of your kid dying and then posting it on YouTube.Š—

A lot of people, especially on the liberal side of the spectrum, will certainly identify with Š—“The Brainwashing of My Dad,Š— Jen SenkoŠ—Ès documentary about how right-wing news programs, talk shows and Internet sites turned her once reasonable father into a raging embodiment of intolerance and suspicion. The film, though, feels as if itŠ—Ès arriving late to its discoveries and, given the current political climate, as if itŠ—Ès only scratching the surface.

Ms. Senko says that her father, Frank, was Š—“a nonpolitical Kennedy DemocratŠ— until the 1980s, when he began listening to a lot of right-wing gum-flappers. She spends too much of the film detailing what anyone who watched Jon Stewart even once on Š—“The Daily ShowŠ— already knows: that Fox News, Rush Limbaugh and the like fabricate and distort routinely; that the rightŠ—Ès most incendiary figures are entertainers, not journalists or academic experts. The film has an interesting segment on the neurology of the phenomenon Š—” how alarm is addictive, how repetition of the same messages transforms the brain Š—” but the subject is left underexplored.

In addition to telling her own familyŠ—Ès story, Ms. Senko invited video submissions from others who have had similar experiences with loved ones, and those provide the filmŠ—Ès most heartfelt moments. But the nastiness that has been brought out into the open by the current presidential campaign demonstrates that hatred and suspicion are more endemic than a collection of personal stories suggests. Right-wing outlets may be exploiting humanityŠ—Ès ugly side, but Ms. SenkoŠ—Ès frail-looking father (who died in January at 93) isnŠ—Èt so much the face of the phenomenon as he is a small and not especially representative sample of it.
Š—“The BronzeŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for vulgarity of all sorts and a crass nude scene.

She is Hope Ann Greggory (Melissa Rauch, Bernadette of Š—“The Big Bang TheoryŠ—), who won a bronze medal in gymnastics in 2004 and has not let anyone in her small Ohio town forget it. Hope was spoiled rotten when she was competing and is still spoiled, terrorizing her patient father (Gary Cole). So when the town produces another gymnast with great promise, Maggie (Haley Lu Richardson), Hope doesnŠ—Èt exactly encourage that younger athleteŠ—Ès ambitions.

Hope is unrelentingly crude, spiteful, petty and loathsome. Ms. Rauch (who wrote the film with her husband, Winston Rauch) nails the portrayal admirably under Bryan BuckleyŠ—Ès direction. But that doesnŠ—Èt mean Hope is anyone you want to spend almost two hours with, even though you can guess that the story is headed for an obligatory feel-good Š—” or, in this case, feel-slightly-better Š—” ending.

A few weeks back moviegoers were given an Olympic story, Š—“Eddie the Eagle,Š— that made really, really sure the audience knew that its underdog hero was likable. Now comes a corrective of sorts: Š—“The Bronze,Š— an Olympic-themed tale that goes way overboard in conveying that its main character is despicable.

When I first saw Š—“The Clan,Š— at the Venice Film Festival last September, I was impressed by its insight and bothered by what I took as a certain glibness, a too-easy accommodation of moral horror to the imperatives of the thriller genre. On subsequent viewings, IŠ—Ève come to appreciate this ambiguity as part of what Mr. Trapero is trying to address, and as an essential aspect of what his film reveals about the nature of authoritarianism. Fascism is seductive not only because it feeds fantasies of power and greatness, but also because, at a primal, visceral, libidinal level, it can be a lot of fun.

It is also a terrifically entertaining movie, which I donŠ—Èt entirely mean as praise. Mr. TraperoŠ—Ès energetic style, his almost gleeful juxtapositions of sex and violence and his exuberantly Scorsesean musical cues often pull against the gravity of the story. The period details are meticulous, and the shifting d’©cor of the Puccio home provides a catalog of strenuously tasteful Š—È80s bad taste that may touch a nostalgic chord in middle-aged viewers. The kidnappings and ransom negotiations provide jolts of suspense, as does the larger narrative of Arqu’_medesŠ—Ès unraveling ambitions. As Argentina inches toward democracy, he becomes more desperate and reckless; AlejandroŠ—Ès doubts about his father grow; and an inevitable reckoning approaches, for the family and the nation alike.

One of AlejandroŠ—Ès brothers leaves Argentina to escape the family business. Another, returning from a year abroad, is initiated into it. Their sisters and their mother are not expected to participate, and one of the questions Mr. Trapero raises is how much they know, or permit themselves to know, about what is happening under their noses. Mostly, they regard Arqu’_medes with deference and adoration, helping to fashion an image of the perfect traditional family. He helps his daughters with their homework, addresses his wife with chivalrous courtesy and strives to embody a Latin American version of a Š—“Leave It to BeaverŠ— fatherly ideal. HeŠ—Ès a provider and a protector Š—” stern, kind, capable and patient.

Š—“The Clan,Š— Pablo TraperoŠ—Ès wrenching, exciting new film, could be described as an examination of the banality of evil. ItŠ—Ès the story, closely based on actual events, of an ostentatiously normal family involved in crimes enabled by a climate of political violence and repression.

But the patriarch, Arqu’_medes Puccio, played with regal sang-froid and deadpan perversity by Guillermo Francella, is also a study in the evil of banality. His steadfast attachment to conformity and respectability is inseparable from his coldblooded, self-serving sadism. In his own mind, everything he does Š—” the kidnappings, the beatings, the occasional murder Š—” is an expression of his essential rectitude. HeŠ—Ès a good father, a good businessman, a paragon of petit-bourgeois virtue who happens to keep hostages tied up in the basement.
Š—“The ClanŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Civilization and barbarism. In Spanish with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 50 minutes.

Argentina awoke from the nightmare of dictatorship in 1983, and in the years since, in the midst of economic and political turmoil, its writers and filmmakers have grappled with the legacy of the Š—“dirty war.Š— Mr. Trapero has set out to examine the period from the perspective of the guilty, to explore the psychology of both the active collaborators with a brutal system and its passive beneficiaries. The cleverest and most troubling aspect of the film is its empathy.

The pathology is not his alone. Š—“The ClanŠ— takes place in Buenos Aires in the early 1980s, when Argentina was ruled by a military dictatorship that specialized in Š—“disappearingŠ— its suspected political opponents. Arqu’_medes, though he is proud of his government connections (and adept at exploiting them), has neither an official position nor any particular ideological commitment. HeŠ—Ès in it for the money, selecting his prey based on the ransom he can collect. Rather than targeting supposed leftists, he and his accomplices Š—” principally his son Alejandro (Peter Lanzani) Š—” focus on members of their own class and social circle, including a young man who belongs to AlejandroŠ—Ès rugby club.

There is an element of grisly, grotesque comedy in the gap between who the Puccios Š—” Arqu’_medes, above all Š—” really are and who they pretend to be, and Mr. Trapero, whose other features include the intense prison drama Š—“LionŠ—Ès Den,Š— choreographs the contradictions of their domestic life with ferocious wit. Š—“The ClanŠ— is partly a dark satire of the authoritarian personality, an appalling CT scan of male entitlement and middle-class vanity.

Alejandro is such an appealing young man that we canŠ—Èt help rooting for him. His father, though despicable, is also intriguing and charismatic, partly because of Mr. FrancellaŠ—Ès commanding, disarmingly dignified performance. As fans of recent antihero-driven cable dramas know, itŠ—Ès hard not to identify with a complicated protagonist, and Mr. Trapero exploits this habit of identification, ensnaring the audience, and maybe also the film itself, in an ethical trap. The violence is exciting, and its perpetrators are more interesting, more vivid and more real than the victims.

Only in the last 10 minutes or so do the actors make us feel the tension, the sweat, the crushing seriousness of TobyŠ—Ès arrest, and the consequences that will be his alone because he, unlike the others, cannot insulate himself with money or connections. And then itŠ—Ès over.
This film fails even to evoke the Š—È80s in costumes, soundtrack or other atmospherics.

And while Š—“The Preppie ConnectionŠ— has a young cast that bristles with film and television credits, the performances are uninspired. Thomas Mann (Š—“Me and Earl and the Dying GirlŠ—) plays Toby, and Lucy Fry (Š—“11.22.63Š—) is Alex, the Southern beauty he seeks to conquer, and the one member of the clique brave enough to accompany him. There is plenty of potential here, but the direction, by Mr. Castelo, is as flat today as a 1984 bottle of Fresca.

In adapting this story, the writers Joseph Castelo and Ashley Rudden donŠ—Èt elevate it above its origins. Without insight or dimension, developments that were shiny or novel when the forces that helped the rich get richer were just gathering momentum no longer dazzle 30 years later in a society that has become accustomed to a Wall Street-take-all economy.

When the story broke in 1984 that a student at Choate Rosemary Hall had been accused of smuggling cocaine to sell to classmates at their elite Connecticut boarding school, it was shocking enough to make the national news.

Š—“The Preppie Connection,Š— inspired by those events, changes the names and details but borrows its title from a Š—“60 MinutesŠ— report on the incident. In the film, a day student, Toby, a relative innocent, makes buying trips to Colombia to please the privileged young hedonists who surround him.

Although Mr. Foster bears some physical resemblance to Armstrong, the air of imperial invincibility that Armstrong projected so skillfully is missing. No matter how he phrases his denial, Mr. Foster sounds about as convincing a used-car salesman cynically peddling a clunker. Because his voice is higher and lighter than ArmstrongŠ—Ès, his pronouncements evoke a quality political pundits once ascribed to the first President George Bush: the wimp factor.

As a smirk plays about the corners of Mr. FosterŠ—Ès mouth, his sneaky, fish-eyed performance suggests he is the directorŠ—Ès designated hit man. Anyone might think twice before buying a used car from this man or even shaking his hand to seal a transaction.

The movie is sporadically energized by its racing sequences. But it shies away from glamorizing ArmstrongŠ—Ès accomplishments. He is portrayed as a soulless, hypercompetitive narcissist addicted to the spotlight who grows to believe his own hype and is mercilessly vindictive toward anyone who threatens him. It is a measure of the publicŠ—Ès desperate desire for heroes and the greed and duplicity in sports that the scam continued for as long as it did.

As Armstrong learns about the miraculous effects of the blood booster EPO, he wants some for himself and his teammates. And when he consults with Michele Ferrari, the Italian doctor, cycling coach and champion of EPO (played with a farcical edge by Guillaume Canet), what the movie dubs the most sophisticated doping scandal in sports history shifts into high gear.

Š—“The ProgramŠ— is nothing like the Alex Gibney documentary Š—“The Armstrong Lie,Š— which was begun when Mr. Gibney was in the thrall of his subjectŠ—Ès mystique. After ArmstrongŠ—Ès downfall, the film had to be revised, but a lingering tone of disappointment gives it an emotional resonance lacking in Š—“The Program,Š— which begins and ends with an attitude of disgust.

Š—“The Program,Š— much to its detriment, concentrates almost exclusively on the history of the doping effort . There is no mention of his childhood or adolescence or any attempt to analyze his character. When the movie touches on the Livestrong Foundation, ArmstrongŠ—Ès charitable support organization for those with cancer, it is portrayed as a cynical buffer against allegations of drug use. The movie strongly suggests that the testicular cancer for which Armstrong was treated in the 1990s, before his ascent, was brought on by performance-enhancing drugs.
Š—“The ProgramŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for language. Running time: 1 hour 43 minutes.

Two scenes in Š—“The Program,Š— Stephen FrearsŠ—Ès patchy docudrama tracing the rise and fall of the disgraced cyclist Lance Armstrong tell you all you need to know about this crude cinematic demolition job. In one, the Armstrong character (Ben Foster) studies himself in a mirror while rehearsing different versions of the statement, Š—“IŠ—Ève never tested positive for performance-enhancing drugs.Š— No matter how he says it, the words ring false.

Even when under extreme stress, Armstrong projected an air of embattled nobility. It was not too hard to buy the illusion that he was some kind of superman. His very name evokes a heroic stone-faced warrior beyond the reach of petty criticism.

In the other, set aboard a tour bus, members of his United States Postal Service team, hooked up to blood bags as part of a doping regimen, banter about who should play the Armstrong role in a Hollywood biography. The bus suggests nothing so much as a nursery of grown-up infants.

The screenplay, by John Hodge (Š—“TrainspottingŠ—), is based on Š—“Seven Deadly Sins: My Pursuit of Lance Armstrong,Š— a book by David Walsh, a sportswriter for The Sunday Times of London. Mr. Walsh (Chris OŠ—ÈDowd) is the patient Javert to ArmstrongŠ—Ès wily Jean Valjean in a 13-year-long quest to expose the heroŠ—Ès secret.

Š—“Kapoor & Sons Š—” Since 1921Š— isnŠ—Èt about the dynastic family of Hindi movie directors, actors and producers. But it does star one of them, Rishi Kapoor (son of Raj, father of Ranbir), who heavily (and skillfully) made up plays Dadu, the about-to-be-90 paterfamilias of a clan made unhappy by the usual secrets and lies and long-cherished grudges.
That older generation has its own agita. Papa (Rajat Kapoor, but not one of those Kapoors) has money trouble, and all signs point to him having an affair. Mama (Ratna Pathak) is restless and angry.

ThatŠ—Ès a tribute to its actors, who make their charactersŠ—È wounds palpable but donŠ—Èt play them too broadly. (Rishi Kapoor, though, has a high old hammy time as the pot-smoking, porn-approving, a-little-too-cute Dadu.) ItŠ—Ès also a tribute to Mr. Batra and Ayesha Devitre Dhillon, with whom he wrote the script. They know how to press the story without pressing it too hard.

Directed by Shakun Batra, the movie starts as a comedy of family dysfunction. Dadu, who enjoys playacting his death, has a real heart attack. That brings home Š—” to Coonoor, a hill station in the state of Tamil Nadu Š—” his diasporic grandsons: Rahul, a successful novelist from London, and Arjun, an aspiring novelist from New Jersey. Arjun (Sidharth Malhotra), angry at his brother for stealing his ideas, feels like a chronic also-ran, and with good reason. Rahul (Fawad Khan) is frequently proclaimed the perfect son by his mother.

It helps that the movie plays against expectations, if gently. The foreign-returned grandsons here arenŠ—Èt swaggering wheeler-dealers in need of lessons about humility and home. TheyŠ—Ère writers who need to repair relations with their family. RahulŠ—Ès secret is also a bit unusual for Hindi movies, and though you may guess it early, it plays out in a mostly satisfying way. When I saw the movie, the audience rewarded it with BollywoodŠ—Ès gold standard of approval: tears, and a few hoots.
Š—“Kapoor & Sons Š—” Since 1921Š— is not rated. It is in Hindi, with English subtitles. Running time: 2 hours 17 minutes.

Mr. Batra, whose previous films include Š—“Ek Main aur Ekk Tu,Š— has a naturalistŠ—Ès feel for character and situations thatŠ—Ès unusual in mainstream Bollywood. Even though Š—“Kapoor & SonsŠ— goes from lightly comic to more darkly dramatic to pretty overtly melodramatic, it never loses its lived-in quality or plunges into the absurd.

What gives? In a sooty gray Paris with twin Eiffel Towers, April (voiced in both the French- and English-language versions by Marion Cotillard), the adult daughter of two missing scientists, seeks answers. Assisting her is a talking cat named Darwin. Among those pursuing her is a slapstick Javert of a police agent with an old grudge, aided reluctantly by a young pickpocket.

Who says they donŠ—Èt make mind-bending French science-fiction animated movies like they used to? Well, very few people, if any, I reckon. But the thought Š—” or something similar to it Š—” crossed my mind while watching Š—“April and the Extraordinary World,Š— a beautiful, inventive and uncannily satisfying new example of animated sci-fi from, yes, France.

Directed by Christian Desmares and Franck Ekinci, adapting a graphic novel by the revered artist Jacques Tardi, Š—“AprilŠ— has an alternate-history peg thatŠ—Ès irrepressibly Gallic. In the late 19th century, a scheme hatched by Napoleon III to engineer supersoldiers scientifically goes horribly awry. The result is an early 20th century of stunted technology. Instead of wars over oil, there are wars over charcoal. And every scientist who shows promise Š—” Einstein, Fermi, you name Š—Èem Š—” disappears from public view in short order.

Š—“AprilŠ— arguably belongs to the genre called steampunk, but the movieŠ—Ès designs and contraptions also evoke Jules Verne, the Czech animator Karel Zeman, Fritz LangŠ—Ès Š—“MetropolisŠ— and more. Influences aside, the movie so teems with delightful detail and has such an exuberant sense of play that it feels entirely fresh. While it bears little overt resemblance to the 1973 French animated marvel Š—“Fantastic Planet,Š— for me, at least, Š—“AprilŠ— bestows a similar sense of otherworldly exhilaration.
Š—“April and the Extraordinary WorldŠ— is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for action and peril, including gunplay, some thematic elements and rude humor.

Š—“BaskinŠ— begins in the mode of Š—“A Nightmare on Elm Street,Š— as a child awakes to the sounds of nearby lovemaking, only to find that some sort of presence is haunting the house. The nested-plot threads blur hallucination and reality, creating a disorientation that is sometimes more confusing than productive.

This proudly derivative genre exercise will not be to every taste (or stomach), but the director, Can Evrenol, shows a certain knack for tension and for framing viscera in wide screen, even if his cutting is sometimes too quick. The movie is being released in theaters and on video on demand, but it benefits from the steady sensation that fellow viewers might flee in disgust.

ArdaŠ—Ès squad responds to a call for backup at an ominous mansion that was once an Ottoman police station. The officers soon meet the buildingŠ—Ès bloodthirsty occupants, whose ringleader (Mehmet Cerrahoglu) resembles a cross between Marlon BrandoŠ—Ès Kurtz from Š—“Apocalypse NowŠ— and the Mystery Man Robert Blake played in Š—“Lost Highway.Š—

Tickling the mind even as it lurches the gut, Š—“Baskin,Š— a stylish, shape-shifting horror film from Turkey, pulls a bait-and-switch. It abruptly morphs from a sinuous psychological thriller into a buffet for gore enthusiasts, without ever totally losing its elegance Š—” unless your definition of that word could never encompass a graphic disembowelment or an unexpected stabbing of an eye.

BakerŠ—Ès glamour never completely faded. As seen in Bruce WeberŠ—Ès 1988 documentary, Š—“LetŠ—Ès Get Lost,Š— Baker, ravaged by his addiction, appeared wrapped in a narcotic haze. Even then, to some die-hard admirers, he remained an object of worship. The alluring mystique of the beautiful lost boy still clung to him, as it does today.

In Mr. HawkeŠ—Ès extraordinary performance, this glamorous enigma becomes a credible, if pathetic character who lives for only two things: to play the trumpet and to shoot heroin. He likes sex, too, especially when heŠ—Ès high.
The words are uttered without apology in the plaintive tone of a stubborn little boy who insists on having everything his way.

Because Baker was a beautiful young man (as seen in well-known photographs taken by William Claxton), he attracted no end of eager female caretakers. In an astute casting decision, the many women in his life are distilled into a single character, Jane, an aspiring actress, played by Carmen Ejogo (Coretta Scott King from Š—“SelmaŠ—), who brings remarkable vitality to this invented composite. The only other continuing character is BakerŠ—Ès sympathetic producer, Dick Bock (Callum Keith Rennie), who founded Pacific Jazz Records.

Suffering from stage fright on the eve of his comeback late in this haunting film, he tearfully tries to explain the relationship between his addiction and playing his instrument. Š—“It gives me confidence,Š— he explains in a husky whisper. Š—“Time gets wider, not just longer, and I can get inside every note.Š—

Baker was forced to take a career break when drug dealers to whom he owed money knocked out his front teeth, and he had to relearn trumpet technique, wearing dentures that kept slipping. Scenes of Baker trying to play in an empty bathtub after the beating, blood streaming from the sides of his mouth, are agonizing to watch.

As for the music, the makers of Š—“Born to Be BlueŠ— made the risky decision not to use BakerŠ—Ès original recordings. The jazz trumpeter Kevin Turcotte conjures BakerŠ—Ès trumpet at different phases, including the period after he loses his teeth and is struggling to make any sound from the instrument. If Mr. Hawke does a reasonably good imitation of BakerŠ—Ès plain, vibratoless voice singing Š—“My Funny ValentineŠ— and Š—“IŠ—Ève Never Been in Love Before,Š— he only fitfully captures the fragility embodied in that voice.

As the pieces of this portrait come together, the movie alternates between black-and-white and color. Baker emerges as a frightened, defiant, arrogant and entirely self-centered musician, who, by his own admission, excelled at only one thing. The rest of his life was a shambles.
Š—“Born To Be BlueŠ— is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 38 minutes.
That explanation of his heroin addiction, voiced by the jazz trumpeter and singer Chet Baker (Ethan Hawke) in Robert BudreauŠ—Ès moody biographical fantasia, Š—“Born to Be Blue,Š— says it all.

In his singing and playing, Baker, who was called Š—“the James Dean of jazz,Š— personified the West Coast style of cool jazz that was later echoed in the harmonies of the Beach Boys. His voice and trumpet expressed a cosmic languor shaded with romantic melancholy. East Coast bebop was more angular and staccato and emotionally volatile.
Š—“It makes me happy.Š—

The movie begins in the 1960s with a scene of Baker on the set of a screen biography that was never made, then flashes back to a 1954 performance attended by Dizzy Gillespie and Miles Davis at Birdland, when Baker was the jazz worldŠ—Ès hottest sensation. Afterward he asks Davis (Kedar Brown) whether he liked it, and Davis scoffs in a gravelly voice, Š—“It was sweet, like candyŠ— and condescendingly advises him to come back when he has lived a little more.

In a telling sequence, Baker visits his parents at their Oklahoma farm and has a poisonous confrontation with his jealous father (Stephen McHattie), a former musician himself, who sneers at his son for singing like a girl and accuses him of Š—“dragging the family name through the mud.Š—
Out of earshot, Baker murmurs: Š—“Hello, Dizzy, hello, Miles. ThereŠ—Ès a little white cat on the West Coast gonna eat you up.Š—

Back in 2012, baseball fans were treated to Š—“Knuckleball!,Š— a documentary about that fickle pitch and the athletes who throw it. Now comes the polar opposite, from a batterŠ—Ès point of view: Š—“Fastball,Š— an enjoyable examination of baseballŠ—Ès most basic pitch.

The film, written and directed by Jonathan Hock, is full of great players and former players talking about throwing or trying to hit a superior fastball, including the obligatory discussion of who throws the best one now, and whether todayŠ—Ès are faster than those of legendary pre-radar-gun pitchers like Walter Johnson.
Š—“You get about 25 times the information just because you have those 50 milliseconds,Š— says Timothy Verstynen, a professor at Carnegie Mellon University.

The film is at its most interesting when it analyzes the difference between a 92-miles-per-hour fastball Š—” a rather ordinary version of the pitch Š—” and a 100-m.p.h. one. They reach home plate only about 50 milliseconds apart, but that fraction of a second makes the slower pitch significantly more hittable because of the firing time for synapses in a batterŠ—Ès brain.

The narration, read by Kevin Costner, finds a certain elemental beauty in the confrontation that takes place when a good hitter is challenged by a good fastball pitcher. It is, Mr. Costner says, Š—“a showdown between the fastest itŠ—Ès humanly possible to throw a ball and the fastest itŠ—Ès humanly possible to react to it.Š— This appealing documentary makes you understand why aficionados regard baseball as a form of poetry.

The screenplay, by Kyle Pennekamp and Scott Turpel, canŠ—Èt quite decide whether to like, or laugh off, its millennial characters Š—” those supercasual, obliviously entitled children of praise. But the so-called adults donŠ—Èt fare better, tending to be sexual clowns of one sort (Ms. BrieŠ—Ès nonsensically obscene office worker) or another (Ms. HardenŠ—Ès alpha female at WillŠ—Ès workplace, caught in compromising positions with another executive).
Š—“Get a JobŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for crude and sexual content, nudity, drug use and language.
NICOLAS RAPOLD

Generically written but featuring a promising cast, Š—“Get a JobŠ— is a long-shelved movie, mostly about 20-somethings entering the sink-or-swim labor force. Miles Teller, Anna Kendrick, Bryan Cranston, Marcia Gay Harden and Alison Brie star in this comedy, which was shot in 2012 and, packed with evergreen bromides, was deemed relevant for 2016.

The father-son bonding (over tacos and beers) does strike a chord in the hands of two winning personalities like Mr. Teller and Mr. Cranston, but itŠ—Ès as calculated as the filmŠ—Ès gross-out and stoner gags. At its sloppy heart, this is meant to be an affirming movie, but the filmmakers could have taken a cue from one line of dialogue: Š—“DonŠ—Èt just feel special. Be special.Š—

This episodic film by Dylan Kidd bops along, focusing on a sanguine recent college graduate, Will (Mr. Teller, before he played the hypermotivated drummer of Š—“WhiplashŠ—). His assured girlfriend, Jillian (Ms. Kendrick), worries that heŠ—Ès not serious about his corporate gig as a video editor, and his bong-hitting housemates tangle with their own career ventures (teaching chemistry, hustling for startup money, surviving at a financial firm). Mr. Cranston plays WillŠ—Ès company-man dad, who is fired and then, dressed in a suit, hangs out in a coffeehouse.

The music is, of course, the point of the story, or should be, even in cover versions, so itŠ—Ès strange that Mr. Abraham doesnŠ—Èt pay it more heed. The story picks up with Hank as an adult and folds in assorted studio recordings and stage performances, but thereŠ—Ès little about who and what inspired the real man, including the black gospel music he listened to as a child and the black musician who taught him guitar, Rufus Payne. Not much appears to be known about Payne, but their relationship has the makings of a classic American story, one that ended with one man in an unmarked grave and the other one, after a rise and fall, enshrined in music halls of fame, biographies and myth.

Mr. Abraham largely dodges that myth and WilliamsŠ—Ès hold on American music, hearts and ears, though he does give him an uncharacteristically articulate speech about why people love his work. Instead, Mr. Abraham focuses on the greatest hits and private headlines, narrowing in on HankŠ—Ès stormy first marriage to Audrey (Elizabeth Olsen), a beauty with a flat voice whose great passion seems to have been a misplaced belief in her own vocal talent. Much of the movie follows the arc of their marriage, a grindingly unhappy union marred by her jealousy of HankŠ—Ès talent and increasingly plagued by fights and infidelities. AudreyŠ—Ès grasping ambition gives the character spark, but Ms. Olsen doesnŠ—Èt have the lines or guidance to elevate this harridan beyond clich’©.

Š—“I Saw the LightŠ— is the latest movie to try to capture that certain ineluctable something about Williams (1923-1953), the poor Alabama boy turned country-music star who died at 29 and inspired later legends like Bob Dylan. Other big-screen disinterments have tried to do right by Williams, including Š—“Your CheatinŠ—È Heart,Š— a 1964 biopic starring George Hamilton, whose singing was dubbed by the teenage Hank Jr. The writer-director of Š—“I Saw the Light,Š— Marc Abraham, sticks closer to the facts than previous treatments, but perhaps because heŠ—Ès farther from WilliamsŠ—Ès moment, he turns the story into an old-fashioned, hand-tinted postcard thatŠ—Ès as inert as it is pretty.

In the big-screen memorial Š—“I Saw the Light,Š— the music legend Hank Williams strums a guitar and hits the road and the bottle, all while flashing a smile as blinding as the lights of a semi on a dark highway. He also sings, but each time he does itŠ—Ès a reminder that itŠ—Ès not Williams on the soundtrack but the British actor Tom Hiddleston. As Hank, Mr. Hiddleston leads with charm and a twang, keeping the beat with his shoulders, hips and feet. He looks as good as the movie, but if you want to hear what white soul music sounds like you need to fire up the real Hank Williams.
As HankŠ—Ès features emerge from the dark, you grasp what Mr. Abraham is trying to suggest, even if he introduces this honky-tonk bluesman as a Sinatra-like saloon singer.
Š—“I Saw the LightŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Wasted tears, jugs of wine, cheatinŠ—È hearts and lovesick blues. Running time: 2 hours 3 minutes.

Part of what defeats Mr. Abraham and may help explain why Mr. HiddlestonŠ—Ès performance, however appealing, never gets below the surface, is that Williams is one of those artists whose eloquence is expressed through his work. That eloquence is in his lyrics and melodies as well as a voice that, especially when it quavers on the high end, conveys a sincerity he transfers to his listeners. That voice has a singular sound, and it carries a specific American history and way of feeling and being that finds the holy not only in the Bible, but also in a lonesome whippoorwill, a midnight train and ordinary life and people. When Williams sang to his audiences, they knew that he heard them, too.

A few barbed scenes with Cherry Jones as HankŠ—Ès mama, Lillie, meanwhile, suggest that you can learn more about some men by spending five minutes with their mothers than a few hours with their wives. ItŠ—Ès instructive that Š—“Hank Williams: The Biography,Š— the book that the movie is based on, suggests that even those who thought themselves closest to Williams didnŠ—Èt know him. Mr. Abraham seems to be acknowledging the elusiveness of his subject in the opener, which shows Hank on a stool in a circle of light, his face in shadow as he sings an a cappella version of Š—“Cold, Cold Heart.Š—

Now Bianca is moving in with her boyfriend, Rob (Amir Arison), in Brooklyn, and her parents want Jane to live with Bianca and Rob, despite JaneŠ—Ès growing assertions of autonomy (and emerging libido). When Jack (Gabriel Ebert) Š—” a bar regular of BiancaŠ—Ès and a neŠ—Èer-do-well with relationships Š—” takes a shining to Jane, BiancaŠ—Ès cautionary instincts kick in.

Polished and often clever, William C. SullivanŠ—Ès Š—“Jane Wants a BoyfriendŠ— examines autism in the context of sisterly ties and intimate relationships. ItŠ—Ès a gold mine for emotional sparks, and in its title character, Š—“JaneŠ— offers the kind of role (see Š—“Rain ManŠ—) that is catnip to actors.

Jane (Louisa Krause) is a 20-something assistant costume designer for the theater, obsessed with movies and living in Queens with her parents, who are moving to rural New Jersey. She also has autism, which is a constant concern for her protective older sister, Bianca (the Š—“Buffy the Vampire SlayerŠ— alumna Eliza Dushku), a bartender and an actress in a production of Š—“A Midsummer NightŠ—Ès Dream.Š—

At times, Mr. Sullivan goes overboard with sound and camera tricks to convey the acute sensory perception of people with autism. The diagrammatic script, by Jarret Kerr, has wit but could sometimes use more nuance. But there are tasty performances. Mr. Ebert (recently on Broadway in Š—“Th’©r’åse RaquinŠ—) adroitly blends goofiness and gallantry. Ms. Dushku, leaving the pyrotechnics to Ms. Krause, is a generous team player. Though Ms. KrauseŠ—Ès Jane rages when frustrated, the movie vacillates in illustrating the extent of her condition. But her blossoming ardor and independence are delightful to behold.

A washed-out recycling of ethnic clich’©s and exhausted jokes, the story (once again by Nia Vardalos) returns us to the smothering bosom of the Portokalos family, where Toula (Ms. Vardalos) is understandably depressed. Her teenage daughter, Paris (Elena Kampouris), no longer needs her and her aging parents, Gus and Maria (Michael Constantine and Lainie Kazan), need her too much. And if her husband (John Corbett) is feeling neglected, it could be because his character seems no more than an afterthought this time out.

While Paris endures her familyŠ—Ès relentless get-a-husband gibes (Š—“DonŠ—Èt waste your eggs!Š—), single-shtick characters cram the frame (the inappropriately oversharing aunt; the old-country granny, repeatedly staged as a mute comic prop). The comedy is forced, the drama nonexistent and the actors melt into a yapping clan that seems to go everywhere en masse Š—” a gesticulating blob of upraised shoulders and upturned palms.

Even those who have spent the last 14 years pining for a sequel to Š—“My Big Fat Greek WeddingŠ— Š—” by most accounts, the highest-grossing American romantic comedy Š—” will rue that longing when they experience Š—“My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2.Š— The imagination expended on the title being a fair indicator of how much was lavished on the rest of this embarrassingly awful retread.

But a plot that keeps pushing Toula aside to focus on Gus is right in the wheelhouse of the director, Kirk Jones, whose 1998 comedy, Š—“Waking Ned Devine,Š— reveled in dislocated dentures and geriatric nudity. GusŠ—Ès cranky obsessions are catnip to Mr. Jones, who makes a meal of the characterŠ—Ès belief in the omnipotence of Alexander the Great and the curative powers of Windex. He should have sprayed some on the screenplay.
Š—“My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2Š— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Mortifying confidences and adult groping.

Still, these two founding figures of the modern comic-book cosmos, whose paths have sometimes crossed over the years, display some potentially interesting contrasts of temperament and background. Superman is an immigrant, a working journalist, an idealist and a devoted participant in a long-running office romance. Batman is an alienated rich kid, a perpetual bachelor with a dark view of human nature. He has no natural ability to leap a tall building in a single bound, and so must rely on intelligence, ingenuity and a limitless fortune.

For fun there are shots of the heroes shirtless and of Lois Lane in the bath. But the point of Š—“Batman v SupermanŠ— isnŠ—Èt fun, and it isnŠ—Èt thinking, either. ItŠ—Ès obedience. The theology is invoked not to elicit meditations on mercy, justice or sacrifice, but to buttress a spectacle of power. And in that way the film serves as a metaphor for its own aspirations. The corporations that produce movies like this one, and the ambitious hacks who sign up to make them, have no evident motive beyond their own aggrandizement. Entertainment is less the goal than the byproduct, and as the commercial reach of superpower franchises grows, their creative exhaustion becomes ever more apparent.

Not that anyone cares. (And yes, there are exceptions.) As long as we are paying attention, or at least buying tickets, the system is working to its own satisfaction. In Š—“Batman v Superman,Š— the newspapers are full of controversy about the heroes, whom the fickle public alternately turns on and embraces. Batty and Supey themselves, meanwhile, perpetually mistake their narcissism for high-minded public service, and are encouraged to do so by the cynical and sanctimonious institutions that are nominally in charge of things in Gotham and Metropolis.

A diverting entertainment might have been made about the rivalry between these two muscle-bound paladins Š—” a bromance or a buddy comedy, an album of duets. Š—“Batman v Superman,Š— directed by Zack Snyder (Š—“300,Š— Š—“Watchmen,Š— Š—“Sucker Punch,Š— Š—“Man of SteelŠ—), is none of those things. It is about as diverting as having a porcelain sink broken over your head (one of the more amusing things that happens onscreen). In keeping with current business imperatives, what Mr. Snyder has concocted is less a free-standing film than the opening argument in a very long trial. Its two-and-a-half-hour running time Š—” not so much a Š—“dawnŠ— as an entire morning spent watching the clock in anticipation of lunchtime Š—” is peppered with teasers for coming sequels. You may have heard a rumor that Wonder Woman shows up, or caught sight of her in a trailer for the film. And here she is, played by Gal Gadot.

Mr. Snyder, for his part, deploys signifiers of importance without having anything much to say. Yes, there is a lot of talk (mostly stuffed into poor Mr. EisenbergŠ—Ès mouth) about Good and Evil and God and Man, and there is also a lot of religious symbolism. (Note the crucifixes dotting the landscape near the end.) There are murky shadows and muddy nightscapes, all redolent not just of ordinary danger but of metaphysical darkness. There is Mr. AffleckŠ—Ès existential brooding and the stoic dimple on Mr. CavillŠ—Ès chin.

So I wonŠ—Èt say anything about the trip Lois Lane (Amy Adams) takes to Washington, or about the senator from Kentucky (Holly Hunter) who holds hearings there, or about Lois and ClarkŠ—Ès boss (Laurence Fishburne), except insofar as I am glad to acknowledge the professionalism of the supporting cast. Jesse Eisenberg, as a tech-twerpy Lex Luthor, certainly earned some money. IŠ—Èd prefer to talk about the images and Š—” so help me Š—” the Themes.

The character arrives in full, vintage costume a bit late (weŠ—Ève seen her in evening wear already), in time to join the climactic battle, which features a giant anthropomorphic slime monster and is a sludgy, noisy, chaotic mess. Even more than what has come before. The studio has, in the usual way, begged and bullied critics not to reveal plot points, and I wouldnŠ—Èt dream of denying you the thrill of discovering just how overstuffed and preposterous a movie narrative can be.

Intellectual pretension, long an occupational hazard in the superhero business, has been elevated to a creative principle. Christopher Nolan is partly to blame. His Š—“Dark KnightŠ— entries in the Batman saga raised the genreŠ—Ès allegorical stakes and dialed down the humor to an all-but-imperceptible whisper. Still, Mr. NolanŠ—Ès filmmaking skill Š—” above all the coherence of his inky, cruel vision of Gotham City and environs Š—” enabled those movies to carry at least some of their self-assigned thematic weight.

In Š—“Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice,Š— when Clark Kent (Henry Cavill) looks at a television screen and sees a child trapped in a burning building halfway around the world, he strips down and flies away to rescue her. When Bruce Wayne (Ben Affleck) discovers sexual predators or human traffickers, he suits up and brands their flesh with his winged bat logo.

What an adversarial time this is. Hulk Hogan versus Gawker. Š—“The People v. O. J. Simpson.Š— Bernie versus Hillary. Trump versus Everybody. And now Batman versus Superman. One of these things is not like the others, I know. Two of the most famous good guys in pop culture canŠ—Èt really be enemies, can they? The Gotham Bat and the Man of Steel inhabit the same intellectual-property universe, and the fight between them is, depending on how you look at it, either a diabolical stunt cooked up by Lex Luthor or a cynical cash grab engineered by DC and Warner Brothers.

Š—“Batman v Superman: Dawn of JusticeŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Hints of sexuality and of extreme brutality are meant to make it seem daring and serious. Running time: 2 hours 31 minutes.

The rest of the population Š—” or the digitally created simulacra thereof Š—” is required only to die en masse, to cower in terror, and to watch in wide-eyed, worshipful gratitude. That is just what this movie expects of you: acquiescence. It wants you to believe that itŠ—Ès on your side. DonŠ—Èt be fooled.

Š—“TheyŠ—Ère Watching,Š— a horror film by Micah Wright and Jay Lender, does a commendable amount with very little, using an amusing premise to separate itself from much of the genreŠ—Ès low-budget fare.

Found-footage films, which is what this essentially is, sometimes strain to come up with a reason to explain why people being subjected to horrific things are filming their ordeal. But the premise here provides the necessary license Š—” of course a reality-TV crew will have the cameras running at all times. Kris Lemche and David Alpay play the veteran cameramen, Mia Faith is the young newbie on their crew, and Carrie Genzel plays the humorless boss. The four characters are so preoccupied with insult-hurling, petty politics and simmering romance that they arenŠ—Èt fully on guard against the possibility that theyŠ—Ève stumbled into a village full of malevolent forces.

Anyone who has squandered time watching one of those dumb home-improvement reality programs will recognize Š—“Home Hunters Global,Š— the fictional show that sends a film crew to a village in Moldova, where it follows an American expatriate named Becky (Brigid Brannagh) as she buys a wreck of a fixer-upper. ItŠ—Ès when the crew returns six months later to see how the fixing up has progressed that the creepiness of this particular village becomes evident.

The storytelling becomes muddled in the middle, and the suspense doesnŠ—Èt build as well as it ought to, but the winking undercurrent keeps the film watchable. When all heck finally breaks loose at that fixer-upper, the gore is delivered with flair.

ThatŠ—Ès more or less it, give or take a few details, like the letters Š—” each forgiving, raw, emotional and hectoring Š—” that the son, Michael, sent to each parent before he died. Seemingly his last testament, these letters give Michael a voice and a kind of ghostly presence that grows as his parents talk about what they knew and didnŠ—Èt about him, and why they were no longer close. In a distracting twist, the parents share the first names of the actors playing them, which suggests a connection between the onscreen and offscreen Isabelle and G’©rard (who have worked together before) thatŠ—Ès more inferred than explored.

As Isabelle and G’©rard walk and talk, occasionally popping into the pool, a restaurant or their respective rooms, the movie opens up an attractive, at times seductive intimacy. Michael sounds like a pill and largely remains a cipher, despite the sketchy portrait that emerges through his parents. But Ms. Huppert and Mr. Depardieu are such tremendous, epochal screen presences and performers Š—” every time they appear in a movie, they bring decades of French cinema with them Š—” that it doesnŠ—Èt much matter that theyŠ—Ève convened for a character who turns out to be completely incidental. This movie is finally only about Isabelle Huppert and G’©rard Depardieu, and thatŠ—Ès enough.
Š—“Valley of Love,Š— which is not rated, is in French with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 32 minutes.

The writer-director Guillaume Nicloux has a fondness for art-cinema clich’©s (meandering long takes, shots of the backs of peopleŠ—Ès heads) but he also has an eye for natural landscapes, and some of the better scenes involve Isabelle and G’©rard just parked under an umbrella and talking while framed against the areaŠ—Ès otherworldly beauty. ItŠ—Ès amusing to watch Ms. Huppert and Mr. Depardieu upstage Death Valley, and to that end, special mention must be made of his monumental stomach, which is often bared and big enough to deserve its own billing. ItŠ—Ès a marvel of sorts, as tight as a drum and proud as that of a heavily pregnant woman, which here seems to be the point.

Watching Isabelle Huppert and G’©rard Depardieu sweat it out in Death Valley amid tears, fights and swigs of wine has its obvious attractions. That at any rate seems to be the operating logic behind Š—“Valley of Love,Š— a logy, woo-woo drama about a former couple who, at the request of their son, who killed himself earlier that same year, have come to find answers in the California desert. There, under the sheltering sky and unforgiving sun, they travel high and low on a journey that takes them into canyons, sand dunes, a lost past, their shared memories and finally the ineffable.

Jake (Blake Jenner), a freshman pitcher, shows up at the team house with a crate full of LPs and an easy, slightly wary smile. He receives a mostly friendly welcome, though one guy is forthright about his distaste for pitchers. JakeŠ—Ès roommate, wearing only underpants and cowboy boots, is talking on the phone with his girlfriend. The coach drops by to explain the rules Š—” no women upstairs, no alcohol in the house Š—” mostly so the audience can have the vicarious pleasure of watching as theyŠ—Ère broken.

Mr. Linklater has never been inclined to moralize, and he has banished all piety from this movie, along with any conflict larger than the occasional collision of male egos. There is no political correctness on this campus, and no politics of any kind beyond the adjacent Carter and Reagan voter-registration tables outside the campus dining hall. The film brushes ever so lightly against issues of race and class, but is finally more interested in how its characters are divided by taste, temperament and attitude.

The facial hair works along with the soundtrack, the cars and the clothes to conjure a 1980 that viewers who were around back then may find uncannily, even painfully realistic. Š—“Everybody Wants Some!!,Š— which partakes of Mr. LinklaterŠ—Ès own recollections of Texas, baseball and college, unfolds in a mood of sweet, lascivious retrospect. Only four years of historical time separate it from Š—“Dazed and Confused,Š— but the director is more than 20 years older now, and the greater distance shows. The high jinks in the earlier film were laced with anxiety and aggression: The pranks had a cruel edge, and there was a predatory vibe to some of the sexuality. When you are in your early 30s, as Mr. Linklater was back then, high school is not that far behind you.

The professor, who is only the second or third responsible adult to appear onscreen, writes a thought-provoking quotation on the board: Š—“Frontiers are where you find them.Š— IŠ—Èm not sure where else they are supposed to be, but since the writer and director of Š—“Everybody Wants Some!!Š— is Richard Linklater, thereŠ—Ès no harm in accepting an invitation to some casual philosophizing. ThatŠ—Ès what the characters in his movies tend to do, even the ballplayers in this one. And though their days are spent in pursuit of sex, beer and other delights, the movie does have an undertow of profundity.

Like the quizzical slackers in Š—“Slacker,Š— the boy in Š—“BoyhoodŠ— and Celine and Jesse in the Š—“BeforeŠ— trilogy, the guys on the Southeast Texas State University baseball team are aware of the riddles and paradoxes of time. The strange rhythms of its passage, and the ways those can be captured and counterfeited on film are among Mr. LinklaterŠ—Ès abiding preoccupations. He has described Š—“Everybody Wants Some!!,Š— which takes place in 1980, as a Š—“spiritual sequelŠ— to Š—“Dazed and Confused,Š— his Š—È70s high school masterpiece. ItŠ—Ès also something of a sequel to Š—“Boyhood,Š— since it picks up at almost exactly the life-cycle moment where that movie left off: a young man arrives at college, approaching an invisible frontier on the way to maturity.

For the most part they all get along, fellow citizens in a republic of horniness. The athletes, who at once embody and upend the stereotype of the shallow, sexually entitled jock, go to a disco, a country-and-western bar, a punk-rock show and various parties, and they have a good time wherever they are. It is impossible not to have a good time in their company.
