You can try to be judgmental or jealous, but the beer flows too freely and the camaraderie Š—” which I guess you could call peer pressure Š—” is just too strong.

Plot summary? The guys play Ping-Pong, practice baseball, tease one another mercilessly, smoke weed, listen to records and try to pick up girls, not really in that or any other order. There is mud-wrestling, half-naked Twister and a lot of casual sex. In the midst of it all, Jake pursues a crush on a theater major (Zoey Deutch), who invites him to a party. He gets to know his teammates, whose names are harder to keep track of than their defining attributes. ThereŠ—Ès the sane one (J. Quinton Johnson), the vain one (Tyler Hoechlin), the philosopher (Glen Powell) and the Š—“raw dogŠ— (Juston Street), an arrogant fastballer with a ratty mustache and a hot temper. Also a secondary assortment of goofballs, dimwits and wingmen, each of whom gets at least one big play for the highlight reel.

Š—“Everybody Wants Some!!Š— is many things Š—” a baseball caper, a sex farce, a campus romance, a campus bromance Š—” but the filmŠ—Ès real claim to distinction may be that itŠ—Ès the least suspenseful ticking-clock movie ever. We start out counting down the days and hours over the last long weekend before the beginning of the fall semester at a Texas college, and at the end of the movie (spoiler alert? are you kidding me?) itŠ—Ès time for class.

But when you are in your 50s, college is an almost mythically distant land, and Š—“Everybody Wants Some!!Š— is more than just nostalgic. ItŠ—Ès downright utopian, a hormonal pastoral endowed with the innocent charm of a childrenŠ—Ès book. There are plenty of movies about lust-addled youth, but itŠ—Ès unusual to find one that feels truly wholesome. In college, one of JakeŠ—Ès new pals explains, Š—“The girls can be just as slutty as the guys,Š— and at this college, at least, the pursuit of pleasure proceeds without shame, risk or hard feelings. (The guys, by the way, are as vain as any gossip girls, primping endlessly before heading out to a club and admiring the curve-hugging tightness of their own jeans.) The premise is explained in the title, and everybody gets at least some of what they want.
Š—“Everybody Wants Some!!Š— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Dude! Running time: 1 hour 57 minutes.

Ms. LambertŠ—Ès film builds nicely, staying in tune with the ordinariness and intimacy explored in Ms. AkermanŠ—Ès boldly rendered films. Nobody knows how Ms. Akerman would have followed the personal watershed of Š—“No Home Movie,Š— but Ms. Lambert wisely directs us back to the stories told across all of her work.

Most moving are conversations about Ms. AkermanŠ—Ès final film, Š—“No Home Movie.Š— That valedictory work centered on her mother, a Holocaust survivor whose presence and past haunted and charmed this filmmakerŠ—Ès oeuvre. Ms. Akerman (looking somewhat vulnerable) and her longtime editor, Claire Atherton, explain the power of precise compositions, timing and sequences.

ItŠ—Ès challenging to make a movie about a filmmaker who was such a master at telling her own story. In Š—“I DonŠ—Èt Belong Anywhere: The Cinema of Chantal Akerman,Š— Marianne Lambert makes a sensitive attempt at portraying Ms. Akerman, a groundbreaking director, and her work, displaying a comfort level perhaps born of working as a production manager for her subject.
Š—“I DonŠ—Èt Belong Anywhere: The Cinema of Chantal Akerman,Š— in French, with English subtitles, is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 7 minutes.

Ms. Akerman, who died in October at 65, is interviewed here in the parts of the world she had inhabited and explored, from New York to Israel. She talks freely about her beginnings in Brussels and in New York in the 1970s, and the personal echoes and artistic thinking behind such films as Š—“Jeanne Dielman, 23 Quai du Commerce, 1080 Bruxelles,Š— Š—“News From HomeŠ— and Š—“A Couch in New York.Š— Aurore Cl’©ment, star of Ms. AkermanŠ—Ès Š—“Les Rendez-Vous dŠ—ÈAnna,Š— pays tribute, as does Gus Van Sant, who cites Ms. AkermanŠ—Ès influence on Š—“Last Days,Š— a film he made that was inspired by the end of Kurt CobainŠ—Ès life.

Professionally comfortable with improvising, the D.J.s make for affable company, and itŠ—Ès amusing to watch radio from behind the scenes. But a tinge of melancholy also hovers over the movie, which suggests that success has a ceiling at a station where even stars go unpaid. Tom Scharpling, seen as a devoted host of Š—“The Best Show on WFMU,Š— eventually leaves. He has spun off his show into a popular podcast.

Matt Groening, creator of Š—“The Simpsons,Š— and Lee Ranaldo of Sonic Youth both praise the programming, known for its eclecticism and rebelliousness. The filmŠ—Ès director, Tim K. Smith, shows WFMU mixing styles and genres (the playlist includes undersung bands alongside a man who makes music on glassware) as freely as it mixes politics. (Nachum Segal, the voice of its show Š—“Jewish Moments in the Morning,Š— gets a testimonial from Rush Limbaugh.)

Ken Freedman, WFMUŠ—Ès manager, speaks of challenges from the recession, copyright issues and competitors Š—” problems that the movie could have explored more deeply. Skimming the details, the documentary observes Mr. FreedmanŠ—Ès race against a deadline from the Federal Communications Commission to finance a signal-boosting tower in New York City. Š—“Sex and BroadcastingŠ— also shoehorns in some of WFMUŠ—Ès six-decade history: It began operating out of Upsala College in East Orange in 1958 and moved after the college closed in 1995.
Š—“Sex and Broadcasting Š—” A Film About WFMUŠ— is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 18 minutes.

Hardly as salacious as its name suggests, the documentary Š—“Sex and Broadcasting Š—” A Film About WFMUŠ— paints an affectionate portrait of this Jersey City radio station  (91.1 FM in the New York City area, and 90.1 in the Hudson Valley), which remains listener-supported at a time when corporate or umbrella funding is the norm. (The first half of the title comes from a book on community radio by Lorenzo W. Milam.)

And thatŠ—Ès it. Obviously, this is not a film for viewers unfamiliar with Mr. TsaiŠ—Ès work. But its insistently austere format does suggest a purpose beyond its immediate context. The leaves that rustle outside as the men talk, and when they pause, bring to mind a fragment of Ezra PoundŠ—Ès Š—“The CantosŠ—: Š—“I have tried to write Paradise/Do not move/Let the wind speak/That is paradise.Š—

Š—“Recently IŠ—Ève been getting this strong feeling that I may be dying soon.Š— The Taiwanese filmmaker Tsai Ming-liang, 58, makes this confession early on in his new picture, the sublimely simple, emotionally charged Š—“Afternoon.Š— A little over two hours, it documents a fitful conversation between Mr. Tsai and the actor Lee Kang-sheng. About 10 years Mr. TsaiŠ—Ès junior, Mr. Lee appears in nearly every film Mr. Tsai has made; many of these, including Š—“Goodbye, Dragon InnŠ— and Š—“What Time Is It There?,Š— are masterpieces of contemporary Asian cinema.

The setup for Š—“AfternoonŠ— may sound familiar to experts in cinematic minimalism; nonetheless, the film has a distinct feel. A single camera, tilted down from a relatively tall position, takes in a corner of an unfinished room in a house. Two windows, one on each wall, show the house is situated someplace high; a mountain covered in lush vegetation is visible through the left window opening, and vines are straggling into the right. Mr. Tsai and Mr. Lee, seated on leather chairs, face each other and chat. Mr. Tsai is chattier; Mr. Lee hardly opens his mouth for the first 20 minutes. Mr. TsaiŠ—Ès volubility barely masks a greater vulnerability, and the conversation, which encompasses family, sexuality and art-making, has an elliptical quality that finally asks, with some anguish, if the duoŠ—Ès collaboration is finished, or will continue.

Using the simplest of settings Š—” and familiar genre devices Š—” Mickey KeatingŠ—Ès horror outing Š—“DarlingŠ— manages to conjure an effectively unsettling miasma. The story borrows from the Polanski playbook (particularly Š—“RepulsionŠ— and Š—“The TenantŠ—): A young woman, Darling (Lauren Ashley Carter), accepts an assignment from a wealthy matron (Sean Young) to mind an upscale Manhattan apartment, only to unravel into a homicidal psychopath. A previous employee committed suicide while performing the same work, so perhaps the apartment itself exerts a malevolent force.

Š—“RepulsionŠ— had an arresting feminist subtext, in which the persistent onslaught of the male gaze drove Catherine Deneuve over the edge; Š—“DarlingŠ— doesnŠ—Èt bother with such commentary (though there is a hapless male victim, played by Brian Morvant). Darling merely has had a hidden history of mental illness Š—” and maybe a bad relationship.

Out come the time-honored trappings: the carving knife; a soundtrack alternating among ambient Lynchian strains, cheesy pop numbers and snatches of hard-core rock; lightning-fast shock cuts in the editing, including glimpses of dismemberment. But also present are impressive performances, especially a compellingly mercurial turn by the horror veteran Ms. Carter (a star of Mr. KeatingŠ—Ès Š—“PodŠ— and Lucky McKeeŠ—Ès Š—“The WomanŠ—). Another invaluable asset is the directorŠ—Ès frequent cinematographer, Mac Fisken, whose gorgeous, haunting black-and-white compositions enlist the Manhattan cityscape as one more threatening entity.

Their negotiations Š—” quiet conversations over coffee and cigarettes, reminiscent of the courteous exchanges between the aristocratic French and German officers in Jean RenoirŠ—Ès Š—“Grand IllusionŠ— Š—” are interspersed with Mr. SokurovŠ—Ès meditations and a twilight tour of the museumŠ—Ès galleries. Our guides are Marianne, the allegorical embodiment of FranceŠ—Ès republican ideals, and Napoleon Bonaparte, the actual embodiment of the nationŠ—Ès imperial ambitions. Together they represent the notion of French universalism, an idea consecrated in the LouvreŠ—Ès gathering of art from around the world.

The fate of art is the main concern of Š—“Francofonia,Š— which takes place mostly in and around the Louvre. Its museum setting makes the film a companion piece of sorts to Š—“Russian Ark,Š— Mr. SokurovŠ—Ès single-shot tour of the Hermitage in St. Petersburg and something of an American art house hit in 2002. But while that film was a 99-minute sprint through the Russian past, this one lingers over a particular episode during the Nazi occupation of France. It takes the form of an extended cinematic essay, blending fictionalized re-enactments of plausible events with excursions into scholarship and fantasy.

ItŠ—Ès also hard not to notice what Š—” or rather, who Š—” is missing from this tableau. As I was leaving a recent press screening, a friend asked, Š—“What about the Jews?Š— There is indeed something unsettling about a chronicle of European history that gives such prominent attention to the Nazis without so much as mentioning the principal targets of their hatred. Not only that. What used to be called the Jewish Question is so deeply woven into the tapestry of modern Europe that to avoid it when talking about Napoleon, Hitler, culture and Russia seems more like a willful evasion than an innocent oversight.

The Russian filmmaker Alexander Sokurov has a gift, perhaps unmatched among his international peers, for turning intellectual brooding into visually arresting cinema. He tackles big, capitalized themes Š—” Power, Art, Virtue, Evil Š—” but his films speak in whispers, murmurs and ruminative pauses. They often feel as intimate and inscrutable as diary entries, even when they deal with monstrous public figures like Hitler, Stalin and Hirohito. Mr. Sokurov forgoes sweeping pictorial gestures and period pageantry in favor of quiet lyricism and tight, sometimes claustrophobic compositions. He thinks a lot about history, and in his best work you can hear history thinking.

The main characters are Jacques Jaujard (Louis-Do de Lencquesaing), director of the Louvre in the 1930s and Š—È40s, and Count Franz Wolff-Metternich (Benjamin Utzerath), HitlerŠ—Ès designated connoisseur and conservator of French art. Though many of the LouvreŠ—Ès great paintings had been hidden in chateaus in the countryside, Jaujard and Wolff-Metternich collaborated to keep the museum open during the occupation and to protect its collection.

While Mr. SokurovŠ—Ès Francophilia is apparent, so is a melancholy sense of national grievance. The extent of Russian suffering during World War II is still insufficiently recognized in the West, and Russia remains on the margins of the European story. Though present-day politics are outside the frame of Š—“Francofonia,Š— they nonetheless cast a shadow. ItŠ—Ès hard to listen in on the directorŠ—Ès thoughts, or to eavesdrop on Napoleon and Marianne, without thinking about FranceŠ—Ès current identity crisis, and also about RussiaŠ—Ès resurgent, defensive nationalism.

The Nazis, who believed themselves the heirs and masters of European civilization, had an interest in protecting ParisŠ—Ès status as a cultural capital. They were assisted by members of the local elite, like Jaujard, who chose compromise over resistance. Mr. Sokurov bitterly contrasts the relative normalcy of France under German rule with the siege of Leningrad, whose citizens starved and froze and whose cultural patrimony was not spared.
Š—“Francofonia,Š— which is not rated, is in French, German and Russian with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 27 minutes.

He appears in his latest film, Š—“Francofonia,Š— thinking out loud in his study, where he also participates in video chats with the captain of a storm-tossed container ship somewhere in the North Atlantic. There are valuable works of art on board, and the vessel itself is an obvious metaphor for civilization, that grand leaky frigate whose contents Ezra Pound once itemized as Š—“two gross of broken statuesŠ— and Š—“a few thousand battered books.Š—

The source and meaning of this omission is one more thing to think about in a film that invites serious thought. ItŠ—Ès a work of art that troubles the conscience, in part because it suggests, both by default and by design, that no art is innocent, and that its preservation, like its destruction, depends on the operation of power.
c. Barware that shatters spontaneously.
a. A woman named Helen who sets her alarm to wake her at 4:50 a.m. for an intimate feeding session with her creepily lifelike baby doll.
2. Who is craziest?
c. A guy, probably not named Helen, who explodes into maniacal laughter upon seeing a mammoth disembodied head (presumably once part of a classical statue) that was pulled from the Hudson River.

Troy, N.Y., in terminally crepuscular winter, is depressing enough without broken glass or dismembered statuary. And this being a Troy replete with Helens, the equine cameos that rear their heads should be no surprise. But Š—“H.Š— would have you believe that an enormously bright and completely unexplained explosion sets off a series of equally inexplicable events when itŠ—Ès clear that these Trojans were (how to say it kindly?) atypical from the start.
b. The violent smothering of a helpless inanimate object.
b. Another Helen, this one pregnant, who embraces her partner in art and life with a brutality that leaves them both bloodied.

Lucky for us, the hyperlocal TV news reports every sneeze, disappearance, group coma and seeming violation of the laws of physics, providing a wealth of clues. Making sense of them as a whole, however, might not be desirable or even possible.
Oh, and all the quiz items do appear in the movie, but the craziness question is your call entirely.
a. Large ovoid snowballs that may contain fetuses.
1. Which of these phenomena can be seen in the movie Š—“H.Š—?
A clever film written and directed by Rania Attieh and Daniel Garcia, Š—“H.Š— keeps the viewer watchful, waiting for it to splatter into a familiar horror plot or spin off into an alien abduction.
A movie that raises more questions than it answers lends itself perfectly to a review that starts with a quiz:

Anchoring the pungent 1990s ambience is Mr. Hoult, easily oozing cool charisma. Not addressed is the imminent tsunami of illegal downloading, which was to sap the music industry of much profitability and presumably help defang sharks like Stelfox.

Stelfox indulges in all manner of corruption, including murder, to achieve his ends, his ascent awash in pot, booze, cocaine, Ecstasy and bacchanals as he flits to a convention in Nice, France; South by Southwest in Austin, Tex.; and Manhattan, chasing deals and potential hitmakers.

On the way he signs a Spice Girls-like group, the Songbirds, only to have his thunder stolen by the Lazies, an alternative band of greater integrity, whose rise he has ignored. Other obstructions to his advancement include his dissipated colleague Waters (a fine James Corden, light-years from his talk-show persona) and Parker Hall (a steady Tom Riley), a hotshot executive on to StelfoxŠ—Ès amoral tactics and blocking his path to control of Unigram. In StelfoxŠ—Ès corner is his secretary (Georgia King, on point, like everyone else in this assured production).

The Britpop scene of the 1990s takes it squarely on the chin in the blisteringly bleak Š—“Kill Your Friends,Š— a richly satisfying poison-pen letter to the music industry directed by Owen Harris. Written by John Niven, a former artists-and-repertoire man, adapting his own novel, the movie follows the Machiavellian destiny of Steven Stelfox (Nicholas Hoult of Š—“Mad Max: Fury RoadŠ—), a ruthless corporate climber at the London record label Unigram.

Š—“Marinoni: The Fire in the Frame,Š— a documentary by Tony Girardin, opens with Giuseppe Marinoni bent over a bicycle heŠ—Ès building, welding torch in hand, in his workshop near Montreal. He doesnŠ—Èt enjoy having the camera around, and hates talking about himself: Š—“The welds can feel the stress,Š— he complains.

Once a champion cyclist who went to Canada to race and never left, Mr. Marinoni, 75, is now a master craftsman whose bicycles are prized by devotees. Mr. Girardin catches him as he trains to break the speed record for his age group, following him from studio to home to Italy, where they visit Mr. MarinoniŠ—Ès village before heading to the velodrome where the attempt takes place.

For all the access he grants, Mr. Marinoni is not very open. ItŠ—Ès left to his fans to attest to his bikesŠ—È superior quality Š—” and his cranky ways. And aside from calling it a passion, Mr. Marinoni doesnŠ—Èt explain what captivates him about bicycles and cycling, or what drives him on this record quest. A chronicle of obsession ought to provide some insights.

A glimpse is supplied by Jocelyn Lovell, a onetime champion Canadian cyclist whose career ended horrifically when he was hit by a truck in 1983. Left a quadriplegic, Mr. Lovell speaks of cycling the way Louis Armstrong did of jazz Š—” if you have to ask, youŠ—Èll never know. In his bid for the record, Mr. Marinoni uses a bike he built for Mr. Lovell four decades earlier, and itŠ—Ès the meeting of these men after so many years that provides the soul for this machine.

But which Miles, which period, which sound? ItŠ—Ès a little of this, a lot of that, with melody, rhythm, harmony. Some of it takes place in the Š—È50s, around the time he met his first wife, Frances Taylor (Emayatzy Corinealdi), and was working with the arranger Gil Evans, with whom Davis cut the record Š—“Miles Ahead.Š— Mostly, the movie gets its funny-strange groove on in Š—È79, when Davis had gone quiet (1975 to early 1980) and didnŠ—Èt play his horn. Š—“I would walk by it and look at it,Š— Davis wrote in his autobiography, Š—“then think about trying to play. But after that I didnŠ—Èt even do that.Š— In the movie, when he eyes his horn itŠ—Ès as if it were a threat or a mirror: You lookinŠ—È at me?

In narrative terms, Dave the journalist is the streamlined and far more economical version of the reporter in Š—“Citizen KaneŠ— who, after death comes to Charles Foster Kane in his castle, sets the investigation Š—” the biography Š—” in motion. Dave breaches MilesŠ—Ès Xanadu with a foot in the door, a scene that Mr. Cheadle plays for slapstick-spiked comedy. (Dave ends up inside, Miles out, banging to be let in.) Davis is a monumental figure, but Mr. Cheadle isnŠ—Èt working in marble. His approach is human-scaled. He lets you see Miles sweat, shows the vanity Š—” Miles primping his hair Š—” panic, drug-hunger, meanness, but also the sly intelligence, pleasure and genius. Miles is modal, as he tells Dave, a nod to the improvisational scale-based jazz exemplified by his landmark record Š—“Kind of Blue.Š—

Frances turns out to be MilesŠ—Ès Rosebud in this telling. Shortly after Dave wedges himself into MilesŠ—Ès life, they end up at Columbia Records, where Miles Š—” after a showdown with some music types, including one played by a peerless Michael Stuhlbarg Š—” ends up in an elevator lined with mounted records. Seeing Frances on the cover of his album Š—“Some Day My Prince Will ComeŠ— sends Miles back in time. There, he is the younger Miles, dressed in sharp suits, on top of the scene and in love with Frances, who melts in and out like a dream as the story shifts between past and present. Mr. Cheadle, making his directorial feature debut, switches times, moods and modes effortlessly.
Š—“Miles AheadŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying adult guardian or parent) for all that jazz. Running time: 1 hour 40 minutes.

Does it matter that stretches of Š—“Miles AheadŠ— Š—” a gun-rattling, squealing-tire car chase included Š—” came out of the filmmakersŠ—È imagination rather than DavisŠ—Ès life? (Mr. Cheadle shares script credit with Steven Baigelman.) Purists may howl, but theyŠ—Èll also miss the pleasure and point of this playfully impressionistic movie. Big-screen biographies tend to come in one flavor: the bittersweet hagiographic. Most are polite exhumations that follow the often great man of history/art/politics arc with the usual highs and lows, witchy and whiny women, and transcendent payoff. Š—“Miles AheadŠ— has these, including the transcendence; this is, after all, about Miles Davis.

ThereŠ—Ès a hopped-up scene in Š—“Miles Ahead,Š— controlled yet frenzied, when you get why Don Cheadle decided to go for broke. HeŠ—Ès playing Miles Davis (he also directed) and the time is the late 1970s Š—” although itŠ—Ès also the 1960s. Time and space tend to blur in this movie and while the setting is a Š—È70s boxing match, a couple of figures from MilesŠ—Ès past Š—” his wife, his younger self Š—” soon swing in to shake things up. SheŠ—Ès running scared and the 1970s Miles is running amok, but the younger Miles, well, there he is, too, playing it cool in the ring. Music is fighting, at least for this pugilist.

Things go bad, as does Miles. Mr. Cheadle doesnŠ—Èt judge; instead, he presents Miles as a man of complications and contradictions who, after hanging up the phone with Frances, returns to a bed full of women. Sometimes, it seems that Mr. Cheadle has shaved off too many of the real manŠ—Ès edges, as in a domestic fight in which Miles doesnŠ—Èt throw the first punch. ItŠ—Ès a tough, furious scene, but for impact it has nothing on the follow-up, which shows a seemingly contrite Miles putting first a jeweled necklace Š—” and then his arm Š—” around the anguished FrancesŠ—È neck. It turns out that Mr. Cheadle is somewhat of a pugilist himself, and he has a killer sucker punch.

The movieŠ—Ès framing device is familiar, but works. In 1979, a journalist, Dave (Ewan McGregor), bangs on MilesŠ—Ès New York brownstone. Dave is a scribbler for Rolling Stone or so he claims, and is here for the story, which is more or less the filmmakersŠ—È and our goal, too. Scuffing around in a bathrobe and dark glasses the sizes of hubcaps, Miles has gone hermit, the Prince of Darkness turned the Prince of Silence. His health is bad and one of his hips is shot, and all the street drugs probably arenŠ—Èt helping. (By his own account, Davis was at one point snorting four or five grams of coke a day, while smoking four packs of cigarettes. Forget playing Š—” how could he breathe?)

While Š—“FilmŠ— was to be BeckettŠ—Ès only foray into the medium Š—” and not, it must be said, an entirely successful one Š—” his collaborators were prominent figures in movie history. In addition to Keaton, there was Boris Kaufman, an important cinematographer and the younger brother of the great Soviet director and documentarian Dziga Vertov. Mr. Lipman makes much of that connection, and threads Š—“NotfilmŠ— with lovely clips from VertovŠ—Ès films and other silent treasures.

Samuel Beckett and Buster Keaton surely possess two of the most photogenic faces of the 20th century, contrasting images of haplessness and stoicism. BeckettŠ—Ès deeply lined visage, surmounted by a sweep of silver hair, is an emblem of late modernism, a quietly charismatic mask of weary resolve in the face of existential absurdity. KeatonŠ—Ès smooth brow and melancholy deadpan, customarily shadowed by a porkpie hat, express an ingenious, innocent determination to surmount whatever obstacles the universe imposes.

Mr. LipmanŠ—Ès title has several connotations. ItŠ—Ès a declaration of modest intentions, for one thing. It also evokes Š—“Not I,Š— the fevered monologue Š—” delivered by a disembodied mouth Š—” that is numbered among BeckettŠ—Ès theatrical masterpieces. And there is more than a hint of Beckettian self-reference, since Mr. LipmanŠ—Ès project, motivated partly by his work as a preservationist, is very much an artifact of the digital age. A charming, earnest, sometimes ungainly mixture of history, criticism and high-minded gossip, Š—“NotfilmŠ— testifies to an almost inexhaustible fascination with the pleasures and paradoxes of cinema.

These are accompanied by voice-over narration that is witty and meditative, and that pushes against the constraints of the Š—“making ofŠ— documentary template. Mr. Lipman has much to say about the making and transmission of moving images, about the role of the movie camera in modern life and about the philosophical underpinnings of BeckettŠ—Ès literary and theatrical vision. At times you may wish he had absorbed some of BeckettŠ—Ès Š—” or KeatonŠ—Ès Š—” ferocious discipline. Both of them were masters of pared-down precision and elegant understatement. Mr. LipmanŠ—Ès sensibility, by contrast, is expansive and digressive, attracted to loftiness and sweep.

Beckett was fascinated and troubled by the mechanical reproduction, by the ways various recording machines both assuage and intensify the alienation of modern life. Extracts from KeatonŠ—Ès work, in particular Š—“The Cameraman,Š— suggest that he had similar interests, though he was always more concerned with technique than theory, and did not think much of Beckett or Š—“Film.Š— All the same, KeatonŠ—Ès performance in it is full of pathos and professionalism, as is Š—“Notfilm,Š— which in exploring the intersection between the Beckettian and the Keatonesque finds a hitherto uncharted dimension of human and cinematic experience.

But that is, in the end, a good thing. The work of Beckett is an invitation to think, and itŠ—Ès an invitation Mr. Lipman accepts with alacrity. Happily, Š—“NotfilmŠ— does not neglect behind-the-scenes anecdotes. Though many of the participants are no longer living, there are illuminating interviews with Jean Schneider, the widow of the director of Š—“Film,Š— and with James Karen, a familiar character actor and close friend of KeatonŠ—Ès who had a role in Š—“Film.Š— These conversations are supplemented with other reminiscences and ruminations, by archival stills and clips, and by extraordinary audio recordings of script readings.
Š—“NotfilmŠ— is not rated. Running time: 2 hours 8 minutes.

The two men can also look like kindred artistic spirits, committed to formal rigor and possessing finely tuned comic sensibilities. It is not surprising Š—” though it is also, somehow, astonishing Š—” that they worked together once, on a film devised by Beckett and titled Š—“Film.Š— A little more than 20 minutes long, devoid of dialogue (though not of sound), it was made in New York in the summer of 1965. And it is now the subject of an intelligent, affectionate documentary by Ross Lipman, titled Š—“Notfilm.Š— (A restoration of the Beckett short, directed by his faithful collaborator Alan Schneider, accompanies Mr. LipmanŠ—Ès film during its run at Anthology Film Archives.)

With brisk, fluid concision, the film jumps to countries fast-tracking solar energy production: Germany and China, which is Š—“now the leading country in terms of how fast they are implementing sustainable technology at really large scale,Š— according to Peggy Liu, chairwoman of the nonprofit Joint U.S.-China Collaboration on Clean Energy.

One notion underlying Shalini KantayyaŠ—Ès winning documentary, Š—“Catching the Sun,Š— is that solar power is not only a cleaner alternative to fossil fuels but can also effectively curtail unemployment. The film begins in Northern California, which has experienced at least one refinery accident, and where clean-energy initiatives Š—” Sungevity, Solar Richmond Š—” are hiring and training area residents.

Van Jones, an Oakland, Calif., lawyer and activist who wrote the best seller Š—“The Green Collar Economy,Š— wasnŠ—Èt so fortunate. His efforts earned him an appointment as the Obama administrationŠ—Ès special adviser for environmental jobs. But vociferous opposition to him from the former radio and Fox News personality Glenn Beck and Republicans in Congress forced his resignation. The battle for a greener tomorrow, we are reminded, has its casualties.

Fascinating portraits stand out. In Atlanta, Debbie Dooley, founder of Conservatives for Energy Freedom, advocates solar energyŠ—Ès growth within a free market, rejecting the idea that itŠ—Ès a left-versus-right issue. Zhongwei Jiang, an entrepreneur in Wuxi, China, lived without electricity until he was 7. Capitalizing on the Chinese governmentŠ—Ès investments in renewable energy, he founded WesTech, a solar business, in 2003. Now it is finding partners in Germany, and, he says, growing by 50 percent every year.
Š—“Too LateŠ— is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 47 minutes.

While it can be frustrating to see some filmmakers dash off copies of other movies, itŠ—Ès deeply enjoyable to find one who so appreciates his inspirations. Mr. HauckŠ—Ès affection is apparent in every frame, yet outside of an occasionally clunky line or show-offy moment (O.K., sometimes itŠ—Ès more occasional than just occasionally), he rarely allows it to alter his aim. That aim is to make a modern noir. That aim is true.

Mr. Hawkes resists the urge to overplay the characterŠ—Ès toughness or his damaged soul, and that makes him all the more watchable as the camera trails him, often as heŠ—Ès smoking a cigarette or drinking booze, while music pulses through those unbroken shots.

Dennis Hauck, in writing and directing his first feature, knows that the story line has been well trodden, so he dresses it up supernice Š—” the movie is shot in marvelous 35 millimeter (Bill Fernandez is the cinematographer) thatŠ—Ès no less picturesque for being so washed-out. Further, there are just five scenes, each filmed in a single take of about 20 minutes.

Those scenes are arranged nonchronologically, ’¾ la Š—“Pulp Fiction,Š— and itŠ—Ès absurdly entertaining to watch the pieces fit together and to see the story loop around in time. IŠ—Èll admit to having several Š—“Aha!Š— flashes the next day, thinking back on images and snippets of dialogue that turned out to be clues.

If I were as cynical as the hard-boiled characters of Š—“Too Late,Š— I might scoff that each scene is overstuffed with fawning references to classic film noir, Quentin Tarantino and pulp novels. Actually, I am that cynical. And yet I still couldnŠ—Èt help loving almost every moment of the movie.

Crystal Reed and Dichen Lachman, as dancers who figure into the plot (about which, the less said by me, the better for you), are by turns adorable and enigmatic. Robert Forster, as a club owner, plays it extra-crusty. His single scene, as staged by Mr. Hauck, is intense and perfectly paced.

Set in a modern-day Southern California that has a 1970s Robert Altman feel, John Hawkes plays Mel Sampson, a private investigator who is determined to avenge a murder. Along the way he meets a collection of good-hearted strippers and heavy-handed baddies who usually have a quirky observation or a tart reply at the ready.

Much of the rest of this two-hour movie takes place in Natalia AkermanŠ—Ès pin-neat, middle-class apartment in Brussels. For the most part, Ms. Akerman simply records her mother in this apartment, fuss-budgeting about while murmuring to herself or talking to visitors like Ms. Akerman, whose camera often sits on a surface like another household appliance (which it is). The conversations between mother and daughter span the continuum from light to dark, present to past, from the young ChantalŠ—Ès untied shoelaces to the Holocaust. Sometimes mother and daughter talk via Skype and you can see Ms. Akerman, who often seems to be calling from a new location, pointing her camera at her laptop, her tiny image in the window that lets each caller see how she looks to the other.

Ms. Akerman died in October, apparently a suicide, at 65. One of the most influential filmmakers of the past several decades, she leaves behind two-dozen features, including Š—“No Home Movie,Š— which serves as a conceptual and emotional counterpoint to her early masterwork, Š—“Jeanne Dielman, 23, Quai du Commerce, 1080 BruxellesŠ— (1975), which she made when she was 25. Her death makes Š—“No Home MovieŠ— even more of a memento mori than perhaps it might have seemed when she finished it, given her motherŠ—Ès impending death. Yet this makes the movie sound far too bleak, especially in light of the love Š—” the love that Ms. Akerman has for her mother, who returns it in kind Š—” that suffuses it.

Midway through Š—“No Home Movie,Š— Ms. Akerman cuts to a succession of traveling shots of a desert. They cleave the movie in two. ThereŠ—Ès no overt explanation for them; thereŠ—Ès no voice-over commentary and none of the traditional documentary time, date and location markers. Again, as she does with the image of the shuddering tree, Ms. Akerman lets you read the image for yourself, even as she has also carefully laid out the movieŠ—Ès meaning in every previous edit, shot and word, including her motherŠ—Ès remembrances of the familyŠ—Ès history, about keeping kosher, about the flight from Poland, the Nazis and the war. In your head, these mother-daughter conversations Š—” Š—“We thought we were safe here, in Belgium,Š— Natalia says at one point Š—” become one with the thrashing desert wind.

Yet the first image in Š—“No Home MovieŠ— is of a tree in a desert. ItŠ—Ès an old tree by the looks of the spindly, half-bare branches shuddering violently in the wind. ItŠ—Ès a simple, seemingly artless and largely stationary shot Š—” Ms. Akerman adjusts the framing, always keeping the tree on the left Š—” and because she holds on it for more than four minutes, you either look at it, really look at it, or leave. If you stay, you notice the wire (telephone?) across the bottom right corner, the road that bisects the image horizontally and the distant hills capped by the pale sky. Mostly, though, there is this resolute, trembling tree perched on what looks like an abyss. How, you wonder, does it survive?

These Skype talks charm you with sweet declarations (Š—“kissesŠ—) and some gentle comedy (Maman is a bit technologically challenged), although mostly with their unguarded intimacy. Like the rest of the movie, they have the spontaneity and ineffable fascination of real life; it feels as if Ms. Akerman had turned on the camera seconds before she and her mother began talking. In time, though, her mother grows increasingly frail, they also assume an undertow of sadness. Ms. AkermanŠ—Ès filmography, which sent her across the globe, from the Baltics to Mexico, has turned her into one of cinemaŠ—Ès nomads, as have the festivals (Berlin, Cannes, New York) in which her work has been presented. ThereŠ—Ès a rootlessness to her, as even her meanderings through her motherŠ—Ès apartment suggest.
Š—“No Home MovieŠ— is not rated. It is in French, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 55 minutes.

And, just like that, the title of Š—“No Home MovieŠ— takes on piercing meaning. Like any number of Ms. AkermanŠ—Ès other movies, this one revisits some of her preoccupations Š—” home, exile, memory, identity, bodies, specifically the female body, on- and offscreen space Š—” through the prism of Natalia, long one her most ineluctable subjects. Ms. AkermanŠ—Ès movies are unmistakably personal in the rigorousness of their formal design but also in their motifs, with each informing the other. ThatŠ—Ès true of Š—“Jeanne Dielman,Š— an unblinking three-and-a-half-hour look at an outwardly impassive Belgian homemaker (Delphine Seyrig) who turns tricks in her immaculate, sterile apartment amid other quotidian activities like folding sheets and making a meatloaf for more than three deliberate minutes.

The last time the filmmaker Chantal Akerman appears in Š—“No Home MovieŠ— sheŠ—Ès tying her shoelaces. Seated on a bed in a dark, sparsely furnished room with a single window, she doesnŠ—Èt say anything. She just ties her shoes, draws the curtains and exits, letting the shot linger on the empty room. Her mother, Natalia, has been failing and Ms. AkermanŠ—Ès melancholy hangs over the scene like funeral crepe. The first time I watched it, her heavy silence was painful to see; the second time, watching had turned into raw feeling because Ms. Akerman is now gone.

If you let it, Š—“No Home MovieŠ— invites you in first with its intimacy and then its deep feeling. ItŠ—Ès filled with Ms. AkermanŠ—Ès signatures, like images of doorways, halls and obliquely shot rooms, which can make her seem like a spy in her motherŠ—Ès house. This is not, as the title reminds you, a home movie in the usual sense, and yet it is. The deaths haunting it as well as some of its themes Š—” the Holocaust, the Jewish diaspora, that far-off desert and the refuge we find in anotherŠ—Ès embrace Š—” can make it unbearably sad. The moment that I keep returning to occurs during a Skype talk when Ms. Akerman shows her reflection in her laptop screen, her face floating over her motherŠ—Ès like a ghost. SheŠ—Ès away yet she also feels home.

A feminist touchstone, Š—“Jeanne DielmanŠ— has often been discussed within a theoretical and political framework (voyeurism, the male gaze) that can feel as mechanical as a 101 intro to cinema studies. With its long takes, silences and emphasis on the kinds of everyday moments that most movies tend to ignore, the film isnŠ—Èt obviously inviting, perhaps particularly for viewers whose rhythms are calibrated to those of dominant cinema and its three acts, ping-pinging shots and counter-shots, inciting incidents and tidy ends. You need to meet Ms. Akerman on her terms, although even when you do, her work may not completely open itself up to you, even after repeated viewings. Its difficulty (or mystery), which can feel like her stubborn persistence of vision, is part of its pleasure.

The film fills in just enough of MalonyŠ—Ès background to suggest that he comes from a clan of troublesome hotheads on his fatherŠ—Ès side, but the family history is sketchy at best, and there are frustrating gaps in the storyŠ—Ès narrative flow. With her unstable, high-strung temperament, MalonyŠ—Ès slovenly mother, who is too intimidated by him to set boundaries, is almost as unstable as he is.

The older of two sons raised by a struggling single mother (Sara Forestier) with substance abuse problems, the tantrum-prone Malony is a spitting, snarling, cursing monster given to convulsive fits of rage in which he violently lashes out against authority. His eyes narrowed to venomous slits, he regards the world with an incendiary hostility.

The movieŠ—Ès closest equivalent to the priest of Š—“Boys TownŠ— is Florence Blaque (Catherine Deneuve), the magistrate in charge of MalonyŠ—Ès case for 10 years, until he turns 18. Ms. Deneuve, whom Ms. Bercot directed in Š—“On My Way,Š— gives one of her warmest, most outgoing performances as a stern but patient judicial overseer whose regal equanimity is continually tested by MalonyŠ—Ès outrageous, furious defiance.

Mr. ParadotŠ—Ès performance is so viscerally intense that there is no escaping its force. One of his favorite stunts is to jump into a car for a crazy joy ride that can end in a crash. Lacking an attention span, he is frustrated by any kind of instruction. When a task is challenging, he freaks out. But he also has a keen native intelligence. The only work he will consider when faced with getting a job is that of a tattoo artist, although he canŠ—Èt draw. Just when your patience runs out, and Malony seems unsalvageable, he crumples into a tearful heap and whines for his mother. ItŠ—Ès a good sign that he can cry.
In the words of Ms. DeneuveŠ—Ès judge, Š—“We lay down the tracks, but we canŠ—Èt drive the train for them.Š—
Despite its upbeat perspective, Š—“Standing TallŠ— offers no pat therapeutic solutions to MalonyŠ—Ès or anyone elseŠ—Ès problems.

In Š—“Boys Town,Š— Mickey Rooney played Whitey Marsh, an incorrigible delinquent in a progressive rehabilitation community founded by the Rev. Edward J. Flanagan (Mr. Tracy). Š—“Standing Tall,Š— directed by Emmanuelle Bercot from a screenplay she wrote with Marcia Romano, brings us a latter-day Gallic version of Whitey in the person of Malony (Rod Paradot), a hyperkinetic troublemaker who canŠ—Èt help himself. Mr. ParadotŠ—Ès electrifying performance won him a C’©sar Award, the French Oscar, for most promising actor.

The character is not an unredeemable sociopath but an angry, flailing youth with no impulse control. In his more subdued moments, he knows his behavior is unacceptable, but his fear and reflexive defiance overcome reason. In despairing moments, he sits alone, his head in his hands, his baseball cap pulled down over his face.

Š—“Standing TallŠ— portrays the French system as much more tolerant, humane and costly than its American counterpart. (The figure quoted in the film is 800 euros a day for MalonyŠ—Ès rehabilitation.) The movie follows him from one detention center to another, where unruly adolescents are taught skills by social workers the movie paints as almost saintly surrogate parents.
There isnŠ—Èt any such thing in the world as a bad boy.
Š—“Standing TallŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for strong language and sexual content. In French, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 59 minutes.

Beno’Ât Magimel plays Yann, a caring social worker and onetime youthful offender whose patience is tested by MalonyŠ—Ès explosive refusal to follow any of his directions. Yann eventually loses control and assaults Malony. In a dangling subplot, Malony is romantically pursued by Tess (Diane Rouxel), the enigmatic, brooding daughter of a social worker and a full-scale rebel in her own right. Although their first sexual encounter looks like rape, the movie makes nothing of it, and the love story, such as it is, advances. As intriguing as she is, the character remains frustratingly undeveloped.

That quaint, reassuring sentiment, uttered by Spencer Tracy in the 1938 movie Š—“Boys Town,Š— popped into my mind while watching the gripping but overlong French film Š—“Standing Tall,Š— about tough kids and the juvenile justice system that works with them. Like its American forerunner, the movie advocates tough love for youthful offenders.

The Gaonas Š—” or, to use their stage name, the Flying Gaonas Š—” are trapeze performers who, in their heyday, the 1960s through the 1980s, appeared all over the world and brought a new verve to the art form. In Š—“The Flight Fantastic,Š— a documentary by Tom Moore, they are genial guides to their own history, reaching all the way back to their childhood in Mexico in the 1950s, when a backyard trampoline first got the siblings Armando, Tito, Richie and Chela airborne.

The film, propelled by archival footage and vivid recollections from the Gaonas and their admirers, moves engagingly from the early days to the spotlight years. Tito GaonaŠ—Ès quest to become the first aerialist to execute a quadruple somersault in performance makes an especially compelling segment. And the familyŠ—Ès work in more recent years to pass along the art form is a nice coda. Is the film a bit self-promotional? Sure, but itŠ—Ès enjoyable nonetheless.
By the 1960s, the family act was touring, and the trapeze had joined the trampoline. Tito, who is now in his late 60s, became the magnetic center, a showman in the classic circus tradition.
If someone were to call and ask, Š—“Wanna come over and watch our home movies?,Š— youŠ—Èd probably think, Š—“Ugh.Š— But thatŠ—Ès because you donŠ—Èt know the Gaona family.
Š—“The Dark HorseŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for strong language and drug use. Running time: 2 hours 4 minutes.

In its other strand, Š—“The Dark HorseŠ— has the feel of a standard Hollywood redemption fable in which losers become unlikely winners. Or do they? The movie partly resists the temptation to follow a predictable feel-good route to a fairy-tale ending. That said, it has enough conveniently timed little triumphs to send up warning signs. And it milks for all itŠ—Ès worth the inevitable suspense over whether Gen can control himself given the stress of competition or give in to a manic impulse.

The movieŠ—Ès portrayal of the complex dynamic involving the brothers and Mana conveys a potentially explosive mixture of fear, love and anger. The movie makes painfully clear the degree to which the impoverished Maori people feel disenfranchised. At any point these volatile elements could ignite.

Š—“The Dark HorseŠ— rides on the impassioned performance of Cliff Curtis, the Maori actor who plays Genesis (a.k.a. Gen) Potini, a New Zealand chessmaster with bipolar disorder. With a partially shaved head and many extra pounds, Mr. Curtis is barely recognizable from his roles in Š—“Whale RiderŠ— and Š—“Once Were Warriors.Š— The film, directed and written by James Napier Robertson, is inspired by Jim MarbrookŠ—Ès 2003 documentary, Š—“Dark Horse,Š— which focused on Mr. Potini, a speed-chess player who died in 2011.

That menacing gang, the Outcasts, thrives on violence. The movie leaves you to imagine how they eke out their livelihoods. Membership in this enraged brotherhood entails a brutal initiation, and Ariki, who is terminally ill, is determined that Mana endure the ritual to achieve whatever protection this scary alternative family can offer after he dies.

The movie skillfully weaves together two strands. It is a power struggle between the brothers for the soul of Mana, who is torn between the values of his angry, hypermacho father and his gentle giant of an uncle. Because Gen longs to do something positive, he takes it upon himself to teach the alienated Maori teenagers in a local chess club, the Eastern Knights, to improve their game and compete for the junior national chess championship in Auckland. When Ariki asks Gen to leave the house and gives him some money for lodging, Gen spends it on the team and sleeps outdoors.

Next to other clean-cut, well-mannered contestants, the Eastern Knights are a ragtag bunch of provincial outsiders, and Gen has increasing difficulty keeping his mouth shut. Once the matches begin, his spontaneous interruptions from the sidelines nearly cost the team its place in the competition, and he is ordered to stand outside. His anguish over losing control is heart-rending.

When first seen in the movie, Gen, recently discharged from a psychiatric hospital, barges anxiously through the streets of Gisborne in a driving rain. Clad in a patchwork quilt and talking agitatedly to himself, he stops at an antique shop in which he spies a chess set. Unbidden, he starts a one-person game while talking out loud. Charged with disorderly conduct, Gen is placed under the supervision of his grim older brother Ariki (Wayne Hapi), a tough, embittered member of a motorcycle gang who has a sullen teenage son, Mana (James Rolleston, the title character in Š—“BoyŠ—).

Š—“The Girl in the PhotographsŠ— is an unfortunate example of the expanse that can open between a movieŠ—Ès ambitions and its execution. Notable only for the involvement of the genre pillar Wes Craven (who died last year and is credited as an executive producer), this sad slasher is as lacking in scares as in ideas.

Triteness may be the point, however, in a screenplay (by the director, Nick Simon, and two others) so clogged with clich’©s that their combined whole must surely be intended as greater than their sum. This hope is fortified by an opening quotation from William S. Burroughs that hints at more highfalutin goals than gouting blood, so we expectantly endure the bland company of Colleen (Claudia Lee), a grocery store worker in South Dakota and the recipient of disturbing photographs of bloodily violated women.
Š—“The Girl in the PhotographsŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Sliced throats and twitching booty.

The small-town police (led by a slumming Mitch Pileggi) are uninterested, but an obnoxiously foul-mouthed photographer (Kal Penn) is intrigued, arriving from Los Angeles with a posse of vacuous models and plans to mimic the mystery shots for his portfolio. At the same time, two masked killers Š—” the standard psycho-numbskull pairing Š—” are feeding cat food to their latest captive before closing in on Colleen.

Cheap-looking and poorly acted, Š—“GirlŠ— has a hackneyed sleaziness thatŠ—Ès not limited to the barely clothed pudenda adorning the end credits. What starts out as a promising commentary on the objectifying nature of photography soon sinks into another rote massacre. The filmmakers, like the photographer, seem mobilized by the belief that an overload of banality is itself a kind of novelty. Not this time. JEANNETTE CATSOULIS

Š—“Vita Activa,Š— while it will surely satisfy and provoke students of 20th-century intellectual history, feels more urgent than most documentaries of its kind. Some of Ms. UshpizŠ—Ès methods are a little questionable Š—” I was bothered by the way she slipped artificial, ambient sound into silent footage Š—” but she shows impressive coherence and fair-mindedness in her approach to Arendt, succumbing neither to hagiography nor to facile skepticism. Instead, she subtly draws the viewerŠ—Ès attention from the past to the present, using judiciously chosen passages from ArendtŠ—Ès letters and published work.

Hannah Arendt, who died in 1975, was a prolific and unclassifiable thinker, a political theorist, moral philosopher and polemicist of unmatched range and rigor. At least outside academic circles, her posthumous fame Š—” or notoriety Š—” rests on Š—“Eichmann in Jerusalem,Š— a piece of extended reportage she wrote for The New Yorker in 1963, and on a single phrase associated with it: the banality of evil.
Š—“Vita Activa: The Spirit of Hannah ArendtŠ— is not rated. It in English, Hebrew, German and French, with English subtitles. Running time: runs 2 hours 5 minutes.

The title insists, as Arendt herself always did, that thinking is a form of action. The Š—“spiritŠ— conjured Š—” through ArendtŠ—Ès own words, the recollections of students, disciples and friends, and carefully chosen archival images Š—” is one of relentless and passionate mental activity. Ms. Ushpiz is determined to rescue her subject from the banality of biography. The details of ArendtŠ—Ès childhood, education, romantic life and professional activity are not ignored, but they nearly always illuminate her ideas.

Two insights stand out in painful relief. The first is ArendtŠ—Ès contention that the lethally dehumanizing logic of totalitarianism originated partly in the massive displacement of populations after World War I. The refugees created by that conflict were not only stateless but Š—“rightsless,Š— regarded by the nations of Europe not as citizens in need of protection but as a problem to be solved. A century after that war, Europe is again in the midst of a refugee crisis, the political consequences of which are not yet fully known.

Š—“The Origins of Totalitarianism,Š— her 1951 tour de force, represents her most sustained attempt to understand German fascism and Soviet Communism not as metaphysical catastrophes but as political developments, as aspects of modernity rather than as horrific exceptions to its progress. Recent scholarship has challenged some of her arguments, but the analytic framework of the book remains powerful and disconcertingly topical.

Arendt was born into an assimilated German-Jewish family in 1906. Her early association with the philosopher Martin Heidegger Š—” she was his lover as well as his student Š—” has been another source of controversy, given his subsequent collaboration with the Nazis and their racial policies. Arendt herself fled Germany in 1933, and much of her subsequent writing wrestles with the lethal contradictions of a homeland that seemed by turns to represent the pinnacle of civilization and the depth of barbarism.

Those words are evoked so often, and in so many contexts, that their specific and controversial original meaning is easily forgotten. Arendt, attending the war crimes trial of Adolf Eichmann, a high-ranking Nazi captured in Argentina by Israeli operatives, was struck by his ordinariness, the bland bureaucratic demeanor seemingly at odds with the enormity of his crimes. Though later research has suggested that Arendt misjudged Eichmann Š—” who was, for one thing, a much more ardent anti-Semite than he seemed to be, sitting in the dock Š—” the idea that great horror can spring from mundane roots has proved tenacious and perpetually relevant.

Š—“Vita Activa: The Spirit of Hannah Arendt,Š— a vigorous and thoughtful new documentary by Ada Ushpiz, frames its inquiry into ArendtŠ—Ès career with her encounter with Eichmann. But its focus is much wider than the still-potent debate over Š—“Eichmann in Jerusalem,Š— which was widely and fiercely attacked for what critics took to be its trivialization of EichmannŠ—Ès deeds and its lack of sympathy for his victims. Though both ArendtŠ—Ès defenders and detractors are heard from, Ms. UshpizŠ—Ès film situates the Eichmann episode within a broad and rich portrait of an intellectual determined to use the tools of rationality to comprehend historical events that seem to defy all reason.

Arendt was also concerned with the ways certain totalitarian tendencies and attitudes could persist in democratic societies, and Š—“Vita ActivaŠ— includes some especially chilling implications for the current state of American politics. Totalitarianism rested, in ArendtŠ—Ès view, above all on the systematic refusal to engage reality, on the substitution of ideological fantasy and outright fiction for reason and empiricism. To risk understatement, those tendencies have hardly disappeared from modern society, and may even be stronger than they were at the end of ArendtŠ—Ès life.

We have a hunch Š—” abetted by the menacing throb of the music and the sneaky, splintered editing of the scenes Š—” that the fates of these characters and the others in Jerzy SkolimowskiŠ—Ès Š—“11 MinutesŠ— will converge and that the convergence will be catastrophic. An illusion of simultaneity is produced by repeating certain moments from different perspectives and by punctuating the action with recurring sights and sounds.

We never really know, but at the same time we know plenty. Every situation is presented with maximum lucidity and almost complete inscrutability. The noise and virtuosity of the ending, while effectively concluding the action and raising the intensity to heart-attack levels, also sends the viewerŠ—Ès thoughts spiraling backward.

We can tell the time by glancing at a clock or noting, once again, that low-flying jet, that errant pigeon crashing through a window, that curious object in the sky. You could call Mr. Skolimowski, who is 77, an old dog, and while the multistranded, chronologically intricate narrative conceit of Š—“11 MinutesŠ— isnŠ—Èt exactly a new trick, itŠ—Ès one he pulls off with devilish panache and startling impact. Have we missed important clues about the story, or hints about its themes? Or have we been subjected to a brilliant formal prank, an elaborate demonstration of a directorŠ—Ès mastery of pacing, mood and manipulation. Either way, itŠ—Ès remarkable how much can happen in such a short span of time.

His best-known feature, at least in America, is probably still Š—“Moonlighting,Š— a haunting psychological drama from 1982 starring Jeremy Irons as a Polish carpenter working in London during the Solidarity uprising. Reviewing that film in The New York Times, Vincent Canby noted its stylistic divergence from Mr. SkolimowskiŠ—Ès earlier New Wave-inflected work, and its acute exploration of exile and political alienation.

What happens between 5 and 5:11 p.m. on a breezy Warsaw day to warrant 83 minutes of your attention? Everything and nothing. A young woman walks a dog. A hot dog vendor chats with a group of nuns. A sleazy filmmaker conducts an audition. A couple watch pornography on a laptop. A motorcycle courier speeds away from an adulterous liaison toward an appointment in a downtown high-rise. A young man rides a bus. An ambulance crew comes to the assistance of a woman in labor. An old man paints a landscape.

Even the most apparently innocuous interactions among the characters seem freighted with hidden motives and painful back stories. Why does a someone suddenly spit in the hot dog vendorŠ—Ès face? What is the source of the scars on the dog-walkerŠ—Ès wrist? How did the husband (Wojciech Mecwaldowski) of the auditioning actress (Paulina Chapko) come into possession of what looks like a very fresh black eye? And what is up with that creepy director? Not Mr. Skolimowski, but the wolfish American smoothie (played with an odd Hollywood accent by the Irish actor Richard Dormer) who might be his alter ego, the projection of his guilty conscience or some unholy combination of the two.

That clunky observation is meant to clue us in to this self-regarding movieŠ—Ès literary pretensions, gleaned perhaps from some misbegotten writersŠ—È workshop. Sure enough, there are metaphors aplenty, and they are wielded with the heaviness of the sledgehammer Davis uses, first at a construction site and later at his picture-perfect suburban home, to demolish the remains of his former life.

Having achieved liberation, Davis skips down the streets of Manhattan in a state of manic euphoria that the movie portrays as freedom. And yes, he can finally get in touch with his feelings, become human and shed a tear.

Not long after JuliaŠ—Ès death, Davis reflects out loud that since his wife has been gone, everything he has encountered has been a metaphor for something else. Ah, metaphor! WeŠ—Ère getting serious here.

Mr. GyllenhaalŠ—Ès strong performance still doesnŠ—Èt add enough substance to a film that is hollow at the center. ItŠ—Ès mostly the fault of Mr. Sipe, who seems to believe that saying nothing is saying something.

When they eventually meet, he discovers she is living with a possessive lout (C. J. Wilson) and has a 12-year-old son, Chris (Judah Lewis), who loves hard rock music and is uncertain about his sexuality.

Mr. Lewis is a promising young actor, but no sooner has the screenplay brought up his sexual confusion than it nervously drops the subject, the better to concentrate on its money shots, in which Davis gleefully destroys his glass house and everything in it and finally has a bulldozer knock down the facade. You canŠ—Èt help shuddering as you calculate the property damage.

The actors do their best to flesh out characters who might as well be stick figures conceived on a drawing board with arrows pointing this way and that. You expect Davis and Karen to begin some kind of romance, and when they remain chaste friends, you can practically hear the movie congratulating itself for defying expectations and taking what some might call the high road.

In Š—“Demolition,Š— Jake Gyllenhaal diligently applies himself to playing a painfully familiar type in American movies that imagine having Something to Say: the Man Who Cannot Feel. His character, Davis Mitchell, is a Wall Street investment banker whose comfortably numb existence is jolted at the start of the film when his wife, Julia, dies in a car crash that leaves him physically and emotionally unscathed. In the weeks after the tragedy, Davis returns to work and acts as though nothing has happened but behaves erratically. His inability to display any grief infuriates his father-in-law, Phil (Chris Cooper), who is also his boss.

Another metaphor is the broken vending machine in the hospital where Julia dies. When it wonŠ—Èt disgorge the peanut M&MŠ—Ès he paid for, Davis begins writing letters of complaint to the manufacturer. In the letters, he confesses his lifelong unhappiness and marital disappointment. Eventually, he receives a reply from Karen (Naomi Watts), a customer service representative who is moved by the honesty of his confessional ravings, and he begins stalking her.
Š—“High StrungŠ— is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). If everyone in Manhattan were this wholesome, it would be called Salt Lake City.

As predictable as the candles-and-roses-strewn loft where the coupleŠ—Ès matching pouts first collide, Š—“High StrungŠ— prefers penciled-in stereotypes Š—” the queen bee; the risk-taking roommate Š—” to real characters. ThereŠ—Ès really only one reason to see Š—“High StrungŠ— Š—” Michael DamianŠ—Ès wishy-washy nod to Š—“FameŠ— (1980) Š—” and thatŠ—Ès the ebullient choreography of Dave Scott, whose accelerated and witty hip-hop routines have long been highlights of movies and reality television shows.

Š—“Louder Than BombsŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Strong language and naughty behavior, but all in good taste. Running time: 1 hour 49 minutes.

They do most of their suffering in a leafy Hudson River town near New York City. Gene (Gabriel Byrne), a schoolteacher and former actor, drives his Volvo to work and tries to communicate with his teenage son, Conrad (Devin Druid). ItŠ—Ès been a few years since the boyŠ—Ès mother, Isabelle (Isabelle Huppert), a well-known war photographer, died in a car crash, and he has withdrawn into video games and the kind of sullenness that is either perfectly normal or wildly alarming in a male adolescent.

It is possible to admire the craft and sensitivity of Š—“Louder Than BombsŠ— without quite believing it. The characters are so carefully drawn that they can feel smaller than life, and the dramatic space they inhabit has a curiously abstract feeling. The kind of fine-grained realism that Mr. Trier is attempting Š—” and that he succeeded in creating in his earlier features Š—” depends on a density of implication. You need to be able to imagine the life of any given character extending beyond the frame, and to perceive the contours of social and domestic life in which the ensemble is embedded.

Or maybe she would. Mr. Trier, who wrote the screenplay with Eskil Vogt, mines the narrative with small surprises and reversals. He allows expectations to build and then gently corrects the assumptions on which they rest. Grief is difficult, people are complicated, and family intimacy can be clouded by secrets and unstated resentments. Jonah and Gene know that IsabelleŠ—Ès death was a suicide, and they worry about what would happen if Conrad found out.

ConradŠ—Ès older brother, Jonah (Jesse Eisenberg), a newly fledged sociology professor with a newborn daughter, arrives to help his father sort out material for a retrospective of IsabelleŠ—Ès work. The three men, joined by Isabelle in flashbacks that are folded without warning into a mostly linear narrative, do their best to manage their grief and stay out of one anotherŠ—Ès way. Gene is consoled by his secret relationship with Hannah (Amy Ryan), a younger colleague, who is ConradŠ—Ès English teacher. Jonah pretends heŠ—Ès not freaked out by fatherhood. Conrad develops a crush on a cheerleader named Melanie (Ruby Jerins), the kind of girl who would never look twice at a diffident, nerdy kid like him.

That intangible sense of continuity, of weight, is missing here, so that you are always aware of the faintly humming machinery of the script, and of the willed subtlety of the performances. Mr. Byrne and Mr. Eisenberg are impeccable, but they seem more hemmed in than liberated by their craft, which is to say that Gene and Jonah are beautifully rendered ciphers.

Isabelle, meanwhile, is an intriguing ghost, animated by Ms. Huppert with her usual fierce precision. It is Mr. Druid, though, who temporarily rescues the film from its own carefulness, piercing its bubble of high-minded complacency with his slow-burning anger and deadpan humor. A late sequence involving an encounter with Melanie and a high school drinking party is the one part of the film that breathes with a sense of freedom and spontaneity. You are aware of ConradŠ—Ès curiosity, and you also share it. He is a cautious rebel, in revolt partly against the narrow fatalism of the film he inhabits.

Š—“Louder Than Bombs,Š— the first English-language film by the Norwegian director Joachim Trier (Š—“Reprise,Š— Š—“Oslo, August 31stŠ— ), is disarmingly quiet, not unlike the Smiths album that shares its title. Š—“Neon BullŠ— is a profound reflection on the intersection of the human and bestial. For all his ease in the barnyard, Iremar longs for something more. Class conscious and upwardly mobile, he describes Galega as a redneck. ItŠ—Ès not clear if they have a sexual connection, but probably they once did. Iremar is not alone in his hierarchical social view. At a horse-trading fair, the finest mare is named Lady Di, and her stallions are handpicked. In a jaw-droppingly graphic sequence, Iremar and Z’© use the scent of a mare to arouse a prize stallion so they can steal his valuable sperm.

In some ways, Š—“Neon Bull,Š— the astonishing second feature by the Brazilian documentarian director Gabriel Mascaro, is a movie about animal smells. An intoxicating reflection on the interconnection of taste, scent, instinct and desire, the film, gorgeously photographed by Diego Garcia (Š—“Cemetery of SplendourŠ—), immerses you in the intensely pungent world of vaquejada, a rodeo sport popular in northeastern Brazil. Two cowboys on horseback flanking a bull seek to tug it to the ground by the tail.

Iremar lives in a truck that transports the livestock from show to show. He shares quarters with a makeshift family that includes Galega (Maeve Jinkings), an exotic dancer and truck driver with blond frizzy hair who dons a horse head with a brushed powdered tail for her sexy routines.

Because so few of us grow up close to stables and barnyards, the primal kinship between people and animals is easily taken for granted. But lest we forget, human beings, probably more than many would like to admit, are beasts. The connection between human and animal is intimate enough that we instinctively project our values and aspirations onto animals almost as though they were our children. At the same time, in our vanity, we need to distinguish ourselves from creatures on which we depend for food, livelihood and companionship. God forbid that we should smell like them.

Š—“Neon BullŠ— doesnŠ—Èt tell a story so much as portray a way of life in which people and livestock coexist as an extended family. While much of IremarŠ—Ès day is spent grooming animals and shoveling manure, he uses his spare time to design GalegaŠ—Ès costumes, using skin magazine photos as inspiration and fitting the outfits on mannequins he cuts with a small handsaw and pieces together.

IremarŠ—Ès aspirations are distilled in his fondness for cologne, which disguises any lingering odor from his regular work. Like the scent used to arouse the stallion, it is an erotic lure, but not one secreted by the human body. ThatŠ—Ès the crucial difference.
In a final image, the camera pans a carcass being roasted on a giant spit and you are reminded that not only in the world of Š—“Neon Bull,Š— but everywhere, you are what you eat.

Iremar might be described as a centaur. In one of several ecstatic moments, he lies on the grass beside a horse, which he strokes and adores almost like a lover. In another, he talks and moos to a pen filled with cattle.

Throughout the film, the line between human and animal behavior is blurred. In one scene, the cowhands argue about whether donkey milk is fit to drink. In another, Cac’ and a cowboy frolic in a box of animal feed, which he insists is fit for consumption. SheŠ—Ès not so sure.

The filmŠ—Ès characters live amid mud and dung, side by side with the animals they love. They also bathe like animals. The wooden stall in which Iremar (Juliano Cazarr’©), a handsome cowboy, and his fellow rodeo workers slosh themselves with buckets of water is the farthest thing from an elegant bathroom. They are utterly unselfconscious about being naked in close quarters.
Š—“Neon BullŠ— is not rated. In Portuguese, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 41 minutes.

GalegaŠ—Ès husband is away for reasons that are never explained. But she has a mouthy, inquisitive daughter, Cac’ (Aline Santana) on the verge of puberty. IremarŠ—Ès co-worker in the bullpen, Z’© (Carlos Pessoa), is a potbellied roughneck with a fondness for pornography.

Sex is always in the air. But without much fuss, Š—“Neon BullŠ— exalts carnal passion in beautiful, almost sculptural love scenes filmed from a middle distance. One is set outdoors at night in the presence of livestock. The other, in a textile factory, involves Iremar and a pregnant woman.

Mr. PerlmuttŠ—Ès film also recognizes the countryŠ—Ès economic difficulties through JoteŠ—Ès job struggles. The movie, set and shot in Moscow, is heavy on spectacular stunt work and relentless in callous violence. Did somebody say the Manson Family? I seem to remember that someone does. Mildred, now in her 90s, agreed to be filmed in interviews and during joint counseling sessions with Gayle. In addition, home movies are excerpted, as are GayleŠ—Ès journals. Š—“Mr. Right,Š— directed by Paco Cabezas, was written by Max Landis, who also wrote Š—“American Ultra,Š— which mined somewhat similar territory. Anna KendrickŠ—Ès star shows no sign of dimming. ANDY WEBSTER

When Martha (Ms. Kendrick), a neurotic given to garrulous patter and lightning mood swings, is betrayed by her boyfriend, she goes on a bender of Olympian self-pity and excess, to the exasperation of her roommate, Sophie (Katie Nehra).

The movie is funny without being much good; mostly, itŠ—Ès another rung on Ms. McCarthyŠ—Ès big ladder up. But, as it turns out, sometimes itŠ—Ès pleasurable enough just watching the most unlikely American comedy star since Bill Murray slip into a groove.
