This insistence on ordinary women with ordinary bodies doing ordinary (sometimes extraordinary) things, some of them very funny, cuts to the appeal of a goof like Š—“The Boss,Š— which, even at its most familiar, feels different because of whoŠ—Ès inspiring the laughter and jostling those breasts. Given this, itŠ—Ès worth remembering that slipped among the jokes is a story about two women who struggle with separate existential and economic realities and thrive in mutual dependency. In its arc, the story recalls the 1933 Fannie Hurst novel Š—“Imitation of LifeŠ— (and its filmed adaptations), about a white woman who makes a fortune off her black female employeeŠ—Ès recipes and likeness. Š—“The BossŠ— dodges race and puts a smiley face on greed, but itŠ—Ès hard not to think that in celebrating female self-reliance, Ms. McCarthy Š—” star, writer, producer Š—” is saying a little something about women in the entertainment industry.

In her new laugh-in, Š—“The Boss,Š— Melissa McCarthy plays Michelle Darnell, an investment guru with a motivational racket along the inspirational lines of Tony Robbins and Suze Orman. Wildly successful, Michelle fills stadiums with true believers who drink her snake oil by the tanker, cheering as she preaches the gospel of personal riches and the power of you you you, even if itŠ—Ès really all about her her her. SheŠ—Ès peddling empowerment of a kind, as is this movie, gleefully silly froth that Ms. McCarthy sells with slapstick, you-go-girl uplift and a Kewpie doll smile thatŠ—Ès one twitch short of pure madness.

Michelle works best when she goes full-bore entrepreneurial hellion and hatches a scheme to sell ClaireŠ—Ès brownies on a mass scale, an enterprise that leads her to recruit members of a girl-scout-like troop and engage in corporate warfare with an amorous foe (Peter Dinklage). Along the way, Ms. McCarthy runs amusingly, at times dementedly, away with the movie, as when Michelle, while offering lingerie advice, plays with ClaireŠ—Ès (clothed) breasts. In its intimate physicality, this bit suggests a delightfully weird riff on a slap-happy Three Stooges exchange. Except that instead of smacking each otherŠ—Ès faces, Michelle and Claire are reveling in the comedy of the female breast, a routine that metaphorically whips the lacy, push-up bra off what is, of course, an ordinary body part.
Š—“The BossŠ— is rated R (under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for vulgarities and one purse-size gun. Running time: 1 hour 39 minutes.

Before it settles into a self-actualization fairy tale, Š—“TammyŠ— touches on economic struggles that both connect it to the real world and suggest that Ms. McCarthy has ambitions beyond the well-executed pratfall. On its glossy surface, Š—“The BossŠ— looks safer than Š—“Tammy,Š— partly because Michelle registers as a more familiar, sellable caricature: the 1 percent meanie who needs a Tiny Tim to administer some emotional CPR. Michelle is plenty self-fulfilled when the story opens, at least professionally, as telegraphed by her bombast and an office stuffed with her framed portrait. She has issues, but money is just the gold thatŠ—Ès plating her wounded self (or something).

It may be a while before Ms. McCarthy gets her Š—“Groundhog Day,Š— though I like to think that the director Paul Feig (Š—“SpyŠ—) might one day deliver on that dream. Until then, she will continue to split sides and make bank, including in disposable, enjoyable nonsense like Š—“The Boss.Š— ItŠ—Ès the second movie that sheŠ—Ès starred in directed by her husband, Ben Falcone, following the 2014 Š—“Tammy,Š— about a sad sack who, after losing her job, sets off on a two-track inner and outer journey. That did well enough at the box office Š—” Ms. McCarthy has become a Teflon laugh factory Š—” despite being unworthy of her talents and despite the uneasy, unfunny jokes about Tammy, burgers and doughnuts.

Money certainly isnŠ—Èt a problem until she loses her fortune after being busted for insider trading. Written by Ms. McCarthy, Mr. Falcone and Steve Mallory, the movie tracks Michelle as she goes from penthouse to prison, followed by a life-changing stay with her wary former assistant, Claire (Kristen Bell, an appealing second banana), a single mom with a kid (Ella Anderson). There, in their cramped apartment, mother and daughter coax out MichelleŠ—Ès inner softy, who, unsurprisingly, is nowhere near as fun as her outer meanie. Mae West once cracked, Š—“DonŠ—Èt marry a man to reform him Š—” thatŠ—Ès what reform schools are for.Š— The same tends to be true about writing characters.

Not so, however, in the West Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan. There, a hypergentrification Š—” fueled by the High Line parkŠ—Ès spectacular revitalization of this formerly industrial area, as well as by wealthy real estate investors seeking new Manhattan addresses Š—” has resulted in a jarring compression of new construction of office space, museums and luxury apartments. The cityscape is being remade not in decades but years, even months.
Š—“Class DivideŠ— is not rated.

Marc LevinŠ—Ès ambitious and engrossing Š—“Class DivideŠ— looks at this phenomenon chiefly through the lens of a single intersection, at 10th Avenue and 26th Street. On the east side are the Chelsea-Elliot Houses Š—” public housing for about 2,500 people, mostly families of the working poor. On the west, and stretching back to the High Line, is Avenues, which opened in 2012, a onetime slaughterhouse converted into an elite pre-K-12 private school, with annual tuition running at $40,000-plus.

So, itŠ—Ès complicated. But to Mr. LevinŠ—Ès young interviewees, issues are a lot simpler. Youths from both sides of the street speak sensitively about inequality. Hyisheem, who has made it out of Elliot to study social work in college, says that the divideŠ—Ès engine is Š—“not racism, itŠ—Ès classism.Š— Yasemin, an Avenues student, and Elliot teenagers talk about having to navigate a world defined by income. (When some public-housing peers visit the school, they are blown away by what they see. Š—“It hurts a little,Š— one says, Š—“to go back and face reality.Š—)

Mr. Levin previously examined globalismŠ—Ès fallout for working people in Š—“Schmatta: Rags to Riches to RagsŠ— and Š—“Hard Times: Lost on Long Island.Š— In Š—“Class Divide,Š— he is on his home turf, having lived in Chelsea since the 1980s. There are no villains here, and everyone gets a say. Joshua David, a founder of Friends of the High Line, and Ricardo Scofidio, the parkŠ—Ès designer, are justly proud of what they have wrought; a developer who recognizes the impact of his buildings sponsors college scholarships for low-income students; a real estate agent who shows apartments in the $3 million to $15 million range smilingly notes that in any hot market, some residents must move because of rising costs: Š—“ThatŠ—Ès what happens.Š—

The film misses a chance to explore ways to ease these collisions. Still, what Š—“Class DivideŠ— does exceptionally well is capture the sense of change at warp speed. In their bones, the public-housing kids know that itŠ—Ès only a matter of time before theyŠ—Ère forced to leave. ThereŠ—Ès simply too much hunger for development to withstand. And if that happens, it will come as quickly as the other shifts the neighborhood has endured: in a New York minute.
Gentrification is not usually the stuff of vivid, gripping documentaries. The impacts typically arrive too slowly, the changes too incremental to register on the lives they eventually affect.

This first feature from Victor Zarcoff, who wrote as well as directed, leans heavily on the stalker trope for its chills, but does so effectively, thanks to the performance of Neville Archambault, who sweats and heavy-breathes his way through the role of the landlord who rents a house to Claire and Ryan. He has wired the place with security cameras, which he uses to peer in on the young coupleŠ—Ès comings and goings, couplings and showerings, and more.

Yes, itŠ—Ès an exploitative sort of filmmaking, but Mr. Zarcoff keeps it fairly restrained for most of the way. You know things will end badly for someone, and perhaps everyone. The ominousness just keeps building.

Note to renters: If, at your initial meeting, your potential landlord gives you the creeps, itŠ—Ès probably best to keep looking. That basic rule, alas, is not followed by Claire (Brianne Moncrief) and Ryan (P. J. McCabe) in the goosebump-inducing Š—“13 Cameras.Š—

Mr. Zarcoff leaves this fellowŠ—Ès motives deliciously unclear. Is he merely a voyeur? Does he intend the couple harm? Does he view himself as some kind of protector, especially of Claire, who is pregnant? Complicating things is that Ryan is not exactly a model expectant father Š—” an attractive co-worker named Hannah (Sarah Baldwin) has caught his wandering eye. And Hannah turns out to be a bit more than he bargained for.

The destitute settings of this Swiss filmmakerŠ—Ès study recall the work of two other foreign chroniclers, Gianfranco Rosi (Š—“Below Sea LevelŠ—) and Roberto Minervini (Š—“The Other SideŠ—), as well as Marc SingerŠ—Ès subterranean New York doc, Š—“Dark Days.Š— Mr. Steiner, too, is consciously photographing locales in the United States that are usually kept offscreen.

Rick and Cindy, for example, are a couple who carve out shelter and fight addiction in the flood channels under Las Vegas. Dave is a loner who fled to the California badlands after failed marriages. A war veteran named April provides a foil to these struggles. SheŠ—Ès enlisted with the Mars Society, a nonprofit group apparently doing dry runs for a Mars expedition, using a desolate Utah dune landscape. AprilŠ—Ès story yields potent visual echoes of terrain seen elsewhere in the film, but her more stable circumstances sometimes make for an incongruous fit with the homelessness of the other subjects. Likewise, the filmŠ—Ès pulsing score sometimes imposes a convenient but unnecessary surge of emotion.

The outer limits and the lower depths loom before us in Nicolas SteinerŠ—Ès voyage into extremes, Š—“Above and Below.Š— Mr. SteinerŠ—Ès tightly interconnected documentary, with transporting shots, visits people on the margins in the United States, primarily transients in Las Vegas and the California desert, but also a participant in an earnest Mars research project.

The montage of Mr. SteinerŠ—Ès movie actively looks for links among his subjects: fierce self-sufficiency, absent but not forgotten family, and unachieved dreams. But the most stirring moments can be the stillest ones, in the strangely cozy darkness of Rick and CindyŠ—Ès makeshift settlement, or near DaveŠ—Ès sunset-friendly home, where the sublime natural surroundings evoke both escape and exile.
Good question.

If the movie were a satire, which it should be, the vanity and snobbery of Luc and his circle of friends, many of them in their 30s, wouldnŠ—Èt be so suffocating. These people who appraise everything in sight with the icy scrutiny of art-world sharks, might as well be humanoids for all the warmth they exude. They also love to complain. How unfortunate it is, one laments, that ancient sites like Machu Picchu and Angkor Wat are being overrun with tourists. The name Ikea is spoken with such contempt that it sounds like a curse. At least we donŠ—Èt hear the Š—“pŠ— word (that would be Š—“peasantsŠ—) applied to those less fortunate, which is almost everybody with less refined taste.

The filmŠ—Ès temperature rises to slightly above freezing in its second half when St’©phanieŠ—Ès angst leads to full-scale panic attacks that result in her hospitalization. Luc, while visiting Toronto to accept an award, succumbs to the charms of Lindsay (Melanie Merkosky), a predatory, about-to-be-divorced beauty who bluntly propositions him within minutes of their meeting. Showing up in Quebec weeks later, she tells him she loves him, although there are no signs of an emotional bond beyond games of footsie leading to cool, picture-perfect sex in which not a hair is ruffled or genuine passion exhibited.

The first sign of a crack in the facade of this cold, perfect world is the discomfort of LucŠ—Ès beautiful wife, St’©phanie (M’©lanie Thierry), while watching a television documentary showing the fall of Muammar el-Qaddafi. It disturbs the serenity of the coupleŠ—Ès modern aerie outside Quebec City and prompts her to wonder nervously, Š—“Are we real?Š—

Because that smug, straight-faced remark by Luc (’_ric Bruneau), a handsome, successful architect to a group of supercilious friends in Š—“An Eye for BeautyŠ— is not entirely facetious, you may never forgive him for it. Nor should you.
A low point in the directorŠ—Ès career, this sleek chilly film isnŠ—Èt acted so much as posed.
Š—“Ugliness is a crime against humanity.Š—

Written and directed by the Canadian filmmaker Denys Arcand (Š—“The Barbarian Invasions,Š— which won a 2004 Academy Award for best foreign picture), Š—“An Eye for BeautyŠ— is the cinematic equivalent of a photo spread in Vogue or Architectural Digest that taunts you with images of rich, well-to-do beautiful people leading the tastefully glamorous life.

The message that Š—“An Eye for BeautyŠ— wants to send is that gorgeous people suffer just like the rest of us. But it is so enamored of them that the message gets lost en route to the screen. What really matters is the lighting.
Š—“An Eye for BeautyŠ— is not rated, is in English and French with English subtitles, and runs 1 hour 42 minutes.
Š—“Barbershop: The Next CutŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Some rough language, but thatŠ—Ès what democracy sounds like. Running time: 1 hour 51 minutes.

Yet the film, as if obeying both the imperatives of Hollywood comedy and the long tradition of black activism, refuses to succumb to pessimism. Instead of a political position, it offers a potent metaphor for political participation. At the end, Calvin expresses his faith that, Š—“eventually,Š— Chicago will pull itself together. That might sound like nothing more than wishful thinking Š—” a thin reed of formulaic faith Š—” if the movie had not already supplied solid grounds for hope in the shape of the barbershop itself. ItŠ—Ès a room full of men and women who agree on almost nothing, except their commitment to the place that gives structure and purpose to their lives. Everyone is welcome, and everyone is challenged and improved. In other words, itŠ—Ès what democracy looks like.

The last feature in the series, Š—“Beauty Shop,Š— was released in 2005. More than a decade later, Calvin Palmer (Ice Cube) is still running his fatherŠ—Ès old haircutting establishment on ChicagoŠ—Ès South Side. To quote an old Mos Def song: A lot of things have changed; a lot of things have not. The shop, for one thing, is now fully unisex, which causes some grumbling from Eddie (Cedric the Entertainer) and allows for a fuller range of argument and intrigue. Chicago has provided the United States with its first black president, and has also found itself swamped in guns and gang violence. Calvin and his wife, Jennifer (Jazsmin Lewis), worry about their teenage son, Jalen (whose birth was part of the wild climax of Š—“BarbershopŠ— and who has grown up into Michael Rainey Jr.).

Directed by Malcolm D. Lee (Š—“The Best Man,Š— Š—“The Best Man HolidayŠ—) from a script by Kenya Barris and Tracy Oliver, Š—“Barbershop: The Next CutŠ— stands as a companion Š—” and, at times, a pointed challenge Š—” to Spike LeeŠ—Ès Š—“Chi-Raq.Š— Both films confront the epidemic of homicide in Chicago, and use that tragedy as a prism to examine a host of other topics, including sexual and electoral politics. Of the two Lees, Malcolm is the less polemical and also the more conventional filmmaker. He passes out soapboxes among the characters, but keeps his feet and his camera firmly planted on the ground. CalvinŠ—Ès barbershop functions as a semi-theatrical set, and also as a town square, a meeting place where every point of view can find a hearing, or at least a chance to be shouted down.

And, above all, to think about whatŠ—Ès being said. Debate topics include President ObamaŠ—Ès legacy, sexism, child-rearing techniques, the different experiences of immigrants and African-Americans, among many others. There are also deeper, more complicated issues in play, contradictions that emerge through the story of CalvinŠ—Ès struggle to understand and protect his son. Like all the other Š—“BarbershopŠ— movies, this one rests on a bedrock of conservative values: ItŠ—Ès a celebration of small business, hard work, family ties and communal solidarity. But it also resists the easy comforts of respectability politics and bootstrap ideology.

But most of this narrative business exists to provide diversion from Š—” and occasions for Š—” a series of wide-ranging, open-ended arguments. These are often very funny, studded with sharp put-downs and EddieŠ—Ès woolly non sequiturs. This installment follows its predecessors in declaring the barbershop a piety-free zone. Anything and anyone can be made into a punch line: Bill Cosby, R. Kelly, Michelle ObamaŠ—Ès hips, Black Lives Matter. ItŠ—Ès pretty much guaranteed that you will take offense at some point, but also that you will be able to laugh off your discomfort and move on.

The most fascinating Š—” and the most moving Š—” thing about this sprawling, sincere and boisterous movie is its tone. I donŠ—Èt just mean that it is able to acknowledge real personal and social anguish amid all the joking and banter. In that regard, Mr. Lee shares with Spike Lee an ability to blend the rough with the smooth, to tickle and provoke in a single gesture. In this case, the collision of humor and horror makes a humanist point. Even when terrible things are happening, people will still find time for petty complaints and ordinary pleasures. Nothing can stop us from teasing, flirting or worrying about how we look.

Movie sequels donŠ—Èt need Š—” and frequently donŠ—Èt have Š—” a good reason to exist, other than to take more money from fans. Š—“Barbershop: The Next Cut,Š— which revives a popular comedy franchise, has plenty of commercial appeal, not least as a kind of hip-hop all-star acting revue, with Common, Tyga and Nicki Minaj joining Ice Cube and Eve, who anchored the original Š—“Barbershop.Š— That movie was a hit in 2002, and it spawned two earlier sequels and a cable TV series. This comeback feels like the opposite of cynical, though. If anything, it seems unusually urgent. WeŠ—Ère back at the barbershop because thereŠ—Ès an awful lot to talk about.

Š—“Barbershop: The Next CutŠ— is crowded with subplots and characters. Some seem to be there for purely comic purposes, like One-Stop (J. B. Smoove), an all-purpose, motor-mouthed entrepreneur, and Jerrod (Lamorne Morris), the requisite workplace goofball. Love trouble erupts when Draya (Ms. Minaj) starts flirting in earnest with Rashad (Common), who is married to Terri (Eve). J. D. (Anthony Anderson) is promoting his for-profit catering business as a nonprofit community service project.

Viewed from one angle, Š—“Barbershop: The Next CutŠ— can seem like a terribly sad film, an expression of fatigue that verges on despair. How can it be that young black men are still dying in such numbers, and that so many neighborhoods are in the grip of fear and alienation? There are plenty of theories, but no good answer.
Š—“CriminalŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for violence and strong language.

Hollywood loves to muck with the human brain, and in Š—“CriminalŠ— the beneficiary is Kevin Costner, who gets to deploy a full range of tics and quirks, playing a convict neurally altered in the name of national security.

Ariel Vromen has directed a decent, fast-paced action movie, and Mr. Costner is enjoyable to watch as Jerico Stewart, a career criminal reminiscent of Hannibal Lecter: HeŠ—Ès so dangerous and volatile that merely locking him up isnŠ—Èt sufficient; he also has to be chained into near immobility. An injury in childhood left him with frontal lobe syndrome Š—” Š—“He feels nothing: no hatred, no love,Š— weŠ—Ère told.

Having an experimental neurosurgery underpinning your plot gives you license to be inconsistent Š—” Jerico, who has spent much of his life locked up, seems to grasp flash drives but canŠ—Èt defeat a childproof cap, because apparently only some of BillŠ—Ès memories and skills transferred. But itŠ—Ès best not to think about this preposterous story too hard. Just ride it to its even more preposterous climax, enjoying Mr. Costner and a steady supporting cast (Gary Oldman as the C.I.A. honcho; Gal Gadot as BillŠ—Ès wife) along the way.

That makes him perfectly suited for a radical procedure the C.I.A. orders up when one of its operatives, Bill Pope (Ryan Reynolds), is killed with valuable information lodged in his brain. Tommy Lee Jones plays the surgeon who transplants BillŠ—Ès memories into Jerico. Security, though, isnŠ—Èt what it should be with a patient like Jerico, and he escapes into London, gradually piecing together his own situation as fragments of BillŠ—Ès memories surface. Bill was working on a case involving a master hacker who had penetrated the American militaryŠ—Ès security systems, and Jerico is pursued by both the C.I.A. and the bad guys who want to hack their way to world domination.

Š—“Echo ParkŠ— isnŠ—Èt as ambitious as other expiration-date cinematic love affairs like Š—“Before SunriseŠ— and Š—“Once.Š— ThatŠ—Ès not a knock against it, but an acknowledgment of its more modest goals. As in those movies, the location (here, the Echo Park section of Los Angeles) plays a big part. Curiously, the fact that Alex and Sophie are an interracial couple is barely mentioned. To be sure, though, skin color isnŠ—Èt the focal point. Instead, this quietly poignant film is exploring whatŠ—Ès below the surface.

Ms. Gummer and Mr. Okungbowa know how to supply those expressions, communicating disappointments and hopes with their eyes and gestures. ItŠ—Ès no surprise to learn that the director, Amanda Marsalis, has a background in photography. Here, in her feature debut, sheŠ—Ès skilled in conjuring moods by using soft images of her actors and their surroundings. The melancholy soundtrack also helps.

Their early romance is easygoing, and even the sight of them kicking around a soccer ball can prompt a smile. Catalina Aguilar MastrettaŠ—Ès script is free of speechifying and delivers just enough story line to keep a plot in motion; words are rarely used when expressions can better convey feelings.

Š—“IŠ—Èm leaving in a few weeksŠ—È time, so itŠ—Ès a kind of a no-risk situation,Š— Alex (Tony Okungbowa) says when asking out Sophie (Mamie Gummer). Sophie replies, Š—“I donŠ—Èt think thereŠ—Ès such a thing.Š— SheŠ—Ès right, at least in this case, and the more involved these two become, the more bittersweet Š—“Echo ParkŠ— grows.

An understated and often charming film, Š—“Echo ParkŠ— begins as Sophie is coming off a long-term relationship. She soon meets Alex, who has seen his American dream fade and has decided to sell his house and return to his native England.
Š—“Green RoomŠ— is rated R (under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Š—“Punk ainŠ—Èt no religious cult. Punk means thinking for yourself.Š— Running time:  1 hour 35 minutes.

Once it becomes clear that the band canŠ—Èt talk its way out of trouble, its members decide to fight back, with their bassist, Pat (Mr. Yelchin), and their guitarist, Sam (Ms. Shawkat), taking the lead, and a couple of less-than-fully-loyal skinheads (Mark Webber and Imogen Poots) playing backup. Once the violence starts, Š—“Green RoomŠ— settles into horror movie logic, becoming steadily more gruesome and less terrifying as the body count grows. You know some people are going to die, and figuring out who and in what order feels more like a brainteaser than like a matter of deep moral or emotional concern.

Things will only get worse. There will be guns, machetes, dogs trained to gobble human flesh, and a forest full of scary homegrown fascists. But before all of that Š—” before Š—“Green Room,Š— written and directed by Jeremy Saulnier, puts its genre cards on the table and turns into a tense and nasty siege movie Š—” the plight of the AinŠ—Èt Rights has a scruffy comic flavor. We could be watching a web series or a spindly indie about four young people (played by Alia Shawkat, Anton Yelchin, Callum Turner and Joe Cole) at loose ends who meet up with a series of rough but also kind of interesting characters.

Which is cool and everything. Mr. Saulnier certainly could have done more, but he succeeds perfectly well within the limited terms he has set for himself. When the situation looks especially desperate, Pat offers a lesson drawn from a long-ago paintball match, the point of which is that the only way to defeat grimly determined professional warriors is with a defiantly playful, anarchic spirit. ThatŠ—Ès a canonical punk-rock attitude, of course, even if it isnŠ—Èt quite an adequate response to hate-based politics. Darcy likes to tell his young followers that Š—“itŠ—Ès not a party; itŠ—Ès a movement.Š— But thereŠ—Ès no reason to take him seriously.

The AinŠ—Èts are hardly innocent: Their touring vehicle runs on fuel siphoned from parked cars. But there is something touching about their devotion to one another and to the dogmas and rhythms of punk rock. It has been around for much longer than any of them. Though Š—“Green RoomŠ— takes place in the smartphone-enabled present and assembles a cast of talented millennials, it explores a venerable subcultural terrain.

Booked to play a show at a remote roadhouse whose patrons are skinheads Š—” the place is decorated with SS lightning bolts and Confederate flags Š—” our heroes unleash a cover of the Dead KennedysŠ—È anthem insulting Š—“Nazi punks,Š— a chestnut from 1981. Some in the crowd take the bait and toss bottles, extend their middle fingers or walk out. Others accept the insouciance of the gesture and dive into the mosh pit. The AinŠ—Èts themselves may be disgusted with the audience, but not enough to refuse the club ownerŠ—Ès money.

That inspired bit of casting is almost enough to inscribe Š—“Green RoomŠ— alongside Š—“Sexy BeastŠ— in the pantheon of against-type British thespian screen villainy. Darcy, his voice an almost soothing growl, presents himself as a reasonable and practical man. His diplomatic skills are called upon when the AinŠ—Èts witness some bad business backstage and need to be placated until they can be dealt with more permanently. This is when the guns, machetes and killer dogs come into play, and when Mr. Saulnier begins to show off his tactical chops.

In the opening scene of Š—“Green Room,Š— the members of the AinŠ—Èt Rights, a punk band from the East Coast, wake up in a cornfield somewhere in the Pacific Northwest. The driver fell asleep at the wheel, the van is out of gas, and the hassles escalate after that. A promised gig falls through, a podcast interview becomes a little awkward, and the groupŠ—Ès corporate assets, not counting the van and the gear inside it, add up to around $25 and a few takeout containers of rice and beans.

The ideological errors of young music fans arenŠ—Èt really the point of Š—“Green Room.Š— The political resurgence of white supremacy gives the movie a frisson of topicality, but extremism is less a theme than a conceit. Mr. Saulnier, whose previous color-coded exercise in mayhem was Š—“Blue Ruin,Š— needed some detestable bad guys, and he chose well. The skinheads at the show are not just obnoxious racists. Many of them are part of a criminal network heavy into heroin, dog fighting and other bad stuff. The captain of this enterprise is a graybeard named Darcy, played by none other than Patrick Stewart.

The show must go on in ’lex de la IglesiaŠ—Ès sprawling ensemble dark comedy Š—“My Big Night,Š— and it does, like an express train. It begins when a camera crane fatally crushes an extra during the filming of a New YearŠ—Ès Eve variety TV show in which dancers and singers perform before a seated audience clad in formal wear. A producerŠ—Ès indifference and desperate haste to remove the body, avoid liabilities and proceed with shooting give you an idea of where this frenzied, Almod’_varesque backstage farce is going.

Just count the behind-the-scenes dramas: The eventŠ—Ès hosts (Hugo Silva and Carolina Bang) want to claw each otherŠ—Ès eyes out; a vain and abusive singer (the Spanish pop vocalist Raphael) feels threatened by a hunky, long-maned young phenom (Mario Casas), who is searching for two gold diggers intent on blackmail; the older singerŠ—Ès adoptive son (Carlos Areces) has hired an assassin (Jaime Ord’_’±ez) to kill his father; two women (Carmen Machi and Carmen Ruiz) in a mobile editing room survive the toppling of their vehicle by demonstrators rioting outside the studio; a portly mamaŠ—Ès boy (Pep’_n Nieto) hired to replace the dead extra falls in love with another extra (Blanca Su’rez).

Thanks to his editor, Domingo Gonz’lez, Mr. de la Iglesia skillfully keeps these many balls in the air, a palpable affection for his players seeping through. For all of the glittering poison darts lobbed in Š—“My Big Night,Š— itŠ—Ès the directorŠ—Ès love of show business that becomes most apparent.

Ms. Nieves and Mr. Copes offer sometimes divergent accounts of their collaboration, which began when both were teenagers. Mr. Copes is understated, masculine and faintly defensive. (Ms. Nieves, he says, was Š—“my Stradivarius.Š—) Ms. Nieves is candid, expressive, life-loving even when acknowledging pain Š—” the two had many breakups and reconciliations before divorcing Š—” and resignation. Cigarette holder in hand, she is the pictureŠ—Ès principal power source, its brightest light.

Today, the bond between Ms. Nieves and Mr. Copes, now in their 80s, appears imbued with a kind of rueful respect. But the love they and the youthful performers have for the tango endures. As will the dance itself.

Both acknowledge their singular stage charisma and dexterity, immortalized in the Broadway hit Š—“Tango Argentino.Š— (Period footage of their specialty, duets on a tabletop, still inspires astonishment.) But that does not diminish the contributions of the young performers here, who listen rapturously to Ms. NievesŠ—Ès descriptions of a vanished Buenos Aires and her embrace of an artistic calling. The dusty trails of yesteryear are heavily patrolled highways lined with garish motels, fast-food eateries and discount stores that suggest a boulevard in hell that stretches to the horizon. Hagit (Moran Rosenblatt), who has a gift for constructing small models out of paper, yearns for autonomy, and most of all for a husband. If you were not a teenager in the 1980s, John CarneyŠ—Ès Š—“Sing StreetŠ— is likely to beguile you with the sweet, universal energy of youth. ThatŠ—Ès my problem, and itŠ—Ès a problem less with the film Š—” an autobiographical tribute to Dublin, hair gel and the power of lip-syncing Š—” than with the passage of time and the tiny schisms that open up within a single generationŠ—Ès experience. The assumption behind omnibus movies Š—” features built out of shorts by various directors, generally on a common theme Š—” is that the contributions will, on balance, add up to a satisfying experience. But this law-of-averages thinking rarely yields a full meal for filmgoers. Usually, the results are a few good shorts, a few terrible shorts and a frustrating lack of cohesion.

So it goes with Š—“Rio, I Love You,Š— the third anthology in a series that began with Š—“Paris Je TŠ—ÈAimeŠ— (2007) and continued with Š—“New York, I Love YouŠ— (2009). Packed with unconvincing pain and unsexy couplings, the (seemingly deliberately) befuddled story dives into the questionable memories of Stephen (James Franco), a spectacularly narcissistic writer. DisneyŠ—Ès first version opened in the United States a year after the country created its first list of endangered species. The studio may not have been thinking of Š—“Silent Spring,Š— Rachel CarsonŠ—Ès 1962 environmental shocker, but Š—“The Jungle BookŠ— hinges on a barefoot child who lives in a furry, fanged commune right out of a pastoral idyll. Sherman wrote with Louis Armstrong in mind.

Directed by Jon Favreau, the busy redo continues HollywoodŠ—Ès infatuation with British actors, though this time itŠ—Ès Idris Elba who puts the purr into Shere Khan. Much like the 1967 movie, this one has a loose relationship with the Kipling tales, originally published in 1894. ItŠ—Ès no surprise, given KiplingŠ—Ès gravity, that the 2016 movie sticks close to the first film in its boyish bounce and sunny vibe. Written by Justin Marks, it opens with Mowgli (Neel Sethi) as a prepubescent, racing alongside his protector, the panther Bagheera (Ben Kingsley), who years earlier placed him in the care of a mother wolf, Raksha (Lupita NyongŠ—Èo). Much of the story involves Shere KhanŠ—Ès plotting against Mowgli amid adventures with Baloo the bear (Bill Murray), Kaa the snake (Scarlett Johansson) and others.

Studios are in the recycling business, and while this Š—“The Jungle BookŠ— is lightly diverting, it is also disappointing, partly because it feels like a pumped-up version of DisneyŠ—Ès 1967 animated film, with more action and less sweetness. It also feels strangely removed from our moment. About the only thing that feels of today is that its lush and arid environments and padding paws were digitally created. The resulting look, pitched between photorealism and impressionism, hovers between the realistic and the uncanny. It turns out that the movie was shot in a Los Angeles warehouse, which paradoxically seems like an old-fashioned way to make worlds.

In the Kipling stories, every creature abides by the Law of the Jungle, a decree thatŠ—Ès been read as a proxy for British imperialist rule. Both the 1967 and 2016 Mowglis, by contrast, live under the Law of Disney, which dictates that humans can exist with nature, as long as nature isnŠ—Èt too wild. ThereŠ—Ès an argument to be made against that kind of cuddly domination of nature. Yet itŠ—Ès also true that generations have grown up loving and respecting animals (as animals, not just human surrogates) because of the peaceable kingdom that Disney has created. HereŠ—Ès hoping that next time Mowgli shows up onscreen, he trades in his four-legged foe for some two-legged villains Š—” before the only wild worlds we have left are computer-generated.

Richard M. Sherman later said that Disney rejected casting a black man, fearing potential trouble with the N.A.A.C.P. For all the ostensible timelessness of its storytelling, Disney has always made movies that speak to its audiences and the world they live in. Even so, itŠ—Ès hard not to squirm through the number with PrimaŠ—Ès scatting ape because of the troubling signifiers it throws out. At the same time, the film partly alleviates, however unwittingly, Rudyard KiplingŠ—Ès weighty colonialist baggage, both by giving Mowgli, an Indian child, a golly-gee American voice, and by casting George Sanders as the villainous tiger, Shere Khan, who sounds just as you would expect a world-weary British royal to sound after centuries of pillaging. So, a mixed Disney bag, as usual, with a hippie kid, confusing politics and fuzzy-wuzzies.

DisneyŠ—Ès new take on Š—“The Jungle BookŠ— is being touted as a live-action movie, though thereŠ—Ès scarcely anything alive in it. That goes for the gaudy and glorious flora, the gathering clouds and the wind stirring them, all of which were created, with various degrees of believability, via computers. The child playing Mowgli Š—” the human orphan turned wolf child Š—” is played by an actual kid, who frolics with computer-generated critters, a smart call, given that animals can be tricky to work with and that some of this menagerieŠ—Ès real-life equivalents are (sorry to be a bummer) endangered.

Shere Khan is still the baddie, but now heŠ—Ès lethally, instead of imperiously, cool, which seems unfair, given that Bengal tigers are endangered. The rest of the adult animals, meanwhile, largely register as noble, particularly the elephants that Bagheera and Mowgli bow down before. In the 1967 film, the elephants are amusingly buffoonish and march in a pachyderm parade as their leader invokes his time with the maharajah. The 2016 movie doesnŠ—Èt refer directly to our environmental catastrophes, including the decimation of the elephant population. Yet when Bagheera now instructs Mowgli to bow before the elephants, it feels as if the filmmakers were gesturing to the truth that this fantasy and its relation to the real world are now tragically different from what they were in KiplingŠ—Ès time.

And when Mowgli helps out the elephants, thereŠ—Ès a suggestion that humans can play their part in their rescue, which is a comforting moral for the children who are this movieŠ—Ès main audience. At the same time, it would be heartening if Disney took a more environmentally aware stance in the sequel thatŠ—Ès already been discussed, especially given that the companyŠ—Ès brand owes as much to the natural world as to princesses. In recent years, the Disney princess has undergone a radical makeover, evolving into a can-do figure who exists in that cinematic sweet spot between her fantastical world and our real one. The studioŠ—Ès animal kingdom could use a comparable makeover.
Š—“The Measure of a ManŠ— is not rated. It is in French with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 33 minutes.

ItŠ—Ès too bad that the movieŠ—Ès blunt original title Š—” Š—“La Loi du March’©,Š— or Š—“Market LawŠ— Š—” was traded in for something prettier and blander. Š—“The Measure of a ManŠ— suggests stirring possibilities (Š—“Of all things the measure is man,Š— as the philosopher once put it), but it doesnŠ—Èt convey the ordinary cold brutality of what it means to be defined by the unpaid and the radically underpaid hour. Yet, with Mr. LindonŠ—Ès help and in several extraordinary scenes in the marketŠ—Ès back office Š—” a white hell in which people are pushed to sell out one another Š—” Mr. Briz’© transforms one individualŠ—Ès story into a social tragedy.

Mr. LindonŠ—Ès physically reserved, inward turn as Thierry (wrinkled brow, downcast eyes) dovetails with Mr. Briz’©Š—Ès restrained realism. (Mr. Lindon won the best actor prize at the 2015 Cannes Film Festival for this performance.) Much of the movie consists of compact, direct scenes that add details to the larger emerging portrait while providing a tangible, lived-in sense of ThierryŠ—Ès ordinary life; how, for instance, he holds on to a worklike routine, even if it means cleaning his familyŠ—Ès kitchen. Over time, you also learn that he has a wife and a disabled son, and that he has tired of meeting his fellow laid-off workers, some of whom are still agitating to fight their former employer.

As he does throughout, the director, St’©phane Briz’©, leads with his strength: his star. A dependable presence in contemporary French cinema whose recent credits include Claire DenisŠ—Ès Š—“Bastards,Š— Mr. Lindon has the weathered, approachable good looks of a real person (and a French movie actor). ItŠ—Ès a face that has miles on it, the kind that suggests thereŠ—Ès a story behind every crease and can also, depending on the role, register as stoic or world-weary, brooding or slightly dangerous, sometimes all at once.

Gently harrowing in its scary familiarity, the story picks up 20 months after Thierry (an excellent Vincent Lindon) was laid off from his longtime previous job. HeŠ—Ès struggling to regain his equilibrium, his place in the world, his sense of personal dignity, but itŠ—Ès a tough, at times humiliating struggle. It might also be an impossible one, though not for a lack of effort on his part. The movie opens on Thierry seated in a bureaucratic droneŠ—Ès cramped, anonymous office and plaintively venting about a training course that hasnŠ—Èt produced the desired results. Š—“How can I pay the bills?Š— he asks. Š—“Bottom line, no job.Š—

Midway through the quiet emotional storms in the French drama Š—“The Measure of a Man,Š— the hero, Thierry, begins working as a supermarket security guard. ItŠ—Ès a bitter victory. There is little thatŠ—Ès secure about the job, which requires Thierry to view not just every customer but also each employee as a potential thief. Supplemented with the trappings of the badly paid Š—” a stifling tie, ill-fitting jacket, squawking walkie-talkie Š—” he embodies 21st-century labor at its most heroically alienated. As he stands and watches, liberty seems a distant promise, as do equality and fraternity.

Josh Fox, the director, begins in a short-lived state of serenity, relaxing at his rural Pennsylvania home after his community won a battle against fracking companies that wanted to drill in the area. (The possibility of fracking there spurred him to make Š—“Gasland,Š— an Oscar-nominated documentary from 2010.)

ItŠ—Ès grueling to hear and ugly to see as he visits some of the places most affected by pollution: a Chinese city with lung-clogging air, an oil spill in the Amazon. ThereŠ—Ès a chance youŠ—Èll miss such moments as you look away or wince at the horror of our collective idiocy and environment-destroying greed.
Š—“How to Let Go of the World and Love All the Things Climate CanŠ—Èt ChangeŠ— is not rated. Running time: 2 hours 7 minutes.

To be sure, Mr. Fox adds a bit of optimism, with occasional scattershot sections highlighting renewable energy and the success of civil disobedience against corporations and governments. But those scenes are like a few grains of sugar dropped into a glass of rancid milk: They donŠ—Èt really change the taste. Even with its final, hopeful words, this film leaves you with some very stomach-turning emotions.
He soon discovered a beloved tree was being killed by woolly adelgids. Cold northern winters can confine these invasive insects to the South, but climate change is increasing their range.

That led him to talk to experts about rising global temperatures. The interviews detail nightmarish scenarios: stifling heat, relentless storms and mass extinctions are soon to arrive, weŠ—Ère told. Even if we gave up fossil fuels tomorrow, itŠ—Ès projected that the catastrophes are inevitable.

The filmŠ—Ès title will use up many of the allotted words for this review, so itŠ—Ès best to be terse when critiquing Š—“How to Let Go of the World and Love All the Things Climate CanŠ—Èt Change.Š— Hence, a one-word assessment of this documentary: Tough. As in, tough to watch. Tough to consider. Tough to ignore.

Some biographical portraits summon up the dead with uncanny or suggestive facial, vocal and gestural resemblances between the original and copy; others just pull out the wigs and clich’©s. Sunlight on rippling water, tanned bodies lounging by a swimming pool, brilliant sunshine in a deep-blue sky, endless summer. Many of the important facts in that movie appear as footnotes or flashbacks in this one. There are so many interesting movies hovering in the air, none of them the one onscreen. Š—“Nina,Š— written and directed by Cynthia Mort, has taken a long time to arrive in theaters. Š—“A Hologram for the KingŠ— ponders a modern world in the thrall of illusions. Of what essential use is a holographic teleconferencing system, we are never told. The movie is set in 2010, when America was still reeling from the financial crisis and months before the beginning of the Arab Spring uprisings that eventually transformed much of the Middle East into a grisly battleground. That movie, directed by Rupert Sanders, could be described as a reimagining of the Snow White story. It found a new idea in old material. This is especially dispiriting because Š—“Snow White and the HuntsmanŠ— Š—” in relation to which this Š—“HuntsmanŠ— is both sequel and prequel Š—” was far from a terrible piece of entertainment. Is Š—“The Huntsman: WinterŠ—Ès WarŠ— the worst movie of the year? ItŠ—Ès too early to say, of course, and itŠ—Ès a complicated question, since there are so many varieties of bad movie. Š—“The Huntsman: WinterŠ—Ès WarŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) because it wants to be taken seriously, I guess. Running time: 1 hour 48 minutes.

She also stares stonily into that galootŠ—Ès eyes and says, Š—“IŠ—Ève done terrible things.Š— Yes, but Ms. Chastain has also done Š—“Zero Dark ThirtyŠ— and Š—“The HelpŠ— and Š—“The Tree of Life,Š— so thereŠ—Ès no need for her to be so hard on herself. But thereŠ—Ès also no need for anyone to keep trying to spin beloved fairy tales into second-rate franchises.

Every resonant theme or intriguing story possibility is stripped away and replaced with a ready-made franchise-movie conceit. The filmmakers compensate for emptiness with redundancy. More is not more.

Ravenna has a sister named Freya, who is played by Emily Blunt. Ms. Theron shows up early and late, at one point in a costume of golden feathers that makes her look like the mascot for a superglamorous drive-through fried-chicken joint. Freya, who shoots ice crystals out of her fingertips, presides over a frozen kingdom and is motivated to do evil out of thwarted maternal feelings. This is an interesting example of Hollywood sexism at work. Disappointed love of some kind Š—” romantic in RavennaŠ—Ès case, parental in FreyaŠ—Ès Š—” seems to be a requirement for female evildoing. Guys, on the other hand, can be bad just for the power-hungry fun of it.

Freya kidnaps children from the lands she conquers and raises them to be ruthless warriors. One of them grows up to be Eric (Chris Hemsworth), the hunky Huntsman who helped Snow White vanquish Ravenna. That momentous victory is pretty much yada yadaŠ—Èed in the middle of Š—“WinterŠ—Ès War,Š— which is mostly about the star-crossed, action-screwball romance between Eric and Sara (Jessica Chastain), a fellow child soldier.

The conventional wisdom holds that none of these disasters happen on purpose, that nobody ever sets out to make a bad movie. Š—“The HuntsmanŠ— challenges that idea, since it seems to be exactly the movie that the money behind it wanted to see made. Its badness is not extreme, but exemplary: ItŠ—Ès everything wrong with Hollywood today stuffed into a little less than two hours.

Sights like these give Š—“Tale of TalesŠ— its lustful heart and carnival soul, best distilled in the barmy lewdness of a scene in which Mr. CasselŠ—Ès king blissfully sucks a shy maidenŠ—Ès digit through a wooden door. Finger-licking good, indeed.
