Strip away the smatterings of sex and globs of gore, and children would really get a kick out of Š—“Tale of Tales,Š— Matteo GarroneŠ—Ès colorful and kinky exploration of what women want. And what men will do to give it to them.

At times, the horrific eclipses the merely eccentric as necks are sliced and broken, skin is glued and flayed, and bodies are tossed from great heights. Magic thrives in ocean and forest, where Peter SuschitzkyŠ—Ès glorious images weave the wondrous into the everyday: The almost limpid bulk of a sleeping sea monster, its milky body surrounded by undulating currents; a Titian-haired nymph slumbering in a glade on a puddle of scarlet satin.

Š—“Sworn Virgin,Š— the debut feature from the Italian director Laura Bispuri, concerns a fading custom in remote Albania, where some women have sworn off marriage, sex and parenthood and proceeded to live as men.

Ms. Bispuri, showing the young Hana in flashbacks, offers harrowing highlights from the womenŠ—Ès upbringing: The girls are told that Š—“itŠ—Ès not good to speak before a man speaks.Š— LilaŠ—Ès dowry includes a bullet in case her future husband ever finds reason to complain about his wife.

The filmŠ—Ès protagonist (Alba Rohrwacher), known as Mark, has taken this path, gaining rights in a fiercely patriarchal culture. Mark is first seen wrangling a goat in a snowy mountain village. This taciturn character travels from Albania to Italy and shows up at the door of Lila (Flonja Kodheli), who was raised as MarkŠ—Ès sister when Mark was known as Hana. Lila appears to know of the new identity, but the two havenŠ—Èt seen each other in 14 years. While living with LilaŠ—Ès family in Italy, Mark tentatively shifts back toward life as Hana.

Although Ms. Rohrwacher captures MarkŠ—Ès uncertain, shifting physicality, the movie doesnŠ—Èt always succeed in getting inside the characterŠ—Ès head. MarkŠ—Ès reluctance to speak sometimes plays like a screenwriting crutch Š—” a way to avoid writing dialogue that reflects complex motivations.

Š—“Sworn VirginŠ— alternates between this oppressive atmosphere and more lyrical present-day sequences. Mark is entranced with female bodies in a pool, and also intrigued by Bernhard (Lars Eidinger), a man who works at the pool and immediately proves receptive to that curiosity.

ItŠ—Ès a little of both, in truth, with some family melodrama and sweet romance thrown in. Affable, earnest and humanly scaled, Š—“The MeddlerŠ— is the kind of entertainment that the studios used to supply by the boatload and that now tends to show up on the small screen. Its emphasis on a mother and daughter relationship, in particular, brings to mind maternal melodramas like the glorious weepie Š—“Stella DallasŠ— (1937), about a woman who asks her wealthy estranged husband to finish raising their daughter so that the girl can live like the people in movies.

The writer-director Lorene Scafaria leads with her laughs. Marnie enters yakking and keeps the motor running, including in voice-over. The patter is inane, funny, lifelike, and Ms. SarandonŠ—Ès Jersey intonations give it a comic topspin. Ms. Scafaria seeds these passages with information Š—” MarnieŠ—Ès dead husband, Joe, was the love of her life Š—” and you can see the narrative machinery in action. But part of what makes the movie work is its unshowy realism, including yammer that isnŠ—Èt the stuff of dramatic setup or tension but instead resembles the churn of random observations and pointless asides. The sort that swirls through your head and you sometimes share with someone when youŠ—Ère unpacking groceries, making dinner or just calling to chat Š—” only funnier.

It would be easy to put Marnie on the couch, to assume that sheŠ—Ès neurotic rather than, you know, friendly, and that she talks a lot only to fill the silences or because the quiet might bring on the grief and self-reflection. But sheŠ—Ès plenty self-knowing already, thanks, and Ms. Sarandon shows you the self-awareness hovering behind MarnieŠ—Ès smile and trembling in her pauses. Still, there is work to be done, a life to live, and, in a sense, the movie is a coming-of-later-age story in which a mother learns how to cut the cord one funny, poignant snip at a time and discovers herself in the process. In this, Marnie receives help from a much younger mother, Jillian (Cecily Strong), and a new friend, Zipper (J.K. Simmons), who each peel back layers.
Š—“The MeddlerŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). I havenŠ—Èt a clue why. Running time: 1 hour 40 minutes.

The first time that Marnie Minervini opens her mouth in Š—“The Meddler,Š— you may wish it were the last. One half of an insistently winning, hopelessly irresistible mother-daughter duet, this buttinsky New Jersey widow (Susan Sarandon) puts the Š—“awlŠ— into call and the Š—“awkŠ— into talk and works both your nerves and ears as she does. Having recently moved to Los Angeles, Marnie has turned her cellphone into an umbilical cord that keeps her hooked to her daughter, Lori (Rose Byrne). Š—“The MeddlerŠ— is a tear-drizzled comedy, but I understand if it sounds like a horror movie.

The same goes for the movie, which has a humble, utilitarian visual style, except that everyone looks really pretty, Ms. Sarandon, Ms. Byrne and Mr. Simmons included. Part of this is the quality of the Los Angeles light, which here has none of its sunshine-and-noir harshness but instead gives the characters an appealing glow, a glow that after a while feels like adoration. When Marnie looks at Lori Š—” and Lori looks at Marnie Š—” you are watching two people who, despite the nonsense, care for each other deeply. You see their happiness and you share in it too because in Š—“The MeddlerŠ— Ms. Scafaria is holding up that softening filter through which each of us sees the funny, maddening, indispensable people with whom we laugh, mourn and, if weŠ—Ère lucky, find love.

The story begins to catch up to MarnieŠ—Ès accelerated rhythms when Lori splits for New York to work on a pilot sheŠ—Ès written, leaving her mom alone. Marnie copes with this separation in her usual fashion, calling Lori amid visits to the mall (cue the Crate & Barrel product placements) and visits to LoriŠ—Ès dogs, LoriŠ—Ès friends and LoriŠ—Ès shrink. Marnie has started to see the therapist (Amy Landecker in a quick, deadpan turn) at LoriŠ—Ès urging, though mostly she seems to go as a way to insinuate herself even more deeply into her daughterŠ—Ès life. ItŠ—Ès no wonder that Marnie seems like a smother-mother whoŠ—Ès one 911 call away from a restraining order; no wonder too that she seems lonely.

The difference being that Š—“The MeddlerŠ— is agreeably (unusually) optimistic about human relationships, despite the melancholy edging its comedy. Marnie is the biggest source of the humor, and Ms. Sarandon plays her beautifully in every shade of sunshine. One of those relentlessly Š—“onŠ— people whoŠ—Ès always on the go, Marnie is always talking (including on her cell behind the wheel) and always doing, and always talking while doing. ThereŠ—Ès compulsiveness to her meddlesomeness. Marnie doesnŠ—Èt just call Lori, she does so repeatedly, babbling away as if each call were another clause in a sentence without end (Š—“anywayŠ—).
The tale, ripped from the headlines, is stirring, even if the repeated rally scenes and aerial views of the region grow stale.

For decades, Arthur T. Demoulas followed a philosophy of low prices, high wages and profit-sharing in running the New England supermarket chain Market Basket, and the company flourished, though with less than larcenous profits.

The beloved chief executive controlled the company by a slender majority but with an inflated contempt for the rules of corporate conduct. In one example from the film, the transcript of a bitter board meeting reveals a costly move that he shared as a fait accompli rather than as a proposal.

When the power shifted and Arthur T. (as he is called in the film to distinguish him from his cousin and nemesis, Arthur S. Demoulas) was fired, a casualty of the pursuit of profit, the path was clear to employees: straight out the door. The customers followed, emptying the stores.
Still, you have to wonder what a director like Michael Moore could have strung on the strong thread of this strange fable from the era of income inequality.

Š—“We the People: The Market Basket Effect,Š— directed by Tommy Reid, takes a hyperlocal approach, relying largely on Boston-area experts, footage of parking lot rallies, anecdotes from employees and working-class customers, and their megaphonic voices of solidarity in support of management Š—” as it was embodied by Arthur T.

When ordinary people win, there is usually a good story behind the victory. In that regard, this documentary about the Market Basket uprising does not disappoint. It is bursting with real-life superheroes who drive trucks and bag groceries and its drama springs from a family feud of Shakespearean proportions.

In 1964, when Eva Hesse went to Germany on a fellowship with her husband, the sculptor Tom Doyle, she was a talented 28-year-old painter with a blue-chip education (Cooper Union and Yale) and a foothold in the art world. By the time of her death six years later, from brain cancer, she was widely recognized as a major artist, a maker of category-confounding forms Š—” abstract and visceral, minimalist and feminist, sculptural and painterly Š—” that have lost none of their power in the decades since.
Š—“Eva HesseŠ— is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 48 minutes.

Everyone is middle-aged or older, mostly dressed in 21st-century studio or academic mufti. Hesse, in contrast, is a revenant from a cooler, smokier, scruffier decade, eternally and intriguingly youthful. At times resembling the actress Dakota Johnson, she appears mainly in black-and-white still photographs, some of which are digitally massaged so that they seem to move ever so slightly. Her voice is heard once, in a snippet of audiotape. But Ms. Begleiter has made ample and judicious use of HesseŠ—Ès letters and diaries, passages of which are read in voice-over by Selma Blair. These selections, along with the pictures, create a powerful illusion of immediacy, a sense of the personality disclosed and obscured by the art.

Hesse was born to a Jewish family in Hamburg in 1936. She and her sister left Germany on a Kindertransport train. Their parents managed to escape the Nazis as well, but many of their relatives were killed during World War II, and the girlsŠ—È mother committed suicide in 1946. Though the Holocaust was never an overt theme in HesseŠ—Ès work, Ms. Begleiter traces the shadow it cast on her life, especially during her sojourn in Germany with Mr. Doyle.

Like many creative people, Hesse veered from heroic confidence to crippling doubt, but in every phase, she seemed capable of remarkable clarity, humor and warmth. Among her closest confidants was Sol LeWitt, the scholarly, sphinxlike Conceptualist visionary who was the subject of an excellent documentary by Chris Teerink a few years ago. Their correspondence is clearly a remarkable trove of art world gossip, fraternal feeling and critical insight, and it provides this film its emotional and intellectual grounding. (LeWittŠ—Ès parts are read by the actor Patrick Kennedy.) But the drama of Š—“Eva HesseŠ— is a story of mastery and self-discovery, of a woman asserting her autonomy in a male-dominated professional realm.

The film is frank about HesseŠ—Ès personal life without being prurient, and it conveys a vivid sense of the sexual politics of the New York art world in the 1960s, a scene still dominated by the myth of the heroic male creator. HesseŠ—Ès response was to cultivate her own heroism, a powerfully idiosyncratic style that could be earthy, delicate, whimsical and sublime, sometimes all at once. Š—“Eva HesseŠ— pays a gratifying amount of attention to the thinking and the techniques that produced her art, and invites viewers to contemplate it further. ItŠ—Ès like a comprehensive exhibition catalog or a thorough critical essay Š—” an indispensable aid to understanding and appreciating a fascinating artist.

Š—“Eva Hesse,Š— Marcie BegleiterŠ—Ès conscientious and moving documentary, tells the full story of its subjectŠ—Ès tragically foreshortened life, but it focuses on those years of artistic emergence, a period of rapid development and furious productivity, with few parallels in the history of art. Hesse herself is both a ubiquitous presence in the film and something of a specter Š—” an animating spirit and a ghost haunting the frames. She is remembered by friends, colleagues and her sister, Helen Hesse Charash. Her work is analyzed by curators and critics. Mr. Doyle is on hand to reflect, tactfully and ruefully, on the ups and downs of their relationship.

Directed by Toni Myers and made in cooperation with NASA, most of Š—“A Beautiful PlanetŠ— was shot by astronauts while on monthslong space missions. From the space station they carried out research and space-walked to make needed repairs. And through it all, they took videos of our planet.

To see vast oceans, immense deserts and mountain ranges from so high up is both humbling and inspiring. And scenes of mighty lightning storms, the aurora borealis and cities illuminated at night are magnificent.

Ms. Myers is an efficient director and editor, though her script could have used a few more of those personal moments to prevent viewer fatigue that may set in after the succession of huge images. Additional specifics on the missions and the science would also have been helpful.

You already know the big scenes will be awe-inspiring in Š—“A Beautiful PlanetŠ— Š—” how can your eyes not bug out when given 3-D views of Earth, taken from space, on a stories-high Imax screen? WhatŠ—Ès surprising is how enjoyable the small moments are in this documentary, filmed aboard the International Space Station.

Just as fun is observing the astronauts as they handle seemingly simple tasks while weightless. A crew member floating as she sleeps looks supernatural; seeing another getting in and out of his spacesuit has a Marx Brothers-like quality. And I can say without reservation that IŠ—Ève never been so fascinated by watching a man shampoo his hair.

Still, this film, which is smoothly narrated by Jennifer Lawrence, finds a nice balance: ItŠ—Ès appealing to adults and accessible to younger viewers. And it delivers an environmental message that is strong and serious while remaining encouraging and optimistic. ThatŠ—Ès important to hear. The rest is just amazing to watch.

Yet Mr. Nikolic, whose 2015 feature Š—“AllureŠ— had an engaging originality that this movie lacks, has a talent for conjuring wistful disillusion among those buffeted by the winds of capitalism and change. When faced with disaster, he seems to be saying, go back to first principles: Eat, dance, fool around. And steal as much money as you can.

Š—“Bourek,Š— which takes its title from a flaky Mediterranean pastry, is described in the publicity notes, somewhat optimistically, as a comedy. Viewers, however, are unlikely to be more than marginally amused by its fair-to-middling acting, enervated plot and forcibly diverse group of drifting souls gathered on the fictional Greek island of Khronos.

That island, though, is languidly pretty, photographed in tones of butterscotch and cerulean by the Serbian cinematographer Vladimir Subotic (a regular collaborator of the writer and director, Vladan Nikolic). In this burnished idyll, assorted characters bicker and lounge against a backdrop of news reports heralding social and financial catastrophe.

An American billionaire (William Leroy) hunkers with his money and his gold-digging honey, waiting for the apocalypse promised by a white-suited televangelist (gustily played by Paul Sevigny, Chlo’â SevignyŠ—Ès brother). A radiant Greek woman (Katerina Misichroni) struggles to protect her debt-squeezed restaurant from a pushy developer while caring for an amnesiac British D.J. Around them, a flotsam of idiosyncratic travelers Š—” a Yeats-quoting Libyan refugee; a Turkish drug dealer-cum-baker Š—” ebbs and flows, saddled with na’Àvely hackneyed dialogue and a director who seems to be entertaining only himself.

The film, directed by John Goldschmidt, is Š—“DoughŠ— and gives us Nat (Jonathan Pryce), whose kosher London bakery is struggling and facing a hostile takeover bid from a cutthroat developer who wants to tear it down. When NatŠ—Ès apprentice quits, he reluctantly hires Ayyash (Jerome Holder), a Muslim immigrant from Africa.

Take an aging white Jewish baker, add a young black Muslim immigrant, and what do you have? The ingredients for a pleasant but pat story in which bridges are built across religious, racial and generational divides in a way that happens far more often in feel-good movies than in real life.
Š—“DoughŠ— is sweet, often funny and always nonthreatening, a movie for those who wish the intractable realities of the world would just disappear.

Ayyash supplements the family income by selling marijuana on the side, and when he makes an unplanned recipe alteration and mixes some into the baked goods, business booms. The joke in which unlikely and unsuspecting people eat something with pot in it is by now rather worn out, but Mr. Pryce and especially Mr. Holder are appealing. ThereŠ—Ès never much doubt where the story is going: Hardships will be endured, mutual respect will develop, bonding will occur, lessons will be learned, the forces of greed will be foiled.

Fassbinder, who died in 1982 at 37, was an extreme workhorse whose stupendous output Š—” more than 60 films and two television series, not to mention plays Š—” was accomplished with little sleep and an indifference to his physical well-being. Copious drugs and alcohol were consumed to keep up the pace. Mr. Thomsen, who directed this reverent tribute, met Fassbinder in 1969 at the Berlin International Film Festival, where his early movie Š—“Love Is Colder Than DeathŠ— was booed. Fassbinder, unruffled, dismissed the Berlin critics as Š—“provincialsŠ— and remarked, Š—“At least they reacted.Š— Over the coming years, Mr. Thomsen interviewed the director and became a close friend.
This frustrating if intriguing film suggests that Fassbinder did the same, but indirectly. He died of overwork. There is a tumultuous story left untold.

FassbinderŠ—Ès changing politics are mentioned, but in bits and pieces, with little effort made to tie everything into a consistent theory. Among the actors interviewed, the most time is given to Irm Hermann, who describes FassbinderŠ—Ès abusive, authoritarian control over her. Other actors featured in Fassbinder films, especially Hanna Schygulla, are seen in clips, but are not interviewed.

In the chapter Š—“Sadomasochism,Š— any details of sexual tastes are missing, as are references to his lovers, most of them male, although the movie notes that three of them committed suicide. In FassbinderŠ—Ès last five years, the documentary says, he lost his trust in the idea of community and decided that the world was crazy and could not be changed except into Š—“a kind of personal madness.Š—

The film is divided into chapters Š—” with titles like Š—“Childhood,Š— Š—“The Actors,Š— Š—“SadomasochismŠ— and Š—“DeathŠ— Š—” that create a semblance of structure. Fassbinder had ambivalent feelings about Hollywood and abhorred sentimentality. Of the many directors Fassbinder admired, Mr. Thomsen says, the closest thing to an idol was Douglas Sirk (born Klaus Detlef Sierck in Hamburg) who used Hollywood conventions only to subvert them in movies like Š—“Imitation of Life,Š— a film with soap-opera theatrics that disguised an underlying social critique.

Š—“IŠ—Èd like to be for cinema what William Shakespeare was for theater, Marx for politics, and Freud for psychology,Š— the German director Rainer Werner Fassbinder is quoted as having said in the Danish director Christian Braad ThomsenŠ—Ès documentary study, Š—“Fassbinder: To Love Without Demands.Š—
Š—“Fassbinder: To Love Without DemandsŠ— is not rated. It is in English and German, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 49 minutes.

The access to Fassbinder that the relationship provided was a boon to the film, but a disadvantage as well because the close-up view results in a patchy portrait rather than a coherent biography. The documentary assumes a familiarity with FassbinderŠ—Ès movies that few American viewers possess. There is no film-by-film analysis of his major works, which include Š—“The Marriage of Maria BraunŠ— and Š—“Berlin Alexanderplatz,Š— or the connection from one to the next.

What is emphasized is FassbinderŠ—Ès obsession with family. The film examines him through a Freudian lens, paying special attention to his mother, Lilo Pempeit, who appeared in many of his films and whose voice is heard in audio interviews. After World War II, Fassbinder was brought up in Munich by an ever-changing group of adults who lived in a house in which he enjoyed almost unlimited freedom. As his career developed, his filmmaking colleagues and troupe of actors became a surrogate family.

ThatŠ—Ès the high-concept goof in Š—“Keanu,Š— a 10-minute sketch thatŠ—Ès been inflated to bloated feature length. Running 90 minutes too long, the movie is a slack, erratically amusing excuse to watch Mr. Key and Mr. Peele tag-team after ending Š—“Key & Peele,Š— their celebrated, often blazingly funny Comedy Central series that turned them into national memes. The road to Mr. Key and Mr. PeeleŠ—Ès future as movie headliners, though, will take more than kittens, guns and a riff on gangbangers head-bobbing to George Michael. WhatŠ—Ès needed is a sharper, smarter edge, like the one they used on their show to lacerate pop-cultural and political targets; also, more and better jokes.

The absurdist kick in Š—“Keanu,Š— the first movie to showcase Keegan-Michael Key and Jordan Peele together, has a tiny tail and squeak. Beloved of crime lords and doofuses alike, Keanu the kitten shows up early, padding underfoot through one of those artfully staged drug labs Š—” armed guards, white powder, ominous lighting Š—” thatŠ—Ès soon lit up with the sights and sounds of heavy artillery. Much like the Buddhalicious star heŠ—Ès named for, Keanu slips unscathed through the fast-and-furious raining bullets, miraculously dodging death as a heavenly chorus lays down an apocalyptic track. Kitten has skills.

On their show, Mr. Key and Mr. Peele turned code switching into an aesthetic principle, most famously in their sketches involving President Obama (brilliantly channeled by Mr. Peele) and his Anger Translator, Luther (Mr. Key). In Š—“Keanu,Š— once Rell and Clarence start hanging with CheddarŠ—Ès group, they swap their everyday speech (Š—“good EnglishŠ—) for tougher, rougher talk and haphazard grammar. They drop their final Š—“gŠ—Ès,Š— sprinkle on the Š—“ainŠ—ÈtsŠ— and vamp like gangbangers. ItŠ—Ès a metamorphosis that sounds like conceptual gold, as Mr. Key and Mr. Peele Š—” drawing from the comedy of masquerade and playing with racially coded speech and behavior Š—” turn a pair of amusing milquetoasts who happen to be black into black stereotypes right out of central casting.

Things start cooking when Keanu disappears, forcing Rell and Clarence to play detective while chasing leads and kitten tail. They end up in a strip club, where women provide the topless decoration on and off the pole in a joint, bada bing, run by a gangster, Cheddar (Method Man), and his gunslingers. (The flat-liner here is that the crew calls itself the 17th Street Blips, ’¾ la the Crips and the Bloods.) There, Rell and Clarence, latter-day Hardy Boys, pretend to be hard-core criminals, a quickie makeover that largely involves putting a swagger in their step, talking street (or like black extras in an exploitation flick) and punctuating their cartoonish braggadocio with R-rated filler.

Rell and Clarence are performing thuggery, at least at first, walking the bad-man walk and talking the talk while frantically looking for the exit. And despite the sluggish passages and hum of unease, itŠ—Ès fun watching these performers play with clich’©s amid a guest visit from Anna Faris and the sight of ClarenceŠ—Ès minivanŠ—Ès becoming a safe space for gangsta sharing and caring. (The director is Peter Atencio, another Š—“Key & PeeleŠ— veteran.) But as the genre machinery chugs along, the bang-bang begins to overwhelm the movie, and the underlying critique gives way to a what-me-worry shrug. Keanu may be Rell and ClarenceŠ—Ès power animal. But heŠ—Ès no match for Liam Š—“Neesons,Š— the character whom Mr. Key and Mr. Peele named in honor of the Hollywood hepcat who explodes minds and bodies both.

The good news is that Mr. Key and Mr. Peele comfortably hold the big screen, whether theyŠ—Ère playing ordinary guys or imitating killers. The movie, which Mr. Peele wrote with the longtime Š—“Key & PeeleŠ— contributor Alex Rubens, opens with the kitten running from the drug-lab shootout and landing at the door of Rell (Mr. Peele), whoŠ—Ès distraught after being dumped by his girlfriend. Like every man in the movie, Rell falls for the cat and Š—” after rising from a miasma of pot smoke while flanked by posters for Š—“New Jack CityŠ— and Michael MannŠ—Ès Š—“HeatŠ— Š—” names his fluffy new friend Keanu. A new love is born, one thatŠ—Ès blessed by RellŠ—Ès cousin, Clarence (Mr. Key), if also nearly doomed.
Š—“KeanuŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Bang bang, bleep bleep. Running time: 1 hour 40 minutes.

Š—“LŠ—ÈAttesa,Š— while it is about the stasis and confinement of its characters, suffers from a different kind of claustrophobia. A model of craft, refinement and visual decorum, it is both a hothouse flower and a cinematic hothouse, nurturing blossoms of exquisite feeling protected from the air of reality. Compared, say, with the Sicily of Michelangelo AntonioniŠ—Ès Š—“LŠ—ÈAvventuraŠ— or (to take a more recent example, also starring Ms. Binoche) the Alps of Olivier AssayasŠ—Ès Š—“Clouds of Sils Maria,Š— Mr. MessinaŠ—Ès Sicily has the shallow picturesqueness of a tourist destination. And AnnaŠ—Ès house, a stately pile of stones, is little more than an impressive piece of real estate, haunted not by history but by a single ghost.
Š—“LŠ—ÈAttesaŠ— (Š—“The WaitŠ—) is not rated. It is in Italian and French, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 50 minutes.

Š—“LŠ—ÈAttesa,Š— loosely based on a 1923 play by Luigi Pirandello called Š—“The Life I Gave You,Š— is a delicate, slightly artificial study in time and emotion. Its slow pace captures the stasis of AnnaŠ—Ès condition, her feeling of being stuck in an agonizing limbo between denial and acceptance. JeanneŠ—Ès presence is both an unbearable reminder of her own loss and a token of her sonŠ—Ès presence, and Mr. Messina is more interested in the nuances of the situation than in the mechanics of plot. At times the plausibility of the story starts to fray, but the feelings and images are strong enough to keep such doubts in check.

Š—“LŠ—ÈAttesaŠ— (Š—“The WaitŠ—), Piero MessinaŠ—Ès debut feature, is an elegant melodrama of maternal grief with overtones of horror, a psychological rather than a supernatural ghost story. Set in Sicily around Easter, the film partakes freely of religious imagery to add gravity and mystery to its domestic tale of loss, longing and deceit. The landscape Š—” volcanic rock and quiet forests surrounding a sparkling lake Š—” is captured in long, wide takes, a beauty surpassed only by close-ups of the two lead actresses, Juliette Binoche and Lou de La’¢ge.

The setting has an atavistic, primal grandeur. Sicily is a place of ancient blood feuds, medieval rituals and Greek tragedies. And there is something similarly timeless about the contours of Ms. BinocheŠ—Ès face. In anguish and repose, Anna could be a figure in an Italian Renaissance painting, a pale image of sorrow against a dark background.

Š—“IŠ—Èm waiting for the right moment to tell her,Š— Anna tells her sister-in-law after Jeanne has stumbled downstairs into a houseful of black-clad mourners. But AnnaŠ—Ès lie, initially a sin of omission, grows deeper, more complicated and more cruel as Jeanne hangs around, waiting for her lover to return and leaving plaintive messages on his cellphone. Anna listens to them, with what seems to be a complicated blend of masochism, jealousy and wishful thinking Š—” as if the fact that someone believes her son is still alive might make him less dead.

Jeanne, first seen in the blinding, sterile light of the airport, can seem as much a time traveler as a tourist, a visitor from the European modernity that is also AnnaŠ—Ès native realm. She comes to regard her would-be mother-in-law Š—” thereŠ—Ès no real word for what they are to each other Š—” as a wise aunt or an older sister, and despite the weirdness of the circumstances, the two women strike up a tentative friendship. ItŠ—Ès a pleasure to watch Ms. Binoche and Ms. de La’¢ge onscreen together. And there are scenes of each of them alone that are piercing and lovely. At one point, Anna wraps her arms around an inflatable raft and releases the valve, catching her sonŠ—Ès preserved breath on her face as it escapes.

The performances are vivid and moving, but there is ultimately less to this well-made, impeccably acted film than meets the eye. Its meticulousness is to some degree a flaw, an evasion of nearly every variety of human messiness. You wait in vain for the full weight of bereavement to become apparent, and also for an indication of the density of experience. You wait in gorgeous surroundings, in marvelous company, for something that never arrives.

Ms. Binoche plays Anna, a Frenchwoman who lives on an estate that belonged to her former husbandŠ—Ès family. Ms. de La’¢ge is Jeanne, the French girlfriend of AnnaŠ—Ès son, Giuseppe. Jeanne, who has never met Anna, arrives for a visit at a tragically inconvenient moment. Giuseppe has just died in an accident Š—” the first images in Š—“LŠ—ÈAttesaŠ— are of his funeral Š—” and Anna is too distraught to break the news to Jeanne. When the young woman calls from the airport, Anna tells her that Giuseppe isnŠ—Èt home and dispatches the caretaker, Pietro (Giorgio Colangeli), to pick her up.
Š—“MotherŠ—Ès DayŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for language of the sort that your mom may use with you if you take her to see this movie.

The unofficial conclusion of an unofficial trilogy of holiday-themed multistar comedy vehicles directed by Garry Marshall, Š—“MotherŠ—Ès DayŠ— has its perfunctory heart exactly where any experienced viewer would expect it to be. That is, in a fantasy world where, among other things, one older motherŠ—Ès lifetime of bigotry can be cured by half an afternoon spent with a mixed-race child.

The movie, a goopy, glossy mess with 10 times more respect for contrived sentimentality than for film grammar, is bereft of genuinely amusing jokes Š—” Mr. Marshall really had some nerve naming his autobiography Š—“Wake Me When ItŠ—Ès Funny.Š— Which is not to say the film lacks entertainment value. ThereŠ—Ès unusual imagery, in the form of Ms. RobertsŠ—Ès recycled wig. (Perhaps she had hoped to pass for a Julia Roberts impersonator.) ThereŠ—Ès suspense, as when Jason Sudeikis, playing a single dad, sings Š—“The Humpty DanceŠ— for a roomful of children, and you wonder if heŠ—Èll make it to the line Š—“I once got busy in a Burger King bathroom.Š— And there are laughs, albeit inadvertent; the biggest comes courtesy of the productionŠ—Ès no-doubt overworked sound department, when Ms. Robertson utters Š—“I have abandonment issuesŠ— without moving her mouth. GLENN KENNY

The major players in this movie of intertwined story lines include Kate Hudson as a daughter and mom addicted to secrets; Jennifer Aniston as a frazzled divorced mom superirritated by her ex, played by Timothy Olyphant (whoŠ—Ès clearly dying to star in a biopic of Billy Bob Thornton); Julia Roberts as a high-powered childless career woman; and Britt Robertson as a young single mom whoŠ—Ès loath to marry her winsome British boyfriend because of her ambivalence about having been adopted. You will guess, immediately, who her mom turns out to be.
ItŠ—Ès often said that the Irish, blessed with the gift of gab, can be splendid raconteurs. YouŠ—Èll find generous evidence to that effect here. And a bit of poetry as well.

Some passages Š—” descriptions of dance halls, first kisses (Š—“a snoggle in the ditchŠ—), wedding proposals, tearful partings with emigrants to America and with dying spouses Š—” are downright poignant. As for inevitable fate, Ms. Nolan says, Š—“IŠ—Èm looking forward to the hereafter.Š—

Š—“A terrible beauty is born,Š— Yeats wrote in his poem Š—“Easter 1916,Š— about IrelandŠ—Ès fight for independence from the British. But the 30 centenarians facing the camera in Alex FeganŠ—Ès delightful documentary Š—“Older Than IrelandŠ— are simply beautiful: frail, yes, but wise, wry, flinty, funny and sometimes very tender. All were born before the Easter Rising, an event widely celebrated this year that sparked the explosion in patriotism that ultimately led to the founding of the Irish Republic.

The film begins with a gently frivolous tone, to a light piano score. In largely flat, symmetrical compositions, its subjects address questions: How does it feel to be 100? WhatŠ—Ès the secret to longevity? What was school like? (Lots of corporal punishment, apparently.) Then it moves into more haunting recollections: Bessie Nolan, 103, recalls the day of the Easter Rising. Jackie OŠ—ÈSullivan, 102, met the rebels Michael Collins and Eamon de Valera. Among others, Michael OŠ—ÈConnor, 101, and Flann Brennan, 101, describe the vicious predations of the Black and Tans. Jack Powell, 101, remembers the early emergence of the Irish Republican Army.

Jonathan Lim, directing a screenplay by Doc Pedrolie and Victoria Arch, juggles the possibilities pretty well. Is Lily crazy? Is she the victim of an elaborate plot orchestrated by Mitch? Henry Ian Cusick lends a creepy air as a counselor who may or may not have her best interests at heart as he coaxes her to accept the reality she sees.

Lily (the Taiwanese actress Michelle Chen) is a young doctor who is coveted by a fellow physician, Mitch (Sung Kang), but is in a relationship with an elementary-school teacher named Neil (Jackson Rathbone of the Š—“TwilightŠ— movies). After she is in a car crash Š—” the filmŠ—Ès title is a reference to a real stretch of roadway in Hawaii that has a reputation for strange occurrences Š—” she wakes up in an unfamiliar world: She is married to Mitch and has a son, and no one in her life has ever heard of Neil.
Š—“Pali RoadŠ— is a decent romantic thriller with an uncredited co-star: the state of Hawaii, where it was filmed. The acting is on the wooden side, but the scenery is gorgeous.
Š—“Pali RoadŠ— is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for a few scary moments.
NEIL GENZLINGER

A lot of the weight of selling the story falls on Ms. Chen, and sheŠ—Ès not entirely up to the challenge, but Mr. Lim is able to build suspense anyway. The film might have been more interesting had it delved further into the darker possibilities. Mr. Lim, though, ultimately lets romance be the dominant theme Š—” the love we want, the love we missed out on, the love we get Š—” and thereŠ—Ès some satisfaction there.

At first, it strains credulity. In the late 1950s, just as rebellion is smoldering in Cuba, a reporter in Miami is laboring over a letter to his literary idol. Then, before you can say Š—“The Old Man and the Sea,Š— the reporter, Ed Myers (Giovanni Ribisi), is whisked away to Cuba for a fishing trip with his hero, Ernest Hemingway. His adventure begins on a dock as Papa himself floats into view, commanding the flying bridge of his boat like a Roman charioteer.
The film does have its treats beyond the historical and geographic. Be on the lookout for PapaŠ—Ès granddaughter Mariel Hemingway, in white cat-eye specs.

Š—“Papa: Hemingway in CubaŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for what a passing 9-year-old called Š—“too many bare butts in the poolŠ— and low-impact sex, fully under the covers. Running time: 1 hour 46 minutes.

Ultimately, however, Š—“Papa,Š— based on an autobiographical screenplay, goes soft at its center. Adrian Sparks, white-bearded and bearish in the title role, lacks the dynamism and bombast we expect. Ms. Richardson comforts and coaxes and exasperatedly, bitingly demeans, but she and Mr. Sparks play past each other instead of engaging.

Abandoned as a child during the Depression, at Christmas, no less, the Kid, as Hemingway calls Myers, fled the orphanage to seek his journalistic fortune. Now, heŠ—Ès in the right place to cover the revolution between tossing back drinks, learning to land a tuna and lounging on pristine beaches with Hemingway and his fourth wife, Mary (Joely Richardson), who invite him to join the family.

But Bob YariŠ—Ès Š—“Papa: Hemingway in CubaŠ— is more artifact than art. Shot at Finca VigiÕa, the authorŠ—Ès home near Havana, it bristles with authentic detail, down to the very typewriter Hemingway used. That the movie was made at all during the economic embargo was a feat of diplomacy, financial and otherwise.

Other shopworn aspects Š—” RatchetŠ—Ès modest origins as a rocket mechanic who, his boss says, should Š—“dream smallerŠ—; a rapacious antagonist (Paul Giamatti, in sinister-capitalist mode) aided by an oversize thug (Sylvester Stallone) Š—” prompted tired eye rolls, as did the trite motivations and frenetic aerial acrobatics.

Watching the generic computer-animated Š—“Ratchet & Clank,Š— youŠ—Ère flooded with reminders of familiar characters. The hero Ratchet Š—” a lombax, a frisky creature with big ears and eyes, who aspires to join the Galactic Rangers, protectors of the galaxy evoking the Green Lantern Corps Š—” has the small physique and intent expression of an evolved Sonic the Hedgehog. His brainy sidekick, the robotic Clank, resembles a diminutive take on the title character from Š—“The Iron GiantŠ—; his voice could be a bookwormish twist on Marvin the MartianŠ—Ès.

It comes as no surprise that Š—“Ratchet & ClankŠ— is built around a PlayStation video game series that first appeared in 2002. But of course. It has little story to tell and few ideas to offer. Just a great deal of product to sell. ANDY WEBSTER

When Ratchet (voiced by James Arnold Taylor) succeeds in entering the ranks of the Rangers, he finds that the vain bluster of their leader, Captain Qwark (Jim Ward, reproducing Patrick WarburtonŠ—Ès pompous shtick in Š—“The TickŠ—), to be hollow. QwarkŠ—Ès flaws are most evident when the universe is threatened by the evil ex-Ranger Dr. Nefarious (Armin Shimerman), a distant cousin to Will FerrellŠ—Ès villain in Š—“Megamind.Š—
Š—“Ratchet & ClankŠ— is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for Š—” what? Clich’©s?

Š—“Who will survive, and what will be left of them?Š— was the ad tagline for the classic Š—“The Texas Chainsaw Massacre.Š— This movieŠ—Ès might as well be: Š—“Who will survive, and will it be too late for couples counseling?Š—

But when Tora unearths (itŠ—Ès a long story) a suspiciously well-preserved female corpse, with runes carved in its skin and its heart missing, itŠ—Ès time, once again, for revelations of The Evil That Keeps Things So Green and Peaceful Around These Parts. ToraŠ—Ès investigations are countered by protests from unbelieving characters that Š—“ItŠ—Ès the 21st century!Š—

While the line Š—“ItŠ—Ès quiet Š—_ too quietŠ— is never spoken in Š—“Sacrifice,Š— this thriller trades heavily on a hoary genre convention. Directed by Peter A. Dowling, who also adapted the screenplay from Sharon BoltonŠ—Ès novel, the movie features a physician, Tora Hamilton (Radha Mitchell), who moves from New York to the Shetland Islands in Scotland after a miscarriage. Her supportive partner, Duncan (Rupert Graves), hails from there, and with the help of some local residents, they intend to mend their hearts by adopting a baby in this pastoral setting.

IŠ—Ève seen versions of this story so many times that I think of that line from Gerard Manley Hopkins: Š—“Generations have trod, have trod, have trod.Š— DowlingŠ—Ès direction, while competent, also trots out every clich’© that a 90-minute movie can contain. And the movieŠ—Ès withholding of some crucial back story for the final third feels like a bad-faith move.

Judging from Š—“The American Side,Š— detectives who say things like Š—“thatŠ—Ès a gene pool screaming for chlorineŠ— and Š—“thereŠ—Ès a joker in every deckŠ— have spent the past several decades hiding in Buffalo Š—” not an obvious graveyard for the spirits of Raymond Chandler and Mickey Spillane.

There, Charlie Paczynski (Greg Stuhr), a private investigator, has a side racket in blackmail with Kat (Kelsey Siepser), a stripper. When Kat is murdered, Charlie uncovers a mystery that involves enigmatic women (Camilla Belle, Alicja Bachleda), estranged energy magnates (Matthew Broderick, Robert Forster), the unrealized inventions of Nikola Tesla and Š—” seemingly Š—” whatever other character actors (Robert Vaughn, Harris Yulin, Janeane Garofalo) dropped by the set.

The director, Jenna Ricker, who wrote the script with Mr. Stuhr, has made a cinephileŠ—Ès movie, a throwback that delights in homages (to Š—“Kiss Me DeadlyŠ— and Š—“North by Northwest,Š— among others) and an off-kilter sense of period (Charlie is never shown using a cellphone). If the self-consciousness can be charming, it also prevents Š—“The American SideŠ— from becoming fully its own film. The movie plays like an exercise for the cast members, who labor with the stylized dialogue, and for an audience flattered at catching a reference.

The injury becomes the justification for one of those fraught family reunions filled with awkward silences, furious eruptions and hushed huddles. Caleb and Camille have faded, becoming art-history footnotes, but their hold on their children remains. ThatŠ—Ès the story, at any rate, though it takes time to buy that any of these folks are related, partly because the more famous actors overwhelm their roles. In their early scenes together, the recessive Mr. Bateman (heŠ—Ès an actor against which other actors bounce) and the industrious Ms. Kidman (you can see her working even when she goes blank) come across as two people whoŠ—Ève just met. ItŠ—Ès especially implausible that their quirky yet bland characters could have sprung from the loins of an extraterrestrial like Mr. Walken.

Š—“The Family Fang,Š— adapted from the Kevin Wilson novel, with a script by David Lindsay-Abaire, tells the story of another unhappy family. It turns on siblings, Annie (Nicole Kidman) and Baxter (Jason Bateman, who also directed), raised by wolves. Specifically, Caleb (Christopher Walken) and Camille (Maryann Plunkett), performance artists who once upon a time used their children in improvised public events. For Caleb and Camille Š—” who referred to their kids as Child A and Child B Š—” art came before everything, including health and safety. For years, the children smilingly played along. They were good little actors; they were also just artistic material, like clay.

The drama of the gifted child is, at least in movies, a gift that keeps on giving. ThatŠ—Ès particularly true in American independent cinema, with its stories of suffering children, monstrous mothers and abusive fathers. There are moments when it feels as if the movie youŠ—Ère watching was written on a laptop propped up by a Syd Field screenwriting book and Š—“The Drama of the Gifted Child,Š— Alice MillerŠ—Ès 1979 book about children and parental narcissism. Act 1: Set up the wound. Act 2: Confront the wound. Act 3: Resolve the wound.
Š—“The Family FangŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Adult language. Running time: 1 hour 47 minutes.

By the time the children are grown, the family dynamic has shifted in obvious and oblique ways. Annie and Baxter keep their physical distance from their parents. But the ties that bind body and soul are hard to cut, and the siblings are still playing supporting roles and still not in control of their lives. Annie is an actress seemingly on a downward spiral who, while shooting a movie, is resisting pressure to appear topless. Baxter is trying and failing to finish a second novel. Reluctantly, he takes a magazine assignment to write about war veterans, a gig that leads to a drunken, woodsy bacchanal with potato guns and lands him in a hospital with a head injury.

Everything shifts in a dinner scene when the family relations emerge with geometric clarity: the charming, domineering father whoŠ—Ès oblivious to the nervously accommodating mother and the exasperated, haplessly stuck adult children. Mr. BatemanŠ—Ès direction of the actors is especially sensitive in this and other tricky scenes, showing a delicacy with emotional textures that isnŠ—Èt always matched by the story, especially when Annie and Baxter speak in therapeutic clich’©s. Thankfully, most of these spill out late after the story has jumped around in time, toggling between the present and flashbacks to Caleb and CamilleŠ—Ès happenings (Jason Butler Harner and Kathryn Hahn play the younger versions). Those scenes expose the dangers of their performances but also the thrill. The tragedy isnŠ—Èt that Caleb and Camille canŠ—Èt tell the difference between art and life, but that they could make only one seem important.
Š—“The Man Who Knew InfinityŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for thematic elements and smoking.

ItŠ—Ès time for Dev Patel to add fresh paints to his palette. This talented actor Š—” who got his feature start in Danny BoyleŠ—Ès Š—“Slumdog MillionaireŠ— Š—” has largely specialized in handsome, earnest and well-meaning characters (in both Š—“Best Exotic Marigold HotelŠ— movies and the canceled HBO series Š—“The NewsroomŠ—). Now comes Š—“The Man Who Knew Infinity,Š— Matthew BrownŠ—Ès respectful and, yes, earnest biopic about the early-20th-century mathematician Srinivasa Ramanujan, who found the divine in integers. Ramanujan, who was mentored by the Cambridge professor G. H. Hardy, eventually became the first Indian to hold a fellowship at Trinity College.

Tidy production values are present (Cambridge locations lend verisimilitude), as is a convenient historical omission (specifically, the real Mr. RamanujanŠ—Ès marriage to a 10-year-old girl when he was 21). Mr. Irons handily hits the emotional beats, as does Mr. Patel, as Ramanujan confronts incipient tuberculosis. But perhaps Mr. Patel is now ready to try his hand at a sinner, not a saint.

We first meet the young, married Ramanujan in a temple in Madras (now Chennai) in India, scrawling mathematical notations like a man possessed. Despite the skepticism of his British boss (a haughty Stephen Fry, barely seen), Ramanujan contacts Hardy (Jeremy Irons) at Trinity with his ideas. And soon he leaves his wife and mother for England. Initially resistant to proofs, he eventually delivers the goods Š—” which yield, among other things, discoveries in the partition of numbers Š—” defying Cambridge bigots and warming the heart of the clinical, atheistic Hardy, as well as those of the scholars Bertrand Russell (Jeremy Northam) and J. E. Littlewood (Toby Jones).

Martine Stonehouse and John Gelmon both have AspergerŠ—Ès syndrome and met at events organized by an autism center in Toronto. They soon fell in love. To JohnŠ—Ès surprise, Martine revealed that she was born as a man but has long lived as, and felt as if she were, a woman. John, who identifies as straight, doesnŠ—Èt want to marry Martine until she has genital reassignment surgery.

While the film looks at their daily trials Š—” John is also dealing with TouretteŠ—Ès syndrome, and Martine is battling obesity Š—” the majority of Š—“TransfixedŠ— follows Martine as she prepares for the operation, and as she experiences problems before and after the procedure.

Alon Kol, the director, captures the inherent isolation of those who arenŠ—Èt easily accepted by the world and who have spent a lot of time being perplexed by life. For sure, there are plenty of humorous moments here. But that underlying sadness is the most affecting aspect of the film. Even though Martine and John are capable adults, you find yourself wanting to encourage them on their journey, and also to remind them that itŠ—Ès O.K. to feel sad sometimes. In fact, itŠ—Ès normal.

Somewhere in Hollywood, a studio executive is probably already looking at this tale with an eye on adapting it for a quirky comedy or a faux-provocative romance. But this documentary is compelling enough without adding false drama. These are just two people trying to overcome their obstacles and lead simple lives.

The new mother, Boryana (Irmena Chichikova), shares a privacy-free flat with her sweet beau (Dimo Dimov) and her own mother (Mariana Krumova). Life changes when the infant, Viktoria, is declared Š—“baby of the decadeŠ— by the state. The girl (played by Daria and Kalina Vitkova, nieces of the director) is spoiled by gifts from BulgariaŠ—Ès president (Georgi Spasov). But despite this good fortune, BoryanaŠ—Ès expressions range from sullen to despondent to listless. When it comes to being a mother, she would rather not.

Archival montages and time jumps underline the historic changes that the spunky Viktoria and her disconnected family live through, including the fall of the PeopleŠ—Ès Republic of Bulgaria in 1990. Ms. Vitkova stages amusingly absurd scenarios and showy compositions goosed with portentous motifs (milk, cords, slowly spreading blood).

Eastern Bloc decrepitude has rarely looked as lovely as it does in Maya VitkovaŠ—Ès Š—“Viktoria,Š— an offbeat allegorical satire that devolves into a cinematographer show reel. Shot in extra-wide screen by Krum Rodriguez, its story begins at the dawn of the 1980s in Bulgaria, where a girl is born without a bellybutton to a morose young woman against the backdrop of an infantilizing government.

But the film Š—” which runs around two and a half hours Š—” is meager dramatically, and the ageless Boryana seems to be perpetually modeling for a depressive magazine spread. Outside of comic bits, Ms. Vitkova is often too restrained in directing her actors.

Jesus, whose mother is dead and whose father abandoned him, lives in a slum, and is watched over by the clubŠ—Ès tough but caring star, an aging drag queen known as Mama (Luis Alberto Garc’_a). Complicating JesusŠ—Ès precarious existence is the sudden reappearance of his father, Angel (Jorge Perugorr’_a), a former boxer released from prison who likes his rum and is rumored to have killed a man. AngelŠ—Ès initial reaction to his sonŠ—Ès homosexuality and fondness for drag is all too predictable: He punches him in the face.

Best of all is Mr. MedinaŠ—Ès lovable Jesus, who is androgynous without the usual clich’©d drag-queen mannerisms. Viva is his stage name. He is also a terrific dancer who, given the chance to perform, displays the charisma of a natural star.

Unlike other macho father-gay son dramas, Š—“VivaŠ— doesnŠ—Èt amplify AngelŠ—Ès hostility to tell a prolonged tale of persecution and liberation. That spasm of violence is more a reflex than an expression of deep hatred.

Š—“VivaŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for strong language, sexual content and brief graphic nudity. In Spanish, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 40 minutes.

Mark OŠ—ÈHalloranŠ—Ès screenplay humanizes the characters to the degree that their relationships assume a dimension well beyond the shallow stereotypes often found in fraught dramas about sexuality and family conflict. Mr. Perugorr’_aŠ—Ès Angel, for instance, is a sad wreck of a man who has lived by a code that has begun to fail him. He doesnŠ—Èt know any other way to be than to put on a brave front.

An exhilarating hybrid of Social Realism and feel-good aspirational entertainment, Paddy BreathnachŠ—Ès Š—“VivaŠ— is an oddity by its very pedigree: an Irish movie set in Havana, where it was filmed with a keen eye to that cityŠ—Ès dinginess in tropical light. It infuses a too-familiar story with so much heart that you surrender to its charm and forgive it for being unabashedly formulaic. Even its one big plot twist is hardly a surprise. At the same time, its portrait of Havana, an impoverished city of crumbling architecture, has a gritty neorealist pungency.
Luis Alberto Garc’_aŠ—Ès portrayal of Mama, who offers to shelter Angel, if necessary, infuses new life into the stereotype of the tough drag-queen survivor.

Angel, who is falling apart physically, is filled with regret about how he has led his life. Without asking, he moves in with Jesus and adopts an attitude of paternal authority. But his machismo is more pathetic than threatening. Instead of cowering before his father, Jesus stands up for himself. Sweet-natured, he is helpful and nurturing and they form a edgy bond.

Its hero, Jesus (H’©ctor Medina), is a gay hairdresser who dreams of becoming a drag entertainer at the nightclub where he coifs the noisy, squabbling divas. To make ends meet, this slim, handsome young man with plucked eyebrows moonlights as a hustler along with his friends. The one brief clip that shows him having sex with a client makes clear that it is grueling, humiliating work.

Early in Š—“Baaghi,Š— a Bollywood action movie with the usual grab bag of romance, comedy and drama, Ronny (Tiger Shroff, son of the Š—È80s star Jackie Shroff) shows up at a martial arts academy in Kerala.
