In time, she also picks up their language: She pierces her ears, wears nail polish and flashes a smile. The drill that the Lionesses practice is part joyous self-expression, part ritualistic bluff, which makes it a perfect manifestation of adolescence.
Š—“The FitsŠ— is not rated, i.e. suitable for all ages. Running time: 1 hour 12 minutes.

The film is not remotely interested in the ethical issues surrounding fetal tissue and its use in medical research. Its primary goal is to trumpet success stories Š—” patients with ParkinsonŠ—Ès disease, cystic fibrosis, debilitating pain and other conditions Š—” who say their symptoms largely vanished after receiving fetal-tissue injections. There is a lot of footage showing these patients golfing, bowling, crewing, piano playing. At times the film looks like an advertisement for an active-lifestyle time share complex. Really itŠ—Ès an advertisement for Stem Cell of America, which markets stem-cell therapies, and cooperated with the filmmakers.
Maybe. That and all the other subjects raised here deserve a more thoughtful examination than this film provides.

Š—“The God Cells,Š— a one-sided documentary advocating fetal stem cell injections, is short on credibility but long on stories about the miraculous reversals of catastrophic medical conditions. That will make it catnip for people who are desperate for help for themselves or a sick child.

The film, awkward and amateurish, is by Eric Merola, and at least itŠ—Ès useful in explaining the differences among the various types of stem cells that are being explored for medical treatments. This film concerns those cells derived from aborted fetuses. The idea of using stem cells from abortions has been a hot-button issue in the United States for years, but these cells are being used at clinics in Mexico and elsewhere to treat various conditions.

Missing are any nonsuccess stories, as well as details of procedures, costs and research methods. The film also makes vague accusations that Š—“Big PharmaŠ— is really behind the limitations placed on research and treatment in the United States, since the miracle cures of stem-cell injections would mean no one would need to buy drug companiesŠ—È expensive products.

Filmed on five continents, Š—“Time to ChooseŠ— is divided into three chapters: coal and electricity, oil and gas, and land and food. Hopscotching from country to country, it begins in the United States with scenes of mountaintop removal mining in Appalachia and its destructive environmental effects. Much of the filmŠ—Ès power derives from devastating visual juxtapositions. The glamorous skyline of Shanghai at night is contrasted with daytime images of its smoggy harbor, crowded with ships carrying coal to fuel ChinaŠ—Ès insatiable energy appetite.

Somewhat surprisingly, Mr. FergusonŠ—Ès two previous documentaries Š—” Š—“No End in Sight,Š— about the American occupation of Iraq, and Š—“Inside Job,Š— about the global financial crisis of 2007-8 Š—” were grimmer than Š—“Time to Choose,Š— which spends roughly half its time examining the rapid growth of clean-energy technology. Its development and improvement have lowered production costs so dramatically that solar and wind power are becoming competitive with fossil fuels.

Charles FergusonŠ—Ès latest documentary, Š—“Time to Choose,Š— is a sobering polemic about global warming that balances familiar predictions of planetary doom with a survey of innovations in renewable energy technology that hold out some hope for the future. Unless the carbon-based energy sources on which we have relied are replaced with solar and wind power (the movie doesnŠ—Èt address nuclear energy), we are ruined.
Š—“Time to ChooseŠ— is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 46 minutes.
The biggest obstacle to change may be peopleŠ—Ès assumptions that global warming is beyond human intervention.

Facts and figures are spewed, and graphics are shown to illustrate the filmŠ—Ès life-or-death view of climate change. Images of the Niger Delta, polluted by international oil companies that have turned Nigeria into a corrupt petro-state, are, in a word, hellish.

The fossil fuel industry and its advocates are seen as the enemy in a David and Goliath battle, and they are not giving up without a fight. The corporate leaders Mr. Ferguson invited to appear in the film all turned him down. Apocalyptic in their foreboding, the images of environmental despoliation Š—” especially in China, Nigeria, Brazil and Indonesia Š—” are more powerful than any words voiced by the filmŠ—Ès soft-spoken narrator, Oscar Isaac.

In the language of Mary Nichols, chairwoman of the California Air Resources Board, who works closely with Gov. Jerry Brown of California, one of the filmŠ—Ès heroes: Š—“First people deny that theyŠ—Ère part of the problem. Then they deny thereŠ—Ès a solution. Then they tell you that if there is a solution, itŠ—Ès too expensive.Š—

Will Arnett is back, and game, as AprilŠ—Ès unctuous former colleague. Newbies include an amiable Stephen Amell as a hockey-stick-wielding good guy, Tyler Perry as a mad scientist and the great Laura Linney. Ms. Linney plays a police captain, and sometimes smirks as if enjoying a joke nobody in the audience has been let in on, at least not explicitly.

Š—“Out of the ShadowsŠ— finds the named-for-Renaissance-artists protagonists contending with both an apocalyptic villain from another dimension and an existential crisis (that is, what does it mean to be normal when you are a mutated superpowered turtle?). This movie is, it happens, easier to sit through than the 2014 film. The 3-D action, overseen by the director Dave Green, is not wholly incoherent. The production values (showcasing new mutants and many gear-heavy extra-dimensional machines undreamed of in any actual engineering philosophy) are ultrashiny. And there are even a couple of amusing, albeit unmemorable, sight gags and one-liners.
Š—“Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the ShadowsŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for language, violence and other ways of not thinking of the children.

In the new movie, April, played again by the attractive, pouty Megan Fox, does not hesitate, in the first 10 minutes, to use her sexuality to extract data from two men. She even concocts a sort of schoolgirl outfit to get close to a target. Apparently, the one note that todayŠ—Ès studio executives will not give to filmmakers is, Š—“Think of the children.Š—

In 2014Š—Ès Š—“Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles,Š— the title characters, on meeting the journalist April OŠ—ÈNeil, comment with aggressive enthusiasm on her good looks. They subsequently learn that April cared for them when they were just regular turtles, and, hence, is kind of like a big sister. At that point, a viewer might expect the fellows to stop hitting on her, but this reboot of the whimsical superhero franchise is partially produced by Michael Bay, so, no.

It is unusual for horror movies to run well over two hours, as Š—“The WailingŠ— does. This isnŠ—Èt just because this writer-director likes to stuff his films with incident. He wants to both settle in viewers and throw them off a bit.

Š—“The WailingŠ— is an expansive and often excruciating horror film from South Korea. It is the work of the director Na Hong-jin, whose 2009 debut feature, the action thriller  Š—“The Chaser,Š— made a huge impression not least for its almost staggering flouting of genre convention. Š—“The Wailing,Š— about demonic possession, is similarly uncompromising.

Things turn more serious once Jong-gu links a wave of crime and physical illness to a taciturn Japanese man who lives in a house high on a mountaintop, and more serious still after Jong-guŠ—Ès daughter (Kim Hwan-hee, in an extraordinary performance) develops a rash and starts using obscene language. Š—“The WailingŠ— has echoes of Š—“The Exorcist,Š— but it is often even bleaker than that 1973 horror classic, as in a scene in which a Catholic priest tells Jong-gu, Š—“The church cannot help you.Š— By this time, I was so invested with Jong-gu and his family that as the suspense, violence and worse ratcheted up, I was not merely scared, but heartbroken. An overly literal bit of business at the end slightly undermines the film. As a whole, though, Š—“The WailingŠ— is the hard stuff. Handle with care.

The movie opens with a police sergeant, Jong-gu (Kwak Do-won), investigating a double murder in his quiet, rural village. The crime is grisly, but Jong-gu is an amiable, likable fellow; his endearing personality gives the first quarter of the film a comic underpinning. Mr. Na enjoys overt directorial misdirection as well; early on, the scenes that end with Jong-gu waking in a panic from a bad dream are numerous enough to remind one of Luis Bu’±uelŠ—Ès Š—“The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie.Š—

Mr. Genovese, now a grandfather, assiduously digs up many sources, including Queens residents nearby that night (and who dispute aspects of The TimesŠ—Ès reporting) and a minister who is the son of Winston Moseley, Ms. GenoveseŠ—Ès killer. A. M. Rosenthal, the editor of The Times who was behind the article, defends it in an interview with Mr. Genovese. (Mr. Rosenthal died in 2006; The Times reconsidered its account in 1995 and 2004.) One compelling voice is Mary Ann Zielonko, Ms. GenoveseŠ—Ès companion, who was ostracized by the Genoveses after the death. A Š—“RashomonŠ— emerges: questionable reporting, widely disseminated, based on police claims; an outlandish alternate history that Mr. Moseley, who died this March, sent Mr. Genovese from prison; a neighbor who recalls holding Ms. Genovese in her final moments.

In March 1964, the fatal stabbing in Kew Gardens, Queens, of 28-year-old Catherine Genovese, known as Kitty, caused international outrage. A front-page article in The New York Times at the time said 38 people had witnessed her murder and failed to act, embodiments of urban indifference. Now James SolomonŠ—Ès seamless documentary, Š—“The Witness,Š— traces the yearslong efforts of Ms. GenoveseŠ—Ès younger brother Bill, who was close to Kitty, to get to the bottom of what actually happened.

Ultimately, the murder is eclipsed by Mr. GenoveseŠ—Ès own struggles Š—” how his obsession exasperates family members, and how the perceived public apathy inspired him to fight in Vietnam, where he lost his legs. A re-creation of the night, with an actress playing the screaming victim while Mr. Genovese observes, is harrowing. You pray he has at last found peace.

Using neither narration nor an inch of original footage, Mr. Andersen skips across time and genre with a blitheness that suggests heŠ—Ès playing a game as much as laying out a schema. DeleuzeŠ—Ès theories might be denser than London fog, but Mr. AndersenŠ—Ès disinclination to elaborate Š—” at least with words Š—” allows his images to breathe. This absence of stuffiness means that, while Š—“ThoughtsŠ— might have a natural home in the academy, it should play equally well in the high street. Its emphasis on movement and emotion, music and humor, reminds us repeatedly that when the lights go down, the heart lifts.

Meaning plays hide-and-seek with montage in Š—“The Thoughts That Once We Had,Š— Thom AndersenŠ—Ès deeply personal, cheekily digressive dance through most of movie history. Yet this by turns transporting, brow-furrowing, nostalgic and obtuse visual essay Š—” inspired in part by the writings of the French philosopher Gilles Deleuze Š—” never feels overwhelming. Even if you donŠ—Èt recognize the majority of the unidentified clips assembled here, or the quotations that divide and guide them, the fascination they exert is all their own.

Yet for all its lightness and whimsy, this compendium of movie memories argues insistently for reverence. How can we not be in awe of a medium that can take a single moment, like a beautiful young woman walking away from the camera, and make us wish that it would never end?

Fabulously expressive faces and bodies Š—” Jeanne Moreau and Molly Ringwald, Gena Rowlands and Mary Pickford Š—” drift and writhe across the screen. Delightful clips of Chubby Checker performing Š—“The Twist,Š— and Maria Montez and Debra Paget, 15 years apart, seducing extras with saucy snake-charming dances, make Š—“ThoughtsŠ— sometimes seem less a love letter than a winking titillation.

The movieŠ—Ès simulation of 1930s Tianjin, then as now a bustling coastal metropolis in China with a strong Western presence, isnŠ—Èt exactly convincing, but it sets a sufficiently varied stage for the movieŠ—Ès action. Š—“The Final MasterŠ— finds Chen (Liao Fan), a vital maestro of the wing chun style of fighting and defense, hoping to establish an academy in the cityŠ—Ès already crowded scene. He consults a grand old man (Chin Shih-Chieh), negotiates for a wife (Song Jia) and discovers an apprentice (Song Yang). Once the apprentice has served his purpose, Chen intends to allow the acolyte to be banished (or worse) by TianjinŠ—Ès powers that be. But the kidŠ—Ès got too much heart, as they used to say in Hollywood boxing movies, and Chen canŠ—Èt betray him with a clean conscience.

Mr. XuŠ—Ès extremely abrupt storytelling style, the way his scenario leans on martial arts traditions and cultural referents without much audience hand-holding, and the pileup of stratagems and betrayals make the movie a bit tough to follow. Still, the characters and the actors playing them are appealing, and the fight scenes have a lot of moxie, not to mention a lot of steel-slinging. Hefty daggers, staggering broadswords and even battle axes are unsheathed and duly deployed throughout. Even the bare-fisted action is accompanied with metal-clanging sound effects, which are ridiculous, but do contribute to the filmŠ—Ès snappy feel, as does An WeiŠ—Ès anachronistic electric-organ-heavy score.

Xu Haofeng, the screenwriter of Wong Kar-waiŠ—Ès 2013 film, Š—“The Grandmaster,Š— adapts his own short story for this not-necessarily-for-novices martial arts tale. Like Š—“The Grandmaster,Š— Š—“The Final MasterŠ— is about the world of martial arts in the early 20th century, a transitional time not just for fighting styles but also for Asia itself.

The unlikely friendship that develops between Armando and Elder seems based on ArmandoŠ—Ès financial largess. But when Armando writes a check for Elder to refurbish a junkyard vehicle, the young man softens. Elder confesses that his father, now dead, used to beat him to teach him the cruelty of the world.

Long-distance shots are used to convey ArmandoŠ—Ès chilly vigilance. He is frequently filmed with only one eye visible, as if he were a voyeur, peeking through a keyhole. The closest thing to warmth he exhibits, even when attending a birthday party at which he meets ElderŠ—Ès mother, is a tight, wary half-smile. At moments, he is practically a dead ringer for Martin Short in a grim mode.

Š—“From AfarŠ— initially appears to be a docudrama about furtive gay desire in a Latin American culture with a powerful taboo against homosexuality. But ArmandoŠ—Ès next encounter with another young man, Elder (Luis Silva), is more complicated and evolves into a diabolical power struggle in which Armando is beaten up, verbally abused and robbed. The stoical Armando accepts these punishments as inevitable risks and hardly seems to mind; he might even like them.

In some ways, Š—“From AfarŠ— recalls Robin CampilloŠ—Ès 2013 film, Š—“Eastern Boys,Š— in which a lonely gay Frenchman becomes the kindly protector of a homeless Ukrainian hustler he picks up outside a Paris train station. Armando is not as softhearted. Although his friendship with Elder seems about to melt into something deeper, the relationship, at least on ArmandoŠ—Ès part, remains a power game through the final shot. In withholding biographical information about the characters, the movie supplies just enough material to prompt you to fill in the blanks.

Yet Š—“From AfarŠ— musters enough compassion to suggest the degree to which homophobia and rejection have shaped ArmandoŠ—Ès cynical view of life in a violent, anti-gay environment. Scenes of Armando drilling dentures make you think of mouths, and the images of two sets of prosthetics, one being repaired, the other a loathsome facsimile of rotten teeth, are played off against shots of ElderŠ—Ès voluptuously puffy lips.
Š—“From AfarŠ— never lets you relax and heave a sigh of relief in hopes that a happy ending may be in sight. Reality is too cruel for that.

The masterly feature debut of the Venezuelan filmmaker Lorenzo Vigas, the movie looks at the world through the icy stare of Armando, who is first seen cruising and picking out his prey. He sidles up behind the young man without speaking or making eye contact. Following him onto a bus, Armando takes an adjacent seat and signals his intentions by flourishing a wad of cash. The young man who ends up in his apartment is instructed to take off his shirt and pull down his pants while Armando masturbates, and thatŠ—Ès the extent of their connection.

Armando is also alienated from his father (seen briefly and from a distance), who he says he wishes were dead for reasons that are never given, but they are easy to imagine. That father has just returned to Caracas (from where it is not said) after a long absence. These fractured father-son relationships become the closest thing to a bond between Armando and Elder, who na’Àvely begins to regard Armando as a surrogate father and lowers his guard.

The term Š—“chicken hawk,Š— applied to older gay men who seek sexual favors from boys in their late teens and early 20s, isnŠ—Èt heard much nowadays, nor is Š—“rough tradeŠ— used anymore to describe the street youths the men pay for play. But in Š—“From Afar,Š— those labels apply to Armando (the brilliant 60-year-old Chilean star Alfredo Castro), a dead-eyed dental prosthetist living in Caracas, Venezuela, and to the hostile young roustabouts he picks up on a corner.

After Elder is seen kissing Armando in a desperate, pathetic plea for affection, to which Armando barely responds, ElderŠ—Ès friends shun him, and he has nowhere to turn. Caracas, as seen in the film, is seedy and ominous, although not nearly as run-down as it is today, amid VenezuelaŠ—Ès collapsing economy.
Š—“From AfarŠ— is not rated. It is in Spanish, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 33 minutes.
And when a patient leaves, a friend sends him off with advice that seems like an imperative to the viewer: Š—“DonŠ—Èt forget about us.Š—

But just as the movie is setting itself up as a modern Š—“Titicut FolliesŠ— Š—” Frederick WisemanŠ—Ès classic 1967 documentary about a hospital for the criminally insane Š—” Š—“Š—ÈTil Madness Do Us PartŠ— begins to locate gleams of humanity amid the squalor. A longtime resident says, Š—“In here, a man can eat and sit, sleep if he can, and no one bothers him.Š— Romance blossoms, and there are fireworks to ring in a new year. The visiting daughter of a new arrival permits another inmate to use her cellphone.

Š—“Š—ÈTil Madness Do Us PartŠ— takes place almost entirely on a single floor of a mental hospital in southwestern China, though you might initially be forgiven for thinking that the director, the documentarian Wang Bing (Š—“Tie Xi Qu: West of TracksŠ—), had discovered hell on earth.
Š—“Š—ÈTil Madness Do Us PartŠ— is not rated. It is in Yunnan dialect and Mandarin, with English subtitles. Running time: 3 hours 48 minutes.

This overlong (nearly four hours) but sporadically extraordinary portrait of a forgotten corner of society may be tough going even for fans of forbidding cinema. Mr. Wang, who shot the movie in 2013, spends inordinate time acclimating viewers to the space and its inhabitantsŠ—È rituals. He seems to have favored shots in which the subjects, committed for reasons ranging from the criminal to the arguably nonexistent, ignore the camera Š—” a strategy that raises questions about how the filmmaker was received.

The walls are riddled with scuff marks, graffiti and dirt. The patients Š—” inmates? Š—” go about their routines with varying degrees of lucidity, urinating in public spaces or taking their medicine in near total darkness. The outdoor hallways, which overlook a courtyard, resemble giant cages. One man, a recent addition who runs laps around the galleries unimpeded, emphasizes the point: Š—“Might as well slaughter me now, like a chicken or a cow.Š—

During his time among the common folk, Jordan is not above employing his celebrity to confound EmilyŠ—Ès judgmental peers or, in one instance, flaunting his wealth to prove his devotion. The audience erupted with deafening delight. ANDY WEBSTER

What, you havenŠ—Èt heard of Matthew Espinosa? Nor had I, until I sat in a theater full of screaming, giggling teenage girls ardently anticipating a screening of Š—“Be Somebody,Š— Mr. EspinosaŠ—Ès innocuous first feature, directed by Joshua Caldwell. Mr. Espinosa, not quite 19, is a nonsinging Justin Bieber look-alike and a Magcon boy. What, you donŠ—Èt know the Magcon boys? TheyŠ—Ère young social media stars, best known through Vine, who make harmless videos and attract the aforementioned vocal legion of admirers. The Japanese have a term for a certain type of character in manga (comic books) and anime: bishonen Š—” pubescent in appearance, devoid of facial hair, sensitive, unthreatening. That would be Mr. Espinosa.
Š—“Be SomebodyŠ— is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested), presumably for a brief, dismissive reference to Š—“getting wasted.Š—

Here he plays Jordan Jaye, a pop singer suffocating under the demands of his manager-mom, publicist and other handlers. Going AWOL from his tour, armed with only his hoodie and skateboard, he meets Emily (Sarah Jeffery), a high-school art student aiming for a New York career. Emily provides a refuge from voracious mean-girl fans and shows him small-town teenage life. They bowl, and discuss creativity, Banksy (O.K., thatŠ—Ès impressive), trusting your instincts and taking chances. He says Š—“heckŠ— instead of Š—“hell,Š— and gets along fabulously with EmilyŠ—Ès parents. (Š—“IŠ—Èm a parent kind of guy.Š—) And the two spend a night spray-painting images and an inspirational message on the walls of EmilyŠ—Ès high school, before he rejoins his tour.

But the film is an emotional black hole, its insufferably smug tricksters augmented by Mr. Harrelson Š—” wearing too many teeth and a wig reminiscent of Š—“DonŠ—Èt Look NowŠ—-era Donald Sutherland Š—” as his characterŠ—Ès identical twin. They never let us forget that their chief superpowers are glibness and ego.

The main sleight-of-hand at play in the illusion-themed sequel, Š—“Now You See Me 2,Š— will be convincing audiences that a single oddball idea Š—” and four bickering, bragging leads Š—” can support a successful franchise. And while the first movie had a certain goofy charm, its appeal barely stretched to feature length. This time the director, Louis Leterrier, has been replaced by Jon M. Chu, who, with Š—“G.I. Joe: RetaliationŠ— (2013), has proved himself more than comfortable with noise and nonsense.
Š—“Now You See Me 2Š— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). One bra, two beheadings and an avalanche of boasting.

Technology might be the enemy of the plot, but itŠ—Ès the best friend of a movie that bounces from New York to Macau and from one stupendously slick stunt to another. Everything is supersized and preposterous, but Mr. Chu, with two films in the Š—“Step UpŠ— franchise under his belt, is undaunted by crowds and confusion. As is Peter DemingŠ—Ès cinematography, which uses speed and shadow to blur the ludicrousness of the cons and fake-outs.

And this cartoonish movie has plenty of both. A brief recap reminds us that the so-called Four Horsemen Š—” Las Vegas magicians played by Woody Harrelson, Dave Franco, Jesse Eisenberg and Lizzy Caplan (replacing Isla Fisher as the token she-geek) Š—” are lying low after robbing a casino in Paris. Called out of hiding by their handler-cum-F.B.I. agent (an essential Mark Ruffalo), our prestidigitators must steal a tech doodad that can control all the worldŠ—Ès computers.

The movie is the work of Ms. ApplebroogŠ—Ès daughter, Beth B, the onetime underground filmmaker who emerged out of New YorkŠ—Ès punk music and art scene in the late 1970s. Ms. B opens the movie with Ms. ApplebroogŠ—Ès recollections of her early childhood in the Bronx. The daughter of Orthodox Jewish immigrants, she was raised in a strictly religious household and told she Š—“should not behave like the Yankees,Š— meaning the Americans around her. Š—“I learned very early on,Š— Ms. Applebroog insists, Š—“how power works.Š—

In one sequence with her daughter, Ms. Applebroog becomes tense when asked to reflect on her past journals. Later she tells a studio colleague, Š—“YouŠ—Ère gonna get me into one of my fits.Š— When Ms. Applebroog opts to recollect her painful past, itŠ—Ès on her own terms, and her daughter declines to press too hard. Beth B is not out to deliver a comprehensive biography. Instead, she achieves a vivid snapshot of a still-vital artist late in a still-purposeful life.

Her art addresses that theme, and others, but her work, often multimedia, is layered in ways that make it more complicated, and arguably more rewarding, than more baldly confrontational contemporary art. Beth B shows her motherŠ—Ès work in some detail, punctuating these views with shots of the artist, who is now in her mid-80s, archiving her work and speaking with gallerists. Sometimes she gets around with a cane or walker, and sometimes she uses a scooter. In every other respect she gives no indication of frailty, speaking in an emphatic voice and engaging colleagues with a fierce alertness.

Š—“Call Her Applebroog,Š— a brief feature about the inventive, provocative artist Ida Applebroog, is less a documentary than a love letter. A love letter that conveys its affection and respect via a particular kind of discretion.

Nick Jonas, who is 23, made a convincing college student in the television series Š—“Scream QueensŠ— last season, but he makes an exceedingly unconvincing high school student in the wretched Š—“Careful What You Wish For,Š— a film that tries to be both titillating and suspenseful but is neither.

He plays Doug, who settles in for a summer on the lake with his parents and stumbles into a teenage boyŠ—Ès fantasy: The gorgeous married woman next door, Lena (Isabel Lucas), relieves him of his virginity. Doug is too na’Àve to entertain the possibility that she is merely using him to escape her abusive, heavy-drinking husband (Dermot Mulroney). That possibility becomes a dark reality when the husband turns up dead, and poor Doug is soon thoroughly tangled in a web of deceit.

The film, written by Chris Frisina and directed by Elizabeth Allen Rosenbaum, is trying for steamy but more often achieves laughable, thanks to numbing dialogue, especially for Ms. Lucas. (Š—“Right now,Š— she heavy-breathes, dragging him off for a quickie in an inappropriate location. Š—“I canŠ—Èt wait.Š—) The movie, with its naughty forbidden-desires story line, seems pitched to the sexy imaginings of teeny-boppers who were fans of the Jonas Brothers, Mr. JonasŠ—Ès boy band, almost a decade ago. But those fans have all grown up now and certainly wouldnŠ—Èt find this comparatively tame, completely predictable movie to be sultry.
Š—“Careful What You Wish ForŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for sexy talk and some beer drinking.

Not that the critics were always kind to Mr. De Palma. While Pauline Kael was an early and mostly steadfast champion, other reviewers objected to the violence and sensationalism of his movies. Audience enthusiasm also ran hot and cold. There were big hits like Š—“Carrie,Š— Š—“Dressed to KillŠ— and Š—“The Untouchables,Š— flops like Š—“Casualties of War,Š— Š—“Bonfire of the VanitiesŠ— and Š—“Mission to Mars.Š— Most of his movies landed in the middle of the popularity bell curve, but a surprising number have lingered in the popular imagination, notably (and to the continued surprise of its director) Š—“Scarface.Š—

Brian De Palma is a devotee of the long take. His oeuvre is a catalog of extended following shots, seamless action sequences and slow-building scenes of intimacy and brutality. So it seems only fitting that Š—“De Palma,Š— an affectionate and absorbing documentary by Noah Baumbach and Jake Paltrow, has the appearance of a single, uninterrupted encounter between camera and subject. Mr. De Palma, dressed in two layers of blue, tells the story of his career with energy and good humor, occasionally interrupted by clips from his own films and some by other directors that are relevant to his work.

Anyone who has seen Š—“ObsessionŠ— or Š—“Dressed to KillŠ— is likely to agree. The structural ingenuity, psychological perversity and visual bravura that characterize Mr. De PalmaŠ—Ès films can all plausibly be called Hitchcockian. But in Š—“De Palma,Š— he discusses, in roughly chronological order, the full range of styles and genres he has explored. (For New Yorkers interested in sampling the fruits of that exploration, the Metrograph in Lower Manhattan is hosting a monthlong retrospective, with 35-millimeter prints of many of the films.)

Š—“De PalmaŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Mr. De PalmaŠ—Ès favorite phrase is Š—“Holy Mackerel,Š— but his movies are full of sex, gore and nudity.  Running time: 1 hour 47 minutes.

Lasting a little less than two hours, Š—“De PalmaŠ— proceeds quickly and nimbly through more than half a century of filmmaking, naturally dwelling on the Š—È70s and Š—È80s, Mr. De PalmaŠ—Ès hectic, heroic decades. His candor and good humor keep things moving, and itŠ—Ès clear that he feels comfortable with his unseen, unheard interlocutors, who are colleagues as well as fans. Some Hollywood dirt is dished, and a few personal matters are touched upon, but the focus remains on the details of moviemaking as an art and a business.

He also was fortunate to find the support and friendship of talented peers like Francis Ford Coppola, George Lucas, Steven Spielberg and Martin Scorsese. Nostalgia for the New Hollywood may be old hat by now, but Mr. De PalmaŠ—Ès recollections are so vivid and warm that ancient war stories seem fresh. ItŠ—Ès hard for even the most determinedly forward-looking film critic to suppress a twinge of generational envy. Forty years ago, we would have been contemplating Š—“Carrie,Š— Š—“JawsŠ— and Š—“Taxi Driver,Š— with the two Š—“GodfatherŠ— movies in the rearview mirror and Š—“Star WarsŠ— on the horizon.

Like any good work of criticism, Š—“De PalmaŠ— will be catnip for passionate fans while also serving as a primer and a goad for the skeptical and the curious. In the 1960s, as a student first at Columbia and then at Sarah Lawrence, Mr. De Palma was drawn not to violence or suspense but to mischievous, countercultural comedy. The first of these is Alfred HitchcockŠ—Ès Š—“Vertigo,Š— which Mr. De Palma, who is now 75, recalls seeing at a New York theater as a teenager. The Hitchcock-De Palma connection is not exactly news, but the juxtaposition of images from both of their works and Mr. De PalmaŠ—Ès specific account of what he learned from the master go far beyond the usual glib critical shorthand. The tension between commercial imperatives and creative ambition is a recurring theme in Mr. De PalmaŠ—Ès career, as it has been for other directors and writers before and since. He holds no grudges Š—” or at least not as many as you might expect Š—” and counts himself lucky to have arrived at a time when the Hollywood system was perhaps uniquely open to risk-taking and personal expression.

Who is this fascinating character with a cunning glint in her eyes who affects a certain hauteur? In the most serious of the many flaws in the screenplay, written by the director and H’©l’åne Zimmer, Madame Lanlaire, for no apparent reason, is suddenly transformed late in the movie from an authoritarian monster into a benign supporter, throwing the film out of balance.

C’©lestine receives several offers to become a prostitute. Wherever she goes, sexual complications follow. Ms. Seydoux holds her own in a lineage of actresses who have played the same role in celebrated screen realizations directed by Jean Renoir (Paulette Goddard in 1946) and Luis Bu’±uel (Jeanne Moreau in 1964). The earlier films are as different from each other as this latest version is from its forerunners. In the funniest scene, C’©lestine witnesses a train inspection during which a prim aristocratic matron is forced to open a jewel case in the presence of other passengers, revealing an anatomically correct dildo.

Mr. Jacquot flouts the sentimental tradition of period costume dramas exemplified by the Š—“Upstairs DownstairsŠ—/Š—“Downton AbbeyŠ— school of historical nostalgia by portraying servitude as a miserable life made more so by the resentment and mutual loathing of the haves and have-nots.

But the focus is Max (Colin Firth) and Tom (Jude Law), a weary study in temperamental contrast. Tom blusters into MaxŠ—Ès office with a yawping Carolina drawl and a manuscript that has been rejected by nearly every other publishing house in New York. There, mildly annoyed by the boisterous play of his many daughters and the amateur theatricals of his wife (Laura Linney), he settles into a closet to continue the manly labor of editing.

At the time, it was Wolfe who laid windy claim to the titular epithet, but history has been kinder to Perkins. A. Scott BergŠ—Ès Perkins biography, which the film cites as its source, is subtitled Š—“Editor of Genius,Š— and the double meaning is clear enough. Š—“GeniusŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Cigarettes and other examples of old-fashioned naughtiness.  Running time: 1 hour 44 minutes.

Well, Mrs. Perkins mostly stays put, except when she takes the girls away on vacation. ItŠ—Ès dispiriting to see a movie about interesting real-life characters reduce them to clich’©s, making them less vivid, less fascinating, less charismatic than they must have been. (ItŠ—Ès also a bit disconcerting, though hardly surprising at this point, to see yet another movie with important figures in American history portrayed by British and Australian actors.) Š—“GeniusŠ— is full of talk about art, life and greatness, but itŠ—Ès only talk.

But the actors can perhaps be forgiven, since they are continually pushed into scenes that seem designed to halt subtlety in its tracks. The most egregious of these Š—” in which Tom drags Max to a sweaty nightclub in Harlem, pontificating on the spontaneous energies of jazz and boogieing with the working girls at the bar Š—” adds a dash of racial condescension to the cocktail.

The result is Š—“Look Homeward, Angel,Š— a best seller and a magnet for critical acclaim at the time that survives mainly as a relic of bygone literary fashion. There is one scene in Š—“GeniusŠ— that captures something of the work that went into transforming WolfeŠ—Ès graphomaniacal effusions into half-readable prose, as Tom and Max amble through the city paring down an overwritten passage sentence by sentence. The rest of the film, directed by Michael Grandage from a screenplay by John Logan, depicts creation via furious montage. Tom stands at the refrigerator scribbling. Max jabs and plucks at pages of typescript. Bourbon and martinis are consumed. Cigarettes are smoked. Women come and go.

Ostensibly a tale of heroic literary creation Š—” of the volatile collaboration between an undisciplined author and his discerning editor Š—” Š—“GeniusŠ— is a dress-up box full of second- and thirdhand notions. Instead, Š—“GeniusŠ— sighs with palpable nostalgia for a supposed golden age of masculine artistic potency and paints the struggle for self-expression in familiar sentimental colors. Mr. FirthŠ—Ès performance is equally broad, even though heŠ—Ès supposed to be the more uptight partner in this bromance. He grimaces and sighs like a vaudeville Puritan.

Š—“When I meet Germans, IŠ—Èm always in the back of my mind, IŠ—Èm thinking, Š—…Well, how do you really feel about Jews?Š—ÈŠ— one woman says at the start. On the run after Jack provoked a bully named Shane, the boys find momentary safety in the bedroom of Harriet (Yainis Ynoa). Š—“IŠ—Èm always trying to figure out, at some level, who I am and how I fit in the world, which I think is something that I share with seven billion other people,Š— Mr. Ma says early in the film. There, a single mother (Frances OŠ—ÈConnor) with four children reported bizarre, violent goings-on in the familyŠ—Ès home. Mr. RuehmŠ—Ès stagy visual choices give the movie a vague theatricality, as do the bare-bones production design and the exaggerated performances, most of which tend to be pitched toward the last row in the house. Š—“Therapy for a VampireŠ— is not rated. In German, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 27 minutes.

The movie takes place in 1932, two years after the publication of FreudŠ—Ès Š—“Civilization and Its Discontents,Š— about the battle between eros and death. Dreams of flying, the real Freud noted, are erection dreams, and the Count has stirred to life.

If the movie fails to do likewise, itŠ—Ès because it has little bite and not nearly enough laughs or thought. (Strangely, it also dodges the coming war.) Š—“TikkunŠ— is not rated. It is in Hebrew and Yiddish, with English subtitles. Running time: two hours.

Mr. SivanŠ—Ès method is to blur the lines between the literal, the fanciful and the metaphorical, so that the actual disemboweling of a steer (Haim-AaronŠ—Ès father works in a kosher slaughterhouse) seems to have the same ontological status as the appearance, in the familyŠ—Ès toilet bowl, of a talking alligator.

As the young manŠ—Ès religious and psychological crisis accelerates, Š—“TikkunŠ— (a Hebrew word with complex theological and moral connotations) grows funnier and darker, without abandoning the empathy that saves it from excessive self-consciousness. Toward the end, the story begins to fray, and Mr. Sivan seems driven to find ever more extreme and provocative images. Haim-AharonŠ—Ès predicament threatens to become preposterous rather than haunting, but there is no denying the filmŠ—Ès uncanny power or its visual discipline. ItŠ—Ès a luminous puzzle with a few pieces missing.

Haim-Aaron (Aharon Traitel, a quietly intense nonprofessional actor) is a yeshiva student who spends his days in prayer and study, or maybe going quietly mad. ItŠ—Ès hard to tell sometimes. And itŠ—Ès also hard for Haim-Aaron or his family to know what to make of his recovery after a household accident that should Š—” or might Š—” have been fatal.

A heady, sometimes headlong blend of fable and nightmare, with overtones of David Lynch and Franz Kafka and arresting wide-screen black-and-white images, Avishai SivanŠ—Ès second feature, Š—“Tikkun,Š— is the latest evidence of the vitality of Israeli cinema, which has recently been moving away from politics-inflected realism in wilder, more allegorical directions. It is set within the insular world of JerusalemŠ—Ès Hasidic Jews, and also in a dream world of the directorŠ—Ès own devising, a place where faith, skepticism and lust entwine in disturbing and surprising ways.

If thereŠ—Ès a mythology here, I missed it, much as I also missed the charm and periodic lightness of TolkienŠ—Ès world, with its hobbits and Shire. Š—“WarcraftŠ— by contrast weighs in as a Hobbesian war of all against all, though it does allow for a little romance and campy winks. It also, more surprisingly, offers some gray-shading, notably with Durotan (Toby Kebbell), an orc chieftain with hands as big as Volkswagen Beetles and a pregnant mate, Draka (Anna Galvin). He has qualms as well as enemies, which surface amid battles and exposition. Stuff happens in one part of this world, and other stuff happens elsewhere: Jaws clench, bodies fall, and scenes oscillate Š—” Š—Ètwas ever thus, genrewise.

There is in this movie, for starters, the visual appeal of those Blutoesque beings, lovingly fabricated and ornamented motion-capture creations who share their name with the creatures that J. R. R. Tolkien called orcs. Tolkien borrowed orc from the Old English, citing Š—“Beowulf,Š— one of the many tales of blood lust and vengeance, heroes and monsters that are woven into the Š—“WarcraftŠ— DNA. The ruler here is King Llane (Dominic Cooper), a rather progressive monarch who fights the invading orcs with a multihued army, a rakish aide-de-camp (Travis Fimmel), a token chick (Paula Patton) and a magical twosome (Ben Foster and Ben Schnetzer).
Š—“WarcraftŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Heads pop like grapes and so forth. Running time: 2 hours 3 minutes.

Mr. Jones doubles down on the action, though without any real shocks (or awe), but he also modestly complicates the question of the monstrous. The orcs in Š—“WarcraftŠ— prove somewhat more psychologically complex than any number of cartoon Hollywood villains Š—” theyŠ—Ère sincere, for one Š—” and theyŠ—Ère generally better company than the king and his crew. It says something about Mr. JonesŠ—Ès choices that he gives Durotan so much screen time and that Mr. Kebbell, with the help of the special-effects wizards, makes good use of that time with a nuanced, moist-eyed turn that evokes old-studio gladiators like Victor Mature. Durotan is a beautiful brute, and all the more human for it.

Even so, despite the incessant clashing and clanging, you can hear the tremulous pulse of a heartbeat. That faint thrumming belongs to Duncan Jones, the director who, against the odds, has mined a watchable movie out of an entertainment franchise that started with a video game and now includes novels, comics and assorted schlock (toys, costumes, a mah-jongg set). That Mr. Jones even factors into this production counts as some kind of actual achievement given that Š—“WarcraftŠ— is such an obvious bid at brand expansion, which may be why no one bothered with an intelligible story. Apparently, branded content (i.e., the characters, their world) was meant to be enough.

Probably the best way to experience Š—“Warcraft,Š— a generally amusing and sometimes visually arresting absurdity, is stoned. If watching the big screen through a cannabis cloud isnŠ—Èt your idea of a good movie time, though, I suggest that you do what I did and just go with the incoherent flow. You may not grasp who the Bluto-like creatures with simian arms and woolly mammoth tusks are or why they seem permanently engorged with rage. But thereŠ—Ès more to movies than narrative coherency, as anyone who has sampled the cinema of Michael Bay or certain art films well knows.

Whether you see more here will depend on your mileage and patience, though moviegoers habituated to he-men (and the perfunctory she) pulverizing one another for 100 or so minutes are likely to have greater tolerance for this diversion than others might. As suggested, trying to figure out whoŠ—Ès doing what to whom and why Š—” or how orcs dress with such huge hands or how they chew steak with those tusks Š—” is often pointless when it comes to spectacles. In cinemaŠ—Ès earliest years, moviegoers thrilled not to stories but what the scholar Tom Gunning calls Š—“the cinema of attractions,Š— with its eye-pummeling shocks and tricks; weŠ—Ère still getting pummeled, story or no.

To get the full Sundance Film Festival experience, you need high altitudes, steady hydration and a diet of convenience store foodstuffs. But for a less robust outing, the IFC Center is hosting a touring program of shorts from this yearŠ—Ès lineup.

Some won awards in January; a few probably played better in Park City, Utah. (Š—“The Procedure,Š— a four-minute flatulence gag, may have seemed funnier at midnight.) Others travel well. Š—“Bacon & GodŠ—Ès WrathŠ— is a documentary portrait of Razie, who, at nearly 90, has always kept kosher. Now a nonbeliever, thanks to what she calls Š—“the Google,Š— she plans to try bacon at a Toronto diner. As this film by Sol Friedman examines what it means to depart from long-held principles, it interweaves RazieŠ—Ès musings with animation and other special effects Š—” most creatively when it reveals that her offscreen interlocutor is a talking pigŠ—Ès head.

Formal ambition doesnŠ—Èt always guarantee results, as in Š—“Thunder Road,Š— a one-take stunt in which a copŠ—Ès mortifying eulogy for his mother reaches its climax with his rendition of the Bruce Springsteen song of the title. Somewhere in the middle are Š—“Affections,Š— in which a young woman, played by the filmŠ—Ès writer and director, Bridey Elliott (of Š—“Fort TildenŠ— and the Bob, Chris and Abby Elliott comic dynasty), tests the fantasy of a new relationship, and Ben PetrieŠ—Ès Š—“Her Friend Adam,Š— in which Grace Glowicki, as a flaky artist, wipes the floor with her director, who plays a jealous boyfriend. Š—“Jungle,Š— in which Senegalese street vendors compete for New York sidewalk space, is a tougher-minded portrait of trust.
For the non-Argentine audience, though, more context would have helped these wonderful songs and dances tell the nationŠ—Ès story.

For Argentina, where rock and pop are much in evidence, and dances developed in cities, like the tango, can seem dominant, the film is perhaps in the same class as the work of Alan Lomax in the United States: It seeks to preserve traditions and educate about them. There is a nationalistic component to this rediscovery, an imperative to embrace the countryŠ—Ès past, its agricultural heritage and its pain.
Š—“This zamba, it sings,Š— one lyric says, Š—“and that gives me my name Š—” ends with an anguished cry.Š—

The director, Carlos Saura (Š—“Flamenco, FlamencoŠ—), has captured a wide array of artists as they perform the folk music and dances that were either indigenous to the country or born of the collision of native and Spanish cultures. He keeps the stagings sparse and the accompanying information even sparser. The art forms are identified Š—” zamba, carnavalito, chacarera doble Š—” but if you want to know their origins and other details, do your homework in advance. The performers are not identified until the closing credits.

Š—“ArgentinaŠ— provides a fine introduction to that countryŠ—Ès traditional music and dance for those already familiar with it. The contradiction in that statement is why this pretty film is also a frustrating one.

These average-looking kids in their mid-to-late teens donŠ—Èt have the sculpted bodies of models or porn stars. Even when their activities get out of hand and a video of one female participant is posted on YouTube, there is no condemnation or generalized panic. Pleasant as it is to look at nubile bodies entwined, the sex they have conveys little passion or erotic charge. The camera virtually yawns at all the goings-on.
Š—“Bang Gang: A Modern Love StoryŠ— is not rated. It is in French, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 38 minutes.

Š—“Bang GangŠ— goes out of its way to avoid stereotyping. Where a Hollywood equivalent would almost certainly punish George, Š—“Bang GangŠ— refuses to designate clear-cut heroes and villains. Its blas’© attitude, however, goes only so far, as the group activity results in venereal disease and an unwanted pregnancy. But the world doesnŠ—Èt end. There are quick, easy solutions: antibiotics and abortion. ItŠ—Ès no big deal. As one girl observes after the fact, it almost feels as if it never happened.

The initiator of games that evolve into orgies is George (Marilyn Lima), who is piqued when the groupŠ—Ès callous ringleader, Alex (Finnegan Oldfield), treats her with indifference after they hook up, and decides to stir things up. Games that begin as spin the bottle and truth or dare slowly turn into sex parties at AlexŠ—Ès house while his parents are away. Even when copulating, Alex seems bored with it all.

To be clinical: There are brief scenes of two girls kissing, but the action is mostly mundane, nonacrobatic boy-girl sex. Except for a scene in which one mischievous boy strips naked by a swimming pool, genitalia Š—” both male and female Š—” are not seen.

The story shifts between the perspectives of George and her friend Laetitia (Daisy Broom), and Alex plays one against the other. Contrasted with Alex is Gabriel (Lorenzo Lefebvre), an earnest aspiring electronic composer and neighbor of LaetitiaŠ—Ès.

What is distinctively contemporary about the French director Eva HussonŠ—Ès teenage sex film, Š—“Bang Gang: A Modern Love Story,Š— is its charactersŠ—È nonchalance. This portrait of middle-class teenagers fueled by Ecstasy, cocaine and pot, whiling away the hours and having group sex during a long hot summer in Biarritz, France, is remarkable for its shrugging attitude. Opposite in spirit to a shocker like Larry ClarkŠ—Ès Š—“Kids,Š— Š—“Bang GangŠ— doesnŠ—Èt aim to titillate or to alarm.

To call Š—“Central IntelligenceŠ— juvenile is to miss the larger point Š—” namely, that juvenile was most likely the goal. A majority of studio comedies have been written at an eighth-grade level or lower for so long that itŠ—Ès astonishing how resilient our hope for greater sophistication is.
Rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). A windpipe is whisked out, fingers are mangled, and fashion codes are thrown to the winds.

Š—“Black people donŠ—Èt go to therapists,Š— he tells his concerned wife. Š—“We go to barbershops.Š— In lieu of analysis, Calvin reunites with Bob (Dwayne Johnson), the once-chubby victim of high school bullies whose gratitude to Calvin for a minor act of kindness has outlasted the flab. Transformed into a solid mountain of muscle, Bob has a fanny pack full of government secrets and an abiding love for Molly Ringwald. For the purposes of the movie, one is no more important than the other.

Yet hope we do, even as the vulgar sight gags and plot inanities pile up. And when performers as sharp and engaging as Kevin Hart are involved, the disappointment is especially keen. Here, he plays Calvin, a dissatisfied accountant and husband still mourning his high school athletic triumphs.

An odd-couple caper of staggering dopeyness that makes you long for the snap and sizzle of the buddy movies of the 1980s, Š—“Central IntelligenceŠ— is a clean-out-the-fridge soup of celebrity cameos and C.I.A. confusion. But not even actors with the heft of Amy Ryan, Jason Bateman and Aaron Paul can fortify a screenplay (by the director, Rawson Marshall Thurber, and two others) thatŠ—Ès an incoherent muddle of stolen satellite encryption codes and messily staged gun battles. Or maybe IŠ—Èm just weary of comedies that seem to contain more bullets than jokes.

Her husband (Jean-Fran’_ois Balmer) is a pompous professorial type who festoons his speech with nonsensical Latin flourishes. Their niece, Catherette (Cl’©mentine Pons), lives with them, as does their daughter, Lena (Vict’_ria Guerra), who is married. Catherette, who has a deformed lip, seems to be in love with Witold, who conceives a feverish, possibly reciprocated passion for Lena. Fuchs goes out cruising at night, returning with fresh welts and bruises that donŠ—Èt dampen his exuberance.

Š—“Cosmos,Š— Andrzej ZulawskiŠ—Ès first film since 2000, is both a comeback and a swan song. Mr. Zulawski, 75 when he died in February, was an important figure in the history of Polish cinema and in the emergence of a borderless, cosmopolitan European style of filmmaking during the Cold War and after. His last work pays tribute to his roots and to his subsequent wanderings. Based on a novel of the same name by the Polish writer Witold Gombrowicz, this French-Portuguese co-production is a witty and energetic Š—” if also somewhat labored Š—” m’©lange of languages, tones and ideas.

The film unfolds with a madcap energy that nonetheless carries a whiff of fatigue. Mr. Zulawski, following GombrowiczŠ—Ès lead, blithely discards narrative logic, and delights in finding images that will do justice to this writerŠ—Ès manic inventiveness. Some images are hauntingly grotesque Š—” like the dead birds hanging across paths in a forest Š—” while others seem to pulse with occult, Bu’±uelian sexual and religious significance. Sometimes a simpler pictorial whimsy seems to be at work, a desire to shoot something crazy.

The protagonist is a sensitive law student Š—” alternately sulky and stormy Š—” named Witold (Jonathan Genet), who explains that his parents gave him the name because they were Gombrowicz fans. ThatŠ—Ès far from the only self-referential moment in the film, which chronicles WitoldŠ—Ès increasingly bizarre experiences at a Lisbon boardinghouse. He and a fellow student, Fuchs (Johan Lib’©reau), are welcomed by the eccentric and effusive Mme. Woytis (Sabine Az’©ma), who may be the sanest member of the household.

It is possible to appreciate Mr. ZulawskiŠ—Ès perverse ingenuity, and to miss his eye and voice, without quite succumbing to the strenuous charms and overcooked provocations of Š—“Cosmos.Š— The film Š—” which is opening in New York at the Metrograph, a young art house with a studied, old-fashioned vibe Š—” feels more like a revival than a new release. It can inspire you to think fondly back on the work of Alain Resnais (Ms. Az’©maŠ—Ès presence is a cue for that) or Ra’_l Ruiz, or, for that matter, on earlier films of Mr. ZulawskiŠ—Ès in which the vision felt more urgent and inspired.
Š—“Cosmos,Š— which is not rated, is in French with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 43 minutes.

Š—“Cosmos,Š— for its part, leaves a curiously paradoxical aftertaste. ItŠ—Ès an exercise in nostalgic avant-gardism, a retro-modernist trip down aesthetic paths that have long since been blocked off, overgrown or paved over.

Though the setup juggles clich’©s, it subverts several of them once the partners take their first case: that of Merete (Sonja Richter), a politician who disappeared in a presumed suicide. That presumption unravels as Morck and Assad pull at its threads, and as we see a series of flashbacks that run parallel to the investigation. One of those, in which the main pieces fall into place, is gasp-inducing.

The film adaptations of Jussi Adler-OlsenŠ—Ès Nordic crime novels were a hit in Denmark, and now all three, known as Š—“The Department Q Trilogy,Š— are being released on Friday in the United States. This pitch-black series, with its brooding protagonist, may draw comparisons with Š—“The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,Š— but consider this: The stories are even sharper. Here are reviews of the other films in the trilogy, Š—“The Absent OneŠ— and Š—“A Conspiracy of Faith.Š—

Admittedly, Morck (Nikolaj Lie Kaas) has cause for his surliness. After a stakeout ignited a brutal moment of violence, heŠ—Ès been busted down to Department Q, a basement office that handles cold cases. There, he meets Assad (Fares Fares), his new and pleasant partner who brews undrinkable coffee. MorckŠ—Ès got still more problems, among them a failed marriage and a rainy Denmark thatŠ—Ès bursting with colors, most of them gray.

Detective Carl Morck has one mood, and boy, itŠ—Ès bad. So bad that by the end of Š—“The Keeper of Lost Causes,Š— you may fear that his stone face will split down the center if he forces himself to smile. But I wonŠ—Èt say whether this angry cop finally grins, nor will I supply any other spoilers about this expertly plotted Nordic noir.

The film, directed by Mikkel Norgaard (whoŠ—Ès borrowed a thing or three from David Fincher) and first released in Denmark in 2013, often focuses on research rather than on gunplay, yet somehow it still feels filled with action. ThatŠ—Ès a testament to its lead actors, who radiate tension, and to the script, adapted by Nikolaj Arcel from a novel by Jussi Adler-Olsen. Yes, there are grisly scenes. But there are moments of dry humor, too. DonŠ—Èt be afraid to smile at those. Your face wonŠ—Èt split.

But in time-honored tradition, the movie also has lessons to impart. Š—“NemoŠ— made the case for indomitability in the face of fear. Š—“DoryŠ— is more about the acceptance of chaos. DoryŠ—Ès inability to make or stick to plans is shown, in the long run, to be an advantage. And her memory issues, played mostly for laughs in the first movie, take on a deeper meaning here. She and Nemo, who was born with a deformed flipper, are both people Š—” well, actually, anthropomorphized fish, but you know what I mean Š—” with disabilities, an identity shared by most of the new secondary characters.
Š—“Finding DoryŠ— is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). A little scary, a little sad.  Running time:  1 hour 43 minutes.

In a way that is both emphatic and subtle, Š—“Finding DoryŠ— is a celebration of cognitive and physical differences. It argues, with lovely ingenuity and understatement, that what appear to be impairments might better be understood as strengths. The inclusiveness of the filmŠ—Ès vision is remarkable partly because it feels so natural, something that no adult will really need to explain. Children will get it, perhaps more intuitively and easily than the rest of us.

Taking place, for the most part, a year after NemoŠ—Ès return to the reef, Š—“Finding DoryŠ— flashes back to its heroineŠ—Ès childhood, when she was an adorable, popeyed, short-term-memory-challenged hatchling living with her mom (Diane Keaton) and dad (Eugene Levy). She wandered off one day, and grew to adulthood looking for her family. The revival of this quest sends her across the seas, and this time Marlin (Albert Brooks) and Nemo (Hayden Rolence) are the sidekicks.

Instead of the open seas, Dory conducts her search mostly in the confines of the Marine Life Institute, an institution clearly inspired by the Monterey Bay Aquarium in California that the filmmakers turn into a theme park full of mechanical ingenuity and aquatic cuteness. There are toys and tots, aquarium tanks and drain pipes, strange birds and the disembodied voice of Sigourney Weaver. The plot, like a theme-park ride, is both predictable and exciting, a fast-moving cascade of triumphs and setbacks, punctuated with humor and pathos.

Not the only ones. Like other films of its species, Š—“Finding DoryŠ— is full of celebrity voice work, including from a number of television performers. Kaitlin Olson of Š—“ItŠ—Ès Always Sunny in PhiladelphiaŠ— is a nearsighted shark. Idris Elba and Dominic West have a Š—“WireŠ— reunion Š—” Stringer Bell and McNulty,  together again! Š—” as a pair of Cockney sea lions. Ty Burrell plays a nervous beluga whale, while his Š—“Modern FamilyŠ— father-in-law, Ed OŠ—ÈNeill, steals many scenes as a wily, grouchy, seven-armed octopus named Hank.

Now Dory has her own movie, imaginatively called Š—“Finding Dory,Š— a merchandising opportunity for Disney and a welcome end-of-the-school-year diversion for parents and children. While it may not join the top tier of Pixar features, Š—“Dory,Š— directed by Andrew Stanton and Angus MacLane, is certainly the best non-Š—“Toy StoryŠ— sequel the studio has produced. That may sound like faint praise given the startling mediocrity of Š—“Monsters UniversityŠ— and Š—“Cars 2,Š— but what Š—“DoryŠ— lacks in dazzling originality it more than makes up for in warmth, charm and good humor.

(Meanwhile, PixarŠ—Ès place on the vanguard of animation is affirmed by Š—“Piper,Š— the short, directed by Alan Barillaro, that accompanies Š—“Finding DoryŠ— in theaters. A variation on the themes of Š—“Nemo,Š— it tells the simple, touching story of a fledgling shore bird overcoming fear and facing danger. It also makes astonishing strides in the vivid and detailed rendering of feathers, foam and sand.)

Everyone will laugh at the sight of an octopus driving a truck, a wild-eyed loon flying with a bucket of angelfish in her beak and the other slapstick set pieces. And very few throats will remain unlumped as long-separated characters are reunited. Maybe there are a few too many reunions. How many times does Dory need to be found? But the repetitiveness of the story is related to its moral, a Disney legacy reanimated by Pixar again and again. Solidarity and kinship are two sides of the same coin. Š—“Friends and familyŠ— is a distinction without a difference.

In Š—“Finding Nemo,Š— PixarŠ—Ès 2003 masterpiece, the ocean was a vast realm of menace and wonder, newly charted by rapidly advancing digital-animation technology. The movie, a visual revelation, was also a welcome defense of risk-taking in an era of anxiety, and something of a cautionary tale about the downsides of helicopter parenting. As often happens in adventure stories, the hero was occasionally upstaged by his sidekick. We rooted for Nemo and choked up when he was found, but the best lines and sweetest grace notes belonged to Dory, the absent-minded blue tang voiced by Ellen DeGeneres.

It is difficult to look at a sugar packet the same way after seeing Š—“Land and Shade,Š— which won the Cam’©ra dŠ—ÈOr (best first feature) at the Cannes Film Festival last year. The writer and director, C’©sar Augusto Acevedo, has set his movie among the sugar farmers of the Valle del Cauca region in Colombia. They work long hours in the fields Š—” the cane leaves, weŠ—Ère told, cut like razors Š—” and are shortchanged pay.

Alfonso (Haimer Leal) returns home after years away to see Gerardo (Edison Raigosa), his son, who is largely bedridden because of a farming-related respiratory ailment. Gerardo would be better off moving away, as his wife (Marleyda Soto) wishes, but he stays because of his aging mother (Hilda Ruiz), who regards Alfonso with disdain.

When it focuses on the workers, the movie resembles the films of John Sayles, who often juxtaposes a family drama with an expansive sociological portrait. In Š—“Land and Shade,Š— the setting holds more interest than the plot: a fable-like, elemental story that sketches its characters too faintly to develop much power.

While Alfonso gets to know his grandson (Jos’© Felipe C’rdenas), Mr. Acevedo emphasizes atmosphere, whether itŠ—Ès in the birdcalls on the soundtrack or shots of ash raining down as fields are burned. The opening composition Š—” in which Alfonso, walking down a dirt road, is forced to make way for a giant truck Š—” captures the movieŠ—Ès perspective in miniature, and little of the restrained material that follows can match that shotŠ—Ès simple power.

There is visual poetry in Jin Mo-youngŠ—Ès documentary, Š—“My Love, DonŠ—Èt Cross That River,Š— and unblinking observation as well. The film covers 15 months with Jo Byong-man and Kang Gye-yeul, married for 76 years and living in a modest, rural riverside home in Gangwon Province in South Korea.

Over seasons captured in Mr. JinŠ—Ès lyrical camerawork, we witness Mr. JoŠ—Ès decline and foreshadowed demise. In an old custom, Ms. Kang burns her husbandŠ—Ès clothes so they may serve him in the afterlife and mourns in a wintry landscape. Many of the passages in this gentle film may be universal, but the love here is extraordinary.

Of their history, we hear only that they met when she was 14; Mr. Jo worked in her parentsŠ—È shop. (Early marriage was common at the time.) Three years after they wed, they became intimate, at Ms. KangŠ—Ès initiative. (She is still grateful for his restraint.) Of their 12 children, six died of measles. Their surviving children visit, with grandkids, and bicker, as family members often do.

He is nearly 100, losing his hearing and plagued with labored breathing that is unnerving to behold. She is almost 90 and blessed with an unwavering spirit. Their bond is profound, strengthened by shared household responsibilities Š—” cooking, collecting firewood, tending their dogs Š—” and a sense of affectionate play. They often dress in identical colors and toss leaves and snow at each other like youngsters. As they retire side by side, he gently caresses her face.

RaniŠ—Ès best friend, Lajjo (Radhika Apte), is regularly beaten by her husband, in part because he thinks sheŠ—Ès infertile but mostly because heŠ—Ès a patriarchal monster. Their mutual friend, Bijli (Surveen Chawla), is a carnival dancer and prostitute; such is their own lot that Rani and Lajjo practically envy her. And the three womenŠ—Ès relationship with Janaki, the 15-year-old bartered bride, is fittingly complex.

With a couple of exceptions, the men in the womenŠ—Ès lives are pigheaded, arrogant, self-righteous and so smug in their power as to be repellent. Scarily enough, they do not come off as caricatures. When Rani tells one of them that he should Š—“learn to be human,Š— itŠ—Ès a satisfying moment, but not nearly as fulfilling as it would have been, say, to have seen him thrown out of a window.

In the village, Ujhaas, a young widow, Rani (Tannishtha Chatterjee), buys a bride for her teenage son, Gulab. The spectacle of an archaic, oppressive social convention, fulfilled with the use of 21st-century technology (mobile phones play a part in sealing the deal), is oddly bracing.

Despite the appalling circumstances and events it depicts, the movieŠ—Ès plain and unstinting affection for its lead characters gives Š—“ParchedŠ— a frequently buoyant tone. Ms YadavŠ—Ès frames are always filled with bright color, and the editing maintains an almost infectious rhythm as the characters move toward whatever self-determination they can find.

The title of this movie, written and directed by Leena Yadav, is an apt description of the desert village in northwestern India which its three female leads toil and suffer. The women themselves, however, are thankfully not arid in any sense, though frequently starved for tenderness.

As its title boldly, somewhat hopefully announces, the documentary Š—“Raiders! The Story of the Greatest Fan Film Ever MadeŠ— recounts the amusing ups and periodic alarming downs of a singular handmade project. In 1982, two Mississippi boys Š—” Eric Zala, 12, and Chris Strompolos, 11 Š—” set out to create a shot-by-shot remake of Steven SpielbergŠ—Ès Š—“Raiders of the Lost Ark,Š— which had hit theaters the year before. For seven years, as these boys became men, they called action and rolled camera, painstakingly, feverishly, recreating Indy and his high-flying adventures.

True enthusiasts sometimes cross the line between fan and fanatic; these kids vaulted over it, deliriously. For them, the remake wasnŠ—Èt a casual backyard frolic, the kind that imaginative, young minds generate after school and before dinner. This was a full-blown, feature-length production with dressed actors and sets, period detail and even dangerous pyrotechnic special effects. Eric created the meticulous storyboards, partly guided by his surreptitious recording of the original movieŠ—Ès audio (this was before home video took off) and served as the baby Spielberg. Chris put on a rakish fedora to play Indiana Jones, running and cracking the whip as his body and voice changed.

You can see the developmental phases slip and lurch by in the smeary, charmingly awkward clips from the remake scattered throughout this documentary. Like latter-day versions of Tom Sawyer and Huck Finn, Eric and Chris were ingeniously resourceful. They brought in another friend, Jayson Lamb, as their cinematographer and special-effects specialist, and together they turned a yard into a jungle, stenciled hieroglyphics on walls and used a dog called Snickers to play the role that had been performed by a spider monkey in the original Š—“Raiders.Š— Summer after summer, these friends convened as the early 1980s gave way to the late, and Pac-Man gave way to Game Boy.

The pleasure of the remake, even when viewed piecemeal, is that itŠ—Ès a testament to the transporting glories of movie love, to that passion that sweeps you up whether youŠ—Ère sailing over the rainbow with Dorothy or riding shotgun with Ripley into the abyss. ItŠ—Ès a fever that can become a kind of madness, send lovers soaring or spiraling, and that sometimes turns fans into directors, writers, scholars, programmers and even critics. WhatŠ—Ès especially moving about Š—“Raiders!,Š— though Š—” and which is evident in the snippets from the remake and the behind-the-scenes glimpses of the boys and their friends Š—” is that this passion is incredibly pure, itŠ—Ès their first love and their greatest.

At first, this new endeavor Š—” which involves blowing up a plane, among other hurdles Š—” comes across as quixotic, but it soon starts to feel like self-promotion. As the documentary details, Mr. Zala, Mr. Strompolos and Mr. Lamb are having an extended moment, which began in 2002 when Š—“Raiders!Š— was screened at a festival in Austin, Tex. The audienceŠ—Ès thrilled reaction lit a long fuse: Vanity Fair published an article about Š—“Raiders!Š—; a fictional movie about its making was announced; and this documentary Š—” a fan film about the making of a fan film Š—” happened. Mr. Zala and Mr. Strompolos, meanwhile, started a production company Š—” and so it goes.

The documentary, directed by Jeremy Coon and Tim Skousen, revisits those tender years and what came after with a lot of obvious enthusiasm and not an ounce of critical distance, as if they too were just two more friends playing along. This eagerness toward the adaptation is understandable, given its ungainly charm, but the problem is that the documentary isnŠ—Èt strictly about the remake. Too much of the documentary is dedicated to the adult Mr. Zala and Mr. Strompolos, who when it opens are in the midst of trying to raise money to shoot a complicated, effects-heavy scene of Š—“Raiders of the Lost ArkŠ— that they didnŠ—Èt pull off when they were teenagers.
Š—“Raiders!: The Story of the Greatest Fan Film Ever MadeŠ— is not rated. Running time:  1 hour 35 minutes.

Š—“A Conspiracy of FaithŠ— is by far the darkest of the Department Q stories. For this pitch-black series of films, thatŠ—Ès saying something. And unlike the first two, which were set in shadows and darkness, this thriller usually takes place in daylight. Somehow, that makes it more disturbing.

A swimmer finds a note, written in blood, in an old bottle. That message, from a boy being held captive, leads Morck and Assad (Fares Fares) to a reclusive religious sect that harbors a serial killer (Pal Sverre Hagen).

All three films were based on novels by Jussi Adler-Olsen. Comparisons with Steig LarssonŠ—Ès books are inevitable. While Morck is no Lisbeth Salander Š—” he has difficulty using a cellphone Š—” these stories are better plotted. And the closing scene of Š—“Faith,Š— beautifully blunt, ends it on the perfect note. Sure, you could point out a few shortcomings here and there. But those sins are easy to overlook.

While the earlier movies were as much about Morck as about the mystery, this one (released this year in Denmark) puts action first. A new director, Hans Petter Moland, has arrived with a bigger budget, and he knows how to stage the chase scenes.

Though the previous film had the Danish detective Carl Morck (Nikolaj Lie Kaas) on the way to softening Š—” as much as a hunk of granite can Š—” heŠ—Ès relapsed into misery. But like a snap of ammonia under the nostrils, a new case makes him practically bolt upright.

Morck hasnŠ—Èt been forgotten, though: In between the murders, heŠ—Ès lashing out at the universe and at Assad as they spar over religion and the meaning of life. Imagine a Michael Mann film, with Kierkegaard as co-director.
Š—“A Conspiracy of FaithŠ—  is part of a trilogy of films in the Š—“Department QŠ— series. Read the reviews for the other films, Š—“The Absent OneŠ— and Š—“The Keeper of Lost Causes.Š—
Unless youŠ—Ère Carl Morck. That guy forgives nothing.

Potholes abound, including student interactions zinging with racial slurs. But the movieŠ—Ès filthy mouth is balanced by its warm heart, an organ that gradually takes charge as the story progresses. Tonal shifts from ribald to sweet and from raucous to sensitive arenŠ—Èt always smooth, and the sentiment can get gooey. (As back stories emerge, so do a surprising number of violent and alcoholic fathers.) Š—“TickledŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). For language, not tickling. Running time: 1 hour 32 minutes.

Narrated in an irrepressibly chipper tone by Gene Tognacci, Š—“Nuts!Š— opens with sepia-toned black-and-white images of goats copulating, roughly drawn and crudely animated. Š—“Nuts!,Š— an inventive documentary directed by Penny Lane (Š—“Our NixonŠ—) from Thom StylinskiŠ—Ès script, tells a quintessentially American story Š—” one that elicits both wonder and horror.

Dr. Brinkley is first seen as a barefoot teenager, begging for admission to Johns Hopkins University, a detail gleaned from  Clement WoodŠ—Ès 1934 biography, which the movieŠ—Ès credits name as a primary source. Š—“Brinkley would put goat testicles inside an impotent man, and nine months later, that man would call himself a father,Š— Mr. Tognacci says in a voice that suggests an affected straight face. The extent of the contrivance will set off multilevel credulity alarms in viewers paying close attention. Also curious is the movieŠ—Ès seeming lack of interest in Dr. BrinkleyŠ—Ès inner life. These apparent defects are all part of the filmmakerŠ—Ès genuinely cunning strategy.

Alternating with animated re-creations, archival footage and interviews with historians, Ms. LaneŠ—Ès narrative, from Dr. BrinkleyŠ—Ès career roots in the once-one-horse town of Milford, Kan., grows to encompass a million-watt radio tower in Mexico, and more besides. As the saga enters the 1930s, the animation and the archival footage shift to bright color, but the story grows more convoluted and bleak. The movie culminates in a cinematic coup de gr’¢ce bold enough to spin your head Š—” one that gives the movie an entirely new dimension. Š—“IŠ—Èm not a man yet,Š— he tells his mother, Annette Jackson, as she encourages him to buckle down. (To the filmŠ—Ès detriment, only one set of parents appears onscreen.) On Š—“The Daily Show,Š— especially in Jon StewartŠ—Ès early years, correspondents perfected the art of the punk sit-down, in which the interviewees seemed not to realize that the interviewers were mocking them. Along the way, we are given an overview of ZappaŠ—Ès career, from his early albums with the Mothers of Invention through his not particularly accessible classical compositions.

Zappa was an early example of a brand of celebrity in which notoriety overshadowed professional accomplishment. As he himself often acknowledged, he became a symbol of various things for various people merely from his appearance and from what those people projected onto him. Meanwhile, much of his music went unheard, especially in the United States.
Š—“Eat That Question: Frank Zappa in His Own WordsŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian), because Zappa pushed language boundaries.
ItŠ—Ès too bad heŠ—Ès not around Š—” heŠ—Èd be in his mid-70s now Š—” to see the age of YouTube celebrity and reality TV.
Š—“IŠ—Èm famous,Š— he says in one clip, Š—“but most people donŠ—Èt even know what I do.Š—
