But if Š—“Happy HourŠ— doesnŠ—Èt quite deliver all it promises, that may only be because it promises quite a lot.
Š—“Happy HourŠ— is not rated. It is in Japanese, with English subtitles. Running time: 5 hours 17 minutes.

This ambitious, unusually paced Japanese feature, from Ryusuke Hamaguchi, runs 5 hours 17 minutes, but the exorbitant length feels almost random. The movie gives the impression that at two hours or eight hours, it would play in a similar way: content to let details emerge over time; happy to dwell on scenes that a more conventional drama might elide for aimlessness; and only tentatively committed to graceful dramatic arcs.

Š—“Happy HourŠ— is the sort of movie that thinks nothing of dwelling for a half-hour on an authorŠ—Ès reading and the subsequent Q. and A. This is after devoting another half-hour to a lengthy, New Age-y trust-building class that encourages participants to Š—“listen to your center.Š—

The first half of this overlong documentary concentrates on Ms. SheilŠ—Ès meticulous investigations and preparation. Š—“If a performance of mine is called Š—…subtleŠ—È one more time, I might lose my mind,Š— Ms. Sheil remarks dryly. Ms. Chubbuck, as seen on videotape, is intense and volatile. Before her suicide, she asked that the broadcast be taped. Viewers are told that the only existing copy is under lock and key.
Š—“In keeping with Channel 40Š—Ès policy of bringing you the latest in blood and guts, and in living color, you are going to see another first Š—” attempted suicide.Š—

When we finally reach the suicide itself and Ms. Sheil hesitates to pretend to shoot herself, Š—“Kate Plays ChristineŠ— feels like an exploitative stunt. No amount of lofty supposition can camouflage the overwhelming feeling that the director has been disingenuous in his choice of a subject.

In the words of a former colleague at the station: Š—“ChristineŠ—Ès basic beef with local news was that it was turning to blood and guts. So the very thing she hated the most is the motivation behind resurrecting this video and highlighting it again.Š— He has a point.

The movie is one of two films about Ms. Chubbuck that were shown at the Sundance Film Festival this year. The other, Š—“Christine,Š— is a straightforward narrative film, directed by Antonio Campos and starring Rebecca Hall, that opens in October.

This all-but-forgotten story is dredged up in Robert GreeneŠ—Ès Š—“Kate Plays Christine,Š— a movie that provocatively blurs the line between documentary and fiction. It follows the New York actress Kate Lyn Sheil as she researches the life of Ms. Chubbuck before portraying her in this unsettling cinematic hybrid. The suicide is wrongly thought by some to have inspired Paddy ChayefskyŠ—Ès screenplay for Sidney LumetŠ—Ès 1976 satire, Š—“Network,Š— whose protagonist, Howard Beale, a network anchorman, inveighing against the evils of television, creates a national sensation by threatening to kill himself while on the air.

That grimly sarcastic announcement was delivered on July 15, 1974, by Christine Chubbuck, a 29-year-old television anchor who shot herself in the head during her morning talk show, Š—“Suncoast Digest,Š— on a station in Sarasota, Fla.; she died 14 hours later.

Ms. Sheil goes to elaborate lengths to prepare for the role. She interviews Ms. ChubbuckŠ—Ès acquaintances, buys a revolver from the same gun store where Ms. Chubbuck bought her weapon and learns how to shoot it. Wearing a dark wig and brown contact lenses, she approximates Ms. ChubbuckŠ—Ès appearance, and consults professionals on depression and suicide. During her research, she remains glum and taciturn and reveals little of herself.

Mr. GreeneŠ—Ès queasy-making film is a sequel of sorts to his 2014 documentary, Š—“Actress,Š— which muses intriguingly about the boundaries between actors playing themselves and fictional characters in front of a camera.

Directed by Jean-Fran’_ois Richet, Š—“Blood FatherŠ— is based on a novel of the same title by Peter Craig, who shares script credit with Andrea Berloff. The movie is basically one of those rescue missions in which two people end up saving each other, in this case John and his long-missing daughter, Lydia (Erin Moriarty). She reappears in his life after having made a splashy, gory entrance with some heavily armed gangbangers and an excitable number in a suit, Jonah (Diego Luna). Things go south, as they must, and she high-tails it back to Dad. ItŠ—Ès a tense reunion Š—” John is sober, she snorts powder Š—” if flecked with comedy. Their laughs take a timeout when the gangbangers show, guns blazing.

Hobbesian to the max, Š—“Blood FatherŠ— is unwaveringly nasty and brutish. ItŠ—Ès also short, a combination that pretty much gives you all that you could want from a pulp fiction in which Mel Gibson plays a grizzled loner inking skin in a spot called the Missing Link Tattoo. HeŠ—Ès Link, of course; first name John. A former bad, bad man with a wild beard and a deep well of cynicism, John lives in a trailer parked on one of those picturesquely godforsaken southwestern landscapes where John Ford-style homesteaders once circled the wagons. The dream of the Old West dies hard, especially in the movies.

Š—“FatimaŠ— is not rated. It is in French and Arabic, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 19 minutes.

Divorced from her husband, whom she followed to France and with whom she is still friendly, Fatima (Soria Zeroual) is a 44-year-old North African woman raising two teenage girls in Lyon. If the movie, loosely based on two books by Fatima Elayoubi, tells a familiar story of immigrants struggling to make something of themselves in an alien culture (Fatima speaks some French but reads only Arabic), it does so in a tone that is kindhearted but clearheaded, and the performances are low-key and believable. Š—“Something else is pulling at me,Š— the gangly young man with the jug ears says. Š—“I wonder if I can write books or hold a position of influence in civil rights,Š— he adds. Š—“Politics?Š— the pretty young woman asks. He shrugs. Š—“Maybe.Š—

Mr. Guer’_n stages the scenes starkly, with few embellishments on his sets or from his cast. Sometimes the screen even goes dark, leaving only the audio. (In his directorŠ—Ès notes, he says, Š—“When I do not have image, I leave the black screen.Š—) These and some documentarylike touches are both admirably art-house and smugly static, as are the characters, whose lives in academia revolve around extended bouts of intellectual discourse.

The dominance of words over actions is what the writer and director, Jos’© Luis Guer’_n, was aiming for, and heŠ—Ès clearly hit his mark. Whether that mark is yours, too, will depend on your craving for a stationary and cerebral film whose pleasures are of the mind rather than the heart.

Š—“The Light Between OceansŠ— begins to lose its majesty when a dinghy appears on the shore. It contains a baby girl and the dead body of a man who is apparently her father. Tom insists they report the child to the authorities, while Isabel, still grieving, begs him to remain silent, allowing them to keep the baby and raise her as their own.

Remaining true to the novel, Š—“The Light Between OceansŠ— steadily becomes a strained fable about forgiveness and revenge that sabotages its best intentions by taking one too many plot turns. But unlike a movie spun off from a novel by Mr. Sparks, the story still remains weightier than mechanical literary claptrap. It eventually dribbles away in a final, perfunctory flash-forward that feels hastily tacked on, even though itŠ—Ès in the novel.

In Š—“The Light Between Oceans,Š— Michael Fassbender exudes the war-weary stoicism of a man who has grown numb from witnessing too much senseless carnage. Tom Sherbourne, his character in this sweeping period romance adapted from M. L. StedmanŠ—Ès 2012 novel, is an embittered World War I veteran who takes a job as a lighthouse keeper on Janus Rock, a remote, uninhabited island on the edge of Western Australia. His hope is to get as far as possible from civilization and its savagery.
Š—“The Light Between OceansŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for thematic content and sexual situations. Running time: 2 hours 12 minutes.

Their inspired pairing suggests that Mr. Cianfrance is a true believer in the romantic imagination: a mystique eroded by social and technological forces that have broken down traditional restraints against intimacy and privacy so that little mystery is left. The last remnant of the romantic imagination is its cheap first cousin, the erotic imagination.

When Tom meets Isabel (Alicia Vikander) in the mainland town where she grew up, their instant attraction is almost overwhelming. They marry, and he takes her to Janus Rock, where they live in isolated bliss until she miscarries. A second miscarriage occurs while he is tending the lighthouse during a furious storm and leaves them feeling desolate.

At this point in Š—“The Light Between Oceans,Š— the pounding surf turns into soapsuds and the brine into tears. Several years later, on a trip to IsabelŠ—Ès hometown, they meet Hannah (Rachel Weisz), a mournful woman who lost her husband and their baby girl at sea around the time the dinghy washed ashore. Realizing that the lost child is the baby they rescued, Tom, feeling guilty, furtively breaches his vow of secrecy with Isabel and drops enough hints to spur an investigation and a bitter struggle between Isabel and Hannah for possession of the child.

At his most besotted, Tom still keeps something of himself in reserve. Behind his icy, imperious gaze, you can discern the pain of the past, along with a certain inviolable nobility of spirit. Here and in earlier films, Mr. FassbenderŠ—Ès screen persona suggests a dashing but harder-edged answer to the Daniel Day-Lewis of Š—“The Age of Innocence.Š— Ms. Vikander mostly keeps in check the tempestuous, fiery side of Isabel, whom you sense, even at the beginning, to be on the verge of eruption. From the moment the two meet, she regards him with a desire that registers as an unflinching determination.

The movie, directed by Derek Cianfrance (Š—“Blue Valentine,Š— Š—“The Place Beyond the PinesŠ—), envelops the image of a lonely, brooding sentinel gazing out over the water in the seething atmosphere of a Winslow Homer seascape. And Alexandre DesplatŠ—Ès lush score washes over it like an endless tide. The filmŠ—Ès solemn visual rhythms exert an almost hypnotic spell that for a time gives a heroic dimension to a story as emotionally fraught as a vintage Bette Davis melodrama.

Š—“The Light Between OceansŠ— begins to suggest an overly plotted, high-end Nicholas Sparks film awash in tears, pleas and threats, and acts of treachery and nobility. Where Mr. FassbenderŠ—Ès sorrowful gravity anchored the movieŠ—Ès first half, Ms. VikanderŠ—Ès volatility sparks the second half with Ms. WeiszŠ—Ès aggrieved, conflicted Hannah providing a moral fulcrum.

Mr. Fassbender and Ms. Vikander make one of the most compelling pairs of screen lovers in the grand David O. Selznick tradition that IŠ—Ève come across in many years. Unlike so many contemporary movie stars, both actors convey a remarkable depth and range of feeling. With that goes an awareness of the essential unknowability of a partner in a relationship, even one as passionate as theirs.
As a drama about adult responsibility, selfishness and moral obligations, however, it never wavers in its commitment to examine what it means to raise a child.

Š—“White GirlŠ— poses a troubling but unspoken question: To what degree has hard partying with sex and drugs become entrenched as a hazardous rite of passage for bored millennials? Leah (Morgan Saylor), the doll-faced blond protagonist of this movie, written and directed by Elizabeth Wood, is an ebullient New York City college student with an appetite for marijuana, cocaine and casual sex.

The movie, which observes the world from LeahŠ—Ès entitled perspective, is the latest in a continuing line of shockers (including Š—“KidsŠ— and Š—“Spring BreakersŠ—), whose depictions of greedy drug-taking and promiscuity are inescapably titillating. Had Š—“White GirlŠ— been directed by a man, it would probably be accused of misogyny. But Ms. Wood has said that it is semi-autobiographical. When shown last winter at the Sundance Film Festival, Š—“White GirlŠ— received some obligatory tut-tutting from nervous male critics.

The movie is keenly aware of its charactersŠ—È class differences. Because Leah is privileged, she can do as she pleases at a dance club where sharp-eyed guards roughly expel grungy-looking suspected drug dealers. At the end of an evening of dissipation, she looks much the worse for wear, but never gets to the point of calling it quits. Her body can take the abuse. Even at her lowest moments, she exhibits an unfailing bravado. Her chirpy motto in times of crisis: Š—“I can figure it out.Š—
WeŠ—Ère all familiar with the term contact high, but not with its antithesis. Because it is so believable, Š—“White GirlŠ— is a contact bummer thatŠ—Ès hard to shake.

Her attempt to Š—“figure it outŠ— includes unloading the drugs at the club and making a quick $24,000. ThatŠ—Ès more than enough to pay the lawyer representing Blue, who faces decades behind bars (it is his third arrest), and BlueŠ—Ès dealer for the drugs he left behind when he was taken away by the police.

Š—“White GirlŠ— dwells completely in the moment. ThereŠ—Ès no mention of LeahŠ—Ès family. In scenes of Leah and Katie at dance clubs, hand-held cameras become participants in orgiastic frenzies. During one such scene, Leah sheds her top, screams with abandon and later collapses from exhaustion amid a bathroom threesome.

When she and her equally wild best friend Katie (India Salvor Menuez) move to a seedy apartment in Queens, she thinks nothing of running downstairs and asking the boys hanging out in front of the building where she can find some pot. They follow her upstairs, and it isnŠ—Èt long before Leah is having sex against a wall with Blue (Brian Marc, also a rapper known as Sene), a Puerto Rican drug dealer and the best-looking member of the group.

For the 21-year-old Ms. Saylor (Dana Brody on Š—“HomelandŠ—), Leah is a career-defining role that she embraces with a ferocious energy. With her platinum-dyed hair, she strongly resembles the young Britney Spears. During the summer between her freshman and sophomore years at an unidentified college, Leah, who envisions a career Š—“in media,Š— works as an unpaid intern at a magazine where her boss, Kelly (Justin Bartha), offers her cocaine. With hardly a second thought, she rewards him with oral sex.
Š—“White GirlŠ— is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 28 minutes.

The movie has what seems to be a heart, although you canŠ—Èt be sure. Leah entertains no expectations of a serious relationship with Blue. Yet when he is arrested for drug dealing, she goes to considerable lengths to help him try to avoid prison. She consults a sleazy, high-powered lawyer (Chris Noth), and in a state of semiconsciousness endures what appears to be a rape.

Mr. Depp also reprises his Š—“TuskŠ— gumshoe character, and channels Peter Sellers and Roman Polanski in a performance that, like much else in Š—“Yoga Hosers,Š— is more disturbingly peculiar than funny. Mix in relentless, albeit ostensibly affectionate, caricaturing of Canadian culture and sayings (the title phrase is repeated in a tone that suggests everyone involved thinks itŠ—Ès the most amusing word pairing ever) and, uh, voil’¾.

Š—“Yoga HosersŠ— brings supporting characters from 2014Š—Ès Š—“Tusk,Š— the first in the series, to the forefront. The heroines, two teenagers named Colleen, are played by Lily-Rose Depp, the daughter of Johnny Depp and Vanessa Paradis, and Harley Quinn Smith, daughter of Mr. Smith and Jennifer Schwalbach Smith, a co-producer of the movie who also performs here. The two young women are game and amiable screen presences. The story line grafts the premise of Mr. SmithŠ—Ès Š—“ClerksŠ— (bored young convenience store workers banter profanely with one another about life and love) to a stoned extrapolation on the Z-movie classic Š—“They Saved HitlerŠ—Ès Brain.Š— Or to the video game Castle Wolfenstein. Or to Š—” I donŠ—Èt even know. It all seems like something that was hatched during a particularly neuron-impaired free-association game.
Š—“Yoga HosersŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for reliably foul language and anthropomorphized sausages that kill several characters.

Behind the frenetic pop-culture frippery is a home-movie about the anxieties of show-business parenting thatŠ—Ès a lot more interesting than the onscreen mess. Some of Mr. SmithŠ—Ès prior work made me laugh so hard that I cried; Š—“Yoga HosersŠ— made me want to cry for different reasons.

Since the ignominious critical and commercial failure of his 2010 comedy, Š—“Cop Out,Š— Kevin Smith has been allowing his filmmaking inspiration to take him in directions that are fanciful even by his own gonzo standards. For reasons best known to himself and perhaps his producers (his explanations in interviews notwithstanding), he is in the middle of a Š—“True NorthŠ— trilogy of films combining comedic and horror elements, all set in Canada.

The film, directed by Pedro Morelli, gives the intertwining-stories method of scriptwriting an amusing twist Š—” yes, the three stories here intertwine, but not the way youŠ—Ère conditioned to expect. To say much more would be to spoil the fun, so instead youŠ—Èll have to settle for vague descriptions.

Š—“Zoom,Š— a brainteaser of a film with a breast-and-penis fetish, bets everything on cleverness and a few appealing performances, and it wins. Its conceit nicely fills up its 96 minutes; 97 would have been too long.

Alison Pill, in her adorable-nerd mode, is Emma, an illustrator who with her co-worker and sex partner (Tyler Labine) designs lifelike, anatomically correct dolls, the kind that fetishists prefer. SheŠ—Ès surrounded by naked fake breasts all day and soon decides hers arenŠ—Èt big enough.

Mr. Morelli mixes live-action and animated scenes to good effect. He doesnŠ—Èt have time to give his characters depth, but thereŠ—Ès pleasure in figuring out how they connect and pondering the movieŠ—Ès modest themes. Yes, we obsess too much about certain body parts, and yes, itŠ—Ès possible that weŠ—Ère all part of someone elseŠ—Ès fictional narrative.

There is also Edward (Gael Garc’_a Bernal), a filmmaker who is being pressured to abandon the vision he has for his current project and turn it into a lazy blockbuster, while also dealing with a shrinking penis. And the Brazilian actress Mariana Ximenes is Michelle, a model who wants to be a novelist but hears nothing but discouraging words from her boyfriend (Jason Priestley).

The filmŠ—Ès music soundtrack is deployed like a cudgel: A musical-comedy-like refrain adds a comic buoyancy; a hard-rock cue suggests GonzaloŠ—Ès defiance; a stirring Prokofiev crescendo lends grandeur to the climax. But the hangdog Mr. Ogalla, a nonprofessional actor and a friend of Mr. VeirojŠ—Ès (and, with the director, one of the filmŠ—Ès four screenwriters), does not project the tension to be expected from a driven man on such a mission. Despite Mr. VeirojŠ—Ès blithe Bu’±uel-like disdain for religion, Š—“The ApostateŠ— lacks teeth.

The Uruguayan director Federico VeirojŠ—Ès leisurely comedy-drama Š—“The ApostateŠ— has its charms, though the story (and its hero) could benefit from a tarter approach. The title character is Gonzalo (’lvaro Ogalla), a disheveled 30-something perennial student and layabout in Madrid, who Š—” believing that the Roman Catholic Church has imposed values on him that have sabotaged his life Š—” is determined to have his baptism expunged from church records. Though his mother is mortified, Gonzalo meets priests (including one seemingly incapable of removing his arm from GonzaloŠ—Ès) to press his demands, only to encounter a wall of obfuscation.

GonzaloŠ—Ès rebellions donŠ—Èt end there. He fawns over his cousin Pilar (Marta Larralde), with whom he resumes a sexual relationship after she separates from her boyfriend; canoodles with an older woman on a train; and flirts with the mother (B’rbara Lennie) of a boy (Kaiet Rodr’_guez) he tutors in his apartment building. Even while dozing off, he dreams about joining a protest movement of like-minded secular sensualists (including nudists).

Ostensibly still a teenager when he started publishing his stories, JT Leroy appeared in public as a soft-spoken waif in a blond wig, dark glasses and baggy, androgynous clothes. Earlier he had struck up intense friendships, conducted entirely over the telephone, with well-known writers and other celebrities. JT LeroyŠ—Ès face belonged to a young woman named Savannah Knoop. His voice Š—” both on the page and on the phone Š—” was the creation of Laura Albert, who is the main subject and primary source in Mr. FeuerzeigŠ—Ès film. She tells the story of her creation with a touch of humor, a measure of candor and very little regret. Ms. Albert doesnŠ—Èt like to think of JT Leroy as a hoax, preferring the loftier word Š—“myth.Š—

He was born in a series of phone calls to crisis hotlines and therapists, one of whom encouraged Terminator (as he identified himself then) to start writing. As JTŠ—Ès career took off, Ms. Albert enlisted her boyfriend, Geoffrey Knoop, a musician, and his sister Savannah in the ruse. Ms. Albert herself played a few different characters in addition to the offstage JT, including Speedie, an Englishwoman who served as the writerŠ—Ès confidante, big sister and informal manager.

He was, in their minds, a wondrous wildflower blooming in the dirt, an immaculate, unschooled talent they were pleased to nurture and protect. He (that is, Ms. Albert), flattered their vanity and allowed them to wrap their voyeurism in the cloak of empathy.

In the literary world, things are a little different. The peddlers of false memoirs and fishy identities are rarely celebrated for their ingenuity. Š—“Author: The JT Leroy Story,Š— a new documentary by Jeff Feuerzeig (Š—“The Devil and Daniel JohnstonŠ—), is a curious attempt to redeem, at least partly, the reputation of a notorious hoax. JT Leroy, whose fame flickered for about a decade starting in the mid-1990s, was both a writer of overtly autobiographical fiction and an entirely fictional character. Š—“HeŠ— was a complex and compelling creation: an H.I.V.-positive underage gay hustler with a history of drug addiction and sexual abuse who infused grim tales of degradation with lyricism and a kind of holy innocence.

ItŠ—Ès sometimes said that forgers of old-master paintings are accomplished artists in their own right. A successful fraud Š—” even if itŠ—Ès ultimately uncovered Š—” requires discipline, hard work and talent, and itŠ—Ès hard not to feel at least a grudging respect for charlatans who fool the public and especially the experts. We donŠ—Èt call them con artists for nothing.

Š—“AuthorŠ— is thus less a documentary than an infomercial, a prelude to an attempted second act. Ms. Albert, having attracted attention while in disguise, now wants more. And her testimony is interesting, even if it Š—” and this movie Š—” cannot be trusted.

To some extent she has a point. But rather than investigate the meaning of the Leroy myth, Š—“AuthorŠ— allows Ms. Albert to revise and perpetuate it. She describes JT Š—” the initials stand for Jeremiah Terminator Š—” as a persona that grew out of her own history of pain and marginality. As a survivor of abuse, bullying and mental illness, she says, she found in the frail and dreamy JT a viable alter ego, the first-person narrator of fantasies that leaked into the real world.

Eventually the bluff was called, in part thanks to reporting done by Warren St. John for The New York Times in early 2006. The tale of JT LeroyŠ—Ès unmasking still has a tawdry tabloid fascination, and Ms. AlbertŠ—Ès account of her frantic attempts at spinning and wagon-circling are in some ways the most forthright part of her narrative, even if she still seems a bit wounded that anyone could have doubted her or JT.
Š—“Author: The JT Leroy StoryŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Awful made-up stories. Running time: 1 hour 50 minutes.

In retrospect Š—” as you watch the archival footage Mr. Feuerzeig has collected and the home-movie snippets and recorded phone conversations Ms. Albert has saved Š—” itŠ—Ès hard to believe that so many people could have been fooled for so long. SpeedieŠ—Ès British accent was laughable, JTŠ—Ès biography was so lurid as to verge on the preposterous, and his writing combined pornographic content with greeting-card sentimentality. Its appeal was based largely on the Š—“factsŠ— of his miserable, magical life.

Ten years later, Ms. Albert is too ambitious and too intoxicated with her own grift to venture a frank assessment of its causes and consequences. And in spite of her well-established history of dishonesty, Mr. Feuerzeig makes no great effort to challenge Š—” or even to verify Š—” her claims about herself or anyone else. A few other people are interviewed, but the ethical, psychological and cultural meanings of the story remain mostly unexamined.

But of course a lot of people, including a lot of famous and creative people, were eager to buy into the myth. Š—“AuthorŠ— is most interesting Š—” and least self-aware Š—” as a study in the gullibility and narcissism of the celebrity class. JT LeroyŠ—Ès prominent friends (including the singers Bono, Courtney Love and Billy Corgan; the writers Dennis Cooper and Mary Karr; and the filmmakers Gus Van Sant and Asia Argento) may have found in him a mirror of their own wishful thinking about art and authenticity.

In the course of her career, Ms. Johnson has found herself in dangerous and somber places, as a witness to some of the worst inhumanity of the recent past. She returns several times to Foca, Bosnia, the scene of mass rapes and killings during the Balkan wars of the Š—È90s, and also visits Darfur, Afghanistan, Guant’namo Bay and ManhattanŠ—Ès ground zero. Š—“CamerapersonŠ— isnŠ—Èt a work of journalism or advocacy. ItŠ—Ès a scrapbook, a found poem assembled out of scraps and snippets of truth.

A philosopher Š—” Jacques Derrida, say, here seen crossing Houston Street a few years before his death Š—” might wax eloquent on the dialectical interpenetration of presence and absence. The brilliance of Š—“CamerapersonŠ— is that it invites and rewards such speculation even as its gaze remains fixed on the concrete, deceptively mundane details of the visible, physical world.
Š—“CamerapersonŠ— is not rated. It is in English, Arabic, Bosnian and Dari, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 42 minutes.

Cinematographers are invisible artists, perhaps especially in documentaries, which often emphasize content over visual aesthetics. Viewers are aware of the faces of the people on screen and the intentions of the director, but we generally donŠ—Èt think about whose eyes we are literally looking through. Ms. Johnson, in correcting that oversight, invites us to reconsider our assumptions about the ethical and emotional foundations of nonfiction filmmaking. Her filmŠ—Ès straightforward title turns out to be profound and complicated. The camera may be a machine, but it has the power to reveal a multiplicity of human presences.

Š—“CamerapersonŠ— isnŠ—Èt arranged chronologically, but it does tell a story. Or several, really Š—” about violence against women and the resilience of its survivors, about the ubiquity of war and injustice in the modern world and about the passage of time within the filmmakerŠ—Ès own family. The death of Ms. JohnsonŠ—Ès mother, who had AlzheimerŠ—Ès, is the filmŠ—Ès central offscreen event. Her loss is both registered Š—” we see the box containing her ashes during a visit to Ms. JohnsonŠ—Ès childhood home Š—” and magically undone when she reappears later on.

You glimpse Ms. JohnsonŠ—Ès face only once, late in Š—“Camera-person,Š— in a moment that is both offhand and startling. At other times you hear her voice, whispering to other members of the crew or coaching an interview subject. Her hands sneak into the frame now and then, clearing stray blades of grass that might obstruct a low-angled shot of sheep on a Bosnian hillside or scrubbing smudges from the windshield of a car. But even without these discreet (and sometimes comical) intrusions Š—” and even without scenes of her mother, father and two small children Š—” Š—“CamerapersonŠ— would be a remarkably intimate film, and a critique of the idea that there is anything impersonal or objective in photography.

And it is, above all, an act of showing rather than telling. There is grist for a hundred essays on the nature of cinematic representation here, but while you are watching your attention is entirely consumed by faces, eyes and landscapes and the sometimes uncanny connections that emerge among them. Ms. Johnson proves to be as skilled at organizing the images as she is at capturing them, assembling evocative montages of images drawn from radically different times, places and projects.

Š—“Cameraperson,Š— Kirsten JohnsonŠ—Ès transfixing documentary, defies easy summary. ItŠ—Ès unlike anything youŠ—Ève seen before, although if you remember films like Kirby Dick and Amy Ziering KofmanŠ—Ès Š—“DerridaŠ—  or Whitney Dow and Marco WilliamsŠ—Ès Š—“Two Towns of Jasper,Š— some of the images may be familiar. Ms. Johnson worked as a cinematographer on those documentaries and dozens of others, but the footage she shares here doesnŠ—Èt come from the finished films. It includes outtakes, offhand moments, snatches of time when the camera just happened to be running. Š—“These are the images that marked me,Š— she says in an introductory note, and she has woven them together into a unique and affecting memoir.

The French film director Christian Carion, whose Oscar-nominated audience pleaser, Š—“Joyeux No’âl,Š— depicted a heartwarming temporary d’©tente between World War I combatants, opens his latest film with a few words of historical context. He follows those with a dedication to his mother, who was among many citizens in northern France who were displaced by the German invasion of May 1940. Š—“Come What MayŠ— grafts a suspense narrative involving multinational characters to a story of genial rural folk compelled to flee their homes before theyŠ—Ère overrun by bloodthirsty trespassers.

Mr. Carion has lined up an impressive and committed cast. The haunted-looking August Diehl plays a German anti-Nazi activist who finds short-lived sanctuary in France with his young son. Olivier Gourmet is a wise and kindly village mayor, and Mathilde Seigner is his warm but no-nonsense wife. Alice Isaaz is a sweet, sensitive schoolteacher. The Welsh actor Matthew Rhys plays a Scottish Army officer who is forced to take a considerable detour on the way to Dunkirk.

The packed-with-incident screenplay, by Mr. Carion and Laure Irrmann, includes several suspenseful scenes that Mr. Carion pulls off effectively with his direction. The depredations of the Nazis are depicted in a way that will make viewers want to declare war on Germany anew. But Š—“Come What MayŠ— is also too pretty of a movie. It is often sentimental and, worse, schematic.
Š—“Come What MayŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for violence and adult themes.
GLENN KENNY

An early scene set in a cemetery is sufficiently weighted that, later, when a different graveyard turns up, what takes place there is not so much moving as predictable. For all the tragedy depicted, Š—“Come What MayŠ— is war movie as comfort food, and the familiar score by Ennio Morricone is not exempted from that judgment.

Waitstill and Martha Š—“left the comfort of a peaceful, small Massachusetts home in order to go into Europe on the verge of war,Š— one Holocaust scholar says at the start. Š—“They were motivated from the beginning to go out there into the kingdom of hell and try to get some people out.Š—

In the end, Š—“Defying the Nazis,Š— directed by Ken Burns and Artemis Joukowsky, a grandson of the Sharps, remains valuable to watch, and commendable for bringing the coupleŠ—Ès story to light. ItŠ—Ès impossible not to admire the Sharps, no matter how their tale is told.
Š—“Defying the Nazis: The SharpsŠ—È WarŠ— is a generic documentary about two people who were anything but. Yet even when the film wanes, its subjects still come across as remarkable.

Interviews with those who knew the Sharps are insightful. Yet footage of Nazi rallies and battlefield scenes often have little to do with the Sharps themselves, except to provide perspective on that time. Those visuals are typical of cable TV documentaries Š—” a mention of Paris is sure to include a shot of the Eiffel Tower, while one of New York will have the Statue of Liberty. The tension that arose in the SharpsŠ—È marriage also warrants more exploration than it receives here.
Before long the Sharps were living in a war zone and working to outwit the police there. Tom Hanks and Marina Goldman read letters from the couple that recount their exploits.

In 1939, Waitstill Sharp, a Unitarian minister, and his wife, Martha, were asked by leaders of their church to travel to Czechoslovakia, where they would help Jews, dissidents and others flee persecution by the Nazis. The couple agreed, leaving their young children behind in the United States.

More mournful than frightening, the dybbuk may upend the celebrations, but the revelers do far more damage. The party begins as one of those bacchanals filled with choreographed chaos, flowing alcohol and tumbling bodies that at times seem almost mandatory in Eastern European cinema. Mr. Wrona takes an alternately cool and hot view of this tumult, by turns pulling back for critical distance, at other times diving into the muck. ItŠ—Ès by turns entertaining and exhausting, though eventually the whole thing grows heavier, more solemn, as the party transforms into another reminder about how rapidly the so-called civilized slip into barbarism. Because, here, as the smiles fade, the shivers turn to chills and a lost world is revealed, it becomes all too clear who haunts this land and why.
Š—“DemonŠ— is rated R (under 17 requires accompanying parent or guardian) for some language, rivers of booze and demonic possession. Running time: 1 hour 34 minutes.

The dead still cling to the living in Š—“Demon,Š— blurring the divide between past and present. The Polish director Marcin Wrona, who wrote the movie with Pawel Maslona, has thoroughly reconceptualized the mythology of the dybbuk for 21st-century Eastern Europe. In his version, though, there is no holy grave; notably, there are scarcely any Jews. Instead, there are signs of prosperity, buried secrets, spooky winds, haunted streets. The opening scene sets the unsettling mood with a frontal shot of squat, barracklike buildings swathed in early morning fog. The focus then shifts to a bulldozer, which suddenly begins winding through the townŠ—Ès emptied, serpentine roads.

Much of what follows takes place the day of Peter and ZanetaŠ—Ès wedding, beginning with his move into the dark, derelict farmhouse where the two will soon settle down. Peter has ambitious plans for their new home Š—” he envisions a new view, a pool in the yard Š—” and heŠ—Ès soon clambered onto a bulldozer (the same or another) thatŠ—Ès on the property, moving trees and dirt as Zaneta prepares for their nuptials elsewhere. ItŠ—Ès while tooling around that Peter accidentally digs up a human skeleton, a discovery that unearths a world of trouble, most obviously in the form of a dybbuk who very soon takes possession of his body, the wedding party and the coupleŠ—Ès happily ever after.

Š—“Demon,Š— a modern ghost story haunted by the Holocaust, opens with an arrival and closes with a departure. These scenes, each set on a raft gliding on a deceptively tranquil country river, bookend a movie that raises light shivers by tapping into historical memory and employing some satisfying, bluntly old-fashioned screen magic. The movieŠ—Ès visual style, narrative ellipses and weighty subject make it ready-made for the art house even if its mystical flourishes Š—” an otherworldly claw, an undead bride Š—” are the sort of woo-woo pleasures more often scared up in genre stories.

Set in contemporary Poland, the story opens with Peter (the Israeli actor Itay Tiran), whoŠ—Ès moved from Britain to a small Polish town to wed a local beauty, Zaneta (Agnieszka Zulewska). Peter speaks Polish more than just passably, but heŠ—Ès an outsider and treated as such by his warily welcoming future father-in-law, Zygmunt (Andrzej Grabowski). Peter seems oblivious to ZygmuntŠ—Ès strained enthusiasm for the marriage and instead plunges into ZanetaŠ—Ès arms and into the bonhomie of her brother, Jasny (Tomasz Schuchardt), a glad-handing bellower who likes to pass a bottle around and refers to Peter by his somewhat ominous nickname: Python.

Š—“DemonŠ— is based on Š—“Adherence,Š— by the Polish playwright Piotr Rowicki, but also shares much with Š—“The Dybbuk: Between Two Worlds,Š— by the Russian ethnographer and revolutionary Shloyme Zaynvl Rapoport (a.k.a. S. An-ski). Set in an Eastern Europe town, Š—“The DybbukŠ— tells of a yeshiva student who uses kabbalistic means to win the woman he loves. Instead, he dies, and his spirit enters her body as a dybbuk Š—” the evil soul of a dead person. (Š—“IŠ—Ève returned to my beloved, and IŠ—Èll never leave her!Š—) The realms of the dead and the living are inseparable in this story, where wedding parties dance around a Š—“holy graveŠ— to Š—“cheer and comfortŠ— a couple murdered in a pogrom.

Mr. Wrona is very good at thickening the air with mystery, and right from the start he slips in enigmatic details and figures Š—” the prowling bulldozer, a keening woman, a scowling man Š—” that disturb the ordinary scene. Like pebbles dropped in water, these disturbances create concentric circles that spread, disrupting everything. By the time the newlyweds are dancing in the farmhouse barn, surrounded by raucously celebrating, progressively drunk family and friends, the dybbuk has crashed the party. Mr. TiranŠ—Ès moving, expressive performance during the possession has an acrobatic elasticity, with hints of Iggy Pop carnality and eyeball work indebted to Jack Nicholson.

Adam Nimoy interviews stars of the original TV series, as well the astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson and principals in J. J. AbramsŠ—Ès big-screen reboot. Such revelations are candid but distracting, and hopelessly eclipsed by LeonardŠ—Ès formidable charisma. Adam may be a successful director, but Leonard Nimoy was an artist who defined a timeless character.

At the outset of his documentary Š—“For the Love of Spock,Š— the director Adam Nimoy (son of Leonard Nimoy) imparts its origins. HomerŠ—Ès older brother, Marcus (Jack Quaid, Ms. RyanŠ—Ès son), is off fighting, so thereŠ—Ès never much doubt about where this tale is going, and Ms. Ryan doesnŠ—Èt try to spin it for suspense. She instead spends time on the details that make this a transformational period in HomerŠ—Ès life: his relationship with his younger brother, Ulysses (Spencer Howell); his efforts to adapt to the drinking problem of the telegraph operator (Sam Shepard, in a fine performance).
Š—“IthacaŠ— is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for themes of death and loss.

Tom Hanks teams up again with Ms. Ryan in the cast, she as HomerŠ—Ès mother, he as the father who has recently died. This story, though, is the flip side of the war movies and mini-series Mr. Hanks is generally associated with Š—” itŠ—Ès a story of the home front, not of the cacophonous battlefields. In any case, Ms. Ryan and Mr. Hanks are bit players here; the real focus is Alex Neustaedter, a relative newcomer who does a creditable job as Homer (a role played by Mickey Rooney in a 1943 film version).

Ms. RyanŠ—Ès muted approach may be what weŠ—Ève come to expect of looks back at this period Š—” nostalgia always comes with a lot of browns and grays, and with plenty of voice-over (in this case, MarcusŠ—Ès letters to Homer). But she executes the formula well.

Š—“Ithaca,Š— Meg RyanŠ—Ès directorial debut, is a quiet, bittersweet adaptation of the William Saroyan novel Š—“The Human Comedy,Š— a story about a 14-year-old named Homer who delivers telegrams in the small town of the filmŠ—Ès title. ItŠ—Ès 1942, so many of those telegrams contain the worst possible news for the families of soldiers.

The appearances of BrandonŠ—Ès fantasy watchdog lend Š—“KicksŠ— a hallucinatory gloss, infusing the film with a pathos symbolized by BrandonŠ—Ès wishful longing for flashy footwear. His beat-up white sneakers are falling apart. Were he to possess a pair of red-and-black Air Jordans, he would be a big shot Š—” with the shoes conferring instant status. Hoarding pennies, nickels and dimes, he is finally able to purchase them. And for a short time, he confidently strides the neighborhood streets and playgrounds.

What follows is not a cut-and-dried urban horror story. There are gunshots and violence, but Š—“KicksŠ— doesnŠ—Èt take the easiest route. It humanizes Flaco, who, when first seen, is wearing a polished-silver grill that gives him a demonic-looking smile. In his interactions with his son, Flaco is shown to be a caring father.

His pride and sense of belonging end, however, when he is attacked, and his shoes are stolen by Flaco (Kofi Siriboe), who, in turn, gives them to his preadolescent son, Jeremiah (Michael Smith Jr.). Having already thrown away his old sneakers, Brandon is reduced to the humiliation of wearing his motherŠ—Ès bedroom slippers. The theft and its effects are strongly reminiscent of Vittorio De SicaŠ—Ès Š—“The Bicycle Thief.Š—

The characters have enough dimension to avoid appearing to be symbols of a social tragedy, and the movieŠ—Ès relative gentleness makes the harsher realities of BrandonŠ—Ès world all the more distressing. Š—“KicksŠ— portrays an insular culture of poverty and violence in which bored, aimless young people do little beyond smoking dope, drinking beer and competing for power.

Teenage life in the East Bay neighborhood of Richmond, the setting of Justin TippingŠ—Ès promising debut feature film, Š—“Kicks,Š— is so rough that itŠ—Ès little wonder that the movieŠ—Ès 15-year-old protagonist, Brandon (Jahking Guillory), fantasizes that he is watched over by an imaginary spaceman. Because Brandon is small for his age and has delicate features, he is a natural target for bullies. He dwells in an anxious limbo where the harsh realities of big-city life coincide with a childlike longing for a magical escape.

Š—“KicksŠ— follows Brandon as he enlists his two best friends Š—” Rico (Christopher Meyer), a smoothie, and Albert (Christopher Jordan Wallace), a raucous, boastful clown Š—” to accompany him on a mission to retrieve the shoes. Along the way, they visit BrandonŠ—Ès Uncle Marlon (Mahershala Ali), who has a gun that Brandon surreptitiously pockets.

For one magical moment, its hip-hop soundtrack is interrupted by a dreamy blast from the past, when the lush 1974 Blue Magic hit Š—“SideshowŠ— is heard during a Š—“sideshowŠ— exhibition, at which rowdy teenagers spin their cars in circles. Four decades have passed since such sweet R&B ballads flooded the airwaves, and the distance between then and now makes you nostalgic for a soaring teenage romanticism that has all but disappeared.
Š—“KicksŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for violence, drug and alcohol use and sexual content. Running time: 1 hour 20 minutes.

The astronaut, invisible to everyone but him, is a faceless visitor in a crumply spacesuit who floats down from above. He suggests a manifestation of an innocence the boy is not quite ready to surrender. At the same time, Brandon, who occasionally narrates the film, raps his story in a hard-boiled hip-hop argot.

This documentary starts in Cateura, Paraguay, an impoverished town outside Asunci’_n, the countryŠ—Ès capital. There, at an enormous landfill, thousands of slum-dwellers support their families by sifting through trash to find things to sell.

Still, the children of Š—“Landfill HarmonicŠ— are wonderful to watch. A section in which David Ellefson, bassist for the metal band Megadeth, comes to visit them is downright adorable. (The orchestra later performs with the group at a concert, and itŠ—Ès excellent.) Here and elsewhere we see barriers disappear Š—” those between genres, cultures and languages become meaningless. For everyone involved, thereŠ—Ès nothing but joyous music.

Mr. Ch’vez and his students formed the Recycled Orchestra of Cateura and gained fame once video of their playing these scrappy instruments went online. Soon, children whoŠ—Èd never left their town were traveling the world to perform.
The story behind Š—“Landfill HarmonicŠ— is so good that even some imperfect filmmaking canŠ—Èt hold it back.

ItŠ—Ès an inspiring tale Š—” if it were fiction youŠ—Èd dismiss it as unbelievable Š—” and Brad Allgood and Graham Townsley, the directors (Juliana Penaranda-Loftus is listed as co-director), capture some endearing moments. Yet in their interviews they often settle for stock answers rather than digging deeper. And too much time is spent watching the group in routine situations, like traveling. That time could have been better used recording additional performances, or learning more about the playersŠ—È complicated lives. The fascinating instruments also deserve a closer look.

Favio Ch’vez, an environmental engineer, came to the area to help with a recycling program. That failed, but he stayed to teach music to children. Instruments were so scarce that Mr. Ch’vez, with help from a resident, Nicol’s G’_mez, created them from materials found in the garbage heaps. Those include violins made with metal cans, a cello built from an oil container and a drumhead fashioned from discarded X-ray film.

Š—“Everyone is very, very nervous, um, and very unsure of everything,Š— says Julie (Olivia Colman, perfection), a single mother with little sympathy for the victims. The refrain is picked up by other residents, the spoken words sliding imperceptibly into song as Adam CorkŠ—Ès score becomes a libretto of sidewalk anxiety. Slyly turning natural verbal rhythms into eccentric choral numbers, Mr. Cork creates a serial-killer opera whose genius is to transform the banal into something exceptional.

Essential to the spell is the movieŠ—Ès most theatrical conceit: A script, by Alecky Blythe, gleaned entirely from interviews she conducted with the townŠ—Ès residents after the murders of five prostitutes in 2006. Using a technique called verbatim theater (similar to that used by Clio Barnard in her 2011 film, Š—“The ArborŠ—), Ms. Blythe reproduces exact phrases, cadences and speech patterns, including every hem and haw.

Original, audacious, funny and perceptive Š—” a sequence involving the murdered women is unexpectedly haunting Š—” Š—“London RoadŠ— (adapted by the director, Rufus Norris, from his successful London stage musical) will either fascinate or alienate. Yet the artifice of the form works something wondrous with the material, highlighting the generic nature of our response to extreme violence. These events unfolded in Ipswich, but they could have occurred anywhere.

An ungainly yet strangely captivating oddity, Š—“London RoadŠ— snags your attention from the get-go in the manner of any razor-edge experiment: By making you wonder, what on earth? As soon as that question is answered, however, youŠ—Ère hooked, and this unconventional examination of the ripple effect of real-life killings on a quiet English town has worked its curious magic.

In Š—“Other People,Š— David (Jesse Plemons), a gay comedy writer in New York scrambling for a big break, returns to Sacramento to help care for his mother, Joanne (Molly Shannon), who has cancer. That means moving back into a conservative, religious home, and living again with a family from whom heŠ—Ès been estranged. His two younger sisters are supportive, but his father, Norman (Bradley Whitford), has never accepted DavidŠ—Ès sexuality Š—” though Norman says heŠ—Ès always ready to Š—“have that debate.Š— Joanne at least acknowledges that she behaved badly when David first came out 10 years earlier.

A deeply personal film Š—” its writer-director, Chris Kelly, based it on his own experiences Š—” Š—“Other PeopleŠ— chronicles a year in the death of a loved one; a familyŠ—Ès attempt to reconnect; and the welter of issues that leave David feeling as if he is a failure. He and his boyfriend have broken up; he may not have an apartment or a job to return to. Even with tragedy looming, everyday anxieties set his agenda.

Š—“Other PeopleŠ— tries to lighten its heavy load with mixed results. Mr. Kelly, a writer for Š—“Saturday Night Live,Š— adds humorous set pieces that donŠ—Èt mesh well. (This is the summerŠ—Ès second film to juxtapose a dying family member with an improv comedy troupe Š—” Mike BirbigliaŠ—Ès Š—“DonŠ—Èt Think TwiceŠ— is the other.) The easy, comic moments that occur in passing among the characters work better.

Inherently melodramatic, the film belongs to Ms. Shannon, who vividly etches Joanne in a full end-of-life range: funny, loving, angry, regretful, exhausted, resigned. Mr. Plemons, understandably, canŠ—Èt keep up.
Š—“As I Open My EyesŠ— is not rated. It is in Arabic, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 43 minutes.

Š—“As I Open My EyesŠ— is best when it observes the fraught but loving mother-daughter relationship between Hayet and Farah. Farah is so single-minded in her pursuits that she can learn only from experience. And when the hard moment of truth arrives, she crumples.
Ms. Medhaffar has the charisma, if not the voice, of the young Joan Baez, and as Farah she performs with an anguished intensity as a member of Joujma, a fictional band created for the film.

FarahŠ—Ès na’Àvet’© is punctured when a band member is revealed to be a government informer and angrily expelled from the group. Thereafter, an undertone of paranoia seeps through the movie. A distracting, unnecessary sequence about political unrest in the phosphate mines of Gafsa, the hub of the spontaneous uprising, is shoehorned into the film so abruptly it fails to resonate.

FarahŠ—Ès boyfriend, Borhene (Montassar Ayari), who plays the lute, exudes a hipsterŠ—Ès cool. But even he is abashed by her bravado and her willingness to be seen drinking in public places that are traditionally male meeting spots. The two rendezvous in the bushes where they kiss but nothing more.

Š—“I see those deprived of work, of food, of life outside the neighborhood,Š— sings Farah (Baya Medhaffar), a fiery 18-year-old Tunisian singer who lights up Leyla BouzidŠ—Ès film Š—“As I Open My Eyes.Š—

The film is set in 2010, shortly before TunisiaŠ—Ès Jasmine Revolution ushered in the upheavals of the Arab Spring. The song, with lyrics by Ghassen Amami and music by the eminent Iraqi oud player Khyam Allami, protests the repressive government of Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, TunisiaŠ—Ès president for 23 years until he fled the country in 2011. It sets the tone of the film in which word of FarahŠ—Ès dissenting voice reaches the authorities and her safety is endangered.

The movie is a sympathetic portrait of the brash, foolhardy Farah, who lives with her fiercely protective mother, Hayet (Ghalia Benali), though she shares her daughterŠ—Ès rebellious streak. But Hayet has lived long enough to witness the suppression of social upstarts in a religiously and socially conservative climate. With Farah about to enter medical school, Hayet frets that her promising future will be derailed if she continues provoking authority.
Š—“Brother NatureŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for a smattering of sexual humor.

The antics, especially those in which Todd figures, are supposed to be hilarious because Roger is a strait-laced fellow who is on the verge of running for Congress. ThereŠ—Ès an election, all right: Mr. Killam and Mr. Moynihan get themselves voted into the support group for Š—“Saturday Night LiveŠ— cast members and alumni who have been unfunny on the big screen. It is, of course, a big group. The filmŠ—Ès directors, Matt Villines (who died of cancer in July at 39) and Oz Rodriguez, have been credited with some memorable Š—“S.N.L.Š— moments, but they couldnŠ—Èt conjure the magic here.

See (actually, donŠ—Èt see) Š—“Brother Nature,Š— a mind-numbing fish story in which Roger (Taran Killam) spends an uncomfortable few days in the woods with people he hopes will be his future in-laws, among them the oafish Todd (Bobby Moynihan). Roger is trying to propose to his girlfriend, Gwen (Gillian Jacobs), during a mayhem-filled visit to her familyŠ—Ès lake house. He encounters the lakeŠ—Ès legendary giant fish, Gill, as well as a bag of pot-laced potato chips and GwenŠ—Ès other relatives.
Every new generation has to learn the lesson: Comedy success on the small screen doesnŠ—Èt guarantee the same on the big screen. If anything, it guarantees the opposite.

Other familiar stars, like Bill Pullman and Kumail Nanjiani, turn up alongside the Š—“S.N.L.Š— people, none of them able to do much with the wan script by Mr. Killam and Mikey Day (based on a story by Cameron Fay).

Academics used to joke that campus politics were so vicious because the stakes were so small. ThatŠ—Ès no longer the case, at least where the stakes are concerned, as Š—“Starving the BeastŠ— makes clear.

As with any introduction to a multifaceted debate, Š—“Starving the BeastŠ— has some gaps. ThereŠ—Ès no reference, for example, to the big bang of taxpayer revolts Š—” the 1978 passage of Proposition 13 and its continuing impact on CaliforniaŠ—Ès public universities Š—” nor is there enough investigation of individual innovative proposals.
Still, as an overview of the issues, the history and the players, Š—“Starving the BeastŠ— makes a powerful survey course, a prerequisite for further studies.

Thus, some states are sharply cutting their university funding, resulting in steep rises in tuition and student fees. And moves to change the very premise of higher education have led to battles on campuses across the country. Mr. Mims reviews the different conflicts in Texas, Louisiana, Wisconsin, North Carolina and Virginia. The film includes interviews with conservative reformers, but Mr. Mims makes no secret that he stands with the traditionalists.

This documentary by Steve Mims describes an ideological war over public higher education that is being conducted state by state. Trying to reframe college as a consumer product, free-market advocates proudly brandish a Š—“disrupt and reformŠ— credo that would apply business-world values and metrics to state universities. If itŠ—Ès a business Š—” not a public responsibility Š—” then it dovetails nicely with the small-government movement to Š—“starve the beast.Š—

Mr. EastwoodŠ—Ès filmmaking is expedient (no fuss, no muss), detailed and distinguished by sudden beauty, as when Sully, after the accident, stands alone while framed against the wintry lead-gray sky out of which he just fell. Mr. Eastwood is a musician, and he plays with the storyŠ—Ès competing moods and rhythms with suppleness, setting one scene to the steady beat of everyday life, only to amp another until it races like a thudding heart. The accident, which remains unnervingly in the register of the real, is a master class in direction, as the reassuring engine hum gives way to a spooky near-silence thatŠ—Ès soon punctured by gasps, cries and terrifying shouts: Š—“Brace, brace! Heads down, stay down!Š—

You spend a lot of time staring at Mr. HanksŠ—Ès face, which, when watched in IMAX, looms as large as an Easter Island colossus. Mr. Eastwood, working with his longtime director of photography Tom Stern, shot most of Š—“SullyŠ— using large-format digital cameras, and so everything on a really big screen is really big, Mr. HanksŠ—Ès head included. At first, this bigness seems off-kilter, even distracting, perhaps because immensity in movies tends to serve visual spectacle. Here, SullyŠ—Ès face is a landscape as vast as a western tableau, full of mystery and, over time, a means for the storyŠ—Ès radical subjectivity.

It seems improbable that an entire movie could be built on the minutes from US Airways Flight 1549Š—Ès takeoff to the instant it flew into a flock of Canada geese that was sucked into both engines (Š—“ingested,Š— in aviation parlance), leading to an almost complete loss of thrust, and its miracle landing. But movie time can be magical in how it bends reality, rather like plane travel, though much depends on how filmmakers play with space-time, freezing events, sliding into the past, only to jump back to the now, as Mr. Eastwood fluidly does. Here, a few minutes open one manŠ—Ès life, revealing layers of consciousness that, in turn, lay bare that lifeŠ—Ès moral center.

The tension ebbs and flows as the story shifts among moments in time and states of consciousness. There are blah generic scenes with SullyŠ—Ès worried wife (Laura Linney) and glimpses of his past (he learned to fly as a teenager); mostly, there is the friction that Mr. Eastwood generates from the investigation, the accident and SullyŠ—Ès imaginary variations on the same. Mr. Eastwood bluntly drops in these imaginings, so itŠ—Ès not always immediately clear whether youŠ—Ère watching a fantasy, a strategy that intensifies their power. These illusions are manifestations of SullyŠ—Ès worst, otherwise mostly unarticulated, fears, like disaster flicks dredged from his depths. And because weŠ—Ère the only ones who see them, we become his secret sharer, or maybe confessor, which amplifies the movieŠ—Ès intimacy.

Clint EastwoodŠ—Ès latest movie, Š—“Sully,Š— is about a man who is excellent at his job. Specifically, it tells the story of Capt. Chesley Sullenberger and how, on a frigid January afternoon in 2009, he came to land a plane on the Hudson River. The movie is economical and solid, and generally low-key when itŠ—Ès not freaking you out. That it unnerves you as much as it does may seem surprising, given that going in, we know how this story ends. But Mr. Eastwood is also very good at his job, a talent that gives the movie its tension along with an autobiographical sheen.

Heroism has long been one of Mr. EastwoodŠ—Ès themes as an actor and a director, though his portraits tend to be complicated by an annihilating violence often unthinkable in the classical Hollywood days. Draped in black, as if swathed in mourning crepe, some of his most memorable later movies explore the tragic consequences of violence, which runs through communities and individuals alike. TheyŠ—Ère profoundly, sometimes uncomfortably, American testaments. By contrast, thereŠ—Ès no tragedy in Š—“Sully,Š— just sighs of relief, probing questions and an outwardly uncomplicated hero whose extraordinariness is so deeply imbued that it is finally the most ordinary thing about him. You might think that Mr. Eastwood had mellowed, but the very singularity of this movieŠ—Ès hero suggests otherwise.

Mr. Hanks slips into Sully easily, with a grandfatherly wreath of white hair, a tidy mustache and an air of steadfast, professional calm thatŠ—Ès only occasionally beaded in sweat. ItŠ—Ès hard to imagine anyone else in the role, except perhaps for an older Matt Damon, another actor who conveys the old-fashioned, stoic heroism that movie companies have been outsourcing to Australian actors for years. So many younger actors read as slier than Mr. Hanks, whose appeal has always been that he seems like an awfully nice guy. It takes talent to persuade a mass audience that youŠ—Ère decency incarnate, but Mr. Hanks goes one better by making decency into something like soul.

The story largely involves what happens after Sully (Tom Hanks), his crew and his passengers were plucked from the river, specifically the investigation by the National Transportation Safety Board. The investigators, a panel of long-faced, mostly male judges, poke and prod at Sully and his co-pilot, Jeff Skiles (a sturdy Aaron Eckhart), forcing them to defend ditching the plane into the Hudson. Framed as a series of face-offs, the inquiry registers as more testy than adversarial, and the casting of comfortably familiar character actors Š—” Anna Gunn, Jamey Sheridan and the affable-looking Mike OŠ—ÈMalley Š—” implies that these sleuths arenŠ—Èt inquisitors, just rolling up their sleeves to get right to work.
Š—“SullyŠ— is rated PG-13 (parents strongly cautioned). If youŠ—Ère afraid of flying, consider yourself warned. Running time: 1 hour 36 minutes.

Š—“SullyŠ— is a portrait of a hero Š—” Mr. SullenbergerŠ—Ès decision to land the plane on the Hudson helped save 155 lives, his own included Š—” but one who, after the accident, is troubled both by what might have been (death, destruction) and by an unassuming manŠ—Ès discomfort with the spotlight. Sully isnŠ—Èt cut along the cynically frayed lines of assorted current screen heroes, with their nihilism lite and butchery, nor does he fit the existential mode, the man in revolt, like Jason Bourne. Sully is hewed from more classical stuff; heŠ—Ès the hero whose dignity, as Lionel Trilling wrote, Š—“is wholly manifest in word and deed, in physique and comportment.Š— Yet Sully is also very much alone, separated by ability and character, as well as by all the directorial choices that isolate him.

Long after our screening of the animated feature Š—“The Wild Life,Š— my almost-10-year-old companion was still chatting about the filmŠ—Ès amusing animal characters. And judging from the sounds emitted during that screening, I suspect that younger children in the audience liked it even more.
Oh, and cat worshipers beware. Evil felines are the persistent villains of this film, poor mangy things.

Sad to say, his role is cut short, possibly because of the exigencies of plot. Š—“The Wild LifeŠ— is, very loosely, a Robinson Crusoe story, and it requires a local wingman Š—” in this case a macaw Tuesday instead of a man Friday Š—” or a dog Aynsley. The mild-mannered young Crusoe (voiced by Yuri Lowenthal) is marooned on an island inhabited by a collaborative bunch of talking animals, including a pangolin, a tapir, a chameleon and a billy goat. The movie stresses the interdependence of the species and how humans can not only fit into the animalsŠ—È society but also learn to adapt and work with them.
Š—“The Wild LifeŠ— is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for perilous situations.

Directed by Vincent Kesteloot, Š—“The Wild LifeŠ— is pretty to look at, with its skies and ocean, calm or stormy, and it has a driving soundtrack. But the story lacks that extra layer of complexity and meaning that parents can appreciate.

While my seat mate found more joy in the film than I did, we agreed emphatically on one thing: The dog named Aynsley Š—” practical, smart and amiable, with an endearing Scottish burr Š—” enlivens the movie greatly.

Though rife with implausibilities, Š—“TranspecosŠ— is fortified by strong acting and a location whose desolate beauty is a gift to Jeffrey WaldronŠ—Ès serene camera. Shot mostly outdoors in Luna County, N.M., the action is framed by purple mountains and arid dunes, the plot advanced by scuffed footprints in the sand and the itinerant souls Š—” a human coyote; a Maya healer Š—” who make them. In the background, the drug cartels operate largely unseen, yet are integral to the story and to the agentsŠ—È vulnerabilities.

At least, Mr. Kwedar (who wrote the screenplay with Clint Bentley) would like us to believe the menŠ—Ès options are intractable. But that would only be true if doubling down on a criminal act were, in this case, anything but foolish. The would-be felon is Davis (Johnny Simmons), a nervous Border Patrol rookie whose secret comes to light when a routine vehicle stop turns nasty. As his empathetic superior (Gabriel Luna) and the groupŠ—Ès eagle-eyed veteran (Clifton Collins Jr.) process this revelation in markedly different ways, the movie embarks on a dusty trek through violent confrontations and moral compromise.

Accomplishing a lot with very little, Greg Kwedar compresses his first feature, Š—“Transpecos,Š— into a single day and night at a remote outpost in the Chihuahuan Desert, where three United States Border Patrol agents will face tough choices.

Leaving politics aside, Mr. Kwedar (who, as a college student, crossed the United States-Mexico border often to do relief work) creates an ethical setup thatŠ—Ès as micro as it gets. On this unforgiving boundary, his sympathy is all that moves freely from one side to the other.

John, a high-powered lawyer, is forced to be the type of inconsistent character you need to make this brand of story work: really smart, except when he needs to not be. His decision-making when Anna starts coming on to him Š—” this woman will bathe or shower at almost any time of day Š—” is pretty terrible. His wife, though, isnŠ—Èt around to see a lot of it because, conveniently, she has to make a business trip.

Perhaps you were wondering if it were still possible to wring any suspense out of an unbalanced-third-wheel plot. Š—“When the Bough Breaks,Š— about a surrogate pregnancy gone horribly wrong, has a definitive answer: No, it isnŠ—Èt.

Š—“When the Bough BreaksŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for a lot of titillation. Running time: 1 hour 47 minutes.

Mr. Kenner interviews many of the participants, including David F. Powell and Jeffrey L. Plumb, who were just a couple of young grunts doing their jobs when Mr. Powell mishandled a metal socket, which fell some 70 feet and punctured the TitanŠ—Ès fuel tank. Mr. Powell speaks movingly about how the moment has haunted him.

There are heroes in the story, men who went back into the silo after it was evacuated as part of the containment effort. One was killed and many were injured when the explosion Š—” a nonnuclear one Š—” came. And, this being the military, some of the heroism was rewarded with discipline rather than honors.

American military history is full of misguided wars, botched battles and scandals of all sorts, so itŠ—Ès no secret that there is fallibility all through the ranks. But the events chronicled in Š—“Command and Control,Š— a documentary by Robert Kenner based on the book by Eric Schlosser, are terrifying nonetheless. The film effectively recreates the sense of confusion over how to try to contain the leak and what might happen if the fuel ignited. The Titan carried the most destructive nuclear warhead in the arsenal; a good chunk of Arkansas, whose governor at the time was Bill Clinton, could have been affected had it exploded or had its nuclear contaminants been spewed across the landscape.

The film recounts in harrowing detail an accident in a Titan II missile silo in Arkansas in September 1980 caused by the most innocuous of mistakes: An airman doing routine maintenance dropped a piece of equipment. The ordinariness of the precipitating event and how unprepared officials were to deal with it are shocking.

Perhaps most alarmingly, the film notes just how commonplace the Arkansas accident was Š—” there have been plenty of other accidents involving nuclear weapons. Since 1980, our weaponry has grown far more sophisticated; whether the sophistication of its handlers has grown as well is something youŠ—Èll be pondering after the ending credits roll.

Marianne has her own idea of how she wants it told. But Mr. Fassaert is invested in unearthing the secrets behind MarianneŠ—Ès past behavior (which sheŠ—Ès coyly reluctant about divulging), and why she now wants to reclaim her family.

Mr. FassaertŠ—Ès resolute focus on MarianneŠ—Ès determined acts of rudeness make the pictureŠ—Ès narrative sluggish in sections. By the jaw-dropping climax (an argument over a family portrait), and the filmŠ—Ès not-entirely unpredictable denouement, you arenŠ—Èt sure whether you are witnessing an investigative family chronicle or an act of revenge.

MarianneŠ—Ès self-absorption and her demand for the adoration and fealty of the still-suffering family she abandoned, come off as monstrous. The Dutch documentarian Tom Fassaert (Š—“An Angel in DoelŠ—) delves into his own painful family history in the peculiar Š—“A Family Affair.Š— The film begins with Mr. FassaertŠ—Ès 95-year-old grandmother, Marianne Cilliers, summoning the filmmaker to her home in South Africa. Š—“Blair WitchŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Gross stupidity.

ItŠ—Ès a lot of suffering with very little payoff. In 1999,  Š—“The Blair Witch ProjectŠ—  was a milestone of low-budget, found-footage horror. And Mr. Wingard does, from time to time, but without summoning the deeper dread or the sharper wit that might make this movie anything more than an elementary exercise.

One of LisaŠ—Ès friends, James (James Allen McCune), is the brother of Heather, an original Blair Witch victim. Š—“Blair Witch,Š— directed by Adam Wingard, is a movie about the futility of filmmaking. The four meet two other pilgrims who have more primitive camcorders, and the 89 minutes of screaming, flashlight waving and falling trees we are watching has supposedly been assembled from the images these luckless souls gathered during their ordeal.

Š—“Can you read cursive?,Š— Willie, a denizen of skid row, asks strangers in Knate LeeŠ—Ès new film, Š—“Cardboard Boxer.Š— He needs their help deciphering the singed journal he retrieved from the debris of a fire. Its author, a child, received the diary from her dying mother.

He writes back, laboriously, with his stub of pencil, then launches his letters as paper airplanes from a Los Angeles rooftop.

But while he may have a gentle soul, at times his innocence makes you wonder how he survives on the street. He steps forward, eager to please when rich kids show up with a video camera. They offer him $50, an arena where he can shine and a hollow promise of friendship. All he has to do is slug it out with another street person Š—” and win.
WillieŠ—Ès own circumstances are enough to make you weep. He thinks nothing of leaning against a trash can as if it were a piece of furniture, or dipping into one to scoop up a half-eaten burger.

Mr. Church fully inhabits the character, making the most of WillieŠ—Ès dented moral sense and his many limitations. Willie blossoms when he enters this childŠ—Ès broken world, and he does make a friend, Pinky (Boyd Holbrook), a legless veteran who carries his treasured Purple Heart everywhere. Pinky consents to read the cursive script to Willie. They share the raw pain of the childŠ—Ès descent from grief into hopelessness.

ThereŠ—Ès more of that in this ponderous documentary, in which Mr. LaChapelleŠ—Ès video is featured, as well as background music like Black SabbathŠ—Ès Š—“Iron Man.Š— A prodigious talent from Ukraine with a determined stage mother, Mr. Polunin is a controversial figure in the ballet world. Š—“DancerŠ— is not rated. In English, Russian and Ukrainian, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 25 minutes.

At the Royal, Mr. Polunin, fueled by drugs and alcohol, earned one of balletŠ—Ès most clich’©d labels: bad boy. And he is still at it. This November, he will appear in a program with his girlfriend, the ballerina Natalia Osipova, at City Center. Has Mr. PoluninŠ—Ès flame burned out? Perhaps the only way to know is to see him in the flesh.

At its core, Š—“DancerŠ— focuses on Mr. PoluninŠ—Ès relationship with his family and how his parentsŠ—È divorce Š—” while he was a student at the Royal Ballet School Š—” reverberates throughout his career. His teenage period was tougher. After his parents announced their separation, he recalled: Š—“I was like, IŠ—Èm never going to be upset again, and I will never suffer and I will never miss anybody and I donŠ—Èt want any memories about anything. That was the last time I cried for years.Š—

Š—“Finding AltamiraŠ— Š—” Hugh HudsonŠ—Ès stately account of events surrounding the discovery of Paleolithic cave paintings in northern Spain in 1879 Š—” addresses a fascinating chapter in archaeology. In Antonio Banderas, Mr. Hudson has a winning de Sautuola of personal modesty, scientific integrity and paternal warmth. And who are among Hillsong UnitedŠ—Ès 11 musical evangelists? Š—“He can move the mountains.Š— Š—“I was blind but now I see.Š— Those lines are but drops in the torrent of clich’©s saturating Michael John WarrenŠ—Ès narcotizing documentary Š—“Hillsong Š—” Let Hope Rise,Š— centered on a concert the Australian Christian band Hillsong United gave at the Forum in Los Angeles in 2014.

The group grew out of Hillsong Church, a Pentecostal ministry founded by Brian Houston and his wife, Bobbie, in a Sydney suburb in the early 1980s. The movie compounds that bit of tastelessness with a direct reference to the 2012 mass shooting at an elementary school in Newtown, Conn. When will it be acceptable to name-check Newtown in a lame comedy? Probably never, but certainly not in 2016.

Perhaps an amusing movie could be made out of that idea, but it would have to contain a lot less bad taste than this one does. Ha, ha! WhatŠ—Ès funnier than a school shooting?

The acting across the board is wooden, and the scriptŠ—Ès efforts to work in a message or two land with a thud. If you want to see a modern take on Š—“Lysistrata,Š— stick with Spike LeeŠ—Ès Š—“Chi-Raq.Š—
Š—“Is That a Gun in Your Pocket? ... Š— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for crass sexual humor.

Everybody involved with the awful comedy Š—“Is That a Gun in Your Pocket?...Š— owes Aristophanes an apology. ItŠ—Ès one thing to borrow a guyŠ—Ès premise; itŠ—Ès quite another to transform it into something this unwatchable.
NEIL GENZLINGER

Rachel is still grieving over the recent death of her mother, an actress. And when her composure suddenly cracks, she needs comfort. If the nearest person who offers a shoulder to cry on is a student, she accepts it with full awareness of the pitfalls.

The combustible and manically energetic Billy (Timoth’©e Chalamet), the most talented of the three young actors, is an out-of-control rebel, desperate for a secure emotional connection. A high point of the movie is his explosive delivery of a monologue from Š—“Death of a SalesmanŠ— during the competition. Mr. Chalamet suggests a younger, more high-strung James Dean.

Margot (Lili Reinhart), who resembles the very young Cybill Shepherd, is curt and officious on the outside and deeply self-doubting underneath. The chatty and openly gay Sam (Anthony Quintal) is eager to explore internet hookups when away from home. The conveniently pat resolution of his frustrations is the movieŠ—Ès one false note.

While acknowledging the erotic undertow of student-teacher relationships, the movie doesnŠ—Èt descend to prurience. In the eyes of a contemporary high-school student, it suggests, a caring teacher is less a mysterious authority figure than a surrogate older sibling. Ms. RabeŠ—Ès beautifully balanced performance reminds you that people never really grow up.

If youŠ—Ère a young high school teacher, should you lower formal barriers and allow a favorite student to address you by your first name? ThatŠ—Ès one of the temptations facing the title character of Julia HartŠ—Ès modest, warmhearted directorial debut, Š—“Miss Stevens.Š—

Something of a teenager herself, Rachel is a bit reckless. Single and lonely, she has a one-night fling with a married teacher (Rob Huebel) from another high school. His polite rejection when she returns to his room the next night leaves her bitterly stung. For all her frailty, she is immensely likable and devoted. Her willingness to test boundaries is portrayed as a strength: a sign of her passionate dedication to her profession, which for her is not just a job but a calling.

The film, which stars Lily Rabe (Š—“American Horror StoryŠ—) as Rachel Stevens, a 29-year-old English teacher who chaperones three of her students during a trip to an acting competition somewhere in California, comes down gently on the side of carefully loosening traditional boundaries. At the same time, it shows how hard it can be for a teacher to resist befriending bright, attractive adolescents burning with curiosity and a desire for personal contact. Rachel may be the supervising adult, but her charges are computer-savvy, can talk the talk of grown-ups and are far from na’Àve.

The screenplay by Ms. Hart and Jordan Horowitz suggests that the biggest difference between adolescence and adulthood is in the degree of impulse control. The students heedlessly throw themselves into new experiences, whereas Rachel thinks before she acts, if not always wisely. Instead of the backbiting and one-upmanship in so many high-school movies, the students here are offer mutual support.
Š—“Miss StevensŠ— is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 37 minutes.

Turning lack of sophistication into a virtue is a skill that the filmmaking hyphenate Matt Johnson has in abundance. Three years ago, he directed and starred in his first feature, Š—“The Dirties,Š— a shrewd commentary on the warped relationship between image and reality. Now he and his prime collaborator, Owen Williams, are back to poke that beast some more with Š—“Operation Avalanche,Š— a Cold War comedy-thriller pulsing with paranoia.

Packed with peekaboo shots through curtains and door grilles, Š—“Operation AvalancheŠ— weaves well-known conspiracy theories into a goofily entertaining satire of youthful ambition co-opted as a tool of government intrigue. Working from no more than a story outline, which he wrote with Josh Boles, Mr. Johnson creates a credible world of Brylcreemed hair and back-room confabs. Old newsreels and radio broadcasts rattle and hum in the background as the cinematographers, Jared Raab and Andrew Appelle, deliver an endlessly diverting stream of images that drift teasingly in and out of focus.

This mischievous, winking sensibility lends lightness and bounce to a story thatŠ—Ès not without menace and even some pathos. Yet thereŠ—Ès a headlong temerity to Mr. JohnsonŠ—Ès style that places the dippy thrill of moviemaking front and center, revealing a director (and a character) so high on his power to misrepresent reality that a future in politics seems all but assured.
Š—“Operation AvalancheŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Reds under the bed and something nasty in the garage. Running time: 1 hour 33 minutes.

The look at times is early Š—“Twilight ZoneŠ— (achieved with a custom-built camera and vintage French lenses), while Tristan ZerafaŠ—Ès cool visual effects Š—” which sneak Kubrick into the action using only still photographs Š—” make the lunar lunacy work. As do the actual NASA employees who appear onscreen, unwitting dupes of Mr. Johnson and his crew, who schmoozed their way into the Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center in Texas under the guise of making a documentary.

Playing Matt and Owen Š—” a pair of Ivy League movie nerds recruited by the C.I.A. in 1965 to investigate the likelihood that the director Stanley Kubrick is a spy Š—” the two soon find themselves in deeper, darker waters. When a wiretap reveals that NASA could lose the space race to the Soviets, they persuade their superiors to let them fake a moon landing Š—” a ruse that will require infiltrating the set of KubrickŠ—Ès Š—“2001: A Space Odyssey.Š— ThatŠ—Ès if they can elude the mole who might be filming them.
