In the opening scene, Bridget celebrates her 43rd birthday with a cupcake speared with a single candle as the song Š—“All by Myself,Š— heard in the first film, bleats on the soundtrack. When the music abruptly segues to House of PainŠ—Ès Š—“Jump Around,Š— a lip-syncing Bridget leaps onto her bed and bounces up and down like a 7-year-old on a sugar high. But Bridget has grown up in one significant way: Her obsession with diet and weight loss has subsided, and at long last she seems at peace with her body.

In the new movie, directed by Sharon Maguire, from a screenplay by Helen Fielding (BridgetŠ—Ès creator), Dan Mazer and Emma Thompson (who also stars), Bridget is now a successful producer of a cheesy television news show. On the broadcast, Bridget feeds its newscaster, her pal Miranda (Sarah Solemani), text from the sidelines.

When Š—“Bridget JonesŠ—Ès Diary,Š— the first novel in Ms. FieldingŠ—Ès series, was published in 1996 (the screen adaptation arrived five years later), the term millennial had been coined but not yet popularized. The new movie acknowledges generational turnover by giving Bridget a cold but kooky new boss (Kate OŠ—ÈFlynn) who spouts enigmatic gobbledygook in an affectedly lowbrow accent. But itŠ—Ès not enough to make Š—“Bridget JonesŠ—Ès BabyŠ— feel remotely up-to-date. A welcome splash of cold water is provided by Ms. Thompson in her sensible nanny mode, playing BridgetŠ—Ès unflappably severe gynecologist.
Š—“Bridget JonesŠ—Ès BabyŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for some strong language, sexual references and nudity. Running time: 1 hour 58 minutes.

Despite an abundance of mostly tepid jokes that keeps the comedic tone at a quiet simmer, Š—“Bridget JonesŠ—Ès BabyŠ— doesnŠ—Èt jell. Ms. Zellweger floats through the picture, charming but strangely detached from her suitors. When she finally goes into labor, she is rushed to the hospital by Jack and Mark, who carry her through the streets and brave the predictable impediments Š—” a traffic jam and a demonstration. In the funniest farcical moment (not very), the three are stuck in a revolving door at the hospitalŠ—Ès entrance.
Yawn. Life on Planet C is so very Š—” 20th century.

Who could dislike Bridget Jones, the zany screwball heroine whose latest and probably last screen incarnation, in Š—“Bridget JonesŠ—Ès Baby,Š— finds the character back where she started: alone and single?

The other possible father is BridgetŠ—Ès old flame Mark Darcy (Colin Firth), who is so dour that when he flashes a smile late in the movie you half expect a heavenly choir to erupt with hosannas. Mr. FirthŠ—Ès caricature of scowling British reserve masking a tender heart is pitch perfect. Because Bridget is afraid to have the amniocentesis procedure that would reveal the babyŠ—Ès paternity, the rest of the movie is a guessing game with no surprises.

Like the recent Š—“Absolutely Fabulous: The Movie,Š— or the film spinoffs of Š—“Sex and the City,Š— Š—“Bridget JonesŠ—Ès BabyŠ— trades on nostalgia for the charactersŠ—È quaint misbehavior and silly fantasies of yesteryear. Ren’©e Zellweger, crinkly eyed and adorable at 47, plays a more poised and confident Bridget, still chasing what she calls Š—“happily ever after.Š— But the question nags: What planet does she think she inhabits? The London shown here might as well be Planet C, as in cute.

Yet you have to wonder: A decade and a half on, does Bridget still have a place in a popular culture where the carbonated dreamland of romantic comedy is hardening into a sexual battleground and the very notion of Prince Charming seems an increasingly ludicrous anachronism?

What follows are a series of mildly farcical misadventures that revolve around BridgetŠ—Ès unexpected pregnancy after dalliances with two dreamboats who appear as if summoned by a genie. The most unlikely, Jack (Patrick Dempsey), is the unctuous American billionaire founder of a dating website who pulls her out of the mud at the Glastonbury music festival, which she attends with Miranda and which the movie portrays as a cheap, gaudy circus. The friends are so clueless about contemporary music that they donŠ—Èt recognize the singer-songwriter Ed Sheeran when they ask him to take their picture.

Jason Cohen, the director, neatly illustrates how the company presaged current trends in technology. HeŠ—Ès also good at generating lighthearted moments with old footage Š—” cheesy advertisements, bulky machines and cringe-worthy fashions make you thankful the 1980s are over.

You wonŠ—Èt walk away with a degree in business or psychology after watching Š—“Silicon Cowboys.Š— But this documentary leaves you with a curious feeling that youŠ—Ève earned college credit in both, and gotten a few laughs as well.

The film, a fast-moving account of the start-up and rise of Compaq Computer, grounds itself in people as well as technology, and that makes the lessons especially engaging. Founded in the early 1980s by Rod Canion, Jim Harris and Bill Murto, the plucky company embraced some brash ideas Š—” compatibility, portable personal computers Š—” at an extraordinarily opportune time.

To be sure, the script, by Mr. Cohen and Steven Leckart, uses broad generalizations to explain events, and is exceedingly sympathetic to the company (the film is based on a book by Mr. Canion). ThereŠ—Ès a fascinating film to be made about CompaqŠ—Ès later years, when it was sold in a contentious deal.

In short order these gee-whiz friends went from sketching plans on scraps of paper to wearing three-piece suits and thick glasses to present their products to customers and investors. Not long after, they were trouncing the monolith that was IBM. Davids sometimes mature into Goliaths, though, and at the end we see Compaq losing focus and stumbling, about a decade after its founding.

Yet on its own, Š—“Silicon CowboysŠ— prizes the human drama behind business events, much as in Š—“The Social NetworkŠ— or Š—“Steve Jobs.Š— Those films, too, pretended that technology was the star. But they knew that people were the real story.

But while the script, which the director wrote with Kieran Fitzgerald, dutifully footnotes the more abstruse references Š—” and explains the mechanics of surveillance with admirable clarity Š—” Mr. Stone remains an old-school humanist, a poet of flesh and blood rather than a deep thinker about technology or politics. Nearly all of his films are ultimately about taking the measure of a man, and Š—“SnowdenŠ— is most effective as a character study. As ever, Mr. StoneŠ—Ès interest in women is limited. They provide pictorial variety and emotional complication, challenging and humanizing the heroes as the story requires. Ms. Woodley has more screen time than Sissy Spacek in Š—“J.F.K.Š— or Joan Allen in Š—“Nixon,Š— but she is, in effect, portraying an updated version of the loyal, long-suffering, uncomprehending wife.

Like those young men in a hurry, Edward falls under the sway of two antithetical father figures, a silky apparatchik played by Rhys Ifans, and an unbuttoned renegade played by Nicolas Cage. Drawn to intelligence work out of a sincere desire to serve his country, Edward is not immune to other attractions of the job. He likes the intrigue, the money (especially after he becomes a private contractor) and the feeling of being part of a select group of insiders who know how things really work.

Still, the relationship between Lindsay and Edward is the key to the film, since it establishes what is at stake for the hero as he faces the conflicting demands of love and duty. It also affirms that he is a nice, normal, humble guy, neither a zealot nor an egomaniac. Not everyone will agree with this Š—” Donald J. Trump, Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama are all prominent nonmembers of the Edward Snowden fan club Š—” but Š—“SnowdenŠ— makes its case with skill and discretion.

But he is not a figure of operatic, tragic ambition in the mold of Richard M. Nixon, Jim Morrison or Alexander the Great (at least as Mr. Stone imagined them). Nerdy in aspect and phlegmatic in manner, Edward never takes a drink or chases a skirt. (His girlfriend, Lindsay Mills, is played by Shailene Woodley.) And Š—“SnowdenŠ— is, by Mr. StoneŠ—Ès standards, a strikingly sober film. Restraint shows in both the filmmaking and the politics. There are very few wild, bravura visual flights and not much in the way of wild conspiracymongering. Edward is a rational, ethical creature Š—” Š—“responsibilityŠ— is one of his favorite words Š—” and the movie takes pains to be reasonable. Its basic argument about government data-collection would not be out of place on the Op-Ed page of this or any other newspaper. And its dialogue and pacing would work just fine on television.

Maybe Mr. Stone has mellowed, or maybe the world has caught up with him. What used to be paranoia Š—” the idea, say, that your electronic appliances are spying on you Š—” looks nowadays like blunt realism. It can also seem as if the physical world, that bloody, sex-infused battleground of the self where previous Stone heroes have raged and fought, had been displaced by a more abstract zone of codes and algorithms. Edward passes from one realm to the other when an injury ends his career as a United States Army Ranger. Š—“There are lots of ways to serve your country,Š— the doctor tells him, and soon enough, his bosses at the C.I.A. and the N.S.A. are explaining that the real war is being waged on computer and cellular networks.

In the context of this directorŠ—Ès career, Š—“SnowdenŠ— is both a return to form and something of a departure. Mr. Stone circles back to the grand questions of power, war and secrecy that have propelled his most ambitious work, and finds a hero who fits a familiar Oliver Stone mold. Edward (Joseph Gordon-Levitt, leaning hard on a vocal imitation) is presented as a disillusioned idealist, a serious young man whose experiences lead him to doubt accepted truths and question the wisdom of authority. He has something in common with Jim Garrison in Š—“J.F.K.Š— and Ron Kovic in Š—“Born on the Fourth of July,Š— and also with Chris Taylor and Bud Fox, the characters played by Charlie Sheen in Š—“PlatoonŠ— and Š—“Wall Street.Š—

At times, I found myself wishing that it would go further Š—” that it would feel angrier, crazier, more frightening. But that would have made it easier to shake, and perhaps also to dismiss. This movie wonŠ—Èt necessarily dazzle or enrage you, and IŠ—Èm not sure that it wants to. What it wants Š—” what Mr. Snowden himself always claims to have wanted Š—” is to bother you, to fill you with doubt about the good intentions of those who gather your data and tell you itŠ—Ès for your own protection.

Oliver StoneŠ—Ès Š—“Snowden,Š— a quiet, crisply drawn portrait of the worldŠ—Ès most celebrated whistle-blower, belongs to a curious subgenre of movies about very recent historical events. Reversing the usual pattern, it could be described as a fictional Š—“making ofŠ— feature about Š—“Citizenfour,Š— Laura PoitrasŠ—Ès Oscar-winning documentary on the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden. That film seems to me more likely to last Š—” it is deeper journalism and more haunting cinema Š—” but Mr. Stone has made an honorable and absorbing contribution to the imaginative record of our confusing times. He tells a story torn from slightly faded headlines, filling in some details you may have forgotten, and discreetly embellishing the record in the service of drama and suspense.

Mr. Stone, well served by his cinematographer, the digital wizard Anthony Dod Mantle, and the composers Craig Armstrong and Adam Peters, evokes the chilly colorations and spooky undertones of our technological reality. The Hong Kong hotel room where Edward meets with Ms. Poitras (Melissa Leo) and the journalists Glenn Greenwald (Zachary Quinto) and Ewen MacAskill (Tom Wilkinson) is an eerie futuristic box. SnowdenŠ—Ès workplaces in Geneva, Tokyo and Oahu are hives full of glowing screens and whispered jargon.

Š—“SnowdenŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Dark secrets, strong language and a trip to a strip club in the interests of national security. Running time: 2 hours 18 minutes.
The film ends inconclusively: In February, a judge ruled that the women should be given a new trial but stopped short of declaring their innocence, the outcome their lawyers sought.

Š—“Southwest of SalemŠ— picks up work that began long before a film crew arrived, but the director, Deborah S. Esquenazi, bears witness to crucial moments, such as one of the nieces, now an adult, remorsefully recanting her accusations, and later reuniting with her aunt, Ms. Ramirez. We watch Ms. Vasquez, on parole, experience a changed world. (She finds that she relates to prison shows.)

Š—“Southwest of Salem: The Story of the San Antonio FourŠ— concerns four Texas women Š—” Elizabeth Ramirez, Anna Vasquez, Cassandra Rivera and Kristie Mayhugh Š—” who were  sentenced to prison after two young nieces of Ms. Ramirez accused the four of sexual assault. The documentary persuasively argues that the charges were wildly implausible, and that homophobia against the women, who had been in lesbian relationships, contributed to the convictions.

The case is portrayed as an example of the satanic ritual-abuse panic of the 1980s and Š—È90s. It is shown as a cause for the Innocence Project of Texas and for Debbie Nathan, a journalist also seen in Š—“Capturing the Friedmans,Š— a film about a Long Island family caught up in sexual-abuse allegations.

The context of interspersed home videos might have been made clearer. Mostly, though, Š—“Southwest of SalemŠ— proceeds with what have become sobering tropes for true-crime documentaries: a defendant saying she didnŠ—Èt realize she needed a lawyer; outsiders explaining how they grew convinced of a miscarriage of justice.

In a device that reminded me of Š—“Beasts of the Southern Wild,Š— much of the action Š—” between the lovers Wawa and Dain, and the feuding tribes Š—” is observed by Selin (Marceline Rofit), a young girl. An eye-opening scene sees arranged marriage defended via the example of Prince Philip and Queen Elizabeth II. (A religious faction in Tanna considers Prince Philip a divinity.) Despite its best efforts, Š—“TannaŠ— drifts into a mode of exoticism that renders it an ultimately frustrating experience.

Named for the remote South Pacific island where it was filmed, Š—“TannaŠ— is a movie in which every single shot is picturesque, and more than a few of them are genuinely beautiful. For a North American viewer, it may serve two functions of cinema: showing a remote and unfamiliar place and culture, while also kicking up questions of how Western cinema sees cultural difference.

Many tribes on Tanna, part of the nation Vanuatu, avoid modern modes of living, and it is among these people that the movie takes place. The story is about opposed tribes, their attempts to make peace and two lovers who rebel after one is steered into an arranged marriage. It has affinities with Š—“Romeo and Juliet,Š— as well as Š—“Tabu,Š— the South Seas picture by the cinematic masters F. W. Murnau and Robert J. Flaherty in 1931. But the filmmakers Bentley Dean and Martin Butler, who wrote the Š—“TannaŠ— screenplay with John Collee, and credit the story to the Š—“real-life people of YakelŠ— (a village whose inhabitants also perform most of the filmŠ—Ès roles), state that the picture is based on events that had a genuine impact on the islandŠ—Ès tribal culture.

The film is a project of Apple Corps, the BeatlesŠ—È company, so donŠ—Èt expect a warts-and-all portrait Š—” in this telling, the band members never misbehaved significantly or had creative differences. The way to watch is to ignore the image burnishing and just feel the moment.
Nah.

But he effectively conveys just how insane these years were. The Beatles werenŠ—Èt the first to make women scream and faint Š—” dial up footage of Frank Sinatra or Elvis Presley at his peak Š—” but the pace and scale astonish even today. Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr, the surviving Beatles, provide fresh interviews, and John Lennon and George Harrison are heard in clips, all of them reflecting on what it was like to ride the beast.

The film concentrates on the years through August 1966, when the Beatles stopped touring after a run that left thousands of screaming fans with sore throats. ItŠ—Ès a period that has already received a fair amount of attention lately, with the 50th anniversary of singular moments like the groupŠ—Ès first visit to the United States in 1964 and its Shea Stadium concert in 1965. Mr. Howard has some rarely seen or heard material in the film, but unless youŠ—Ère a scholar, itŠ—Ès hard to tell what it is, so familiar is the overall tale.
Ron HowardŠ—Ès new documentary, Š—“The Beatles: Eight Days a Week Š—” The Touring Years,Š— is 90 percent familiar and a bit hagiographic as well, but just try watching it without smiling.

That, at least, is likely to be your reaction if you were alive during Beatlemania. A trickier question is whether the film will enthrall or just bore the audiences Mr. Howard has said he is particularly interested in Š—” millennials and whatever other generations werenŠ—Èt yet born when John, Paul, George and Ringo took the world by storm. If these viewers can get past their Š—“enough already with the Š—È60sŠ— gag reflex, they too will surely warm to this study of full-force fame.
Sure, they were great, but itŠ—Ès possible to get too much of the Beatles, isnŠ—Èt it?

Ten years after a tsunami took the lives of 46 children in an unnamed Latin American seaside village, the surviving residents remain deeply traumatized. They include Leo (Lucas Quintana), whose mother (Jacqueline Duprey) is a mute mass of quivering sorrow still mourning the death of LeoŠ—Ès brother. As for Leo, his anguish cost him the love of Soraya (Aris Mejias), who has married someone else. Only Father Douglas (Martin Sheen, performing in Spanish with masterly assurance) believes in a better future, but his efforts to encourage the locals to replenish the population have been fruitless.(Š—“The VesselŠ— is being released in English- and Spanish-language versions.)
Š—“The VesselŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for sexual situations.
ANDY WEBSTER

When Leo survives an accident that kills a friend who had aspired to escape the village, neighbors react with skepticism, suspicion and demands, if not outright aggression, to LeoŠ—Ès seeming resurrection. When he undertakes a daunting project Š—” the construction of a crude boat using ramshackle materials Š—” the antipathy of the townspeople reaches a boiling point.

Mr. Quintana, who has been a cinematographer and a camera operator, has worked with Terrence Malick (an executive producer of Š—“The VesselŠ—) and displays a similarly exquisite visual acumen. Using wide-angle lenses, gritty yet stunning Puerto Rican locations and a skilled cast (including Lucas, his brother), he conjures a timeless hamlet devoid of modern appurtenances, the kind of enchanted place where miracles Š—” like breaking the shackles of paralyzing despair Š—” can happen.
Julio QuintanaŠ—Ès Š—“The VesselŠ— is a modest, but not maudlin, parable of hope about mustering the strength to vigorously plunge again into lifeŠ—Ès uncertainties after a devastating loss.

Š—“The Thief and the CobblerŠ— is to animated movies what Š—“The Magnificent AmbersonsŠ— is to live-action ones: a staggering masterpiece that can never be seen in its ideal form. Š—“Ambersons,Š— directed by Orson Welles, was completed but then mutilated by its studio, its original version lost; Š—“Cobbler,Š— a dream project the animator Richard Williams had been working on since the 1960s, was wrested from him by financiers in 1993, incomplete by about 15 minutes.

ItŠ—Ès unclear how Mr. Williams would have made the disparate elements of his vision cohere, but itŠ—Ès also ultimately irrelevant. Though several distinctive animated movies have been released this year, Š—“The Thief and the Cobbler,Š— even in its sadly incomplete state, leaves them in the dust. Novices and kids may be alienated by its rough-cut form, but mavens will rightfully rejoice.

Its story features an exotic kingdom, a beautiful princess and an evil vizier. The title cobbler is taciturn and pragmatic in a way thatŠ—Ès magical; the sneaky thief is as persistent as Wile E. Coyote. The fully rendered material is amazing. Backgrounds evoke Š—“Sleeping BeautyŠ—-period Disney with a surrealist skew reminiscent of the work of the Czech master Karel Zeman. The action is dizzying, and the frequent playing with perspective is convincingly Escher-like.

The material supervised by Mr. Williams (whoŠ—Ès esteemed for, among other things, his work on Š—“Who Framed Roger RabbitŠ—) was shaped into two subsequent features, one a well-meaning but ineffectual salvage job, the next an out-and-out bastardization. Bootleg Š—“reconstructionsŠ— have circulated among buffs for years. This week, the Museum of Modern Art (in collaboration with the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences) screens a restored version of Mr. WilliamsŠ—Ès last work print of the film, titled Š—“The Thief and the Cobbler: A Moment in Time.Š—
Š—“The Thief and the Cobbler: A Moment in TimeŠ— is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 32 minutes.
Its conclusion, harrowing, humorous and arguably unfortunate, only reinforces the idea that the unsophisticated country people are better off as they were.
In this light tale, Budhi (Usha Naik), a widow in a rural hamlet, has lost her son, a farmer, to suicide because he could not repay a moneylender, a very real problem in the region in recent years.

Her best friend is the young man next door, Sudama (Sandeep Pathak), a goatherd who shares tea with her. He is the one Budhi chooses to accompany her on a shopping expedition to a nearby town after she comes by a few 1,000-rupee notes at a political rally.

And that is where the singularly third world misadventures begin, for what merchant can break such a large bill, especially at the beginning of the business day? And what unsavory police official can resist someone from the countryside carrying a handful of bills?

She cherishes each match and drop of oil in her one-room hovel, yet she always shares, giving part of her meager meal of bread to a dog and even a few crumbs to a colony of red ants. A year after her sonŠ—Ès death, she smiles as she passes through the village buying necessities. To support herself, she cleans the home of a wealthy family.
A parable about the contagious nature of corruption and the curse of dirty money, Š—“1000 Rupee NoteŠ— asks, How valuable is a windfall to people who live their lives largely without money?
ItŠ—Ès not every day you see a film in Marathi. But Shrihari SatheŠ—Ès Š—“1000 Rupee Note,Š— true to its origins in the Maharashtra State of India, is told in a dialect of that language.

It focuses on two cases. The first, from Saratoga, Calif., involves Audrie Pott, who committed suicide in 2012, days after an incident at a party when she was unconscious. Three boys later admitted in juvenile court that they had sexually penetrated Audrie while she was intoxicated and possessed lewd photos of her on cellphones.
The Netflix documentary Š—“Audrie & DaisyŠ— is intended to spread awareness of teenage sexual assaults and how technology can amplify their ramifications.

Š—“Audrie & DaisyŠ— is strongest when it investigates what it regards as shortcomings of justice, for reasons technical and implied: The special prosecutor in the Coleman case says certain legal standards can be difficult to meet. In an eyebrow-raising moment, the sheriff for Maryville holds forth on how Š—“girls have as much culpability in this world as boys do.Š—

The filmŠ—Ès slick presentation includes visuals of online chatter and a manipulative score. ItŠ—Ès revealed toward the end that two of the defendants from Ms. PottŠ—Ès case appeared in the documentary, with their identities obscured, as part of the settlement of a suit brought by her family.

The movie, directed by Bonni Cohen and Jon Shenk, is, among other things, a vehicle for Daisy Coleman, the Missouri victim. She and her family came forward to share the repercussions of the episode. (The family moved after feeling ostracized in Maryville, which then had a population of about 12,000.)

The other is a widely publicized case from Maryville, Mo., in which a former high school football player, Matthew B. Barnett, was initially charged with the sexual assault of a 14-year-old girl in 2012. (He was 17 at the time.) Those charges were dropped, but after public outrage and a review of the case, he ultimately pleaded guilty to endangering the welfare of a child.

Will fluffy, poodlelike chickens replace cats on the internet? Maybe not, but these chicken people, with deep connections to their birds, make for a fun and at times astonishing film. Just donŠ—Èt raise the prickly question of whether there is a platter in a chickenŠ—Ès future. As one poultry fancier says when asked if he eats his birds: Š—“Do you got kids? Do you eat them?Š—
They hold grudges. They have best friends. They arenŠ—Èt big on foreplay, and you can revive them with mouth-to-mouth resuscitation if they choke during a shampoo.

They are chickens: the ones with perfect combs, pedicured toes and gleaming feathers that compete on the show circuit. Š—“Chicken People,Š— directed by Nicole Lucas Haimes, looks at dozens of devotees of these fair fowl. The hens and roosters in this documentary are pampered royalty, and their caretakers find fulfillment in the pursuit of perfection.

Shari McCollough of Indiana introduces us to a harem, imitates a mating dance and discusses what she calls the Š—“wham, bam, thank you, maŠ—ÈamŠ— nature of chicken sex. Brian Knox of New Hampshire has some gorgeous specimens with geometrically patterned plumage. He is meticulous about developing the best traits in his birds, but when his relationship with a fellow hobbyist ended, he decided he was no good at dating. We also meet Brian Caraker, a singer in Branson, Mo., who was forced to choose between his career and his flock, which remains in Illinois with his parents. Still, he frequently consults the poultry bible of breed standards, and lets us in on the protective yet sly nature of roosters and what raising chickens has done for his self-esteem.

David cares deeply about his patients, but he doesnŠ—Èt love them in a familial or romantic sense. Š—“ChronicŠ— dramatizes the caregiverŠ—Ès paradoxical relationships to his charges with an acuity that can make it almost unbearable to watch. David hardly shies away from intimate physical contact with the dying. Several scenes show him tenderly undressing and holding a patient in what looks like an embrace while meticulously bathing and drying the body.

Radically unsentimental, it portrays the end of life largely without the emotional concomitants of grief, suffering and solace. Its icy aura of inevitability befits a film whose central character goes from client to client like a polite, expressionless deputy of the Grim Reaper. Since there are no explicit death scenes, only the certainty of imminent finality, an alternative title might be Š—“Scenes of Impending Mortality.Š—

In the quietly devastating Š—“Chronic,Š— Tim Roth, never more impressive onscreen, plays David, a palliative care worker whose intimacy with death and dying both scares and shames family members who nervously peek in on loved ones they have more or less abandoned. The first English-language film by Michel Franco, the Mexican director of Š—“After Lucia,Š— a harrowing study of high school bullying, Š—“ChronicŠ— stands back from its characters, which it views with a cold documentarylike detachment.

Often observed from behind, David is a soft-spoken and stoop-shouldered, slightly creepy misfit with a dry gallows humor. When the family of John (Michael Cristofer), an architect who suffered a disabling stroke, threatens to sue David for sexual harassment after finding pornography on JohnŠ—Ès tablet computer, the movie implies that such accusations are to be expected in a situation where relatives who canŠ—Èt bear to deal with a patientŠ—Ès illness project their guilt onto the caregiver.

Š—“ChronicŠ— has been compared to Š—“Amour,Š— Michael HanekeŠ—Ès portrait of a devoted elderly Parisian couple whose world shrinks as the wife succumbs to dementia. But the perspective of Š—“ChronicŠ— is more clinical than metaphysical.

The film focuses on three patients. Sarah (Rachel Pickup) is an emaciated woman who can neither speak nor walk and who exhibits few indications of sentience. In a bar after her funeral, David converses with a newly engaged young couple who ask if heŠ—Ès married, and in a deadpan voice, he replies that Sarah, his wife of 21 years, died of AIDS. When asked his name by a clerk while browsing in a bookstore, he answers Š—“John,Š— and sketches out a biography identical to the architectŠ—Ès.

Š—“ChronicŠ— ends with a sudden, terrible slap in the face that is a final blow to your equilibrium. It is left up to the viewer to decide whether it is a cheap stunt or an ultimate moment of truth. I vote for the latter.

In a particularly uncomfortable moment, he cleans a womanŠ—Ès buttocks after she has inadvertently soiled herself. For David, it is all in a dayŠ—Ès work, while for a patientŠ—Ès loved ones and for the viewer, it is a stark reminder of a future most of us would rather not think about.

The most wrenching scenes belong to Martha (Robin Bartlett), an exhausted cancer patient who after two grueling rounds of chemotherapy refuses a third that might prolong her life a little longer. When she bluntly asks David to help her die, he sympathizes but resists. Or does he? Ms. BartlettŠ—Ès extraordinary performance is a grim, deeply unsettling portrait of despair whose stoicism conveys an aching nobility.
David is humanized by a scene in which he reunites with his college-age daughter, Nadia (Sarah Sutherland). As they allude to a family tragedy, his eyes well up.
Š—“ChronicŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for some nudity and strong language. Running time: 1 hour 33 minutes.

Near the end of Š—“Closet Monster,Š— OscarŠ—Ès mother recalls his difficult birth, explaining that he has rarely been fortunate. ItŠ—Ès a tough scene that may portend his future. Of course, we donŠ—Èt know if Oscar will be safe, and neither does he. In this film, and in life, that uncertainty is both deeply scary and greatly exciting.

As in Š—“Mysterious SkinŠ— or Š—“Boyhood,Š— this coming-of-age story can feel entrancing, particularly with its surreal touches. Oscar talks to his hamster, which speaks back (voiced by an actress Š—” no spoilers Š—” who knows something about the surreal). And OscarŠ—Ès imagination occasionally takes flight, and we ride along.

We first meet Oscar as a boy struggling to comprehend his parentsŠ—È breakup. Soon he witnesses a sadistic assault against another boy. Those events echo years later when, in high school, heŠ—Ès desperate to escape his home and understand his sexuality.

Still, as with all of us, happiness isnŠ—Èt guaranteed, a fact made clear in Stephen DunnŠ—Ès script. Mr. Dunn, who also directed, has created individuals who defy easy branding. Outcomes are far from assured, and thereŠ—Ès a constant sense of danger. That threat, as Saul Bellow said of death, becomes Š—“the dark backing that a mirror needs if we are to see anything.Š—

You may find yourself hoping that Š—“Closet MonsterŠ— fades to black during one of its few cheerful scenes Š—” that way, the conflicted young man at its center will get a happy ending. This affecting film prompts that kind of concern for its characters. You want them to be safe.

Connor Jessup wonderfully inhabits the teenage Oscar, who observes others while trying to find himself. Aaron Abrams, as his father, and Aliocha Schneider and Sofia Banzhaf, as friends, are just as multilayered. Jack Fulton is heartbreaking as the younger Oscar.

Directed by Andrew Neel from a script by David Gordon Green, Mike Roberts and Mr. Neel, the movie is shot in hand-held, quasi-documentary style, although Mr. Neel weirdly forgoes a lot of what would have been useful exposition in the first quarter. The movie is similarly indirect in its approach to the admittedly inarticulate charactersŠ—È psychology. But in depicting the atrocities of the fratŠ—Ès Š—“Hell Week,Š— it is painstakingly explicit, a junior varsity variant on Pier Paolo PasoliniŠ—Ès study of fascist sadism, Š—“Sal’_, or the 120 Days of Sodom.Š—

I have limited sympathy for young people who collude in their own degradation in the interest of socialization and Š—“brotherhood,Š— but the plight of Brad and his gentler roommate, Will (Danny Flaherty), canŠ—Èt help eliciting shudders. Š—“If the fraternity goes, everything goes with it,Š— Will observes at one point. Since the movie gives us no other view of campus life but the fratŠ—Ès (the picture takes place at a fictionalized school), the viewer has no choice but to believe that.

A credible and dispiriting chronicle of late-adolescent male toxicity, Š—“Goat,Š— adapted from a 2004 memoir by Brad Land, begins with a senseless assault. The quiet, seemingly sensible Brad (Ben Schnetzer) bails on a college party his older brother, Brett (Nick Jonas), has allowed him to attend, and is waylaid by a couple of local lowlifes. Brad nevertheless resolves to go to BrettŠ—Ès school, and pledge his frat.

The performances are conscientious and earnest; Mr. Jonas has not much to do but come off as callow, with a streak of kindness, and he does so. James Franco, a producer, contributes a bro-caricature cameo thatŠ—Ès not as funny as he must have thought it was.
Š—“GoatŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for very ugly frat hazing activity, bad language and sex.

Aside from that, though, thereŠ—Ès not much to recommend this formulaic film, which stars Pierce Brosnan as Mike Regan, an executive who apparently missed all the memos about security in the internet age. HeŠ—Ès a business hotshot with his own company, but with a big deal looming, he entrusts his corporate files to Ed Porter (James Frecheville), a tech guy who is temping at his company. Mike doesnŠ—Èt even bother to have the fellow checked out.

Ed uses his unfettered access to bring MikeŠ—Ès company to the brink of ruin and also to gain control of everything in that fancy house, including the cameras, which he uses to voyeuristic ends. Can the overmatched father protect his family and thwart the psychopath? John Moore, the director, and Dan Kay and William Wisher, the screenwriters, donŠ—Èt have anything new to add to that familiar dynamic.

If that werenŠ—Èt improbable enough, he then asks Ed to pay a house call because his teenage daughter (Stefanie Scott) has been complaining that the internet in his high-tech home is too slow. Needless to say, Ed turns out to be a psycho, and an all-purpose one at that: He is envious of MikeŠ—Ès success, lusts after his daughter and apparently pops pills, too.

Wishing you had one of those Š—“smart houses,Š— where there are cameras everyplace, and the plumbing and lighting and appliances are all computer-controlled? The thriller Š—“I.T.Š— could save you a lot of money. It will make you grateful that you live in an old-fashioned dumb house.

The new movie is as moth-eaten as the serapes strewn through the 1960 film, but thereŠ—Ès no denying the appeal of the image of Mr. Washington riding a horse, shooting a Colt and leading a posse of vigilantes to save a mostly white Western town. Mr. Washington is, to state the overobvious, a great star, which means that he has that ineluctable whatŠ—Ès-it for selling the goods no matter what their sell-by date. And he has nice help in his amusing backup team, which is divided between parading peacocks (Chris Pratt, Vincent DŠ—ÈOnofrio and Mr. Sarsgaard) and slinking foxes (Ethan Hawke, Lee Byung-hun and Manuel Garcia-Rulfo), who steal gnawed-off bits and pieces of the movie.

And so once more onto the saddle Š—” again! This time, the seven are riding Š—” and shooting Š—” under the adequate if unremarkable direction of Antoine Fuqua. Working with truckloads of dust and high-contrast cinematography that tends to turn shadows into bottomless inky blots, Mr. Fuqua approaches the western like an ardent fan, leaving no genre element untouched, from gun spinning to trick riding to atmospherically flapping dusters. The story Š—” the script is credited to Nic Pizzolatto and Richard Wenk Š—” pretty much follows the line of the 1960 film, with some tweaks that speak to contemporary mores, including a gun-toting frontierswoman, Emma (Haley Bennett).
Š—“The Magnificent SevenŠ— is rated PG-13 (parents strongly cautioned) for relentless gun violence. Running time: 2 hours 12 minutes.

Mr. WashingtonŠ—Ès hero Š—” because heŠ—Ès a black man and especially a black man in a genre historically defined by white men routing nonwhite men Š—” is inherently more complex than BrynnerŠ—Ès was. That could have been enough to justify this remake, so itŠ—Ès too bad that Chisolm has been given a rationale for his actions. The 1960 film never really explains why BrynnerŠ—Ès character helps the villagers, which suggests that he doesnŠ—Èt need a reason to do good, he just does it, a silence that suggests a code, however fraudulent. Chisolm, by contrast, has his sights set on vengeance, which means that his deeds are strictly a matter of self-interest. ThatŠ—Ès pretty grim, but also very now.

The font of all this mock magnificence is Akira KurosawaŠ—Ès Š—“Seven Samurai,Š— a version of which was released in the United States in 1956 as Š—“The Magnificent SevenŠ— (with an hour chopped). In his review, Bosley Crowther of The New York Times compared it to Š—“High Noon,Š— calling it Š—“a solid, naturalistic, he-man outdoor action film, wherein the qualities of human strength and weakness are discovered in a crisis taut with peril.Š— Mr. Crowther noted that its story was malleable enough that Š—“it could be transposed without surrendering a basic element to the nineteenth century and a town on our own frontier.Š— From his pen to some Hollywood executiveŠ—Ès ear.

Denzel Washington looks just right high in the saddle, which makes sense given that heŠ—Ès become our John Wayne Š—” our point-and-shoot savior. ItŠ—Ès a funny business being a hero these days, and Mr. Washington has the r’©sum’© to prove it, with characters Š—” a corrupt cop, a drug kingpin Š—” that would have been unthinkable for Wayne, who saved the day when the lines between right and wrong were more rigidly defined. Those lines have blurred, of course, and good guys went sort of bad and sometimes very bad, partly because we like it like that. (It feels so good.)

Mr. WashingtonŠ—Ès latest, Š—“The Magnificent Seven,Š— is a remake of a remake thatŠ—Ès as fresh as recycled recycling suggests. Its principal source is the 1960 film of the same title about a septet of hired American guns protecting a Mexican village. In that film Yul Brynner played the prowling avenger and real cool cat who assembles a team that includes a blade-thin James Coburn and Steve McQueen, whose beauty had not yet hardened. Directed by John Sturges, the film is an easy, meandering male weepy, best enjoyed for its macho posturing and Elmer Bernstein score; less memorable are its Mexican clich’©s, even if Eli WallachŠ—Ès mustache-twirler delivers a defibrillator punch.

SheŠ—Ès sassy, but some messes a gal canŠ—Èt clean up alone, so she hires the gunslingers, beginning with Mr. WashingtonŠ—Ès bounty hunter, Chisolm. She wants to rid her town of its own mustache-twirler, Bartholomew Bogue (Peter Sarsgaard), a trigger-happy dandy with a devilish goatee, an embroidered vest and hordes of help. He and his gang are terrorizing an American town, which has the bad fortune of being next to a mine heŠ—Ès plundering. Emma makes her pitch to Chisolm while he stares down at her from horseback. He casually asks if sheŠ—Ès after revenge. Š—“I seek righteousness,Š— she replies, Š—“but IŠ—Èll take revenge,Š— an exchange that affirms the storyŠ—Ès bloody course.
Š—“My Blind BrotherŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Some sex.

The ensuing love triangle requires the writer and director, Sophie Goodhart, to take most of the sting out of her central comic conceit. (If Robbie were irredeemable, Rose wouldnŠ—Èt have a decision to make.)

WhatŠ—Ès left is a thoroughly harmless comedy that spaces its one-liners a bit widely. ItŠ—Ès made watchable by an appealing cast, even if the romantic angle prevents Mr. Scott from reprising the transcendent nastiness he showed in Š—“Step Brothers.Š— Ms. Slate, if not quite the revelation she was in Š—“Obvious Child,Š— offers another winning study in frazzle and self-effacement.

Then Bill meets Rose (Jenny Slate), a fellow couch potato and possible soul mate. But Rose, feeling responsible for a boyfriendŠ—Ès recent death, wants to atone. Through sheer coincidence, she becomes a helper and prospective girlfriend for Robbie.

Robbie, celebrating his victory before the media, forgets to thank him. Almost immediately, he announces plans for a swimming fund-raiser: Š—“Kids donŠ—Èt stop being blind, Bill.Š— He even sometimes drives (Š—“I have pretty advanced spatial awareness and memoryŠ—) and basically acts as alpha to Bill, his constant companion.

In Š—“My Blind Brother,Š— Robbie (Adam Scott) is a world-class jerk, an athlete who brags about his achievements. He also happens to be blind, and during sporting events is guided by his brother, Bill (Nick Kroll), introduced Š—” exhausted and sweaty Š—” running beside him in a marathon to raise money for blind children.
BEN KENIGSBERG

Ms. NalwangaŠ—Ès watchful, quiet presence conveys both shyness and determination, a habit of humility in tension with an almost superhuman intelligence. PhionaŠ—Ès awakening sense of her talent is the engine that drives the main plot of Š—“Queen of KatweŠ— and also what makes it an affecting character study. When she starts to learn chess, she can barely read, and her growing awareness of the powers of her mind is thrilling to watch. Ms. Nair makes this process as visible, as palpable Š—” as irresistible Š—” as any boxing match or soccer game.

Chess enters their world thanks to Robert Katende (David Oyelowo), who teaches the game to KatweŠ—Ès children as part of a youth ministry. Robert, whose own youth was scarred by poverty and war, has an engineering degree but lacks the connections that would help land him a job working for the government or a private company. He is an inspiring coach Š—” when Mr. Oyelowo wants to inspire you, you are darn well going to be inspired Š—” and also a sly and cheerful class warrior. He fast-talks his way into a chess tournament held at a snooty private school, and proudly leads his charges into battle against opponents who are reluctant to shake their hands.
Š—“Queen of KatweŠ— is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). A few scary moments and hints of sexuality. Running time: 2 hours 4 minutes.

To be fair, the film, directed by Mira Nair, based on Tim CrothersŠ—Ès book and enabled by the magical corporate synergy of Disney and ESPN, belongs to a genre that specializes in defeating skepticism and swelling the stoniest hearts. Just as surely as a creaky door or a clap of thunder will summon shivers of fright the thousandth time you hear it, so will the spectacle of a scrappy group of strivers following their unlikely coach to victory bring lumps to throats and tears to eyes. Did Š—“HoosiersŠ— make you cry? Š—“Queen of KatweŠ— will wreck you.

Š—“IrresistibleŠ— is one of those adjectives that critics should handle with utmost care. No matter how universally charming or winning a movie or a performance might seem to be, there is always a chance that somebody, somewhere, will be able to resist it. For all I know that may be the case with Š—“Queen of Katwe,Š— but if there is anyone out there capable of remaining unmoved by this true-life triumph-of-the-underdog sports story, I donŠ—Èt think I want to meet that person.

The sight of well-fed, well-dressed schoolboys beaten by a girl Š—” a poor girl, at that Š—” would be satisfying even if Š—“Queen of KatweŠ— were a less vivid and engaging movie. In Ms. NairŠ—Ès hands, PhionaŠ—Ès story has a richness and unpredictability that separates it from other, superficially similar movies. It also has the buoyant, cleareyed feel for the particulars of culture and place that is among this directorŠ—Ès great gifts, evident in films as different as Š—“Mississippi Masala,Š— Š—“Monsoon WeddingŠ— and Š—“Vanity Fair.Š— PhionaŠ—Ès circumstances are harsh, and the film hardly minimizes the brutal choices and painful limitations placed on women like Harriet and Night. Nor does it suggest that winning chess matches is a magical solution to the worldŠ—Ès injustice. Š—“Hope is not a tactic,Š— Robert likes to say. But despair is not a strategy, and Ms. Nair and the screenwriter, William Wheeler, refuse to turn African life into a pageant of grimness and deprivation.

Katwe is a poor township outside of Kampala, the Ugandan capital, and it is the hometown of Phiona Mutesi, a chess prodigy played by Madina Nalwanga in her film debut. Phiona lives with three siblings under the watchful, tired eye of their mother, Nakku Harriet (Lupita NyongŠ—Èo), who has lost her husband and another child and who scratches out a living selling food on the street. The family never has enough money, and Uganda is depicted as a country of stark inequalities ruled by an unforgiving cash economy. Shelter, schooling, medical treatment and transportation to the hospital after an accident must be paid for up front. Harriet, her mouth a permanent frown, is nearly consumed by worry and fatigue. Her eldest daughter, Night (Taryn Kyaze), has taken up with an unsavory guy on a motorbike. The middle children, Phiona and her younger brother, Brian (Martin Kabanza), scarcely have enough to eat.

Š—“Queen of KatweŠ— is likely to be embraced by young viewers, and there is nothing here they wonŠ—Èt be able to handle. Adults, meanwhile, can surrender to some old-fashioned melodramatic pleasures, as the busy plot takes in Harriet and RobertŠ—Ès struggles as well as PhionaŠ—Ès. But in the end it is Ms. Nalwanga who will rivet all eyes in the way that untrained, naturally charismatic screen performers sometimes can, especially when supported by actors with the technical expertise of Ms. NyongŠ—Èo and Mr. Oyelowo.

Birds have been fine Š—” memorable, even Š—” as secondary characters in animated fare. Zazu in Š—“The Lion King.Š— Scuttle in Š—“The Little Mermaid.Š— But giving a bird or birds top billing is another matter, as demonstrated by Š—“Storks.Š— This film, directed by Nicholas Stoller and Doug Sweetland, is a harmless enough way to occupy a youngster for an hour and a half. ItŠ—Ès just not especially rich in extraordinary characters or moments.

The premise is promising enough. Storks have long been out of the baby-delivery business and have instead been delivering packages for an internet retailer, cornerstore.com. But a sequence of events too complex to bother enumerating here causes the companyŠ—Ès long-dormant baby-making machine to produce an infant, and a stork named Junior (the voice of Andy Samberg) feels compelled to deliver it.
Š—“StorksŠ— is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for mildly harrowing moments.

He pairs up with Tulip (Katie Crown), a human teenager who has been raised by the storks since her delivery was botched 18 years ago, the event that led the company to get out of that business. Starting to sound complicated, isnŠ—Èt it? It grows considerably more so as the story goes along: Bad guys (Kelsey Grammer voices the main one) try to thwart the mission; a human family violates zoning laws in preparing for the babyŠ—Ès arrival; and more. The very young crowd that the movie seems aimed at may have trouble sorting it out.

That can be irrelevant with young viewers if the characters are engaging, or the music. Yet (unlike in Š—“Rio,Š— a pretty good animated film with bird leads) music is used only sparsely here. And Junior, frankly, is no Ariel or Simba. A pack of wolves and some penguins provide the best scenes. Blame the writing or the voice acting if you like, but maybe itŠ—Ès just that birds simply arenŠ—Èt warm and fuzzy or adorable. Tulip tries to make up some of that gap, but sheŠ—Ès one likable human in an undistinguished avian sea.

These issues are for the most part voiced by small farmers, counterculture types and others who are earnest but donŠ—Èt bring much gravitas or scientific evidence to the case. The film would be better if it had fewer shots of quixotic explorers sampling jungle plants while airy music plays and more hard information. When your opposition consists of giant corporations like Monsanto (the companies are not heard from in the film, by the way), youŠ—Èd better bring more to the fight than a flute and some folk tales.
Š—“Seed: The Untold StoryŠ— is one of those documentaries that get you riled up about a situation but leave you feeling that nothing significant can be done about it.

The film, by Jon Betz and Taggart Siegel, takes a wide-ranging look at the issues of diminishing diversity in the worldŠ—Ès seed supply and ownership of those seeds. (The title is disingenuous; other documentaries have also examined these questions.) The rise of big agriculture, weŠ—Ère told, has led to an alarming reduction in the varieties of food being grown and has imprisoned farmers in debt as they have become beholden to the corporations that sell seeds and pesticides. Along with this sea change in the way our food is produced has come the rise of genetically modified crops, something that to many people is yet another case of humansŠ—È manipulating nature with no idea of potential long-term consequences.

Like a reader skimming a novel to find the juicy parts, Kim Jee-woon gets through the story dutifully enough in Š—“The Age of Shadows.Š— But this director is really looking to stage the action sequences, which he prolongs and savors once they arrive.

After Lee fails to save the life of a fleeing rebel Š—” pursuing police leap from rooftop to rooftop with coordinated moves that would impress Cirque du Soleil Š—” he travels to China with Hashimoto, a Japanese detective, to thwart a resistance plot to smuggle explosives to Seoul.

Inspired by real events, the plot takes place in Korea in the 1920s, when the country was under Japanese occupation. Lee Jung-chool, a Korean serving in the Japanese police force, is torn between loyalty to his homeland and dedication to his uniform. His unease increases when heŠ—Ès ordered to capture resistance fighters seeking Korean independence.

As Lee, Song Kang-ho (Š—“SnowpiercerŠ—) mines the internal discord as much as the script allows while struggling over his allegiances, whereas Um Tae-goo is a snarly Hashimoto. Mr. KimŠ—Ès sympathies lie entirely with his Korean heroes. The Japanese are merely hostile obstacles.

Still, Mr. Kim will sacrifice anyone for the sake of a good fight or torture session. A scene on a train, in which the police stalk the rebels before a gun battle erupts, runs more than 20 minutes, all of them tense. A bomb-planting scene, set to RavelŠ—Ès Š—“Bolero,Š— is almost as taut.

Š—“The Age of ShadowsŠ—  might tempt another filmmaker to dwell on issues or delve deeper into its charactersŠ—È hearts. Yet, for this director, exposition canŠ—Èt hold a candle to elegantly staged shootouts. And who can blame him. He knows his strengths.
Š—“IŠ—Èm back, you bastards.Š—

Unfortunately, and despite its promising start, Š—“The DressmakerŠ— doesnŠ—Èt move much beyond the level of well-costumed playacting. The tone shifts, abruptly and awkwardly, from jaunty comedy to dark, violent drama, and the plot is a pileup of incident and complication, with revelations withheld and bestowed almost capriciously. The contrast between TillyŠ—Ès taste and beauty and the townspeopleŠ—Ès nastiness is cartoonishly overdrawn, even as the cast members work valiantly to humanize their simplistic roles. They are worth watching, but the question you find yourself asking of Tilly Š—” what on earth is she doing here? Š—” applies equally to Ms. Winslet and her fellow troupers.

There are the opening lines uttered by the first three major characters encountered in Š—“The Dressmaker,Š— Jocelyn MoorhouseŠ—Ès adaptation of the novel by Rosalie Ham. An intriguing start, made even more so by the actors who are speaking: Kate Winslet, Hugo Weaving and Judy Davis. Ms. Winslet, who says line one, is wearing the dress referred to line two. ItŠ—Ès not Dior, by the way, but it nonetheless effortlessly evokes a certain postwar femme fatale glamour, which is duly undermined by the opossum in line three.
Š—“Have you come about the opossum?Š—
Š—“Is that Dior?Š—

ItŠ—Ès the early 1950s, and Tilly Dunnage (Ms. Winslet) has returned to her dusty Australian hometown in search of vengeance. She moves in with her dotty mother, Molly (Ms. Davis), and promptly sets tongues wagging and bad memories stirring. As a child (then known as Myrtle), Tilly was bullied by a rich kid and blamed for his death. That supposed crime will be revisited, and the closets of this wicked little hamlet will disgorge their skeletons.
Š—“The DressmakerŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Nasty small-town secrets.  Running time: 1 hour 58 minutes.

Meanwhile, Tilly will put her sewing skills Š—” acquired in Paris during her long exile Š—” to work outfitting the local women with fashionable frocks. She will also catch the eye of a hunky fellow outcast (Liam Hemsworth) who lives in a trailer with his mother, his mentally challenged brother and a gaggle of other siblings. Ms. Moorhouse (whose previous films include Š—“ProofŠ— and Š—“How to Make an American QuiltŠ—) and her costume and production designers make the most of the period setting, and itŠ—Ès fun to watch good actors play dress-up, especially Mr. Weaving, whose character is a cross-dressing constable.
Š—“The Free WorldŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for extreme violence and strong language. Running time: 1 hour 40 minutes.

In the film, the directorial debut of Jason Lew, who wrote the skimpy, overblown screenplay, MoŠ—Ès years behind bars made him so violent that even the Aryan Brotherhood left him alone. Nicknamed Cyclops after tearing out a cellmateŠ—Ès eyeball, he became a jailhouse legend also known as the beast of Angola. He eventually embraces Islam to try to calm his rage (he calls himself Mohamed), and in moments of stress he prays.

The movie finds him shortly after his release, working at the Second Hope Animal Shelter, a center for stray and abused dogs run by Linda (Octavia Spencer), a fortress of calm whose wise, all-seeing gaze conveys several lifetimes of sorrowful knowledge. Mo is very tender with the caged dogs, and any resemblance between him and the canines is entirely intentional. The movie beats you over the head with images of him communing with animals from which he is made to seem virtually indistinguishable. The unsubtle message: We are all caged animals.

Boyd HolbrookŠ—Ès performance in Š—“The Free WorldŠ— is so intense in its compressed fury that you can almost see steam coming out of his ears. An approximate Š—È80s Mel Gibson look-alike, Mr. Holbrook plays Mo Lundy, a recently released prisoner who served time in the Louisiana State Penitentiary for murders he did not commit.

Impulsively he risks everything to help Doris (Elisabeth Moss), the battered wife of a police officer who took their dog to the shelter. Doris later shows up at MoŠ—Ès apartment bloodied, panicked after killing her husband, and hides (where else?) in a conveniently handy dog carrier when the police come searching for her.

The movieŠ—Ès shaky plausibility crumbles when Mo and Doris become fugitives and sweethearts. Because thereŠ—Ès nothing remotely Southern about Ms. Moss, including her accent, she seems miscast, despite a committed, fiery performance.

The heavy-handed man-beast comparison is one of several grossly overstated themes in a movie that abruptly changes direction as it goes along while taking shortcuts that leave its characters underdeveloped and crucial plot elements barely fleshed out. As the title suggests, freedom is every bit as awful as incarceration. Mo is continually taunted by police officers trying to arouse his ire.
The moral? In a beastly world, youŠ—Ère no safer cowering in a dog carrier than you are behind bars.

The bohemian paradise of this environment had a dark side, and the movie doesnŠ—Èt give it short shrift. Nevertheless, a genuine exhilaration holds throughout. You can tell that the interviewees who werenŠ—Èt there (including the contemporary jazz pianist Jason Moran and Ben Ratliff, a former music critic for The New York Times) dearly wish they could have been. Many viewers will feel similarly.

In the last years of the 1950s, the esteemed American photojournalist W. Eugene Smith was at a personal and professional crossroads. Several years spent on a productive but ultimately abortive project (documenting the city of Pittsburgh) forced him to sell his large home in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. His marriage ended. He acquired a Manhattan loft on Avenue of the Americas in the 20s Š—” then known as the flower district Š—” where his immediate neighbors were up-all-night musicians. A different resident might have complained of the noise. But Smith, whose predilection for recording eventually developed into something like a mania, started shooting and taping, and kept at it for almost a decade.

Š—“The Jazz Loft According to W. Eugene Smith,Š— a fascinating documentary directed by Sara Fishko, tells the story of SmithŠ—Ès peculiar endeavor and pays conscientious tribute to the manŠ—Ès artistry. It also tells several other discrete stories within the larger narrative. Superb portraits of the arranger and composer Hall Overton and the protean saxophonist Zoot Sims figure here. The Icarus-like rise and fall of Ron Free, a jazz drummer from the South, is largely related by Mr. Free himself. The preparations for Thelonious MonkŠ—Ès celebrated 1959 big-band concert at Town Hall are laid out in thrilling detail in the last third of the movie.

Despite its flaws and will to kitsch, Š—“The Lovers and the DespotŠ— has enough enigmas and chills to merit a look, even if some of its spookier moments involve cinephilia rather than the usual weapons of mass destruction. Yet while Mr. Cannan and Mr. Adam certainly engage Mr. KimŠ—Ès extreme movie love, thereŠ—Ès so much more to explore, including the contents of his film library, which is said to have included 15,000 titles. Mr. Kim even wrote a book, Š—“On the Art of the CinemaŠ— (1973), in which he writes that Š—“directors must focus on stimulating peopleŠ—Ès emotions rather than on the logical connection of events.Š— You can buy it on Amazon, where it has a four-star rating.
Š—“The Lovers and the DespotŠ— is not rated. It is in English and Korean, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 34 minutes.

ItŠ—Ès a familiar story that goes bonkers once the scene shifts to North Korea, which the documentary opens up Š—” provisionally Š—” with generous clips (including of Mr. Kim), peekaboo looks at everyday life and images of jaw-slackening spectacles featuring thousands of smiling, weeping citizens in perfect synchronization. What happened to Ms. Choi and Mr. Shin was outlandish, bizarre and tragic, at least for her, and for their children, who were left behind in South Korea. (The filmmakers poke into rumors that Mr. Shin defected.) WhatŠ—Ès happening to the millions inside North Korea is the greater tragedy, which tends to get lost amid the documentaryŠ—Ès approach and breathlessness.

ItŠ—Ès a small, weird world, as this documentary outlines twist by twist. Directed by Rob Cannan and Ross Adam, it revisits Ms. Choi and Mr. ShinŠ—Ès harrowing ordeal from beginning to end by using a variety of sources. These include original interviews, notably with Ms. Choi (Mr. Shin died in 2006); archival news material; clips from the movies the couple made in South and North Korea; and dramatic re-creations. It traces the arcs of Ms. Choi and Mr. ShinŠ—Ès personal and professional lives before and after they were married. There were many movies, many awards and a couple of children along with dark swirling clouds, largely because of Mr. ShinŠ—Ès serious money problems.

Every so often a documentary has such a head-shakingly bizarre story that alone makes it worth seeing. If you follow the news, this one may sound familiar: In 1986, a popular South Korean actress, Choi Eun-hee, and her ex-husband, a once-successful film director, Shin Sang-ok, entered the United States Embassy in Vienna and said that years earlier they had been kidnapped by North Korea Š—” where they had been held against their will Š—” and were now seeking asylum. It was stranger than fiction and also true (mostly, maybe).

Dramatizations of real events can be used to stunning effect, even if sometimes the results raise serious ethical questions about the subject, the audience and when the art of the real turns into the rank exploitation of the same. Alas, the dramatic re-creations in Š—“The Lovers and the DespotŠ— often undermine the movie because Mr. Cannan and Mr. Adam have a bad habit of trying to juice up already sensational material, as in a staged scene of two people running toward freedom, camera shaking. And because the filmmakers donŠ—Èt identify the images they sample, it can be impossible to tell if youŠ—Ère watching fact or fiction. This obfuscation is doubtless intentional, but it can make the documentary feel exploitative. Ms. Choi and Mr. Shin actually lived through this.

But did Mr. Shin go willingly or not? ThatŠ—Ès a mystery that Mr. Cannan and Mr. Adam play up, though defecting to a totalitarian country seems like a deranged career move, even for a filmmaker down on his luck. The documentary leans toward skepticism about Mr. Shin, which isnŠ—Èt a singular take. In the book Š—“North Korean Cinema: A History,Š— Johannes Sch’_nherr writes that when Mr. Shin was working in South Korea he Š—“was not shy when it came to who he was collaborating with.Š— Collaborating is such a heavy word, and implies so much. Perhaps Mr. Shin wasnŠ—Èt always especially discriminating, but, then, he worked in movies and mercenariness tends to come with the territory.

Š—“The Lovers and the DespotŠ— explores how and why Ms. Choi and Mr. Shin landed in North Korea, as does Paul FischerŠ—Ès 2015 book, Š—“A Kim Jong-il Production: The Extraordinary True Story of a Kidnapped Filmmaker, His Star Actress, and a Young DictatorŠ—Ès Rise to Power.Š— Mr. Fischer is also a movie producer. In a review of that book, the journalist Bradley K. Martin noted that Mr. FischerŠ—Ès title is the same as a movie that was being developed by the British producer Jeremy Thomas, who in 2011 characterized the project as a Š—“dramatized film noir.Š— ThatŠ—Ès a fair description of sections of Š—“The Lovers and the Despot,Š— which Mr. Thomas doesnŠ—Èt seem to be involved with.

Mr. Daum makes friends with Yacoub Odeh, a Palestinian in the coalition; interviews other Palestinians driven from Lifta; and hears accounts from Israeli historians. Despite all the good will, though, rifts exist, even among coalition members; as long as Israel remains an occupying force, Mr. Odeh says, there are lines that cannot be crossed.

Š—“The Ruins of Lifta,Š— an achingly poignant documentary by Menachem Daum and Oren Rudavsky, investigates a debate in which dueling narratives collide Š—” just as they do everywhere in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

Among the hills on the western outskirts of Jerusalem stands an abandoned group of stone buildings, the remains of Lifta, an Arab village whose residents were driven out in 1948, during what Israelis know as the War of Independence and what Palestinians call the Nakba (Catastrophe). Plans to demolish the homes and build a new development have drawn opposition from an Israeli-Palestinian coalition seeking to preserve the site.

Mr. Daum is an Orthodox Jew from Brooklyn, and a son of Holocaust survivors. He and Mr. Rudavsky have explored before, in Š—“Hiding and Seeking,Š— how Mr. DaumŠ—Ès family history had taught him to think the worst of non-Jews. Here, Mr. DaumŠ—Ès questioning of that perspective leads him to recognize that tragedy had begotten tragedy: Š—“The Holocaust and Nakba narratives are not exclusive,Š— he says. Š—“I do not have to choose between them.Š—

The coalition wins a court ruling, and development plans are delayed. While the film is meant to be hopeful, it just feels very sad. Mr. Daum introduces his friend Dasha Rittenberg, a Holocaust survivor, to Mr. Odeh, but the two end up in a heated, though civil, debate. If even these gentle souls canŠ—Èt find common ground, where is the way forward?

It opens on the 18-year-old Layla (Lamis Ammar), who Š—” far from their remote village Š—” is driving the familyŠ—Ès truck under the eagle-eyed supervision of her father, Suliman (Haitham Omari). SheŠ—Ès a daddyŠ—Ès girl, at least outwardly, a favoritism that she uses to her advantage and against her mother, Jalila (Ruba Blal-Asfour). A frowner who moves with the sharply impatient, no-nonsense gestures and stride of the permanently exasperated (get out of my way, her elbows suggest), Jalila may be the dutiful wife but sheŠ—Ès also in obvious, unmistakable revolt.

As a director, Ms. Zexer has a fine eye for the texture of daily life, which she fills in with resonant physical details and sweeping, scene-setting views. The peeling walls of Jalila and her daughtersŠ—È austere, underloved house convey volumes about their struggles, as do the jerry-built fences Š—” barriers made of wooden pallets and corrugated metal Š—” that seem to almost reluctantly meander through this village of Bedouins. If anything, Ms. Zexer is at her best when she daubs in color and minutiae, as in an almost interstitial scene in which Jalila bakes bread on top of an oven, an action that says something about both this specific woman and the world she inhabits.

The reasons for her rebellion emerge piecemeal, starting with the first wedding, and imply a greater, more destabilizing insurrection is in process. Suliman has taken a second, much younger wife and all the daughters that heŠ—Ès had with Jalila intimate the reason for his new bride. The ceremony itself is nicely handled, with a throng of women celebrating separately from the men (some of the women wear fake mustaches), and itŠ—Ès only a little later that it becomes clear that the wedding is entirely sex-segregated. Yet itŠ—Ès also not altogether evident if Suliman has wed again because convention demands that he start producing sons or if the pressure for progeny is wholly self-generated.

There are complications and contradictions, though, as well as unruly girls and women. Written and directed by Elite Zexer, an Israeli making a solid, sensitive feature debut, Š—“Sand StormŠ— is a story about the perils of unruliness set against a family of women. When the movie opens, the forces of modernity Š—” signaled by the images of young and older girls running free and sometimes boldly straying Š—” have already begun scratching at the stronghold of tradition, producing cracks that (scratch, scratch) threaten to become gateways.

Set in a Bedouin village in southern Israel, Š—“Sand StormŠ— is framed by two weddings, events that donŠ—Èt as much bookend this movie as seal it closed. ThatŠ—Ès because despite the raucous celebrations, the clapping and trilling cries, neither marriage is especially joyous, at least for the brides. Here, in this rundown desert hamlet, tradition is passed from generation to generation, from mother to daughter. Daughters, in turn, are passed from family to family.

Much of Š—“Sand StormŠ— hangs on Layla, whoŠ—Ès carefully, at times recklessly, navigating between radically different worlds. Some of this negotiation involves a romance with a student from her university, a forbidden, not especially engaging, liaison that generates friction and melodrama. Ms. AmmarŠ—Ès performance relies too heavily on her doe eyes and pout, so itŠ—Ès a good thing when the narrative center of gravity shifts to Ms. Blal-Asfour. A smoldering force, this is an actress who can express the entire history (and mystery) of a marriage and the complexities of people with a drag on a cigarette and a dark, unbearable look at the man whoŠ—Ès at once her lover and her betrayer.
Š—“Sand StormŠ— is unrated. Running time: 1 hour 27 minutes.
Š—“TharloŠ— is not rated. It is in Tibetan and Chinese, with English subtitles. Running time: 2 hours 3 minutes.

Š—“TharloŠ— begins with its title character, a middle-aged shepherd who has lived practically all of his life atop a Tibetan mountain tending his animals, reciting a speech by Mao Zedong to a local law-enforcement official, who is greatly impressed with the shepherdŠ—Ès memory. Tharlo, who is nicknamed Ponytail for his long braid, shyly exclaims that he showed prodigious powers of memory in elementary school, where he learned the speech, but had no further opportunities for education.

The movie is shot in black and white, in often very long takes. The style calls to mind the early films of the American director Jim Jarmusch, but this picture does not emulate Mr. JarmuschŠ—Ès knowing sardonic tone. Š—“TharloŠ— instead opts for fleeting charm and shaggy humanism, until the narrative takes a grim turn thatŠ—Ès both trite and sexist. The bottom drops out of the movie, leaving its interest almost exclusively ethnographic.

Written and directed by Pema Tseden, adapting his own novella, Š—“TharloŠ— is a character study at a turning point in that characterŠ—Ès life. Obliged to get an official ID card, Tharlo, beautifully played by Shide Nyima, ventures into a nearby city to procure a photograph. Told by the photographer to clean up, he visits a beauty salon where he charms Yangtso (Yang Shik Tso), the young woman who washes his hair. They spend an awkward evening at karaoke, a social activity that Tharlo has never even heard of before. On returning to his flock, he finds himself almost catastrophically distracted, and decides to change his life for good, and include Yangtso in that change.

With few exceptions, the movieŠ—Ès voices Š—” including most of its several dozen interviewees Š—” speak in concert. Some (like a galvanizing Angela Davis) are more effective and persuasive than others; at least one Š—” Newt Gingrich, speaking startling truth to power Š—” is a jaw-dropper. Even with its surprise guests, the movie isnŠ—Èt especially dialectical; it also isnŠ—Èt mainstream journalism. Ms. DuVernay presents both sides of the story, as it were (racism versus civil rights). Yet she doesnŠ—Èt call on, say, politicians who have voted against civil rights measures for their thoughts on the history of race in the United States. She begins from the premise that white supremacy has already had its say for centuries.

Powerful, infuriating and at times overwhelming, Ava DuVernayŠ—Ès documentary Š—“13THŠ— will get your blood boiling and tear ducts leaking. It shakes you up, but it also challenges your ideas about the intersection of race, justice and mass incarceration in the United States, subject matter that could not sound less cinematic. Yet Ms. DuVernay Š—” best known for Š—“Selma,Š— and a filmmaker whose art has become increasingly inseparable from her activism Š—” has made a movie thatŠ—Ès as timely as the latest Black Lives Matter protest and the approaching presidential election.

Written by Ms. DuVernay and Spencer Averick, Š—“13THŠ— picks up Ms. AlexanderŠ—Ès baton and sprints through the history of American race and incarceration with seamless economy. (Mr. Averick also edited the movie.) In its first 30 minutes, the documentary touches on chattel slavery; D. W. GriffithŠ—Ès film Š—“The Birth of a NationŠ—; Emmett Till; the civil rights movement; the Civil Rights Act of 1964; Richard M. Nixon; and Ronald ReaganŠ—Ès declaration of the war on drugs. By the time her movie ends, Ms. DuVernay has delivered a stirring treatise on the prison industrial complex through a nexus of racism, capitalism, policies and politics. It sounds exhausting, but itŠ—Ès electrifying.
Š—“13THŠ— is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 40 minutes.

The documentary might have benefited from more articulate jaggedly discordant voices than Mr. NorquistŠ—Ès to enrich the dialogue and as a reminder of the other views on race, history and the criminal justice system, including those in the mainstream. One popular textbook, Š—“The American System of Criminal Justice,Š— states that the 13th Amendment Š—“had little impact on criminal justice.Š— And a booklet on the Constitution, Š—“Know Your Rights,Š— available through the Justice Department, reads: Š—“The 13th Amendment protects every person in America Š—” all races and creeds, citizens and noncitizens, children and adults Š—” from the bondage of slavery. It is unconstitutional for slavery to exist in any form or by any name.Š—

Speed is one reason Š—” youŠ—Ère racing through history witness by witness, ghastly statistic by statistic Š—” but youŠ—Ère also charged up by how the movieŠ—Ès voices rise and converge. ItŠ—Ès like being in a room with the smartest people around, all intent on rocking your world. Ms. DuVernay is working within a familiar documentary idiom that weaves original, handsomely shot talking-head interviews with well-researched, occasionally surprising and gravely disturbing archival material. All these sources, in turn, have been shaped into discrete sections that are introduced with music and animation. Every so often, the animation underscores an intervieweeŠ—Ès point, as in one sequence in which the word Š—“freedomŠ— morphs into flying birds and then the Stars and Stripes and then a slave ship.

Ms. DuVernay isnŠ—Èt the only American director to take on race and the prison industrial complex (Eugene JareckiŠ—Ès Š—“The House I Live InŠ— charts adjacent terrain), but hers is a powerful cinematic call to conscience, partly because of how she lays bare the soul of our country. Because, as she sifts through American history, you grasp the larger implications of her argument: The United States did not just criminalize a select group of black people. It criminalized black people as a whole, a process that, in addition to destroying untold lives, effectively transferred the guilt for slavery from the people who perpetuated it to the very people who suffered through it.

Ms. DuVernay forcefully and sorrowfully challenges that confident assertion, tracing the history of systems of racial control from the years after the abolition of slavery all the way to George ZimmermanŠ—Ès speaking to a police dispatcher about the 17-year-old Trayvon Martin. Š—“HeŠ—Ès got his hand in his waistband,Š— we hear Mr. Zimmerman say shortly before fatally shooting Mr. Martin. Š—“And heŠ—Ès a black male.Š— When this documentary reaches its culmination, which features graphic videos of one after another black man being shot by police, Ms. DuVernayŠ—Ès rigorously controlled deconstruction of crime, punishment and race in the United States has become a piercing, keening cry.

In her book, Ms. Alexander (the most charismatic of the movieŠ—Ès interviewees) argues that mass incarceration exists on a continuum with slavery and Jim Crow. As one of Š—“the three major racialized systems of control adopted in the United States to date,Š— it ensures Š—“the subordinate status of a group defined largely by race.Š— Under the old Jim Crow, state laws instituted different rules for blacks and whites, segregating them under the doctrine of separate but equal. Now, with the United States having 25 percent of the worldŠ—Ès prisoners, a disproportionate number of whom are black, mass incarceration has become Š—“metaphorically, the new Jim Crow.Š—

The movie hinges on the 13th Amendment, as the title indicates, in ways that may be surprising, though less so for those familiar with Michelle AlexanderŠ—Ès 2010 best seller, Š—“The New Jim Crow: Mass Incarceration in the Age of Colorblindness.Š— Ratified in 1865, the amendment states in full: Š—“Neither slavery nor involuntary servitude, except as a punishment for crime whereof the party shall have been duly convicted, shall exist within the United States, or any place subject to their jurisdiction.Š— As Ms. Alexander underscores, slavery was abolished for everyone except criminals. (Š—“13THŠ— opens the New York Film Festival on Friday; it will be in theaters and on Netflix beginning on Oct. 7.)

Ms. Alexander has been criticized for oversimplifying the origins of mass incarceration in Š—“The New Jim Crow.Š— This may account for why Ms. DuVernay, in perhaps a bid to pre-empt similar criticism, does include a few divergent voices, including the conservative lobbyist Grover Norquist, who frankly comes off as an exemplar of blinkered power and racial myopia. He pops up in a section on the rise off mass incarceration during the 1980s thatŠ—Ès tied to crack cocaine and the racial gap in arrests and sentencing. Mr. Norquist puts the onus for this disparity on politicians (calling out United States Representative Charles B. Rangel, another interviewee), stating that it had nothing to do with Š—” as he puts it Š—” Š—“mean white people.Š—

SwedenŠ—Ès official entry for a best foreign-language film at the Academy Awards proves that Swedish pictures can be just as sentimental and conventionally heartwarming as Hollywood ones. Granted, few Hollywood films would deign to tell the story of a protagonistŠ—Ès life through a series of flashbacks brought on by unsuccessful suicide attempts. But still.

Adapted by the writer and director Hannes Holm from a best-selling novel by Fredrik Backman, Š—“A Man Called OveŠ— begins with its title character (a convincingly gruff Rolf Lassgard) losing the railroad job that heŠ—Ès worked at for more than 40 years. Lumbering, frowning and curmudgeonly, Ove trudges back to the small gated community that he watches over like a hawk and determines to join his recently deceased wife by hanging himself. He is interrupted by new neighbors, a young family whose matriarch, Parvenah (Bahar Pars), becomes both a conscience for and disciple of the old crank.

Slightly won over by ParvenahŠ—Ès delicious Middle Eastern cooking, Ove softens into the mensch viewers will no doubt figure him for from the first frame. (Things really pick up when Ove reluctantly adopts a fluffy Persian cat with striking blue eyes.) Beneath the twists and turns of this ordinary manŠ—Ès life story thereŠ—Ès a casual social history of Sweden in the last half of the 20th century. In a way, Š—“A Man Called OveŠ— is also kind of a message picture, its finale insisting that the best route to cultural continuity is community, not ethnic exclusivity. Good-hearted stuff, to be sure, but mainly of interest to lovers of cinematic comfort food.
Š—“A Man Called OveŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for raw crankiness.

The members of this crew are at once con artists and suckers, fabricating stories for potential customers about scholarship funds and college assignments and contributing their labor to a dubious cause.
