Every night they hand over their earnings to their supervisor, Krystal (Riley Keough), who is barely older than her charges. She doles out threats and discipline and travels separately in a convertible driven by Jake (Shia LaBeouf), her top earner and possible boy toy. Her job is to deliver pep talks and mete out discipline, but Krystal is not really the boss. An unseen corporate entity Š—” a cult or a parallel-marketing network or a low-tech start-up Š—” is running the show, not that Star and her new friends care much about such things. They are too busy flirting, arguing, smoking and singing along with Rihanna and Ludacris during long van rides. Then they disembark to go into neighborhoods pretending to be starry-eyed young strivers. Their lives are like an endless class trip to nowhere.

For her part, Ms. Arnold is in no hurry to reach any particular narrative destination. Her earlier features Š—” Š—“Red Road,Š—  Š—“Fish TankŠ— and Š—“Wuthering HeightsŠ— Š—” were more tidily plotted, but they share with Š—“American HoneyŠ— a willingness to be diverted by sensual detail and an empathetic curiosity about the inner lives of their female protagonists. She likes to shoot in narrow, boxy frames, as if to visually underscore the limitations that the world places on girls and women. At the same time, her camera ranges freely and widely within that world, zeroing in on tiny instances of strangeness and beauty and looking upward and outward at the sky and everything under it.
Š—“American HoneyŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). What kids will do in the absence of adult supervision. Š—_  Running time: 2 hours 42 minutes.

Her sexuality is a source of both the danger and the power, and in the hands of a more prurient director Š—” Harmony Korine or Larry Clark, say Š—” Š—“American HoneyŠ— might have been a leering cautionary tale. Instead, the movie is a sprawling anthology of contradictory feelings, sensations and genres. ItŠ—Ès an episodic travelogue, a coming-of-age chronicle and an indictment of grim social conditions, with roughly equal measures of Jack Kerouac, J. D. Salinger and Charles Dickens in its DNA.

Really, though, the awfulness and grandeur that Š—“American HoneyŠ— discovers is the product of StarŠ—Ès restless Emersonian consciousness. Ms. Lane, who like most of the cast has no previous professional acting experience, is a fierce, self-contained riddle. Star is almost childishly na’Àve, but at the same time ruthlessly self-assured, heedless of danger and intuitively aware of the power she possesses.

That sky is vaster in the American West than in the cramped and clammy places the British Ms. Arnold has previously investigated. Star and the rest of the crew zigzag across the heartland, through Oklahoma and Nebraska and the Dakotas, alighting in truck stops and oil fields as well as suburbs and trailer parks. Sometimes these spots are shot through a filter of exoticism, with the eye of an artist from elsewhere who is fascinated, appalled and intoxicated by the amber waves of grain and the sparkling sands of our diamond deserts.

ItŠ—Ès also a love story of sorts. Star is initially drawn to the crew by the sight of Jake, a boisterous, snaggletoothed dreamboat with suspenders, a braided rattail and an eyebrow piercing. HeŠ—Ès not exactly boyfriend material, but he and Star pursue a romance (in defiance of KrystalŠ—Ès rules) that has real heat and genuine tenderness. Jake is both a bit of a jerk and a wounded lost boy, and Star certainly has her own issues, but the movie declines to treat her as a victim or a sinner, and refuses to set her up for punishment or rescue. Being young, poor, female and unloved is a raw deal, for sure, but StarŠ—Ès instinct for survival and her appetite for pleasure inoculate her against pity.

On the shelf of essential cultural products whose names begin with the word Š—“American,Š— Andrea ArnoldŠ—Ès new film (her fourth feature and the first set in the United States) might find a spot between Grant WoodŠ—Ès Š—“GothicŠ— and Green DayŠ—Ès Š—“Idiot.Š— This is not solely a matter of alphabetical order. Š—“American Honey,Š— which takes its title from a song by Lady Antebellum, is a roaming, rambling road picture propelled by sex, hip-hop and close-ups of insects. It probes the murk and terror beneath the surface of contemporary life, and illuminates the vital role of ignorance, poor judgment and wishful thinking in our national character.

Following the adventures of a young woman named Star Š—” she says sheŠ—Ès 18, and might be telling the truth Š—” Š—“American HoneyŠ— tells a tale of youthful recklessness that could easily have swerved into moralism or exploitation. Star (Sasha Lane), first seen Dumpster diving with her two younger siblings, inhabits a sad prairie landscape of big-box stores and strip malls. Sexually abused by the lecherous drunk she calls Daddy and all but abandoned by her mother, she runs away with a band of feral teenagers who travel the country in a white van, selling magazine subscriptions door to door and sleeping in cheap motels.
Š—“American Honey,Š— long and messy as it is, is by turns observant and exuberant, and sweet in a way that is both unexpected and organic.

Opposing views do arise in Š—“Among the Believers,Š— including from Pervez Hoodbhoy, an activist and scientist, and Tariq, who has helped build a school; Zarina, one of the students there, has fled a madrasa. Still, as hopeful as it is to hear these moderate voices, itŠ—Ès also worrisome Š—” several critics of the Red Mosque have been threatened or assassinated. Even as you cheer these courageous Pakistanis, you must fear for them.

The film, directed by Hemal Trivedi and Mohammed Ali Naqvi, revolves around interviews with Abdul Aziz, a cleric and leader of the Red Mosque in Islamabad, Pakistan, which indoctrinates thousands of students at its Islamic schools. Mr. Aziz is not shy when discussing his goal of imposing Shariah law on the country. Though the mosque has sometimes been subjected to government crackdowns (including a violent siege in 2007), those only strengthen Mr. AzizŠ—Ès conviction.

ItŠ—Ès just one disturbing statement in a documentary thatŠ—Ès packed with them. Elsewhere we hear from a boy who hopes to be a jihadist, and watch dozens of others swaying back and forth as they spend their youths studying little but the Quran (or rather, memorizing it, as one student admits he and the others cannot understand its meaning), which is being interpreted to them by extremists.

The directors let their subjects speak without overtly passing judgment. And while it is maddening to see the aversion to open-minded education by Mr. Aziz (Š—“Š—…Progressive thoughtŠ—È is dying,Š— he declares, pleased), we also see the stark poverty that leaves others with few choices but to follow him.
Š—“Once we train their minds, theyŠ—Èll never change until they die,Š— the dean of the Red Mosque madrasa says casually and, for the viewer, chillingly, in Š—“Among the Believers.Š—
Š—“Deepwater HorizonŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Catastrophe and profanity. Running time: 1 hour 47 minutes.

Or at least Mr. Berg Š—” working from a script, by Matthew Michael Carnahan and Matthew Sand, based on an article in The New York Times Š—” creates an effective illusion of knowledge. Since Williams, Fleytas and Harrell (known to all as Mr. Jimmy) clearly know what theyŠ—Ère talking about, the viewer absorbs some of their confidence, and gains at least a rudimentary insight into how this enormous, complex piece of machinery works. And even as the film provokes outrage at the sloppiness and corner-cutting of the oil company functionaries, it also induces a sense of awe. The ambition and ingenuity required to bring petroleum up from beneath the ocean floor is pretty remarkable. The Horizon is at once a grand accomplishment and a catastrophic folly, and Š—“Deepwater HorizonŠ— is above all a study in the mechanics of hubris.

The three main good guys in Š—“Deepwater HorizonŠ— Š—” Mike Williams (Mark Wahlberg), Andrea Fleytas (Gina Rodriguez) and Jimmy Harrell (Kurt Russell) Š—” are cut from similar cloth. They are disciplined, clearsighted professionals, and the pressing issues they face are not moral, political or philosophical, but practical. Can the rig be stabilized? Can the damage be contained? Can as many people as possible be rescued?

This insistence on specific, concrete concerns is part of what gives the film its power as an indictment of BP and its managers. A few of those are on hand as the crisis unfolds on board the Deepwater Horizon, a drilling rig that floats over an oil deposit off the Louisiana coast. The filmŠ—Ès designated villains are Donald Vidrine, played by John Malkovich as a smiling buzzard with a gumbo-thick accent, and Robert Kaluza, played by the Š—“Friday Night LightsŠ— stalwart Brad Leland. Vidrine, Kaluza and their colleagues, aware that they are behind schedule and potentially squandering profit, push workers and their supervisors to ignore signs of trouble.

There are no big speeches or rhetorical flourishes. ThatŠ—Ès not really Mr. BergŠ—Ès style. As a director, he favors speed, impact, clipped dialogue and specialized technical information. At his best Š—” or letŠ—Ès just say in everything except Š—“BattleshipŠ— Š—” he combines blockbuster-flavored effects with fine-grained, sinewy naturalism. His heroes (the football coach in Š—“Friday Night Lights,Š— the counterterrorism agents in Š—“The Kingdom,Š— the soldiers in Š—“Lone SurvivorŠ—) are unsentimental troubleshooters dealing with unpredictable problems in less than ideal circumstances.

And also a celebration of the unassuming, lifesaving skill that resists it. Mr. BergŠ—Ès commitment to craft Š—” the meticulousness with which he manages time, space and the skills of his excellent cast Š—” becomes a form of tribute. The people who lost their lives on the Horizon, and those who prevented more lives from being lost, were doing their jobs, and the movieŠ—Ès achievement is to insist upon and honor that fact.

Š—“Deepwater HorizonŠ— is a swift and suspenseful action movie, full of noise, peril, muck and fire. ItŠ—Ès also a true-crime story, the highly detailed procedural chronicle of how, on April 20, 2010, 11 people were killed and a vast marine ecosystem was despoiled because of negligence and greed. Like Š—“The Big Short,Š— this film, directed by Peter Berg, dramatizes a broadly familiar story and stands as a work of popular narrative for an age of corporate impunity. The anger and grief you feel leaving the theater constitute a kind of catharsis, a modest symbolic compensation for the failure of justice in the real world.

The accident that results Š—” a horrific sequence of jolts, explosions and murderous jets of mud, seawater and oil Š—” occupies most of Š—“Deepwater Horizon,Š— which stakes its credibility on close attention to detail. The film itself is as much a feat of engineering as a work of art, an efficient machine for delivering intricate data and blunt emotions. We start the day at home with Williams and his wife (Kate Hudson) and daughter. Once he choppers out to the Horizon, where he works as an electronics technician, we stay on board for the duration, and we come to know the corridors and chambers of the rig intimately.

The absence of an emotional catharsis in the film, efficiently directed by Mick Jackson (Š—“The Bodyguard,Š— Š—“Temple GrandinŠ—) from a screenplay by the British playwright David Hare, leaves a frustrating emptiness at its center. You wonder if the material would have been more effective as a courtroom procedural adapted for the stage. All of the trial testimony comes from court transcripts.

If it didnŠ—Èt concern a momentous historical tragedy, the campaign against Ms. Lipstadt would have amounted to little more than a publicity-seeking nuisance suit. But the defense had no choice but to fight back. Had Mr. Irving won his case, the potential repercussions would have been catastrophic.

No courtroom fireworks detonate in Š—“Denial,Š— a sober, methodical recounting of a 1996 libel suit brought by David Irving, a discredited British historian, against Deborah E. Lipstadt, author of the 1993 book Š—“Denying the Holocaust: The Growing Assault on Truth and Memory.Š—

Surely the creators could have found some compelling drama in the charactersŠ—È personal lives. But Š—“DenialŠ— rarely ventures outside its narrow journalistic parameters. Once the verdict is rendered, there is no judicial post-mortem, only an exhausted sigh of relief. As the world knows, the court ruled in Ms. LipstadtŠ—Ès favor.

With her curly red hair and strong Queens accent, Ms. Weisz is a noble firebrand, but her character, as written, is little more than an outraged mouthpiece reduced to near silence when the defense decides that neither she nor the Holocaust survivors clamoring to testify should take the stand because they will be Š—“humiliated.Š—
Š—“DenialŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for thematic material and some strong language. Running time: 1 hour 50 minutes.

Shortly after his visit, Mr. Irving brought a lawsuit in Britain against Ms. Lipstadt (Rachel Weisz), and her publisher, Penguin Books, for calling him a Holocaust denier and hurting his reputation as a historian. In his writings, Mr. Irving, an admirer of Hitler, insists there were no gas chambers at Auschwitz and that any deaths there were the results of illness and starvation.

The closest thing to Mr. Welch in Š—“DenialŠ— is Richard Rampton, a libel lawyer embodied by Tom Wilkinson, who builds a case against Mr. Irving by cataloging the deliberate falsehoods and distortions of the facts in his inflammatory screeds. Mr. WilkinsonŠ—Ès humane, thoughtful performance imbues the film with much of its moral weight.

But in Britain, where libel laws differ from those in the United States, the burden of proof is on the defendant. To Ms. LipstadtŠ—Ès chagrin, she and her legal team must focus on disproving Mr. IrvingŠ—Ès evidence.

Amassing legal evidence against Mr. Irving was not simple: The Nazis diligently covered their tracks and made sure no photographs were taken of prisoners being gassed inside chambers that they later destroyed Š—” and which Mr. Irving insists never existed. In a smugly disingenuous bit of showmanship, he challenges the defense to find holes in the collapsed roof of the gas chambers at Auschwitz through which cyanide pellets were pumped. A scene in which Ms. Lipstadt and her legal team visit Auschwitz shrouded in winter fog injects a note of elegiac sadness that is deepened by Howard ShoreŠ—Ès hushed score. But the moment, for all its eerie beauty, feels forced.
On the other side is Timothy SpallŠ—Ès sly, jovial portrayal of Mr. Irving, who argued his own defense, as a canny trickster with an impregnable ego.

Š—“DenialŠ— begins with Mr. Irving loudly interrupting one of Ms. LipstadtŠ—Ès lectures at Emory University in Atlanta, where she teaches history, by offering $1,000 to anyone who can prove the Nazis gassed Jews at Auschwitz. ItŠ—Ès a tense moment for Ms. Lipstadt, who has vowed never to debate with anyone like Mr. Irving, a notorious gadfly who has built a lucrative career by claiming the Holocaust didnŠ—Èt happen.

Because moviegoers have been conditioned by countless courtroom dramas (and sometimes by real life) to expect an emotional flash point that encapsulates a moral truth, you long for a delicious turning point like the lawyer Joseph N. WelchŠ—Ès lofty dressing down of Senator Joseph McCarthy at the Army-McCarthy hearings in 1954.
And once his rarest talent is shown, he soars. As Snowman takes the highest jumps, gathering his haunches, he extends himself until his body is almost vertical, as if he were climbing a mountain.

On camera, Mr. deLeyer says he felt an immediate connection with Snowman. A Dutch immigrant Š—” the movie shares tantalizing tidbits about his past in the underground in World War II Š—” Mr. deLeyer tells of hiding Jews in the cellars of family barns in the Netherlands.

The Snowman of Ron DavisŠ—Ès documentary Š—“Harry & SnowmanŠ— is a horse that melts the heart. Purchased in the 1950s for $80 off a truck bound for the slaughterhouse, Snowman became a champion show jumper. And that was only one surprise in the long friendship that began when this scruffy white gelding locked eyes with Harry deLeyer, who raised horses and taught riding at a girlsŠ—È school in Long Island.

This film skillfully challenges our expectations by unfolding SnowmanŠ—Ès abilities one at a time: In summer he is a swimming water taxi for a passel of deLeyer children; in winter he pulls them on skis.

When we meet him, Mr. deLeyer is pushing 86 and still riding. As a young man, he looked dashing in his riding clothes, as seen in archival footage. Š—“A lot of times the kids went without so that he could have,Š— she said.
In the film, a student of Mr. deLeyerŠ—Ès recalls some of his advice: Š—“Throw your heart over the top, and your horse will follow.Š— Š—“Harry & SnowmanŠ— makes you want to do the same.

Š—“I blame popular culture,Š— Zach Galifianakis says at the start of this comedy, the ridiculousness of his Southern accent rivaling that of his very fluffy hairstyle. The results are mixed. This isnŠ—Èt necessarily because the movie is finally seeing release after spending more than a year in the vortex of the bankruptcy of its studio, Relativity. The story gets awfully busy Š—” you may get lost in 1943 or perhaps closer to the present Š—” but it scarcely matters. Mr. BurtonŠ—Ès attention to detail and to the ebb and flow of tone (scary, funny, eerie), as well as his sensitive, gentle work particularly with the child actors, make each new turn another occasion for unfettered imagination. As time loops and eyeballs pop and Samuel L. Jackson shows up as a villain and then Judi Dench drops in for a while, the movie holds you tight with one after another marvelous, horrible, indelible vision. Here, women turn into birds and a boy holds a rope tied to the waist of a girl who, in turn, floats above him like a balloon, a thought and a dream.

Once Jake starts hanging out with his new crew, a charming sideshow Š—” the girl with the gobbling mouth in the back of her head, the boy with prophetic gifts Š—” he proves to be somewhat of a dullard. (The children are ideally cast, even if one is playing an invisible boy and two others are obscured by delectably creepy masks.) This isnŠ—Èt Mr. ButterfieldŠ—Ès fault, just the fate of the hero who has to serve as the intermediary between the world of the spectator and the world on the other side of the looking glass. With his lanky limbs as well as his dark hair and clothes, Mr. Butterfield canŠ—Èt help but bring to mind Mr. Burton, who of course plays the same role for us.

Miss PeregrineŠ—Ès home Š—” its inhabitants, chambers and time-stuttering enigmas Š—” turns out to be a delightful cabinet of curiosities, those wonder rooms in which (once upon a time before Instagram) collectors stashed marvels like body parts, scientific instruments, odds and ends. Movies are kind of wonder rooms, too, though much depends on the collector. Mr. Burton, whose artistry is at times most evident in its filigree, can be a great collector when given the right box to fill, as is the case here. He revels in the storyŠ—Ès icky, freaky stuff; heŠ—Ès right at home, which may be why he seems liberated by its labyrinthine turns and why you donŠ—Èt care if you get a little lost in them.

This is all nonsense except that itŠ—Ès not, though, you know, all in good time. First, Mr. Burton has to wind up the story and dispense with the usual preliminaries, the introductions and scene-setting, which he manages nicely. Some of this is dreary (the parents), some less so, particularly the skipping between past and present Š—” a foreshadowing of later time traveling Š—” which begins with a very young Jake listening to Abe in wonderment and ends with Jake as a squirmy, awkward teenager (like a super-abridged take on Richard LinklaterŠ—Ès Š—“BoyhoodŠ—). And while Mr. Stamp seems eccentrically cast, his coolness works here because distance invariably draws you in closer.

Š—“Miss PeregrineŠ—Ès Home for Peculiar ChildrenŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). For once, the rating makes sense given that there are scenes, including with eyeballs, that may be too intense for young children. Running time: 2 hours 7 minutes.

Eventually, after the parts are snapped into place and well-oiled, Jake and his rather more reluctant father, Frank (a tamped-down Chris OŠ—ÈDowd), arrive in Wales, chasing down AbeŠ—Ès legacy and stories. While his father dithers and drinks, Jake goes down the rabbit hole and lands in a time loop where Miss Peregrine (a delightful Eva Green), welcomes him to 1943 with mad eyes and a Sherlock-sized pipe that she likes to clench between her pretty teeth. And weŠ—Ère off, having finally arrived in an otherworldly fantasy thatŠ—Ès been etched with meticulous loveliness, from the meringue peaks of Miss PeregrineŠ—Ès black-and-blue hair to the vaguely vaginal apertures in her jacket sleeves.

It takes a while for Mr. Burton to get his kink on. Although he has some fun setting up JakeŠ—Ès juvenile detention (i.e., life), the story begins to sag almost before itŠ—Ès begun, despite the time-skipping and peekaboo at the mysteries to come. ThereŠ—Ès a brief, amusing party scene at JakeŠ—Ès house that suggests who he Š—” and Mr. Burton Š—” believe are the real monsters. But the movie also needlessly dawdles when it climbs on a high horse as Jake, after delivering a school presentation on his grandfather, is mocked and cruelly told that Abe lies. As if anyone, especially anyone watching a Hollywood movie, needed reminding that some people will always try to snuff out creativity.

Ah, but he slips beautifully into his latest, Š—“Miss PeregrineŠ—Ès Home for Peculiar Children.Š— Based on the book of the same title in the young-adult series by Ransom Riggs, it follows the curious and curiouser adventures of Jake (Asa Butterfield), a Florida adolescent whoŠ—Ès begun to wither in all that tedious sunshine. The only beguiling shadow in an otherwise terrifyingly pastel life is his grandfather, Abe (Terence Stamp). Raconteur or fabulist, Abe likes to amble down a twisting memory lane, telling tales about the monsters he fought in the war or the childrenŠ—Ès home in Wales where bees buzzed in a boyŠ—Ès head and a girl named Emma (Ella Purnell) floated as light as a leaf on the wind.

The movies have long made room for phantasmagoric visionaries, the strange ones, the different ones, who like to peek under rocks (or peel back the skin) to peer at what squirms beneath. Fitting their deliriums into bright, shiny, commercially palatable vehicles can be difficult, as Tim BurtonŠ—Ès career attests. Time and again, Mr. Burton has tried to smooth down his singular art, rather like one of CinderellaŠ—Ès stepsisters sawing off a bit of her foot to squeeze into a happily-ever-after slipper. Mr. Burton should never hack off his strange bits; they can be glorious.

Raised in Kansas, Edwin Ramsey, then just a lieutenant, was based in Manila when the Japanese overran the Philippines shortly after the attack on Pearl Harbor. In the days that followed, he successfully led an attack that proved to be the last mounted-horse cavalry charge in the ArmyŠ—Ès history. More significant, after Bataan fell in 1942, Mr. Ramsey avoided capture and became a leader of an extensive Filipino guerrilla network, shadowing the Japanese and supplying information to Gen. Douglas MacArthur for years before the generalŠ—Ès return. MacArthur himself awarded him the Distinguished Service Cross.

Directed by Matthew Hausle and Steven C. Barber, Š—“Never SurrenderŠ— frustrates with its lack of focus. We learn as much or more about the Oklahoma Military Academy, where Mr. Ramsey trained, and polo, a sport he loved, than we do about what it was like living as a wanted man behind enemy lines. Through interviews with Mr. Ramsey (he died in 2013), military historians, friends and family Š—” his wife, Raquel, was also an executive producer of the film Š—” we hear about how good a dancer he was, and about his postwar life as a business executive. But the episodes of greatest interest are left underexplored. The Ramsey story is a project that actually cries for Hollywood development.

Š—“Never Surrender: The Ed Ramsey StoryŠ— introduces one of the hundreds Š—” if not thousands Š—” of inspiring military heroes from World War II whose valor and courage have rarely gotten wide notice and appropriate appreciation.

Jean-Christophe Jeauffre, the director, accompanied the crew and recorded the unremitting cold and mechanical breakdowns that plagued them. He captured beauty, too Š—” this land has a harsh splendor and haunting silences Š—” and later recorded journal entries, read in voice-over by Zachary Quinto, written by Pascal Lee, a NASA scientist and crew member.

Take Š—“Ice Road Truckers,Š— mix it with Š—“The MartianŠ— and blend in a book of verse, and youŠ—Ève got something that resembles Š—“Passage to Mars,Š— a beguiling documentary thatŠ—Ès concerned as much with images as it is with information.

During a recent mission NASA tried out the HMP Okarian, a five-ton vehicle designed for long-range land travels. To get this Humvee-like truck to Devon, NASA flew it to the western Arctic then gave it to a team to drive some 2,000 miles to the island, much of it over sea ice Š—” part delivery service, part trial.

While those seeking interplanetary scenarios may want more details, fans of endurance stories will be pleased. Indeed, Š—“Passage to MarsŠ— has the effect of making a trip to another world appear almost secondary. The journey undertaken here seems nearly as frightful and fascinating.

Mr. Jeauffre savors lyrical words and footage. Though we get a few specifics about Mars, this film is more of a poetry and photography seminar than a science course. Facts and theories are often meager, as are particulars on the crew.

Devon Island, located in the Arctic, is the largest uninhabited island in the world. In that desolate place, described as Š—“Mars on Earth,Š— NASA has established an outpost to test strategies and equipment that may one day be used in space exploration, particularly on a trip to the red planet.

You donŠ—Èt have to remember the gutter headlines inspired by its namesake to find the true-crime documentary Š—“Amanda KnoxŠ— completely riveting. And not because of the lip-smacking speculations surrounding Ms. KnoxŠ—Ès eight-year battle with the Italian legal system after being charged with the 2007 murder of a housemate and fellow exchange student, Meredith Kercher. Rather, the directors, Brian McGinn and Rod Blackhurst, have produced a tightly edited, coherently structured and ultimately moving reassessment that burrows beneath the lurid in search of the illuminating.

Not the directors, who spotlight a possibly contaminated crime scene, shaky forensic evidence and abusive police interrogations. They also show how we judge attractive young women who dare to stray from what we consider appropriate social behavior. And Ms. Knox, now a self-possessed advocate for the wrongly convicted (after being exonerated in 2015 by ItalyŠ—Ès highest court), fully understands how her quirky personality abetted the tabloid narrative.

Their tactic is simple: Deep-dive into the crimeŠ—Ès physical evidence (including previously unreleased police and television footage) and give the key players sufficient time to explain, redeem or indict themselves. What emerges is less a portrait of an accused killer than a glaring revelation of unprincipled journalism and unapologetic sexism. Inflamed by the smug moral certitude of the chief prosecutor, Giuliano Mignini, and by the smutty insinuations of reporters like Nick Pisa Š—” a former contributor to The Daily Mail of London who marvels that anyone would expect fact-checking in the race to the front page Š—” the public was all too eager to embrace rumor over reason.

That narrative, though, makes Š—“Amanda KnoxŠ— a savage denunciation of the way entertainment imperatives have corrupted the news media. At this singular moment in our political history, the resonance is deafening.

Š—“Danny Says,Š— named for a Ramones song thatŠ—Ès named for Mr. Fields (heŠ—Ès their former manager), lets him speak at length, both in sit-down interviews and in audio clips. Said by the music photographer Leee Black Childers to be out of the closet before he was ever in, this Harvard Law dropout was a mainstay in Andy WarholŠ—Ès Factory scene (we see him in the 1965 film Š—“SpaceŠ—) and stumbled into reporting almost by accident.

To hear it from the new documentary Š—“Danny Says,Š— Danny Fields had a hand in the breakup of the Beatles and the discovery of the Ramones. He palled around with the photographer Linda Eastman (a.k.a. Linda McCartney). He tried playing matchmaker for Jim Morrison and Nico, an introduction that resulted in a strange stare-down. He signed MC5 and the Stooges to Elektra in one swoop. He tripped on acid on the floor of Leonard Cohen and Judy CollinsŠ—Ès hotel room.

To paraphrase one of the many friends who share stories of Mr. Fields in this anecdotal, loosely structured movie, heŠ—Ès the guy who would talk you into buying some sort of abstract painting before the work was widely understood. Variously a journalist, a publicist and a Zelig-like gadfly of the music scene, he had a consistent ear for the next new thing.

Mr. FieldsŠ—Ès presence at so many filmed and photographed events gives the director, Brendan Toller, plenty of visual material. But if Mr. FieldsŠ—Ès contributions to pop music deserve more fame, the movie plays like an overcorrection, a spirited but repetitive testament to one manŠ—Ès excellent taste.

ItŠ—Ès easy to fault the one-sidedness of Š—“Do Not Resist,Š— Craig AtkinsonŠ—Ès documentary about the militarization of the police in the United States, but thatŠ—Ès missing the point. Sure, plenty of local police officers Š—” a majority, even Š—” have more in common with Andy Taylor (Andy Griffith), the genial television sheriff of the 1960s than they do with a storm trooper. But this unsettling film is about the planting and nurturing of a mind-set, one grounded in hostility and fear.

The film doesnŠ—Èt unearth anything that hasnŠ—Èt already been voiced, and it could use more details on the scope of the phenomenon. But with more police shootings in the headlines just in the past few days, itŠ—Ès nothing if not timely.

Later we see a drug raid in which overwhelming force netted little, some high-testosterone training sessions and debates over a program that funnels used military-grade equipment to police departments. The concern is that police officers and agencies are being inculcated with a military frame of mind that views the citizenry as the enemy and are being given formidable weaponry that reinforces that perception, both among the officers and among the populace.

The film begins with footage of Ferguson, Mo., in the aftermath of the shooting of Michael Brown in 2014. The images are familiar from television, but on the big screen they take on a deeper ominousness.
Š—“Girl AsleepŠ— is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 17 minutes.

Its protagonist, Greta Driscoll (Bethany Whitmore), is first seen glumly sitting alone on a schoolyard bench while behind her students wearing hideous school uniforms Š—” maroon shorts and yellow shirts Š—” are playing basketball. A cheerful frizzy-haired boy with braces on his teeth introduces himself as Elliott (Harrison Feldman), and these two outsiders become instant pals. Minutes later, Greta is approached by three snooty girls who condescendingly offer their friendship; when she doesnŠ—Èt know how to respond, they sashay off.

The day arrives, and the house suddenly fills with teenagers dancing to SylvesterŠ—Ès 1978 disco hit, Š—“You Make Me Feel (Mighty Real).Š— Greta also has a moody older sister, Genevieve (Imogen Archer), whose handsome boyfriend affects the air of a Gallic lounge lizard.

How might it feel to be a shy 14-year-old wallflower going to a new school in an Australian suburb in the late 1970s? Rosemary MyersŠ—Ès charming offbeat fantasia, Š—“Girl Asleep,Š— offers a giddy approximation. Much of this uncategorizable hybrid of a movie and childrenŠ—Ès theater piece is played out on an elaborate stage set.

The movie was inspired by the writings of the psychologist Bruno Bettelheim, whose most famous work, Š—“The Uses of Enchantment,Š— analyzed fairy tales from a Freudian perspective. Shot in a 4:3 aspect ratio, the film originated as the third part of a theatrical trilogy mounted at the Windmill Theater in Adelaide. For all its flirtation with nightmarish imagery, it is too sweet-natured to be scary.

Initially, Š—“Girl AsleepŠ— threatens to be a cute comedy about social misfits who rescue each other, but it quickly takes a sharp left turn and morphs into a surreal exploration of that in-between age when childish fears and fantasies collide with the realities of teenage society. The story begins in earnest when GretaŠ—Ès eccentric parents, Conrad (Matthew Whittet) and Janet (Amber McMahon), over her strenuous objections, decide to bring her out of her shell by giving her a 15th birthday party to which they invite the entire school.

At the party, Elliott appears and confesses to Greta that he wants them to be more than friends and is shattered when he tries to kiss her and is rudely rebuffed. Increasingly anxious, she flees the party, plunges into the woods behind her house and embarks on a through-the-looking-glass adventure that is the movieŠ—Ès centerpiece. In the forest she flees the sounds of barking wolves and encounters mythological creatures as well as family members in storybook disguises. The movie is so aggressively art directed that its strongest creative force appears to be its scenic designer, Jonathon Oxlade, whose imaginative whimsy evokes Tim Burton at his most lighthearted.

The movie is punctuated with zany visual jokes. A boy whose face blends in with her bedroom wallpaper pops out of the design, and enigmatic signs are posted in unlikely places. At such moments, Š—“Girl AsleepŠ— conveys a sense that anything might happen. As it seesaws between GretaŠ—Ès conscious and unconscious minds, the movie begins to feel like a waking dream.

The story isnŠ—Èt flashy and neither is the animation in Š—“Long Way North,Š— qualities that give the film a certain low-key charm in an age of fast-moving sagas eye-poppingly served. This tale, which in its theatrical release is being shown in both English- and French-language versions, has a young heroine, but you wonŠ—Èt mistake it for Š—“Frozen.Š—

The frosty landscapes have a subtle beauty, pale and sometimes shrouded in mist, giving the film a very different look from what often comes out of the big studios Š—” somber, which is appropriate to the story. The movie is likely to seem thin in every way to many young viewers, but discerning ones might appreciate its differences.
Š—“Long Way NorthŠ— is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for perilous moments.

The director, R’©mi Chay’©, who drew inspiration from the expedition of Ernest Shackleton in the Antarctic, resists the temptation to turn her quest into a cheesy romance. Oh, there are hints of one as she talks her way onto a ship and heads north, but the movie stays focused on her quest, which is full of dangers and disappointments.

She is Sacha, a 14-year-old member of the Russian aristocracy in the late 1800s, and like any strong-willed animated teenage girl, she is determined not to be bound to the life her parents have mapped out for her. In some movies of this genre that merely means sneaking out of a castle and exploring the marketplace, but for Sacha it means going in search of her beloved grandfather, an explorer who led an expedition to the Arctic and didnŠ—Èt return.

In the few performances shown, the Stones are in full, astounding flower: Mr. Jagger still moves as sinuously as ever; Mr. Richards still coaxes rockŠ—Ès most expressive yawps and howls from his guitar. And the reactions recall when rock truly mattered as a force for change: Š—“Obama and the Rolling Stones in the same week!Š— shouts an exultant Cuban, one of an estimated 500,000 at the Havana show. Š—“The chains are broken!Š—

Early in Š—“The Rolling Stones Ol’©, Ol’©, Ol’©!,Š— Mick Jagger notes that several Latin American nations in the 1960s and Š—È70s censored rock music. Š—“The Rolling Stones, being part of this rebellious movement,Š— he adds, Š—“was anathema to a lot of these regimes.Š—
Š—“The Rolling Stones Ol’©, Ol’©, Ol’©!: A Trip Across Latin AmericaŠ— is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested), perhaps to maintain the bandŠ—Ès street cred.

Directed slickly by Paul Dugdale, Š—“Ol’©Š— is less a concert film or travelogue than a historical account Š—” swiftly, smartly assembled, reflecting events only six months old. While the band plays stadiums in Chile, Argentina, Uruguay, Brazil, Peru, Colombia and Mexico, negotiations are underway for a free show in Havana. Complications arise, the sort that crop up when youŠ—Ère the Stones: President ObamaŠ—Ès surprise announcement of a visit to Cuba forces a scheduling change, and the pope weighs in, tsk-tsking when the revised date is Good Friday. Š—“ItŠ—Ès a bit cheeky,Š— Keith Richards says of His HolinessŠ—Ès comments. Š—“HeŠ—Ès not my manager.Š—

Wait a second: The Stones have never been all that political, much less associated with any movement. But try telling that to fans on the Ol’© tour of Latin America. To those like the cultish Š—“rolingasŠ— of Argentina, the Stones embody not just the music but a way of life.

To warm to the biopic Š—“M. S. Dhoni: The Untold Story,Š— you probably do have to be a cricket fan, and an indulgent one at that. Long (180 minutes) and languid, it takes you through the life of Mahendra Singh Dhoni, the unflappable captain of the Indian cricket team that won the 2011 World Cup.

The movie, written and directed by Neeraj Pandey, is not hagiographic or overly obvious. Instead, itŠ—Ès something of a quiet muddle, with too many squandered or dramatically blurry scenes. (Even the song montages are wasted; in one we see three versions of the same action, as if the editor ran out of ideas or footage.)

Mr. Pandey gets a bit of help from his star: Mr. Rajput lends Dhoni a poker-faced charisma and manages to convey some vague determination. But vague determination does not a hero make. I learned more about Mr. Dhoni Š—” his enigmatic character and what marked him as a great captain Š—” by reading about him after watching this movie than I did during three long hours.

You donŠ—Èt have to understand cricket to enjoy a good cricket movie. Š—“LagaanŠ— (2001), whose centerpiece was a rousing match of underdog (Indian) versus overdog (British colonials), got the heart pounding, even if you couldnŠ—Èt follow all the ins and outs of the game. It was the rare Bollywood movie to reach across the aisle, as it were, attracting moviegoers beyond the faithful.

Dhoni (Sushant Singh Rajput), as presented here, is a natural athlete Š—” cricket wasnŠ—Èt even his sport of choice as a boy Š—” a nice guy and, in the end, something like a national hero. He meets setbacks with a pause (a kind of timeout) and a hard-to-read smile. Then he goes on. What makes him tick? That remains the untold story.
Š—“M.S. Dhoni: The Untold StoryŠ— is not rated.
Š—“Homeland: Iraq Year ZeroŠ— is not rated. It is in Arabic, with English subtitles. Running time: Part 1, 2 hours 40 minutes; Part 2, 2 hours 54 minutes.

Family members and neighbors seem close to one another in Š—“Before the Fall,Š— the first half of Š—“Homeland,Š— although their houses are separated by concrete walls. ThereŠ—Ès a bit of squabbling when Mr. FahdelŠ—Ès family digs a well. The residents know war is coming; theyŠ—Ève seen it before. The current state of the neighborhood has been defined, it appears, more by foreign incursions and sanctions than by Hussein. In any event, the people depicted are cheerful and congenial, even when they boast of the victory they expect to achieve should any American dare to set foot on their territory.

A little over an hour into Š—“Homeland,Š— in a bit of text barely distinguishable from the English subtitles, Mr. Fahdel tersely imparts a piece of information concerning one of the filmŠ—Ès subjects. ItŠ—Ès a blink-and-you-miss-it moment that both makes the heart sink and lights a fuse. Subsequent moments of lightheartedness, including a scene at a bazaar thatŠ—Ès practically redolent of the multifarious spices sold therein, are freighted with that terrible knowledge. And as Mr. Fahdel depicts the tone of the state propaganda heating up via various living room televisions, a stomach-churning tension mounts.

WhatŠ—Ès coming canŠ—Èt be stopped, we know. The filmŠ—Ès second part, Š—“After the Battle,Š— is a little surprising in that it depicts its subjects trying to maintain ordinary life amid the rubble and military checkpoints. American soldiers are shown treating the citizens of the land they invaded as if they were minor nuisances, like insects. Yet Mr. FahdelŠ—Ès family responds to its new reality with a kind of resigned resilience. (While the movie doesnŠ—Èt reprise Vice President Dick CheneyŠ—Ès confident assertion that the United States forces would be Š—“greeted as liberators,Š— this film, like so many other pieces of Iraq War reportage, lends that prediction an awful, hollow irony.)

Saddam HusseinŠ—Ès regime in Iraq was despotic, oppressive, criminal and worse. Yet something that Westerners can recognize as Š—“ordinary lifeŠ— took place in certain sectors of Iraq during his rule. The Iraq-born filmmaker Abbas Fahdel, who has long resided in France, chronicles his own extended familyŠ—Ès everyday life in Iraq in 2002 in the first half of his two-part film, Š—“Homeland: Iraq Year Zero,Š— opening on Thursday. Shooting on video in his brotherŠ—Ès home near Baghdad, he shows his niece and nephews watching television one morning; a piece of state propaganda referring to Hussein as Š—“Beloved LeaderŠ— soon gives way to a Looney Tune cartoon featuring Foghorn Leghorn.

But resilience cannot resist everything. In the movieŠ—Ès final moments, certain events that seemed to be portents of a hopeful future are counteracted by wartime catastrophes, including, finally and most terribly, the death of a family member, of which the director had informed viewers (with that fleeting text) in the first half. It is almost unbearable to sit through, which is as it should be. Š—“Never think that war, no matter how necessary, nor how justified, is not a crime,Š— Ernest Hemingway wrote. Š—“Homeland: Iraq Year ZeroŠ— is both an irrefutable proof of that statement and a nagging reminder that the statement is insufficient to address the ultimate tragedy of war.

So thereŠ—Ès that. But how is the movie? It is a competent if sometimes heavy-handed affair, a mosaic of fictitious and underexplored characters who hear the assault but are too self-preoccupied to act. A family moving in (Samira Wiley of Š—“Orange Is the New BlackŠ— and Michael Potts, both fine, play the spouses) struggles with mice, decrepit walls and rearing their son; a superintendent (Adrian Martinez) fights off vandals; a boy (Evan Fine) witnesses his parentsŠ—È crumbling marriage; a girl (the promising Sophia Lillis) living with her grandparents believes Kitty might be the mother who abandoned her long ago.

There is a conceit to Puk GrastenŠ—Ès drama Š—“37Š— that must be addressed up front. The film assumes that the oft-repeated circumstances surrounding the rape and murder of Kitty Genovese in Kew Gardens, Queens, in March 1964 are true Š—” that 37 witnesses (actually, 38) did nothing to intervene. But the facts are otherwise, as Š—“The Witness,Š— an effective documentary released in June that follows Ms. GenoveseŠ—Ès brother Bill as he investigates the crime, proved. The popular belief that neighbors ignored her cries, a notion, based on police claims, reported in a New York Times article at the time (and since reconsidered by the paper), was an exaggeration. Alas, a closing intertitle quotes the piece.

Pressure builds in a protracted sequence of sputtering lobby lights, leaky fixtures, dying dowagers, the assault itself and the hysteria of the young girl. Implicit is the idea that the murder embodied a neighborhoodŠ—Ès moral decay. In the face of real-life tragedy, Š—“37Š— only perpetuates a myth.

Over coffee at the local Blue Jay diner, and later, while sitting by a lake, the pair catch up and look back. Jim has never married, while Amanda, who is visiting a pregnant sister, declares, none too convincingly, that she is happily wed to an older man with two grown children. Later, she confesses her anxiety about having married a soon-to-be senior (heŠ—Ès 64) whom she realizes she may have to care for in the not-too-distant future.
Š—“Blue JayŠ— is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 25 minutes.

In its richest moments, Š—“Blue JayŠ— is a bittersweet reflection of midlife regression, in which onetime teenage sweethearts momentarily throw off present-day cares and relive a magical past. As they go back, the years seem to fall away. When the blond, beautiful Amanda relaxes her guard, her smile broadens, and a sunnier new dimension of her character emerges. SheŠ—Ès playful, impulsive and passionate; the light is back in her eyes.

Jim, in his late 30s, lives in Tucson, where he has been working in construction, hanging drywall. He has returned to his childhood home after the death of his mother, to clear up her affairs. A typical Mark Duplass alter ego, Jim is a playful, insecure man-child, not unlike Brett Pierson, his character on the shambling, bittersweet HBO series Š—“Togetherness,Š— for which he was a writer, and which was canceled this year, after two seasons. That show, in which Mr. Duplass portrayed a married man trying to be a responsible adult, was steeped in a similar mood of middle-aged disappointment and angst.

Š—“Blue Jay,Š— Alex LehmannŠ—Ès amiable black-and-white film about ex-lovers who meet by chance two decades after breaking up, has the inestimable benefit of Sarah PaulsonŠ—Ès emotional electricity zapping through it. When Ms. PaulsonŠ—Ès character, Amanda, runs into her former high school boyfriend, Jim (Mark Duplass, who wrote the screenplay), at a supermarket in Crestline, Calif., there is a moment of shocked recognition. Crestline is a faded resort town 80 miles east of Los Angeles, in the San Bernardino Mountains. It sets the tone of a movie drenched in nostalgia and regret for what might have been.

The two repair to the house where Jim grew up and where the closets are crammed with memorabilia and the bookshelves stacked with his motherŠ—Ès romance novels. On an old cassette recorder, they listen to their younger selves improvising a routine in which they play a long-married couple. Their bygone romance momentarily rekindles as they slow-dance to the Annie Lennox hit Š—“No More Š—…I Love Yous.Š—ÈŠ— As a rap song plays, Jim falls to his knees to do an awkward break dance.

Š—“Blue JayŠ— is wistful and beautifully acted until the moment Amanda produces an unsent letter from Jim that she has discovered among the piles of old clothes and keepsakes. Nostalgia gives way to melodrama, and dramatic truth to soapy histrionics, and Š—“Blue JayŠ— falters on a formulaic revelation about mistakes made and lessons learned too late.

Thanks to Matthew BrownŠ—Ès fanciful script, however, their predicament never feels remotely perilous. Emboldened by a street-wise cookie (Nell Williams) and the pile-driving music of the Clash, Shay shoulders his grown-up responsibilities with shocking ease. His charmed adventures are given an even greater assist by the bandŠ—Ès frontman, Joe Strummer (played with cool magnetism by Jonathan Rhys Meyers), who pops up periodically to deliver buck-up homilies.

ItŠ—Ès the late 1970s in Š—“London Town,Š— where 14-year-old Shay (Daniel Huttlestone), a fragile-looking kid in neatly pressed bell-bottoms, is about to be catapulted into adulthood. Punk and Thatcherism are at loggerheads and the far-right group known as the National Front is peddling white supremacy on street corners. But for Shay, the most pressing problem is his falling-apart family.

More guardian angel than punk idol, this Strummer (the real one died in 2002) is a big-brother fantasy. Mr. Rhys Meyers does his own singing and convincingly mimics the legendŠ—Ès intense stage presence. Yet the eraŠ—Ès skinhead riots and striking workers Š—” and StrummerŠ—Ès biting, pro-immigrant lyrics Š—” are never more than window dressing in a movie that would rather scatter fairy dust than grit.

An awkward merger of wide-eyed innocence and political unrest, Derrick BorteŠ—Ès sweet, almost sugary picture wants to rock but never finds the gumption Š—” unlike ShayŠ—Ès mother (Natascha McElhone), who absconded years earlier to a London squat to pursue her musical career. And when his father (the reliable Dougray Scott), a music-shop owner and part-time taxi driver, is hospitalized after losing an argument with a runaway piano, Shay and his little sister must fend for themselves.

ItŠ—Ès no coincidence that Shakespeare is referenced in Š—“MirzyaŠ—; there are echoes of Š—“Romeo and JulietŠ— in several scenes. Adil works as a stable hand, while Soochi is on the cusp of marrying a wealthy and clean-cut man, Karan (Anuj Choudhry, always slick), who just happens to be AdilŠ—Ès employer. The nearer Adil and Soochi get to rekindling their old romance, the closer they come to danger.

The film, by Kim A. Snyder, revisits the shooting in December 2012 that left 20 students and six staff members dead at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn. The focus, though, is on the aftermath Š—” not merely the initial reaction, but the lingering effects on families, teachers, emergency medical workers. That makes it must viewing for the audience least likely to watch it: Lawmakers and others who failed to use the shooting as a catalyst for reasonable gun control measures. The film isnŠ—Èt a strident piece of advocacy Š—” the gun control issue is just a small part of it Š—” but its sentiments are clear, underscored with heartache eloquently expressed.

Those who relate their stories talk repeatedly about how the shooting was so beyond the scope of anyoneŠ—Ès experience that there was no template for how to respond or recover, whether for parents who lost children, children who lost playmates or staff members who eventually had to return to work. There is a real sense of everyone still being at sea almost four years later. This film is not about people who have made peace with what happened or learned how to move on.

Š—“NewtownŠ— is as hard a documentary to watch as youŠ—Ère likely to encounter. It needed to be; anything less would have been too dismissive of one of the most traumatic American tragedies in recent memory.

Working with naturalistic dialogue and organically developed characters, the two leads are a pleasure to watch. Š—“OvationŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Supposedly for language, but unless the phrase Š—“bikini waxŠ— sends you ducking for cover, youŠ—Èll be fine.

Henry JaglomŠ—Ès movies are like artisanal cupcakes: The shape is sometimes weird, the flavors unpredictable, and the frosting occasionally overdone. The two could hardly be more dissimilar. Thomas is the adopted biracial son of sheep and cattle farmers in the Pyrenees. Damien is a spoiled, high-strung son of Marianne (Sandrine Kiberlain), a doctor from the valley below, and her husband, Nathan (Alexis Loret), a helicopter pilot in an unidentified war zone. The family keeps in touch via Skype. In one of her strongest performances, Ms. KiberlainŠ—Ès Marianne is a dedicated physician who goes out of her way to help others and has no qualms about exerting authority.

Marianne makes a house call to ThomasŠ—Ès farm when his mother, Christine, has a pulmonary infection, and discovers that Christine, who has a history of miscarriages, is pregnant. Unaware of Thomas and DamienŠ—Ès mutual hostility, she invites Thomas to stay in her house so he can avoid the daily three-hour round-trip commute, much of it on foot, and she coaches Christine through her pregnancy.

Once Thomas has moved in, Damien, the more articulate of the two, nervously confesses, Š—“I donŠ—Èt know if IŠ—Èm into guys or just youŠ— and initiates a first embrace, which Thomas seems to welcome before recoiling.

Scenes of Thomas pitching hay and brushing cattle underline the suggestion that he is a symbolic force of nature exerting a gravitational pull. As he tramps through the snow on his way to school, you have a piercing sense of a young man in harmony with nature. In certain shots, he is almost heartbreakingly beautiful, yet unaware of his charisma.

To fight or to fall in love: That is the choice two antagonistic high school classmates face in Š—“Being 17,Š— a touching drama about raging hormones, bullying and sexual awakening Š—” and the strongest film in many years by the post-New Wave French director Andr’© T’©chin’©.

The film follows their conflict over three academic trimesters. Their scuffles begin as pranks by Thomas, who trips and shoves Damien in surprise attacks. The matches become increasingly brutal and ritualistic, inflicting injuries.

While Thomas struggles with his schoolwork, Damien is an academic star, math whiz and arrogant nerd who in his spare time takes classes in self-defense. ThomasŠ—Ès visceral hostility is exacerbated by DamienŠ—Ès air of superiority and by the rhinestone earring he wears. But in the high school pecking order, both are outsiders.

Š—“Being 17Š— is Mr. T’©chin’©Š—Ès first screenwriting collaboration with C’©line Sciamma, whose films Š—“Water Lilies,Š— Š—“TomboyŠ— and Š—“GirlhoodŠ— address gender and sexuality with a contemporary immediacy. The movie is not really about deciding whether youŠ—Ère gay or straight Š—” those terms are never spoken. ItŠ—Ès about the chemistry of two people at a moment in time.

Even when punching each other furiously, Thomas (Corentin Fila) and Damien (Kacey Mottet Klein), combatants whose senseless schoolyard fights have an undertone of repressed desire, wear the stricken expressions of innocents caught up in a war they donŠ—Èt understand and would rather not fight.
Š—“Being 17Š— is not rated. It is in French, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 54 minutes.

Notes of magical realism are threaded through the movie. One night in the mountains, Thomas strips naked and dives into an icy lake while Damien watches, entranced. In another scene, Marianne, whose husband is away on a combat mission, has an erotic fantasy in which Thomas makes love to her. Such moments give Š—“Being 17Š— a semi-mythological dimension. At one point, late in the movie, the boys exchange literary quotations about desire.
Š—“Middle School: The Worst Years of My LifeŠ— is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for naughty words cut off in midutterance.
ANDY WEBSTER

Lauren Graham is sufficient as RafeŠ—Ès mother, while Rob Riggle brings standard-issue smarminess to the role of her boyfriend. As RafeŠ—Ès co-conspirator Jeanne, Isabela Moner is merely adorable. Rafe Khatchadorian (an affable Griffin Gluck), booted out of two educational institutions, is now enrolled at Hills Village Middle School, dominated by the pompous, rules-obsessed Principal Dwight (Andy Daly). The latest entry in the revenge-on-the-educator genre Š—” extending at least as far back as Š—“MatildaŠ— Š—” is the slick, harmless Š—“Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life,Š— from CBS Films and adapted from the novel out of the James Patterson book factory. Directed by Steve Carr (Š—“Paul Blart: Mall CopŠ—), the movie borrows a trick or two from the Disney XD series Š—“Kirby Buckets,Š— with a dollop of Š—“A Beautiful MindŠ— for dramatic heft.

But then, in August, details emerged about a sexual assault case involving Mr. Parker when he was a student at Penn State in 1999. He and his friend Jean Celestin (who shares a story credit on Š—“BirthŠ—) were accused of raping a fellow student. Mr. Parker was acquitted. Mr. Celestin was initially convicted, but the charges were dropped after he appealed. The accuser committed suicide in 2012. The ugliness of the episode, coming to light at a time when rape on college campuses and the sexual depredations of celebrities are all over the news, triggered public rejections of the movie, including a powerful Op-Ed piece by Roxane Gay in The New York Times.

In movies (from D. W. GriffithŠ—Ès Š—“The Birth of a NationŠ— in 1915 through countless westerns and action thrillers), the violation of women is the strongest, least arguable pretext for male violence. ItŠ—Ès what makes killing the thing that a manŠ—Ès got to do. But precisely because itŠ—Ès such a potent and readily available premise, this pat, patriarchal rape-and-revenge logic is one of the things that makes Mr. ParkerŠ—Ès Š—“BirthŠ— feel smaller than its ambitions and less radical than it perhaps wants to be.

Š—“The Birth of a Nation,Š— Nate ParkerŠ—Ès debut feature as a director, presents an unusually vexing and complicated case. In the months between its debut at the Sundance Film Festival in January and its release this Friday, the movie Š—” which dramatizes the slave rebellion led by Nat Turner in Virginia in 1831 Š—” has found itself on both sides of the argument, simultaneously the must-see and the wonŠ—Èt-see movie of the year.

Such rapes were part of the everyday reality of slavery. In Š—“The Birth of a Nation,Š— the assaults (filmed more discreetly than other acts of brutality) reveal the vulnerability of enslaved women. They also expose the powerlessness of enslaved men, who are denied the traditional male prerogative of protecting Š—” which is also to say of controlling, of owning Š—” their wives. In dramatic terms, Nat and Hark are the victims, the ones on whom the task of seeking justice falls.
Š—“The Birth of a NationŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Violence begets violence.  Running time: 2 hours.

Recent scholarship (notably Edward E. BaptistŠ—Ès Š—“The Half Has Never Been ToldŠ—) has emphasized both the systemic cruelty and the economic basis of enslavement, and Mr. Parker forcefully dismantles some of the lingering mythology about the Old South. The benevolence or meanness of individual masters makes very little difference in a society built on the total exploitation of human bodies for profit.

The novelist William Styron, in his controversial Š—“The Confessions of Nat TurnerŠ— (1967), notoriously depicted Turner as a psychopath. Mr. Parker wants to present him as a prophet and a political thinker, a mystical visionary who is also a canny tactician and theorist, an amalgam of Malcolm X and William Wallace, the hero of Š—“Braveheart.Š— The elements of the characterŠ—Ès personality donŠ—Èt quite cohere, and as the movie progresses toward its bloody climax, Mr. ParkerŠ—Ès gifts as an actor Š—” his quiet sensitivity, his ability to register nuances of pain and insight in his eyes Š—” are undermined by his choices as a director. He occupies the center of the frame and strikes a series of warrior poses, bellowing exhortations at his followers.

Which is not to deny that he has attempted something grand and accomplished something real. The movie, uneven as it is, has terrific momentum and passages of concentrated visual beauty. The acting is strong even when the script wanders into thickets of rhetoric and mystification. And despite its efforts to simplify and italicize the story, itŠ—Ès admirably difficult, raising thorny questions about ends and means, justice and mercy, and the legacy of racism that lies at the root of our national identity. There is still a lot of reckoning to be done. Birth is a messy business. And so is what comes after.

Can going to a movie be a moral obligation? A political gesture? There are occasions when various interested parties Š—” filmmakers, publicists and perhaps especially critics Š—” would like you to think so. Buying a ticket can become a test of seriousness, of personal commitment to a position or a cause. Jerry SeinfeldŠ—Ès sitcom mom would not rest until her son had fulfilled the duty to watch Š—“SchindlerŠ—Ès List.Š— (Š—“Oh, you have to go. You have to!Š—) To make other plans would have been a filial, tribal and ethical betrayal, a lapse only a few steps removed from outright Holocaust denial.

Nat TurnerŠ—Ès owner, Samuel Turner (Armie Hammer), was his childhood playmate. SamuelŠ—Ès mother (Penelope Ann Miller) taught young Nat to read, a small act of subversion that would have large consequences. Restricted to the Bible Š—” Š—“those books are for white folks,Š— she says of the other volumes on the shelves of the plantation house library Š—” Nat grows up with a perverse pastoral calling, traveling around the county to preach obedience to his fellow slaves. (Samuel pockets the money for his services.) Nat witnesses unspeakable tortures and deprivations that are also entirely routine. As he is radicalized, his eloquence, his charisma and his knowledge of Scripture become weapons deployed against his oppressors, and the relative kindness of the white Turners proves to be an illusion.

In any case, Š—“The Birth of a NationŠ— is not Š—“only a movieŠ—; itŠ—Ès precisely a movie, an ambitious attempt to corral the contradictions of history within the conventions of popular narrative. It dwells, sometimes too comfortably, sometimes too clumsily and sometimes with bracing effectiveness, within long-established patterns of mainstream movie storytelling. In the context of Hollywood history, Mr. Parker is less a revolutionary than a revisionist, adapting old strategies to new purposes, inflecting familiar tropes of violence and sentimentality with fresh meanings.

Arriving at Sundance in Utah amid an ultrawhite Oscar season, the film was greeted with ovations and a lucrative distribution deal. Hollywood had sinned, and redemption was at hand. Beyond that, an aura of almost messianic promise gathered around Mr. Parker (who plays Nat Turner) and his movie, which assumed an uncommon burden of importance. With a title evoking a grotesquely racist cinematic masterpiece and advertisements depicting the starŠ—Ès head noosed in an American flag, Š—“The Birth of a NationŠ— presented itself as an indispensable document not only of the countryŠ—Ès brutal past but also of its inflamed and polarized present. There was no question that you would have to see it.

Like Quentin TarantinoŠ—Ès Š—“Django UnchainedŠ— Š—” albeit in a more somber key Š—” Š—“The Birth of a NationŠ— is a revenge movie, a tale of righteous, bloody punishment for an unforgivable crime. Like Steve McQueenŠ—Ès Š—“12 Years a Slave,Š— it is most powerful when it dwells on the particulars of that crime, on the everyday wickedness of 19th-century slavery.

The question can also be asked in reverse. Do you ever have a moral obligation not to see a movie? Sometimes this is a matter of objectionable content, but more often nowadays the principled refusal to watch a film is a response to the bad behavior, proved or alleged, of its maker. People stay away from Woody Allen and Roman PolanskiŠ—Ès movies because they believe that to do otherwise would be to condone Š—” or at least not to condemn strongly enough Š—” the sexual crimes of which those directors have been accused.

Š—“ItŠ—Ès only a movieŠ— is not a phrase you are likely to hear from me. I believe in the moral force of art Š—” and in the special power of film to write history in lightning Š—” and also in the ethical responsibilities of artists and audiences. But my job is not to be your surrogate conscience, to tell you either that seeing this movie will affirm your abolitionist bona fides or that skipping it will affirm your solidarity with victims of sexual violence. Nor is it my job to judge Mr. Parker, except as the author and star of this film.

The emphasis on TurnerŠ—Ès singular, heroic stature is understandable Š—” this is, as IŠ—Ève suggested, a movie that traffics in familiar arcs and beats Š—” but it also thins out the story and warps its political implications. At one point, reference is made to the Š—“grapevineŠ— through which slaves in different places, despite being isolated and heavily policed, were able to communicate with one another. It would have been good to see that network in action, and to see the larger context of resistance in which TurnerŠ—Ès revolt Š—” hardly the only such event of its time Š—” took shape.

The idea of nationalism that Mr. Parker embraces is a decidedly old-fashioned one, based above all on the assertion of manhood. The sexual violence of slavery is dramatized in two episodes. NatŠ—Ès wife, Cherry, (Aja Naomi King), is brutally attacked by a gang of white men (led by a slave-catcher played by Jackie Earle Haley). (The close-up of her battered face afterward recalls the open-coffin photographs of Emmett Till, who was lynched for supposedly whistling at a white woman in 1955.) Later, Esther (Gabrielle Union), who is married to NatŠ—Ès friend Hark (Colman Domingo), is ordered by Samuel to have sex with one of his friends after a dinner party.

You need a tough woman for that sort of job, and Ms. Blunt, who moves easily out of crinolines and into combat gear, holds this material together with fierce, unwavering conviction. RachelŠ—Ès fantasy duo turn out to be Megan (Haley Bennett) and Scott (Luke Evans), a married couple who tend to pose or rut whenever RachelŠ—Ès train conveniently passes by. Megan also likes to stand on her balcony, playing peekaboo with her robe and flashing her undies and tummy. Or at least thatŠ—Ès how Rachel sees Megan. ThatŠ—Ès also how we see Megan, an outlook thatŠ—Ès meant to change as the points of view shift, diverge and unite. As always, much depends on whoŠ—Ès telling the story.
Š—“The Girl on the TrainŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for extremely bad adult behavior. Running time:  1 hour 45 minutes.

Its loomingest head belongs to the hard-working Emily Blunt, who plays Rachel, the storyŠ—Ès hub. She was once married to Tom (Justin Theroux, trying out his smile), whoŠ—Ès now married to Anna (Rebecca Ferguson), with whom he has a baby. A hard drinker, Rachel chugs booze like water and weeps like a broken faucet. SheŠ—Ès a sloshy mess, or so weŠ—Ère meant to believe from her alternating lightly or heavily smeared eyeliner, which functions as a kind of mood ring-Breathalyzer. SheŠ—Ès a masochist: She stares out of a commuter-train window at the house where she lived with Tom, and where he now lives with Anna and their child. Rachel is also a fantasist: She ogles another couple, dreaming about their lives.

Mr. Taylor doesnŠ—Èt so much juggle the movieŠ—Ès various parts Š—” including a fragmented timeline, a device that here is nothing but empty mannerism Š—” as lob them at the screen. (Erin Cressida Wilson wrote the script.) When Megan disappears, Rachel turns detective, if one mildly hindered by her drinking and narratively convenient habit of blacking out, which means that she doesnŠ—Èt always know whatŠ—Ès happened in her own life. Rachel goes through a crucible of agony, braving abuse, infertility, betrayal and ravages of the body and the mind. But she looks. And she learns, including about other women. ThatŠ—Ès the moral of this story, the appealing, gleaming jewel in the trash.

ItŠ—Ès based on the 2015 book by the British author Paula Hawkins that vaulted to the top of the best-seller list with a mix of unreliable narration, suspicious characters, ugly emotions, freewheeling gender stereotypes and a slowly kinking mystery that becomes as perilous as the labyrinth at the Overlook Hotel. With a troika of dubious female narrators, the book isnŠ—Èt an obvious choice for the big screen, partly because of its rotating first-person voices. One problem is how to get into those separate heads, which the director Tate Taylor has tried to solve with voice-overs and by piling on close-ups, creating a proximity approaching the dermatological.

Š—“The Girl on the TrainŠ— is a preposterous movie but not an unenjoyable one. If that sounds like faint praise, well, it is and it isnŠ—Èt. ThereŠ—Ès always something to be said for an entertainment that sustains its nuttiness all the way to its twisty finish. This one may not make much sense, but Š—” like a demented old film noir or a Shonda Rhimes show at its crazed best Š—” Š—“GirlŠ— doesnŠ—Èt falter in its absurdity or commitment to its own seriousness. It never winks. You may laugh (as the audience I saw it with did, on and off), but thereŠ—Ès genuine pleasure in that mirth.

Put another way, Rachel is a stand-in for us, the viewer, the voyeur who peers into other lives. Specifically, sheŠ—Ès a proxy for the consumer of a certain kind of glorious romantic fiction, in which beautiful women suffer magnificently. Hollywood used to excel at these kinds of stories, movies in which, say, Bette Davis or Ingrid Bergman suffered, endured and suffered some more before their teary, square-jawed, set-shouldered triumph. Those types of movies arenŠ—Èt all that common in American cinema these days, partly because women and their stories arenŠ—Èt. The sobs and drama nonetheless did keep flowing, first in daytime soap operas and later in nighttime soaps.

Rachel is a clever surrogate, especially because she doesnŠ—Èt really appear that far gone. She may drink way too much, but, well, she looks like the lovely, spunky and very appealing Ms. Blunt, just with chapped lips, splotchy skin and raccoon eyes. Like almost every star in a mainstream vehicle who plays a problematic character, Ms. Blunt Š—” her persona, filmography, likability, relatability Š—” serves as a kind of assurance from the filmmakers to the viewers not to worry, that things will turn out all right. Her stardom is our light at the end of the dark tunnel, a flickering promise, which is one thing that hasnŠ—Èt changed much since the days of old-studio female martyrdom.

The title character is a child, but two adult actors, Kathy Bates and Glenn Close, really give Š—“The Great Gilly HopkinsŠ— its considerable heart. This movie, though uneven, is affecting because of these two reliable stars.

Sophie N’©lisse, looking a bit too old to portray the 12-year-old sheŠ—Ès supposed to be, plays the main role, that of an unpleasant foster child who, as the movie opens, is being deposited at her latest home. Her new foster mother, Maime Trotter (Ms. Bates), keeps a messy house but has good will to spare, for both Gilly and her foster brother, W. E. (Zachary Hernandez).

The film, directed by Stephen Herek, is based on Katherine PatersonŠ—Ès award-winning 1978 book. (David Paterson, her son, wrote the screenplay.) GillyŠ—Ès transformation isnŠ—Èt entirely convincing, partly because not enough time is spent exploring the roots of her initial hostility, but the story is beautifully ambivalent. There is a feel-good element, but Gilly also experiences plenty of disappointments. ThatŠ—Ès what Š—“coming-of-ageŠ— is really all about: the realization that life is both kind and cruel.

Gilly is a tough sell, wanting only to be reunited with her biological mother, whom she has built into an idyllic figure, based on the very occasional postcard she receives from her. And yet she gradually warms to her new foster family, so much so that when her maternal grandmother, Nonnie (Ms. Close), shows up unexpectedly on the doorstep, Gilly doesnŠ—Èt want to go live with her, despite NonnieŠ—Ès lavish home.
Š—“The Great Gilly HopkinsŠ— is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for some moderately distressing themes.

Pete is a sex therapist who has achieved modest fame with a book that suggests that people spend too much time thinking about intercourse, orgasms and such, and would be more productive if they channeled their energy elsewhere.
