Arrested in 1939 by the Stalinist secret police and executed in 1940, he was granted posthumous official rehabilitation in 1954. Much of his work is lost.

Iggy Pop, born James Newell Osterberg Jr., recalls growing up in a trailer home outside of Ann Arbor, Mich., with amazingly supportive parents. It was Soupy Sales, an early television idol, who instructed his audience to limit their letters to 25 words or less, and itŠ—Ès advice that Iggy Pop took to heart when he began writing songs. While working in a record store, he discovered the avant-garde music of Harry Partch and other experimental composers. When he was briefly managed by Tony DeFries, David BowieŠ—Ès manager, he turned down the opportunity to star on Broadway in Š—“Peter Pan.Š—

Š—“Gimme DangerŠ— is handsomely designed and embellished with stop-motion animation depicting scenes from Iggy PopŠ—Ès childhood. It makes a strong case for a man who is widely credited with being the first rock performer to dive off the stage and into the audience, as the protopunk rebel who spawned a lineage that includes the Sex Pistols, the Ramones and those who came after.
Š—“Ever since,Š— he says, his eyes blazing, Š—“IŠ—Ève been out to get Š—Èem.Š—

For those who imagine that feverishly working out and losing enough weight can preserve a perfectly toned body at any age, images of Iggy Pop, over 60 and performing shirtless, reveal that there is no forestalling the ravages of time. At a certain point, the flesh starts hanging off the bone, no matter how skeletal the frame.
The closest Š—“Gimme DangerŠ— comes to a Rosebud moment of revelation is Iggy PopŠ—Ès recollection of how, as a teenager, contemptuous frat boys rocked the family trailer back and forth.
Š—“Gimme DangerŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for drug content and some strong language. Running time: 1 hour 48 minutes.

But between those tantalizing flashes of the anarchic hell raiser, he comes across as a smart, articulate chronicler of his own history and a musician fully aware of his influences and proud of his place in the annals of rock. Other members of the Stooges are interviewed separately and offer little of interest. The most informative is James Williamson, who left the band in the early 1980s and became a successful electronics engineer. He returned after the death of the guitarist Ron Asheton in 2009.

The spine of the documentary is an in-depth interview with Iggy Pop, 69, who tells his story in a deep, almost feral growl. Occasionally, his face lights up with a demonic grin, and you glimpse the soul of a proudly unrepentant wild man, who even more than Frank Sinatra, did it Š—“his wayŠ— and lived to tell the tale.

Considering the frenzied psychedelic circus it might have been, Š—“Gimme Danger,Š— Jim JarmuschŠ—Ès reverent documentary portrait of Iggy Pop, one of rockŠ—Ès ultimate daredevil provocateurs, is downright prim. There are casual confessions of self-destructive, out-of-control behavior by Iggy Pop and his band, the Stooges. But you donŠ—Èt see it. You only hear about it, and itŠ—Ès glossed over as yesterdayŠ—Ès bad-boy antics.

In performance footage, Iggy Pop is a live wire. Cadaverous and sinewy, with dyed blond hair, burning blue eyes and a chiseled torso, he is an extraordinary specimen. His look, he says, was partly inspired by Hollywood pharaohs like Yul Brynner in Š—“The Ten Commandments.Š—

Perhaps the director, who calls the Stooges Š—“the greatest rock Š—ÈnŠ—È roll band ever,Š— worried that hair-raising tales of past excesses would undermine this exercise in canonization. Š—“Gimme DangerŠ— also inexplicably leaves out Iggy PopŠ—Ès solo career, when he released the great albums Š—“The IdiotŠ— and Š—“Lust for Life.Š— That said, Š—“Gimme DangerŠ— is still plenty entertaining and includes many moments of foaming-at-the-mouth musical fury.

The film includes no retrospective scenes of indiscriminate drinking and drug taking, rampant sexual behavior or fights among bandmates. Iggy Pop is not shown vomiting onstage or rolling around on broken glass, both of which he was known to do. Not a groupie is to be seen. His current wife Š—” his third Š—” is mentioned but not introduced. Which is strange for a film about rock musicŠ—Ès closest equivalent to Dionysus. For the filmŠ—Ès intents and purposes, Iggy Pop hasnŠ—Èt had a personal life outside of rock Š—ÈnŠ—È roll.
Š—“InfernoŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for gun and bomb violence. Running time: 2 hours 1 minute.

Mr. Hanks, who changes young female sidekicks in this series more than he seems to switch jackets, keeps company in this movie with Felicity Jones, as Sienna Brooks, a lethally earnest doctor. SheŠ—Ès at his side in the hospital and soon on the run with him, chasing and being chased while finding clues in destination sites like the Palazzo Vecchio in Florence and St. MarkŠ—Ès Basilica in Venice. As in a lot of globe-trotting thrillers, these (mostly real) locations are attractive backdrops for the frenetically spinning story and characters. Like the references to classical literature and art, they are also meant to class up the joint, adding some high-culture luster to the pulp.

This savior complex is familiar but it also creates an argument about belief. Unlike in the earlier movies, the Roman Catholic Church is a supporting player in Š—“Inferno,Š— largely evident in landmarks and cultural touchstones rather than cults and murderous agents. (The script is by David Koepp.) Even so, skepticism about deep faith remains, most obviously in the billionaireŠ—Ès deranged belief and in the image of bomb-wielding fanatics. By the end, the story has shifted to Turkey and a dubiously coded landscape dotted with minarets, crescents and stars. ItŠ—Ès there that this doomsday fantasy reaches a frothing, hysterical climax and offers deliverance of a kind, once again with a savior right from a promised land called Hollywood.

Certainly Mr. Hanks, slipping back into the role of the so-called symbologist Robert Langdon for a third time, is a master of that great Hollywood sleight of hand in which a big star beguiles you so artfully that you donŠ—Èt see (or simply ignore) the deception. In Mr. HanksŠ—Ès case, this legerdemain depends on his natural appeal, which has deepened as heŠ—Ès settled into stardom, as well as his ability to bring remarkable characters down to earth. ThatŠ—Ès especially crucial with a civilian superhero like Langdon, one of those preposterously capable types who wears professorial threads instead of a cape and excels at cracking gnarly codes rather than bad-guy heads.

One of the obvious draws of civilian champions, those latter-day Nancy Drews and Hardy Boys, is that theyŠ—Ère inordinately, at times vulnerably, ordinary until they start doing their special thing. So when Langdon first appears in a hospital bed in Š—“Inferno,Š— groaning in pain amid the woozy camerawork, youŠ—Ère ready to put a cold compress on his (or, really, Mr. HanksŠ—Ès) head. ThereŠ—Ès no time. As a director, Mr. Howard tends to be a lead foot, either because he likes it like that (as in his racing movie Š—“RushŠ—) or knows that one of the smarter ways to handle certain material is to sprint through its twists. Here, he skips ready and set, and just goes.

As in the first movies (Š—“The Da Vinci CodeŠ— and Š—“Angels & DemonsŠ—), Langdon is called on to furrow his brow and fire up his genius to solve a puzzle. The main pieces in Š—“InfernoŠ— include a lethal virus and a megalomaniacal billionaire (Ben Foster), who apparently took his TED Talk too seriously. ThereŠ—Ès a shadowy security firm with an enigmatic owner (an amusing Irrfan Khan, whoŠ—Ès ready for Bond villainy) and the World Health Organization, which has been given a sexy makeover with enigmatic players (Omar Sy, Sidse Babett Knudsen) and fleets of gun-toting paramilitaries. There are flying bullets and drones, racing characters and cameras, nods to Dante and Botticelli.

Part of the draw of these movies is that they donŠ—Èt create beauty, but instead borrow the emotions of the beauty they depict. (This, more or less, is one definition of kitsch, courtesy of the philosopher Tomas Kulka.) That makes the movies easy to watch and easy to forget. As important, their postcard beauty and rented emotions also attenuate some of the less palatable aspects of their conspiracy theories. ThereŠ—Ès pleasure in watching characters solve puzzles and turn hunches into facts, yet when scaled up Š—” out of crime labs and onto the global stage Š—” all that problem-solving suggests itŠ—Ès only supermen like LangdonŠ—Ès brainiac who can save the world.

Late in Š—“Inferno,Š— Tom Hanks blurts out, Š—“My God, this is a labyrinth.Š— Well, of course it is, because Mr. Hanks is running (and running) through another muddled Dan Brown maze. Once again, this one comes to you from the director Ron Howard and his producing partner, Brian Grazer, who bring clenched-jaw commitment and a whole mess of filmmaking to every project, even the most disposable. In this case, the story may not make any sense, but theyŠ—Ère going to throw so much at you Š—” so many jumpy moves, so many tangled threads Š—” that you might not notice (or care).

Mr. HerzogŠ—Ès partner here is the volcanologist Clive Oppenheimer, a professor at the University of Cambridge. They met (where else?) at the edge of a volcano when Mr. Herzog was shooting Š—“Encounters at the End of the World,Š— his 2008 documentary about the Antarctic its splendors, secrets and visitors (like Mr. Oppenheimer). Š—“InfernoŠ— is a deeper plunge into some old preoccupations, as Mr. Herzog suggests by folding in scenes from that earlier movie as well as from another of his films, Š—“La Soufri’åre Š—” Waiting for an Inevitable DisasterŠ— (1977), about a volcano on the verge of eruption. Š—“Waiting for an Inevitable Disaster,Š— of course, could be the subtitle of many of his movies.

In his latest, Š—“Into the Inferno,Š— Mr. Herzog takes you straight to the edge of the abyss. In quotidian terms, it is a documentary about volcanoes. In Herzogian terms, it is a metaphysical exploration of the wonders and terrors of nature as well as the fragility and comedy of human life, complete with beautiful cinema-tography, haunting music, a church that looks like a chicken and a Communist attraction that resembles a Bethlehem manger. Written and directed by Mr. Herzog, it vaults across the globe Š—” from the South Pacific to Indonesia, Ethiopia, Iceland and North Korea Š—” as he peers into volcanoes, confers with experts and tries to understand what draws people to the fire.

ItŠ—Ès an exhilarating trip, filled with strange stories, fascinating rituals and ethereally beautiful images of bubbling magma and flowing lava, some of which were captured using drones. (The director of photography is Peter Zeitlinger.) By far the weirdest stop, though, delivers you right into North Korea, where national lore has it that the countryŠ—Ès founder, Kim Il-sung, first led the fight for independence at the foot of Mount Paektu, living in a log cabin where armies of civilians now come to worship. It would be easy to laugh at this spectacle, with its beloved leaders and mad smilers, if the whole thing were not so heart-rending and tragic, and if Mr. HerzogŠ—Ès gruff humanism didnŠ—Èt bring you to tears.

Few filmmakers make the world seem more wondrous than Werner Herzog, more worthy of exploration and veneration. For decades, he has been probing the limits of existence, charting its mysteries and madness in fiction and nonfiction movies that together have created an extraordinary body of work. Part cinematic magus, part cosmic philosopher, he takes you places you never knew you wanted to go, asks questions you never considered and introduces you to characters who suggest the worst and the very best about us. ThereŠ—Ès a strain of melancholia in this searching. IŠ—Èm not sure if Mr. Herzog thinks that we can be saved Š—” or are worth saving Š—” but his restlessness suggests perhaps.

That bond also works as a kind of through line, something to hold onto as the movie jumps from one location Š—” and one scientific and philosophic theme Š—” to the next. After its interlude in Vanuatu, where inhabitants speak of spirits in the volcanoes, it shifts to Indonesia, where farmers plant near a belching Mount Sinabung. From there, the movie travels to the hellishly hot, eerily stunning Afar Triangle in Ethiopia, where anthropologists are unearthing human bones tens of thousands of years old. Then itŠ—Ès off to Iceland, where Mr. Oppenheimer surveys the voluptuous, otherworldly landscape and Mr. Herzog reads aloud from the Codex Regius, a medieval manuscript.

Mr. Herzog brings the beauty and provides the on-and-off narration, the probing questions and the occasional glint of characteristic deadpan comedy, but he also relies on Mr. Oppenheimer as an on-camera interpreter. Mr. Oppenheimer is a charming interlocutor and, with his easy manner and slightly elfin face, he soon becomes an emblem for scientific inquiry at its most accessible and exciting. He grounds the movie in science but he also helps give it a conversational lightness, as he stands and delivers on, say, molten rock and Mr. Herzog ponders creation. ItŠ—Ès a winning, sneakily warming division of labor partly because this is also a documentary about friendship.
Š—“Into the InfernoŠ— is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 44 minutes.

Despite this oneŠ—Ès subject and Mr. HerzogŠ—Ès fondness for the word catastrophe, Š—“Into the InfernoŠ— is surprisingly buoyant, partly because of Mr. Oppenheimer, whoŠ—Ès credited as a collaborator. The movie was inspired by Mr. OppenheimerŠ—Ès 2011 book, Š—“Eruptions That Shook the World,Š— an inquiry into the impact of worldwide volcanic activity. From fire and brimstone to killer plumes and dinosaurs, it explores claims that, he writes, Š—“volcanism shaped prehistoric and historic social trajectories.Š— The film shares places with the book and narrows in on the impact of assorted eruptions, starting in the South Pacific nation of Vanuatu, a lush archipelago thatŠ—Ès home to active volcanoes.

When the commissioner brings along a sympathetic American philanthropist providing the financing, we discover the officialŠ—Ès own baggage: a habit of skimming money. (Not embezzlement, his secretary says, Š—“the optimal allocation of resources.Š—)

In 1942, a struggling school in rural China needs money. The faculty members, an agreeable if fractious lot, each have psychological baggage: Zhang Yiman (Ren Suxi) is blithely laissez-faire about sex; Pei Kuishan (played by an actor with the same name) has sensitive digestion; Zhou Tienan (Liu Shuailiang) is a righteous hothead; and the dean, Sun Henghai (Da Li), is trying to preserve his institution while raising his 15-year-old daughter, Jia (Bu Guanjin). A pending visit from a severe education commissioner (Han Yanbo) prompts the group to pressure an illiterate coppersmith (A Runa) into masquerading as an English teacher Š—” the title character Š—” to impress the official and secure funds. Enter antic pandemonium.

The second act is grim, as humiliations imposed by the commissioner, enraged by the ruse, exact a toll. TienanŠ—Ès defiance is broken; Yiman is verbally abused and, shorn of her hair, neutered. Like Ophelia in Š—“HamletŠ— (partly performed for the commissioner), she grows unhinged. Knowing the winning charisma and bracing independence Ms. Ren has manifested up to then, we feel YimanŠ—Ès pain, and by the end even more so.

Zhou Shen and Liu LuŠ—Ès bleak farce Š—“Mr. Donkey,Š— adapted from their play, has a sentimental streak, and, as farce can, a tendency to overheat. But beneath its mild staginess and intermittent mania lies a cynical, piercing parable about ChinaŠ—Ès past and perhaps its present.

Most infuriating are stories of those whoŠ—Ève sought treatment in the understaffed federal Veterans Affairs system. One employee recalls, Š—“We knew of horrific firsthand accounts of veterans who went to V.A. one, two, three times trying to get mental health care only to go out to a V.A. parking lot and literally blow their brains out in their car.Š—

Š—“Thank You for Your ServiceŠ— starts with a frantic, tear-filled 911 call reporting a suicide. ItŠ—Ès a gut-wrenching moment in a documentary thatŠ—Ès filled with them, and with scenes that make you want to scream in frustration at the bureaucracy faced by combat veterans seeking mental health services.

The statistics here are backed by interviews with those who have returned home in agony after fighting. One man describes being alone and playing Russian roulette, while others talk about constant nightmares and crippling survivorŠ—Ès guilt.
Still, that hope is tempered by cruel reality. This important film ends with a silent onscreen note: Š—“While you have watched this documentary, a veteran has committed suicide.Š—

Š—“Thank You for Your Service,Š— directed by Tom Donahue, uses its late scenes to explore nongovernment programs that have arisen to help veterans. Those examples are heartfelt and encouraging, and offer some hope after the devastating early sections.

Š—“We couldnŠ—Èt have drawn up a more catastrophic way to fail to meet mental health needs than the blueprints that were followed in this war,Š— a retired Navy psychologist says about Iraq. The facts bear him out: Over the past decade, the number of  suicides among veterans has soared.

Thank heavens Jim HoskingŠ—Ès lurid live-action cartoon, Š—“The Greasy Strangler,Š— found financing, because this oddity Š—” borrowing liberally from a precious, vanishing institution, midnight movies Š—” invites strong reactions. Yet its willful determination to be outr’© proves its undoing.

The actor Elijah Wood and the director Ben Wheatley (Š—“High-RiseŠ—), among the producers here, clearly love midnight-movie excess, and deserve credit for supporting this venture (written by Mr. Hosking and Toby Harvard). Cinematic provocation is always welcome. But John Waters and David Lynch, even at their most eccentric, have always had originality and a measure of heartfelt compassion. Mr. Hosking has only derivative posturing.

When father and son both seduce the zaftig kewpie doll Janet (Elizabeth De Razzo), tensions mount, as does the body count. An accusatory expletive is repeatedly invoked, as if future cult viewers were to share a whiskey shot whenever it recurs.

The plot concerns a milquetoast son, Big Brayden (Sky Elobar), and his domineering father, Big Ronnie (Michael St. Michaels), who revels in flatulence in their squalid home. By day, the two, clad in Pepto-Bismol-pink tops and shorts, conduct walking tours of landmarks of dubious Los Angeles disco history for gullible tourists. (Andrew HungŠ—Ès score sounds like flat, mildly dissonant Devo.) By night, Big Ronnie stalks human prey, coated in grease. (Mr. St. Michaels also wears an elephantine penile prosthesis for the part.) Characters with names like Oinker (who has a porcine proboscis) expire with eyeballs popping in low-budget splatter.

So Angela has both the hostile house and the thugs to worry about as she tries to protect both herself and her young charge. A particularly gruesome death awaits one of the people involved; some of the frights work reasonably well; and Ms. Ferland is convincing. But there arenŠ—Èt enough surprises or innovations to make this one stand out in the sea of horror fare that comes along this time of year.

ItŠ—Ès hard these days to make a memorable cursed-house movie. There have been so dang many of them, and the format is so limiting Š—” you can slam doors, make staircases creak, have the kitchen knives come alive Š—” and then what?

The scary stuff, though, lands mostly on Angela (Jodelle Ferland of Š—“Silent HillŠ—), who takes a job as a nanny to the boy. Mr. WilsonŠ—Ès best idea is the complication he introduces: Local toughs have been using the vacant house to store drugs, and they are pretty eager to retrieve their stash.

Š—“The Unspoken,Š— written and directed by Sheldon Wilson, has decent performances but fills up a lot of its time with the same old stuff as it tells the story of a rundown house where, back in 1997, a family of four vanished; the authorities found a lot of blood but no trace of the inhabitants. Now, a single mother (Pascale Hutton) and her silent son (Sunny Suljic), who hasnŠ—Èt spoken since his father died two years earlier, are moving into the old place.

The documentary filmmaker Anthony Baxter captured the fallout in Š—“YouŠ—Ève Been TrumpedŠ— (2012), which portrayed Mr. Trump as a callous despoiler of the environment with no respect for his neighbors. Some of them, we learn in Š—“YouŠ—Ève Been Trumped Too,Š— have hung Mexican flags in protest Š—” a reference to Mr. TrumpŠ—Ès promise to build a border wall.

Before he became a presidential candidate, Donald J. Trump began a lengthy campaign of chicken with the residents of Balmedie, Scotland, near Aberdeen, where his plans to build a golf resort went forward after a contentious approval process.

The big shock is that the elder Mr. Trump met with Mr. Baxter in March 2013, a gesture that Mr. Trump attributes to the showing of Š—“YouŠ—Ève Been TrumpedŠ— on the BBC and elsewhere. (Š—“YouŠ—Ève become a much more important person in terms of doing an interview,Š— he tells the filmmaker.) Given the scant screen time devoted to the encounter, Mr. Baxter doesnŠ—Èt seem to have gotten much from the interview, though he undercuts himself by keeping excerpts from it so brief.

His most effective gambit is to accompany Mr. Forbes and his wife, Sheila, to the Republican National Convention in Cleveland; Mr. Forbes says that the political divide in America reminds him of the initial debate over the golf project. This time, the Š—“youŠ— in the title is the United States.

This timely if ragged bookend finds Michael Forbes, and his mother, Molly, still without reliable running water after five years, because of pipe damage that, as Donald Trump Jr. and other members of the Trump Organization acknowledge in the film, resulted from the construction. The movie also argues that the resort has created only a fraction of the promised jobs.

As a filmmaker, Mr. Baxter often tends toward needless force-feeding. He juxtaposes Ms. ForbesŠ—Ès reminiscence of how as a young woman she used to keep cows Š—“bonnieŠ— (pretty) with a photo of Mr. Trump Jr. holding the severed tail of an elephant, killed in a hunting expedition. In a Michael Moore-style stunt, Mr. Baxter stands in front of the White House to tell passers-by about the familyŠ—Ès lack of running water.

In some ways, the movie is too abrupt for its own good. When itŠ—Ès revealed that PierreŠ—Ès younger sister, Jaqueline (Lais Dias), was also stolen by Arcay, the film doesnŠ—Èt pursue the matter, and a potentially rich subplot is lost. The narrowness of its perspective and its relatively brief 82-minute length disappoint. Yet Š—“DonŠ—Èt Call Me SonŠ— still manages to be a fascinating, sympathetic portrait of a lost boy abruptly thrown to the wolves.

It is not long before PierreŠ—Ès attitude of sullen acquiescence bursts into flames. He bridles when his biological parents, Gl’_ria (Ms. Nefussi, who plays both mothers) and Matheus (Matheus Nachtergaele), insist he take the name they gave him at birth, Felipe. But the real slap in the face comes during a clothes-shopping spree, when he steps out of the changing room wearing a black-and-white zebra-patterned dress. The homophobic Matheus is outraged, and the father and son nearly come to blows.
Š—“DonŠ—Èt Call Me SonŠ— is not rated. It is in Portuguese, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 22 minutes.

Who are you? That question nags at Pierre (Naomi Nero), the brooding androgynous protagonist of Anna MuylaertŠ—Ès Š—“DonŠ—Èt Call Me Son.Š— This Brazilian filmŠ—Ès title takes on a double meaning after Pierre discovers that Arcay (Dani Nefussi), the woman he presumed to be his biological mother, stole him from the hospital when he was a baby. That upsetting news arrives when the authorities burst into their shabby apartment, slap handcuffs on Arcay, then immediately subject her and Pierre to DNA tests.

The movie is a critique of identity on several levels: biological, sexual, social, cultural and class-related. The unstable, impulsive Pierre is no heroic rebel. He is a floundering young man with many hurdles ahead. But the movie unequivocally takes his side. In its blas’© way, Š—“DonŠ—Èt Call Me SonŠ— is subversive.

We have already seen Pierre, a tall, willowy 17-year-old, shedding his pants in the lavatory of a crowded dance club to reveal a black lace G-string and garters before having sex with a girl. At home he locks himself in the bathroom, shaves his chest, puts on eye makeup and lipstick, and shoots selfies. A guitarist and singer in a rock group, he is also seen passionately making out with a male band member after enraging a girl by refusing to kiss her.

His biological parents are affluent bourgeoisie who had been tirelessly searching for him since his disappearance, and his return leaves them overjoyed. But PierreŠ—Ès new family treats him like a precious possession that was lost and then suddenly retrieved. Instead of being a cut-and-dried exploration of his difficult adjustment to a new environment, Š—“DonŠ—Èt Call Me Son,Š— which scrutinizes the world through PierreŠ—Ès eyes, is a scathing critique of upper-middle-class complacency and materialism and a worthy successor to Ms. MuylaertŠ—Ès 2015 film, Š—“The Second Mother,Š— which also explored class frictions.

Š—“DonŠ—Èt Call Me SonŠ— is notable for its utter lack of sentimentality. There are no anguished farewells when Arcay is dragged off to prison. And Pierre becomes the helpless pawn and showpiece for a couple who have been searching for him for 17 years. Gl’_riaŠ—Ès maternal fussing is seen as selfishly possessive, and MatheusŠ—Ès hostility as bigoted and potentially violent. MatheusŠ—Ès revulsion deepens during a scene in a bowling alley in which Pierre, in a red dress, halfheartedly sends the ball into the gutter several times. The only sympathetic member of his new family is the coupleŠ—Ès young son, Joca (Daniel Botelho).

All this is to say that Pierre is a haughty, willful powder keg of conflicting drives in a film whose subject is teenage identity in an age of bewildering choices. For a topic this fraught, Š—“DonŠ—Èt Call Me SonŠ— is surprisingly breezy and matter-of-fact. After her arrest, Arcay disappears from the movie, and Pierre finds himself living unhappily in luxurious but stifling new circumstances.

That hero, Desmond Doss, is inscribed in the history books as something of a paradox: a conscientious objector who was awarded the Medal of Honor for bravery in combat. A Seventh-day Adventist who refused to carry a gun, Doss served as an Army medic in the Battle of Okinawa. What he did there is easily Googled (and is the subject of Terry L. BenedictŠ—Ès documentary Š—“The Conscientious ObjectorŠ—), but I wonŠ—Èt go too far in spoiling a tale that Mr. Gibson retells with vigor and suspense.

Sarge does not much care for Desmond. Neither does his commander, Captain Glover (Sam Worthington). DesmondŠ—Ès refusal to bear arms strikes these officers as a potential threat to morale, and they try to get rid of him Š—” encouraging the other soldiers to harass and beat him, trying to arrange a psychiatric discharge and finally convening a court-martial. This parade of indignities leads to scenes of quiet defiance; a few rousing, tear-streaked speeches; and a bit of mildly interesting philosophical reflection. Mr. Gibson is too impatient to linger over the nuances of patriotic duty and religious devotion. He and the screenwriters, Robert Schenkkan and Andrew Knight, are content to remind us that both are very important. Then itŠ—Ès time to get back to Okinawa and deal with the Japanese Army.

Ever since Š—“Saving Private Ryan,Š— Hollywood has been eager to revisit World War II, partly to explore gray areas and narrative corners neglected in earlier eras and partly to have a high-minded reason to try out advances in bloody special effects. Realism is less a principle than an excuse to concoct vivid fantasies of battle for the benefit of noncombatants, to rub our faces in details that our fathers and grandfathers were famously reluctant to discuss.

Š—“Hacksaw RidgeŠ— opens with a taste of hell, a battleground that belongs more in a horror movie than in a combat picture. Rupert Gregson-WilliamsŠ—Ès jarring, minor-key score plays under a slow-motion tableau of spurting blood, splintering bones, burning flesh and general agony.

And also in graphic and gruesome detail. Mr. GibsonŠ—Ès appetite for gore is without equal in modern Hollywood. Maybe thatŠ—Ès saying a lot, or maybe it goes without saying, but the man is an aficionado Š—” a connoisseur, an epicure, a gourmand Š—” of exploding heads, shattered limbs and burst abdomens. As he did most famously in Š—“The Passion of the Christ,Š— he once again plunges a man of peace into a charnel house of cruelty, testing the fortitude of protagonist and audience alike.

Then the music changes, the light shifts, and we are in paradise: a hilly, pastoral corner of Virginia years before Pearl Harbor. Young Desmond (Darcy Bryce) and his brother, Hal (Roman Guerriero), chase each other over rocks and streams. Not that they dwell in a perfect Eden. There is a whiff of Cain and Abel in their relationship, and more serious trouble from their father, Tom (Hugo Weaving), a bitter, alcoholic World War I veteran. Though he hates war, the elder Doss is hardly a pacifist, and his violent behavior toward his sons and their mother (Rachel Griffiths) helps push Desmond toward peace-loving piety.

And Š—“Hacksaw RidgeŠ— uses the moral dilemma of its hero Š—” who is sometimes tempted to forsake his vows and pick up a rifle in the heat of battle Š—” as a pretext for its own ethical sleight of hand. The film pretends to be a grim reckoning with the horrors of war, but it is also, true to its genre, a rousing celebration of the thrills of battle. Desmond Doss was calm, humble and courageous, qualities Mr. Gibson honors but does not share. It is possible to be moved and inspired by DesmondŠ—Ès exploits while still feeling that his convictions have been exploited, perhaps even betrayed.

Mel Gibson can be accused of many things, but subtlety is not one of them. Even at his worst Š—” I mean as a filmmaker, not a political thinker Š—” he consistently proves to be an able craftsman and a shrewd showman. Š—“Hacksaw Ridge,Š— the first feature he has directed since Š—“Apocalypto,Š— a decade ago, is a bluntly effective faith-and-flag war drama, the true story of a remarkable hero with a knot of moral tension at its center.

Played as a young man by Andrew Garfield, Desmond is a happy anti-warrior, with a goofy grin and wide, trusting eyes. He courts a nurse named Dorothy (Teresa Palmer), and their romance is so sweet and squeaky clean Š—” he kisses her; she slaps his face; he proposes Š—” that you might think the old production code was still in effect. And until the fighting resumes about halfway through, Š—“Hacksaw RidgeŠ— often feels like a throwback to an earlier era, a work of careful and calculated nostalgia.

When Desmond arrives at basic training, he is introduced to a platoon whose composition Š—” one guy from Brooklyn, another from Texas, a Pole, an Italian, a pretty boy and a hothead Š—” would have looked corny back in the Š—È40s. And letŠ—Ès not forget Sarge, a fountain of colorful insults played by Vince Vaughn, who stands out among the mostly Australian and British cast members for his effortlessly flat vowels and the equal effortlessness of his scene-stealing.
Š—“Hacksaw RidgeŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Blood, guts and period-appropriate racial slurs and tobacco use.  Running time: 2 hours 11 minutes.

In form and content, then, this is a movie that expands your sense of what is possible. A girl can hunt with an eagle. A camera can fly. Sometimes it all seems a little too smooth and easy: AisholpanŠ—Ès preparation for the festival seems to proceed without a hitch, and restless viewers may crave a little more suspense. Viewers jaded by daily doses of digital dazzlement might not fully register the reality of the wonders they are witnessing. But that doesnŠ—Èt, in the end, make Š—“The Eagle HuntressŠ— any less wonderful.

Aisholpan is a 13-year-old girl who lives in Mongolia, dividing her time between a boarding school and her nomadic familyŠ—Ès campsite. With the release of Š—“The Eagle Huntress,Š— a thrilling new documentary directed by Otto Bell, she may well become something else: a pop-culture heroine with the power to inspire girls (and not only girls) everywhere. Š—“The Eagle HuntressŠ— is rated G. In English and Kazakh, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 27 minutes.

That event, which gathers 70 eagle hunters on horseback in a Mongolian provincial capital, Olgii, near the Kazakh border, provides the film with a sports-movie structure. We follow Aisholpan through the stages of preparation, as she plucks an eaglet from a mountainside nest and teaches it to follow her directions. Nurgaiv is a wise and patient coach, adept at managing expectations and meting out praise when itŠ—Ès most needed. His daughter, meanwhile, wrangles her captive raptor with ease and confidence, and commands the screen with natural charisma. She is open and cheerful and also, as her father proudly notes, Š—“a very tough child.Š—

It could hardly be otherwise, given the challenges of her vocation and the harshness of her surroundings. Š—“The Eagle HuntressŠ— may be driven by its main character and her story, but itŠ—Ès also a nature documentary, reveling in spectacular images of the Central Asian steppes and the snow peaks that surround them. In keeping with the avian theme, the movie abounds in swooping, sometimes vertiginous aerial shots, most of them captured by drone-mounted cameras. The military and commercial uses of drone technology may be controversial, but itŠ—Ès hard to deny the cinematic benefits that these hovering, buzzing robots bestow, especially in the hands of a skilled cinematographer like Simon Niblett.

A hit at the Sundance and Telluride film festivals, Š—“The Eagle HuntressŠ— has been shaped with wide accessibility in mind. The subtitled dialogue is supplemented by gently didactic voice-over narration, read by the British actress Daisy Ridley (also credited as an executive producer). A rousing Sia song plays over the end credits. A few moments that might trouble the sensitivities of young viewers Š—” the sacrifice of a sheep at the beginning and the death of a fox at the end Š—” are edited to minimize bloodshed. And the story is a simple and appealing fable of indomitability and father-daughter companionship.

AisholpanŠ—Ès father, Nurgaiv, comes from a long line of eagle hunters, men who catch young birds and train them to hunt other animals for meat and fur. The tradition of eagle hunting is almost exclusively male, and the filmmakers assemble a counsel of elders to explain why girls should not participate. Nurgaiv ignores their arguments, and when his daughter shows up at the annual eagle festival as the youngest and only female contestant, nobody tries to stop her.

To say that this was a casual boyfriend is a bit of an understatement. As Mary notifies his acquaintances, figures out what to do with his dog and tries to dispose of his ashes, she learns both that Primo was a complex, multifaceted fellow and that he wasnŠ—Èt always the most faithful lover. Helping her on this journey of post-mortem discovery are her friend Zoe (Katherine Moennig); PrimoŠ—Ès dog walker, Howard (Scott Michael Foster); and a mysterious older man named Joey (Griffin Dunne) who says he knew Mary when she was much younger and now wants only to converse with her over restaurant dinners.

Heather Graham is that star, playing Mary, a slacker of a woman who is drifting through life in New York in 1999 when she comes home one day to find her boyfriend, Primo (John Corbett), dead in front of the television, apparently of a heart attack.

Š—“My Dead BoyfriendŠ— desperately tries to look and sound like a quirky indie hit, but thatŠ—Ès not an achievable goal when you have an unlikable lead character indifferently rendered by a name star.

The film, based on the novel Š—“DogrunŠ— by Arthur Nersesian, canŠ—Èt decide whether itŠ—Ès an offbeat romance, a self-discovery piece, an exploration of the 1990s punk scene (Mary once played bass in a band and eventually finds herself doing so again) or what. Š—“My Dead BoyfriendŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for strong language and sexual themes.
Š—“Doctor StrangeŠ— is rated PG-13 (parents strongly cautioned) for supernatural violence. Running time: 1 hour 55 minutes.

You donŠ—Èt need to know Dr. Strange to know his story. A tale of hubris Š—” with foolish pride and an inevitable fall Š—” it opens in contemporary New York, where Dr. Strange (Benedict Cumberbatch), is flying high as a supersurgeon. After a crippling accident, he abandons his old life (partly embodied by Rachel McAdams, dewy and funny) for a grand exploit, traveling simultaneously into his soul and to the misterioso Far East. He meets leaders and fellow travelers, studies books and unlocks secrets, in time becoming a superhero with magical powers, a dubious goatee and a flirty cape that dries his tears.

Most Marvel movies open like Robert Downey Jr.Š—Ès stand-up routine in Š—“Iron ManŠ— before it goes south. They deliver quips and silky come-hither nonsense, only to end up like a big green monster stuck on rewind: Š—“Hulk smash!Š— again and again, ad infinitum. In between start and finish, there are moments of levity and discovery in the machined product, but too often you canŠ—Èt see the movie for MarvelŠ—Ès action plan. Its latest, the giddily enjoyable Š—“Doctor Strange,Š— is part of MarvelŠ—Ès strategy for world domination, yet itŠ—Ès also so visually transfixing, so beautiful and nimble that you may even briefly forget the brand.

The space-and-time warping and mirrored realities in Š—“Doctor StrangeŠ— are a blast. TheyŠ—Ère inventive enough that they awaken wonder, provoking that delicious question: How did they do that? At the same time, Mr. Derrickson resists the temptation to loiter. Drawn-out set pieces have become endemic in effects-driven vehicles and can stop a movie dead as filmmakers show off their cool toys (and budget) and ignore everything else, the story and restive audience included. In the modern-era superhero movie, this kind of grandstanding has nearly assumed the level of a genre prerequisite, especially in finales that never seem to end, but end and end and end (then die).

These impossible visions at times evoke the work of M. C. Escher, who used perspective to destabilize otherwise realistic images. Elsewhere, the movieŠ—Ès pinging-ponging characters seem caught in one of Rube GoldbergŠ—Ès mischievous machines, like the witty chase in which Dr. Strange runs atop a platform while an enemy runs below him upside down, transformed into a gravity-defying doppelg’_nger. And, as with the dreamscapes in Š—“Inception,Š— the special effects in Š—“Doctor StrangeŠ— serve beauty and meaning rather than the grimly tedious destruction that drains energy out of most contemporary superhero movies. Here, you remember the wit, not the rubble.

Mr. Derrickson does a lot right, including with his lineup of strong actors (the cast also includes Benedict Wong and Mads Mikkelsen) who hold your attention even as the ground shifts below their feet. They help elevate the more generic beats in Š—“Doctor StrangeŠ— because, for all the phantasmagoria and time-skipping, there is also much by the book, including the vaguely Christ-like, fallen and risen savior. The movieŠ—Ès more lysergic sections are followed with carefully aligned narrative bricks and mortar and sometimes sealed with a quip, as if to reassure you that thereŠ—Ès nothing too far out about any of this. ThatŠ—Ès hardly unexpected, and it also scarcely matters because when a good fantasy fiction like this opens that door of perception called imagination itŠ—Ès a total trip.

Dr. StrangeŠ—Ès voyage of self-discovery is as old as the ancients and as familiar as Christopher NolanŠ—Ès 2005 Š—“Batman Begins,Š— where men become near-gods while training amid hazy, low-key lighting. And just as Mr. Nolan borrows from the original Dr. Strange, this Š—“Doctor StrangeŠ— borrows from Mr. Nolan. It owes a conspicuous debt to his delirious 2010 fantasy, Š—“Inception,Š— and that movieŠ—Ès vision of a city folding in on itself. In Š—“Doctor Strange,Š— the director Scott Derrickson and his crew push the mediumŠ—Ès plasticity further, creating spaces that bend, splinter and multiply. A wall folds open like a spreading hand fan while cityscapes fragment into whirring, shifting fractal forms.

Mr. CumberbatchŠ—Ès affable screen presence works up a strong, steady counterbeat to his characterŠ—Ès narcissism. As is the case when he plays characters like Sherlock Holmes, Mr. Cumberbatch comes across in this movie as at once supremely capable (itŠ—Ès easy to accept him as a neurosurgeon) and more than a little goofy, with the kind of lopsided beauty and spring-loaded physicality that seem ready-made for silly faces and walks. Dr. StrangeŠ—Ès arrogance ruins his career, but Mr. Derrickson makes sure that it doesnŠ—Èt weigh down the story. The characterŠ—Ès conceit is a mask thatŠ—Ès always in danger of slipping, which complicates his heroism with moments of bluffing, comedy and doubt.

Š—“Doctor StrangeŠ— tethers its plunging purples, acid greens and altered states to a heroŠ—Ès journey with its call to adventure, its mentor, its allies and its enemies. After his crisis, Dr. Strange lands in Nepal, where he meets a guide (Chiwetel Ejiofor, as brooding and sincere as Hamlet). There, he studies the way of the hero with the Ancient One (Tilda Swinton), a Celtic sorcerer, who in the comics emerged from the Himalayas and the WestŠ—Ès long fascination with, and appropriation of, Eastern mysticism. (The screenwriter C. Robert Cargill has said that some of the changes involving the sorcerer, originally from Tibet, stemmed from concerns that depictions of Tibetans might anger China, a movie market powerhouse.)

Dr. Strange first popped out of the glorious head of Steve Ditko, the comic-book visionary who brought him to life with Stan Lee (a pairing best known for Spider-Man). Dr. StrangeŠ—Ès travels east evoke the inner and outer magical mystery tours of the 1960s, summoning visions of head-tripping and Š—“Lucy in the Sky With Diamonds.Š— In a, well, yes, strange bit of timing, Dr. Strange appeared in 1963, around the time Harvard fired Timothy Leary and a colleague for conducting experiments with hallucinogens. Five years later, in Tom WolfeŠ—Ès Š—“The Electric Kool-Aid Acid Test,Š— the Merry Prankster Ken Kesey was downing acid and absorbed in Š—“the plunging purple Steve Ditko shadows of Dr. Strange.Š—

Every now and again, the movie settles down to present a thoughtful bit of characterization, as in a fraught encounter between Diesel and a young woman heŠ—Ès brought to his hotel room in the mistaken belief that she intends to sleep with him. Despite the stiltedness of some of the dialogue, the scene has genuine emotional power. The young woman, played by Louisa Krause, discourses on the singer-songwriter Elliott Smith, sounding like a character out of a novel by Bret Easton Ellis, who wrote Mr. SchraderŠ—Ès previous picture, Š—“The Canyons.Š—

The filmŠ—Ès screenwriter, Matthew Wilder, and director, Paul Schrader, have loosely adapted Edward BunkerŠ—Ès grim, earnest 1997 crime novel (which is flecked with genuine social commentary about mass incarceration, corporate malfeasance and other issues) into a purposefully coarse, giddy-approaching-giggly, pulp-Pop Art cartoon.

Despite its slim running time Š—” barely over an hour and a half Š—” Š—“Dog Eat DogŠ— somehow feels like six different movies. The first one, which depicts an especially appalling double murder through the speedy, sickly colorful perspective of an extended drug binge, is probably the least effective of the batch. But it lets you know that the filmmakers are not coming at you from a benevolent place, and that impression never lets up.
Š—“Dog Eat DogŠ— is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for violence, language and maybe nihilism. Running time: 1 hour 33 minutes.

Š—“Dog Eat DogŠ— shows three criminal pals careening through a garishly bleak Cleveland, filmed by the exceptionally sure-footed Alexander Dynan, here shooting his first feature. (BunkerŠ—Ès novel was set in California.) Troy, played by Nicolas Cage, is the ostensible brain and calm center of the mini-outfit. Willem Dafoe skitters through the role of Mad Dog, the paranoid, drug-fueled loose cannon. Christopher Matthew Cook plays Diesel, the physically intimidating muscle of the gang whoŠ—Ès more tightly wound than heŠ—Ès willing to admit. Aware of the fact that all of them carry jackets heavy enough to earn life in prison if theyŠ—Ère pinched again, they embark on a couple of high-risk capers set up by a crooked lawyer (played with infectious relish by the director himself).

But too often the movie is content to come off like a cranky old uncle whoŠ—Ès seen a lot more crime movies than you have. And this particular old uncle is also actively nasty, taking random potshots at Taylor Swift, mocking prostitutes who have a poor grasp of geography, and so on. Š—“Dog Eat DogŠ— is a movie that wants everyone off its lawn, but only after theyŠ—Ève had time to appreciate that said lawn is way more nihilistic than their own.

In other sections, the movieŠ—Ès knowingness rewards us with idiosyncratic dividends; as the main characters discuss a job that will pay off as no job has ever paid off before (and which they are, of course, fated to muff in a spectacular fashion), their dialogue circles around the Š—“one last scoreŠ— clich’© with a droll self-consciousness.

Š—“Dog Eat DogŠ— is mined with cheeky references to films like Stanley KubrickŠ—Ès Š—“A Clockwork Orange,Š— Don SiegelŠ—Ès Š—“The KillersŠ— and Mr. SchraderŠ—Ès own Š—“Blue Collar.Š— The characters are plainly racist, and the movie seems to revel in the Š—“political incorrectnessŠ— of allowing them to act it. They utter a particular epithet with breezy frequency. Their raid of a black drug dealerŠ—Ès store house is so soaked through with their hostility that the secondary point of the scene Š—” that these criminals arenŠ—Èt particularly good at what they do Š—” barely registers. The genuine exploration of racial tension that distinguished some of Mr. SchraderŠ—Ès prior work as both a director and screenwriter, including Š—“Blue Collar,Š— is replaced here by glib nose thumbing. The depictions of violence have a similar flip antagonism.

Š—“We heard one word repeated by everyone we spoke to Š—” China,Š— a voice-over says. Other countries and groups are also chastised for their roles in ivory smuggling, including the Vatican. The director, Sergey Yastrzhembsky, and his team are determined to name names and even assist in a sting operation in which a suspected illegal ivory seller is later arrested.

Still, this story remains crucial no matter how itŠ—Ès told. The bloodiest scenes are difficult to watch Š—” seeing one elephant shot and moaning as itŠ—Ès hacked with machetes by poachers is extraordinarily brutal. Mr. Yastrzhembsky hasnŠ—Èt chosen a pleasant topic, and to his credit, he treats it with the harshness it deserves.

The animals seem more humane than people in Š—“Ivory. A Crime Story.Š— This roughly constructed yet passionate documentary isnŠ—Èt shy about showing the massacre of elephants or about calling out the groups implicit in the killings. That bluntness and courage usually overrides the uneven filmmaking.

African elephants are being killed at a frightening rate Š—” one every 15 minutes, weŠ—Ère told Š—” and their population has declined by the hundreds of thousands in recent decades. While some are butchered for food in poor areas of the continent, a major reason for this slaughter is ivory, and thereŠ—Ès a main destination for it.

Mr. YastrzhembskyŠ—Ès fervor, however, also leads him to overfill the screen with footage from dozens of locations, from the African bush to Chinese shops, cargo ships and conservation conventions. ItŠ—Ès a lot to take in, with tenuous connections between scenes. The portentous narration, too, could use a good editor and some variety in its consistently ominous tone.

The movie lightly traces the arc of the LovingsŠ—È story, including their decade-long legal fight to live in their home state as husband and wife, even as Mr. Nichols plays with time, omits certain facts and glosses over others. HeŠ—Ès more interested in showing Mildred and Richard laughing with their friends than in hanging around courtrooms, watching their defense. Here, in scene after scene, the story of the Lovings is nothing if not wrenchingly personal. (The lawyers Š—” played by a broadly funny Nick Kroll and a rather more subdued Jon Bass, with a sardonic twist Š—” humorously sweep in like the cavalry, courtesy of Robert F. Kennedy and the American Civil Liberties Union.)

The Lovings have been the subject of both books and movies, including Š—“The Loving Story,Š— the 2011 documentary directed by Nancy Buirski that is partly the basis for Mr. NicholsŠ—Ès movie. Ms. BuirskiŠ—Ès documentary primarily consists of archival film footage, including of both Lovings at home with their three young children, and with the lawyers who helped the couple in their legal fight. The footage is charming, in the way that some images from the past tend to be, with their old-fashioned clothes and recognizable yet faraway worlds. Part of the allure, though, is just the Lovings themselves and how they look at each other and how they look at the camera Š—” her shy openness, his wary reserve.

The America that the Lovings lived in was as distant as another galaxy, even as it was familiar. The movie opens in the late 1950s, when Mildred (Ruth Negga, a revelation) and Richard (Joel Edgerton, very fine) are young, in love and unmarried. They already have the natural intimacy of long-term couples, the kind thatŠ—Ès expressed less in words and more in how two bodies fit, as if joined by an invisible thread. ItŠ—Ès a closeness that seems to hold their bodies still during a hushed nighttime talk on a porch and that pulls them together at a drag race, under the gaze of silent white men.

Movies get a lot of mileage from the fantasy that we are the heroes of our own stories. LifeŠ—Ès regular hum Š—” the effort and joy of making homes, having children and nourishing love Š—” tends to be drowned out by speeches and dramas in which characters rob banks to get out of debt instead of struggling or despairing. ItŠ—Ès why the insistent, quotidian quiet of Š—“LovingŠ— can feel so startling. It plucks two figures from history and imagines them as they once were, when they were people instead of monuments to American exceptionalism. It was, the movie insists, the absolute ordinariness of their love that defined them, and that made the fight for it into an indelible story of this country.

Mr. NicholsŠ—Ès most distinct aesthetic choice is the movieŠ—Ès quietness and the hush that envelops its first scene and that eventually defines the Lovings as much as their accents, gestures, manners and battles. He wraps them in a deep-country quiet, the kind that can unnerve city people and sound Š—” feel Š—” utterly foreign, especially to ears habituated to the noise of American movies with their therapeutic chatter. ThereŠ—Ès beauty in this silence, as when Mildred closes her eyes as the wind stirs the trees. ThereŠ—Ès also diffidence and thudding fear, because while RichardŠ—Ès taciturn affect may be a matter of temperament, his darting, haunted eyes also suggest those of a whipped dog.
Š—“LovingŠ— is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for racist language. Running time: 2 hours 3 minutes.

With exacting economy, Mr. Nichols borrows from the documentary Š—” its people with lined faces, its rooms with weathered walls Š—” drawing on signifying minutiae, textures and cadences to fill in his portrait. He captures the era persuasively, embroidering the realism with details like MildredŠ—Ès knee-skimming skirts and RichardŠ—Ès brush-cut hair. One sequence restages a 1965 visit to the Lovings from a photographer, Grey Villet (Michael Shannon, a bolt of lightning), who was on assignment from Life magazine and whose exquisite, artfully casual photographs remain the most recognizable images of the Lovings, partly because they suggest the unforced intimacy of family snapshots.

Those hard, reverberant stares are about the only hint that the world in Š—“LovingŠ— is going to be falling off its axis. Mr. Nichols (Š—“Take Shelter,Š— Š—“MudŠ—) has a way of easing into movies, of letting stories and characters surface obliquely. If their story didnŠ—Èt open when and where it does, there would be nothing remarkable about Mildred and Richard. But this is a Virginia still in the grip of Jim Crow, so when they decide to marry, they exchange vows in Washington. Not long after, the local sheriff (Marton Csokas) and his deputies Š—” prowling like thieves Š—” enter the coupleŠ—Ès home in the middle of the night and arrest them for breaking the stateŠ—Ès law against interracial marriage.

There are few movies that speak to the American moment as movingly Š—” and with as much idealism Š—” as Jeff NicholsŠ—Ès Š—“Loving,Š— which revisits the era when blacks and whites were so profoundly segregated in this country that they couldnŠ—Èt always wed. ItŠ—Ès a fictionalization of the story of Mildred and Richard Loving, a married couple who were arrested in 1958 because he was white, she was not, and they lived in Virginia, a state that banned interracial unions. Virginia passed its first anti-miscegenation law in 1691, partly to prevent what it called Š—“spurious issue,Š— or what most people just call children.

ItŠ—Ès perhaps unsurprising that Š—“LovingŠ— elides how the real Mildred Loving saw herself, which apparently changed over the years. At times, she identified as part white, part black and part Indian; at other times, Ms. Loving said she was Indian and white, with no African-American ancestry. On the LovingsŠ—È D.C. marriage license, she is identified solely as Š—“Indian.Š— (The scholar Arica L. Coleman details these complexities in her book Š—“That the Blood Stay Pure,Š— which, among other things, looks at VirginiaŠ—Ès contribution to white supremacy.) In Š—“Loving,Š— race is a fiction, but it is a lie that continues to justify terror long past slaveryŠ—Ès end, reducing people to boxes, one checked black, the other white.

The irascible 68-year-old Vermont farmer and focus of Tony StoneŠ—Ès wondrous documentary portrait, Š—“Peter and the Farm,Š— is a man who contains multitudes. With his snowy beard and imperious bearing, Peter Dunning, at his most eloquent, conveys the authority of a biblical prophet but without a religious platform. There is also more than a touch of King Lear in his ravings. His devotion to the farm, he says with a mixture of bitterness and pride, has cost him Š—“four children, two wives and an inheritance.Š— None of those figures are heard or seen here, except briefly in photographs. At a low moment during the filming, which took place over a year, he suggests that Mr. Stone document his suicide.
Š—“Peter and the FarmŠ— is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 32 minutes.

He has a traditional farmerŠ—Ès vision of human and animal interaction. Those sensitive to animal rights are likely to cringe during a scene in which he shoots an ewe in the head in preparation for butchering, but misses and has to do it again. The film goes on to show the entire process of skinning and eviscerating the animal. It doesnŠ—Èt shy away from documenting the repositioning of a calf stuck inside a cow giving birth. Mr. Dunning even displays sympathy for coyotes that have decimated his sheep herd.

It is the filmŠ—Ès cosmic dimension that makes it so special. To borrow the title of a Tom Wolfe novel, Mr. Dunning is Š—“a man in full,Š— by turns majestic and cantankerous, and unafraid to look into the void and to ask the deepest, most personal questions about the purpose of life. As the camera surveys the glorious landscape of rural Vermont with the same dispassion that it focuses on a cow defecating, the film evokes the natural world with a grand poetic awareness of the primal connectedness of things. From the rapturous to the gross, you canŠ—Èt have one without the other.
His declaration late in the film that Š—“life announces itself in force Š—” death slinks offŠ— suggests that he is still winning the daily battle.

The film also explores Mr. DunningŠ—Ès younger years. He had a mysterious childhood: Born on the Lower East Side, he was adopted by a family who he believes never gave him the full story of his parentage. He recalls his days as a free-spirited Marine stationed in Hawaii. In college, he majored in painting and minored in sculpture, and he still draws and writes poetry. He was attracted to farming in the early 1970s during the countercultureŠ—Ès back-to-the-land movement. He was 33 when he bought the farm in 1978. He describes a sawmill accident in which he nearly severed one hand and endured Š—“nine or 10Š— operations to restore its functionality.

The film is essentially a protracted soliloquy by Mr. Dunning, with minor interruptions by barely glimpsed part-time farmhands and the film crew hovering on the sidelines. A self-described alcoholic, he is subject to bouts of severe depression and suicidal despair, and at one point he describes waking up in the middle of the night and guzzling alcohol to forestall the DTs. But his binges are interspersed with periods of abstinence.

The farm has been in slow decline since the late 1990s, when members of his immediate family left the property on which he raises organic livestock, fruit and vegetables. Mr. DunningŠ—Ès love of the land and his sheep, cows and pigs are palpable in scenes of him toiling in the fields and barns and herding his animals. And his poignant declaration Š—“I care more about the farm than meŠ— rings true.

The speaker in Š—“Trash FireŠ— is a young man named Owen, played by Adrian Grenier with maximum puppy-dog-eyed smirkiness. GLENN KENNY

Hence, the writer-director is also invested in depicting everyone surrounding the protagonist as in some way worse. Š—“For as long as I can remember, IŠ—Ève been waiting for my parents to die, so I could commit suicide without feeling an overwhelming sense of guilt.Š— With this opening line, Š—“Trash FireŠ— lets you know that its writer-director is committed to commanding your attention. That mixture of sadness and persistence pervades Š—“The Ivory Game,Š— which follows some of the men and women struggling to end ivory trafficking. There are plenty of heroes here, yet only a little optimism.

Š—“The destiny of elephants is entirely in the hands of one single person Š—” the president of China,Š— Andrea Crosta, an investigator, says. ItŠ—Ès a statement that Xi Jinping, ChinaŠ—Ès president, needs to hear directly. Someone give him this documentary.

Š—“I donŠ—Èt know if itŠ—Ès ever going to make a difference, and if weŠ—Ère ever going to do enough, but weŠ—Ève got to try.Š—

Š—“Traders in ivory actually want the extinction of elephants,Š— Mr. Millar says. The fewer elephants there are, Š—“the more the price rises. The more the price rises, the more people want to kill them.Š— This circle is illustrated with footage of slain animals in Africa and of ivory carvings in China, where regulated trade is permitted but illegal sales are rampant.
ItŠ—Ès all harmless enough, and as movies about pickles go, itŠ—Ès probably a Top 10 contender. Just donŠ—Èt expect to be laughing out loud much.

In this way, Ms. StoryŠ—Ès unconventional approach provokes responses that a traditional facts-and-figures discussion might not. Yet the filmŠ—Ès formal abstraction, far from creating emotional distance, is unexpectedly moving. In Š—“The Prison in Twelve Landscapes,Š— a meditation on mass incarceration in the United States, the Canadian filmmaker Brett Story arranges a series of oblique, geographical vignettes into an unsettling mural of systemic damage.

Neither lecture nor argument, Š—“Prison,Š— artfully photographed by Maya Bankovic, attempts to make the invisible visible. So when we watch a roaring mountainside fire and listen to an unseen inmate enthuse about her firefighting job, we can immediately sense the awfulness of a life where being surrounded by flames feels like a kind of freedom.

You will barely see an actual prison, or hear about an actual crime. But this drifting, at times dreamy documentary follows the tentacles of the confinement industry to stories that hide in plain sight. Like the small playground in Los Angeles constructed purely to prevent paroled sex offenders from moving into a nearby halfway house. Or the enterprising man in the Bronx who runs a thriving business in prison-approved care-package items.

Some of the segments possess a strange poetry. In Eastern Kentucky, where new penitentiaries squat atop the pancaked mountains left behind by coal mining, prison jobs are highly valued. What we see, however, is no less than the draining of hope from one group of citizens to benefit another.

The movie begins with an elliptical prelude that guides you in but is forgotten as soon as the aliens touch down minutes later. The director Denis Villeneuve teases his way through these preliminaries, with shots of newscasts and panicked crowds, revealing just enough to work up some excitement. In a sly preview to things and tall creatures to come, Louise keeps looking up Š—” at a blaring television, at shrieking military jets Š—” turning Ms. AdamsŠ—Ès pale face into a screen for the movie thatŠ—Ès just starting to come into view. In a nice reversal of how many puzzlers work, the movie becomes more fragmented the closer that Louise gets to figuring out why the aliens have arrived, what they want from Earth and why. Increasingly, her steadiness becomes the very foundation for the narrative, which serves its meaning beautifully. The movie complicates Mr. ChiangŠ—Ès story, adding action scenes and political notes, which comes off as pretty puny compared with its larger, grander adventure about a woman who, in staring into the void, leaps into life and finds herself.

Having been spirited away, Louise is moved into a makeshift military base in Montana, one of 12 locations across the globe where the aliens have dropped anchor. There, next to one of their enormous ships Š—” a vessel that hovers over the ground and looks like an elongated black egg with one side neatly sliced off Š—” sheŠ—Ès briefed and prepped amid furrowed brows, data crunching and intimations of the apocalypse. Once she settles in, the movie gets its groove on. The visitors have set up regular visiting hours for the humans, opening a portal through which a small team in hazmat suits can enter. As their machines whir, Louise and the rest gape across the cosmic divide and into the unknown.

The scenes inside the alien ship are transporting. After Louise and her team move through the shipŠ—Ès portal, they end up in a large chamber facing a luminous rectangle, a kind of window Š—” it looks like a movie screen Š—” through which they can see the aliens. But the room is also a type of a stage, an immersive theater that engages sight, sound and a sense of touch. LouiseŠ—Ès hands and voice quaver, but her eyes shine and widen as the pleasure of the new Š—” and knowing Š—” edges out fear. And when her physicist colleague, Ian (Jeremy Renner), runs a gloved hand over one of the shipŠ—Ès textured black walls, his expression suggests the delight of a child at the moment of discovery.

Š—“ArrivalŠ— is a science-fiction parable in a distinctly more idealistic hopeful key than most movies in this genre, one in which the best solutions donŠ—Èt necessarily materialize in a gun sight. SheŠ—Ès thoughtful, serious, at ease with her own silence and fears. SheŠ—Èd get along fine with Sandra BullockŠ—Ès character in Š—“Gravity,Š— which like this movie leans into feeling and thinking, and reminds you again that thereŠ—Ès more to this genre than heavy artillery.

In whatŠ—Ès perhaps the first science-fiction film Š—” Georges M’©li’åsŠ—Ès 1902 marvel Š—“A Trip to the MoonŠ— Š—” a group of astronomers lands in the Man in the MoonŠ—Ès eye. TheyŠ—Ère soon taken prisoner by moon men, but a quick-witted astronomer clobbers the king and they escape, with one earthling vanquishing moon men with an umbrella. Humans have been zapping extraterrestrials ever since. ItŠ—Ès so easy to fight the unknown, at least in movies.

Š—“ArrivalŠ— doesnŠ—Èt need self-regarding jolts. ItŠ—Ès based on Ted ChiangŠ—Ès Š—“Story of Your Life,Š— one of those unassumingly smart science-fiction puzzles that blend absorbing storytelling with meditations on the universe, being, time and space. Part of what makes it so enjoyable is that Mr. Chiang not only raises questions about the nature of reality and what it is to be human, but he also embeds them in his writing through different verb tenses and times. In one section, he rummages around in the past; in another, he jumps onto a separate timeline. The movie Š—” the script is by Eric Heisserer Š—” does something similar with cutaways to LouiseŠ—Ès life, shardlike glimpses that help fill in the whole.

Mr. Villeneuve likes big stories with big stakes, and heŠ—Ès very skilled at working your nerves. In some of his movies, he punctures the stories with bluntly violent shocks Š—” a stunned survivor seated before a burning truck in Š—“Incendies,Š— corpses sealed inside a drug-house wall in Š—“SicarioŠ— Š—” that distill terror into a grabber moment. These visuals can be real showstoppers (the narratives briefly shift into idle); theyŠ—Ère at once off-putting and unsettlingly seductive, and even if you want to look away, it can be hard to. Some of his limitations as a filmmaker are best expressed in the perfect crackling of those flames and the pictorial balance of that shot of walled-up torture victims.

Mr. Villeneuve nods to Š—“2001: A Space OdysseyŠ— here and there in the astronaut-like hazmat suits, the allusions to the abyss (the humans sometimes float, as if in space) and of course the looming monoliths, one of them named Stanley Kubrick. These references can seem decorative, almost ritualistic, with one director paying homage to a master. Š—“ArrivalŠ— isnŠ—Èt a visionary movie, an intellectual rebus or a head movie; itŠ—Ès pretty straight in some respects and sometimes fairly corny, with a visual design thatŠ—Ès lovely rather than landmark. And, as it revisits some of the uncertainties in Š—“2001Š— Š—” free will, extraterrestrials, God Š—” it seems to turn inward instead of out. (It does both.)

Their dismay at breaking up (theyŠ—Ève since reunited) is sometimes aggravated by their conditions. While much of IsraelŠ—Ès political establishment dismisses the group as a far-left organization, its members Š—“see this as a long-distance run,Š— says Avner Wishnitzer, a founder. Š—“And we will continue to go on with it.Š—

One member, Chen Alon, an Israeli Army veteran, denied clearance at a checkpoint to a Palestinian father desperate to deliver his sick children to a hospital. Mr. Alon, a father himself, realized Palestinians can be loving parents as well.

Shifa al-Qudsi, a Palestinian, who lost teenage cousins and a sister-in-law in the conflict, planned to blow up a supermarket. Apprehended beforehand, she was imprisoned for six years. There she met a guard who lost a brother in a suicide attack, and Ms. al-Qudsi, too, recognized her adversaryŠ—Ès humanity.

Combatants for Peace, formed in 2005, is dedicated to nonviolent demonstrations and dialogue. Outside a rally, its members endure savage insults from onlookers but are undaunted. Š—“We canŠ—Èt push you out of here and you canŠ—Èt push us out, either,Š— Jamil Qassas, a Palestinian, says onstage. Š—“We have to coexist with one another.Š—

How much bloodshed can a divided populace stand? Rather, it briefly offers wrenching images (a bombing in Tel Aviv; razed Palestinian homes) before delving into the personal histories of members of Combatants for Peace. The transformations they describe are less like lightning bolts and more like dawning epiphanies.

ItŠ—Ès the story of a young pianist, Monty (Johnny Simmons), whose life hasnŠ—Èt been going anywhere and is threatening to get worse, since his girlfriend (Frankie Shaw) has lost interest in him. The movie is being released in two forms: a 3-D, super-high-definition version with an accelerated frame rate in a couple of theaters and a more conventional version everywhere else. The Indianapolis was the cruiser that in 1945 carried parts of the atomic bomb that was to be dropped on Hiroshima to Tinian Island in the Pacific, where the weapon was to be assembled. Professor HullŠ—Ès blindness, he decided, was a gift: Š—“Not a gift that I want, but a gift nonetheless.Š—

Not only his vision faded, but his visual memory to the extent that he felt his past disappearing as well as his future. At his lowest point, he was overwhelmed by a profound loneliness and isolation, a sense of being forever cut off and trapped in darkness.

Shortly after this nadir, Professor Hull was roused from his despair by the sound of rainfall, which gave a shape and texture to his environment, and he began using the tape recorder to document his interactions with his wife and children, as well as his inner thoughts.

But he was not alone. By his side until his death in 2015, at the age of 80, was his wife, Marilyn. The couple are portrayed by Dan Skinner and Simone Kirby, who lip-sync his words with such impeccable precision and delicacy you quickly forget theyŠ—Ère actors. One of his first responses was to amass a collection of recorded books related mostly to his academic career. But behind his determination lurked fearful dreams and fantasies. In the most vivid nightmare, restaged in the film, he is in a supermarket aisle as a torrential wave rounds a corner and rushes toward him. A low point came at Christmastime 1983 when he suffered panic attacks and decided he could never accept blindness. He describes a desperate sense of being enclosed and Š—“entirely alone.Š—

The spine of the film Š—” the first feature directed by  Peter Middleton and James Spinney Š—” is an audiocassette diary that Professor Hull kept for three years and published in 1990 as Š—“Touching the Rock.Š— A decade earlier, while awaiting the birth of his first son, Professor Hull became alarmed by black discs interfering with his vision and underwent a series of unsuccessful operations to correct the condition.
